description:
Our local friend took us here for lunch because he said it had really good wings, comparable to San Tungs...
well anyways, we gave it a shot because San Tung's was actually closed when we went over the weekend since they were on vacation.

Anyhow, this place is a hole in the wall and had a lot of random decorations on the walls and ceilings lol thought that was pretty interesting and random.

Anyhow, we ordered the wings that my friend recommended, and asked the server what else is popular:

Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes - full of flavor! Really enjoyed this dish
Taiwanese Eggplant - AMAZING, definitely everyone's favorite. Super flavorful
Shrimp and Pork Spring Rolls - crispy on the inside, I liked it, it was definitely different
Chicken Wings - the wings were dry not drenched in sauce. It had a nice kick and flavor to it, I wouldn't compare it to San Tung's because it is different.

All in all, we killed all the plates and was very satisfied!
Service was nice.
author: Katelin N.

description:
It has been a while since I've been here but WTF? Great food, terrible host. Arrived on time for a 6pm reservation. The food was super tasty. The wait staff terrific. About 50 minutes into the meal, the check arrives without prompting by the host. No asking if we might want anything else. A few minutes after that our water bottle was removed from the table in a brusque manner. A few minutes after *that*, one of the waitstaff (somebody I knew to talk to from another restaurant) was sent over and apologetically said she was asked to get us to go. 

We said we got the message and left the restaurant. Checking the time: 7:04pm. We were astonished. It was almost comical. Smitten ice cream made things better.
author: patrick g.

description:
Like everyone has said, do not expect authentic Chinese here. Rather it's the hype. 
After a long 6 hours photoshoot, the photographer suggests to dine in here since it's close. Plus, he'd been hearing many talks regarding this place. "Mission Chinese"? It is an interesting name so I thought.

The place is quite small. Decoration is rather an old ancient Chinese, nothing great, a bit messy. The water cup...smells unwashed. The food, *sigh*, not great. I got the Ramen of the day, which is a spicy duck confit ramen. Tastes like any ramen noodle bowl. My crew has duck chow Mei, fried chicken with fried rice and something else. The bill comes out with $25/each, not incl tips. Uhm, in Mission, tastes so under average and charges this much...I wouldn't even recommend. Ofc, not coming back. It's good to try a new place so you love your regulars even more ;)
author: Bao V.

description:
My friends got dinner for takeout and it was great, but they discovered only when they got to our place that Mission Chinese hadn't packed the pork belly they ordered! Overall it was a good dinner, rice + 4 entrees were enough food for four of us for dinner. The cost was about $82 total. 

CLASSIC DISHES
* Pork Mapo Tofu ($15) - 3.5 stars
Love the silky tofu & ground pork. Definitely a spicy dish, the flavor was pretty dominated by Szechuan Peppercorn. 

* Broccoli beef brisket ($18) - 4.5 stars
The brisket was incredible, very tender & soft. Chinese broccoli was nice & crunchy.

VEGETABLES
* Stir Fried Sweet Corn ($15) - 4 stars
Nice! I didn't realize such a simple concept could be so good.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I've actually been past this restaurant a couple times during my time in SF. I heard about it before visiting the Bay and definitely had to try it at one point. However, I could never find it! I only realized later that the sign of the location said "Lung Shan Restaurant" and that Mission Chinese was actually located inside...

The vibe there really stood out to me as more Chinese-American as opposed to a traditional Chinese restaurant with cut outs of a Mickey Mouse and Michael Jordon and also some random Christmas lights hanging around. 

We ended up ordering the lamb dumplings, the famous chongqing chicken wings, and a salt cod rice for the each of us. The lamb dumplings were delicious, but considering the size of each dumpling and the amount of them (5) for $9, it wasn't really worth the price point.  I could literally smell how spicy the chicken wings were and each of my friends was even afraid to eat it. However, trying it, it was a good amount of spice. I expected the wings to be a lot more oily considering it was a Chinese restaurant, but the chicken was cooked very evenly with the dry spice rub.

The salt cod rice was probably the best bang for your buck here. For $13, the amount was pretty wild. There was so MUCH RICE. I actually expected pieces of salt cod in the fried rice, but I feel they mixed it in when cooking the rice so the rice had a salt cod taste to it otherwise it was just eggs and Chinese sausage. Nonetheless, I left a satisfied customer. All the items I had was very good, but the price points for most of them isn't really worth it.
author: Timothy D.

description: I love this place for many reasons. It's held up over the years and maintained the quality of food. Some rare ingredients that you don't get anywhere else at least not via the same capable hands. I love that they maintained the original decor of the previous restaurant - it's novel and adds to the vibe.
author: RJ D.

description:
Came here a couple of times, the first time I was a little disappointed by the hype, the second time I came with a more open mind. You have to understand this is very much an asian fusion cuisine.

Got the beef and broccoli (which is actually just brisket and bok choy). It was so much fattier than the normal dish and I really enjoyed that. 

Got the chongching wings. They are spicy fried wings, and if you ever had la zhi ji, it has that ma la flavor as well. I really enjoyed these.

Also had some rice cakes with bacon dish. The ratio of rice cakes to the meat is a bit too carb heavy. I'd probably pass on this dish. Really loved the other two dishes though
author: Victor D.

description:
3.5 stars
I still can't get over the weirdness of this restaurant. Outside, the marquee says "Lung Shan Restaurant," but inside, the heart and soul of the restaurant is the famous Mission Chinese Food. The decor also looks nothing like a typical, drab Chinese-American restaurant--instead, there are colorful dragons dancing along the ceiling, along with a cutout of Michael Jordan, Mickey Mouse, and strings of Christmas lights. What??

And then there's the menu. Some of the items may have a Chinese food-sounding names, but the descriptions are anything but! We started with the spicy sichuan Kimchi in spicy macadamia oil and the amazing fried Westlake lamb dumplings served with tzatziki sauce and spicy chili oil! The lamb dumplings were a standout for me--the flavor of the lamb somehow went so well with the creamy tzatziki sauce, and the chili oil gave everything a spicy-numbing tinge.

Next, we had the cabbage cooked with pistachio milk, which was a nicely seasoned vegetable dish, as well as the Mongolian longbeans, a huge platter of fried beans with horseradish and Sichuan peppercorns. The matcha meyer lemon noodles were just as interesting as the name sounds--the noodles sat in a matcha-infused broth and were dressed with cucumber, radish, and herbs. But the definite favorite dish of our group was the lamb and squid ink pappardale. The thick strands of black pasta were perfectly al dente and had the most amazing texture, and they were complemented with tender pieces of lamb shoulder, along with harissa yogurt, fennel, onion, and watercress. The flavors of the dish were reminiscent of a Chinese stir-fry ("wok-hay"), but the dish also had a distinctly Mediterranean/Italian feel--fascinating!

Indeed, Mission Chinese was a cool, memorable experience. If you think you know what eating at a Chinese restaurant is like, just try this one on for size, and you'll be amazed at the creativeness and unexpectedness of it all!
author: David K.

description:
I like this place! The food is flavorful and good! It can get crowded, but is easier for Friday dinner or Saturday lunch.

I've gotten the Mapo Tofu, the chicken wings, and loved them!
author: Jenée S.

description: Bring two people and get the fried lamb ribs. It is everything I could want in a single dish. It is spicy, salty, moist, crispy, rich, and creamy. The most delicious thing I've put in my mouth in the Mission.
author: Jazmin H.

description:
This place is a Chinese fusion kind of concept and I came here for lunch where they offered their bentos with a variety of items. 

I had the beef (brisket) broccoli bento which came with cucumbers over what looked like hummus, peanuts in vinegar, and two spring roll like items but wrapped in those rice noodle sheets instead.

For the most part, the food overall was too salty, especially the beef broccoli. It tasted like the gravy the dish was cooked it had been soaked in salt and oil, and wasn't really all that pleasant to eat.

The spring rolls were an interesting concept but a little bit boringly executes. It tasted pretty one dimensional, of mostly just the soy-like sauce and a bunch of lettuce.

The cucumbers ended being my favorite part, that one actually came together quite nicely.

At $15 for a bento, the price is okay but the quality and taste isn't really something to write home about. The staff was friendly though!
author: Tyler T.

description:
I used to lo love this place. Granted it was a good 4 years ago. 

Times change. I understand this. 

The food I ordered was a vast departure from what I had years ago. It was no longer special.

I could have been eating in any random Chinese restaurant on Taraval Street. 

Mission Chinese Food was something special to me years ago.

Now? It's another face in the crowd.
author: Jennifer C P.

description:
We visited Mission Chinese Food in the Mission District of SF with two of my friends when we visited SF in May 2017.  This place is incredible!  From its gorgeous dragon-themed decor to its ambrosial shareable plates, I was incredibly impressed with our entire experience there.  We decided to order a bunch of plates to share to be able to sample a wide variety of food and ordered the following for the 4 of us: 

-Ginger Scallion and Chicken Fat Rice 
-Broccoli Beef Brisket (smoked oyster sauce, toasted seeds)
-Stir Fried Asparagus (pea leaves, salted red chili, ginger). This dish was amazing!!!!
-Taiwanese Eggplant (Basil, Fried Garlic)
-Matcha Squid Ink Noodles (ginger scallion, hoisin, cucumber, matcha)
-Classic Chow Mein with Beef (celery, mustard green, leek, bean sprouts)

Everything tasted great and I loved how authentic this fusion-style food was!  I really wish I lived in SF so I could visit as often as possible!! I certainly would love to visit again next time I'm in SF!  Incredible food and we all had a great experience.
author: Pegah Y.

description: Great place. I had the delicious thrice baked rice cakes which inspired me to try them at homes a couple times and I wasn't able to recreate the magic. Everything we had was spicy. The fusion/trendy feel of the food was kind of a mismatch to the stereotypical Chinese decor of the place, but can't complain much about that. And some weird naming/branding thing going on with the Lung Shang name floating around. Maybe the ambiguity is a draw for people who are initiated?
author: Leslie T.

description:
Mission Chinese never lets me down (except that one time it took two hours to arrive). I have eaten in the restaurant twice, which has a sick very eclectic funky atmosphere, but honestly the line and wait is not worth it when you can pick up or have it delivered. 

I was really excited to see the new burrito options on the menu. Completely brilliant idea for the Mission. We ordered the Kung Pao, salt cod fried rice, string beans. All absolutely delicious!!! The pastrami is not to be missed!!
author: Kylie F.

description:
First of all, the place is dirty. I wish I didn't use the restroom before sitting down to eat. I was disgusted after that. If the restroom is that dirty, I don't want to even think about the kitchen right next to it. 

The lamb dumplings with the tzatziki sauce were the best thing we ate. The mules tasted like lemonade. The Chongqing chicken wings were okay. My husband really wanted to try them so that's the only we stopped by.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Mission Chinese has been on our "must go" list for years, but for whatever reason, we haven't been! We finally visited a few weeks ago, and it was amazing! I noticed that there were a lot of negative reviews, and I just don't get it. Our experience was great, and so was the food! We stopped in about 630ish on a monday, bc we knew that it could get pretty busy - the restaurant was half empty, and so we scored a table right away. As we were ordering however, the entire restaurant filled up! The place was packed, and there was a line by 700pm. Come early, I guess!
We ordered a bunch of stuff, and everything came out really quickly. My favorite was the squid ink noodles, and my companion was in love with the pork belly. Pastrami kung pao was also a big hit at the table. The eel roll was AMAZING. soft and crunchy in all of the right ways! Plus the red hued ambiance is super cool, ultra casual.

Don't listen to the yelp haters - the food is great and service is attentive but still casual. I noticed a ton of low starred reviews where entitled brats were looking for fine dining service at a hole in the wall hipster chinese joint - don't listen to them -this is a great spot for friends or a date (unless your date is one of those bratty yelpers)
author: CC C.

description:
Give it a try, but it's saaaalltttttyyyyyyy as fuuuuuuuuuuuuq

Cool unique dishes but saaaaltttt assss fuuuuuk

Good service and everything else.....

But oh so salty
author: Peter D.

description:
Yummy! It was a great option for staying in. Tons of flavor and the spice was fantastic. The heat doesn't over power the flavor, but it does linger. 

Some things were a little heavy on the salt, but still managed to taste the other spices and flavors. 

I loved the eggplant!!!
author: Eden C.

description:
Tingling wings!! "Chongqing chicken wings" OMG! Say no more... order them! 
I also CRAVE the cabbage in pistachio milk with chrysanthemum. So good. Love this unassuming place.  Never judge a book by its cover-- this place lacks curb appeal, but what comes out in the plate is superb.
author: Lessa V.

description: Another place that everyone loves and I'm like meh. Every single thing is so damn spicy that it all blends together and your mouth is essentially on fire the entire time. Don't get me wrong, I love spice- but this is just unpleasant. Also, let's talk about the prices... absolutely ridiculous. It is 100% not worth what it costs. Last two times we've ordered I've been so unimpressed and so annoyed about the price I vowed to stop eating here. I think I finally convinced my husband to give up trying to make this place happen.
author: Taylor P.

description:
This small shabby restaurant is probably one of the most famous and hipster restaurants in SF. 

You will find some interesting items on their menu, definitely nothing traditional.

My favorites are mapo tofu, and thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes. Mapo tofu is seriously THE best and that's what keeps me coming back to this place. Tingling and numbing and just so so good! Note their food runs on the saltier side. Their lunch special menu is also well packed and worth every penny.

This is not cheap chinese food despite shabby exterior and interior. And dinner time wait can be craaaazyyyy for real. Never had to wait for lunch though.
author: Janey L.

description: Place was really over hyped. The food was descent but nothing I would rave about, yet the reason for two stars is due to the service. My friend and I went there to try as many of the dishes we can due to the hype. Issue is, they forgot 1/4 of our orders and have us the check right after our third dish. Like WTF!!! My friend and I ordered the Ma Po Tofu and the waitress recommended a rice dish to go with it so we ordered the chicken fat rice. When the Tofu came in we got plain rice which we thought it was for the Filipino Fried Chicken we ordered but no, because that dish never came. How can you recommend a rice dish to pair with another dish and not get said dish when it was ordered? What's funny is the waitress used a tablet to put in our order which I thought was supposed to effeciently put in our orders but no it was possibly just used to check the waitress' Instagram feed.
author: Joseph G.

description:
Feelings are moving towards 3.5 stars for Mission Chinese. This place had been on our list for sometime and finally got to try it out back in August.

I am a chinese food lover but not sure why I didn't love this place enough. We came on a weekday at lunch hour but the place was deserted which kind of scared me in the beginning since I had heard about huge lines.

Our waitress was a little rude in coming 3 times in a span of 5 minutes while I kept asking her we needed more time to decide. We had literally just sat down and was checking out the menu. No one likes to feel rushed when they try out a new restaurant!

I've tried few asian places so far and no matter how small they have been, usually the kitchen doesn't pave the way for the bathroom. For some reason, the sight of seeing staff chopping veggies while i'm walking through to get to the restroom just left me disappointed. 

Between the 3 of us we shared:

- classic chow mein with eggplant
- kung pao pastrami
- mapu tofu

Loved the chow mein it was really tasty and delicious and went so well with the eggplant! Kung pao pastrami was a great dish but I felt it was too heavy, way too salty and way too much meat eventhough we shared. Mapu tofu was something I was looking forward to and I really liked the few first bites but the tingling feeling perhaps is not for me as it just got too much at the end. Also it was swimming in oil :( Needless to say we were unable to finish these 3 dishes so we packed them to go. The portions are really huge so unless you come starving in a large group you will pack leftovers to go.

Not sure I would want to come back again.
author: Heliana M.

description: It's crowded, noisy, dark, looks kind of filthy TBH, the service is slow and the host is kind of rude... but the food is worth it. Would definitely come back.
author: Mariana S.

description: Interesting and unique restaurant. They have very unique memus that created originally and I've never seen. My favorite one is Sichuan Carbonara, that for vegetarians, but very tasty.
author: Keisuke W.

description:
This place is known for taking the classics and fusing spicier and more flavorful elements to them.  I truly don't understand the hype because nothing quite blends well together.  The pastrami fried rice and Kung Lao are two items I was looking for but turned out to just be too spicy and salty.  The American classics can't be messed with for a reason and to me they don't do anything that makes the dish taste better.  Different for sure.  I never experience a dine in service so I can't judge on that. 
 
Food 3
author: Patrick C.

description:
Always enjoyed the food and atmosphere here. If you don't mind loud upbeat music, sitting in close quarters with strangers, and raising your voice to your meal companion(s) to converse, and eating in in a somewhat dark and red lit place, the. you would enjoy this dining experience. It is fun to come in a group and enjoy the dishes as everything is shareable and it is good to try as many dishes as you would like/can. They play old school hip hop/90s music so it is a fun atmosphere and good vibes.

Must get:
- Chongqing Chicken Wings: spicy and numbing so make sure you can handle the heat. But it is super addicting. The numbing feeling is an experience. Take hold and enjoy!
- Filipino Fried Chicken: super flavorful and huge portion
- Kung Pao Pastrami: unusual but really unique flavors and good smokiness
- Westlake rice porridge: the most flavorful porridge I have had.  Most are usually bland, focusing on the condiments added to your liking, but this one had a tasty broth. 

Was better last time:
- Salt Cod Fried Rice: this came to our table literally 2-3 minutes after waitress walked away with our order. The rice should be piping hot...but it was warm. It was as though someone previously ordered it by mistake and it was sitting there. Or they just stirred the rice together with the set ingredients and plated it. Either way, it was not hot, sausage was not hot, and barely any salty cod. Disappointed.

Hoping that this place isn't going downhill as I have been frequenting here every so often for about 8 years.
author: Kayli T.

description:
The wait wasn't too long, and I'm guessing this was because of how fast they make and serve the food. We ordered around 5 dishes between the 4 of us, and we were very full and had to take some of the food home!
The mapo-tofu was really good. I was tempted to put in another order to get it to go.
author: Yoon Sung H.

description:
I feel conflicted about this place. My guess is first-timers here will either love it or hate it. What's confusing is that the menu seems really exotic, but the dishes themselves are actually a pretty standard, slightly fusion-y mosh of Asian (Szechuan, Taiwanese, southern Chinese, ...) fan fare. 

Food:
- Mapo tofu: I've had this at many places and this was pretty good. The peppercorns are quite generous here so if you like the numbness of traditional Szechuan dishes this one is for you. 4/5
- Sour chili chicken: This was so salty I feel like the Chef must have done something wrong. I wouldn't recommend this order. 0/5
- Cumin lab ribs: This is alright. It came out screaming hot on a cast iron mini server and smoked up the whole table. Pretty entertaining to watch but definitely overkill (thanks for the carcinogens?). Also didn't really taste the cumin here. 3/5
- Steamed market greens: This was actually my favorite, and had a nice light broth and cooked in peanut oil I think. Probably was the most authentic dish we ordered. 5/5
- Chinese Giardiniera: Cloud ears are wood ears: that brown, floppy mushroom that is popular in China. This tastes like something my ma would make. 5/5

Other comments:
- We were a party of 4 who came here ~6 pm and left at 8:20. So the wait time/service was fine. 
- I'm 5'9 and I sat next to someone who's 6'2. We felt very squished. 
- Apparently you have to walk through the kitchen to use the bathroom. 
- Ambiance is a tad bizarre, but not objectionable. 

Tl;dr: 
This is more Asian fusion than not. If you're looking for authentic Chinese food, Chinatown is a better option. The veggie dishes are better/more authentic than the meat dishes.
author: Julia Y.

description:
Creative twist to Chinese food and we had a great time dining here! If you are looking for fun, creative, flavorful dishes then this is the place to be.

Matcha meyer lemon noodle: What an interesting dish. Matcha flavor is barely there, or was overpowered by lemon. Either way this noodle dish is refreshing!

Pork mapo tofu: omg so spicy, but well worth the pain. Sichuan peppercorn was a bit much for my liking but enjoyed the dish.

Thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes: shared this dish with a complete stranger sitting next to us. Spicy but good, it's one of their popular dish. 

That's about all I can remember since I was drunk. Great food and fun times!
author: Manami S.

description:
There aren't a lot of tables at Mission Chinese and it was pretty packed when we got here so we decided to get the ma po tofu to go. If you order to go, head to the back counter and someone will take your order and pay. It was awkward being in the restaurant since there wasn't really anywhere to stand or sit while they were making the order and we felt like we were in everyone's way since servers were rushing back and forth from the back to the front and vice versa. Our order was made very quickly though (They must make a huge batch and ladle it out as orders come in) and we were on our way.

The ma po tofu was a very generous portion, and at $15 it better be! It was a pleasant balance of delicately fragrant Sichuan peppercorns, bold spicy doubanjiang, black bean sauce, with soft tofu and ground meat. The soft tofu had soaked up the flavor of the sauce which was nice. Unfortunately even though we paid so much for our meal it didn't even come with rice so we had to get rice from another restaurant on the way to our hotel. It did come with a spoon at least.

Good ma po tofu, but a bit pricey for my tastes especially since rice apparently costs extra.
author: Karen W.

description:
Loooved my experience at Mission Chinese. We arrived at 6pm on a Saturday, and luckily, they were able to seat our party of two immediately. Otherwise, it's best to make a reservation because they can get pretty busy. The restaurant is pretty small, but it's got a very cozy/casual ambience and fun decor, including a giant dragon hanging from the ceiling.

There are several vegetarian dishes on the menu, as well as dishes that can be made vegetarian/vegan by request. They really make an effort to provide unique and creative twists on Chinese food. We ordered the Matcha Meyer Lemon Noodles and the Taiwanese Eggplant. The matcha noodles are DELICIOUS. They come soaked in green tea and lemon and absorb so much flavor, and because of that they can a little salty. Since we ordered the eggplant too, it balanced out the flavors. The eggplant was really good and the sauce had a great sweet & sour flavor. It came in large chunks though, that were a little difficult to eat with chopsticks. 

They have decent portion sizes for a reasonable prices, which make it easy to share family style. Definitely a great place for a casual sit down meal in the mission.
author: Apoorva A.

description: After watching Mind of a Chef, I was very excited to try Danny Bowien's Mission Chinese Food. I  went in for lunch service and had the bento box special. I chose the broccoli and brisket. This was a brilliant idea of mixing smoked bbq complete with peanuts and pickles with Chinese food. Did I mention how excited I was? Unfortunately the meal fell short of what I was hoping for. The rice, tiger salad, and Beijing vinegar peanuts were brilliant, however the brisket was extremely tough and the sauce was salty. I enjoyed the  smokiness of it and the crispness of the broccoli but that was it. So in short, my food adventure to Mission Chinese was a bust :(
author: Desmond C.

description:
Mission Chinese Food is not the name outside the restaurant (actual name is Lung Shan Restaurant), but you can easily spot it by the yellow sign with red writing). This place is not big so it gets busy for dinner, especially on the weekend. But they do have delivery service if you are lucky enough to live within the range of delivery (check their website for more info). Inside of this restaurant has an exotic vibe created by dim lighting, laser, hip hop music, and a dragon-dance  hanging across the ceiling. 

"Food is great here", says me, someone who grew up in China eating Chinese food. While I can't say the food here is authentic, the food hits the spot and satisfies my palate nonetheless. What I admire and crave the most are actually the fusiom dishes. Mission Chinese is known for the Ma Po Tofu and it really did not disappoint, best I've had in the US! Just the right amount of "ma la" (numbing spicy) that makes you want to est bite after bite. Be sure to get a bowl of white rice to go with it. Other dishes I really liked were General Tsao's Short Ribs and hand-pulled noodle with spicy lamb. The most surprising of the night was the stir-fried pumpkin with pea sprouts. It was spicy and smoky, and the texture of thinly sliced pumpkin worked well with the pea sprouts. 

Guess what is authentically Chinese? The service. You will get your food eventually, just don't expect it to be quick or in any particular order.
author: Maggie L.

description:
The wait can be long. The place can be crowded. But the food. Oh, the food. It tastes like the classic Chinese food I so often crave but with a twist. And I don't mean add-some-gratuitous-avocado-and-make-it-Instagrammable "twist." Or drown it in Hoisin and call it a day "twist." 

I mean creative dishes like spicy pumpkin soup or salt cod fried rice or thrice-cooked bacon kinda twist. The kind that takes real and thoughtful experimentation to find the exact right register of. It's so good that I've spent many a teary-eyed post breakup night watching Game of Thrones and eating takeout from this place by myself at home when little else could console me. The hype is wholly deserved.
author: Dulma T.

description:
totally Mission-hipster vibe for this place, and kind of a mix of asian-y food styles, not only Chinese, but 100% great food. go with as many ppl as possible in order to try as much as you can. it's open late and gets crowded at the post-post-post-cocktail hour

must-haves: chicken wings, kimchi, fried chicken, eggplant and I think the mapo tofu might be the best I've ever had. for real
author: Bob U.

description:
Mission Chinese Food was one of my favorite restaurants in NY so I was excited to find out there was a location in SF as well. We managed to snag the last table for two on a Friday night with no wait.

If you like spicy food, you absolutely have to get the chongqing chicken wings - this is what they are famous for. Although this wasn't as spicy as the wings in NY, it was still good. We also got the pork mapo tofu with rice, which I loved and couldn't get enough of. My friend really liked the taiwanese eggplant we ordered as well.

Unfortunately, they don't offer the delicious cocktails the NY location does, but I'd still recommend going here if you want some delicious Chinese food.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Because of the size of our party, we were forced to follow a fixed menu. The options were mediocre at best, at a very unreasonable price. The wait staff was also unfriendly and felt rushed the whole order.

Would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Chris T.

description:
First I will say, I hate yelp bc of the wanna be restaurant critics who think they know everything. 

I've worked in the restaurant industry for 20 years as a Chef, GM & DM. This place has been on my restaurant bucket list for 6 years now until tonight. What a disappointment. 

For all the fame and press this place gets, it  was filthy. I totally can see why they got a 72 health score. Don't get it twisted with the eclectic decor. I mean the amount of disgusting black dust that is covering pretty much everything made me cringe. The sticky soy bottle and the ring on the table shows the lack of Love and Passion one has and instills in their staff. 

You get 5 stars for the golden shrimp rolls with the noodle- they were fantastic 

Noodles with beef. To greasy and shocker Salty-1

Fried chicken.  Your Filipino ancestors are rolling in their graves with disappointment. -000


Sorry not sorry.  You're a disappointment to our food community. Stop trying to go on tv shows and plead your case.  The proof is in the lack of care in your establishment.
author: Tanya O.

description:
If you're a squeaky beans kind of person look no further: The beans are super squeaky. 

But let me backtrack. Overall solid, eggplant was delicious and tender and sweet and savory. Y'all know me and A. love carbonara but this incarnation was kind of boring (and shouldn't be called a carbonara just because it comes with an egg yolk). Mongolian beans a little spicy in a great way but SQUEAKY-- you chew and it squeaks, I am telling you it's odd. So squeaky. So if you like squeaky beans, this is your place.
author: Simon S.

description: Sooo yummy! One of our new favorite neighborhood spots. We usually get 3 vegan dishes to share and leave so full! The food is delicious with rich flavors and it comes out sooo quick. I would happily bring anyone visiting town here.
author: Gaby L.

description:
For the life of me, I can't understand why this only gets 3.5 stars on Yelp. 

This place is excellent. It provides a modern take on Chinese cuisine in a decorous way that doesn't go overboard. 

Everything to the wings to the Ma Po Tofu is excellent. I've been here three times and have enjoyed every meal.​

The weirdest thing about this place is that the entrance door doesn't have a self-closing mechanism. So a hapless waiter or waitress has to continually go over to close the door because it is sitting wide open. 

​
author: Felix C.

description:
Fairly authentic Chinese food that's been tweaked and gussied up a bit for Western tastes. 

The salt cod fried rice (mackerel confit, Chinese sausage, lettuce, egg) is one of their dependable hits, the 3x-cooked bacon and rice cakes (sweet tofu skin, bitter melon, Szechuan pepper) a spicy, somewhat noodly surprise, and the stir-fried squid ink noodles (with chopped lamb, cumin fennel, harissa, and yogurt) quite delightful.

If anything, judging by the mostly non-Asian servers and crowd here, you wouldn't know how authentic it was until you had a taste of the food and until you took a peek into a kitchen and realized that it it's all Chinese folks working back there.

That's about the only thing that gives me pause, though - that somehow the Chinese folks are stuck working in the back, with the subtle implication that things would be sullied a bit and not as trendy if Chinese or Asian folks were front and center.
author: Vincent L.

description: Lydia was our server and she was wonderful. She walked us through the menu and we ended up having an array of dishes, giving us a tasting menu of their most popular orders.  The interior of the restaurant is nothing fancy. There is a dragon hanging from the ceiling... but the interior say that the only thing they care about is the food. No frills, no time for presentation, just food. Lydia is the best thing to ever come out or Oklahoma.
author: Ethan D.

description:
A very interesting take on Chinese cuisine. Not quite fusion, and not crazy upscale, which is great.

-Matcha Meyer Lemon noodles - great noodles and very unique dish for sure
-Lamb paparadelle - the lamb was delicious and squid ink pasta too!!
-Dumplings - crispy on the outside and delicious on the inside, just as they should be
-Pork belly- a little fatty for my liking, but crispy skin
-Brussel sprouts - if you like brussel sprouts, you're bound to like these.
-Fried Chicken- some of the crispiest I've had

Every dish was tasty, delicious, and well done. 
The ambiance is quite loud, the lighting is quite dim, with a red twinge (you can tell in all the pictures), but the food is great!

Service- They forgot to put bacon in our brussel sprouts initially, but then said no worries, we'll bring you another. They also brought us an extra dumpling since we had one more person than the amount in the order. All I can say is, so thoughtful and above and beyond!

Definitely a great place to check out if you're in the area!
author: Alison L.

description:
It's expensive for what it is, and more importantly, the food was just so-so. Of all the things I ordered, there's only 1.5 things I would eat again, and not sure if I'd bother going back for those things.

Here's what we had:

- Chinese giardiniera ($5)
- Chongqing chicken wings ($11)
- Salt cod fried rice ($13)
- Cumin lamb ($26)

The chongqing chicken wings was spicy-numbing and uniquely delicious, and I really liked it even though I think it could have been done better.

The cumin lamb was good as well, but I've had way better cumin lamb in China. I think my aunt could probably also make better lamb. The other dishes were kind of a disappointment given how critics raved about the food a few years ago.
author: Ted W.

description: Was really disappointed. My boyfriend and I went here for dinner and truly wanted to like the place. We got the spicy chicken wings, the brisket and broccoli, and the pork belly. The chicken wings were plain--had a dry powder spice on them, but were boring and uninventive (and not spicy AT ALL, which my boyfriend was very disappointed about). The brisket was overly smoked and tasted almost off because of it; the smokiness completely overpowered the dish. The whole dish tasted reheated. Lastly, the pork belly had a nice flavor, but was oh so fatty, to the point of unappetizing. We won't be back here. Does not live up to the hype whatsoever. Go to Le Colonial if you want Asian fusion done correctly.
author: Erielle D.

description:
Hipsters everywhere! ...but if there's one thing I'm grateful about when it comes to hipsters, it's that it means there's usually vegan options.

Oh Mission Chinese Food. You're so hip that the sign outside says "Lung Shan" and if you look really hard behind the bars in front of the window, you'll find a one-foot square sign that actually says Mission Chinese Food. http://bit.ly/2n2WqoK

This place is so hip, the small restaurant was crazy crowded at 6:30pm on a Saturday night. We added our name to the waiting list and got a table roughly 20 minutes later. This place is so hip that it has a large dragon hanging from the ceiling, extending the length of the restaurant with club lights flashing to the loud rap music. The Meateater BF has a theory about the loud rap music, which wasn't even good rap, is that it's a tactic to turn tables more quickly. I think he has a point. Who would want to sit and linger when it's too loud to have a decent conversation?

The food came out super quick! We ordered more than we could handle:
- Sichuan Kimchi http://bit.ly/2mIl9Cu
- Stir Fried Pumpkin http://bit.ly/2lM1xsj
- Mongolian Long Beans http://bit.ly/2mqwVR3
- Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes (sans bacon) http://bit.ly/2n2Z8dQ
- Kung Pao Pastrami (for the Meateater BF)

The Sichuan Kimchi was our one cold dish. Very gingery and refreshing. I like the use of macadamia nuts. This was the perfect palate cleanser.

Mongolian Long Beans, while they were good, sort of fell below our expectations. The menu sold us on the idea of fresh horseradish which we could absolutely see sprinkled on top but could not taste it at all. Also, this dish was a bit on the salty side.

My favorites were definitely the Stir Fried Pumpkin and the Rice Cakes. I wasn't expecting the pumpkin to be thin-shaved pieces nor was I expecting it to be a bit on the al dente side which made me super into this dish! The Rice Cakes had this tasty black bean sauce and sweet tofu skin. Yum! ...except for the bitter melon. I've never liked bitter melon when I was a kid so I have no idea why I thought I'd like it now. Bleh!

I enjoyed my meal but I'm not so sure I would want to dine in again. Don't get me wrong, service was friendly and fast but the atmosphere is just not my scene. Perhaps next time I'll do take out. Still a fan though. Would definitely order the Stir Fried Pumpkin and the Rice Cakes again.
author: Harmonie T.

description: Still good after a four year break from this place, it was a delight to enjoy the delicious funky food that's so specific to this restaurant. I was with a vegetarian friend and she really enjoyed the meal.
author: Andrea Y.

description: Definitely one of the worst Chinese meals I've ever had. This is "Chinese with an American twist" gone horribly horribly wrong. If you've never had authentic Chinese food, you might think this place is okay. But if you've ever had a near-decent Chinese meal, you're most likely gonna hate this place.
author: Andy H.

description:
Whoa. Horrible. I'm still recovering about two weeks later. We ordered the fried rice, Mongolian Long beans, ma Po tofu, and hamachi. It was ALL BAD. By bad, I mean, pre cooked, too salty, too oily stir fry masquerading as Chinese food. I'd go as far as to say it was inedible. I was super thirsty for 24 hours post meal (you know that means, HELLO, MSG!!!) I had the pleasure of a ~$80 for crappy food, lousy service and uncomfortable ambiance. 

Never again. BEWARE MY YELP FRIENDS!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Believe the hype. This place is so good. We ordered the salt cod fried rice, crab Rangoon (order it- just trust), lamb and squid ink pappardalle, and the pork mapo tofu. Food came out quickly, we arrived around 6 pm on a Thursday and there were plenty of tables. Place was about half full by 6:30.
author: Maria R.

description: Our friends introduced us to this unique restaurant. The interior has a large dragon hanging from the ceiling. This isn't your typical Chinese restaurant, it's definitely Chinese inspired but has a modern twist to it, a little bit of fusion flare mixed in there too. Everything we ordered came out pretty quickly and was hot and fresh. We enjoyed the hot wings, eggplant, and fish cakes.
author: Sonya K.

description:
I think I missed the boat on Mission Chinese Food's hey-day because, having just eaten there for the first time yesterday, I had a somewhat lackluster experience. This is definitely a destination restaurant because the neighborhood itself has zero charm. (But this is coming from someone who has not spent much time in SF.) In 2010, it would've been novel to eat at a hipster restaurant hidden inside an old Chinese hole-in-the-wall storefront. Today, it feels a little tired, like the restaurant itself hadn't evolved. But I'm probably missing the point--"if it ain't broke why fix it". I'm also eight years older now and fall into a completely different age bracket.

That being said, the menu is indeed filled with inventive Chinese-fusion dishes, though, we veered toward the more familiar ones. The Sichuan Kimchi and Tiger Salad were a light refreshing start. I actually really loved the Tiger Salad, which appeared as large bundles of dressed mizuna greens and herbs wrapped in wide, supple rice noodles and topped with a stack of shredded nori and sesame seeds. Next, we had their popular Chongquin chicken wings. To me, these were just OK. The wings were crispy and coated with a dry spice mix and tossed with dried whole chili peppers. I expected them to be spicier but they were pretty tame. I think this recipe is in their cookbook with the inclusion of fried tripe. I think this dish really needed that kind of outré element to make it pop. As our entree, we shared the Pork Mapo Tofu with a side order of steamed jasmine rice. It was delicious, like what you would probably find at a traditional Chinese hole-in-the-wall (and I mean that in the best way).

The good thing for us was that we came here for a late lunch and didn't have to wait in line. I really wanted to love this place but it felt a little bit neglected and as though it lost its verve. Maybe the vibe is different at nightfall. (Come to think of it, I don't think I'd feel safe coming to that neighborhood at night.) Unfortunately, I can't see myself going out of my way and returning to dine here. All in all, I think Mission Chinese Food could use a 2018 reboot. It has so much potential and I could definitely see that it began with a wellspring of creativity and lots of energy. It just needs attention and a renewed spirit!
author: Jessica D.

description:
I am torn because last week I ordered delivery from here and then went to the restaurant last night and both times there was at least one dish that blew me away but then again there were dishes that were just ok.

Let's start with the great:
Lamb dumplings - this dish was AMAZING! the tzatziki sauce on top was an excellent compliment to the spicy lamb dumpling. I was licking the bowl clean because it was sooo sooo delicious
Bacon and rice cakes - this had a great spicy kick to it. bacon was crispy and thick cut. Lots of flavor.
Fried chicken - holy cow what a HUGE portion. Each piece of chicken was giant. The outside was perfectly crispy and the chicken was super moist. I was not a huge fan of the vinegar sauce that came with it - a little too much vinegar but the chicken itself was sooo good and moist that it didn't need the sauce.
Greens - this was one of my favorites. It had excellent flavor and little bit of spice.

The just ok:
Some cod neck dish - I thought it was decent but on the fishy side
Pork belly - was good but didn't blow me away unfortunately
Beef Lo Mein - standard noodle dish. I ordered this for take out so maybe by the time it got to me, the sauce had dried out just a tad.
Rice - plain. not much else to say

Service was good and quick. Ambience was hipster and loud. Just be aware that it's a small space - we didn't bring our baby with us but I imagine it would've been hard to get the stroller in there. Getting a reservation for sunday evening was super easy. I made it on saturday morning
author: Lisa D.

description:
8/10 this was one of the weirdest clubbing experiences ever. Came here for a fabulous boys night out and was pleasantly surprised by the lack of cover fee. If you like edm, abgs, or piping hot meat in your mouth, this is the place to be. 

We didn't even need to pay to reserve a table!!!! Unlimited water on the house which was pretty neat considering the fact that scientists just discovered that if you drink enough water you will end up in the hospital, which is also where you go if you get alcohol poisoning. 

The lack of a bar was kind of off-putting but I guess rent is expensive in SF so that makes sense. 

Low key tho, at this place you can pay ACTUAL MONEY for some . It has been a long, wrinkly, and crusty dry season for me but for a small price of $16, let's just say I got stuffed real good.
author: Grilled Cheese S.

description:
Decently good Chinese fusion food. I would label it as "an upgrade from Panda Express but definitely not authentic." 

When I say this is Chinese fusion, I don't really mean it in the class westernized way but in the fusion of East Asian flavors into a single dish. You can think of this place as "Chinese food with a Korean twist" or "Chinese food fused with flavors from Vietnam, Korea, Japan" etc etc. 

I have a pretty severe peanut allergy (aka I can die if I eat peanuts) and they have some dishes containing peanuts. I told the waitress about this and she communicated that to the chef who said they would be able to make it sans peanuts. We also had a vegetarian person eating with us and they were able to accommodate for that as well

We ordered the family style set (feeds 7+ people) which included:
Sichuan-style Kimchi 
Smashed Cucumbers
Chinese Giardiniera
some kind of Vietnamese-style Chinese-y spring roll (apparently the owner's wife's favorite...?)
Chongqing Chicken Wings 
Mapo Tofu
Thrice-cooked Bacon and Rice cakes (highly recommend this)
Mongolian Long Beans
Taiwanese Eggplant

If you want to try a variety of dishes and don't mind sharing, I would recommend to do this. It's A LOT of food and we ended up taking home leftovers (we were a party of 8). The food is oily so don't raise your hopes too much on SF-clean-eating. They have a couple light beers (mainly lagers and Asian malty beer) to wash your meal down. 

If you're coming here with a large group, definitely make a reservation ahead of time since the place is quite small and I think they only have 1 large table. The ambiance is very casual and decor is funky slightly stereotyped Chinese dragon themed. 

I'd come here again if I was craving some greasy, guilty-pleasure Chinese food. 

--
tl;dr
Food is decent. 
East Asian fusion type of fusion, not westernized fusion Chinese food. 
Oily/greasy (not healthy)
Vegan/Vegetarian options available 
Portions are large
They have peanuts in some dishes but can make things peanut-free
author: Victoria C.

description: Not traditional Chinese food but still pretty tasty. Strong flavors. Some ingredients though you wonder if they actually contribute to dish. Overall on the priced side. We were the only non-hipsters there during dinner
author: J S.

description:
Delicious food that can be over-salted at times. Perfect joint for catching up with old friends. Recommend sharing plates and trying the numbing chicken wings, rice cakes w/beef, and the eggplant.
Mouth watering stuff!!
author: Andy D.

description: Wow! Delicious Unique dishes with incredible flavors! The staff is very friendly. The food came out fast. It was a wait but WORTH IT!
author: Jasmine K.

description:
I've loved this place for around 8 years. It is so funky and original, flavorwise! Definitely not for everyone, but if you love asian flavors and have a creative/interesting flavor palette, try this place. I live up in the North Bay and I make it a point any time I come to the city to eat here or get take-out. I wish they delivered up north!!

First off - tiger salad - delicious herbs wrapped in a chewy noodle wrap, with a smoky vinagrette dressing.... superb!
Sauteed greens - yum!
Wings - yes!!!! Super fun to dig through a pile of chilis for your wings, and they have that amazing szechuan ghost heat that cools after it burns!
And finally, MAPO TOFU!!!! I have tried to recreate this dish, and while I make it pretty well from the cookbook,  its not the same.... this is my favorite chinese dish, and this is the only place where I have enjoyed it! THe szechuan peppercorn is off the chain! Ghost pepper! what a tingly mouth experience. If you don't like heat... then we're not friends.
author: BeckyZão A.

description:
Brussels Sprouts - too salty, skip
Thrice cooked Bacon - almost too salty but its fine.  Could use more bacon but this is orderable 
Salt Cod Fried Rice - Good to order if you're getting any of the salty dishes above because its not as salty but lacks flavor in general compared to any real Cantonese restaurant.

I used to love this place 6 years ago but it looks like the innovation died here and all that is left is over priced Chinese food for the new gentrified audience that can't tell the different between food from Hong Kong, Beijing, Canton, Taiwan and Panda Express from Glendale.
author: Vince L.

description:
Love this place. Ordered the eggplant and beef broccoli and it was legit. The place smelled like garlic from a mile away, which I thought was a good thing for yummy Chinese food. 

The only weird thing was the sign outside is not the name of the restaurant....
author: Laleh E.

description:
Had a pretty outstanding dinner here last night. Went around 8 with a group of 4. We're visiting friends in town and they talked this place up as one of their faves in the neighborhood, so we obviously had to check it out. I'd say it delivered! We signed our name on the sheet outside and were seated within ten minutes. The vibe is cool and laid back, with unusual kind of funky decor and neon lights. Our server was pretty brusque but it was cool. She was very quick - we were barely there 45 minutes total. 

We decided to order a bunch of things to share. They brought everything out whenever it was ready which resulted in our little table completely covered with foods. Luckily everything was so good that dishes disappeared rapidly! 

Matcha Meyer Lemon noodles - star of the night. all four of us loved this. Very unique, refreshing, and light. I wouldn't want to eat a whole bowl of it but it was great to have some on the side of some of the saltier dishes. 

Kimchi - very good. I liked the added peanuts. Wasn't too spicy. 

Smashed cucumber - I don't get why this is called smashed, because it was sliced? Light and tasty regardless. 

Chicken wings - my husband talked about them all night after we went home. Spicy and delicious. Nice and crispy. He says they're the best wings he's ever had which means something from a man who has literally never turned down a chicken wing in his life. 

Tiki pork belly - I loved this one. Perfectly cooked, and i liked the fresh pineapple and addition of coconut. 

Kung Pao Pastrami - probably the only dish I wasn't super impressed with. The meat was good, but it was VERY salty. I needed to mix it with rice to even eat the serving I put on my plate. 

Overall, was super pleased with our dinner here and would totally go back anytime!!
author: Hannah M.

description:
Easily snagged some dinner res for 2 earlier in the week for a Sat night primetime 645 pm dinner. I'm not sure why people wait in lines outside when ressies are very easy to make. Anyways, we got there about 10 min late, the store sign shows Lung Shan Restaurant so don't be fooled. 

We were quickly seated though initially, we were asked whether we would be ok taking a seat at the end of a communal table. When I asked how long it would be for a wait for a private table, we were still able to be seated immediately (I guess I can't blame him for trying though later on, I saw the 2 seats at the end of a communal table and there definitely wasn't enough room for 2). 

Love love the ambiance - there's a huge dragon, great energy, lots of hip hop music in the background, but they still maintain remnants of Chinese restaurants (those plastic cups). 

Was disappointed to see only 1 cocktail on the menu (Chinese mule) when I heard the location in NYC has a lot more interesting options. Even more disappointed to see our server pour it from a premade pitcher :( Guess this isn't the place to get a nice cocktail.

We settled on sharing a few things - thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes, country fried hamachi collar and tiger salad. The bacon rice cakes were good - definitely very glutinous and heavy but good flavors. Tiger salad was actually wrapped in rice paper similar to rolls you'd see at a Vietnamese restaurant. They were just ok. My favorite was the hamachi collar which was the most interesting and authentically represented; however the portion size is pretty small for $18. 

Service was just ok. Our server who initially took our orders was really awesome but halfway through the meal, we were handed a check even though one of our dishes hadn't come out yet. It was strange that she didn't even ask us anything but just handed us the check. I guess they're going for the authentic hole in a wall Chinese restaurant experience? haha

Overall, there's some interesting food that's worth checking (and the ambiance is great) out but unlikely to return. $70+ bill for 3 dishes and 2 drinks - very anti-Chinese :) I also didn't think the food was that spicy and it was pretty telling that most of the clientele were non-Asian.
author: Yin H.

description: Tasty goodness and inventive Chinese or Asian fusion.  Food was pretty good but the friendly service and good vibe tops it up to 4.
author: Scott H.

description: I give this place credit, it's an amazing restaurant. My LA friends love this place and we go whenever they're in town. The spicy chicken wings are BOMB! We've ordered almost everything from the menu and I would say the food is amazing. The chow mein noodles, the corn, the string beans, eggplant- everything is amazing! Service is great. Cute restaurant dimly lit, nice ambience. Def will be coming back!
author: Nessa H.

description: Probably more of a 2.5 star.  I got the bacon with rice cakes, which was overly salty and tasted burnt, which exaggerated the bitterness of the bitter melon and made the whole dish not so pleasant.  I took a bite of my girlfriend's broccoli and brisket, which tasted like pot roast.  The crushed cucumbers appetizer was decent, though.
author: Simon L.

description:
Once upon a time, this was my favorite Chinese place in the mission. Cumin lamb, the ma po tofu, and the wings were stellar. Sadly over the last three times I've eaten here or taken my food to go, I've been very disappointed and today was the last straw.

I ordered Hainan chicken rice and the thrice cooked bacon with rice cakes. Now, a Hainan chicken rice ought to contain chicken. If only to live up to its name, perhaps? Unfortunately none was to be found here. I asked the lady on the phone later whether this was her idea of a complete dish, to which she replied in the affirmative. Well then.

Things get even more despondent. The thrice booked bacon dish contained three small pieces of bacon (see attached). Not a hint of all the other vegetables and things they're supposed to have in there. It was more a thrice cooked rice cake dish with a dash of bacon. Sad, but true.

With $17 for what's essentially a stir fried rice cake dish, and $12 for a small container of rice with no chicken and not enough flavor - if I wanted a $30 rice dish, I'd go to Nobu you know? - I'm confident in my assessment that the things that once made this one  of the most interesting and delicious restaurants in the city are no more. 

Callous customer service, a detached cooking process that optimizes a bottom line vs being true to a dish, and exorbitant prices for dishes that barely live up to their names are more than enough for me to recommend steering clear of mission chinese.
author: Viksit G.

description:
Came here last night with my family for my dad's birthday and we really enjoyed it!

We live 4 blocks away, always see a huge line, and are huge fans of Chinese food so we figured we'd come try it. Because of the long lines, we decided to make an early reservation on a Tuesday and it was a greta choice. By the time we were seated you can see the crowd starting to show up.

When we first arrived we expected some authentic Chinese food, especially because the sign on the outside is nothing like the environment in the inside which I though was kind of cool. The inside is decorated with dragons and various ornaments hanging from the ceiling and there was this cool red lighting. The place was also very dicey and trendy in the sense that they play hip, up-to-date hip hop music!

Anyways, the menu is definitely more fusion and not your typical dishes for a Chinese restaurant. There were five of us and we are a family that can eat. I would probably suggest EVERYTHING that we ordered.

1. Smashed Cucumbers
2. Golden Mountain Spring Roll (Crispy)
3. Broccoli beef brisket
4. Beef Chow mein
5. Mongolian Long beans
6. West Lake Rice Porridge 
7. Steamed Rice
(This was perfect for a group of five very hungry people who know how to eat)

There were so many other things on the menu that I will definitely be back to try! GO GO GO!
author: Kassie E.

description:
All you really need to know about is the thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes, but whilst we're here... don't miss out on the pork belly and salt cod fried rice either!

I've gotten take away a few times (lucky enough to live within range) and it's good. Not quite the same as actually sitting in with the quirky decor and fun (if a little cosy) atmosphere. 

I was told this is a San Francisco experience that's not to be missed. I'd say that was 100% accurate. Get over there!
author: Rowena H.

description:
I have ordered from MCF about 6-8 times. Usually it's pretty good; a little pricey but if I'm too lazy to leave home, then that's on me, no?
Anyway, I ordered from here a month ago & it was terrible! Too salty, too spicy, nothing delicious, just a mess.
What happened, MCF? 
So, what do I do? I do what any 25 y.o. millennial would do: run to the internet!* 
If you want to know what theories there are about why the food is bad, do the same. Otherwise, I'm sorry that it's gone downhill. Maybe I ordered on a bad night. Maybe not. But it's too expensive to try again, especially when there's so much else to choose from....
Sorry MCF :-(
*I am not a 25 y.o. millennial, nor am I portraying one on TV.
author: Yasi S.

description:
Friends have been telling me about Mission Chinese Food for years but I have failed to go.  My friends who actually live in SF laugh when I mention a Chinese Food place in the Mission, but laugh no more. It's amazing!  Tea Smoked Eel Roll, Thrice Cooked Back and Rice Cakes, and a very tasty Beef Chow Mein made for an incredible dinner for 2 (definitely could have been for 3).  

Can't wait to go back and try more!
author: John H.

description:
This is based on an order through Grub Hub for takeout!

I ordered the Thrice cooked bacon and Rice Cakes, CRAVING those delicious medallions of goodness and something with a little spicy kick. Pick up was quick and easy on a Friday afternoon--they were empty and my food was ready when I arrived 2 minutes too early!

I inhaled that dish like breathing. I was starving and it smelled and tasted so good--the bacon with the perfect amount of fat that I like and the spice level not overbearing but just enough to warm me up all over. 

The only reason I ordered through GH was because I had a coupon which made the dish roughly only $10 instead of the usual $16+. Even at $10, I would NOT say this was worth it--so expensive for something so simple! Now that I've had it, I think I could make a version of my own for way less. 

Would I go back? Maybe. Good flavors and food, great takeout service, but it was wayyyy not worth the $$ to portion ratio.
author: Nerissa C.

description: A Chinese food place you'd go if you were desperate for some decent Chinese food that's not too far
author: Rene C.

description:
So on the plus...
they comped our entire meal.
On the negative...
Hair. So much hair. At first, I thought, oh, this must be mine. But it was the wrong length. And the wrong texture. 
No. 
Then there was another...and another...and another...I found six pieces before I said anything. 
The entire pot of rice porridge was filled with it.
They took the porridge away, saying they would comp the porridge. 
After looking, they came back and said "We don't want you to think that our kitchen is contaminated", and comped our entire meal. Umm...

This was pretty gross. 

So yeh, my first time here I was not the most impressed.
author: Danielle L.

description: OMG, the rice porridge ftw! Way more complex than I was expecting! Best porridge I have had yet...granted I live in the D.C. area lol
author: Bernadette K.

description:
I've heard so much about Mission Chinese Food and how amazing its food is, but personally I'm not a huge fan of the food... The food is Americanized and mixed up w/ non-traditional ingredients like lamb, squid ink pasta, and bacon... that mixed with Asian flavors was just too weird. Although the food is adventurous and creative, it's just not for me....

For those of you who are wondering why it's called Lun Shan Restaurant instead of Mission Chinese Food, it's because MCF was originally a pop up in the previous hole in the wall Lun Shan Restaurant. The food here is definitely on the heavier side, so come hungry and bring a few friends to try a bunch of different dishes. Portions are generous too so be prepared to fall into a food coma!

My favorite dish is the fried rice... but I love fried rice. We also got the thrice cooked bacon which is good, and the eggroll wrapped springroll dish which tasted really gross to me.The texture of the rolls was just too strange and the texture was soggy but slightly crunchy?  Also, all the food was super greasy and oily which I'm not a huge fan of. 

I would not come back but it could just be a personal preference. Adventurous foodies may like this, but it's just not for me...
author: Janet H.

description: Weirdest "Chinese" food I've ever had....and everything was surprising, interesting and delicious.  My favorite was the thrice cooked bacon; the spicy rice cakes and sweet tofu skins were a wonderful balance to the smoky bacon.  We tried the cucumbers
author: Corinne H.

description:
Love this place it's so punk!

I got the Kung Pao Pastrami and a can of beer from someplace local.

They've got lazers in there!
author: Mark C.

description: Definitely not traditional Chinese food but extremely tasty. Get the Mongolian string beans and chicken wings for intense flavor. A restaurant that successfully blends traditional with other cuisines in flavorful probably-msg-filled dishes.
author: Kaison T.

description:
I'm a big fan of Cantina (when it was open, moment of silence) and Mission Chinese in NY so you know I had to try the OG while I'm in town!

Of the three, I have to say that this one is my favorite in ambiance. It's 80% in the styling of an early nineties Chinese joint that I grew up with - down to the menu and wooden tables - and 20% owner's personality. Dragon and lights hanging from the ceiling were a sight as well as the mostly hip-hop soundtrack. You can't sleep on the art in the restaurant as well - personally admired the one with the Chinese men on horses. I also respect how they advertised the Asian Art Museum.

For the food, the rice cakes with (vegan option) bacon was unexpectedly sweet. It was less spicy than what I remembered it to be but still flavorful. It was also a bit tangier (in a very good way) than my next dish. The Sour Chili Chicken had a nice surprise with the potatoes. Garlic Fried Rice went well with the Nori. Mint and Oolong tea to wash it down; it was the perfect closer.

One note though: I can't give the W to this over my hometown team. Simple reason: I really like the pizza at the LES location. It's odd that I find it to be one of my favorite pizzas in NY but that's just me (it's subjective, deal with it)!

Either way, it's a great restaurant and worth the wait. Wishing Danny Bowien luck in whatever new ideas he wishes to pursue!
author: David N.

description:
DOV: 11/12/16 
9th stop | 6:50 PM-7:30 PM

IMO, cuisine category should also be "asian fusion"! 

NOTE: The store banner shows "Lung Shan Restaurant" (龍山小館), not Mission Chinese Food. You can't miss the huge dragon inside though, if you pass by!

The ingredients and concept of dishes are "東北" (North-Eastern China) style. You'll see lots of chili peppers sign, a lot of carbs/red meat, and usage of bold flavors!

Pro tip 1: Put your name on the waitlist! It's hanging on the door. 
Pro tip 2: if you're party is small (aka 2-3 people), I highly recommend asking right away about being seated at the communal table. Yes, you'll sit next to strangers but it's so dark who caressss...
Pro tip 3: Gratuity added to parties of 6 or more. 
Pro tip 4: Reservations are possible, just give them a call. 
Pro tip 5: MSG option now available!!! (???)  

Menu is split into "small cold dishes", "small hot dishes", "vegetables", "classic dishes", "family style dish- limited availability", "noodles", "rice". 

Types of drinks: free water, 9 types of beer, 6 types of wine, 1 cocktail ("Mission Chinese Mule"), 4 types of sake, 3 alcoholic beverages, 2 teas.  

Everything is served family style! 

We ordered: 

CLASSIC DISH: 
1 order of Thrice Cooked Bacon & Rice Cakes ($16, v*, vegan/vegetarian option available): sweet tofu skin, bitter melon, salty black beans // 
+/-1 two chili signs, but we requested it to be reduced to one. In hind sight, I could take on another chili pepper! 
+1 This wasn't too oily and it had great hints of bitter melon and bacon. 
+1 Perfectly cooked rice cakes! Most places get too sticky or soggy, but this was the perfect "heat" (火候). The dish was addicting and great for leftovers!

1 Broccoli beef brisket ($18): smoked oyster sauce, toasted seeds //
+1 Delicious chunks of beef! Not really "brisket", more like braised beef. 
+1 Chinese broccoli! Not your typical Panda Express "beef and broccoli".
-1 Too much oyster sauce...definitely need a bowl of rice with this. 

Pros:
+Great service! Super quick to order, serve, clean up. 
+Love the ambiance and rap music! 

Cons:
-Kinda pricey....I didn't expect the dishes to be that heavily priced since this place isn't super upscale. 
-A bit too dark, but I shamelessly flashed everything to see what I was consuming.

Tips/Observations:
-Environment is definitely hippy! Would recommend for a fun date. 
-Food to go and deliveries available! If you come for to-go, just head to the back and order. 
-They donate 25 cents from each red meat dish to ZeroFoodprint.Org to offset their carbon footprint!

Overall, I would come here again! I had a fun time and their dishes blew me out of my expectations. Huzzah for cool fusion food in Mission!
author: Hurjane V.

description:
Chinese food served in the Mission area with a trendy, hipster twist! Let's be clear... this isn't authentic Chinese food at all. My parents would hate the extra MSG, salt and oil in the food. The decorations and ambiance in the restaurant though, might be authentic; I really liked the dragon and paper light decor that looked like it may have been there since the 1980's.

My favorite dish that I tried that day were the Matcha Squid Ink Noodles. Mapo Tofu could've been a second favorite, but the spicy oil in the sauce overtook the dish. I'm really glad we ordered a rice dish because you need rice as a vehicle for all the sauces in the dishes!! 

Overall, I did enjoy dining at Mission Chinese Food. It was a very tasty, but way too salty and saucy on a lot of the dishes.
author: Kristie F.

description:
I like the decor and background music. 

We ordered matcha squid ink noodles , spicy chicken wings and lamb dumplings. Everything is just very meh taste, meh cooking skill, and being very pricy for these kind of shitty foods! As a Chinese, I can't handle any of these bad poorly tasted food-- no wonder full house of none-Chinese guests.
author: Miri L.

description:
We so so hungry I came right into restaurant .. the place jus open for dinner.. usually crowded n pack every time we walk by here.. 
We sat down n look at the menu.. Asian food with a twist.. 
spring rolls was good with noodle wrap around fried shrimp n pork cake..
Grilled pork belly good
Squid ink noodles over powering garlic n salt..
Salted cod n sausage fried rice with lettuce.. lol no taste.. 
Our waitress ?? Not sure if she our waitress.. she bought the food to our table.. but she jus toss the order down our table..!!! 
And also toss our check on our table too.. pretty disappointing with our Order then have someone throw the check to u too.. 
maybe for the fame of yelp this place has long line dinner time.. but for me a hungry Asian woman.. and friend won't be coming back...
author: Crisy G.

description:
Overall I enjoyed my meal at Mission Chinese. Ambiance is unique with a serious hipster vibe. Service was pretty good. There was a huge wait outside but we got lucky and beat the rush and got seated right away. What we ordered:

1. Mongolian Long beans - these were really good. Get these. Perfect balance of flavors on these blistered beans!
2. Taiwanese eggplant - I'm a sucker for some gooey eggplant and they nailed this here. Flavorful and texture on point. Get these too. 
3. Salt Cod Fried Rice - Neither my friend or I enjoyed the flavor in this dish. The pieces of Chinese sausage and the lettuce were my favorite elements. I would not recommend or order again. Waiter recommended the garlic rice, we should have listened. 
4. Pork Mapo Tofu - I know this is one of the 7x7 must eats dish this year, but I can't say any of us were crazy about this dish either. Not bad but not great either. I love mapo tofu but I don't get the hype on this one! It did taste much better once I added chili paste though. The peppercorns definitely get your mouth tingling. 

Will be back to try more dishes!
author: Jacqueline ..

description: after trying the majority on the manu, it came down to three dishes" Pork Belly" " " ma po tofu". " rice cakes with bacon". they are to die for! make sure you like spicy food. we cannot get enough!
author: Souris L.

description: I've always been skeptical about this place and I should of followed my instincts. My friend really wanted to try it so I finally gave in tonight and thought how bad can it be the place is so popular they opened up in NY. Oh it was so bad. The msg on the table should of been a sign  We ordered the following : MO Po tofu, smashed cucumbers, pastrami Kung pao, garlic rice, thrice cooked rice cakes. And a Diet Coke that came more than half way through the meal ( the guy obviously forgot not once but twice  he then said he would comp it but didn't). Now why was the food so bad? Well after a big bite of the insanely over salted tofu it ruined  everything! We couldn't get the salt out of our mouths. The garlic rice, where's the flavor?? Everything was just the taste of salt. Then the bill came it was insane! I could get better Chinese for half that price.
author: Karen T.

description:
If I judged this place by the dude who works as the "host" this place would get -1 stars because he was pretty rude to my party and others.

However, judging Mission Chinese Food off the food and the service that the servers provided I give this place 5 stars. Holy Mary the food here is flipping GOOOOOOOOD! Being a party of 5 we decided to just order a bunch of dishes to share. Every dish ordered we absolutely loved. I bow to those working in the kitchen because you all produce food that takes your taste buds to nirvana!

What we had and highly recommend.
*Chonqing Chicken Wings 
*Lamb Dumplings
*Thrice Cooked Bacon & Rice Cakes
*Cumin Lamb
*Mongolian Long Beans
*General Tso's Beef Rib
*Steamed Jasmine Rice
author: Norm J.

description:
After couple of failed attempts to get a table, finally managed to get in during the long weekend. I am so disappointed with the place that I would like to give it 2.5 stars.

We ordered lamb dumpling and chicken wings. Both were different but just average. Main course was kung Pao pastrami and chow mein. Both were super salty.

However, what makes the experience so disappointing was the service. The server kept dropping by every 5 mins. And when we inquired about the saltiness, he was super rude.

Won't be coming back and won't be recommending this place.
author: Suparna J.

description:
SIMPLY THE BEST! If you are sick of prissy, boring "New American" cuisine served in bland rustic settings completely devoid of character / spirit / spice / creativity, THIS IS THE ANTIDOTE. Don't come here expecting to be waited on like a queen, and don't expect straight-up "Chinese food". This isn't it. There are no dainty Instagrammable place settings (it's dim AF) but that is THE POINT! It's unfussy, the food is damn good, and it comes really fast. Be prepared to expand your culinary mind. 

It's best to go with a larger group so you can try as many dishes as possible (or go when you have the munchies. Either works). Best times to go are early for dinner or lunchtime with a bigger group so you get seated fast. 

My favorite dish on the menu is the hamachi kama. This is the best cut of fish ever (tuna collar). It is deep fried and smothered in a sweet Vietnamese sauce and adorned with pickled daikon / carrots. ORDER ONE FOR YOURSELF because you will not want to share. If I go with a larger group I insist on ordering my own.

My other favorites are the lamb pappardelle (the lamb is so tender) and the garlic fried rice (the shiso imparts an excellent herby flavor). I just want this stuff dumped in my mouth by the bucket.

At Mission Chinese, the weirder the combination sounds, the better it tastes, IMO. Those Meyer lemon matcha noodles? To die for. The salted cod fried rice? Unmatched. 

Skip the beef+broccoli and the chicken unless you're boring. 

Mission Chinese has been around for awhile and I've loved it forever and even though they're not the hot new restaurant anymore, they are still damn good. They're ACTUALLY creative with the way they use / combine ingredients, and 85% of the time, it's executed extremely well. For this they deserve....AN EXTRA LONG YELP THE REVIEW! (And five stars)
author: Natalie S.

description: This is hands down the best effing Chinese food I've ever had in my life. Wow! We ordered family style and shared all the plates. It was perfect. The food was original and they had a great mix of vegetarian and meat plates, spicy and not spicy. I would make a list of what I enjoyed most but that's pretty much the entire menu. Check it out, you can't go wrong.
author: Nicholas L.

description: Love it!! The vibe is so great. Waiters are friendly and their playlist is super. Quite a few vegan options. The Mongolian beans and garlic rice was insanely delicious. Their peanuts were also very good. Eggplant and broccoli were also solid choices. It doesn't say Mission Chinese anywhere on the sign and definitely expect a wait during weekend dinners although they seem to get through the list relatively quickly.
author: Santho G.

description: I love the food and music. Waiter was excellent and I know it's not super nice decor however food overshadows it. Tea smoked eel roll, pastrami kung pao and chow mein are fabulous. Any place that plays Roky Erickson is good with me.
author: Keefe M.
Miko B.

description: Classic. Mission Chinese is a staple of San Francisco and an inspiration to many. Years on, it's menu is still strong and the management has gotten even better. The food is still great and affordable. Mission Chinese is a regular spot for us.
author: Adam T.

description:
Came here having heard great things and left wondering what person could have such awful taste as to call this good. 

First of all, the restaurant  itself is filthy. I get that it is in the Mission district, but the level of unclean here is not acceptable.

I was with a large group so we tried a variety of dishes, and several the server recommended as house favorites. All were bland, and tasted 2similar to each other. 

In all this was a supremely disappointing visit, and the food was not worth the time or money spent. Why there was a line to get in is beyond me. This place may have once been great, but they have clearly become complacent.
author: William M.

description:
Off the chain like Yao Ming!!
Get that pastrami and rice, dank!
This is the best Chinese in Sf hands down
author: Rob V.

description: I've been wanting to try their food for quite some time and when we arrived, we got lucky they were able to sit us before the lines began. The food was incredible and better than the Mexican Chinese food I've had in Mexicali. It was authentic with their own twist. We never got the servers name but when he came around he was attentive to our needs. Tip if you are hungry, arrive before 6pm or call to guarantee a table.
author: Gardenia H.

description: Mission Chinese always has a wait. It's a special location: one of the handful restaurants with a published cookbook. It's definitely fun to try the exotic dishes here inspired by Vietnamese, Chinese and other East, South Asian cuisines. The space is small almost screams fire hazard yikes but it's a fun experience even for people who are from Asia. Would bring a date here. It's a fun city hole-in-the-wall experience.
author: Dilys S.

description:
I strongly admit this restaurant do serve delicious food. It was incredibly good. The colorful atmosphere and the hipster-looking staff is what this Chinese restaurant made unique. Unlike most Chinese restaurants, the menu itself is purely in English which is unusual since most menus in Chinese restaurants are written in Chinese with English translation on the bottom. It was also on the news when the phone of Serena Williams was stolen at this restaurant.

But why only 2 stars despite of enjoying such tasty food? I rated this restaurant based on its quality of food, service and the environment.

The food deserves at least 4 stars. It was delicious but incredibly pricey. I ordered the Sour Chili Chicken which I truly enjoyed.

The service is awful. It should be rated at least 1, zero or -1. As a proud working class who value the importance of customer service, I find the service incredibly rude and lousy. If only the owner can suspend or replace these despicable staff? One of the male waiters gave me the bill while I'm in the middle of meal. The female staff with a tattoo was obviously ignoring me for some reason. I only wanted to have at least a glass of water. 

Overall, good food but bad service. I hope the management fixes this.
