author: Dan Mark D.

description: Fucking terrible the pork belly was just a deep fried fat chunk and the beef brisket broccoli was tasteless. We cancelled the chow mein before we had to suffer it down. I was embarrassed to bring my girl here with high expectations to be let down so badly. Why did you get rid of the Coca Cola ribs that made you famous? Why? Also your pork belly game is slippin. Look at the pictures you dont believe me. Shoulda went to R&G!
author: Matt C.

description:
Serena Williams came here with her boo and some jag tried to steal her phone off the table and run out. 

Good news: She ran that f*cker down, got her sh*t back, and hopefully beat his ass down. 
Who the f*ck thinks they can outrun freaking Serena Williams? 

I was not there for this heist and following (alleged only by my) beat down, but I think it's an interesting anecdote about Mission Chinese and knowing I ate in the same establishment as a celebrity is a quality I look for in a restaurant.

I came here with an equally as impressive woman after the SF film fest came to town and we felt we needed to reward ourselves after sitting through a particularly brutal Q&A with the film's director where, as expected, no one in the audience understands the difference between asking a question and just giving a personal comment and half-heartedly trying to phase a question into it. If you're a Q&A commenter it's important that you know you're a garbage person who belongs on garbage island. 

Aaaanyway, my incredible goddess of a friend had already been to Mission Chinese, which I never would have found on my own based on signage visible from street-view, but she wasn't exactly excited about sharing a bunch of non-meat plates with this pescetarian and after looking at the menu, I could understand where she was coming from. 

The star stuff here def seems to lie in the meat dishes (freakin pastrami Chinese goodness) but they do have a decent-ish selection of seafood and a limited veggie dish selection that's still pretty hearty. 

I thought most dishes had an ingredient or two that contributed to the plates being a little trippy. Like, my mouth flesh felt kinda numb all over and I'd move on to the next dish it would get a different type of numb and tingly. It was strange but interesting and an experience I'd happily look forward to again.
author: Candice G.

description: I really liked Mission Chinese Food. A hipster restaurant that serves gussied up American Chinese in a fun and festive atmosphere.  It's not cheap, it's definitely loud, but it is a little bit more inventive than your average American Chinese place.  The menu also changes, which is nice.  If you like the concept then I think you'll like the reality.
author: Ben S.

description:
I'm Chinese and I think the food was delicious. Plus NO WAIT for me on a Sunday evening. But this was one of my more expensive Chinese dinner. Over all the food was pretty tasty,  the services was fast and good.The only thing I was disappointed in was they no longer serve their Tea-Smoked Eel - Fresh Rice Noodle. Bummer!!

**Ma Po Tofu. So good. Better than most places in Chinatown and it was SPICY. I love it. RECOMMENDED
**Salt Cod Fried Rice. Kinda like the chinese dish, salty fish and chicken fried rice. YUM. Instead of chicken they used chinese sausages. RECOMMENDED 
**Mongolian Long Beans - Very flavorful. 
**Country Fried Hamachi Collar - Was pretty good but the dish is small. But I did feel like it was over cooked a bit not as moist as it should be.
author: Sandy B.

description: I love Mission Chinese! I always order the chicken wings. They're so good that i never want to share. My bf and i always order two orders hahah. These wings are one of a kind! I literally can't explain all of the different flavors and their unique texture. So amazing!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I can't not give this place five stars. Their mapo tofu is ...unrivaled. The sezhuan peppercorn just makes it. If your group is on the fence about it because some folks don't love tofu, definitely get it anyway. Everytime I do this one of my friends walks away calling it a new favorite dish of theirs (sometimes even the tofu-haters!). Definitely get it with some rice. 

Other great aspects of this place: some might say the service is rude but if you've ever been to China (or are homesick for China!) then the service will likely only amuse. Also it's FAST, I'll take that over super friendly but slow any day. 

The decor is also amazing. Playlists also on point. I take all of my out-of-towners here and it is always a hit.
author: Adrienne S.

description:
3.5 because I had high expectations for the food. Reservations are a must. A small group of people were already waiting outside when we arrived for our 7:30p reservation on a Wednesday night. Dishes came out pretty quickly after ordering, which was a pleasant surprise since they were so busy.

Sour Chili Chicken - For some reason, this chicken lacked both acidity and heat. It was mildly sour and spicy and the chicken a bit overcooked.

Bacon and Rice Cakes - This one was packed with flavor and also heat. My favorite parts were the sweet tofu skins that absorbed the savory and spicy sauce like a sponge.

Mountain Spring Roll - Interesting concept to have a crispy egg roll inside of a rice noodle roll but there was an herb in the roll that I did not like.
 
Mongolian Long Beans - This was fine. Met expectations.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
I do not know what is the fuss about this place. We had chicken wings, pork belly and fried chicken fried rice. 

First off, we did not know who are working no uniform or t shirt for the matter that states who are the employees. The host/slash server was wearing shorts and snickers, I don't know about you but this maybe too casual for me. 

The chicken wing was numbing outside but the inside was bland. It needs some salt other than Szechuan peppercorns. The pork belly was tender but sweet it needs a steam bun to make it into a sandwich appetizer. 
The fried chicken rice was okay nothing special about it. 

This place was recommended to us, I think it may have been good then but I don't know.
author: Cathe K.

description:
This place is horrendously underreviewed on Yelp. Don't trust Yelp for asian places in the bay area for some reason. This place is bomb. My favorite dish is the sour chili chicken. The fingerlings, the broth, just delectable. And I don't normally even like sour dishes. So that really speaks to the high quality of food put out this establishment.

This place has the vibes, the food, the rep. What more is there to ask for? Go. 4.5 stars.
author: Aakash G.

description:
You know I was so ready to write off this place as pure hype, but I actually LOVED it. This isn't where you come for authentic Chinese food. No, sir. But it's freakin' gooood.

smashed cucumbers - awesome starter

thrice cooked bacon and rice cake - carby and bacony. what more could you ask for? they are these little delightful soft and chewy rice cakes drenched in bacon flavor. salty and excellent. 

cod fried rice - i really couldn't tell there was any fish in this dish, but still mixed with everything else, i appreciated the rice. 

spicy lamb - amazing one of my favorite dishes. 

we also got two other chicken dishes that were amazing. one was a fried chicken that I don't see listed on the men. the other was a chicken stir fry that was one of my favorites that I don't see listed on the online menu. Either way, I literally enjoyed every single dish we ordered and we had a wonderful variety of plates. 

Definitely tailored to the western palate which is why it's notorious for a line up of hipsters, but I cannot hate. Not even a little. 

Quirky spot with an over stimulating atmosphere and the food is simply delicious.

tip: reservations are not honored appropriately, so come here with patience and time even with a rezzie.
author: Priti K.

description:
don't care what they say
don't listen to the haters
I'm giving this five

wait long, food is fast
true to my ABC taste
true fusion Chinese
author: Angela W.

description: I've been to this restaurant several times, and I just gotta say that the food is GREAT.  Like really great.  I'm a major fan of the tingly mapo tofu and the kimchi.  The tingly sensation makes you crave the physical sensation of the mapo tofu and not just the taste.  The kimchi is a non-traditional take on a classic dish that has an interesting macadamia flavor to it.  I recommend taking advantage of their reservation system to avoid the line.
author: Lisa F.

description: I eat Mission Chinese almost twice a month. It's the best reward after a long week! Thrice cooked bacon is as good as it sounds. It's rich in fatty goodness and absolutely divine to pair with the Ma Pao Tofu. I get the vegan version because the bacon balances out the spicy tofu flavors. I've tried other things on the menu but honestly I always come back to those two things. Pork belly is ok. Eel is ok. Three crew cooked bacon and Ma Pao Tofu are perfect together.
author: Joshua G.

description:
My friends love Mission Chinese and I can see why--it throws you for a surprise. The food is kickin'. Have a cold? Come here to clear your sinuses, but really the food is on the spicier side. Their fusion menu gives a lot of options. The atmosphere is extremely fun with rap music bounces, colorful lights and a huge parade like dragon overlooking all the hipsters. 

Not the best service. I asked for my food to be takeout as I sat with my friends at the table, gotta get to those SF side hustles. My food was brought out after my friends food was and after I asked about it. The waitress didn't check on the table very often. 

All that being said, want to go to a whole in a wall with some flare, go to Mission Chinese.
author: Laurisha C.

description: I am not sure why this restaurant is so popular? The food was okay, the eggplant was out favorite dish.
author: Kams j.

description: I've been coming here for a while and the Mapo Tofu has progressively become tame in terms of spice level, which I'm guessing is an adjustment based on the vanilla palettes that have moved into the neighborhood. I ordered delivery today and asked for them to make it as spicy as they used to. They did. I'm happy. Good to know that the spice is not dead; just toned-down unless you ask for it.
author: Anna S.

description:
The food was good. If you're looking for authentic Chinese I would say this place is about 3/4 there. We came here on a Friday night around 8 pm and got seated prompted for a table of 2. We ordered the cumin lamb rib and black ink Noodle. Both dishes are a little oily with only the cumin lamb having a slight spicy taste to it. 

I have two complaints. First the menu says cumin lamb rib however our dish was 90% vegetable and about 10% lamb. The lamb just came in small chunks. Not what I imagine for lab rib, but the food still tasted good. My second complaint was the service. Our waiter was rude and seemed like she just didn't care about customer service. When we asked for more water or a to go box she wouldn't respond which was confusing because I had no idea if she heard us. Then she would come to our table, bring whatever we asked and then leave without saying a word. Maybe she was having a rough day but it does put a slight damper to experience. 

The ambience of the place is nice. The music isn't loud to a point where you can't hold conversation. The restaurant is fairly clean and I like the punk artsy feel to it. 

Overall I would recommend this place and would come back!
author: Ann T.

description: Absolutely worth every minute of the hour wait. Unbelievable decadent, and for such reasonable prices, if the wait really bothers you that much go grab a drink at one of the many bars around and then enjoy your meal even more.
author: Anthony F.

description: They tried to overcharge us and included the tip in the "pre-tip amount", to charge us an extra $60. Not cool and very overtly unethical. Also, food was below average.
author: Bob G.

description:
Ahhh I'm not sure why people are giving this place 3 stars. My experience was great and I can't wait to return. A friend and I met there at 6:00pm on a Thursday and were seated right away. 

The tiger salad was bomb--salty, tangy, sweet, crunchy, herbaceous, refreshing, not too filling. This is a great way to start the meal. The presentation is impressive. 

The beef brisket and broccoli totally shattered my expectations for what beef and broccoli should be. I thought I was ordering the most boring thing on the menu, but it turned out to be one of the best things I've ever eaten. The brisket totally melted in my mouth. The broccoli was nice and crunchy. The sauce tied it all together into a smokey, salty dish that I would absolutely order again. 

My friend's eggplant was velvety and delicious. This is always one of my favorite things to order at Chinese restaurants. 

Oh, AND all of this food came out within 5 minutes of ordering. I will be back.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Hey! It's been a long time I was trying to convince my gf to go have a dinner at Mission Chinese, because I'm a big fan of Danny Bowien and followed his cooking adventures on VICE. So, finally, last weekend we came to visit you guys and I was tuned for best. 

First dish we got was westlake lamb dumplings. Should say we both enjoyed the crispiness of it and that wonderful sauce it came with. Cool. I'd try that again, but will I ever get back?

Then suddenly pork ma po tofu and kung pao pastrami came suspiciously fast! Do you guys cook it in advance? Well, anyways, main point is it's taste. Tofu thing was, oh... Spicy? Minty? Whatever that was, felt like somebody just dropped the whole jar of spices into the bowl and was too lazy to re-cook it afterwards. 

Unfortunately, pastrami was exact same story. I personally love salty foods, but it was too much. Salty AF. Like, so salty that I had a pain expression on my face while eating it. We actually took it to go and mixed up with a bunch of rice at home, which barely made it less salty.  

Damn. I think it was THE WORST restaurant experience in my life. It was traumatizing :(
author: Alexander S.

description: Delicious food but the worst service. All the waitresses were rude and did not check on our table once.
author: Allie G.

description:
Wow. Where do I even start with Mission Chinese. A weird, funky Chinese - American fusion restaurant situated in the heart of the mission. Tacky and vibrant decor, a small cramped feel that makes eating alongside your neighbor even that much more intimate. 

Everything is good. My favorite dish is the bacon rice cake things, but I usually order it without bacon and just eat the chewy little rice cakes. The squid ink noodles are also unreal. 

There's always a line and it's always worth it to wait. If you're in the mission and want dinner, go.
author: Alexander C.

description:
Too salty.

You'll see that in a lot of reviews and it's true.  I like well seasoned food but any more salt and I couldn't have eaten it at all. 

This place has TONS of potential but they need to chill on the shaker.
author: Matt P.

description:
It's a very interesting spot. The decor is great and the constant hip-hop is a great choice (and an unfortunate rarity in SF.) The food is probably a four out of five.

What really pulls them down is the service. Both the hostess and our waitress were curt and seemingly annoyed that we were there. Some restaurants give off that cool nonchalance that comes from being phenomenal, but if that is what they were going for, they struck out hard. Rather than blasé indifference, the staff came exuded more of a pretentious hipsterism. 

Unfortunately, in a city like SF, they weren't nearly as cool or the food outstanding enough to pull it off.
author: Chris M.

description:
My love affair with Mission Chinese Food has only slightly declined, since I last dined and raved about it a little more than a year ago. We made the clever decision of ordering take-out before a night out with some friends (since there's no way I'm waiting in line for any amount of time on a perfectly good Friday night).

OUR ORDER.
~ WESTLAKE LAMB DUMPLINGS (~5 for $9)
+ CHONQING CHICKEN WINGS (~8 for $12)
- MAPO TOFU ($15 for a bland tub of tofu and pork)
+ KUNG PAO PASTRAMI (still worth the $16)
~ MATCHA & GINGER SCALLION SQUID NOODLES ($15 for a small, very subtly flavored serving)

Ultimately, I can't stomach such high prices for such small portions - even with the quality provided, it stings to pay $80 for 5 small dishes that ranged from outstanding to mediocre. Stick with your favorite menu items, I guess,  if you continue to dine here.
author: Claire S.

description:
The Danny Bowien restaurants all get some universal "meh" ratings on Yelp but I'm a fan of the original Mission Chinese. Sometimes the food is an exercise in peppercorn tolerance rather than taste but for the most part I appreciate their flavorful and unique takes on traditional Chinese dishes.

First off, I love the interior of this place. It's divey, dark and moody instead of ultra brightly lit like many Chinese places, and if you're like me this makes a big impact on whether or not your truly enjoy sitting down for a meal. Yes, a standard like Z&Y is really good and perhaps more authentic but I don't really want to hang out in that dump for more than the time required to order and eat. This said, even though the space is more enjoyable at Mission Chinese you're likely going to feel some pressure to get out because it's often pretty busy (especially during the weekends!)

I've enjoyed most of what I've had on the menu. There are a few things that sound better than they are: the Kung Pao pastrami is so salty you'll think they brined it for a month out in the Pacific Ocean, and the Salt Cod Fried Rice was a little too subtle for my tastes to warrant an order in the future. But man, the Mapo Tofu is worth every drop of sweat you'll produce wolfing down what is perhaps one of the best, most flavorful versions of the classic Szechuan dish. Speaking of over-the-top numbing, the Thrice Cooked Bacon & Rice cakes can occasionally be a bit painful and no amount of the delicious, sugary cakes will counter balance the effect - but it's worth it.

This is also some of the best takeout in the city as they offer their own delivery to most of the city and the prices are pretty cheap (2-4 bucks for most places), especially if you consider the same delivery would cost you 4x from Postmates.

Some of your friends are going to roll their eyes at you when you say you want to eat here. Tell them to go get some avocado toast and shut up cuz Mission Chinese is delicious!
author: Matt M.

description: Best Chinese food I've had in a long time. We got there early so luckily it wasn't a long wait, but could see a line forming outside as we left.
author: Pippa T.

description:
Way too overrated, rude servers and the place were so filthy. 
Every time when I pass by I see a long line outside so I was so exited to try out this place. So last friday I literally dragged my bf to have lunch here. We arrived and our waitress was so rude I felt like she didn't want to be there at all. Made me feel like I had to please her in order for me to feed my stomach. 
Food was mediocre nothing special or less. 

Note: I drafted this review long time ago maybe 5-6 years ago perhaps. Been sitting there and waiting for me to finish up and post.
author: Namuna B.

description: Surprisingly bad food.  Everything was over salted by approx 300%.  I couldn't taste anything but salt.  We ordered 5 dishes. Seasonal greens, Mongolian long beans, chicken wings, squid ink noodles and matcha lemon noodles.  Only the greens and chicken wings were ok.  The other dishes had so much salt, it was unbearable.  I really wanted to like this place, but unfortunately, I walked away very disappointed.
author: Frank M.

description:
I can honestly say that this was the most unexpected environment I have ever encountered for a Chinese food place. And I say that in the best possible way. I am not from San Francisco, so maybe it is because I am not a local that this all seemed so amazing to me, but when I walked in the first thing I noticed was the house music playing in the background. The wait staff were all young 20-somethings who had pretty amazing, alternative style. This is not typical to the Chinese food places back home. The décor was awe inspiring and the food was absolutely delicious!!!

The only reason it loses a star for me, and again this could be related to the fact that I don't live in San Fran and don't experience their prices either, is that it was extremely expensive. For spring rolls, noodles, and dumplings with tea and a beer we paid $50. However, the food was absolutely amazing, just a tad expensive for me.
author: Emily R.

description: Dankest Chinese place in town. It's not traditional, it's not Szechuan, its dank. If you like dank food go here.
author: Sai M.

description: A group of four of us came here and got the squid ink noddles, thrice cooked bacon rice cakes, salt cod fried rice, and the Taiwanese eggplant. All of it was really good. This is a cool divey spot, but we were super rushed so I wouldn't get a bottle of wine or anything that you may not be done with when you are finished eating.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Finding this was an adventure in itself. With no mention of "Mission Chinese" on the outside, this somewhat kitschy restaurant did not at all resemble the legendary Chinese restaurant everyone raves about. My party arrived around 1pm on a Sunday afternoon, and there was surprisingly no line. In fact, there were only two other groups in the restaurant, so our meal arrived quickly.

When it comes to authenticity, I'd say the food here falls right in between authentic Chinese food and Americanized versions like Panda Express. The mapo tofu we ordered tasted pretty similar to the real thing you'd find in China, but the kung pao pastrami, on the other hand, was a unique dish with true Asian flavors but foreign ingredients. Many items on the menu are labeled spicy, but the spice levels were not at all bad. As someone with a relatively low tolerance, I was still able to enjoy every dish. I also tried the salted cod fried rice, which was good, but very similar to something I could just make at home myself. The few pieces of cod were delicious, but it definitely takes some digging to find them. For me, the star of the show was the pork belly. While paying $15 for two chunks of meat isn't what I normally consider to be a great deal, it was well worth it. The adorable tiki-fashioned dish tastes as good as it looks-- the meat is juicy, tender, and bursting with flavor!

Altogether, the meal was enjoyable and I had a lot of fun trying these creative fusion dishes. Very impressed by how they took all these dishes in a new direction while still maintaining the traditional flavors of Chinese cooking!
author: Amy C.

description: Best bang for your buck in the city probably. Freakin delicious. Get the beef broccoli.
author: Alex P.

description: The food here is kind of mind bending. The Ma Po Tofu is one of the best things in the world. It tastes like nothing else. It is layer upon layer of flavor and it haunts me because I have never had anything like it. Family style is a must so you can try as many different dishes as you can.
author: Dylan K.

description:
I reluctantly tried Mission Chinese again. I have to say, this time was much better. 

Friends ordered take out for a cozy night in. Dishes were still very bold and flavorful, but a much better experience than the initial meal. 

Dishes include:

Lamb larb
Spicy rice cakes
Wings with pink peppercorn
Salted fish fried rice
Long beans 
Squid ink noodles, ginger scallion sauce. 

Every dish had a spicy kick, paired well with lots of Syrah. Our meal convinced me to add another star. 

Not your typical Chinese take out.
author: Sonya T.

description: First off, the food was closer to four stars. However, the service was really off-putting. First, the host outside snapped at us to stand back from him when we were trying to let him know we were there for our reservation. Then, our waitress was pretty much non-existent throughout the meal. The cherry on top was that she brought us a water pitcher to use. It sat on our table for probably ten minutes while we paid the check. Before we left, she came back, picked it up and set it down on a table a few tables away. Ick! Do they really need to reuse a pitcher that's already been given out to one table? That combined with a 72 health rating and their NYC location being closed by the Health Department, I think I'll  pass.
author: Amanda S.

description: I personally really enjoyed my meal and experience at Mission Chinese. Great, down and dirty Chinese in unassuming setting. Feels Cali, feels sodium filled, and feels very satisfying. Service can be better, but fits chill atmosphere. Have realistic expectations and go for experience not for amazing asian cuisine.
author: Alex R.

description:
*BEST CHOW MEIN EVER* 
This is the chow mein I mentioned in my other review where I had the best fajita ever. Check out my profile and other reviews to find out where I got that fajita.

Now for the real review:

There are different aspects to Mission Chinese Food (or really Lung Shan Restaurant) that I do and don't like. But, overall, I would definitely recommend coming here. One aspect of this place I did not like was how cramped it was. There really was not much space in the restaurant and some people had to even sit at a communal table. The restaurant was also very loud which may not be so annoying to you but was to me. Additionally, the neighborhood isn't exactly pretty if that is important to the enjoyment or relaxation of your meal. But despite these non ideal aspects to Lung Shan Restaurant, I still give it 5 stars . This is because of the incredibly delicious food it serves. The chow mein I ordered was the best plate of Chinese food I had ever had. The flavors released by the chemical bonds of the splendid chow mein noodles were pure and righteous. As you can tell, I thoroughly enjoyed the chow mein. In conclusion, despite its small size and high noise level, I would definitely recommend coming to Lung Shan Restaurant for its impeccable food.
author: Daniel S.

description:
My 8th visit made me fall in love with Mission Chinese all over again. Initially, you're wowed and overwhelmed by the bumping music, red strobing lights, and rowdy atmosphere. Later, when you can bring your attention to the food, you are blown away by the aggressively delicious combinations of flavours. 

I am consistently impressed by the black vinegar peanuts, lamb ribs (gigantic, with onions and sauce and texas toast, which hold up perfectly well as leftovers reheated on a pan), and kung pao pastrami.
author: Wiley W.

description: This restaurant is great, very good Chinese food. The broccoli beef is excellent!  My wife is Chinese and she approves, only negative is the long lines
author: Jerry W.

description: If you don't lose your appetite walking through the trash on the streets or the smell of wet dog in the restaurant, you might enjoy the food. Especially if you like salt.  If you are looking for that authentic grunge of an old Chinese restaurant you'll love the peeling paint, chipped tables, efficient if not friendly service, and waking through the kitchen to get to the bathroom. The food is inventive and interesting. Some of the portions (like the long beans) are gigantic while others (like the lamb dumplings and the wine) are pretty small. Everything is pretty greasy. Lamb dumplings were very good. Kung pao pastrami was so salty it was almost inedible. Beef chow mein was pretty good. Smashed cucumbers were fresh and tasty. Family enjoyed fried chicken that I didn't try. Bacon and rice cake dish was pretty good. Long beans were good but just huge plate. Would like to give 2.5 stars but cannot so I would say that it's certainly an adventure not for the faint of heart.
author: Jocelyn H.

description: Food is good but I don't think I'm going to go here again because of the poor service. Some of the servers at the restaurant are really rude. They act like like they're doing customers a huge favor by serving them food. I do like the food here so I only get takeout from Mission Chinese instead of going to the restaurant in person.
author: Anupama S.

description:
Finally tried this for the first time today. Had my expectations lowered since it opened years ago and the hype seemed to have died, also bc the chef is over at the new restaurant in NYC now. 

Walked in and it's like I walked into a Chinese American Horror movie set. The dragon hanging overhead was cool, but the red orange dimly lit setting made it a big dingy and scary. You could see the age of the place as the lanterns and dragon was covered in dust and colors were faded.

Food- between the four of us: KUNG pao pastrami- super salty and dry, flavors are all over the place, too heavy on peppercorns, least of my favorite dish today. MATCHA ginger scallion noodles- favorite dish today, noodles are squid ink and cooked al dente, with nice balanced flavors of ginger, scallions, and a tiniest bit sweet. CHINESE bento with mapo tofu- mapo tofu was okay, the mala (numbing spiciness) was at a good level. CHONGQING chicken wings- pretty good, fried crispy and the meat was moist, spicy and numbing. 

Service/Staff- very good service from our waiter who took our orders correctly and was attentive. Brought us two pitchers of water and didn't rush us to pay the bill. There was an older female staff whom he called 'grandma' who helped set the tables and didn't smile at all, sat behind us and blasted her iPad with mandarin soap opera. Interesting. 

I would not wait more than 20 minutes for food here. I was pleasantly impressed by the noodles, so may come back to try other noodles. Price is not cheap, noodles were $14 and the Kung pao pastrami was $16, which I wouldn't pay $5 for (we left half the plate uneaten). Be prepared for high sodium and loads of msg. Restroom is in the way way back. As I walked to it, I passed by the kitchen and several staff who were working. Interesting mixture of staff. It was an interesting experience.
author: Iris H.

description:
My friend and I were meeting up after not seeing each other in months. We wanted to make it an epic night, and boy, was it! We had put our names on a list at another restaurant, and were walking around to possibly find something sooner. My friend asked me, "Have you ever been to Mission Chinese?" I told her that I hadn't, and have always wanted to, but I JUST had Chinese food yesterday. "This isn't Chinese food," she said. I decided to take her word for it, and now I know exactly what she meant. Mission Chinese is an experience that everyone should have, more than once. The seating is mostly communal, the ceilings house flying dragons, and the music and light combination create a legit yay area vibe, yadidamean?
We ordered some beers and Tiger Salad to start. The food here is an art, crafted for your eyes and mouth to water. The Tiger Salad reminded me of some sea creatures that would dance along with Ariel underwater. Tasty, fresh, simply phenomenal.  Also, we ordered the Garlic Rice, Vegetarian Thrice Cooked Bacon, and Eggplant. Party in my mouth good! 
We were also graced with a complimentary bottle of sake from some generous sake angel. Our waitress, Stephanie, was super sweet and knew how to throw down some dance moves as she moved between tables.  
My first experience here was definitely a wild ride that I'll be ridding again.
author: Alicia F.

description:
Food = good. Glad I finally went here with a friend. 

Chongqing chicken wings = dry wings (outside, not inside), moist meat, and salty. Numbing spice. $11.00

Tiki pork belly = melts in your mouth, slightly sweet, and addicting. We probably would have ordered another order if we didn't have everything else... This was one of our favorite items! $14.00

Pork ma po tofu = the best version ever, smokey, numbing spicy, and full of flavor. I love that it isn't sweet. Just so many layers of flavor.  Worth it. $15.00

Westlake rice porridge (dungeness crab, medium rare brisket, egg, cilantro) = good. But not my favorite, because it was too salty for me. $14.00

Salt cod fried rice (mackerel confit, chinese sausage, lettuce, egg) = fluffy fried rice with a great combination of flavors, and perfect to balance out the ma po tofu dish. $13.00 

Service = friendly, efficient.

Prices = moderate. Dinner for two with leftovers came out to under $70. 

Note: It's quite red in here...red lights and noisy, so if you're looking for an intimate setting, go somewhere else. We didn't mind. Oh, and they do accept reservations!
author: Fannie S.

description: One star for their horrid useless website. Why go to the trouble of creating your own site and then not put some of the most important information on it. Like your friggin hours and what friggin days you're open for friggin lunch.
author: Ben D.

description:
This place is Szechuan-Korean fusion. Let's start with that: if you don't like or understand those cuisines then you won't understand Mission Chinese! It literally all begins and ends with that...

Now if you enjoy those flavors and textures, you will really enjoy this restaurant. It's inside decor is a play on regular Americanized Chinese restaurant you'd find in any town USA suburbs and their signature cocktail is served in a plastic cup... it's all in good fun. 

Every dish I've had here I've enjoyed and returned for more. I highly recommend this place if you like spicy fusion cuisine.
author: Steve B.

description:
Ah, Mission Chinese. TFW something hyped is just as good as its reputation, if not better. Even takeout, people. That is one thing I love about cities. High quality food delivered to one's door is surely a civilized luxury.

The Sichuan green beans were superb. Perfectly spiced, cooked at high heat to blister and get a bit smoky...tender but with some snap. The cumin lamb could have been a bit more plentiful, but it was exquisite. Depth of flavor layered on top of great quality lamb chunks. Covered with fresh cilantro. Oh, but the standout, the standout dish was the chicken fat, ginger, and garlic fried rice. Let's talk about umami, friends. It has it. It's just delightful, essentially. Tiny crunchy bits of garlic and bites of bracing ginger with the umami chicken fat all permeating the glorious rice...yes. 

This is food.

This is living.
author: Janara N.

description: One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in SF! Try the mapotofu, delish. Also, cool environment with great dj inside.
author: Peter P.

description: Well, this what happened.. we came, we were so excited, we both work at one of the top 100 restaurants in the city and have not been more blown away by the lack of service---real bad.
author: Sarah B.

description:
This might be my favorite restaurant.  I always take friends who are visiting from out of town here, and it never disappoints.  It is also one of my go-to place with friends who are NOT visiting from out of town, because we all love it that much.  I will say that some of the items on the menu are just slightly-higher quality things you could get at any other Chinese restaurant in the city, so if you make the mistake of ordering these items then you won't get the awesome experience that is Mission Chinese Food and you will be disappointed.

Delicious amazing things to order that are on the current menu:

Tiger Salad- subtle flavor, but delicious, and a lot of fun to eat
Pork Ma-po Tofu
Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes
Westlake Lamb Dumplings

The menu changes from time to time, which means there are always more delicious amazing things to try! Thank you Mission Chinese Food for being so awesome!!!
author: Emma A.

description: Mission Chinese Food is a legacy on Mission. Fantastic food, love the Tsing Tao beer, restaurant interior feelings are "COOL", service is OK, approx 25 per person without drinks, very good value, worth a try. [Mark Sun Review]
author: Mark S.

description:
Finally got a chance to eat at the legendary Mission Chinese. The traditional divey chinese place is still intact, with some faint lighting and the music blasting. It's quite an experience to walk in. The staff was fun and on point - protip: they take reservations. This place has mastered the art of the sichuan peppercorn and much, much, more.

Top 5 dishes from our dinner (in order):
* Chongqing Chicken Wings - spicy, lightly fried chicken wings with a slight numbing effect sprinkled with delicious beef tripe
* Stir-fried squid ink noodles - this dish was def on the Italian side of things - but off the rails
* General Tso's Veal Rib - spit roasted for extra skin/char pleasure... Yum.
* Kung Pao Pastrami - brilliant combination - I wish the pastrami was a little more tender, but yummy.
* Bacon & Rice cakes - due to some vegetarians floating around in our group, we had to go sans bacon, but I'm imagining how good these would be with bacon. 

Oh, they have some beers there, but BYOB also available.

Be sure to get an MSG shaker for your table. 'mo MSG, 'mo flavor
author: Billy D.

description:
I had heard so much about this spot that I was starting to feel like a bad local for not having tried it. Not that I need my food to be trendy - I mean that I like supporting local institutions.

Mission Chinese has been around for ages and built quite a reputation. Though I didn't try some its more unusual and well known dishes, the fried chicken was fantastic, served over rice with a bowl of spicy dipping vinegar. The rice porridge with sausage, crab, and egg was also wonderful - very comforting and satisfying.
author: Chris M.

description: It's true, everything you've heard about this establishment is true. If you have enough people, DEFINITELY do the buffet thing where they just bring you way more dishes than you need of stuff you wouldn't have ordered and it blows your heckin mind. Leftovers so sweet and saucy it brings you back the following week. Wonderful gem, will return soon.
author: Ryan B.

description: Got the mapo tofu and the salt cod fried rice. Both were amazing. Mapo tofu had the perfect amount of tingly / numbing Szechuan pepper in the sauce but the star of my meal was really the fried rice. The salt cod lends this kinda funky, umami flavor to the dish that really elevates it well above any fried rice dish I've ever tasted. Definitely try it!
author: Ailien V.

description: Went here for lunch with partner yesterday and overall enjoyed the food.  I had the lunch bento with the spicy chicken, vinegar peanuts, crushed cucumber and salad wrap.  Lots of food and tasty.  Partner had the porridge which was yummy.  Least favorite dish was the green beans.  They were very bland and not exciting.  Server was detached and not friendly but I would try them again and recommend!
author: D. C.

description: Squid ink papparedelle was amazing with lamb that was braised and melted. Highly recommend this place for a date
author: S. L.

description: Always love this place. But have to give extra thanks bc in a mixup (that was 100% my fault), I thought I had ordered delivery and actually had done takeout. After I realized my mistake and called, they immediately offered to deliver and were super fast too. Food is always killer and surprising, and the location is badass but extra service they gave definitely puts them over.
author: Max R.

description:
The food here is fantastic but the service is what docks it a star. We had a young male waiter that was quite possibly the rudest waiter I've had in awhile. 

What we ordered:
- salt cod fried rice: 6/5 (loved the added dried baby shrimp - def someone Asian working in the back of the house)
- thrice cooked pork: 5/5 (loved the added bitter melon and fermented tofu, would be better if there was more meat. They do this one vegetarian too.)
- Mongolian long beans: 4/5 (too salty, but still good!)

I'll come back but I'll request a different waiter. I'm doing you guys a favor I'll tip one of the other waiters more.
author: Lucy W.

description:
My favorite restaurant find in San Francisco so far! (Apart from some service issues) 
They have an amazingly diverse and unique Chinese menu, with new takes on Chinese favorites that I've never even imagined. I used to be a chef, and I've never had pork belly more perfectly cooked and seasoned anywhere. The Kung Pao pastrami was delicious, smoky, full of flavor, and enough to share and take home. I love the variety of small plates and nibbles. The restaurant atmosphere is extremely laid back and non-fussy, making it a go-to after a long day at Dolores Park when you don't feel like getting dressed up to go out. The prices are very reasonable for the portion sizes in San Francisco. The staff was quick and accurate, but definitely did lack in politeness. The host initially refused our request for one of many slightly larger tables, which we asked because my friend is very tall and couldn't fit at the tiny one they gave us, but he then sat well-dressed couple at the table we had asked for. And the waitress was not friendly and kinda slammed our entrees down and hurried away without a word. My friend and I are both in the service industry and are great tippers, even though we look sorta "edgy." Hopefully next time they will treat us like the other customers. Otherwise, utterly incredible and delicious, and will be back many times!
author: Jessica H.

description:
This is not your authentic Chinese restaurant but the dishes are really creative. There was no wait for an early dinner on a weekend. The place was dimly lit with loud rap music playing. The service was friendly and attentive.

I really liked the westlake rice porridge ($13) with brisket and egg. Nice spin on your traditional congee. The taiwanese eggplant with basil and garlic ($13) was my favorite. It was super flavorful and the sauce was delicious. The pork ma po tofu ($15) and chicken wings ($11) were both too spicy for me to finish but the rest of my group loved it.

Overall I would definitely come back here to try the other items on their menu. Everything looked so unique!
author: Linda X.

description: I went here recently (this past weekend) and I was disappointed that the quality of my favorite dishes had gotten bad.  It also seems like they're cutting back on ingredients.  In my last review, I raved about how great their salt cod fried rice was; however, this time around, it lacked the saltiness and flavor that came from the bits of salt cod that was supposed to be in the dish but for some reason, were absent.  As for the chicken wings, I remember them serving bigger portions of the wings with definitely more peppers.  This time, there were less wings and less peppers.  Therefore, I can't help but give Mission Chinese one less star.
author: Anne D.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE Mission Chinese! On my visit to San Francisco, I could not wait to eat here, and it did not disappoint. The food is wonderful (try the pastrami and the porridge). They have a great sake selection, along with beer and wine. I loved the ambiance (lights everywhere, rap music blasting) so if you're looking for a quiet place, this might not be your spot.

I will say I made a reservation the night I went, and we still had to wait about 20 minutes. However, the staff/manager was super-apologetic and frankly, it was worth the wait!
author: M G.

description:
One of the best things about Chinese food is that it is good and cheap.  Unfortunately, I didn't think Mission Chinese Food lived up to those two things.  It was pricey for Chinese food, and maybe I didn't order the right things but what I got was just okay, not worth the price IMO.  

Salt cod fried rice- they're really known for this.  It wasn't salty like I expected and I didn't care much for it.
Westlake rice porridge- I usually am down for basics and blands, but this was missing something too
Taiwanese eggplant-  I liked this.  Straight forward and what I expected.  

I would say this food is catered to a more Americanized taste of Chinese food, but not in a Panda Express way.  I really want to like the food here because of the rave reviews and recs, but maybe next time I'll need to get something less pescatarian.
author: Lyn C.

description: The thrice cooked bacon rice cakes were by far our favorite thing on the menu! For vegetarians, you can get the bacon on the side. The long beans were also incredible. Highly recommend this place.
author: Jenna B.

description: This place is solid, but a bit overpriced for the quality. I still eat at Mission Chinese Food regularly but it's not exceptional. They have very efficient carry out and do their own delivery that we've been really happy with.
author: Kyle W.

description: My go to for chinese food. I love getting the tingly mapo tofu , or broccoli brisket. So good.
author: April C.

description:
Szechuan food with a twist. The popular dishes seem to be the pork belly, the ribs with coca cola, 3x cooked bacon, the kung pao pastrami, and the cod fried rice. We got the pastrami as well as Mongolian Long Beans (四季豆). 

It's been awhile since I've had such good long beans - they were not too thin and not too salty - really well seasoned!

The pastrami was great at the beginning, but I started to feel my pores dying because the dish was drenched in oil and spicy seasoning.  I'm sure I'd love it more if I was extremely drunk. 

Overall, I was satisfied with the food. The portions are huge so we took away the unfinished food.

The restaurant reeks of a consistent oily smell (reminds me of stir fried beef or something) so it felt kind of dirty in a way. The music choice is interesting, but it wasn't unbearable nor was it too loud. The darkness with the red lighting during dinner hours reminded me of Fang in SoMa, though it was definitely bright enough to see my food and the people around me. I am guessing the ambience is very different during daytime hours. It's definitely not a good place to have a family dinner, but great for a group of friends. 

Service was decent and we had no issues with our waiter. The wait for a group of 2 was about 15m on a Sunday night (before Labor Day), which wasn't bad. I definitely wouldn't come here too often simply because of the high salt content of most dishes, though I'd come back to try the less spicy/salty dishes.
author: Elisa L.

description: Delicious! And so spicy. Usually a long wait, though. Try lunch or takeout if you don't want to wait. Thrice cooked tofu is the best dish on the menu, but it's all good.
author: Jacob H.

description:
Every time I come to San Fran, this is my first food stop. I love it!! It's not your traditional "Chinese fare" but that shouldn't stop you from trying it out. Highly recommend the mapo tofu (spicy AND salty), the cod fried rice, the thrice cooked bacon (the rice cakes in the dish are everything!!!) and the Mongolian beans. I enjoyed the kung pao pastrami, though I found that to be the saltiest of the dishes. 

Bottom line, MUST TRY!
author: R S.

description:
Ordered Lamb dumplings (quite good), Tiger salad (ridiculously plated and tasteless), Ma Po Tofu (poor, the one I had when the original LES in NY was much better), salt cod fried rice (horrible, cold rice, fishy, and no other flavors), Gai lan with peperoncino and parmesan (best dish), and General Tso's Veal Rib (Horribly sweet and bland).

3 minutes after we ordered the rice and salad came out, 5 minutes later the dumplings came out, then the tofu and the gai lan,  and 20 minutes later the veal rib (and the rice was cold).  

Very unimpressive.....(for all the hype).  Now I appreciate the American-Chinese I go to when I visit my parents in Maryland.
author: Jonathan L.

description: They can't understand English over the phone. I wanted to order Vegetable Chowmein but no luck.
author: Sameer T.

description:
(walking towards the restaurant) This isn't Mission Chinese Food.  The sign doesn't say Mission Chinese Food.  We are not at Mission Chinese Food.  Mission Chinese Food must be on the other side.  (see's a small paper sign that says Mission Chinese Food) Oh, this IS Mission Chinese Food. If the Dude has eaten here before and is certain that this is Mission Chinese Food, don't doubt him.

Tiki Pork Belly - PORK BELLY ORGASM. Now I know how Sally felt...  This dish comes with 2 pork belly so I would recommend ordering your own plate =P
Sichuan Pickles - not too spicy but still good.  I really enjoyed it with the peanuts

Will definitely come back to try the other dishes.
author: Linda N.

description: I ordered to go so I'm not sure how the in house experience is but I ordered the West Lake lamb dumplings, the Taiwanese eggplant and the Lung Shan Mushroom Chow Mein and it was all excellent and ready to go when I got there. So my service was prompt and ready to go and the cuisine was sublime. I ordered around 8:45 on a Thursday evening with no problem at all. My bill was around $36 including tax plus a $7 tip so $43 total. Go for it! It's so yummy!!
author: Hillary E.

description:
Fast service, untraditional cuisine, and Chinese dragon vibes.

We loved the lamb dumplings as it was a flavor was something we've never experience before. Imagine a fried wonton, stuffed with lamb, and greek tzatziki sauce. Yea, we were thinking the same thing, weird, but somehow delicious.

We also had the twice cooked bacon and rice cakes because it was mentioned in so many reviews. It was so unhealthy, that I probably wouldn't order it again, but nice to try something new.
author: Tabitha S.

description: Intrigued by the long line I saw the previous evening, I decided to take my girlfriend to see what the place was all about.  After a few bad customer experiences with other Chinese restaurant I was a bit hesitant, but before entering some customers walked in with us explaining how good the food was here. The door was a bit tricky to open, gotta put a little bit of force with it. Once inside the decor wasn't your standard Chinese design. There was a Micheal Jordan human size poster on the ceiling, a customary dragon custom that hung from the entrance to the back. We were pleasantly greeted and sat down right away. The food wasn't your typical Chinese menu. The waiter was friendly and went on and explained the menu with us (although it was pretty straight forward). We went with the pork belly and the Filipino fried chicken. And both were absolutely great! Some people might disagree, but I think this had the best Filipino fried chicken! We will be back to this place again!
author: yoyo v.

description:
Mission Chinese Food must suffer from a serious case of identity crisis... because its name is. not. actually. mission. chinese. food. The deception runs deep - I have been hearing about this generically named Mission Chinese Food from my roommates to my coworkers for quite some time and yet failed to realize this was the same Lung Shan Restaurant I walked past EVERY DAY to work, for the past EIGHT months. This split personality disorder is so entrenched that it goes as far as breaking off into two different Yelp listings, each with its own set of reviews. 

Walking into Mission Chinese is but a continuation of its confused identity. Am I here to eat or am I here to party? This was the reverberating question for the rest of my evening as I walked into the red-lit room with flashing disco lights and amped up party music. Trying to order food with my friends was akin to shouting conversation at the person sitting a foot across from you at a bar. The lights cast every dish in an unnaturally neon pink hue - instant filter for all you foodie instagrammers, whether you like it or not.

Despite the bizarre ambiance, Mission Chinese does have surprisingly authentic and great Chinese food:

* Mapo Tofu - If you aren't ordering their most famous dish, why are you even here?
* Chonqing Chicken Wings - Delicious for the first 5 bites. After that, expect to permanently lose all feeling of your tongue.
* Smashed Cucumber - This refreshing dish can slightly alleviate the above situation and downgrade you to semi-permanent numbness. Until you inevitably take another bite of the wings. Repeat vicious cycle.
* Westlake Rice Porridge - Have always loved this dish although I'm not quite sure I like the rare-steak variation they've added. Questionable meat that I can't really identify under the pink lights aside, this was a solid choice.
author: Jenni H.

description:
Eh. I'm giving this 2.5 stars, rounded to 3, for the lower-than-average food.  I came with a buddy close to closing time, so the rushed service was understandable but still poor. We got the wings, kung pao pastrami, green beans, and white rice. The wings were hot, but dry and lacking that juicy flavor I come to expect (high standards in SF). The kung pao pastrami was the worst dish; the salt overpowered the flavor. Pastrami itself is already cured and salty, so the added salt clearly destroyed the dish. The white rice was good and helped drown out the salt, along with some water. The green beans were good, and pull the rating from 2 to 3 stars. They were well-cut and flavorful. The ambiance was cool, yet the dishes left something to be desired in a city with high standards for Chinese food.

TL;DR: average SF-Chinese food, poor service, cool atmosphere
author: Jonathan C.

description: This place was on food network so we wanted to try it. Outside looks like a dump, inside looks like a garage sale. The menu looks like every other Chinese food restaurant, except they added something to each dish. The things they added don't normally go Chinese. Wasn't really impressed but decided to give it a try. What a mistake! The male waiter walked up to the table with a bad attitude, almost like he's so busy he's overwhelmed, there was six people in the entire place. Then we asked about an item on the menu and started to ask and he said "are you going to let me finish". I left money for my drinks and left! Bad!!
author: Scott D.

description:
TL;DR: Interesting food, interesting atmosphere, loud, overpriced.

I and a couple of my friends found ourselves in San Francisco and decided to ask another friend who lived nearby if there are any good places to eat around there. We agreed we would go to Mission Chinese, a recommendation from his brother. When I first saw the place, I was confused as to why the sign doesn't say "Mission Chinese Food" but "Lung Shan Restaurant." And then I saw the sticker with the Mission Chinese Food rickshaw on the window of the restaurant and felt that it was oddly familiar...

Okay, so this place's twin sister in New York was featured in Anthony Bourdain's show "The Layover." I immediately got excited because I adore Anthony Bourdain and have so far loved everything he recommended. This place is... very different. There is a huge Chinese paper dragon that hangs on the ceiling throughout the place while EDM-y music blasts away. The place was mostly dark with a lot of red-ish LEDs and green laser lights, so if your concealer isn't working to cover up your pimple, don't worry, because nobody will see it in this place. The menu items were weird but I was open to trying something new. The price of the dishes was pretty high up there, but I didn't mind spending it to get a different experience. Or so I thought...

Our party ordered Chongqing Chicken Wings, Kung Pao Pastrami, Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice cakes, and Kung Pao Pastrami Burrito with Cod Fried Rice and Fries (if I'm not mistaken). The portion sizes were not that big for the price - definitely not family-size. Each of the plates are individual-sized and rice is not included in the price. Since the prices were already pretty expensive, we didn't order any sides and only ordered water for drinks. Now for individual dishes...

Let me start with the Kung Pao Pastrami Burrito with Cod Fried Rice and Fries. Yeah, so I thought each of those things would come seaparately - like it's 1 Kung Pao Pastrami Burrito, an 1 Cod Fried Rice, and a bowl of fries. At around ~$13, I thought it was a steal! Nope. EVERYTHING is in ONE burrito. The burrito was okay. I went there 2 weeks ago and already forgot, so not that memorable, but I remember it being okay.

Moving on to the Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes. Very greasy. Very salty. But tasty. Worth the price? At $16, I don't think so. The rice cakes are cut into little disks and the bacon cut into little squares. The bacon was very flavorful while the rice cakes were almost devoid of flavor except for the outside, so it balances the aggressiveness of the bacon flavor. But I felt that something was missing - the rice cakes were too bland. Like eerily bland on the inside. Other than that, it's an okay dish.

Kung Pao Pastrami. $16. Very Salty. It's also pretty good, but bite after bite, the saltiness will overthrow the balance of the taste.

Now moving on to a diamond in the rough for this restaurant and the redeemer of my whole visit. Now, I like spicy food, but anything that will inflame body parts other than my tongue, I'm opposed to. The Chongqing Chicken Wings changed my mind. In the first bite, it was okay. Slightly spicy to the tip of the tongue. But a true feature of an excellent spicy savory food is the build of the spice. Yes, what I meant is that it will get spicier with every bite. This chicken does just that. The salt levels were on point, the sweetness is there, the spice builds to the point where I didn't realize that my mouth was going slightly numb. And the numbing feeling is surprisingly very fitting to the whole experience. It truly is sublime.

Am I glad I went here? Yes. Would I go back here again? Probably not. As good as the chicken wings were, it was a once-in-a-blue-moon experience that is better savored when it's not often repeated. Everything else was meh and talking over the music is hard. I would go somewhere quieter for a hangout next time.
author: Jessica P.

description: This place is the ultimate example of 'food gentrification.' Why put a twist on traditional Chinese? Probably to make it palatable for people who look like they work at Vice. I ordered the infamous Salt Cod Fried Rice -- it wasn't worth it. By no means am I a professional food critic and will admit that I can not dive deep into flavor profiles, but I can tell you if the food is mediocre or good from a general perspective. So generally, this Cod Fried Rice was dry and lacking. I wanted to pick things apart and hoped that some flavors would fade with the next bite. This place is the equivalent of wearing New Balance sneakers with a Valentino suit. It's something amazing tainted by curiosity.
author: Ian B.

description:
Greeting- kind of
Vibe- disgusting
Service- like they were doing me a favor
BR- top ten worst ever. walk through kitchen to alleyway
Parking- street if lucky
Food
Kung pao pastrami $16 is a creative dish. I give them that. The pastrami is excellent. But the dish is served room temp to cold. Why? Not too good because of this. It could have been a contender if hot
-$2 for rice wtf! 
Area is gross. Place is gross. 
WIGB? Not at this point. There are some interesting menu items. But prob over hyped
author: Hungry K.

description:
Excellent: 
the kimchi
ma po pork
salt cod fried rice

Skip:
hamachi collar: it's like 4 bites of fried fish for $18 lol
author: Adam S.

description:
It's always a gamble going to a "popular" place, or an "institution," as Mission is. You really, really want to try the food you've been hearing so much about, but dealing with the waits or the overworked staff or the "get-you-in-and-out" attitude can make it feel a bit un-special.

Thankfully, the food at Mission more than makes up for all those minor inconveniences! It is clean and exotic, unique and fresh. I never thought I'd eat shaved pumpkin at a Chinese restaurant, but I did, and it was good.
author: Valentina V.

description: Super disappointed in this place despite previously being a regular customer. Came in to make a reservation for two and was told by the manager to come back at the time I wanted a table. When I returned with my full party the same manager asks me "do you have a reservation or did you just want to come back?" Then he told me that I had to put in a new reservation and wait in line. Guess I'll have to find a new spot for Chinese food.
author: Doc R.

description: The Line is crazy so plan ahead but the food is worth the wait. Seasoned really well. Some of the dishes don't seem so Chinese like the chicken with potatoes :/ I guess it's just not the Chinese food I'm used to but the taste is darn good though!!!!
author: Hanan A.

description: The food is always good at this small Mission Chinese food restaurant.  I don't give it more stars because its small, dingy and most of the time there's a huge line to get in.  but the food is worth it!
author: Mariaté G.

description:
I was seriously freaking out that there would be a long wait so I got here a little before 5pm, when dinner usually starts.  The restaurant wasn't packed even an hour later at 6pm.  This place has been majorly hyped and it met my expectations.  I've had Sichuan food quite a bit and I'm not a fan of the constant numbing sensation or the Sichuan pepper taste, but I loved the food here!  Everything tasted interesting and not annoyingly fusion.

Tea-smoked eel rolls: Enjoyed the texture of the crispy eel against the supple rice noodles.  A little on the salty side though and I had no idea there was braised pork in it.

Mapo tofu: I never order this dish when I go out but I knew I had to get it here.  It was chunky and saucy.  Even the version without pork was delicious.

Thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes:  My second favorite dish of the night!  It has the same flavor profile as the mapo tofu (spicy, greasy, peppery) but the bittermelon offsets the intenseness.

Mongolian long beans: Even if you're craving vegetables, I would skip this dish.  It won't feel healthier because it's covered in quite a bit of grease and the flavor is intense.

Stir fried squid ink noodles: My FAVORITE dish of the night.  The squid ink noodles pairs perfectly with the lamb chunks.  I don't know how but it just does.  The lamb is so good even on its own.  This dish is a nice balance to the other very spicy and grease-laden dishes.  I overheard other tables say this was their favorite dish as well.

Even though I really enjoyed the food, it's a bit heavy for me.  I feel like I've tried the most popular dishes but if there is a new, must-try dish, I'd consider coming back.  It's a nice place to take out-of-towners because it's likely that they've never had something like this before.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Picasso had his Blue Period.  Matisse went through his time of collage.  I'm currently enjoying my month-long Chinese immersion and how better to do so than a repeat visit to Mission Chinese Food?  

Not many restaurants could serve as litmus tests for the range of human personalities but I'm convinced that if any could, it'd be Mission Chinese.  I'm not certain that I'd like everyone who fell into the camp of "MCF fanatic" but I do think scientists studying the brains of those in that camp would find many similarities.  Perhaps we all have our "flaming hot" receptor turned to "enjoy" which would explain how we can endure 2-fiery-star dishes like Kung Pao Pastrami ($16), Pork Ma Po Tofu ($15), and Mongolian Long Beans ($13) without skipping a beat.  

Nearing the end of this visit one among my party of 3 was physically removing peppers from his plate.  Perhaps he's not one of the tribe but I'm all in.  Call it greasy, oily, overpriced for Chinese food, overly-hyped, whatever; I'm just calling it all - every last bit of it - delicious.  And that includes the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts ($5) and the Pickles ($5) which didn't taste like anything grand upon first bite but were simply divine as a snack the following morning.  This food ages well.  

Prices have risen by $2-$4/item since my previous visit (dinner for 3, pre-tip, ran about $90).  They've added outposts in NYC and LA.  Cookbooks have been issued.  They'll now omit MSG upon request, as a sign in the window attests.  They're still donating a good portion of profits to good causes and they're still producing greatly tasty food.  The lights are dim, the music is loud, the bass is thumping, the lines are long (though reservations are now accepted), servers practically throw the food on your table as they pass by, and the place is somewhat of a dump but everything - every last thing here - is still working. 

As you read this your dopamine receptors either lit up or stayed flat.  If you're in the former camp you've found your meeting place.  Get thee to Mission Chinese Food stat.
author: Tracey A.

description:
A recent visit confirmed my previous review:

The restaurant is way too dark inside, with an atmosphere to emulate the typical American Chinese restaurant's grimeyness. However, that also makes me a little worried of cleanliness because you just. can't. see.

The food is mostly definitely San Franciscan, drawing a lot on more exotic Chinese spices that got popular in recent years. Dishes tend to be saltier than you think, for example, the Kung Pao Pastrami, while delicious, consist of salted meat, and more salted flavorings, and requires you to eat a lot of rice. However, if you wanted to try the salted cod fried rice... well, that's plenty salted too.

I still like the food. However, I feel like I need to drink a whole gallon of water to dilute all the sodium I'm consuming. It's definitely still worth a try, but it's not a place I will go back to again and again if I have other choices.
author: Alice C.

description: I unfortunately came back here today and had dinner with a friend and the worst idea to order food to go to bring to my boyfriend, just arrived home to a hungry boyfriend who was waiting for his dinner only he found a bug in his beef chow mein this is gross and unacceptable! I will never ever be back and this has to be brought to management attention, we both feel sick and I ate the same food this is so upsetting and disgusting!!!
author: Vanessa K.

description: Very very long wait for takeout. All dishes I ordered had a lot of chili, pepper and salt but lacked other flavor depth. Everything I tried was too salty for me. Hate to give poor reviews, but this one just didn't do it for me.
author: David T.

description:
Love this place, I get the mapo tofu just about every time. I haven't had anything I do not like here.

Not very traditional with the ingredient choices for each dish but not too out there either.
author: Max W.

description:
We were famished after a long day at Folsom Street Fair. We ordered SO MUCH FOOD. The Kung Pao Pastrami was really unusual and delicious. The Thrice Cooked Bacon was not how I usually like my bacon (not even close to crispy), but was super tender and flavorful. 
The garlic rice was a great addition. As were the long beans. 
Hamachi collar was outstanding. 
The lamb ribs came at the very end and were so big and decadent I couldn't eat my portion. 
The low point was definitely the pumpkin.
author: Melissa M.

description: I used to like this restaurant, however ever since they revamped their menu, the food is amazing and delicious. It's a great dependable food option in SF. This is my go to place for Chinese food.
author: Tanvi G.

description:
We ordered Salt Cod Fried Rice, Westlake Lamb Dumplings, and ChongQing Chicken Wings for Saturday lunch.

Salt Cod Fried Rice: ....Goddamn, this was almost an insult.  Barely any salted fish. 咸鱼 is a staple for the whole Guangdong province for centuries!!! If you don't know how to use it in your dishes, then don't. Anyway, even though it was suppose to be the flavor of the fried rice, I couldn't taste any salted fish. There were not enough Chinese sausages either. If I combined all the slices of meat on that place, it wouldn't even make up one WHOLE sausage. I go through a Kam Yen Jan pack a week, I'd know. 

Conclusion: The overall fried rice was dry, lacking flavor. Taste like how fried rice would taste if a teenager was trying to make fried rice for the first time and forgot to turn on the stove burner. 

Westlake Lamb Dumplings: Pretty good. The dumplings were deep-fried so the lamb meat was dry and tough. Probably not the ideal meat to put in a fried dumpling, in my opinion. The ranch sauce it sat in made up for it.

ChongQing Chicken Wings: On the menu, it said it was numbingly spicy. Spoiler: It wasn't. These wings was the dry rub kind. Pretty good but nothing worth praising.

Service was underwhelming. Servers looked like they didn't want to be there, but it's cool because same.

This was a disappointing experience. Maybe I tried the wrong menu items, but I wouldn't come back.
author: Brenda L.

description:
This review really saddens me, as I have been to the restaurant once as well as ordering delivery probably over two dozen times. Those past experiences were everything other people have said; their food was delicious and innovative. There's a reason they are internationally famous at this point. Unfortunately, as a foodie, a home chef, and someone who has worked in the restaurant industry, I have to now give them a one star review.

I ordered delivery again tonight, and the food, for the first time ever, was awful. I ordered the sour chili chicken, the market greens and an order of rice. I've ordered these dishes many times and they have always been impeccable. This time, the rice had literally no stickiness whatsoever. The greens were tough like they had barely been cooked, and under-seasoned. The chicken was cold and flavorless. And, about halfway through my bowl I found a long hair in my food. Mission Chinese has always been very consistent. Consistency, I feel, is one of the most important aspects of running a restaurant. It establishes trust with the customer and the integrity of your brand. I can understand one or two minor mistakes; but to go from internationally famous cuisine to awful, overpriced delivery in an instant is unforgivable.

Fortunately, as I said, I'm a very proficient home chef, and I just purchased their cook book, so I will probably be able to produce better results at home compared even to the restaurant's original awesomeness, simply because well-cooked home food is always going to be better than what you can get in even the most high-end restaurants. I purchased all of the ingredients for the thrice-cooked bacon a couple of days ago, and I can't wait to eat it over freshly cooked donabe rice.

The unfortunate side is that I no longer have a solid, amazing and convenient Chinese food delivery option. And I will probably not visit the restaurant again now. It's especially sad because they really were one of the best Chinese food restaurants in the city. There are many other restaurants that for some reason have had much longer staying power in terms of consistent quality, delivering the same excellent product for years or even decades. Sadly, some restaurants just don't have that kind of stamina, and the quality eventually falls. I'm especially saddened that Mission Chinese is one of these restaurants as opposed to the former. 

Thank you Mission Chinese for the excellent food in the past, opening my mind to the possibilities of Asian fusion, and the excellent cook book that will yield countless unforgettable meals for myself, my spouse and my friends; so long.
author: Steve S.

description: Ok so....I have been wanting to try this place for a number of years considering all the hype its received especially from my peers in the food industry. So I have to say my expectations were high coming into the experience. My girlfriend and I came in last night at about 6pm, myself a professional cook most of my life and she a General Manager of a restaurant in SF, both with lots of first hand exposure to high quality food in San Francisco. We ordered the Crab Rangoon dip, Filipino Garlic Fried Chicken and some sort of Beef Rib dish with Sticky Garlic Sauce we didn't see on the online menu. Sparing the particulars about each dish the food was mediocre at best, the flavors weren't there and the service was horrible, it was like zombie service, almost as if our waitress was doing us a favor but letting us eat there. If you want GREAT Chinese you wont have to look far, this is San Francisco, but you certainly wont find it here!
author: TRafael R.

description:
Heard so many good things about Mission Chinese Food and finally gave it a try to be let down. I have had my fair share of restaurants, but MSF has let me down to a new level.

First off, I came here around 8:30pm on a weekday and was seated after a short wait. I sat by the entrance and could not ignore the horrible stench coming from the street that smelled like trash and other unnamed odors. Atmosphere was definitely off putting on the smell alone, but the rest of the restaurant wasn't so great either. The whole establishment is dark and lit by lanterns with a giant dragon hanging overhead, which seemed over the top and tacky. Tables were also so close to each other that you can overhear other peoples' conversations and getting by around the restaurant was a hassle, along with probably being a fire hazard.

The worst part was probably the food. I used Yelp as a guideline on what to order and ended up getting the pork mapo tofu, broccoli beef brisket, and salt cod fried rice. Before anything else, THIS FOOD IS SALTY. The rice and brisket came almost immediately upon ordering which was surprising since the restaurant was busy and the tofu came about ten minutes after. The waiter and waitress who attended us were also pushy when we were deicing to order and asked if we knew what we wanted before we even sat down. 

The pork mapo tofu was probably the most disappointing dish I have ever had, and I have had plenty of mapo tofu in my life. Upon first taste, the soft tofu with spice is delicious, but then the worst after taste comes immediately after. My boyfriend also thought the same about the dish; the tofu was nicely cooked but the sauce was unpleasant. It was spicy, but had a tangy aftertaste that burned the tongue in a strange way I had never experienced before. 

The broccoli beef brisket was interesting, but had much too salt to actually enjoy it. The dish was mainly broccoli stalks with a skimpy portion of cubed brisket. There was a sauce that overpowered the entire dish to the point where the broccoli didn't taste like a vegetable and the beef tasted like a sauce sponge instead of meat. The idea of this dish is great, but poorly executed in a way where the flavors did not agree and work together. Less sauce and salt would have definitely done this dish some justice.

The salt cod fried rice was just ok. It reminded me of homemade friend rice, so it was nothing outstanding or great despite the multiple raves for this dish. Typically, salt cod fried rice lives up to its name of being salty rice dish, but with the tofu and brisket dish being so over flavored with salt and sauce, the rice tasted lacking. Salt does not equal "flavor."

Overall, this place is a complete miss. Parking was also a hassle on a weeknight so we had to park over 1.5 miles away, so definitely consider walking or taking public transit. I feel that the hype for this place gave me expectations that could have been met, but Mission Chinese Food dropped the ball. The food was also priced for the portions and quality, with most dishes being over $10 with messy presentation. Overly salted food, lack of service, and disgusting environment and atmosphere makes MCF a no-go for me.
author: Cindy L.

description:
I guess I'm not quite sure what all the fuss is about. It's certainly decent Chinese fusion food. But is it really worth waiting outside for to snag a table. If you walked past it, you'd think folks were waiting to get into a club.

Our party of six fortunately made a reservation in advance, so we didn't have to wait too long outside in the cold. The menu definitely has some eye-catching dishes (tomato beef tartare, and Westlake Lamb Dumplings) - and a few head-scratching ones as well (Kung Pao Pastrami??). Our group decided to order a bunch of dishes to share, while our vegetarian friends did their own thing. The carnivore side of the table opted for the Kung Pao Pastrami, the Beef Chow Mein, the Sour Chili Chicken, and the Ginger Scallion Chicken Fat Fried Rice. It was all fine for the most part. Though truthfully, nothing really stood out for me. I'm thinking maybe we should have tried a few other things like the Mongolian String Beans or the Chicken Wings. The famous "Kung Pao Pastrami" really didn't work for me. I think it's one of those dishes that sounds more interesting than it actually is. If you're thirsty for an adult beverage, they have s small selection of beers and wine. But if you're looking for cocktails, I'd recommend going to Cha Cha Cha across the street, or Blondie's a few blocks away.

It's clear that Mission Chinese is in the business of moving tables. They don't want you staying too long, because they've got plenty of hipsters outside waiting to take your seat. Now I would never normally complain about fast service, but I was a bit surprised by how quickly our dishes came out of the kitchen (we're talking 5-10 minutes after ordering), especially in a restaurant that's so busy. It did make me wonder if perhaps we received another table's order, or if they just have a bunch of pre-made dishes that they just warm up and serve. 

All in all, it was a 3-star dining experience (good, just not great). I wouldn't travel out of my way to eat here again. There are far better (and more affordable) Chinese restaurants in this city.
author: Kevin B.

description:
What to even say, besides TERRIBLE.

I decided to order the Salt Cod Fried Rice since I haven't in a long time. Every time I've tried it at other restaurants, it's been really good. I ordered through Caviar along with a Coke, about $20. I live nearby so delivery was free. 

Let's start by the serving size. Usually restaurants serve this is a big square box, but this place is just a super small box. I'm like, fine. It isn't really a traditional Chinese restaurant. At least it'll be good since it's smaller and more expensive. I was so wrong. It was basically all rice. No salt cod flavor, like 3-5 pieces of cod, maybe 5 pieces of super super super super super thin slices of sausage. Even the egg was pretty lacking. Not over exaggerating, it was like 98% rice, 2% egg, sausage, cod. 

I don't review too much, basically only when it is terrible which isn't often. I'm also not that picky of an eater, so when I say it's bad, it's BAD.
author: David W.

description:
Mission Chinese Food - what happened to you?

This past Friday I ordered a few items for pick up, both of which failed:

Kung Pao Pastrami - the pastrami was so salty that it was hard to eat in regular bites. 
Matcha Squid Ink Noodles - The noodles were that dark squid ink color, but that's where squid ink ended, it didn't have the flavor of squid ink that you would expect, nor did I taste the matcha in this set of noodles.  I also find it out there's no meat or seafood to accompany this dish - it is just a big bowl of (kinda bland) noodles.

I'd love for them to improve on their dishes.
author: Mary X.

description:
