I reserved a table for Sunday evening for 5. We got to the reserved time and got seated very quickly. Between 5 of us we ordered pork belly, pastrami, salt cod fried rice, wings. We had leftovers only because we were hungry before our reserved time so we ate a meal before hand but still wanted to go to Mission Chinese. 

The crowd favorite was the pork belly. We personally felt the dishes were a tad bit too salty. My group felt like the wings were not spicy at all. I personally have a really low spice tolerance and I felt like it wasn't all too spicy. The fried rice was good. 

This is a fun place to go to with your friends to try different dishes. I like this place.
author: Jay L.

description:
Pros:
- great 90's R&B playlist
- instagram-worthy kitschy Chinese decor

Cons:
- terrible service made me and my group of friends feel unwelcome
- food was decent but overpriced (I understand they are being experimental and fusion-y but it just wasn't my thing for the amount we paid)
author: Jon C.

description: This is my favorite Chinese food in the city. It is definitely a twist on your average chinese food. It has a unique menu with great meat and vegetarian options. My go to dish is always the rice cakes! They are spicy and not something I have been able to find anywhere else!
author: Sarah A.

description: The atmosphere was lovely. The service was great. The food was incredibly disappointing. After all that I had heard I was so excited about the food, but UGH! The kimchi was labeled as very spicy and left barely a tingle. And the chow mien was SO salty!!!! And this is from someone who loves salt
author: Whitney B.

description:
What a let down...
I've been wanting to come to mission Chinese for awhile now and my friends and I scored an early reservation for 4 last Saturday. It was pretty empty when we got there so we were seated right away and greeted with water (nice touch with the pitcher at the table- I suspect this is mainly because of the overly salty food...but I digress)
We started with a couple of apps for the table. I don't eat pork but my friends enjoyed it saying the flavors were decent. The tiger salad is basically these HUGE spring rolls that are dry inside and so slippery they fall apart everywhere when you try to bite into them. 
For entrees we got the salt cod fried rice, ma po tofu, chicken wings, dumplings... And I'm still waiting on that side of plain rice I ordered and never got. We also all got "the cocktail" which is basically like a Moscow mule.
The food all arrived pretty quick (except that rice) everything was so so greasy, salty, spicy. Just all over the place. Would have been nice to wash it down with our cocktails, but we didn't really receive them (in the fancy plastic solo cups) until our meal was almost over. 
The service felt very very rushed once our food was dropped. There was already a line forming out the door of hungry hipsters so the servers were just taking things off our table and rushing is out. I think I had about 1/3 of my cocktail left and they took it away and tossed it... 
All in all. No. Just no. I don't get it. About $200 for four people eating over salted greasy Chinese food in a hip atmosphere? Nope. I'll just order take out next time.
Pro tip-
Oh yeah. Don't use the bathroom you basically walk through the kitchen (health code?) and wait in this weird back room with food and misc kitchen products.
author: Kelsey B.

description: Great food, good service, fast service. We had the Brussel sprouts, salt cod fried rice, broccoli and brisket, chicken wings and lamb dumplings. Each of these dishes were delicious and the service was prompt. We highly recommend this spot.
author: Anand N.

description:
Food was 5/5: We got the spicy ma po tofu, salted fish fried rice, and spicy beef chow mein. The salted fish rice went really well with the spicy ma po tofu. It would go really well with a vegetable dish as well, but I didn't order any vegetable dish. The spicy ma po tofu was spicy, but not in a way where you can feel the heat. I think it literally burns your taste buds and leaves your mouth tingling-- that kind of spicy. After I stopped eating it, and went for a cup of water, the mouth tingled even more. Breathing in air through my mouth even tingled. I don't know what that means but the tofu was bomb af either way. The spicy beef chow mein was definitely the kind of spicy where you can feel the heat and the sweat forming on your face. Nice portion of meat on the chow mein.

Service was 4/5: I would give it a 3/5 because one of the workers ignored the bill I was holding for ~5 minutes. The two times he passed by, he looked at it, and kept walking without saying "just one moment" or "another waiter / waitress will pick up your bill" and we even made eye contact! But another lady was really helpful and service was great from her so overall, 4/5 stars.

Location: I arrived around 5:30PM, when the sun was still up, and there wasn't a wait (but as we were leaving, people were putting down reservations and the wait list was 4+ parties already). The area is kinda sketchy. We parked .4 miles away from the actual restaurant and passed by a couple of people that catcalled my friend on the way back. We also passed by people holding syringes and people selling stolen clothes. So, note: walk in groups if you feel unsafe after it gets dark.
author: Jasmine L.

description: Hip hop and rap filling your eardrums as the light dim down low real low. Try the Eggplant. But honestly if you are Pescatarian or Vegetarian? This place isn't for you.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Into it! I love the vibe and communal seating. I even got to try a few dishes from my neighbors :) I went with a vegan friend and we had the Turnips on special and the Tofu Ma Po with rice. The turnips were 5 stars, highly recommend, and the Tofu Ma Po was okay. I will definitely be back to further explore their menu!
author: Britt M.

description:
Twisted up Chinese dishes packed with flavor make this spot a must try for the adventurous food lovers!  The ambiance is nothing to write home about but it fits perfectly for the concept of this place.

I tried the Kung Pao pastrami, Mongolian long Beans (vegan!), and the salted cod fried rice.  Hands down the winner for me were the long beans - they were so delicious!  I really enjoyed everything I had though.  Service is quick and friendly and the staff are great about recommending items to try.  It's a great spot for dinner and I thought the portions were generous and fairly priced.
author: Anna P.

description:
So much fun! I love the music here, feels like proper fun restaurant! 
We had cold kimchi appetizer and also the mashed cucumber appetizer, both were yummy, I'd come back just for that. I also appreciate the vegan/veg options. 
Ma po tofu on the other hand was terrible. My husbands cumin lamb not crispy as it usually is.
Service was good and the type of place your waitress would wipe the table with her sleeve lol. I don't mind, as long as you got the right attitude. Which both girls did. 
Will come back!
author: Julia S.

description: Loved the thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes!! It sounds strange but it's the best thing on the menu, in my opinion -  I have dreams about the sweet tofu skin. The chow mein with beef is amazing as well, but we weren't too crazy about the hamachi collar, it was flavorful but not enough of a portion to make it worth the price - maybe three bites. The atmosphere is fun, and I definitely recommend for vegetarians and meat eaters alike.
author: Simone B.

description:
5 Stars for the food!
I heard about this place from an interview with Terry Gross on Fresh Air - NPR. The interview was fascinating. The chef spends 80+ hours a week on his restaurants, Korean guy who taught himself to cook Chinese food.

I've tried every dish on the menu over 3 visits. I love this place! Specifically I like:
- Atmosphere: this place keeps casual and does not take its self too seriously. From the funny signs to the rock music to the lights. It's awesome!
- There is not one dish I recognize as really Chinese. This place is true fusion. The Pastrami Kung Pow is one such example. Amazing! Like nothing you have had before ever! 
- I could keep going... but why. Just try this place. Words are hard to describe!
author: Chris S.

description:
This review is for eat in and take out. 
 
Either way you get absolutely crapola service. That's never ever gonna improve. The people working here are bummed the f--- out. Who knows exactly why and who cares. Be a f--ing professional. 

SF has officially now become the forgotten step sister to NYC. Like a step sister she is disintegrating into a shell of rotten urine smells just like the good old mission always has. 

For the prices Danny Bowen (I spelled his name wrong on purpose) can make the not cool dirty restaurant cleaner,  AT LEAST. At most he can respect that SF put him on the map and share the love with us. 

the food score is 86?? WTF??  Which brings me to the food. It's a great concept. It's crap execution. and the revolting open kitchen is no help. 

I don't care if this was the original and use better quality meats and veggies (they don't). When the place stinks worse than Sam Wo's it's no wonder they keep the lights so dim. It's to hide the gross factor. 

Suck it Danny. All the way to the bank. But this guy is f'n gone for good. Later, Byaaaatch. 

$37 with tip for takeout noodles. F- it!!
author: Nik D.

description:
Loved the ambience and food was amazing. We ordered the asparagus, mapu tofu and sour chili chicken. Everything was delicious! Would suggest to pair the sparkling sake with spicy food, goes very well. 

Hidden gem for a date night!
author: Ankit S.

description:
This Is a overprice Chinese food restaurant! Food is nothing special and I cannot understand why so many people are waiting! Sesame chicken are not the real Chinese food. Sesame chicken is so greasy! And it costs 16 bucks! That rice cake also costs $16, and there is no seafood, no big meat in it! And portion is not big either! The dishes I ordered only worth less than 9 bucks in most of the restaurants in Chinatown and east bay. Giving them 2 star just for that tiger salad, good shape! And they also charge tea money for that tea bag tea! We came in as 2, and we spent $47 (no tip included)for 3 small portion dishes! I expect to eat at a nicer restaurant at this price range!
If u do not know Chinese food, you will like it and you will be ripped off!
author: Nina H.

description:
TL/DR: Overrated overpriced dingy hipster joint!

 The waiter  Wednesday, March 1 approx 7:15PM had a Jimmy Fallon vibe enthusiastic which made up for the weird wait/sign up ...and the chipped saucer which he replaced ...and a super small  wine glass with smeared lipstick which he comped so I bought another ... the water carafe was also smeared and looked unclean but I didn't want to complain 3 times.

Mission Chinese Food is overrated perfect for shallow show off hipsters tourists and San Francisco newbies. It's super dark and low-fi the better to hide the dirt.

I had the duck chow mein which tasted like ham hocks seriously, was that duck sure didn't taste like it and the lamb dumplings were horrible deep fried yuck.

 Thank gawd for that cheery waiter. I have no reason to return unless some hipsters are doing the treating.
author: SF T.

description: Rude & disrespectful. Walked inside the restaurant to figure out how to check-in and instead of assisting us the waitress kept telling us to move out of the way in an extremely offensive and impolite manner.  She was so rude that it was hurtful to me and my party. Then another waiter walks us out to tell us where to sign in for the waiting list and then tells us they are full and won't take any more parties. Fine, I understand that they are full and busy but there is a much nicer way to approach your customers - it's called common courtesy and not speaking to your customers like they are beneath you. I hope Danny Bowein reads this review. So disappointing and hurtful.
author: Eli O.

description: Food was a bit greasy and fatty for me. The ambiance was cool and the staff was nice. Price was so so.
author: Khalid N.

description:
I've been to both the NYC and SF Mission Chinese Restaurants and was surprised how different they are both vibe-wise and menu:

Vibe
SF - chill and hipster vibe, discrete sign, long communal tables for seating, very casual
NYC - upscale! the basement has a take away area, but the main floor seating is formal, bar area has some shared seating

Menu
SF - Smaller, there is no lobster fried rice, more cold plate options, bottles of wine are very affordable ($40-50 a bottle)
NYC - larger menu, including extensive cocktail menu (very unique!), lobster fried rice, free scallion pancake provided 3-4 plates are ordered

Overall both are great, both have the kung pao pastrami, and have good service, just very different.
author: Nikita K.

description: A lot of hype only to be disappointed. Food was alright, but not amazing by any means. Salt Cod Fried Rice ($13) was too dry, lacked flavorful, and very little actual cod in the dish. The Sesame Chicken ($14) had a nice crunchy exterior, too sweet on the sauce, but the best dish out of the two. Overall, not a big fan.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Ah, the ever hyped Mission Chinese. After a day of drinking and finally back home, our group wanted some dinner without wanting to go anywhere or cook anything. This was Mission Chinese's time to shine. So we placed our order consisting of more food than we could possibly finish. 

This is, as you probably already know, not your typical Chinese food. It has a very distinctive SF hipster flair which is readily noticeable in most of the dishes. 

Some were good, some were great, a few were misses, but in total it made for a great, unique meal. Of particular note, the kung pao pastrami was delicious and definitely worth its spot on the 7x7 list. I didn't much care for the tea smoked eel or the wings. The rest were either average or better. 

Overall, Mission Chinese offers a type of meal that you aren't going to find anywhere else. It may not be the most mind blowing food but for delivery Asian fusion-esque Chinese food, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
This restaurant overcharged my tip!!  What crooks. 

I left $36.54 including tip, and I checked my credit card statement and to my shock they charged me $41.54.  See my attached photos for proof.  How messed up is that?

Do not trust this restaurant.  They are running a very dirty operation scamming money from their customers.
author: Tommy W.

description:
Great flavors, sometimes a bit heavy-handed with seasoning, but that's a personal preference.

It is definitely a hipster spot. But it's also an everyone spot. A couple seated next to me at the communal table asked, in my expertise (being an Asian-looking person, to them), if it was as good as Panda Express. In all earnestness.
author: Victoria C.

description: We got food to go, but the chicken wing came out very disappointing. The portion is tiny compared to what they normally serve :(
author: Sherica L.

description:
Food is creative
Wine is expensive
Can cook Chinese long beans for a little longer
Nice to mix hummus to Cucumber
This is the stuff I would not have in China but very interesting combinations.
Service was good too.

Just too pricey
author: Amanda D.

description:
Meh, don't know what all the hype is about. It's gentrified Chinese food. Being Chinese, I can't say that I'm impressed. I was going to say it was bougie, but it's not - it's homey cooking turned up a notch.

We had the eggplant, which was good, but wouldn't rival any other Chinese restaurant or Thai place. We also tried the squid ink noodles with matcha, which were fine, but neither tasted like squid ink or matcha. And we also had the chicken fried rice, which yeah, that tasted good, but also wouldn't rival any Hainan chicken rice either.

The line was long, even for 9 PM on a Friday night and we were planning to take out. Not a place I'd recommend as a must-see.
author: Christina K.

description: A little bit lackluster. Though I liked the kung pao pastrami from delivery, the Filipino garlic fried chicken was a bit dry, and no need for the vinegar dipping sauce. I'm Filipino, and this chicken doesn't have that flavor in its fusion. The tiki pork belly, though flavorful, doesn't need that little japanese umbrella, it's not a cocktail. Please update your cutlery, it looks old.
author: Raymond V.

description:
I am a fair believer in giving people a second chance.  When it came to Mission Chinese Food, I'm glad I did.

One night I was busy working (from home, but still working nonetheless) and didn't want to go out and pick anything up for dinner.  In a moment of desperation and starvation, I decided to order Mission Chinese Food for delivery.  It would be an hour and a half wait, but I still had work to do, so fine.

I was craving the salt cod fried rice, which is why I actually ordered MCF because I'd read good things about that dish.  Since there was a delivery minimum, I decided to make two meals out of it and order what I had almost 4 years ago - the thrice cooked bacon with rice cakes.

My order was actually 17 minutes late (I only know this exact number because when I looked up at the clock, it was 7:18 and I checked the email to see when the food was promised, and it said 7:01).  Just as I was about to call them, the doorbell rang, and I was able to shove all the food in my face.

Thrice cooked bacon - they definitely updated this.  No onions, but there were lots of rice cakes, tofu skin, and some pieces of bacon.  There were also hot peppers and bitter melon slices, which I could've done without.  Overall a bit too spicy for my liking - I don't remember that it used to be this spicy, actually.  Better than last time though, because there was actually substance.

Salt cod fried rice - I liked this a lot.  It didn't feel super traditional as if I was eating it at a Chinese banquet restaurant, but I couldn't place my finger on what was missing.  I liked the addition of the sausage - lapcheong - and the flavors were good.

A bit too expensive for delivery for just one person, but it beats some of the other Chinese options in the Marina for delivery.  Would I try them again?  If I had a larger delivery order, or if I went into the actual restaurant (without a wait), yes.  But just for one person, split into two meals (and my husband ate some of both dishes), $40+ was just a bit pricey.
author: Tori S.

description: I made a reservation a month ago and was so excited to have my friends and husband try the food. I had a great experience there a few months ago. We were enjoying our dinner and decided to order more food and were told we could not because we were they thought we were done and needed our table. The staff kept taking dishes we were not finished with to hurry us up. The food was not as good as good as last time and as we left, I saw the 72 rating from the health department, which is considered unsafe and includes rodent infestation, unclean cooking surfaces, food not stored at proper temperatures etc. I am nauseas this morning. There are way too many amazing restaurants in SF. Spend your money somewhere else.
author: Jill D.

description: We ordered 2 stir fry dishes, one noodle soup, and a plate of fried rice. Overall the food is okay but extremely overpriced.  They weren't particularly more interesting than traditional Chinese food around. Especially the fried rice, the portion wasn't that generous even though it's just a plain and simple fried rice dish. It is definitely less greasy than many restaurants, but still not worth the money.
author: Pei F.

description:
186 weeks ago before Serena Williams and the GQ write up, the chicken wings looked like this (see pic) at least 8-10 pieces, fried crisply, swimming in dried pepper and a little cheaper. At one point, you even fried tripe and mixed that in. Today, the wings looked anemic, not crispy, barely any dried peppers, no fried tripe, about 3 pieces, 6 pieces if you split them (see pic). 

I've probably spent over $10,000 on chicken wings so far in my lifetime. Mission Chinese's was my 3rd favorite one so I know my wings. 
Today really broke my heart and hurt my feelings deeply. 

Super happy that you did a NYC venture, you've hit national spotlight and such...but I will no longer bring my 'rents and my friends for the 3rd best chicken wings of my lifetime...unless you make it right, send me flowers or a bouquet of your original chicken wings. 

I guess this is goodbye. It's not me; it's you...you've changed; you've let your compliments get to your head.
author: Katrina N.

description:
Second time ordering in - this time was even better than the first (which was a pleasant surprise, as the first time was delicious!).  This place offers such FRESH tasting Chinese food with interesting flavor profiles.  We love that it's not overly saturated in grease like most Chinese cuisine.  After eating this food we don't wake up the next day with gut-rot!!!  We've only ordered in, but plan on eating at the restaurant soon so we can try some of the dishes that we think would be better if we didn't do take-out/delivery (e.g., pork belly dish).

The first time we ordered the Tea-Smoked Eel rolls (3.5 stars), Kung Pao Pastrami (4.5 stars), and Forbidden Fried Rice (3.5 stars).  

We loved the Kung Pao Pastrami so much that we ordered it again the second time, and then opted for the Salt Cod Fried Rice (5 stars) and the 3x Smoked Bacon (4 stars).

We will ALWAYS order the Salt Cod Fried Rice and then layer in two other dishes to share.  Such good Chinese food - a must if you haven't tried!
author: Rachael S.

description: Delivery was prompt and courteous. Wings were tasty. The Kung pao pastrami, however, was so salty it was barely edible.  I had read some good reviews and really wanted to like this place, but ultimately can't recommend it.
author: Daniel D.

description:
Oh. My. God.

Waited for awhile in the cold to eat here because in my hangry state I was just dead set on waiting instead of walking around. And I did not regret it. The exterior--hole in the wall Chinese restaurant I expected. Walking in: some strange, grungy rave complete with a dragon hanging from the ceiling. The waiters were white, which made me think: "Does this place have what it takes?"

The cumin lamb was really good, although I wish there was more lamb, less onions. The flavors reminded me of the cumin lamb I've had at restaurants before, although it was strange that the lamb seemed a little ground up. And again with the onions. I like onions a lot, but it's like they were trying to hide that there wasn't a lot of meat. I know what I'm doing--I don't get distracted by vegetables.

The other thing we tried was the thrice cooked bacon with rice cakes. As someone's who had bitter melon daily for three months at home I was not excited to subject myself to that awfulness again. But I forgot that with black bean sauce and greasy bacon, bitter melon is a nice change of flavor.

Thing that I didn't enjoy that much--the kung pao pastrami burrito. Sure, it sounds good, with the raved about kung pao pastrami and the renown salt cod fried rice together in a burrito--what could go wrong? But I think the flavors of both just drowned out the either, making it taste bland.

Overall, I'm coming back to try the ma po tofu, but I think I'll hold off on the burritos.
author: Rosy H.

description:
We wanted to try the SF restaurant since we had tried the one in NYC in July and had such a great experience there. Giving it 2 stars mostly because of the poor service. The person who sat us down acted like it was an annoyance to do so. We had 3 different wait staff and when the bill came there was a mysterious $23 charge. When we asked they said it was gratuity they had added on without telling us so (and with only 5 of us dining!) The thing is, despite the lame service, we always tip well and if we had not been paying attention, would have tipped again without our knowledge.

Overall, the food was okay. Not as good as the NY restaurant. In addition, only beer/wine at this one. I will not eat here again unless I hear it goes through an upgrade in customer service and food, but I will definitely eat at the one in NYC again and encourage others to seek it out if you visit.
author: Amy O.

description: Food was okay. I applaud the family run business right on mission street. They also serve donuts so if you plan on getting something sweet after, it'll be right there.
author: Myleen R.

description:
2000th review here! That makes my opinion really stand out, ha. 

Finally got to dine in at the famed MCF and boy let me tell you. It will fulfill all of your wildest red light Chinese karaoke dreams with an extra serving of sodium. 

Food here is spicy. I love spicy peppers. On my way to the bathroom I saw them chopping up fresh jalapeños and serranos in the kitchen. I've got to say everything tastes similar- salty, spicy, greasy, and salty. After a while it's a bit overpowering but overall I do like the food here.

After all these years they still do good business here so expect to wait. I'll probably stick to takeout deliveries.
author: Stine H.

description: I know I'm coming into this super late in the game, but I had a super tasty good first time here. I was skeptical about coming here. I'm one of those angry people who grew up in San Francisco, hating how things have changed. And so when I see something that turns the Mission into a hip joint, I'm a little stubborn about it. You know the deal... blah blah blah. I was taken aback by the prices, like the $26 General Tso Ribs. But then the food comes out, and I grub, and I am satisfied with every bite. I love matcha green tea and I love squid/squid ink, and I love how they have Matcha Green Tea Squid Ink noodles here. The taste of ginger in the noodles is a nice touch too. I'm also a big fan of rice cakes, but never thought to have them with bacon. Good call there, Mission Chinese. And last, but not least, the General Tso Ribs are genius. Sooo tender and so gooood. I can't think of anything I didn't like it. And while, I thought things were a bit pricey at first, we had a ton of leftovers, that were great the next day. It was definitely a worthwhile experience, enough for me to forget my stubbornness for a short bit, as I focused on enjoying my meal. Just forget what you know, and come to this restaurant with an open mind! I didn't, but I totally changed my mind with every bite.
author: April D.

description:
Great Vibes, Better Food...so honestly I don't really like Chinese food that much but I thought this menu was creative (+1) and tasty (+1). Definitely exceeded my expectations for a Chinese place.

S/O to broad city for mentioning Mission Chinese (even tho they were talking about the NYC one)‍

Recommend.
author: Andrew P.

description:
A friend took me here because she kept hearing good things about this place and wanted to try it. I was honestly blown away. I know this is probably because the food was just Americanized enough for my tastebuds -- but I'd call this the best Chinese food I've had in a long time.

We had the salt cod fried rice and the thrice-cooked bacon and rice cakes, both of which have a lot of favorable reviews on here already; as well as the spring rolls with shrimp and pork, which had great flavor and just the right amount of crunch.

I see a lot of people complaining about prices, but honestly, it's San Francisco. I think it's well within the usual range for the city.

A+.
author: Glenn W.

description:
Food is overhyped.  Had a group of 7 people  - ordered a ton of food... nothing was that special.  This is definitely one of those hipster spots that doesn't really deserve it. Overpriced. 
Service is terrible. Was asked to vacate our table after we paid (had only been a few minutes) and then when we were standing on the sidewalk trying to figure out where to go next we were asked to clear the sidewalk in front of the restaurant.  Overall a less than pleasant experience especially for the price.  This restaurants' time has passed.  Time to find another place ...
author: Faisal Q.

description: This review is about the food, this is not the place for you if you want a fine dining experience. First off, this is Szechuan fusion, so it is going to be spicy! Loved the Mapo tofu, it was perfect. My favorite dish was the eggplant, it was creamy and amazing. Also loved the vinegar peanuts.
author: Sea A.

description:
3.5 stars is more accurate. Overall, I'm really torn about my rating of Mission Chinese Food because they're highly inconsistent, but I really like the restaurant concept. I've ordered the same exact dishes during two different times, and the quality of the food I received varied greatly. For example, the Porky ribs. The first time I ordered them, they were juicy, with great flavor and plenty of sauce. The second time, it was dry, tasted just okay, with very little sauce. So disappointing! I also would not recommend the Eel Rolls appetizer that everyone seems to like. I thought it was really boring, bland, and not very interesting. They were also cut so large that it was almost unappetizing because you have to either break it apart or try to stuff it all in your mouth.

That being said, I've been here a couple of times because even though on the surface it seems like hipster Chinese food, a lot of flavors are actually super authentic and nostalgic to what I'm used to (I'm Chinese). For example, the Mapo Tofu is NOT the Americanized version. It's full of chili, tons of spice, delicious and also very spicy. 

My favorite dishes are: the porky ribs (when consistent), the mapo tofu (again this is spicy so be prepared), salt cod fried rice (highly recommend) and Westlake Porridge (however, on the salty side).
author: Claudia C.

description:
I was so looking forward to eating here.  Four of us shared close to half of the relatively small menu.  The cumin lamb larb was good but the lamb was cold. Not super spicy.  The smashed cucumber wasn't spicy but it left your tongue and lips tingly. They had a nice crunch. The Chongqing chicken wings were really good.  Great crisp! Only spicy if you happened to grab one the the thai peppers.

The beef tartare with roe was a miss for the whole table. Nice presentation, but the roe overpowered the flavor of the beef. The Singapore rice was good with nice portion size. We looked forward to the kong bao pastrami, but it was disappointing.  We left half of the order. The beef brisket with broccoli was okay.

The service was good and attentive.  

Overall we were disappointed given the reputation.
author: Frank T.

description:
Love this place! I've had this on my list since I moved to SF around 2 years ago to visit, but haven't gotten around to it until this month. I was a bit dismayed by the fall in rating, but decided to go for it anyways, and I was not disappointed. 

Most fusion restaurants nowadays call themselves fusion but in reality either just serve 2 cuisines at their restaurant, or timidly mix together food from different places to create a dish that is mildly different from the original. Mission Chinese Food, however, is bold about their flavors and unafraid to "fuse." Case in point(s):

Kung Pao Pastrami. 
Yes, like kung pao chicken but with pastarami. My mouth was so confused in such a good way. It tastes exactly like you think it would, but how does anyone think of this? The pastrami was a little on the salty side, but it is pastrami. Order rice or noodles to go with this dish.

Tiki pork belly. 
This is a familiar fusion - pork belly with citrus and nuts (think classic Hawaiian flavors) slow roasted (or baked, not sure) to perfection. Meat that melts in your mouth like butter, mixing deliciously with soy caramel and pineapple complemented perfectly by the crunch of the macadamia nuts. Heaven.

Not so memorable were the vegan noodles, but still a solid 3/5. I will definitely be back for more!
author: Patricia K.

description: Been here twice and Mission Chinese lives up to the hype: everything was delicious, service was good. Ambience is loud, but not too bad.
author: Tom M.

description: Food was decent but crazy salty. BUT the service was possibly the worst ever. We had reservations for 4 people and after taking our order (asked for suggestions and the waitress just shrugged and said it depends what you like), they never came back to check on us or ask if we wanted another drink. THEN they brought us a check assuming we were all done. The craziest part is after being there for exactly 1 hour, maybe even a few minutes less, they came over and said we needed to leave because they had another reservation!!! Uh ok? Considering the mediocre food as well, I would never go back.
author: Carly K.

description:
The food was good but didn't quite meet the expectations I had. 

We ordered 4 dishes for our party of four and took some leftovers home. 

Kung Pao Pastrami - tasty but quite salty

Salted cod fried rice - pleasant but nothing too unique

Mapo tofu - Saucy and good with rice. The peppery spice snuck up on us!

Long Beans - Interestingly, this was our favorite dish of the meal. We asked for it to be mild, and the beans were tender and the portion was quite large.
author: Michelle H.

description:
I eat quite spicy and that's why I like this place a lot. Especially love their chicken wings with the Sichuan pepper, their brisket kung Pao and their rice cakes with bacon. 

I haven't tried too many of their vegetarian specialties but I think they are pretty good too. Good for groups and decently priced. Their fried rice with garlic is actually pretty tasty too.
author: Rohan D.

description:
OH BOY! Quirky and delicious with OK (at best) service and kind of garbage atmosphere in the best way possible. The Kung Pao Pastrami was absolutely memorable but nothing else was good enough to write home about. 

Side note, the drinks are super small for the price.
author: Dustin H.

description:
Came here knowing what to expect from all the hype about Mission Chinese in both NYC and the Bay. I love fusion (as a multi racial azn I kind of was made this way) & I'm always here for it but this wasn't the best experience.

Pickled cabbage: combining the cabbage with those peanuts you usually get at Cantonese restaurants, this kind of worked but missed the bar in terms of being pickled. It wasnt really pickly like kimchi or Chinese pickles.

Smashed cucumbers: my mom makes something like this so I was surprised when the flavors were more oily than cool and salty. Would pass on this

Matcha noodles: this was basically ramen mixed with a green salty garlic sauce. Yummy but nothing special, felt like something I would make at home out of lazy desperate-ness haha

Mapo tofu: Sichuan food is one of my favorites so this was something I wanted to try here. It wasn't anything unique or different, I was kind of confused since it was like a less interesting version of normal mapo tofu... I love spice but this tasted just like heavy peppercorn.

Thrice cooked bacon: BEST THING, came with tteok rice cakes and super yummy bacon. The bacon fat was soaked by the rice cakes. Never had anything like this before which is what made it so tasty.

I think the stuff that works here are the new unique dishes, not their takes on old school Chinese food. I probably should've ordered more of the unconventional dishes to try.
author: Hana S.

description: The charm and kitsch has worn off.  There are dives that serve amazing food, and beautiful restaurants that serve mediocre food.  This is the worst of both worlds - a dive serving mediocre food.  The food is neither authentic nor a fusion-y improvement on old classics.  The place feels tired and overdone, simply relying on its longstanding reputation as a staple of the Mission food scene.  It's time to move on, SF.
author: Straight S.

description:
Probably my favorite sit down Chinese food place in SF right now.

A little unorthodox with the flashing lights and the deep house music lightly playing in the background, but I actually appreciated the different environment.

We were seated relatively quickly (make sure to put your name on the sign-in sheet OUTSIDE) and dove into the diverse menu.

Was a VERY big fan of the Mapo Tofu here - it was definitely just as good as how I remember it when I was back eating Szechuan food back in China. I hope to come back soon, but even when I can't make the trip out, I know it won't be far away as it is on Seamless!
author: Rotimi O.

description:
I'm not sure what to say about a restaurant that intentionally flips its health score upside down so it looks like a 98 when it's actually an 86... Our entire table stared at it, we continued staring at the waiter and cook as they passed by who noticed us pointing and taking photos of the sign, but I believe the sign still remains in its upside down state.

The food is alright, but expensive for what it is. Would likely not return.
author: Vivien O.

description:
Is there a negative number of stars I can give? I actually didn't even get a chance to try the food. I have lived in the Mission for over 10 years, and worked in service in the Mission for about as long, so I am not one to bitch and moan at the drop of a hat. But this place served up a special kind of rudeness. 

My husband and I went on a date and I said I'd never been to Mission Chinese. I went to get a table while he was looking at comics next door. There were two servers and the restaurant was maybe a third full. Not busy at all. I waited by the "Please Wait to be Seated" sign for ten minutes while the servers glided by me without even making eye contact, over and over. Finally, I asked one of them if it was possible to get a table. "I'll get the host," he said, rolling his eyes. "Never mind, I'm leaving," I said, not wanting to put him out any further than I already seemed to have, by daring to ask a question. 

"Okay, bye. Whatever." That is what this dude said to me as I left. After being ignored for ten minutes standing by the door. 

So, after 10 years living in this neighborhood, and serving drinks to the people in it, I now will never try Mission Chinese. I was treated so poorly that I couldn't possibly stomach trying again. Really, really beyond bad.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Food wise - they have great flavor and offer unique dishes.
The restaurant itself is a hole in the wall, pretty dingy, and the service is less than desirable. 
Should you go, just get in and get out.
author: Aliké S.

description: I enjoyed their delicious food. The service was just OK. I recommend the pork belly, the lamb soup, the smashed cucumbers, and the crunchy spring rolls. It's a bit place with a cute inte
author: Joni W.

description:
This place is dope and honestly, I was skeptical. The menu is kind of limited and I am generally pretty picky, but my skepticism was undeserved. There's a lot to love here.

First, the place is pretty small. We went on a Saturday afternoon half expecting it to be packed because of the reputation, but our large party was able to be seated fairly easily. YMMV on this front. 

Back to that limited menu--the thought is that your table will order several items and just share them family style. Our group was a bunch of couples and chose to just split items amongst ourselves. My wife and I ordered the pork belly, the salt cod fried rice and the chicken wings. All delivered

The standout for me was the chicken wings. Not sure what kind of voodoo flavor this was--it was spicy but not overwhelming, richly flavorful and for eleven bucks, plenty. Highly recommend these.

The pork belly was a favorite among the others in my party and it was really quite good--pork belly is always good because it is pork belly. Definitely wouldn't be put off by some of the fusion elements of the menu. The flavors work and you are unlikely to be disappointed. The staff is super-friendly and engaging and will make sure you know what you should order.

Lastly, the music? Yes, yes, yes! It's not often I feel like the music wasn't selected by someone's grandmother--trap/trip hop/drill/swag--I'm a fan. Worth the trip just to peep the playlist. 

SF has unlimited options, but I wouldn't be surprised if I made it back here eventually. Again, dope.
author: Renard M.

description: I really enjoyed the food, super flavorful and goes well with beer or cold sake.
author: Michael A.

description: Waited about an hour on a saturday night so reservations is the best way to go for this place. Sooooo good would definately recommend the broccoli and beef brisket and lamb dumplings!! Would kill for this meal again
author: Tori D.

description:
Oh Mission Chinese. Why was there all that hype surrounding you?! Maybe I was too late to jump on the bandwagon and try you. But boy did you disappoint! I understand why Michael Bauer's review said you're missing the mark.

On a lazy day back in early April when I couldn't decide what I wanted to eat, I decided to cough up the $6 and pay for delivery from Mission Chinese. With the cost and time of getting to the Mission, finding parking and waiting for a table, I thought $6 wasn't a bad tradeoff. Now I'm wishing I didn't waste the money. Delivery time wasn't too bad. Too bad I couldn't say that about the food!

Mongolian long beans ($11) - Xinjiang spices, horseradish, chili oil. The only dish I actually like! At first they tasted kind of sweet. But I realized that was due to a burnt dish I had prior to taking a bite of this. After a few bites, I could taste the subtle spiciness of the long beans. Yum!

Westlake rice porridge ($12) - Chopped beef, dungeness crab, sawtooth herb, egg. So oily! And the egg just seemed so misplaced. It was like a soft boiled egg that you bumped into halfway through the dish. It just made the dish that much heavier since the porridge had much oil in it.

Salt cod fried rice ($12) - Mackerel confit, chinese sausage, lettuce and egg. I don't get it! Why was this on the 7x7 list?! It was completely tasteless! I wanted the salty savory goodness I was expecting from the description. Instead I got bland fried rice! 

Spicy beef chow mein ($15) - Seared hanger steak, Shanghai noodles, spicy miso, bell pepper, pickled mustard green, mung bean sprouts, fried shallot. From the description, I thought I'd like this the most. That's why I was willing to shell out $15 for beef chow mein! Instead I got burnt meat and noodles. Since only the meat had a strong burnt taste, I thought maybe eating just the noodles would be ok. Nope! The burnt flavor permeated through the whole dish! Such a bummer! 

Tea smoked eel ($9.50) - Fresh rice noodle, chinese celery, salted plum hoisin, braised pork, cognac soy. The flavors in this dish did not come together at all! The eel was dry. The celery overpowered the taste of the eel and pork. The hoisin sauce and the cognac sauce did not blend well together. I felt like all the ingredients were fighting each other in a taste test instead of working together to made one nice dish.

To sum it up, I'm glad I finally checked Mission Chinese off my list. And I didn't have to go all the way to the Mission to do it. But what a waste of money! If Mission Chinese really was as great as I've read in past reviews, it really is just a shadow of it's former self.
author: Elena N.

description: Wow. It's got to be the worst chinese ever. Horrible service but I expected that but food was so salty that it felt like they dumped a whole cup of salt.
author: David K.

description:
After hearing great things about Mission Chinese Food, I was pretty excited when my friends wanted to venture out to the Mission District for some.. well Chinese food! Walking in, the restaurant is super dark and super stuffy. It was so hot inside - I was wearing a t-shirt and still trying my best not to sweat. (TMI? Apologies!) 

Since we had a big party, we ordered a lot of the popular dishes. I didn't understand why the salted cod fried rice was so famous. It was nothing mind blowing. It was pretty mediocre, really. I liked the mapo tofu, but you really can't mess that dish up. All of the dishes were so salty or full of MSG. I drank a lot of water, but I still had the worst headache after dinner. Not cool. 

I think my favorite part of dinner that night was the $3 cold beer. It was the only thing that was refreshing and kept me cool and happy. I'd definitely go elsewhere for Chinese food - authentic or not!
author: Christine S.

description:
So many things to taste, to try, and to experience, that you just want to keep coming back and spending more and more time together with this menu. Everything I've had has been terrific, and while that doesn't always mean you want to order the same things over and over again, I just want to explore every little item and understand the nuances, the flavors, the depth, and spend a lot more time tasting it all.

What I can tell you is that it's cramped, hot, busy, and absolutely mad with the pumping music. It's perfect. All your senses are assailed in the best possible way. That, of course, is my experience and depending on the day of the week and time of day, YMMV.

I was impressed by the width and breadth and depth of the dishes. You go from a stir-fried (sorta) green bean dish, to squid ink noodles to my one of my favorites, the sour chili chicken. I didn't do all of the ordering, but I actually like being surprised with new dishes, new tastes, and there are so many flavors to be had that I didn't want them to stop. Some it spicy, some of it smooth, all of it welcome. Bring on the adventures!
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Wow. Just wow.  That Kung Pao burrito just made me rethink every single burrito I've every eaten ( and let's just say...hundreds have been consumed! ).

Smoky, savory, crunchy... just so delicious.  Can't wait for another...very soon!
author: C S.

description:
Hot Garbage.

After hearing all the hype about this place an opp arrives to shlep it to the mission and see what all the holier-than-thou, cooler-than-you, crafty-as, hipster kids are raving about....and like the hispters that bloviate about this place the food was skin deep and confused about its place in life.  Possibly griped about all the other typical, basic chinese spots that would never try something as inspired as pastrami stir fry.

So we get some take out because eating around hipsters is detrimental to your mental state.

We get 5 dishes.

The mapo tofu was an absolute MSG bomb.. my tastebuds were high AF. i swear i could taste the universe and the universe taste like bootie.

The porridge was inedible.   

The fried rice wasn't that bad but not any better than food ive had in Chicago's chinatown. Why so pricey?  Oh right...hipster tax.

Eggplant a greasy college experiment

Tan tan noodles a peanut butter nightmare.

Aaand ther service. ..typical hipster BS.  "I'm sorry was my order, whuch you asked for, interrupting you?" Does my attore offend your artistic sensibilities such that you can't stand to be within 3ft of me.  Well i guess so does my tip...

Bottomline...is that this place is living proof about a basic rule about "ethnic" food. If nearly all of the people in the restaurant are not of the ethnicity the restaurants food then you should probably leave.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Pretty good. I've always been a little wary about this place because it seems like its just hipster hype, but having recently tried it, it's actually quite good. It's interesting because if you go use the restroom in the back, you have to walk through the kitchen, and you'll see that everyone cooking in the kitchen looks like an old Chinese grandmother/grandfather. So even though they've somehow branded themselves in a way as hip, new age Chinese food with punchy menu lines and clever line items, the kitchen really has some old school stuff going on.

The SO and I came here because we just wanted to grab a light lunch on a weekend. We got the tea-smoked eel and the salt cod fried rice. The tea-smoked eel is pretty freaking amazing. I really loved it. Really delicious, super nice smoky flavor, definitely not traditional Chinese but still so good. The salt cod fried rice is pretty much what you would normally expect from a Chinese restaurant, but still really well executed. I mean I guess it's not fancy or the most amazing fried rice you'll ever eat, but it's fried rice and it's delicious, and I would definitely come back.

Overall, basically a more upscale/better branded Chinese restaurant, but a restaurant that is actually serving up pretty authentic Chinese food even though it's kind of branded like Asian Fusion. The cooks in the back are definitely experts at authentic Chinese cuisine, and I'm definitely a fan. Can't wait to come back soon and try more of this menu.

tldr; seems like hipster Chinese food but it's actually just normal Chinese food (a few dishes are pretty innovative) and good hipster branding and marketing
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Ate there for lunch Friday Nov.27 
Out of beef ribs but the veal ribs substitute was really fantastic. Had tiger salad and long beans also.The reason for the 3 stars was the mache ramen which was no more than Top Ramen in a bowl without the broth for $12.00
You can buy a package of ramen for 20 cents that tastes the same.
The service was fine and everything else was tasty but the ramen was a big bust.
author: Helen K.

description:
Ate:  bacon and rice cake, kung pao pastrami, squid ink noodles with lamb.

The hostess recommended the squid ink noodles.  Thick, black noodles with tasty bits of well-seasoned ground lamb.  The noodles were bland, so we picked out the lamb.

The waitress recommended the kung pao pastrami.  The square chunks of tender pastrami were super flavorful.  The dish is completed with the usual peanuts, celery and bell peppers.  Personally, I'd prefer just a big plate of the pastrami cubes.

The guy in the back - the one with the big, round belly, chopping stuff - recommended the bacon and rice cake.  This was served first, and, by far, the best tasting dish.  The strength of it's flavors rendered the squid ink noodles helpless, and the pastrami kung pao weak in the knees.  However, and yet again, I'd prefer a heaping helping of just the bacon.
author: Sondra H.

description:
Mission Chinese was the second destination as my proper introduction to San Francisco food after La Taqueria, whose hype has inconceivably outgrown its brick walls and wooden benches. Mission Chinese is no different; there's a waitlisted crowd on the sidewalk almost every night. You like tables? Inside, they almost have tables on tables.

My favorite part about Mission Chinese is the look. There's no proper name on the outside, just the old signage in Chinese characters of what the previous restaurant used to be. The inside is plain, with classic Chinese wall decor - men on horseback prancing in a uniform line, faces painted flat and facing forward like cats detecting a thump. Hold on... dim the lights, play some throwback mid-2000s, add a strobe light, and hang a long dragon from the ceiling. That's what the youth like.

"Fried Rice with Cod" is my favorite, mostly because I love rice. Yes, they have standard dishes like "Beef with Broccoli" and some unique, like "Squid Ink Chow Mien." It's all decent/good. If it isn't sprinkle some of that MSG at your table. It's not salt. It's MSG. Try it.
author: Olivier K.

description: Heard so much about this place, but I thought the food was fair. It's not traditional Chinese food, different meat choices such as brisket which sounded interesting to me, but was a disappointment. We had lots of left overs in the fridge that ended in the trash...eventually.
author: Claudia A.

description:
With TV Shows, blogs and all sorts of chatter, Mission Chinese is a restaurant that has all the makings of being a place that is all hyped up, and I wanted to find out if it would deliver! I rounded up 8 close friends who are as down to devour whatever lands in front of them as I am, and we set off on our "Mission" to the Mission to try out this spot.

We arrived to find a line outside the red glowing doorway, and we could just barely make out the sounds of the EDM/Dance/Trance soundtrack playing inside. The smells coming from inside were so ta filling, and my excitement grew with each sweep of the breeze that carried new aromas right to my nostrils. I couldn't wait for our new to be called, and just as I started to wonder when we'd get in, our table was called! 

Id finally made it and I felt like I was entering hallowed ground as I passed through the doorway into the warm, dark and humid dining room, illuminated by glowing red lights and guarded by a giant golden Chinese dragon overhead. At first I was bothered by the temperature, wondering if id be able to enjoy my meal, but that quickly faded as I began to peruse the menu. The dishes here are like nothing you've seen before, bringing together traditional Chinese ingredients in some very inspired and non-traditional ways. 

As a crew that likes to eat and drink, we had about 12-14 dishes on the table for the 9 diners, and by the end of it all, the carnage was something to behold. We ordered the Mongolian Long beans, stir fried with dried Asian chiles, Serrano chiles and chile paste, the Tiki Pork Belly exterior crisped to perfection and complimented by the unctuous and meaty interior and sweet sauce, 3X Bacon with Rice Cakes and Bitter Melon, Tiger Salad, Squid Ink Noodles, Cod Fried Rice, Sour Chili Chicken, Explosively spicy wings and more!

My favorite bit was the 3X Bacon, thin slices of lightly smoked pork belly served with chewy Chinese rice cakes and thinly sliced bitter melon, was an incredible bite of food. The bacon was thin but meaty with a light charcoal/hardwood smoked flavor that played really well with the bitterness of the bitter melon and spicy/savory/salty sauce and the rice cake added the perfect texture. I couldn't stop eating this combo throughout the meal. 

The surprise of the night was the Tiger Salad. Described as simple and light by our server, this dish arrived and had us all confused. On a long plate stood three bundles of lightly dressed fresh herbs, ties together by wide pieces of chow fun rice noodles. They were roughly 3-4" tall! The freshness of the salad was the perfect contrast to the rich and spicy dishes on the table, and I would suggest this as something anyone who comes should order.

The star of the night was the squid ink noodles, which are served with cumin spiced and charred lamb, harissa, a few fresh greens and a tangy yogurt sauce. As with a lot of Asian food, texture is important and the noodles added that beautifully. The ground lamb was delicate and delicious, providing a warm spice from the cumin, which combined nicely with a light heat from the Harissa. The surprise ingredient was the yogurt sauce, which rounded out and carried all of the flavors across your palate, bringing you back for more.  These are clearly freshly made noodles, and taking this to go would ruin their perfectly chewy texture, which is why it's only available dine in, and well worth waiting for!

Bite after bite of this spicy fare had me mopping my brow and downing glass after glass of reasonably priced, moderately cold, sake, which in turn had me focused on the next bite and forgetting about the warmth in the room. We passed dishes for what seemed like an enjoyable eternity, and when we examined our efforts, we all sat back satiated and smiling knowing Mission Chinese has left us much more to explore in a future visit. Tingly lamb face noodle soup, Kung Pao Pastrami, and so much more!

On a scale of one to hype, this place is all that and a bag of fried wontons! I can't wait to go back!
author: Michael T.

description:
Have been wanting to try this for as long as I can remember! Finally a visit to SF and I'm not missing it ....

Got there around 5:30 pm because I have heard about lines but absolutely no problem getting a table in this fairly small, quaintly tacky venue. Can only try a few dishes as we have been eating non-stop.

Grandma's Pork Dumplings in a ham broth: just okay. Dough was a little thick and meat was nothing special. Broth was a little interesting but I wouldn't have guessed ham hock.

Kung Pao Pastrami: hmmm ... rich, very rich. And very different. With peanuts, celery and chili. Gotta give them points for creativity. 

Salt Cod Fried Rice: THE BOMB. Mackerel confit (what???), chinese sausage, veg. Flavor, flavor, flavor.

In our party of 3, I'm the biggest fan. One didn't love it, the other neutral. I have to give them 5* (though 4.5 would be better) for creativity in their ingredients and style. It's genius. And I only tried a few dishes. I love the feel. Nerd-out, cheesy but clean, glam chinese hole-in-the-wall. I can't wait to go back and try the rest of the dishes. Guess I need to find new friends to go with!

Did I mention they donate .75/entree to the SF Food Bank? Almost $300,000 so far? Can you give more than 5*? Because they deserve it for that.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Here, let me say all the things that most people here don't say.
I love this place and I hate this place at the same time.  If this joint had a health code letter grade, it would get a F-

I've never been to an eating establishment where the kitchen looked cleaner than the dining area.  They set their sanitation and silver/napkin area on a dirty shelf right in front of the entrance.  What a great way to have the city dust all over your silverware.  Also, they let all the customers literally walk THRU their kitchen to get to the only bathroom they have on the premise.  I saw a stressed out Chinese cook back there smoking a cigarette while I peed.  The bathroom and the back prep kitchen stunk of cigarette smoke, but all this is okay.  Hey, I get that this place is trying to mimic a hole in the wall joint somewhere in deep mother land of China but c'mon, I don't want to eat like this when I'm paying $80 for some nice culinary grub.  

The menu reads like something that bunch of stoned chefs would eat after a crazy night of doing 350 covers.  It is greasy as hell and hot as hell and good as hell.

I wish they'd invest some money into this joint and get a new carpet and clean all the cobwebs off of the ceiling.  Maybe even new tables and chairs.  But who am I kidding, they probably tell me to go screw myself.  But it would be nice to have some ice in the water.  How they don't have ice when serving insanely spicy food is beyond me.  C'mon, we're throwing you our hard earned cash to eat your good food.  Throw us some bones.

If you like good, spicy, artery clogging food inside a dark, dirty hole, this place is definitely for you.  Be ready to sweat your brains out and eat like a dirty rat.
author: Liz P.

description:
Short version: O to the M to the G. It was wonderful. 

Walked over to the restaurant and almost walked past because of the signage, or lack thereof. My eagle-eyed wife found it, and I was a little hesitant to go inside since it looked like a run-down Chinese-American restaurant. There are times for that, but I was in the mood for something different. I was knocked off my seat, but scrambled back up to continue eating. 

The servers were friendly and quick, so me, my wife and daughter were seated pretty quickly. As a line quickly grew outside, I can see how they stay organized: if they aren't, they are deep in the weeds. 

We ordered the ginger/mint tea, green beans, spring rolls, pork belly and chow mein. Usually I'd say that the pork belly would be the best thing, since, you know, pork belly is amazing. While good, it was first blown away by the spring rolls. They were a wonderful concoction of crunchy and soft. Then the green beans came out and were pleasantly spicy, crunchy andy heavily fought over. If my wife and I renew vows, that is going in there. I deserve half, if not more. I could have spent more time enjoying the tea, but sick wife and sniffly kid = fast'ish dinner. The tea went well with the meal and stood out on it's own. The chow mein with eggplant was good too, and my wife and daughter took the lions share. I was content with my pork, spring rolls and beans. And I know when to quit when ahead. 

I'm definitely going back, closer to 6pm next time if we go on a Friday night.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
What everyone says is true:  Mission Chinese is a suuuper hipster Chinese restaurant in the Mission.  There's always a line around dinner time, but thankfully, it moves pretty quickly.  Once inside, your senses will become intoxicated with piquant white pepper and hot chili aromas, as your eyes adjust to the dim lighting from a sinuous paper dragon overhead, dotted with red and purple orbs on its side.

As you sit down, you grab some menus and peruse the options.  Oh, cool, this menu has more items than what was listed on the door!  At your side, your friend pouts, "Why does my spoon have food in it?"  Well, that doesn't bode well.  Our waitress casually replies, "Oh, your spoon has food in it? Heh. Heh," as she whisked the spoon away to replace it with a fresh one.  That was easy.  

We ordered the Westlake porridge, squid ink noodles, thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes, and grandma's pork dumplings.  All dishes were tasty, although not in the traditional sense.  Hipster Chinese food is nothing but traditional, after all!  Our winning dishes were probably the porridge and the squid ink noodles.  The former because of the savory scallion, Dungeness crab, and flavor of home-cooked porridge consistency, and the squid ink noodles for its unique black and chewy noodles with greens on top.

While tasty, we came away feeling unsatisfied that we didn't have THE dish that carried the flavor that matched the lovely piquant aroma that greeted us when we first walked through the door.  Where art thou, l'eau de M.C.?  Our best guess was that we should have ordered that salted cod fried rice dish...but we're not certain.

All in all, a great place for a quick bite to eat, but none of the dishes we had really stood out.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here, but I'd be curious to try the salted cod fried rice if some friends wanted to try it out :)
author: Brittany N.

description:
Been wanting to try at this famous spot? Come for lunch! No lines, no wait, all the greatness. 

Tried the pastrami kung pow burrito - perfectly portable delivery and lunch appropriate portion of their classic dish. The off menu "secret dumplings" are a must try. The broccoli and brisket was a smoky delight, if not just a little on the salty side - but that should be obvious and expected. 

Best service in town was the cherry on top of this visit. I'll be back and you should, too!
author: emma l.

description:
We came in at 6:30pm on a Saturday without a reservation and were seated by 6:45pm. This was just the right time to come in, as we left, there were hoards of people sitting outside waiting for their table.

After the meal, I do not understand why this place is hyped up. The four of us went in on a few dishes family style, which is probably the way to go. Vegan Dan Dan Noodles, Vegan Ma Po Tofu, Szechuan Long Beans. and Garlic Fried Chicken would have definitely been enough for the mix of our vegan / omnivore posse.

However, our server never brought us rice after we asked for some or checked on us until after we had already finished, which made eating the ma po tofu very difficult, as it has a very assertive flavor (a lot of star anise going on). While the vibe of the place is interesting, the service was poor (did not bring us rice after they asked us for some), and the food didn't make up for it. All of it was very salty and it felt like an unbalanced meal, overall. 

I would skip it.
author: Nathan T.

description: I ordered the Kong Pao Pastrami. I was shocked by the quality of the food as well as the how much salt they put  in the dish.  Everything else, the veggie, peanuts, sauce, potato, red bell pepper, was good. And I can tell how tasty the pastrami will be if they put less salt when marinating it. What a pity that they put triple amount of salt than appropriate in the beef.
author: Rui Z.

description: Last time I was there it was the junk food recipe : fat, salt, but excess spice instead sugar. A lot of hipsters slumming in a dirty restaurant  just to be seen, it couldn't be the food. Unfortunately, in SF, being different means hip, even if it isn't good by any standard. I will try it one more time and revise this negative review if the food merits it.
author: William M.

description:
Everything was good, enjoyed the long beans, dan dan noodles, and mapo tofu. Everything was delicious, although I will say the long beans were incredibly salty (I enjoyed them, but they may not be for everybody).

Service was mediocre - the same person was waiting our table and then going outside to seat the next guests, which meant she'd sometimes disappear for a bit. Also, it got pretty cold in the restaurant, especially after the front door was left open for a while (not really sure why, it was 50 out).
author: Eric F.

description:
The food was really good.
Their mule cocktail was delicious.
The service was really good.
And yet I'm giving it two stars, because I have no interest in ever going back.

- WAY too loud. Not from the crowd, from the music blasting.
- WAY too dark. We took out our phone flashlights to see the food. 
- Really crowded. Our party of six was seated at a square table pushed against a wall. (There was a constant shuffle to make sure we didn't interfere with each other during the meal.) The entire place was packed to the gills. The wait staff are amazing that they can serve food with the tables so close to each other.

Apparently this vibe appeals to some people, because they were packed and there was a line outside. I just found it incredibly overbearing and stressful.

So if you enjoy the ambiance of a nightclub while eating dinner, this place might be exactly what you're looking for. 

It's just not for me.
author: Jason G.

description: This place is amazing. I had mazing squid ink pasta, and perfectly cooked guylan. Can't wait to return.
author: C R.

description:
I was with a friend in San Francisco and was craving Chinese food. We decided to walk around and we stumbled upon this restaurant. Seeing that the wait list was short, i wrote my name on the clipboard outside and waited approximately 5 minutes. I'm grateful that they allowed my small pet inside (unless they didn't see him as he's quite small).

We were seated in a communal table which means that we were seated in a long table with other strangers.

The bathroom was awkward to get to because you have to go through the kitchen while the workers were working.

ATMOSPHERE:
The restaurant itself is pretty small. I would estimate that it's about 60 feet long and 25 feet wide with about 16 tables. The lighting was dark, mostly red which hurt my eyes. The music playing was loud also which made it harder for me and my friend to communicate. The table I was seated at didn't have the basic condiments of salt and pepper along with soy sauce.

FOOD:
Most of their entrees were more than $10-15. The menu was small for a Chinese restaurant and depending on what you get, rice doesn't come with your entree. I ordered the sour chicken and it was amazing! If you love chicken I highly recommend it. For $13, the food I got didn't fill me up which is unusual for a Chinese restaurant. Also their servings are small.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
They seemed busy and weren't given drinks for about 15 minutes. The water came in warm along with a jar of water and it seemed like they had jars of water just waiting to be given at tables. Not once did the waiter come and see if we were doing okay. 

Will I come back? Most likely not but I'm intrigued to try some more of their food! So if you wanna try something new, go ahead and try this restaurant out.
author: Aj C.

description: Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.  I thought it would be overrated but everything was tasty and the service was great.
author: Ray Z.

description:
While I do enjoy their food, tonight's customer service experience left much to be desired. I ordered three entrees (for four people) and a side of rice -- and was told about an hour. Order arrived 1 hour and 50 minutes later and only contained two entrees, one of which was completely cold. 

I phoned inquiring about a refund and I was told that a) I didn't order the third entree and b) that if I indeed had four people to feed, I should've ordered more rice (imply the customer is lying, always a low blow) and that c) if I want a refund she would send the driver back to pick up the food.

Though exasperated, I politely asked to speak to a manager and she said that wouldn't be possible... nor at any point in the future. And I quote "if you don't like it, you don't have to order it". 

I am online and find exactly zero ways to contact the business, other than to leave an online review. 

So be it. 

Danny Bowien -- if you're still at all involved with managing this restaurant, please incorporate a system for employees to be accountable. It seems even posting on Yelp doesn't result in followup. Piss poor way to treat your loyal clientele.
author: Sarah N.

description:
I've heard of Mission Chinese and the hype for years. Finally, my husband and I tried it out on a Friday night. We made a reservation for 7:45, which meant someone put our name on the list for us. This saved us a lot of time, even though we still waited till about 8 pm for a table. 

We definitely ordered too much food! We looked at the prices and figured that since they were so reasonable they must be small portions. So wrong! We ordered four dishes - the 3x cooked bacon, the pastrami, the cherry cola ribs, and the squid ink noodles. All were really good! The pastrami was probably my least favorite of the bunch. It was good, but the others were so remarkable that the pastrami just didn't hold up next to them. The ribs were so tender and the sauce was sticky and sweet - perfect! As everyone says, the 3x bacon is not to be missed, but its not because of the bacon, its because of the rice dumplings/patties that accompany it. They are chewy pillows of heaven. Sort of like gnocchi? I also really enjoyed the squid ink noodles with lamb, which had more of a middle eastern flavor set. 

So, ordering four dishes between two people gave us enough leftovers for dinners the next two nights. This might be exactly the way to play Mission Chinese - if you're going to wait in the line, order a lot of food so you can enjoy leftovers for the next few days!
author: Maria M.

description:
SF is lucky to have delivery of this caliber.  

Our delivery guy waited 15 minutes in the lobby of our hotel for me to wake up from my pre dinner nap.  He was so nice and sweet, taking it all in stride.  Wow.  

Food veers on the oily side and pretty salty, but didn't seem to have the same MSG effect.  

Enjoyed:
-Market Greens, choy sum, large portions and quite light!
-Grandma's Spicy Lamb Dumplings, good, gets a little old after awhile
-Stir-Fried Pork Jowls and radishes, tender pork and loved how they cooked the ENTIRE radish.  
-Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes, LOVED this, smoky bacon and chewy rounds of doughiness.  SO good.  

Interesting and unique take on Chinese.  I probably couldn't eat it everyday, probably would burn a hole in my intestines, but a playful spin on traditional dishes. 

$62, tax, tip, delivery.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Last time I came back and ordered the cumin lamb, there were only 3 flecks of ground lamb in it. they've really gone downhill
author: Mimi M.

description:
Mission Chinese Food. You hold a dear place in my heart, especially because I had you for the first time after my first half marathon. I was tired, hungry and you saved my starved body. 

Since then, I've come back 4-5x. Reason? They're probably the most decent place to get real Sichuan food in SF, as far as I know. The restaurant is clean, food is quality (although sometimes greasy and salty), service is good and the beer selection pairs well with Sichuan food. A lot of the food, however, are too greasy and salty for me sometimes. They use a lot of Sichuan peppercorns and chili flakes and chili oil, sometimes to a point where it is overbearing and makes everything tastes the same. That being said, it becomes important that you know what to order to have a well balanced meal and experience here.

My suggestion is to order 2 spicy dishes and 2 mild dishes. By mild, I mean that it won't kill your taste buds. My favorite spicier dishes are the Mapo tofu, Mouth Watering (Chong ching) Chicken, Thrice cooked bacon, string beans. My favorite mild dishes are: Egg Egg Noodle (Dan dan noodles with poached egg), Cumin Lamb Ribs (definitely flavorful but not spicy), Salt Cod Fried Rice. 

Keep your meal balanced and pair it with a nice white, crisp beer/wine, you'll survive, and leave happy. That being said, this place doesn't not joke around with their sichuan food. It's going to be numbing, but delicious, if you know what I mean. Also, I recommend the icelandic white ale to drink with your spicy food.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Well, I guess I just don't get it.

I've heard rave reviews about Mission Chinese Food but I really find it to be simply Chinese food with a minor twist, certainly not enough to warrant the inflated price. Again, I just don't get it.

We started with salad wrapped in rice noodle and it was a nice light, refreshing way to start the meal. The herbs had good flavor and the ginger sauce was a nice touch too. Then we moved onto the thrice cooked bacon which is just oily pork slices stir fried with rice cakes and a ton of spices. Yeah...it sounds good in theory but I really couldn't get any subtlety of flavor when my tastes buds are blown out with spice, oil and fat. Really hard to pick out an intricacies of the dish. We finished with the spicy beef chow mein which again, is just oily chow mein. The mustard greens on top were a nice touch but not enough to deem this anything more than another bowl of chow mein.

I'll end this review with some insight. Maybe it's not you, Mission Chinese Food, maybe it's me. Either way, I'll stick to my lower cost Chinese staples when I'm hankering for some wok-fired goodness.
author: Christina L.

description:
Mission Chinese is one of few restaurants I would not hesitate for a second to award five stars. 

I came here with a group in 2013 and my Chinese-American friend placed the order for the group. Based on her recommendations, we all shared the pork belly, long beans, salt cod fried rice (combining two of my favorite Portuguese foods -- shout out to southern Massachusetts!), chow mein, and pickles. A couple of us in the group were fairly picky eaters and despite that, the food was gone faster than a sorority girl from my bed when her mom unexpectedly shows up on campus early Saturday morning (that happens, right?)

The best dish by FAR was the Westlake Rice Porridge. I essentially stole the bowl from my friend and finished it off -- savory beef, hot, salty broth, fresh cilantro, egg, and tobiko (don't pretend you know what it is - 9.5/10 people will Google this word).

When I think of iconic/the best San Francisco food, Mission always pops into my brain first. Come to think of it: When I picture the best meal I've had post-college, Mission is still standing proudly on the winners' podium pretentiously and unapologetically kicking everyone else off the edge.
author: Eric L.

description: Out of this world Iced Coffee and Mapo  Tofu at Mission Chinese! Unequalled and way upgraded several notches up!!!!  The Iced Coffee had coconut milk without the cocnut after taste and it had a hint of lime. The Mapo Tofu had  mushrooms, sauce, delicate tofu that are mixed lovingly together with a magic spicy sauce. Very quick, personable and efficient service!! A few garage parking lots in the area if you want to drive. Danny Bowien  was in the restaurant himself signing his new book. He was very unassuming and friendly to the patrons which his staff assumed as well iin terms of customer experience. Great atmosphere.
author: Kitty D.

description: Still salivating over that tiki pork appetizer! Checked this place out as soon as they opened to avoid a crowd and had no problem getting a table. Food was out quick but the waitress looked semi annoyed the whole time. In a sketchy looking  neighborhood but parking was easy to find. Will 100% be back.
author: Betty D.

description: My first impression of the food here was that it's very salty (and it wasn't just me who thought this in my group). I could sometimes taste the salt chunks in the food as well. I'm not sure why the food wasn't properly prepared, maybe it's because we went in on a Sunday afternoon when the restaurant was quite busy but I don't think it was worth paying $15-20 per menu.
author: Lori K.

description:
Quite good. If you're looking for amazing atmosphere & fine dining, this isn't really your place  but if you're looking for FANTASTIC flavors, this IS your place!!
The porridge is my fav, my husband & I get it every time!
Free delivery w/in a short radius of the restaurant & quite inexpensive outside that area.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Can anyone say, "Hipsterssss?"

My bf loves this place. I think its the combination of the decor and everything is spicy Don't get me wrong, the decor is...modern. Not really romantic. Kinda too hollister dim. The music makes me feel like I need to go out to the clubs right after. All really confusing, I feel like the name doesn't really meet it's standard. For me the spice is too overpowering. I like to taste the ingredients and not the spice. We've eaten here twice because I really wanted to give it a second chance but it's just not for me. The pineapple fried rice was good but still a bit spicy. My bf got the lamb and I felt it was doused with cumin or something and of course spice. Not my cup of tea.
author: Lynn C.

description: Food was very good but kind of pricey. The service staff was pretty surly and ruined the experience. The woman checking names was rude and made comments like, "These people must live in a barn. They don't understand what close the door means!" Not something you should say out loud about your customers. Don't need to to spend $140 on Chinese food for that kind of treatment. Won't be back.
author: Dave W.

description:
The good: the pork belly appetizer

The mediocre: the smashed cucumbers; the matcha, squid ink noodles

The bad: the ridiculously oversalted lamb ribs accompanied by slices of Wonder bread; the tepid beer

The worst: the way-too-hip-to-be-expected-to-wait-on-people, attitude-oozing-out-of-every-pierced-orifice waitress whose "service" did not even merit the sub-10% tip I left
author: DarkwingDick _.

description:
We came off lunch and there luckily wasn't a wait. My favorites were the lamb and the pork belly. The lamb had tons of flavor and didn't have the gamy taste, which was my biggest concern. The tea smoked eel and the egg noodles were so-so and I wouldn't get those again. The eel was interesting but flavors were bland and the egg noodles were too sweet. We also tried the mapo tofu but I was used a more spicy and numbing one from a restaurant back home.
