I would come if you are looking for Asian fusion kind of food. Definitely had a huge hipster vibe. Service was okay but nothing memorable. We pretty much kept to ourselves.
author: Allison S.

description:
Come here for a late lunch and avoid the lines! Purely by chance, my gal pal and I got in this past Friday - when hundreds of thousands of hipsters were descending upon SF for Outside Lands! We came in around 1 pm and were seated immediately. Thank you, restaurant gods!

I've eaten at Mission Chinese before, probably about 2 years ago. At the time, my palate was still getting used to SF cuisine and I wasn't a huge fan. If you come here expecting the traditional Panda Express fare (and trust me, I'm still a Panda fanatic), you'll be sorely disappointed. But if you show up with an open mind and tummy, prepare to be impressed.

Two people with normal appetites could easily split an entree or two, but since we were on vacay and don't often eat gourmet food such as this, we opted for three plates of food: Salted cod fried rice, egg egg noodles as well as spicy Mongolian long beans. Surprisingly, my favorite dish was by far the beans. They were pretty damn spicy, but not a "oh shit, I'm going to have indigestion later", more of a "my mouth is slightly numb from the burn, but I can't stop eating" feeling. I liked it. Second favorite was the noodle dish, minus the pile of jalapeños on top - an easy fix. Rice was also excellent (kudos to that butter flavor!), would order any of these again in a heartbeat. 

Since it was Friday, after 12 pm, and we were not at work, beer and sake were definitely in order. Helped to cool our burning tongues. And of course we couldn't eat everything, so it was boxed up and properly handed off to a homeless person down the street. Let's just say if I were hungry and without money, would definitely be lurking around this restaurant for handouts... 

Worth the wait, definitely worth the price (really affordable plates and huge portions), a winner in my book.
author: Abby S.

description:
Please. Some of these reviews are ridiculous. People are complaining that a restaurant that serves "Kung pao pastrami"... Is not authentic???

I am pretty sure these whiners would have a hard time finding better kung pao pastrami in China. 

Mission Chinese serves up the most amazing hipster Chinese on the planet.
The triple cooked bacon is one of the best things I've ever tasted in my life  

5.5 stars.
author: david l.

description:
I wanted to like this place but the food here was unfortunately way too salty for me..... Even for Chinese food. 

They were missing a lot from the menu since I came here right before they closed. I may come back to try other dishes. 

The servers started putting all the chairs up on the table to clean while we were still eating. I guess they are truly Chinese when it comes to customer service.
author: Yoshi O.

description:
"Dude, you got all of the wrong things."

Not exactly the kind of thing I like to hear after trying a restaurant for the first time, but especially so in this case.  I've been wanting to try Mission Chinese Food for so long, seeing all of the reviews and hearing all the praise heaped on them made me that much more hopeful for a great meal.  It's disappointing that it didn't happen, but I could see it being better a second time around...

**Apologies for the poor photo quality...didn't want to annoy people with the flash.

- TEA-SMOKED EEL - Fresh Rice Noodle, Chinese Celery, Salted Plum Hoisin, Braised Pork, Cognac Soy...$9
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco-4?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#JmyWO6-U2P4IdlPTf3WgNQ)
It sounded so good on the menu, but this one did the least for me.  The eel wasn't bad, but the hoisin and soy dominated the dish with a salty flavor.  It was so strong I couldn't taste much of the braised pork.

- TIKI PORK BELLY - Soy Caramel, Mandarin Orange, Pickled Pineapple, Shaved Coconut, Macadamia Nuts...$10
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco-4?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#SatHmOmubxV-UOuj5hZhwg)
Although it was on the sweet side, I thought this dish tasted the best.  The blend of flavors was nice, but the cuts of pork belly left me wanting.  One piece was all meat and the other was all fat.

- KUNG PAO PASTRAMI - Explosive Chili, Celery, Potato, Sweet Peppers, and Roasted Peanut...$12
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco-4?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#OiaERJDipb2u5Ku9mOsr2g)
I don't usually get "Kung Pao" dishes, but this one was pretty good.  I really liked how the dish had a slight kick and that the pieces of pastrami were so meaty.  If it wasn't as salty as it was, this would have been a terrific dish.

- SALT COD FRIED RICE - Mackerel Confit, Chinese Sausage, Lettuce, Egg...$11
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco-4?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#xz7o_XqXfm7cY94Rp--e5Q)
Even though I wish they left out the cilantro (not a fan), it was a solid dish for the most part.  The dish was well seasoned and the salt cod added just the right amount of salty/fishy flavor.

- MONGOLIAN LONG BEANS - with Xinjiang Spices, Horseradish, and Chili Oil...$10
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco-4?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#oRiu_GaiMEyx4tzL-AKhJg)
Not bad, but not great.  Although there was nothing wrong with the dish, it was hard for me to get excited because I just had a similar version at Hawker Fare in Oakland right before this one that tasted much better.

- SMOKED BEEF BRISKEY NOODLE SOUP - Cheung Fun, Mire Pork, Bok Choy, Cardamom Broth...$12
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco-4?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#7yebO14nZqr7UjkshUY44Q)
Like the long beans, I was rather indifferent on this one.  The broth was light yet flavorful and the bowl was filled with generous amount of goodies.  However, again on a personal level, it was hard for me to get passed the cilantro.

(If it wasn't clear already, I should note that I have a serious distaste for cilantro.  So in fairness, given that it was used in nearly every dish we had, it was hard for me to really fall for any particular dish regardless of how much I tried to set my bias aside.)

Overall, I'd give the food THREE AND A HALF STARS, but I rounded down because of the service.  Although our server was attentive enough, she seemed to cop a bit of an attitude with one of my friends as we were putting in our order.  Still, I definitely want to come back to give their food another chance.

"Let me know when you want to go again - I'll show you the right things to get."

No pressure buddy, no pressure.
author: Mike L.

description:
Super glad that our Airbnb host and a guy at Brasserie Saint James recommended Mission Chinese to us, because our lunch here was faaaaantastic!  As surely everybody knows by now, Mission Chinese is in a completely unassuming storefront that looks like a crap Chinese takeout joint, but is in fact an awesome, casual, incredibly creative restaurant that should not be missed!  

We had no problems getting a table for Friday lunch, and between four of us shared the Chongqing chicken wings, the Mongolian Long Beans, Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes, and Broccoli Beef Brisket, with some steamed rice.  I am drooling just remembering this meal.

Okay first up - chicken wings. We were warned that Szechuan spice is different than spicy food we may be used to - it sort of numbs your mouth more than overtly burns it.  This is totally true, and these chicken wings will definitely do that to you.  They were dry-fried, which my husband loved, as he is a chicken wing aficionado and sometimes gets tired of the ones soaking in sauce.  Crispy, piping hot, and numbingly spicy as previously mentioned, these were a hit for my husband, and I liked them, but not as much as he did.  I loved the texture, maybe the numbing was too much for me?  I don't know.  They're worth a try, though.

Everything else, however, was perfection.  The broccoli beef brisket isn't spicy at all, and isn't in the same league as any "beef with broccoli" you've had at a Chinese restaurant.  The brisket tasted right out of a Jewish grandmother's kitchen, and the dish was full of leafy, rich-green Chinese broccoli, not regular broccoli.  Smoky, hearty, with tender meat and yet somehow seeming healthy-ish from the abundance of veg, it was a great dish.  The bacon and rice cakes may have been my favorite - this unusual dish features chewy Chinese rice cakes, sort of shaped like UFOs.  They are addictive, glutinous little discs of yumminess, and they were drenched in savory sauce and surrounded by crispy, hearty pieces of thick bacon.  YUM.  The long beans were perfectly cooked, boldly flavored with chili oil and horseradish, and a great companion to the rest of the meal.

We talked about the meal the rest of the day, my husband saying it was the best Chinese food he's ever had, and I think I must agree.  I'm only sad we didn't have room to try the other dishes, because everything on the menu sounded truly delicious!  And $58 for 4 people to be completely full of delicious food ain't bad at all!
author: Meredith A.

description:
One word: SALTY!
So many reviews mention that their food is too salty.. why aren't they getting it?
Besides the salt, everything has a great flavor. Sour chicken, ma po tofu, matcha squid ink noodles, and steamed greens were all yummy. Could be so good if they didn't ruin it with all the salt.
author: Vee N.

description:
After having a wonderful meal in NYC restaurant i really wanted to explore our local, original place.  I read all the reviews and had what i think was a reasonable expectation level. 

Upon arrival, i asked to use the restroom to wash my hands. I knocked on the door and a man came out--a worker of some sort who glowered at me as if i had bothered him.  The cigarette smoke that followed him out set the scene for our dinner. 

Rude waitresses that seem to be annoyed when asked questions. Dirty (plastic) water glasses were dropped onto the table along with a lukewarm, not overly clean bottle of water. No thank you i will go without any. 

Our food came out in random order. The cod rice was suggested---and as it was really fishy, no one ate it.   The salt and pepper lamb is a delight and i would eat it over and over. The other dishes were good. Except the one dish i had been excited to have my guests experience--the spicy chicken wings--were massively overcooked. Sad.
author: sue m.

description:
Ordered Mission Chinese through Postmates on Friday night. My subtotal of the charges was $44 based on the 3 items of food I ordered. However, when the final credit card charge went through, the subtotal increased to $52.30 - nearly 20% higher. This increase was not explained, and certainly not approved. 

I emailed Postmates, and they advised that MCF had increased the subtotal of charges. They said this was inexplicable from their end and refunded me the difference. 

Not only did MFC try to pull a fast one on the charges with me, but the food was so bad, it was ultimately inedible. I threw it all away. I swear the chicken in the sesame chicken was rancid. I'm not by any means a picky eater, or have crazy high expectations, but frankly this was the most awful dinner I have had in a VERY long time. 

In short: buyer beware with this company, or at least carefully check your credit card statement.
author: Liz C.

description:
I was so disappointed last time when we didn't get to go here the last time we were here (they're closed Wednesdays) but we made it our business to make sure that we got there this time! 

I loved it but it's definitely not your traditional Chinese. Yes, it has some of the elements of what we know as Chinese food - but for the most part it's way different. Almost an experimental Chinese - and I love that! 

When you walk in, it's one of those hipster places that doesn't really have a sign. This reminds me of Ludo's place in LA - they both have the same thing going on with the old sign of the previous business above the door. The Mission district definitely reminds me of DTLA. A bit grungy and up and coming and definitely a bit hipster. 

The inside is pretty dark. There is a gigantic paper mâché dragon above all the tables by the ceiling and the tables aren't much. There isn't salt on the tables - just a shaker of MSG. Hipster. I kinda want to say this place looks a little dirty - but it could just be dark.

Now for the food:

Tea Smoked Eel Rolls - I'm not a huge eel fan but I can tell this was cooked well - and I actually picked the eel meat out of the roll - my only gripe was the skin was a little flabby for my taste. The eel here was way better than the eel I had at Jose Andres' Bazaar in LA and you could really taste the tea. Not a bad dish at all! And definitely the best tasting eel that I've had.  

Sour Chili Chicken - Oh my god! I do not have words for how much I loved this dish! This dish almost seems to have a basis in the more traditional black bean chicken dish - as those beans were still in the dish but there were so many other flavors. I LOVE romanesco! And this was cooked to perfection! It was so good - I was literally picking them out of the dish - and I'm not the type of girl who's typically picking veggies out of my plate and gobbling them up - but they were amazing! I also loved that pickled Serrano chili pieces. The mixture of the pickled taste and the heat - absolutely amazing! Loved Loved Loved! 

Cumin Lamb Ribs - this was Pump's dish and he said he liked it but they needed a little salt but they were definitely very cumin-y! They looked a little on the dry side and I think they needed a little sauce but they were nice and fatty according to him.

Westlake Rice Porridge- this was my first time having anything like this. I liked it - although I wasn't as obsessed with it as I was with my chili chicken dish! It was what it sounds like - a thick rice porridge - with bits of crab and bbq slow cooked pork. That to me, was a little off putting and I could have done without the smokey pork flavor - but Pumpkie liked it - so to each its own. You'll have to try it for yourself to see how you feel about it! 

Overall, it was an amazing meal. That sour chili chicken is to die for! And... Bi-Rite is around the corner so you can go get some ice cream after your meal!
author: Sam L.

description: I didn't get to try much, but we loved the pork belly here! We are looking forward to going back.
author: Greg F.

description:
This has been on my list for the longest time, even before they turned into Lung Shan full time. So imagine the disappointment that consumed me after my first bite. This place is over-hyped and EXTREMELY OVER PRICED. My points of reference/comparison: I grew up eating home-cooked chinese food, dined in many of the chinese restaurants in SF Chinatown, Richmond, Sunset, and have resided in, and traveled throughout, China during college. 

The ambiance/atmosphere. Imagine a hodgepodge of stereotypical Chinese decor (the dragon, the communist-era poster, the paintings of horses), dim/non-existent lighting except for a single eerie red bulb along with a string of Christmas icicle lights, in a hole-in-the-wall restaurant-esque Chinese restaurant, with 90s club/psychedelic music bumping in the background, staffed by hipster wait staff who speak perfect English. Oh and by the way, if you are unfortunate enough to be seated in one of the middle tables, be prepared to rub elbows and eavesdrop on your fellow diners. In summation, the environment was repulsive and offensive. 

The food:

1) pork belly (aka: hong shao rou): i don't understand why there was chinese new year coconut shaving on top of the two fatty piece of pork. and I really dont understand why there was a half slice of pineapple and a cocktail umbrella. The pork was extremely fatty, even for the belly cut, and it was overpoweringly salty. 

2) salt cod fried rice: if you are gonna advertise it as salt cod, please actually have salt cod. aside from that, I have no other complaints about this dish, it was done a-okay, but I have had way better chinese sausage/egg fried rice for a fraction of the price.  

3) thrice cooked bacon with rice cake: let me re-name the dish for you, it should actually be called "rice cake with a few small piece of bacon." This dish unnecessarily spicy, why? The "bacon" (aka lap yook) is a cantonese (southern) dish, and you will rarely (if ever) fine spicy food in canton. The entire dish consisted of stir fried rice cake (which is a Northern Chinese dish), interspersed here and there with a few small piece of "bacon." There is a reason why there are both Northern and Southern Chinese cuisine...because the two should not mingle together! This is served with a side of exorbitant price.   

4) the tea-eel wrap: this one gets points for creativity in concept, but it gets negative points for execution. The rice paper and the eel, fine. But who's idea was it to stuff it with celery leafs (the parts that you typically throw out!), which gives it a) a weird texture, and b) a nasty herb-y taste. 

Total bill for 2 people with tips: 50 dollars. 

FYI: you can find the same (if not better caliper food) at almost any Chinese restaurant. just because you do not see fancy schamcy english names like "thrice cooked bacon" and "salt cod fried rice" does not mean they dont have it. Do yourself a favor, bring a friend who speaks/reads the language and have them order, you will realize that Chinese restaurants that charge a fair/cheap price serve more than coconut shrimp and kung pao chicken.
author: Long C.

description:
Ok I thought I would give this place another chance (I'm too generous) AND IT WAS COMPLETELY AWFUL!!! Ordered the tofu plate with mushrooms and holy crap that shit was SOOOOO PEPPERY AND EACH BITE OF MUSHROOM WAS LIKE THEY SEASONED IT WITH A HANDFUL OF SALT! Me n my bf felt like our tongues were numb from all the salt. Disgusting! We told the waitress (I hate doin this) and she tasted it and offered for us to change our order. Would have given this place a 1 star but the waitress was extremely accommodating to us. Thanks lady! (She def must've thought the plate was Too salty also lol). Also ordered the cod fried rice and there were literally 3 mini pieces of cod in there. Tasted like regular rice with chopped green onions....

Long story short the food here sucks I don't get it. And I even heard a guy at the table next to us say "the food was not good. I'm not coming back, I would rather go to Panda Express" DITTO
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I'm only going to talk about one thing here...

The chicken wings.

These wings defy traditional explanation. They arrive liberally doused with spices but crispy and not overwhelmingly moist like most wings. I don't know exactly what spices constitute the blend that these wings are cooked with, but the first bite captures your senses like nothing I've experienced before. I saw stars as the flavor wave made my mouth tingle. It was a borderline psychedelic experience. I questioned everything about life, fate, and reason. For a moment, I forgot where I was. And this was just one chicken wing.

Be prepared. Mission Chinese will change your life. Embrace that prospect, order the wings, and get ready to transcend existence.
author: Miles H.

description: mids service, salty ass food holy shit !!! worst ma po tofu ive ever had. the amount of non-asian ppl eating here is indicative of how bad the food is tbh
author: Eric C.

description:
Ever been dating in the dark...in a co-op? Oh great, either have I! *high five* Well, if you ever want to experience it, this is probably the only place I can think of. 

Once you walk in, you won't be greeted by their waiters. Instead, you'll be greeted by deafeningly loud retro hip hop and R&B music, a barely lit room (so watch your steps), and close quarters that are small enough to induce claustrophobia (if you don't have it already). And on top of that, if you're planning to enjoy your dinner with some privacy, you can throw that out the door if you're visiting on a weekend. You're more likely to be seated at a 'co-op' table (unless you're willing to endure the long wait).

You may be thinking...what the eff is a 'co-op' table?! Great question! It's one big, rectangular table where a bunch of random people are seated next to each other. Sounds like fun, right? Oh, but watch out...some neighbors can get pretty friendly. One of our neighbors had no qualms about chiming into our conversation and another neighbor used a generous amount of our hand sanitizer before proceeding to share that amongst his group of friends. I suppose it's one step better than having frisky neighbors, but not by much.

On top of that, there was a dissonance between their 'hip' Asian decor and their ambiance. If you can see in this dark room, you'll notice that among the Chinese paintings displaying on the walls, there are also dimly lit, red-glowing lanterns hanging from one side of the room to another. All the while loud and fast beating music is blasting in the background. I guess it's a plus if you wanted to take a picture for your IG using a red lantern filter. Go ahead and use that #nofilter shamelessly! You know you want to! (;

Without further ado, the main course(s)...

+Forbidden Fried Rice: When using the word 'forbidden' to describe a dish it better be so darn good that it's a sin to take one bite out of it. Sadly, this lackluster dish wasn't it...far from it. Not only did it lack the typical nutty flavor (in fact, it probably lacked all flavors), but it also lacked the chewy texture. Though it complemented our entrées, it definitely was not mouthwatering foodgasmic.

+Dan Dan Noodles (aka Egg Noodles): I had such high hopes for this dish, but, alas, it just didn't hit the spot. Don't let the vibrant colors and the delicious smell of these noodles deceive you. Once you begin mixing the noodles, you'll uncover the fresh smell of ginger. But, be careful when taking a bite out of those noodles because...little did you know, these saucy noodles are jam-packed with ginger flavors! So much so that the first bite felt like a punch in my throat...it BURNED so badly! Definitely took some getting used to. But, even then, it just wasn't my cup of tea. The ginger taste was so overwhelming that I couldn't taste anything else. If you really like ginger, this just might be for you! Otherwise, it'll just seem like they drenched these noodles in a jar filled with ginger sauce.

Before we even finished our meals, our waiter began circling around us, indicating it was time to go. The food left such a bad aftertaste in my mouth (literally!) that we didn't mind. Definitely not worth the price...over-priced and over-hyped. This place isn't to die for, but it also wasn't the worst thing ever. Just don't come with high hopes and expectations. But, our Uber driver made up for it with his epic music as he drove us away from this place and into the sunset (yes, I'm being a bit melodramatic d:)!
author: Jacque C.

description:
I've only ordered delivery.  The fact that I can even get Chinese food of this caliber delivered to my door is a great thing in of itself.  

Between the chef & co-founder Danny Bowien winning the James Beard Award in 2013, & all the national accolades he has garnered before & since, it was only a matter of time for MCF to become the chronically packed mainstay that it is.  

Say what you will about the venue...
Hipster.
Pricey.
Subpar digs...

My view? 

Hipsters are everywhere.  No big deal.
Being pricier than other Chinese joints is not a fail per se.  In life, I believe you get what you pay for.
Subpar digs?  It is a pop up you know.  And ultimately it should be about the food.  

The food...
Pork dumplings.  Light & flavorful.  They are not fried, but served in a broth.  Very nice.

Pork belly.  It may seem small, & it is indeed listed under small dishes on the menu.  But you get 2 good sized pieces, & they are crisp, rich, & juicy.  Lip smacking good.  Literally.

Salt cod fried rice.  I'm a pork fried rice girl.  This version is a nice change up from that.  Full of cod flavor.  I understand other yelpers claiming this to be too salty, but I myself like salty.  If you don't care for fish or salty, probably not for you.  

Kung pao pastrami.  I love pastrami, & this dish again is a nice change up from the traditional options.  Very smoky.  It's obvious this meat received a lot of smoked love before it landed on your plate.  Tender, spicy.  A win.

Spicy beef chow mein.  Wow!  This is the star so far in my MCF cast of characters.  The chow mein noodles are fat & pillowy soft.  Heavenly.  Made me think of a long, thinned out version of gnocchi.  A very zesty dish.  And when they say spicy, they mean it.  Skirt steak was delish, but honestly w the chow mein & the spicy flavors being so fantastic, I don't think the meat matters.  A major win.

Innovative & fresh, MCF is killing it.  Still.
4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Love the flavors. Trice cooked bacon is my favorite. I normally call in to pick up the food. That takes much less time than if you walk in.
author: K Z.

description:
Oh man where to begin. 

I haven't left bed nor have any of my other three friends after eating here last night. We had the beef tartare, beef chow mein, pickled cabbage, pastrami, pork belly and within a few hours of leaving (we all four shared one bottle of sake, and then we all went home shortly after dinner) My boyfriend and myself began showing common symptoms of food poisoning within 1-3 hours of dinner. I had asked the other couple as I wasn't sure if it was just myself (this morning) but they had also become very ill. Vomiting, chills, fever, diarrhea, you name it. It's been a very rough Sunday and we are not looking forward to going back. Avoid the tartare as we aren't sure what food could have caused this however this dish was the only undercooked item we had (aside from the pickled cabbage). The food we received was also room temperature and was very high in sodium.

Everyone had me really excited about this restaurant however this experience is the worst I've had in San Francisco.
author: Daisy A.

description:
I'm a fan of the food and the lowkey decor. This spot was actually hard to find and my boyfriend passed it by two blocks before realizing we were lost. Just FYI, the main sign outside the restaurant doesn't actually say Mission Chinese Food. 

We ordered just the Salted Fish Fried Rice to share because we weren't that hungry, and I'm glad we only ordered one dish because it was a pretty large portion. Sometimes with the salted fish fried rice, it can be a game of risk because you never know if you're going to get a bite with too much salty fish or a one with none. We were pleasantly surprised with the dish and I think it might actually be the best that I've had. 

The only downside that it is pretty pricey for Chinese food, but I'd definitely come back sometime with an emptier stomach!
author: Estelle C.

description: Service is not consistently great, but the amazing food makes up for it tenfold.  Also BYOB with a slight surcharge, but it's usually waived if you're nice to your waiter.  Thrice cooked rice might be the best plate in the city.
author: Topher H.

description:
I should have looked at Yelp before ordering. I only picked this place because when it first opened, my friends raved about it. 

Chow Mein was plain. The only flavor it had was from all the onions in it. Tingly Ma Po Tofu was just overwhelming garlic and something else. My mouth was on fire the whole time. Felt like I had dumped agricultural fertilizer on my tongue. No flavor and just blah. 

Never again. Avoid this place. Unoriginal flavor. Unoriginal spin on Chinese food. When you only have one sensation on your tongue, that's a bad sign they're hiding something or they don't have any real creativity worthy of restaurant food.
author: D M.

description:
Did I mess up and order wrong?? 

This place has so much hype, so when we caught a minimal wait when we walked by, we decided to try it. I don't get it, it was just ok for such a massive ego and reputation

- Salt Cod Fried Rice: Alright. Nothing great. Fried rice. Sorta salty and fishy. I get it. But alright.
- Beef Chow Main: Good. Little oily, but again, nothing that one of those spots on Stockton in Chinatown couldn't serve up.
- Sesame Chicken: Again. Ok. Panda Express has better orange chicken than that.

Maybe I need to try it again and see, but I just don't get it. It's ok and if you want chinese, it totally does the trick. But as for an amazing chinese experience, Meh. Service was good. Ambiance is entertaining.
author: Natalie G.

description:
The decor was a bit "hip" for my understanding, but I enjoyed the ambience. 
The food is westernized enough those who are new to asian food would enjoy and simultaneously satisfy my asian food craving.
The service is pretty slow. Waited about ~15 minutes after asking for water.
author: Carol K.

description:
Danny Bowien, the founder of the Mission Chinese Food restaurants, didn't grow up cooking Chinese cuisine. Born in Korea, then adopted by a family in Oklahoma, Bowien was already an adult living in San Francisco when he decided to learn how to cook Szechuanese fare, known for its bold, pungent, spicy flavors.

Burned out from working in fine dining establishments, Bowien considered applying to work in a Szechuanese restaurant as a line cook. But since he couldn't speak Chinese, he realized he would have a hard time. Plus, many of the restaurant owners he approached viewed him with suspicion. "They thought I was crazy," Bowien tells Fresh Air's Sam Briger. "They thought I was trying to steal recipes."

Ultimately, Bowien wound up teaching himself how to cook Chinese food. Later, he opened the first Mission Chinese Food -- a pop-up restaurant with a punk rock, DIY attitude. Located inside an existing Chinese restaurant in San Francisco's Mission District, it was a hole-in-the-wall takeout joint that drew long lines and rave reviews: Both Bon Appetit and GQ magazines named it one of the best new restaurants of 2001.

Looking back at his efforts to master his own brand of Chinese cooking, Bowien says, "It [was] audacious, but at the same time, the whole feeling behind what we were doing just felt very organic, and for me there was no risk."

Bowien took that audacious attitude with him when he opened the first Mission Chinese in New York City in a tiny space in the Lower East Side. It, too, earned accolades -- one reviewer said Bowien did to Chinese food what Led Zeppelin had done to the blues.

But it broke too many rules: In 2013, the New York restaurant was shut down for various violations. Bowien describes it as a devastating blow. But, he recovered. Indeed, later that same year, the James Beard Foundation bestowed Bowien with its prestigious Rising Star Chef award. And last year, Bowien re-opened Mission Chinese Food in a new New York location.

Bowien is now the co-author, with Chris Ying, of The Mission Chinese Food Cookbook. Highlights from his Fresh Air interview are below.



On how the original Mission Chinese Food started in San Francisco 

It was just a pop-up inside of Lung Shan, and then it slowly took over, over time. You could order off two menus -- I loved that about it -- but the problem was that we'd be running our menu alongside their menu, and their chef was responsible for cooking 154 dishes off their takeout menu, just one guy on this little station. If they got really busy for delivery, which they would, and someone ordered something from their menu, I didn't know how to make their food. ...

Then eventually, I think they saw Mission Chinese Food, which was becoming very popular, and we were running out of storage space for two full-sized menus. So they actually were the ones that said, "Look, we're just going to change it and you guys just do everything, and our chef will work for you and we'll make your food. Just show them how to do it."

On opening a Mission Chinese Food in New York that closed - despite its many accolades - because of structural issues and a sanitary violation 

In retrospect, should we have [had] a structural engineer go through the building with us and everything else? Yeah, probably. We just let our emotions get the best of us. We felt an energy in that space when we walked through it. ... It wasn't legally supposed to even be a restaurant. ... The basement wasn't even legally zoned to be used for any sort of kitchen prep or preparation at all, it was supposed to be a cellar. We opened the restaurant three months after we moved here. ... We didn't do any major construction, nothing structural, we just opened. ...
author: Didi F.

description: Was really looking forward to trying this place, but was disappointed from the minute we arrived. Very lackluster wait staff, kept us standing around while he was on his phone. The beef ribs were overcooked, with very little edible meat. Lamb dumplings were very good. Garlic rice also good. Spring salad rolls ok. Wouldn't go back.
author: Amy F.

description:
This place is great! This is some of the best food I have had so far in the Bay Area! I have eaten here two times and both times have been amazing. The scene is interesting, and from the street you would not guess this place was as good as it is. 
Now some recommendations:
We had...
Sour chili chicken- very good, not to spicy 
Cumin lamb shoulder- even better than the chicken, so, so good!
Family sized salt and pepper lamb ribs- this might be the most amazing thing I have ever eaten...YOU MUST GET THIS
Squid Ink noodles- this is good (nothing to write home about, but tasty
Lamb dumplings- this is a delicious appetizer (comes with about 5 dumplings).
author: Dustin T.

description: Wow!!  This place is great!  If I walked by this place, I would never have gone inside just based on the facade - but you know how the saying goes....  never judge a book by its cover.  The food was very flavorful.   I went with a group of 4 people and we must've been ahead of the crowd because we were seated immediately.  We ordered a cornucopia of food and each dish was amazing!  They did not hold back on taste and flavor profile.  I liked how dishes were representative not only of Chinese cuisine, but also of SE Asia.  Everything we ordered was packed with flavor, from the thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes to the eggplant and even the rice porridge - yum yum yum!  This place is a definite yes! In my book!!
author: RJ S.

description: I normally write long reviews. But this one is simple. DONT MISS IT! Delicious, nice people, very casual, they do not have a full bar, but a beer and this food leaves nothing to be desired. We had the pork belly, smashed cucumbers and the beef short rib. The short rib is enough for 4 people. This is an inspired chef that seems to be living the dream of making great food without needing the fancy schmancy decor often found in San Fran restaurants. We would NEVER have found this place without social media. We were in San Francisco for only 3 nights and made this a bucket list restaurant. Danny Bowien, head chef, THANK YOU!!! We will see you again!
author: Dan S.

description:
I don't want to give such long winded review so i'm going to break it down simply as I can as to why this is possibly the worst restaurant I've ever been.

Food - 2 out of 5 - Greasy, cold and just bad flavoring. Not good Chinese food. Menu is limited and not very good.

Servers - 0 out of 5 - Unfriendly, even rude, can't take orders, Basically threw plates on chicken on to the table that I didn't order (I'm veggie) and shouted "Chicken" as the plate smacked my elbow. At the end overcharged us for food that didn't turn up. Absolutely useless.

Price - 2 out of 5 - wasn't too expensive. But too expensive for what it is. 

Atmosphere 1 out 5 - I'd describe it as the Zoolander 2 of restaurants. Crappy scenester BS music, crappy decoration just generally 'Derelicte' 

Would never go again and never advise anyone to go. Couldn't understand why people were waiting outside to get in. There are so many great places to eat SF. Mission Chinese is not one of them.
author: L W.

description:
"Authentic Chinese"

What does this mean? I know it's not sweet and sour chicken or my beloved greasy broth wonton soup.  I have arrived people. I have arrived to a land of authentic, authentic Chinese food tucked away in a less-than-attractive (which actually attracts me more) building in the Mission (who would have guessed it?) neighborhood. The wait was around a half an hour on a Sunday night - sign one that this place is a winner. 

In a little disgusting way, I impress myself with the amount of food I am capable of consuming. Soup downing is actually my specialty, but on this particular night it seemed that Chinese was the star of the show. It probably didn't help that I was eating with three fellow Yelp CMs whose appetite's were giving mine a run for its money. We ordered the sliced peanut noodles, rolls, a bean dish and a zillion other options that my food coma'd mind can't recall. The amount of water that accompanied this meal speaks for the sinus clearing experience that it was. The Thrice Cooked Bacon entree was definitely my favorite by far with rice cakes, tofu skin and chili oil. 

The food wasn't the only thing that made this place five stars in my book - the atmosphere - red lighting, semi dirty strip club-esque feel with a giant paper dragon spanned across the ceiling. In some spots there was barely enough room for the waiters to wedge between tables. But the cherry on top as far as atmosphere goes, is definitely the bathroom setup. You walk through the kitchen and into the overflow space that is used for recycling, storage and is open to the outdoors. This would probably gross out most folks, but for me it adds an extra layer of charm.
author: Brittany S.

description:
This is based on takeout. Maybe dining in is better?
    I was hoping for more. I was hoping to leave my first 5 star review. This is not the case. I have to preface this review with the fact that I have been a fan of Danny Bowien for the last few years, cooking many of his recipes from the Mission Chinese Food Cookbook at home, so I was  super eager to try this place. Maybe it was a case of building something up too much in my head, but I was underwhelmed. We ordered the vinegar peanuts, lamb dumplings, chicken wings, pork belly, kung pao pastrami and the mapo tofu. The peanuts were a nice snack, the lamb dumplings mostly forgettable. The chicken wings were tasty, though not as spicy as I had hoped. The tiki pork belly was good, but the portion seemed a little small.  I enjoyed the kung pao as well as the mapo, but it was on par with what I have cooked at home from the cookbook.
    All in all, it was good for what it was. I would eat here again. I would recommend it. I just had it built up so much in my mind, there was no way it could hold up. I guess this is how Guy Fieri's fans feel after eating at one of his establishments. Lol.
author: Jesse J.

description:
It was my mission to go to Mission Chinese Food when I was in SF. I first heard about the restaurant while reading an article in GQ by Alan Richman (I got a free subscription, ok?). Then, I read an online article about them in the NY Times. I also saw that Jessica Alba dined here via her Instagram photos. 

I tried going one other time, but the wait time was over an hour. No matter how long the wait, I was determined to eat here this time. Luckily, there were seats available. The food came out quickly. The two dishes smelled great. I barely ate all day, but I didn't realize how hungry I was until I scarfed everything down. That and I thoroughly enjoyed my meal. 

Salt Cod Fried Rice- mackerel confit, Chinese sausage, lettuce, egg 
I can't live without rice and now I can't live without their fried rice. I'm exaggerating, but I don't remember the last time I was this satisfied eating fried rice.

Stir-Fried Pork Jowl (cheeks) and Radishes- fermented black bean, mint, red perilla (mint family)
The radishes were quartered and served with their green leaves attached. I never had them like this. They were firm with a bit of a bite to them. The pork jowls were fat and tender.

It's a hole in the wall, so don't expect much of the surroundings. Don't even expect your chopsticks to match- my friend had two different length chopsticks. Something that bothered me were the fake flowers that were sitting at our table and had a layer of dust on them. Might as well get rid of them if they're not going to be dusted. The other thing is you have to walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom. At least you walk through the dishwashing side and not the cooking side.

I rarely bookmark Chinese restaurants, but this was an exception. Mission accomplished!
author: Helen H.

description:
Not like it used to be.  

This small restaurant used to have great imaginative dishes but I think the reputation went to their heads.  I ordered their chili chicken wings, and got a $13 dish with 8 small dried out wings.  They had the chili taste I expected but with way too much salt.  And they arrived very quickly but were not fresh and not even hot.  

The Vegetable dish was good and so was the rice, but the $50 cost was not worth it.  

The service was lackluster at best.  Either the servers were not efficient, or they smoked a bit too much before their shift.  

If you want a trendy place to go and be seen...go for it.  If you want great food, good service, and an appetizing environment,  go somewhere else.
author: Larry J.

description:
My friend and I stumbled across this place after seeing a line form outside the store front and quickly realized it was the Mission Chinese we've been hearing about from other folks. Even though there was a line, we took a leap of faith and put our name on the list. We went down the street to Boba Guys, came back, waited a bit more and got seated. We weren't in a rush, so we didn't mind the wait.

AMBIANCE/SERVICE:
At night, it's dimly lit with red lights. All the food was hued in that red and if you asked me what my food looked like, I probably couldn't tell you. HAHA. It's a very hipster vibe with a hipster/yupster clientele. Our server was not as pleasant as we would hope, but the food service was quick.

FOOD:
Definitely came into this with some hesitations since I have this idea of what "chinese food" is. But you really just have to come into this with an open mind and know that it's a different, modern take. I can see the less traditional, fusion elements and the influences from other cuisines melded in. Which created some confusion for my palette, but was still weirdly interesting. We got the following:

*Tiki Pork Belly: SOLID! Two hearty portions that were tender and THAT SAUCE. I loved it, sweet and complimentary to the saltiness of the pork. I wanted to slather it on the pork and rice. 

*Cherry Glazed Porky Ribs: For me, wasn't a highlight of the meal, but a very big portion for just two people to share. 

*Squid Ink Noodles: This was one of the memorable dishes for me. I love noodles so this was a cool take, taste wise and visually. There's this yogurt sauce that feels very mediterranean and then the meat tasted reminiscent of chorizo, so it felt Spanish. Weird combination, but tasted well together. 

Weirdly intrigued and curious about the other dishes, so I'm inclined for another visit. All in all, a solid experience. But in true hipster style, I'll just shrug my shoulders and say, "it's aight." Haha.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I can't compliment this place enough.  Yes its run down, yes it plays loud music, and yes it total hipster.  But unlike one couple who left right away during my meal, stay and be wowed.

We let our server guide the way and every recommendation was spot on.

The thrice baked bacon and rice cakes was a perfect balance of spice and fatty bacon with a fun chewy rice cake. Incredible combination.  The kung pao pastrami was a great blend of smokey heat, but I could have done without the veggies on this one. Salt cod fried rice exploded with flavor. Mongolian long beans made me a fan of them.  Everything was stellar at a great price.
author: Trekforbeer B.

description: Came for lunch with a group of friends and ordered a bunch of stuff! We had eel rolls, string beans, fried chicken, forbidden rice, pork belly, and another pork belly dish with radishes and fried pork skin. Eel rolls were bomb, rice was delicious, the chicken wings were good not too spicy, but left a weird tingly feeling in my mouth. The pork belly though I thought was just all fat, not much meat. The other pork belly stir fry dish was good, especially when it's the crunchy pork skin! Their menu has a lot of interesting dishes, will have to come back to try them all!
author: Linz C.

description:
MCF touts itself as being an interesting take on Chinese food and for good reason. the food is fairly tasty, but 100% inauthentic which is ironic given their exterior decor. It's also important to note that MCF is kind of a stickler on reservations - they don't seat you unless your entire party is there, which is a pain.

Onto the food:
1) Salt Cod Fried Rice
Meh dish. It didn't taste bad, but you could literally have this dish at any Chinese restaurant. It wasn't bad, but it was just really pedestrian. 

2) Tea Soaked Eel Roll
I actually really enjoyed this dish. The eel had a smoky flavor and was well complemented by the vegetable and the soft texture of the rice roll. It definitely was not Chinese, but was yummy all the same.

3) Tiger Salad
An interesting take on the tiger salad - they wrapped the salad up in a rice roll which made it a little tricky to eat. Still, it was flavorful, but definitely not a must get dish.

4) Sizzling Cumin Lamb
This was really not good at all. I would not recommend it. The lamb was overcooked and had a gamey taste and not much flavor at all. The vegetables that came with it were soggy and really salty. 

5) Lamb Faced Noodles (?)
I was so disappointed when I got this dish because I was under the impression that this was a "biang biang mian" dish, but it wasn't. Although the noodles were underwhelming - soggy and soft - the soup base was really quite delicious. The numbing spices sent tingles down my tongue and was actually really addictive. The lamb was a little overcooked though, so it was an interesting dish, but definitely not a must have.

Overall, the food at MCF was enjoyable, but very forgettable. Most Asians looking to eat real Chinese food would probably really hate this place.
author: Sarah T.

description: It's unfortunate when your server says, "You have over stayed your welcome" when you have only been in the restaurant for an hour. We tried to order more food and we were told we couldn't because they needed our table. Any restaurant should be prepared for people enjoying themselves and wanting to stay longer than an hour. After all dinner time should be spent conversing and enjoying your friends and family, not eating fast and dashing out.
author: Rachel H.

description: Was ok, but not worth the hype. Way too rushed - if you are looking to enjoy your time and talk with your group, as you eat, forget it. They serve your food really rushed and want to out of there so they can seat the next group. The server actually said we stayed too long. Which was odd because we did not linger. Much better places in the neighborhood.
author: Dave H.

description:
Mission Chinese Food used to be my go-to Chinese restaurant. Loved the strong flavor pairings and audacious menu. It's always good to update your menu and keep it fresh, but my my party's 2 favorite items were axed (coca-cola ribs and black fried rice). The Tiger Salad recipe has changed to be extremely biter (adding arugula methinks).  They removed the images and description of items on the menu, so you have to guess what's in the dish or look on Yelp. 

Not many options if you are vegetarian. The Dan Dan Vegan Noodles are very good but overall the experience was very disappointing considering the number of people we've brought there in the past & referred. Will definitely go back (won'g give up) but now looking for new place to try... :(  Hopefully next time will update review to 5 star glory once again.
author: Megan V.

description:
All in all, very Mulan with boho Mediterranean vibes. 

I came here having no idea what this place was about, and I do have to say I am quite impressed. Too be fair I did opt out of the basic choices (chow mein, rice, etc). I went for the matcha squid ink noodles; didn't get the matcha but there was quite the gingery surprise. Went for the eggplant and lamb as well, hence the boho med vibes. Didn't disappoint one bit. 

If you're on the fence about this place, just do it.
author: Gilberto L.

description: Forget what the haters say. I'm a regular SF visitor and, despite the complaints about how it's declined, was never good or is just a hipster fixation, I'm of the party that says, "Mission Chinese Food is actually good." It's a small, somewhat dingy, poorly lit storefront but the food is good, innovative, and nicely spicy. I've never failed to order the Kung Pao pastrami and I've never found it disappointing. Spicy Pickled cabbage (basically, non-fermented kimchi) is also excellent. Honestly, I've never had a lousy meal here. Go.
author: Eli L.

description:
I love this place (I know it's not authentic..blah blah). It can be a bit salty but everything is very flavorful. The Mongolian Long Beans and the Kung Pao Pastrami are the way to go. 

I think they also offer options on spice level now ....other than "Melt Your Face Off". Anyway, my friends will come with me now.
author: Erin L.

description: Worst Chinese food ever. Order delivery last night and could not eat,  nasty soaking in oil. Do not recommend
author: Amalia L.

description:
Don't take this the wrong way. But seriously, I've never seen more non-Asians eating at a Chinese place than here at Mission Chinese Food. It was so unexpected that my friend and I (both Chinese) felt strangely out of place. Haha.

The restaurant is pretty run-down. The decor is dated. The tables and chairs have seen better days. Not only that, the restaurant is so small! We got seated at the awkward nook by the front window. The space was so tight that I had to climb onto my chair to sit down.

As for the food itself, it was definitely a twist on traditional Chinese. I would describe the food selection as standard Chinese dishes with the incorporation of non-traditional ingredients. 

2012: 7x7 #1
Salt Cod Fried Rice. $10. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=BWPN1e3Cg3W1Mpm6VXsnwA#BWPN1e3Cg3W1Mpm6VXsnwA): As someone who grew up eating salted fish fried rice, the one at MCF was underwhelming. The amount of scallion was ridiculous but barely any salt cod and Chinese sausage. The dish was greatly missing the salt cod flavor. At least it was filling. 

Thrice Cooked Bacon. $11. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=BWPN1e3Cg3W1Mpm6VXsnwA#9Mnk_4oEuFA21sfAyO_eLg): My friend and I imagined the thrice cooked bacon to be the traditional thick pieces of pork slow cooked and then stir-fried with rice cake. When the dish came out, we saw that it was literally bacon. How and why would you need to cook thin slices of bacon three times? The bacon just added some salt and grease and nothing else. 

We also ordered this dish based on its use of bitter melon, which we both enjoy. There was one piece in the entire dish. We told our server, who then made a comment about people not usually liking bitter melon. Hmmm okay. Well, we like them. The chef ended up cooking us some bitter melon, except they were simply stir-fried in oil. For those who are unfamiliar with cooking bitter melon, seasoning and a soften texture are needed to reduce the bitterness. Our extra bitter melon was al-dente and extremely bitter.      

Fusionness aside, I just don't care for a restaurant that skimps on ingredients. Prices are high. The wait is long. MCF is not for me.
author: Marti L.

description: Solid place in the Mission. I like the diversity of the menu and the fact that they don't have all of your typical dishes.
author: Dylon W.

description: Ummmm yess!!! I loved my dinner here, it was one of my favorite dinners of my SanFrancisco trip. The wait wasn't bad and once we were seated the interior is quite a trip, like rave meets Chinese food spot. The menu was super expansive and luckily I was with a group who wanted to share. Oddly enough their sautéed greens were one of my favorite dishes. Super flavorful and light. The squid ink pasta was also something I would like to be eating right now. The long beans were tasty as well, they had a kick, but nothing too crazy. Salt Cod fried rice? Sign me up! Really the list goes on and on. I loved it and can't wait to go back.
author: Holly K.

description:
We've finally discovered the trick to this place. Order delivery if you're lucky enough to live close by. Yes, you'll still have to wait awhile for that delivery, but it's on its way and you won't be standing in the street.

Mission Chinese had become our go to Chinese placee before we moved to San Diego and now when we come to visit, we still make a point to grab a meal here. 

The vinegar peanuts are addictive, the tingly wings and lamb put your lips on fire (on a good day) and the green beans are a solid staple. We recommend finding some friends and doing it massive family style.

Not typical Chinese food at all, but far better than most!
author: Amy D.

description: Great vibe, totally laid back. Kimchi and mapo tofu were addicting! Get a cold Tsing Tao to wish it down! Great service, but go early to avoid the crowds.
author: Ehren H.

description:
You would never find or try this place if people did not tell you about it.
The store front looks like a traditional Chinese place.  It has Lung Shan Restaurant frontage sign in bright yellow and red.  It also has a metal sliding gate for the hole-in-the-wall atmosphere.  But it is actually run by non-Chinese people, serving Fusion Chinese food, and the real name is Mission Chinese.
 
We had the Kung Pao Pastrami.  It was too spicy for me.  I also thought price was too high.
author: Connie W.

description:
I know Mission Chinese gets a lot of hype, but I just think this place is AOK.

Set aside the fancy decorations, t-shirts for sale, and MSG on the table for a second. After all, it all comes down to the food, right? And the food here is nothing fancy. The spicy noodles are drenched in soy sauce, while the broccoli and braised beef is mostly broccoli -- sneaky sneaky. The green beans are great, but they do not make a meal.

I wouldn't go so far to say it's bad, but it's nothing mind-blowing.
author: Casey S.

description: Today was the second time I had eaten here, both times for lunch so I wouldn't have a huge wait. Both meals were really not good. Today, three of us ordered lots of small and 1 large plate. The greens were so stringy as to be almost impossible to eat, not cut up (as if that would have helped...) and in a mediocre broth. I love salt, but the chicken dish was so overly salty, and had an overall unpleasant flavor. The other two dishes, eggplant and a noodle peanut sauce thing, were not that appealing at all, and didn't have much in the way of good flavor. The pot of tea came and was lukewarm, and had to be sent back. What do people see in this place?? When the bill came, I felt ripped off having to pay a lot for bad food. Never coming back here again.
author: K C.

description:
I was really excited about trying out the food here but I was disappointed. I came here on a Friday night with a few friends and we ordered Mongolian Long Beans, salt cod fried rice, thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes and finally, the Filipino garlic fried chicken.  I really didn't think the food was that special. Yes, it's fusion & special & blah blah blah but you can probably find better tasting & cheaper Chinese food somewhere else. Furthermore, the fried chicken was really dry and for ~$20, you just pay for some super fried but dry chicken pieces on top of plain rice with some sauce on the side. I definitely wouldn't order these 4 things I tried again. But I am willing to give some other dishes a try if I come here again.

 As a bit of a warning, I wouldn't come here if you're trying to catch up with friends or have a conversation. As you can tell from all of the pictures, it's really dark red inside the restaurant and the music is really loud. The coating on my plate was chipping (gross) and the seats/tables just don't feel that clean. Service on the Friday night I went was not friendly/attentive/welcoming. Maybe they were trying to go for that authentic "asian" restaurant service style and go for that horrible service/great food vibe. But the food wasn't that special.
author: Kyungji M.

description:
Arrived half an hour before opening to no line. Put name on the list and ate oysters and beer next door. Returned fifteen minutes later and were lucky to be first in line as numerous other couples arrived imminently. 

Situated in a slightly underdeveloped part of San Francisco, Mission is a darkly lit, loud music blaring, vinyl chair covered, crooked table kind of place with white a probes servers who are efficient and friendly. 

My girlfriend and I ordered way too much, or I should say that I made about three too many ordering decisions. 

The tiki pork belly ($10) with pineapple slices, coconut chunks in a soy caramel orange glaze showed us the true caliber of this hidden operation. The three inch square chunks of pork are crispy on top with a melting layer of fat that melds into a middle layer of firm meat. Absolutely the most flavorful piece of pork ever served.

Egg and egg noodle soup ($12) elevates soup to a new plane - fat, freshly pulled egg noodles in a chicken pickle broth with sliced scallions, cilantro and jalapeños. A large egg yolk resides atop and in the middle of the heap of noodles to be enjoyed as it cooks itself into the broth. A healthy dose of hoisin sauce is poured to the side to provide a base for all of these ingredients to come together. Simply outstanding. 

The Sichuan pickles ($4) are a variation of kimchi and offer a fiery but palate cleansing dish throughout the meal. Served with giant roasted peanuts and pepper flakes, an unusual variation of an Asian staple. 

The Kung pao pastrami ($12) is a classic stir fry dish in that it is a pile of pastrami and vegetables on a plate. However, the thick pieces of salty pastrami easily extract the sweet celery and red pepper from the pile. Peanuts sprinkled atop provide a little crunch. 

The combination fried rice ($15) is light on oil, heavy on fresh vegetables - cilantro, onion, red pepper, scallions - light pork and a size able dollop of crab meat atop. A perfect dish to serve with all of the rest of the meal. 

Beer, wine, sake. 

A dose of unusually well refined food, this chinese is otherworldly. A stop is a must when you next make it to California.
author: Simon L.

description:
Apparently there is always a wait. But, I went on a Saturday at 5:30pm and our party of 3 was immediately seated.
We ordered: Ma po tofu, thrice cooked bacon, pork belly, salt cod fried rice. Hands down, the pork belly was our top favorite. Then the ma po tofu, salt cod fried rice and last the thrice cooked bacon.
They brought out all the entrees within 5 minutes of ordering. 
Service was good, food was delicious. I would definitely return!
author: Mendy M.

description:
You know something is off when you walk into a Chinese restaurant full of white people. (this is excluding take out/fast food places). 

Like all the reviews say, this is extremely hipster. This was the weirdest place I saw when I visited San Francisco...but it was in the mission district and I decided to give it a try. 

I got take out but for all the people that were waiting around 1.5 hours to sit down for 2 people; the reason is they are extremely understaffed. I only saw 1 waiter and the other waiter that was supposedly working just somehow disappeared.....1 waiter for at least 15 tables on a Friday night is pretty ridiculous staffing on the restaurant's part. 

I really want to give this place a better review but I can't. The food just honestly wasn't that good. It was a good effort to make tea smoked eel and the concept was nice. I was expecting it to be really flavorful but it turned out too salty in the end. Same with the Kungpao pastrami....poor use of sauce I guess. 

Anyway I guess if you wanted t ocome here for a date/hangout it is nice for the atmosphere. Otherwise, I would eat somewhere else since tacos/burritos seem to the strong point in this area.
author: Shushu C.

description:
Everything was salty except carb dishes and eggplant. Lounge dub step music was confusing, made the ambience feel all fancy when the food is not. Second time here, will not return. Best part of the meal was $2 pineapple sake shots.

Way too salty:
Rice cakes with pork
Pastrami stir fry
Brisket stir fry
Chicken and lamb stir fry

Not salty but meh, I'd rather go to Panda Express for the price:
Chicken chow mein
Hamachi collar
Stir fried Chinese broccoli

Pretty good compared to everything else:
Stir fried eggplant
author: Christine T.

description:
I've had far more problems with MCF's delivery than any other restaurant in SF. It's frequently late, the delivery guy has a horrible attitude, and my most recent order never showed up at all.

I've been a fan for a while, but I've lost my patience.
author: Jade M.

description:
This is not your average Chinese-American joint. An innovative and creative menu makes this place an exemplar of successful experimentation with old and new ingredients. 


Mission Chinese Food, why must you confuse a longing pilgrim, (at the end of a longish drive from Marin) by putting up "Lung Shan Restaurant" on your store-front?  This attempt at subterfuge will simply not work! It was at best only  a fleeting and temporary annoyance, like a pebble in my shoe. I burst forth into the temple and (after waiting a minute for the hipster waiter outside to finish his smoke break) was whisked away (rather languidly) to my table. I kept thinking "faster damn you!" and "can we fast forward through the formalities and get down to business?" But alas, social constructs (civility, courtesy) have a powerful hold on us and so I had to endure the ritual of waiting for my beverage to arrive before placing an order.
But when the opportunity came I pounced- a baby dragon bursting forth from its crib with flames and froth emanating from the sides of its mouth.

After feigning uncertainty (I had of course studied the menu to the point that I could see it with my eyes closed as I lay in bed the previous night), I ordered the following:

Tea-smoked eel rolls and Grandma's pork dumplings to further wet an already drenched appetite.

Sour chili chicken, because I was feeling silly and I really like shishito peppers. Yeah, anyway.

Reflections and Musings:

The Tea-smoked eel rolls were like a pagoda but instead of roof over roof there was layer upon layer of texture and taste. I had to go back to the menu to decipher what it was that had perplexed my taste buds. I have to conclude that it was the salted plum hoisin sauce and cognac soy that had colluded to slay the picky beast that lurks in my palate. I was conquered without a shot. All it took was one bite.  

Grandma's pork dumplings were served in a bowl with ham broth. The dumplings weren't floating so much as just soaking a little, the way you would dangle your feet into a swimming pool while keeping the rest of your body out of the water. These little jewels had been steamed to perfection. Each bite was preceded by a rapidly learned behavior similar to Pavlov's dogs. You could say I was merely drooling. So much so that Pavlov would lean over and say "keep it together man" (through a translator of course).

The sour chili chicken took the chicken tenders of my youth and replaced that memory with something mightier and more delicious.  The malange of shishito pepper, chicken tender and little marble potatoes was a well-constructed fusion of smells and textures. The soft crunch of the aromatic peppers and the crisp exterior of bite sized potatoes that sealed a perfectly cooked interior was completed by bites of soy & chili seasoned chicken. Not too spicy but definitely flavorful. You won't start sweating or hiccupping from chili intoxication despite the little flame by the menu entry. You might giggle with joy at how good this dish tastes. 

My one request (a sure sign of the looming demise of good health) is to dial down the sodium if at all possible. I know, I know, that's like asking for grandma to stop squeezing your cheeks in front of your friends. Possible but not probable.

And a side of steamed white rice has to be ordered separately. Just so you know. Please don't whine and cause a mini scene when you get there. 

Food:     5
Service: 4
Facility:  4. It's got an interesting very old world vibe. If that world was a small neighborhood somewhere in China. You'll know what I mean when you see it. A bit of a delightful take on time travel circa 1980s.

IV Yelp Stars. (The Romans had a funny way of writing 4)
author: Jahan T.

description: Had an amazing dinner here. This was my first time, and I came with my family to celebrate my dad's birthday. First of all, the young lady from Haiti who helped us was incredible (wish I asked her for her name). She was very attentive and super sweet. Even spoke a little bit of Spanish for my parents. She helped guide us through the menu and the 5-6 dishes we ordered were great. The food was really tasty and we had a nice balance of meat and veggies- which is what we wanted. The environment was really cool and hip, I was a fan of the techno lights. Will def come again and recommend it. Note: this isn't your typical Chinese food, it's Def fusion, but if you're open minded to new flavors and dishes, this is a great place.
author: Rico H.

description:
I went here 2-3 years ago and liked it so I convinced my wife to try it. It was not good...unfortunately. I was really looking forward to some excellent, unusual food. Well, as desired and expected, it is unusual. Unfortunately, the quality is not there...nor is the service. 
We had the pastrami, spicy wings, spring rolls and  nori rice. The spring rolls were very good but the pastrami was so oversalted it was almost inedible. The rice was cold and must have been left over from the prior day. Service was lack luster throughout the meal.
author: B S.

description:
My wife and two others in our party are not Chinese food fans but we all walked away loving our experience here.  It's definitely not fancy dining but the food delivers which is all that matters.

We started off with some Tsing Taos (which were unfortunately not cold) and the Mission Chinese Mule which was super sweet.  The it seemed liked we ordered almost everything on the menu.

We got the Chongqing chicken wings (prepared really well), Tiki pork belly (one of my favorites of the night), Kung Pao Pastrami (my favorite), 3x cooked bacon and rice cakes (watch out as this one is spicy), sour chili chicken, broccoli beef brisket (so good) and spicy beef chow mein.

All that and it ended up being $35 a person.  Great deal and great food even if you're not a Chinese food fan.
author: Blake B.

description:
First things first, food is amazing and the wait is not. This place always has a wait. Aways. There was one time I called in and the hostess said there was no wait so I cruised over only to end up waiting for 50 minutes to get a table for 2. Despite my raging hanger this did not diminish the greatness of this establishment.

I can only describe this place as hipster chinese food. There's this really great juxtaposition between high and low culture, traditional and irreverent. Come here with an open mind, patience, and of course an appetite.

I recommend the Forbidden Fried Rice, General Tso's Veal Ribs, and the Pork Belly w/ Macadamia Nuts. All dank as hell.
author: Alex P.

description:
Heard of this place from their sous chef who I met in Tahoe.
Decided to try it out when I was in the city next time.
It's an interesting take on Chinese food.
immensely enjoyed the spicy Cumin Lamb, the scallion fried rice and the Dan Dan Noodles.
Will definitely visit again.
The only con: the wait for a table on a Saturday.
author: Nandini B.

description:
Love it.  Totally loved it.  Makes no pretense about what it is, doesn't really care about anything other than putting a damn tasty and unique bowl of Chinese somethin' in front of you.  Walk though two kitchens to use the bathroom only to discover a random guy sitting on a milk crate right next to it barking into his phone in Mandarin while smoking a cigarette?  Don't care.  Just give me some more tea smoked eel.

Wife an I split the smashed cucumbers, fresh rice noodles with a kick ass peanut sauce, the aforementioned tea smoked eel roll, and the squid ink cumin lamb noodles.  Everything was phenomenal.  

Every Chinese restaurant should be exactly like this.  Just add Peking duck.
author: Adam O.

description: What a menu, Chinese food with major twists, like Kung Pao pastrami. The beans knocked me out, and the brined pickles were gone in a flash. Eat here and smile!
author: William M.

description:
I hadn't planned on reviewing this place, but apparently my dining companions really wanted me to.

The six of us (my brother and his wife, my step-sister and her fiance, and my girlfriend and I - I've always been the slow one . . . ) stopped in on Saturday evening.  We were visiting from Reno, while everyone else lives in the city.  They were surprised that we were able to get in with only a five minute wait or so at 6:30 on a Saturday evening (maybe everyone was at Outside Lands?).  

In any case, for non-city folk, the space is small, and you're packed in like sardines.  There's barely walking space between the tables and seats, and you definitely need to do a little bit of weaving and dancing to navigate.  Our party of size was sat at the end of three or four tables in a line, so people were seated next to us as well.  To reach the single, co-ed bathroom, you need to go through the kitchen and out the back door to get there.

The six of us ate family style, ordering lots of items: vinegar peanuts, fresh rice noodle, cucumbers in garlic sauce, thrice cooked rice cakes, sour chili chicken, rice porridge, ribs, egg egg noodle, and probably a dish or two I missed.  The damage for our group was around $130. 

The reason I was reluctant to write this review was that this was one of those meals were you have little bites and tastes, but don't really get to explore a dish.  I really liked what I was having, but many times was thinking "man, I should have taken more of that", but was already moving on to the next bite.  While I love sampling and grazing, I also like having a whole entree to myself to really explore and enjoy. So, take all my food thoughts with a grain of salt . . . 

First things first, I was surprised how spicy the rice cakes were - very tasty, but surprisingly spicy for a one flame item (for a menu that goes up to two flames).  If the food was served in a fancier venue than this divey space, I feel like it'd be called fusion, as the dishes feel more Chinese inspired than Chinese.  The egg, egg noodle was delicious, but I think most anything with yolk is amazing.  

On food alone, this would likely be a 3.5 star experience with the limited tastes I had.  There were tons of dishes with potential, but so hard to tell with only a bite or two.  The last star is because I love that a place like this exists - it's got character, people love it or hate it, and a group of six of us can go out and have a rad meal together, with good company and solid food.
author: Ernie C.

description:
It's like going to eat at your best Chinese friend's house. Except now you're in your mid-20s and it's super hipster. But, still good.

The forbidden fried rice is all you need to know. That paired with any meat dish and you're set. The beef noodles and sour chicken are pretty solid choices each visit.

The service has always been pretty quick every time I've come here. I think the portions in relation to what you pay is pretty good. This place is a staple in my rotation of places to go to when I can't think of anywhere else to go eat.
author: Shawn B.

description:
Been here a handful of times and I've had to wait hella long every time; except once when I got it to go. At one point I got the genius idea that getting it to-go would make me forgo the long waits here! So my friend and I just got it and ate it at the tennis courts in dp. It was pure genius if I didn't say so myself lollll. 

   The food in general is not bad and does pack quite a punch especially with their spicy dishes. I'm happy to say that their spicy is reminiscent of the traditional Sichuan spice (of course still not quite as spicy). Their wings and mapo tofu were especially bomb and had that numbing spicy Taste I  loved! The Chinese call that spicy a numbing spicy because you can't really feel your tongue after! (But don't quote me on that since I'm southern Chinese lol) 

   I also had their green beans and westlake rice congee. I loved the green beans but the westlake rice congee was mediocre. They added too much water and the congee wasn't the right consistency that I liked. But they had some expensive stuff in there like Dungeness crab meat which was super awesome! But there should be for $14-$15 an order! If you sold it at that price in Asia no real Asians would buy it. Congee used to be poor people food but I guess they just changed the game.
author: Janet K.

description:
WOW! Wow. What a crazy good take on Chinese food ,this place blew my mind come on ! Pork belly appetizer with an umbrella, Kung pow pastrami, lamb face noodle soup,
Completely thinking outside of the box. Beat the crowds by showing up for lunch at 2:30
author: Barry B.

description:
I'm not sure if this place qualifies as Chinese food. The hallowed Kung Pao Pastrami is basically a bunch of celery, bell peppers, peanuts, pastrami, and salt thrown together.. almost like a firesale of last night's dinner in the fridge. It didn't taste like anything remotely close to the original Kung Pao nor did it have any flavor worthy of its $13 price tag. The salt cod fried rice was acceptable, but it barely had any salted cod as well as a smidgeon of chinese sausages. 

Also, I'm Chinese - and I'm saying this is NOT chinese food. I could care less if the original chef was some James Beard dude. This is the worst "chinese" food I've ever had.
author: Henry W.

description:
Mission Chinese is nothing short of amazing.

I'm from the midwest, and when I want my rib fix I go here for the Porky Ribs (dine-in only) over any BBQ spot in town. Bizarre I know, but true.

When I want my Jew-food fix, I go here for the Kung-Pao Pastrami and Broccoli Beef Brisket. Totally bizarre I know, but again true.

When I want wings, I go here for the Chongqing Chicken Wings. They have numbing chili and are dry-fried with lots of cumin. Amazing.

The real key of Mission Chinese is to order for delivery. They'll deliver for just a couple of bucks to almost anywhere in San Francisco, and the wait for that is about as long as you'd wait to dine-in. Seriously some of the best delivery in town.
author: Edward M.

description:
Had a birthday reservation at Mission Chinese for 2, called ahead that we would be delayed 10min due to traffic and the hostess dismissed us upon arrival. To quote, "I'll talk to you outside." Like we were in trouble... and never spoke to us again till I approached her 20mins later. If you're gonna take reservations, respect the people that plan ahead. 
 Rude service and and great food don't mix.
author: Alex P.

description: host (tall guy) was a TOTAL DICK. food was fine, I got the eggplant and really liked it, my boyfriend got the Kung pao pastrami and hated it.
author: Helen S.

description:
Cool place. Perhaps a bit too hip for its own good though. 

If you like Szechuan style numbing spice, definitely try it here. They do a great job of that.
author: JM H.

description:
Three of us had dinner here.

The food was good and the service was good. 

I would recommend it to others. And would go back again myself, if I didn't live in Los Angeles...

A-OK...
author: Moon S.

description:
I know Danny Bowien has hit it big, doing things like getting drunk with Bourdain around North Beach, and has been flitting to and fro between SF and NYC in his ventures. I'm getting up the mettle to go against the flow and write a review contrary to public opinion.

He was even standing behind our table when we came over for lunch, and doing something with the cold case... thing is, 

We weren't terribly impressed with our lunch choices. We chose from the tips page on Yelp, and really, the whole thing was lost on us. From pork belly to other dishes, we thought that it was all very forgettable. 

Please.. someone... unravel the mystery for me. Food was greasy, and quite pricey.
author: Jana C.

description: The veg version of the thrice-cooked bacon and rice cakes... that'll be my last meal.
author: Angel V.

description: The two of us alone finished 2 orders of the sizzling lamb cumin. I can't speak for anything else, but this dish alone has been my reason for coming back. Good spot for dates too.
author: Kim L.

description:
I'd give this place zero starts or even minus if I could. I ordered my food via delivery.  The photo I saw of the tofu looked really tasty.  When it arrived it was in a soup of oil and grease, even the plastic container it came in was oily.  Seriously, a pint of gelatinous tofu oil soup, no mushrooms (as described) and laced with grit filled, peppers, black peppers, dried red peppers and more gritty spices.  I took on bite and had to get it out of my mouth ASAP.  Really gross and disappointing to say the least.

Next came the salad rolls.  I was hoping for fresh butter lettuce with a hint of herbs. The whole roll was filled with herbs and stems and the sauce was exactly the same as the Tofu (soup) dish!

Steer clear from this place.  They don't make what they say they are making and it's not tasty and made me feel sick.  Maybe thins is one of those places that give sub-par food for deliveries and saves the semi-good quality food for eating on-site.

I have no clue as to why this place is so highly rated other than it's rep for being a hipster haven.
author: emily b.

description:
The best way to describe the food at Mission Chinese is super greasy Chinese takeout that will light up your taste buds. It's good, but different. The flavors were bold and absolutely amazing. The restaurant itself is small and you will often find multiple parties waiting outside. I love the tacky decor that adorns the inside of Lung Shan restaurant. The ageless Christmas lights and tissue paper dragon lantern almost balances out the heavy metal music perfectly. Despite some reports of  crappy service, I found our waitress to be pleasant and helpful.
