What I liked: The salt cod fried rice was probably my favorite dish of the night. It was just a perfect marriage of greasy fried rice with that salty, briny flavor of dried cod. I also loved the thrice cooked bacon. The rice cakes were the perfect texture and the crispy bacon was fantastic. 

What I found to be mediocre: The tea-smoked eel had a nice presentation and texture, but there was nothing tea-smoked about it. 

What I though flopped: The ma po tofu was a slimy, spicy mess. They were stingy on the pork shoulder and everything else just tasted of chili paste.  The beef cheek "a l'orange" was a crispier version of Panda's orange chicken, except you couldn't taste the beef cheek. It was thoroughly fried, but lathered in the orange glaze. 

Tips: Come here with your entire party present before 6 pm. In general, stay clear of the spicy menu items if you can't handle the heat.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Wonderfully innovative Chinese dishes.  This restaurant does not have a sign, it uses the old sign from the Chinese restaurant it replaced.

We went for lunch and had:

--Smashed cucumbers: Not what it sounds like.  Chunks of cucumber with salted chili and sesame paste.  A great pallet cleanser.

--Kung Pao Pastrami:  Great take on Kung Pao with pieces of smoked pastrami. Delicious.

--Salt cod fried rice:  OK dish of rice with fish flavor and pieces of sausage

--Mongolian long beans:  Delicious beans cooked in spices and chili oil.

Get there early for dinner or have a late lunch. Customers line up to get in and there often is a wait.

I will definitely return for more of this non-traditional fare.
author: Max G.

description: I heard David Chang loves to go here when he is in San Francisco, well....,.,,,.,....Fuck you David Chang!!!!!  Momofuku's dumpster tastes better than this place.
author: Mark S.

description: I never understood the hype about this place.  The food is mediocre at best and is not authentic Chinese food by any means.  If you think Panda Express is delicious, then this place is for you.
author: Roberta V.

description:
Food is decent - tasty and came quickly. Our waitress was lovely. But worst. host. ever. Young guy with floral tattoo on his right forearm. We wrote our names on the waitlist at the door at 615pm and he tore the sheet off, so when we returned at 645pm the sheet was gone. We asked if we could put our names down again on the list and he said "come back at 8pm, we're not feeding anyone till then. No, no list - list starts again at 8pm.
So we decide to go somewhere else for a drink and return at 8pm. It is now 810 and people have gathered outside, and started writing their names on the paper outside the door. We do the same (we are now third in line). Same dude walks out, swears at us "FFS don't write names there!!" And tears the list off again. People are... Shocked. He then comes out with a fresh piece of paper maybe 5 mins later, sticks it up - leaving the people milling around at the entrance confused. We then take matters into our own hands and say, ok - let's go in the same order we wrote on the previous piece (something I imagine the host should really be managing). The other groups outside thank us for taking charge and being fair. Everyone talks about what a douche the dude is. Bottom line - that particular person really does not have the personality to be working in the service industry. Unprofessional, verbally abusive, obviously rattled by what was a very ordinary, orderly Friday evening crowd just trying to get on a waitlist.
author: Camellia D.

description:
Was so hyped up for this place for several reasons:
1) In the Mission District (most good SF restaurants are here)
2) Chinese food (my favorite)
3) Always a crowd (good indication of either repeat customers or raving reviews)

Sadly, like Icarus, it was too ambitious and flew too close to the sun.  What Mission Chinese Food was trying to accomplish is the dirty hole in the wall Chinese style food (great food, reasonable prices, authentic, etc) without the bad hole in the wall things (F- health rating, etc).  What they ended up with is the traditional comfort food I know but with a higher price point.  Sure, it ain't dirty Chinatown but if I'm going to pay those prices, I expect more.  Here's what was ordered:

1. Tea Smoked Eel - Eel covered in rice noodle.  A great appetizer to start.

2. Salt Cod Fried Rice - Saltier than normal salted fish fried rice.  1.5x the price of what one will expect.  Portion size is on par with the hole in the wall equivalents.

3. Cumin Lamb Ribs - Tasty but small portions.

4. Spicy Beef Chow Mein - A good carb filler.

5. Tiki Pork Belly - Big slices of bacon but not enough pieces to be satisfactory.

6. Ma Po Tofu - Too numbingly spicy for a ma po tofu and oilier that standard.
author: Ronald L.

description:
We came into Mission Chinese Food this past Sunday during the SF Sunday Streets event in the Mission. At around 230pm, the restaurant wasn't too packed. We were seated pretty quickly and ordered just a few minutes later. The waitress made a few recommendations for us since it was our first time, which was nice. Since there were just 2 of us and the meals come family style, we went with two dishes..the Kung Pao Pastrami and Salt Cod Fried Rice. Both were good, the Kung Pao wasn't too spicy, and the fried rice was flavorful. Perhaps the pastrami was a little salty, but still very tasty. 

The restaurant has a divey feel, definitely nothing fancy.  I'll be back again to give the other dishes a try.
author: Camille B.

description:
Great chicken. Great cod. Open late, but man it's a lot of hype. Typical Mission, hipster hype I suppose? Somehow Mission Chinese has attained a certain cemented reputation amongst late night food. For that reason check it out and dabble about, but I can't see the reason to really go back to this watering hole again unless I am really that intoxicated and craving of Chinese food at such inane hours. 

Can't say that trend with last much longer so I may no longer be a patron ... but if you are, come check it out and grub!
author: Joseph L.

description:
We all try this place because it's #1 on SF's 7x7 100 eats, but after I tried this, I don't think it's something I'd crave coming back for.  

And that's how someone should feel if it's number ONE on 7x7, right?! It's top 100 places to eat in SF and being number one, it should be AMAZING. 

Well, sorry folks. I wouldn't even call this restaurant a real Chinese restaurant. The customers nor the waitresses were even chinese, and that's the FIRST thing I look at to validate some authenticity in chinese restaurants. If anything, I would say this restaurant is a Hipsternese restaurant, playing rock music, dimly lit, christmas lights all around, waitresses in colored denim jeans and tanks, and everyone in the restaurant being Caucasian (no offense). My friend and I were the only Chinese people eating in a chinese restaurant. *awkwardd* 

I kind of got disappointed at that first sight, so I told my friend I would "use the restroom" and spy on the cooks to see if they were even Chinese.  Luckily, they were! So I said ok we'll give it a shot then. We ordered a lot of food just to try it all out, and honestly, the food was average. If you're someone who doesn't eat Chinese food very often I can see how it can be delicious, but I eat Chinese food every day and I can find more authentic food with half the price at a legit chinese restaurant.

1) Infamous Salt Cod Fried Rice: 3 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#w9CRR9nw86uOCQYMhrtbdg
It's good, but it's not amazing. It wasn't salty like some restaurants make it, but I also don't think they added much salt cod in the first place. $10 for this dish but I can get it just as good and cheaper at a local chinese restaurant. But if you like the Americanized atmosphere, then you can come get it here. 

2) Thrice Cooked Bacon: 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#-pKUB0ezT1gypMHSsxgv2Q 
I thought this tasted better than the salt cod fried rice! And though it's supposed to be about the bacon cooked three times, the spicy rice cakes were delicious. If you must come here, I'd recommend getting this and the salt cod fried rice.

3) Slow Cooked Pork Belly: 2.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#6SEs1KMOD-pwuTQe5p579w
Good, but FATTY. I could only eat one and after that was just gross from too much fat. 

4) Sizzling Cumin Lamb: 2 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=OxrqaLf5HrqFtwSrIk9UEA#sR4eAjdfxYnNYwKZeIQr0Q
I'm sorry I can't say much for this dish because from this dish I found out I don't like cumin. I had a feeling it would smell or taste like curry (which I don't eat at all) and it did, so my friend ate it. But he said it was alright, not bad if you like lamb and don't mind cumin/curry like me

OVERALL: not impressed. If you must come here, order the salt cod fried rice and thrice cooked bacon. Otherwise, go to any chinese restaurant where CHINESE people are eating and CHINESE servers are serving.  I like San Tung just because of their fried chicken wings, but this place aint #1 7x7 worthy! Who rates them anyway?
author: Raquel Y.

description:
We got MCF for delivery.  We got the salt cod fried rice, thrice cooked bacon, and broccoli and beef.

salt cod fried rice: very tasty, but can use a lot more cod and sausage though.  

thrice cooked bacon: do not get!  There's virtually no bacon in this dish!  It's mostly the "dough."  Completely not worth the money and way too spicy.  Nothing special about this dish at all.

Broccoli and beef: good, but the broccoli was a bit overcooked.  The beef was tender and good, but again, not enough.  It's mostly vegetables.

Tastes good, but not worth the money for the portion size and the lack of meat in the dishes.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Ordered:  
Smashed cucumbers
Thrice cooked bacon rice cake something something?
Kung pao pastrami

I admittedly have huge biases against Asian fusion, so this may not actually be the most fair review.  However, it's because of places like this that I have such disdain for Asian fusion.  If I had to summarize it in a word?  Lazy.

I asked the waitress what the favorites were, and she referred to the above.  The cucumbers were there mostly because I felt the need for something green, and maybe something refreshing to counter the meaty sounding dishes.  I say this mostly to show that I didn't go out of my way to order the worst dishes here and that it was likely a representative sample, if not among the best that they serve.

The food was only superficially Chinese.  Kung pao with celery?  No, just no.  I don't even know what was going on in the bacon dish, as it was just a mish mash of tastes and textures that it just felt off and didn't synergize into anything resembling Chinese food.  And yes, I understand that this is "Asian fusion," but like I said, it did it in a lazy way.  That is, protein substitution.  Pastrami instead of chicken, isn't that original ha ha ha ha ha aren't I hip ha ha ha ha ha???  No.  Please stop.  I mean, it's not Panda Express, but it's more like oriental flavored American food than anything resembling a fusion of either cuisine.

None of this justified the price, by the way.  Entrees were about double what you would find in normal Chinese restaurants (barring the fancier dishes like Peking Duck or whatnot).  Portions were okay though.

The service was quick, but I'm not sure I would call it friendly.  I noticed that our waitress never made eye contact, always staring off somewhere out towards the street.  Maybe she was looking at another table, but I don't know what distant locales she really saw while asking if I wanted some rice with anything.  Somehow, this "I don't really give a fuck" attitude was the most authentically Chinese part of this restaurant experience.  But you know, it did its job.
author: Norman S.

description: Food is pretty good, but definitely not great enough to be worth the wait (we even had a wait with a reservation). Also the ambiance is horrible. The servers don't seem to care about your basic needs like water, the food takes a very long time to show up, and you are crammed in so much with other guests that I'm amazed that it is not a legal fire hazard. I would say order takeout but the food is too expensive to be a good takeout option. I know it is hip but I won't be back after both times I visited.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Today is a sad day. It marks the last time I will eat at Mission Chinese Food SF. 

I've always been a fan of lamb face noodle soup -- see my review from 2012. I had that same dish for lunch today, and was disappointed in both taste and portion size. I told the waitress that the portion size was smaller than I remembered (after I had finished the food, I had no intention of sending the food back). She said "yeah it's a little bit smaller but not that small". After she swiped my card and came back with the receipts, she said "the chef says food has gotten more expensive".  I weep for you MCF, if the $7 pho place down the street can still turn a profit, yet you can't survive with your $14 child-sized noodle soup.
author: Sylvia W.

description:
This place has been on my list to visit for a long time and I wanted to love it.  The highs were the Beer Brined Sichuan Pickles, which were so flavorful and spicy.  The second runner up was the Tea Smoked Eel which was a very nice break from the pickles.  On to the mediocre at best was the Salt Cod Fried Rice which I would have liked to see more Salt Cod.  The Cumin Lamb Ribs were a huge disappointment. They were overcooked and the pool of sauce couldn't break through to the hard exterior to flavor the meat.  To make matters worse I couldn't detect the vaguest hint of Cumin.  I would have to call this dish lamb abuse at it's worst.

The interior is dim with a big red dragon floating overhead.  The service was fine if unremarkable.  The beer list covers the expected, but no complaints.  With all of the really great places to eat, many that provide more bang for the buck, I would skip this experience.
author: Heather D.

description: The most incredibly tasty meal!!!! I'm only visiting SF for a few days but I may have to go back....each dish was so tasty and flavorful. Squid ink noodles, rice porridge, the fried pumpkin, and the cumin lamb were all smash hits. Also points for unique decor and ambiance, every element was loud like the flavors.
author: Miranda B.

description:
Overrated....

I was super pumped to try out Mission Chinese for dinner with some friends but we didn't have a very pleasant experience. We arrived a little after 5 PM (after looking for parking for a good 10-15 minutes) and added our name on the list outside. We were called after five minutes and they sat us right in the middle of the tiny restaurant and brought us menus. *Caution: Once you step inside you are overwhelmed with the smell of spices... people were coughing all over the place!!! 

We looked at the dishes and decided what we wanted to order, but for some reason we couldn't flag any of the waitresses down! It seemed like they were just walking by and ignoring us even when we were all looking around and obviously ready to order. I even asked one of the waitresses "Could we order please?" and she said "yeah" and never came back. WTF. Not cool. After 10-15 minutes of being ignored and no service a bunch of my friends started trying to flag someone down and FINALLY one of the waitresses came over. Not a good start.

We ordered the tea smoked eel, dumplings, cod fried rice, and mapo tofu. The eel was quite good, big pieces of eel with a nice rice wrapper and some crunchy celery inside. The dumplings were tasty but they were small and way overpriced for what they were. The cod fried rice had barely any cod in it =( which was disappointing because COD is in the name, but the addition of Taiwanese sausage in the mix was nice. Finally the mapo tofu was SPICY! Be aware this dish will make your mouth tingle. I am a big fan of mapo tofu but I've never had it this spicy before; it was good but you sure have to be careful!

In the end the food was meh, the service was horrible and the prices were too high. Save yourself the trouble, there are plenty of better Chinese places in the city.
author: Sam F.

description: The neighborhood was not pleasant (an understatement). The cod fried rice was bland. The eggplant side dish had a terrible licorice flavor and was undercooked. The chow mien was the best part of the meal but not by much. AND, it was expensive! I would definitely not return. The one plus of the restaurant is that the ambiance was kinda cute inside.
author: Erica P.

description:
Came here 3 years ago and remember not being impressed, left thinking "this is a chinese spot for white hipsters".. meh. Very likely an untrue and unfair statement, but you know how it sometimes goes..

I gave it another try tonight after finding out they deliver now through eat24, no line? OK ready to go round 2!!

I can't say I felt much differently tonight than I did 3 years ago.  For some reason it just didn't hit the spot, although I would say I went in wanting to love then rave about it!  My favorite was the salted cod fried rice of the things I had this time around.

Salted Cod Fried Rice - 4 stars
Mapo Tofu - me = 3 stars, the hubby thought this was amazing and he usually doesnt like touf. i always LOVE tofu, but thought this was 3 stars.
3x cooked bacon & rice cakes - too salty for me and didn't like the flavor overall

For me, there's too much other stuff I want to try in SF to give this another try, but CLEARLY it is loved by lots of other folks and is doing well.
author: Melody T.

description:
Awesome fusion food! I love how some people complain it's not real Chinese food! Duh!!!! 
If you don't want to wait in lines go there for lunch! Super hipster place! Love it!
author: Dimitri L.

description:
So many haters out there! I loved Mission Chinese Food, and in a city where there  is a plethora of amazing restaurants, I can honestly say: "I'll be back."

Far from authentic, or at least far from the authentic I know. I can tell you this much, the Oakland Chinatown scene isn't serving up chicken schmaltz fried rice and kung pao pastrami, both of which were devoured at Mission Chinese.

Quick back story: Danny Bowien (chef/restauranteur) opened one up in NYC after so much success here in SF and the wait to eat in NYC was hours. Like unbearable. If you didn't get there at 5pm to put your name down, you weren't gonna get a chance to eat until 11pm type deal. I am so pumped that was not the same experience here!

Ok the deal: no reservations, first come, first serve and your party must be present to be seated. You leave your name on a pad and you either wait or leave and if your name is called while you have taken reprieve at a local bar, you can come back let them know and you'll be up next. It works. We arrived at about 7 on a Saturday night to a wait, came back at 9 and were easily seated.

Hip hop is always the best music you can play, especially when eating in a dark, kitschy Chinese restaurant. Yes, call me a hipster, call me whatever you like, but I'm into the vibe. Service suits the restaurant. My water glass was always full, my food came out quickly and we exchanged pleasantries. What else are you looking for?

Now the food. I suggest going family style. All of the portions were large. There were 3 grown men and myself and this was more than enough food. Nothing was over oily, like Chinese food can tend to be. Lots of sodium, but again they didn't over do it and what do you expect? This is Chinese food!

 - Thrice cooked bacon - Salty, delicious and those flat slices of dough add this great texture. A nice side dish to share.
- Pork dumplings - This is on the to-go menu, but they hooked it up. More gyoza than dumplings. They were good, but there's better out there. 
- Tea smoked eel - Funky. I liked it, but didn't love it. I wouldn't order again. The combo of ingredients didn't mesh as well as it could have. Definitely unique.
- Kung Pao pastrami - Such a unique dish. Chunks of pastrami sauteed with potato, celery and peanuts with a hint of spice. Really great dish. A table favorite.
- Schmaltz rice - chicken fat dressed rice with cucumber and a hint of hot sauce. I wouldn't order this as a main entree, but it went perfectly with the spiciness of the other dishes. Very subtle flavor, but so buttery and delicious. I loved this.
- Spicy beef chow mein - My favorite with the rice. Spicy, delicious beef sauteed with noodles and vegetables. 

Between the quality ingredients, the large portion sizes and the creativity of the food, Mission Chinese is it. We left full with a bottle of sake, dropping about $30 per person. For a night out in the Mission that isn't a massive burrito, look no further.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
It's always good to give back to the community.

For every entree ordered, 75 cents is donated to SF Food Bank. Between the three of us, we ordered 4 dishes, so my good deed is done for the year! ;-)

Mission Chinese Food operates at Lung Shan restaurant and on this stretch of Mission st, it's a bit sketchy but brave it and get ready to treat your taste buds to amazing Sichuan inspired Chinese food.  Don't go looking for sweet and sour pork here, think more traditional (but with a modern twist!) less Americanized Chinese food. 

Beijing vinegar peanuts? my cousin loved this! 

Tea smoked eel with pulled ham hock wrapped in rice noodle? divine! 

Salt cod fried rice with Chinese sausage in escolar confit? a new twist on an old fave of mine! 

Cold eggplant with sliced onions and tzatziki sauce? fusion-y but delish!

Beef cheeks with poached oysters and gai lan in smoked oyster sauce? OMG. me love you long time!

MCF is a no frills Chinese restaurant. They have a no-reservation policy so there's always a line, but the fact that nothing on the menu is over $16 makes this place worth the wait.
author: Janice C.

description: Used to really like this place but quality has gone down since. Smaller portions and the dishes are not as tasty as they were.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Haven't been to Mission Chinese for a long time. Only tried it a few other times when a friend got it to go. Enjoyed it every time. But I was not very impressed with what I got this time.

Salt Cod Fried Rice - $13 - Remembered this being my favorite. It was solid, but just not as good as I remembered. It was cooked well, but I just don't know if it was worth $13.

Pork Ma Po Tofu - $14 - Pretty good, but the chili pods were a bit overwhelming and completely took out my taste buds.

Kung Pao Pastrami - $15 - This dish had everything that I know I would love, and it was ok, just WAY too salty for me, and I love salt, so that's saying a lot.

The wait staff was very friend, the food arrived quickly, and the atmosphere was great, but with all the good Chinese spots in the bay area, it's hard for me to say if I'll be back again.
author: Ronny D.

description:
Only reason Mission Chinese isn't getting a better review is 100% because of their awful service. For the amount of hype this place gets, you'd expect a nicer staff or at least one that pays attention to you! We had a reservation for 7:15 and were ignored for about 20 minutes left standing in the doorway. Surprised we even stayed!

After finally being seated....
Apparently their chicken wings are amazing but they were way too spicy for me to try. The Brisket was good - a bit fatty. My favorite by far was the sesame chicken (but can you actually go wrong with that?)

Don't think i'll be coming back.
author: Becky S.

description:
We stopped by for a snack before dinner and it was good. But a couple minutes after paying the bill, the staff took my half beer and let us know that they had reservations waiting and we needed to leave, with attitude. 

I'm sorry, but that is not my problem. Meanwhile there wasn't anyone waiting. 

I was excited to eat here, but it seems like the notoriety has gone to your head and you somehow feel this is acceptable service.
author: Steve G.

description:
just average americanized chinese food. meepsies. and i wanted to love it. buutttt i also came here with a not so fun date, so i guess that's part of why i didnt love it. sigh! 

we got a beer each, which were almost room temperate. meeps. i kinda like my beers to be cold! ordered the wings, which were not spicy! meepes! and there were like 6 wings, a mountain of chillies, and crispy pork skins! then we got squid ink noodles with cumin lamb. this was probs my fave..! lots of good flavors :)

overall a good spot in the mission for some eeeeaaats, but probs will not be coming back.. :(
author: Christina L.

description: Good food. But not quite sure if it's worth the wait. Weather was horrible. Good thing we didn't need to wait long. Make reservations online. Or take home. Pork belly was yum!!
author: John Z.

description:
Don't come here thinking you'll get authentic Chinese food.  Instead, come with a blank slate and open mind.  The boyfriend and I came here as soon as it opened so there was no line.  We opted to order their more fusion-y dishes over their traditional sounding dishes.

Smashed cucumbers:  topped with some kind of tahini based sauce.  It was refreshing and tasty.  A nice palette cleanser to munch on in between the heavier dishes.

Tea Smoked Eel:  Also a refreshing.  Wrapped in fresh rice noodle.  The celery added a nice crunch factor to the bite.  

Kung Pao Pastrami:  This was interestingly tasty.  The Sichuan peppercorns were definitely there.  Savory and salty (so it would be good with rice).

Fresh Squid Ink Noodles with Lamb:  This was our FAVORITE dish.  It was like an Italian/Chinese fusion.  A chow fun pasta with a savory sauce and gamey lamb meat.  Definitely try this dish.  It is not available for take out.

The food is great and the prices are reasonable.  Come here if you're interesting in new style dishes.
author: Michelle T.

description: I have been trying to get my wife to come here for months. We ordered the dumpling and fried chicken. The dumplings arrived very quickly and were burnt and maybe room temperature. We sent them back and the next batch arrived. They were hot and still burnt. the oil seem old too... The waiter was super nice and gave us a free seaweed salad. He said this would get us to the fried chicken which takes 20 minutes. That salad was good. The chicken took 40 minutes and was good but by then we had lost all interest and our appetites. Also, the Dumplings were not taken off the bill. I don't send food back often but when I do it is usually comped. I was expecting a James Beard experience. I got a James Beard bill with a rather disappointing experience.
author: Dennis M.

description:
October 2013

You know that horror movie Saw where Jigsaw asks victims to "play a game?"

I felt like I was a character in that movie eating at this place. My buddies and I came here for a birthday and we ordered the pork belly, lamb, and steamed eel.

Oh my goodness, if I had an option to put a knife through my leg, or take another bite of this macabre Asian fusion, I would gladly take the dullest knife and stab myself with it.

The eel came in a weird spring roll form that was soggy and bitter, the lamb was overcooked and dry, and the pork belly was just pork fat. Not crispy, not juicy.

If they're going to make Saw 8, this is the prefect location. Very few would make it out alive.
author: Jack R.

description:
WARNING!!! 

CLOSED UNTIL March 13th 2014....the least they can do is notify/edit Yelp.....
thanks for ruining my SF plans tonight....
author: David W.

description: We had a great time at Mission Chinese. We only had to wait about 10 minutes until we were called in. The Beef Brisket was delicious, the meat just melted in my mouth. Be sure to get the peanut appetizer - AMAZING.
author: Gracie S.

description:
Over-hyped and overpriced.  Food itself is delicious, but better value and authenticity can be had elsewhere.  Service is subpar; too many fatigued hipsters working front house.  Cramped quarters force you to make new friends or flip tables.  

PROTIP:  You must get the breakfast fried rice.  Heartiest twist on a traditional staple.  Fried rice riddled with ikura, bonito flakes, bacon, and egg.  What's not to like?
author: David C.

description:
This is our second time here. The first time I came here I thought the food was pretty good, portions are always bigger and fit for family style with a group of friends if you like sharing plates and trying different dishes.

This time around the food was extremely salty, our lips felt tingly and our mouth felt dry. It was so uncomfortable we couldn't eat any more. 

We had the fiery chicken wings, stir fried long beans, tofu with pork and salt cod fried rice (which was probably the most bearable to eat).

The service was good, considering it was a Friday night, they sat us down pretty quickly. The food was disappointing - not sure if I'll be back again anytime soon.
author: Rosie R.

description: VEGAN MAPO TOFU, so good and so hard to find this dish without meat. Ordered delivery- great for takeout as it's often busy in the restaurant.
author: Mariana P.

description:
it was spicy. Crowded. Interesting tastes. A bit overrated.
The thrice cooked bacon with spicy rice cakes was nice. I wish they had Malaysian Beef jerky fried rice on their menu and we didn't order their special spicy hot chinese fried chicken wings.... I regret not doing that.
author: Stan W.

description:
3.5 stars

I've heard so many things about Mission Chinese Food from NBC Bay Area to Details Magazine, newspapers and much more. Portions are big are MCF and the service is great. If you arrive early, you can get a table easily at the restaurant. My friend and I ordered the pork belly with the pineapple and the thrice cooked bacon with the rice cake, tofu, bittermelon and onions. Also a cup of steamed rice too!

The pork belly dish was good and it reminded me of a very, very similar dish at The Playground in Santa Ana from the chef who won The Food Network's Great Food Truck Race. Simple fried pork belly with some peppers, pineapple and a sauce similar to hoison sauce. I loved this a lot and would definitely get it again. The thrice cooked bacon however, I could hardly find any bacon. The dish was very spicy and I love me some spicy food but this even made my lips burn. It's a very greasy dish I might add and goes better with steamed rice. If you need to go to the bathroom, you might be a little shocked because you get to walk through the kitchen and it's quite a sight. Overall, at least I got to try MCF and thought it wasn't bad but not the best.
author: Danster L.

description: Great fresh simple Chinese that went to the next level!!  The greens and the porkbelly were to die for!!  I mean absolutely fantastic!!  I won't forget this meal for a long time!!!  This place is fed hard to find even though it is directly on mission street but if you try hard enough you will find this small hip place!!
author: Billy F.

description:
Disappointing given the hype.

I had super high hopes for this place - so well rated and spoken about. 

The dishes were just too fatty for me - we got some beef brisket and the chow me in. We also had a Hawaiian pork belly app and that was also tough. Everything was very smokey tasting. 

Loved the old school Chinese food restaurant vibe and cool waiters.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
So first off we USED to love this place. After a few meh to-go orders, we had super high hope and were craving the pork ma po. I called about our missing 11 dollar rice, I was met with extreme condescension and was called a liar. This is about RICE, people. We just want what we ordered.

To Danny Bowien: in congruence with other yelp reviews... Please,for the love of your business, fire that lunatic bitch that answers your phone and takes to-go food payment for orders. She doing some major damage to your rep.
author: Slone F.

description: Hip spot, interesting food, however the order the food arrived was really wrong. Two mains arrived before appetizer, rice followed a long time afterward. It's possible to have yummy food and screw it up by ordering things completely wrong...
author: Nancy M.

description:
What a pleasure.

I came here Saturday night with some friends. We had reservations at 7pm but were running late so we called and asked to push them back to 7:40pm, surprisingly they pushed it back and seated us promptly at 7:40 even though the other 2 in our party were running about 5mins late.

The atmosphere is fun and hip. It is sticking with that old Chinese hole in the wall restaurant feel but at the same time being super hip and fun. 

The food was exceptional, the service was great and the overall vibe was amazing.

This truly was a great treat for a Saturday night. I left with a huge smile on my face that night!

Thank You Mission Chinese
author: Kyle U.

description: While Mission Chinese can certainly put out a decent plate of food, I found their service to be lacking and in some cases a little rude. My plate had three large jagged chips on the face of it, so I politely asked for a replacement just to have an employee of the restaurant exclaim "They're all chipped!". The obvious solution is to get some new plates, you're a restaurant after all. Later this employee turned out to be the chef who was helping with tables. Regardless, that's not an excuse for a bad attitude in response to a reasonable request. Lastly we ordered 4 small dishes but the 4th, some simple green beans didn't show up until the conclusion of the meal. This time our waiter exclaimed "they're coming!". Funny part was we only asked about them once, and the remark was made later without any prompt from us. In general the service was slow, and it took a long time to get refills on water. I couldn't help but get the impression that as a customer we were somehow an inconvenience to them. In the end our green beans were taken off the check, which is why this review is 2 stars instead of 1.
author: Benin B.

description:
VEGAN REVIEW: they've got V labeled for the things they can make vegetarian and vegan so major props for that! 

I got the 3X cooked bacon with rice cakes - it was spicy and pretty good except for the oiliness - toooo oily! And it was loaded with jalapeños, something I don't do well with personally. All in all, nice atmosphere and it was fun to check out but the food wasn't memorable.
author: Dorothy T.

description:
Went here for dinner one Friday night because I've had friends recommend it for months and months.. so I finally get a chance to go here with my girlfriend and mother of god...... you couldn't pay me to eat here again.

Maybe they had a new guy in back of house?...... Maybe they sabotaged me because I asked for light spiciness on the Kung Pao Pastrami because my girlfriend isn't a big fan of it?.............Maybe the top of the salt shaker fell off, like in that age-old prank where you unscrew the lid and wait for the next person to use it?

I have no idea what the cause, but bruh I left here feeling like my insides were decaying because of the level of saltiness on that Kung Pao Pastrami. The texture of the sauce was straight up Clint Eastwood with all that grittiness from the salt.

Combine this magical experience with a red strobe like flashing in your face and watch how much fun the rest of your night is. If I had any form of epilepsy or high blood pressure walking into this place... I'd have left on a stretcher.
author: Michio F.

description:
There's been an odd renaissance of Sichuan style food in the bay area recently. Most of them are new establishments executing traditional recipes in wonderful ways. Danny Bowien and Anthony Myint are executing things with a twist. Their dedication to the smoked meat arts is what makes the twist interesting here. 

-Thrice cooked bacon, rice cakes, bitter melon, tofu skin, scallion, black bean, chili oil
-Kung pao pastrami, explosive chili, celery potato,roasted peanuts
-Sizzling cumin lamb, salt & pepper lamb belly, chili pickled long beans

Lots of classic flavors with their modern twists. Pretty darn tasty. I'm not sure that it's the game changer that a lot of the food critics are heaping but it is solid food. 

The place is crazy hipster crowded. In fact People are just flowing out on the streets. It's a veritable shit show. So just get your food to go. They pump that shit out fast like any respectable Chinese place. 

The one distinguishing thing that MCF does that's different than most Chinese places or any places that serve food in general is the impact and policy/politics of said food. They donate a portion of each entree price to the food bank. Like the former Mission Street Food (their chef homages), Myint's association with Commonwealth, and quite possibly the future Mission Bowling Club, they're carrying a sense of food activism. It's something refreshing to see. I think it's worth picking up their recently published book to delve deeper into what they're about.
author: Kim N.

description:
I went to Mission Chinese Food with high expectations. I visited Mission Cantina in NYC for their Vietnamese breakfast. Mission Cantina is under the same ownership as Mission Chinese Food and I was expecting the same greatness I had encountered at Cantina. Unfortunately, I left disappointed. The food was a bit below average, the service was solid, the music taste was on point. 

A friend and I ordered three dishes. General Tso's veal rib, egg noodles, and forbidden  fried rice. The veal rib came out first and it tasted great. The sauce had the right balance of sweet and tangy. The viscosity of the sauce gave it a really nice visual. It was crispy and fatty and my favorite dish of the night. The egg noodles and forbidden fried rice came out together but neither was impressive. We both agreed that the egg noodles heavy use of ginger completely destroyed the dish. We could not taste anything but ginger. It was as if the noodles were a vehicle for the ginger. The forbidden rice was neither good nor bad. It was just your average fried rice. The three dishes left us wondering wether we had simply ordered the wrong items on the menu or went in with incredibly high expectations.  I think it was a little of both. The food was average, but the service was solid.

The waiter was pretty knowledgeable of the menu. Went with the veal rib after speaking to him about the dish. The dishes came out in a  reasonable amount of time and the wait for a table was in the neighborhood of ten minutes. The decor was what you would imagine a hipster Chinese American restaurant would look like. 

The restaurant was incredibly dark. The only lighting being provided was some old christmas lights and lanterns. It felt like one of those rooms where pictures are developed. The music was on point, but it was loud to the point where we could not carry  a conversation. 

The high expectations were not met. I thought it was going to be as awesome as Mission Cantina's Vietnamese breakfast but it did not come close. I don't put too much weight on decor and service if the food is amazing, but the overwhelming ginger in the egg noodle dish and the unremarkable forbidden rice left me disappointed. I will be trying the Mission Chinese Food in New York City to see if there is a difference.
author: David M.

description:
I can see how some people might not like the vibe here - maybe too hipsterish with a twist?

Personally, I liked the vibe. As a Queens gal, I appreciated the music even though it was all west coast hip hop ;-)

In terms of food - loved the sizzling cumin lamb, the chili chicken. 3.5/5 for the chow mein (a tad greasy) and 3/5 for the spicy chicken wings - weren't too spicy and left a weird taste in my mouth.

Gotta come back for some more tunes and to try the eel rolls and a few more things.
author: Yomna N.

description:
So we stopped at this Famous Chinese non Chinese place as part of our tour. There was an interesting story about how a gentleman wanted to cook food and rented space at this Chinese restaurant and somehow they started making strange Chinese food.  Now when I say strange, I mean strange but not necessarily good.

We tried Kung Bao Pastrami and I found it to be way to salty and really not very tasty.  I love pastrami but it just didn't blend well for me.  I rated this place three stars as I did look over the menu and several of their items did sound quite tasty.  

I know this place is quite famous but I will just give her 3 stars for now.
author: Douglas Y.

description:
I should start this review by telling you that I'm a picky eater. The 3 people I dined with arn't though. After being recommended Mission Chinese by so many people I was really looking forward to trying it.

Then I saw the menu. Nothing looked super appealing, but I had been recomended the burrito, so I ordered the one with the tofu inside. The people I was with ordered a bunch of other things to all share. My burrito came with cod fried rice. It was super fishy. Like fish that had been left out on the counter for 2 days fishy. Unbareably fishy. It was totally inediable. My other friends tried it and agreed that it was too fishy and no one wanted a second bite. Thus 3/4 of the burrito went uneaten. 

My friends ordered the mushroom fried rice, ribs, chicken wings, and some noodle dish. The only dish that anyone actually enjoyed were the ribs, though I wasn't a huge fan of them. To me the only thing that I wanted a second  serving of were the chicken wings, but not because they are good. They are covered in some sort of chili - lime rub. When you eat them your mouth goes numb and everything tastes weird afterwards. Not a totally enjoyable experience, but I had a second one for the novalty of it.

There's also only one toilet and this place is always packed, so expect waiting 10 minutes or so for your chance to pee.

All in all a super dissapointing dinning expereince. Never again.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Smart, spicy, and doing it like no one else, Mission Chinese Food deserves every bit of these 5 stars just for the Thrice Cooked Bacon alone. 

Look, I know it isn't cool to still love Mission Chinese. I know Danny Bowien has left SF to sling tacos in NYC. But guess what citizens and visitors of San Francisco? Danny Bowien's greatest legacy to food right now is not Mission Cantina (I have eaten there many times btw) but Mission Chinese, especially with such outstanding and inventive dishes as Kung Pao Pastrami, Salt Cod Fried Rice, and Tiki Pork Belly. And y'know what? There is NO Mission Chinese Food right now in NYC. 

The Chongking Chicken Wings are so good but have so much Szechuan Peppercorn that my mouth was vibrating for the next hour. The Schmaltz Rice here is ADDICTIVE, be warned. The Mongolian Long Beans are also amazing and are way more tasty and less oily than the braised pea leaves. As mentioned, the the Trice Cooked Bacon here is phenomenal.

This really is still where it's at in terms of Bowien's best cuisine and I really feel anyone with access to the original MCF should count their lucky stars (especially now that they deliver all over SF)

Now, I am not going to say I came all the way to San Francisco with my girlfriend just to get my Mission Chinese fix, but I will say that once I sat down and ate this inventive, wildly delicious food I was once again deeply saddened we no longer have anything like this in NYC.
author: Paul A.

description: My #1 in SF! Thrice cooked bacon might be my favorite thing in the world! The wait staff is always on point, and the food is just insane!
author: A.J. S.

description: This place is a gem. Everything is good on the menu. Come at night. The red lights and music makes it a great date spot.
author: Phil K.

description:
7x7 100 Best Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2012

#1 Salted Cod Fried Rice (not in order)

Mission Chinese Food simply put is, Americanized Chinese food meets modern day youth. As soon as you walk in, you will notice immediately how dim and cramp the restaurant is which made it really hard to sit comfortably while attempting to read the menu. Gone are the typical chinese fixtures and soothing ambient music. Instead, there is house music blasting throughout the slightly "run down" vibe of the room.

Salted Cod Fried Rice: wasn't too salty which is a good sign of quality salted cod. If its too salty that means its inferior quality

Mapo Tofu: it was so ridiculously spicy that it blew out my palate. This is probably the most nontraditional Mapo tofu I have ever tried

Pork Belly: overly charred top but the meat itself was flavorful, slightly overcooked

Porridge: the burnt pieces of pork ruined the dish and made it hard to enjoy the rest of the dish

Spring Rolls: fresh but lacked much seasoning

Thrice Cooked Pork: sliced rice cakes were great, pork was adequate but overall felt there was a strange flavor in the dish that I couldn't overlook

Price point and service was in line with what we got

Overall Thoughts

My friends loved it more than I did mainly because I don't find myself to gravitate towards these kind of establishments where they try to add a modern twist to traditional fares.
author: Eddie W.

description:
Whoa. This place wasn't like the Chinese restaurants I'm used to in South Bay.
I came here for a late dinner with three other friends, and we waited about 15 minutes before we got seated. It is small and pretty dark inside (red lights), and I don't know if this is the norm, but the restaurant was playing a lot of hip hop music (mostly Kendrick Lamar songs). It was a unique experience eating at a Chinese restaurant while bobbing my head to some MAAD City. 
We ordered Salt Cod Fried Rice, Spicy Beef Chow Mein, and some other dish I forgot. Out of the three, the Salt Cod Fried Rice was hands down the best. If I come back, I wouldn't order anything else but that entree.
author: Annie S.

description:
The food was OK. They are trying so hard. Its very hipster. By hipster I mean they pack people in to a loud tiny area so that a line forms, and then use the line as a sort of attraction to get the line longer.

I hope they follow the emerging trend of seating less people at a time in order to raise the quality of the overall experience a notch. Yes, this might require a small investment from the business. Better than having the servers ass bang against the back of customers heads in order to maneuver around and take orders all night long.

I will check back again in a couple of months, hopefully not like the rest of the Mission.... going going gone.
author: Warren D.

description:
This was my cousin's favorite spot during our foodie pilgrimage to SF last weekend.  I would say that it wasn't mine, although it was quite tasty.  I found the dishes we ordered a bit on the greasy/ oily side, but I think those going for Chinese-American food are looking for that, no? The menu was definitely creative and interesting.  Although our waitress was a definite ditz, her suggestions were spot on:

-- Tea-smoked eel
-- Sour Chili Chicken
-- 3x cooked bacon and rice cakes (without the bacon)
-- Stir-fried Squid Ink Noodles

We found that the mix of 2 apps and 2 entrees were the perfect amount for a not-super-hungry group of 4 people at 5:30pm (early dinner).  (At 5:15pm on a Saturday night, we arrived to an almost empty restaurant but the place filled up quickly and by 6:15pm it was a packed house with a short line outside!) My fav was the thrice cooked "bacon".  Being that the group is used to spicy food, I didn't find anything mouth burning, as other Yelpers have mentioned, but I am glad we went with a mix of fiery and non-fiery dishes.  I'm glad I tried MC once, but I can't see myself craving it.  My cousin, who conveniently lives in the Bay Area, was saying that she'd likely come once a month as she LOVED it.  So different strokes...

I don't quite get MC ending up at the #9 spot on BA's Top 20 Restaurants in America.
author: Arti N.

description: If you're on a mission in the Mission for good Chinese food, then look no further than Mission Chinese Food. I have eaten Chinese food all my life and thought that it was mission impossible to surprise me. The thrice cooked bacon and rice cake dish was succulent and full of complex flavor. The wings are fiery, but have other herbs to give it an additional zippy kick. If you want a dish that is pleasant and not overpowering, I would suggest the salt cod fried rice. Mission Chinese Restaurant rose to my challenge and accomplished it with flying colors. The sign outside says Lung Shan Restaurant.
author: Alexander W.

description:
How is this place rated 3.5 stars on Yelp? It is amazing. I'd come here all of the time - if there wasn't always a 1 hour long wait :(. 

That being said, we ended up popping down at the BBQ place down the street and doing flights of whiskey. Came back just as our names were called (40 minutes?) so I guess the wait wasn't SO bad.

Order:
* Tea smoked eel rolls: Was looking forward to this and wasn't disappointed. There's a very pleasant crunch that I didn't expect when you bite into it. 
* Chicken wings: If you like spicy, this is for you. It's mouth-numbing in a wonderful, delicious way. I love authentic Sichuan food and this hits you in the mouth hard. 

Maybes:
* Ma po tofu: Really yummy but less of a ma po tofu (kill-your-mouth-spicy) and more of a tofu cooked in a pork sauce. Good but not really what I had hoped for.
* Squid ink noodles: Nice thick noodles cooked in squid ink. Very good. But wish I had room in my stomach to try something else instead... like the rice noodles.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
Mission Chinese Food is the epitome of HIPSTERNESE FOOD! Residing next to a ghetto fabulous beauty shop, MCF serves Szechaun fare cooked by a Korean Chef and served by an all English-speaking waitstaff in a cheezy, stereotypical Chinese hole-in-the-wall joint playing West Coast rap. Only in the WEST SIDEEEEEEEEE would you experience something like this. 

While I'm a twinkie in some retrospects, I have a FOB palate, Fung Zhao (Chicken Feet): BRING IT and Lauh Lin (Durian): GIVE IT TO ME BABY! *Burp* Yah, sexy feet breath!  Yes, I devour things my Mom who grew up in the villages of Macau wouldn't even touch. So given the hype, naturally MCF sparked my interest although I knew it was a hipster restaurant probably catering to the western palate. Not wanting to be left disappointed, I came with no expectations.

MCF is a hybrid of Old Mandarin Islamic Restaurant, Spices, and Beijing Restaurant that serves Northern Chinese (Szechuan and Shanghai) influenced cuisine, so you will not find your typical Sweet and Sour Pork or Chow Mein here. 

Yesterday, 7.14.11, my friends and I (party of 8) came to MCF for dinner at 7 PM (we put our name down at 6 PM). To avoid a long wait, come before 6 PM.

F O O D
Since we had a large party, we doubled/tripled up on some dishes. MCF also serves wine and beer. 

*SZECHUAN PICKLES w/ Roasted Peanuts ($3) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=gs2cjGHQL-c-5HhZzQqM8w
Like a Chinese version of kimchi, the napa cabbage and cucumbers were tangy and spicy and the roasted peanuts gave a nice crunch. 

*THRICE COOKED BACON w/ Rice Cakes, Black Bean & Chili Oil ($10) - 4.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=pW5oWXH6t9PzfYJGfFGD3g
Like very thick noodles, rice cakes can be bland but these babies had a toothsome chewy bite and were packed with flavor from the salty black sauce and the fiery chili oil. The bacon slices were the icing on the cake adding a rich savory porkyness with a pop of smoky flavor.

*SLOW-COOKED CHAR SIU PORK BELLY w/ Soy-Cured Egg ($9) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=JD289Q3xLJtXn_EfWO_KhA
The pork belly was cooked to PERFECTION; it was had a crackling crisp skin and a moist tenderness. The cut had a great balance of tender meat and crispy fat so it wasn't too rich. However, it lacked seasoning to bring out the pork's natural flavor.

*BROCCOLI BEEF CHEEKS ($12) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=LWc-uH-4AENs-L9yp5Refw
The beef cheeks were uber tender, soft and moist with an intense beefy flavor. The gui lan was a vibrant green that was cooked to a perfect al-dente crisp, the way it should be.

*SIZZLING CUMIN LAMB ($12.50) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=gNp9QDwaPoV5d0wK5lHpuw
Consisting of meat from the rack and belly, the lamb was cooked to a perfect crispness while still maintaining a moistness inside. The seasoning of salt, pepper, cumin and peppers created a nice melding of salty, spicy and earthy flavors.

*YELLOWTAIL DUMPLINGS ($8) - 4 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=qfTyPxrnprGtunLHF7WYIg
An unlikely pairing that was surprisingly good; the skin was nicely thick and al-dente with a delicate softness from the yellowtail and savory sweetness from the broth.

*WESTLAKE RICE PORRIDGE w/ Oxtail, Crab & Poached Egg ($10) - 3 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=-DUK_iiv0XGPsUm3tSilEA
Although the oxtail was a savory tenderness and the crab was freshly sweet, the porridge itself was bland with scallions as the prominent flavor. 
 
*SAVORY EGG CUSTARD w/ Uni & Trout Roe ($12) - 3 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=KKgGYs6iFVqXiJ8CozqFlg
The custard was on the firmer side and the uni was missing that creamy brineyness. It was bland and missing a savory tanginess.

*TEA-SMOKED UNAGI w/ Ham Hock & Rice Noodle ($9) - 3 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=1hCHPqLRz2Q69dEhZ-a1BA
Wrapped in too many layers of rice noodles, the rich, fatty, and sweet savoryness of the unagi got lost in the noodles.

*7 PEPPER CHICKEN WINGS ($8) - 2 STARS 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=B7ffYTnKL2TlkVD-92MHEw
The wings were a bit boney, dry, and too salty. Although it was topped with a mound of chili peppers, the prominent spiciness was from the black pepper. 

S E R V I C E
Fast but not friendly. Except for the Asian waiter who tended most tables, the Caucasian and Hapa waitress seemed aloof. Dishes came out lightening fast which satiated our ravenous post-HH appetites. 

For a Korean Chef who learned how to cook by watching cooking shows and only started cooking Chinese food last year, he satisfied my FOB palate while still allowing me to maintain by twinkiness. Yes, even with a calculator, I still can't split the bill without looking confuzzled...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
1-September, Sunday
The interior was drab, dimly lit, 
and seemed like the perfect breeding conditions for roach town.

Stir Fried Pork Jowl w Radish: which was generously portioned but with half a garden's worth of mini-radish and merely a tenth cheek of jowl, topped with fermented black beans, mint, and a dash of crushed peanuts. 

Squid Ink Noodles: wok tossed, with green onion, and yellow onion.

Both dishes were infused with sodium, and grease, more so even than what you normally would expect of Chinese take-out. I really had to apologize to my poor arteries after this one, sorry guys!

Perhaps I'm just not a fan of Chinese no matter how you put a spin on it, and how hyped up it becomes (truth-be-told I did come here after seeing it featured on Anthony Bordain). Although I'm glad I came here over Labor day weekend, and avoid that uncomfortable looking line of broke hipsters.

This place would definitely be more appropriate as an 'open past 2AM' kind of eatery after a rough night out. But perhaps not if you're expecting to still feel any ounce of energy after a starch/grease-heavy lunch here.
author: Ty T.

description: Worst Chinese food experience. The spring rolls that stated crispy on the menu came wrapped in some greasy white cheese looking goop. The chow mein was a weird mix of celery and bean sprouts with soggy noodles and the beef brisket with broccoli was overly salty and instead of broccoli it came with some overcooked leafy veggies. Not sure what it was but certainly not edible. The jasmine rice was the only decent thing on the table. Overall sad experience even in the service as the chow main was randomly dropped off  10 mins later the weird concoction of spring rolls were dropped off and a couple of minutes later the disappointment of a beef brisket was brought to our table. What baffled me was that the place was packed on a Wednesday evening.
author: Eva B.

description: I had the kung pao burrito with pastrami, cod fried rice, celery, peanuts. The spice was just right and the pastrami was very tender. About the pastrami- they give you delicious squares of fresh pastrami, not the shredded stuff. The flavors are there for the stir fry vegetables and cod fried rice are just right. There an interesting crunch you get, which is tasty and that would be the soft peanuts in there. It's definitely a hipster spot like other reviews are saying.  They are friendly. Ordered to-go, and turn around was 10 minutes.
author: Jaime F.

description:
If you're from Sichuan or have a good idea what Sichuan food actually taste like, you can't eat here.  I keep on forgetting that I kinda hate this place. But they look pretty earnest and there really isn't any good Chinese food in the mission. 

But if you're Not very picky about taste you won't know the difference. So enjoy!
author: Fei L.

description: Hmmm....so yea talk about "Red Light Special"....so I took a friend out for the day of fun, frolick but no fornication.....for his birthday. He is of the Asian race so I truly thought this restaurant would be in his wheel house....awwwwhhhh hell naw....and I had to apologize and put a redo on the calendar....oh boy. .....I made the reservation through the Reserve App (that app sucks btw, but that's a different review). We arrived 30 minutes early and they were able to seat us right away. It is a small narrow place with red Christmas lights going along the sides of the walls....yea. We sat down to take a look at the menu (I peeked beforehand). One thing that we noticed at the same time was that there was American Cheese in the Dan Dan Noodles...my friend's temperament did a complete 360 from talking and engaging to complete silence until we left the restaurant.....talk about awkward .... He was so fuqn annoyed not to mention even though they had fans going in the restaurant it was still a hot azz box up in there.....Jeeb-burzs.....different  servers would come to the table and by it being our first time there we had a lot of questions ......I guess we had too many questions for one of the servers she lost her patience, turned her head and rolled her eyes.....it took everything for me not to lose my shit.....of course I knew how to take care of that (she made our dinner that much shorter and cheaper, thanks doll)...we ordered the Filipino fried chicken and the smoky spicy American corn to share @ Mission Chinese. CTFU......we got our food quick...but uhm yea the food was really salty.....so before you go make sure to hydrate!!!!!! I would have to agree with another review...."the food is skin deep and confused about its place.......or maybe I was just confused and wanted it to be much more....Oh Boy.....
author: Stacie J.

description: Finally giving out a one star rating. Terrible experience. We had a reservation but had to wait 30 min. When they finally sat us it was at a cramped table in the very front. The waitress said the dishes we ordered weren't spicy but they were so spicy we couldn't eat them. And we paid $75 for the privilege.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Finally have been able to try Mission Chinese. 

My friends got there around 6 and there was apparently no line. But around 6:30 when I finally made it there, it was packed inside and there was a large line outside as well. 

We ordered:
Thrice cooked bacon - this was as good as i remembered it. However, I must have been able to handle the heat, or the last time I ordered it, it didn't have as much heat in it, because my mouth was burning up. Still delicious though
Forbidden fried rice -  It was pretty good, but not amazing. Somehow I think I could have made a better fried rice. I like my fried rice full of veggies and this was just a bit of egg. Not even that much. 
Cumin lamb ribs - so tender, fatty and delicious. the sauce that they put on it makes it just so good. 

Overall, good place, long lines. Definitely one of the better Chinese places in the area. It's more like a new spin on traditional Chinese dishes - which I enjoy sometimes.

Protip: get there early and grab some decent Chinese food.
author: Nina Y.

description: Each time I'm in SF, I'll always make sure to eat at MSC. Overall a consistent dining experience with a hip atmosphere.
author: Gary B.

description:
I thought I'd give it a second try and returned to MCF recently. But immediately, I was again disappointed with it. It's Chinese food with a twist, and not necessarily in a good way.
 
We shared the pork belly, explosive spicy chicken wings, and ribs (with coca cola glaze). The pork belly was tender and tasty, but the chicken wings were dry and way too spicy and the ribs were just too sweet. Overall, another meh service and not worth the price.
author: Cassy H.

description:
Man, what's with all the bad reviews? I read about MCF in Bon Appetit, so despite all the negative reviews, I had to come try it. We got here around 8:30pm on Sat night and ended up waiting over an hour. (That part sucked.) I will warn you that this place looks like a ghetto Chinese restaurant, but it does not serve ghetto Chinese food. The food is more fusion, and most of the people eating here are hipsters or non-Asians. I think initially that was a really big negative, since usually a sure sign of an ethnic restaurant being good is when _insert said ethnic group_ eats there. Like my brother said, "I feel a little embarrassed to be the only Asian people eating at an Asian restaurant."

But if you set your expectations as coming to MCF to eat straight-up good food, not about coming to eat specifically Chinese food, I think you'll be pleasantly surprised. That may be an understatement. 

Must gets:
#1- Squid ink noodles. I guess they don't do to-go so it's not listed on their website menu. This dish was awesome. It's squid ink (thick) noodles with lamb, fennel, chickpeas, and onions. It also comes with a dipping sauce, which might have been some buttery lamb broth. I don't really care what it was, but if you're a big fan of lamb, you'll love this dish.

#2- Thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes. Rice cakes with sweet tofu skin, pepper, and thrice cooked bacon. Really tasty, but the thrice cooked bacon was soft, not crispy, like I'd expect of something cooked thrice. Actually, it was kind of hard to distinguish between the bacon and the tofu skin in the dimly lit restaurant, since both were kind of soft and floppy.

#3- Mongolian long beans. This is mandatory if you're one of those people that feel like you need a vegetable-heavy entree with every meal. It's spicy, but not burn-your-mouth-off spicy. It's a huge dish with lots of long beans, lots of other semi-edible vegetable parts, like ends of boy choy? Like I said, it's hard to tell what things are in the dark. 

Skip it/not sure what the hype is all about:
Loser #1- Kung pao pastrami. Meh. The pastrami was really tender and salty, but it felt like the flavor completely clashed with the kung pao flavors of peanuts and heat. It wasn't by any means bad, but I just wouldn't order it again.

Loser #2- Salt cod fried rice. Sounds exciting with the fish, Chinese sausage, and egg, but at the end of the day, if you've had a fried rice, you've had this fried rice. Nothing about it stood out. Sure, you'll get yummy bits of fish or Chinese sausage, but it's mostly rice and egg.
author: Alice T.

description:
I went to mission Chinese earlier today with my wife and two friends. The food was pretty good, and so was the conversation we were all having as a group. I noticed the staff started removing all the empty plates from our table as soon as we finished our meal, which I thought was a sign of employees at the restaurant being diligent. 

The wait staff then proceeded to drop off the check on the table. My friends and I were in the process of finishing our beers and deciding how to split the bill. We then noticed a restaurant employee with a long face was standing next to our table, which made us feel uncomfortable because he was really looking at us as if he wanted us to get out of there right away. I then asked him (trying to be nice and ask him what his preference would be given we were going to split the bill): excuse me, what's easier for you, if we include the tip on the credit card charge or if we pay it later? He then responded: it doesn't matter what you do as long as you do it fast. At this point I realized this restaurant employee -who appeared to be the manager- did not care about the customer experience and only wanted to get us out of there to make a quick buck on fast table turnarounds. 

I then went on to confront him, letting him know that it is customers like my friends and I who pay his salary and that he shouldn't be treating us like that. I felt I had to do this given we were trying to be nice to restaurant staff - by asking him what payment option would be most convenient for them. Definitely not going back to this establishment given the poor treatment we received. 

I have been to at least 200 different restaurants in San Francisco over the years and have never been treated like this. I'm also not someone who exclusively obssesses on service when going to a restaurant,  but I really feel this mission Chinese employee falls under the 'extremely rude' category.
author: Herman R.

description:
The place was way over-hyped. They were amidst some changes in the menu. This limited our options quite a bit. We went fairly late, so got lucky with the wait :) The 
16 Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes was quite good and had a very interesting texture to it. The Chow mein on the other hand was disappointing, with a very strong ginger flavor

Pros: Service. The waitress gave us a heads-up about the changes
author: Divya A.

description:
OK. Let me start this off by saying that I generally don't write bad Yelp reviews for any businesses, but this needs to be said, and this place will inevitably have long lines of hipsters no matter what I say, so....

Mission Chinese is offensively awful. I have lived in the Bay Area for years and am eternally grateful for its amazing food. This place is what happens when you trick a bunch of kids into uncharged nonsensical crap dressed up in fancy words. The quality is poor and the combination of ingredients is flat out bizarre. Like, not creative, just wrong.

The over seasoning of chicken wings made it borderline inedible, and the squid ink noodles were also hard to eat. The cola pork ribs were fine. 

The best thing going for this place is the E-40 playing in the background, which you can do from your living room.
author: Kira M.

description:
this place provides an unique twist to chinese.
i love the kick of the chongching wings.
the eel rolls i felt had too 2 too many stalks of celery.
egg egg noodles were not too saucy.
overall, everything was done well, but dont expect fine dining or transcendence.

pricing is on par with most of whats in the mission.
if you think this is cheapo chinese food, then its not the place for you.

this place was overhyped in the past, but their food is still good. so now its a good time to visit without the lines.
author: Jason C.

description: I am not sure what the hype is all about - perhaps because there is a great Chinatown in SF and I am comparing my experience to that but the food was lackluster.  A friend took me there for my birthday lunch (I requested it because I heard so much about it) and was thoroughly disappointed.  The food was ok, I don't have complaints but it didn't meet my expectations.  The one small area of improvement...I ordered Jasmine tea and I got a large pot of hot water with a single tea bag.  Either give me a smaller pot or add 2 tea bags.  The tea was tasteless.
author: Katherine K.

description: So much hype but not worth it at all. Bathroom (singular) is in an ally in the back. You have to walk through kitchens to get there and it does not look clean. I was served my sake (nigori) with no cap so I couldn't shake it to prepare for drinking. I had to ask for a glass to drink it. Food was ehh. Not at all one of the best restaurants in SF
author: Meaghan H.

description:
Overpriced and the food was fine. I got a mission Chinese mule, and it was way sweet and in a plastic cup. $9. Then I got the Mongolian long beans--spicy, like I wanted, but wayyyyy too salty. And they make you buy rice separate on the side. I don't think I need to go back. Maybe I would try something else, but this place won't be my first choice. 

Also I was there by myself, so I got stuck at the end of a table right next to a couple--like I was sharing their table. The guy next to me kept bumping my chopsticks. They cram probably 1 or 2 too many tables inside.

Interesting choice of indie music and "Chinese" decor--a big paper mache dragon hanging from the ceiling, a strange stylized portrait of various communist leaders on cartoonish horses.

Overall, eh.
author: Levi P.

description:
More like 3.5 rather than 3.0

Beware--the MaPo tofu gives your tongue a numbing sensation!! I almost thought i was having an allergic reaction until my whole family felt the exact same numbness in their mouths too.

And while Mission Chinese's flavors and spices are used with an amazing depth, it can be a bit overwhelming. My mouth was punched and socked with tons of different tastes--sweet, salty, spicy mostly. It was a great culinary experience for sure; but not necessarily something I think I could come back and have again.
author: Alana L.

description: After hearing so many great things about Mission Chinese, I finally decided to give it a try. Anthony Bourdain, Serena Williams and Aziz Ansari raved about this place. Like what everyone said, THIS IS NOT CHINESE FOOD. It's overpriced fake Chinese food served by hipsters. The food was underwhelming. I never waste food but threw away my leftovers because it was not good. The waiter didn't even bother to ask how we felt throughout the meal. He didn't show much emotions overall. We ordered a sesame chicken, thrice cooked bacon, salt cod fried rice, and Mongolian string beans. All of them  were meh. I would try it none the less so that you can see what you are not missing out on.
author: TravelingHungry ..

description:
Why Mission Chinese Food Continues to Rock:

1)  MCF still donates $0.75 for each entree and has raised over $200k so far.  Whoa!

2)  Great appetizers.

My favorites include the Wide Peanut Rice Noodles with an awesome sauce, sliced cucumbers, and tangy pickles and the Salty Tea-Smoked Eel rolled up with Chinese celery and braised pork. 

(We've also tried the Tiger Salad Rolls and Spicy Lamb Dumplings which were fine but not as memorable.)

3)  You can test your spice and fat limits.

I haven't found an entree here that I'm in love with (yet)! 

Like a food war story, we still talk about the Ma Po Tofu ($12) that was so spicy we couldn't eat it!  The Thrice Cooked Rice Cakes ($12) and Braised Watercress ($11) had great flavors but were overpowered by the heat from the spices.  When they mean spicy, they mean spicy!
  
Similarly, although we love lamb the uber fatty Sizzling Cumin Lamb ($15) was too much for my arteries.

4)  Where else can you order online with a flying ninja and get a James Beard awarded chef's creative food delivered to your doorstep?

That's what I thought.

p.s.  Cool clip:  http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2013/05/24/watch-danny-bowien-make-thrice-cooked-bacon-on-jimmy-fallon/

Updated 11/2013
author: Amy C.

description:
Loved this experience, besides the delicious food the whole ambiance and process was a ton of fun. With Yelpish babes by my side we waited an easy half hour (The wait can be MUCH longer) for our table. In case ya don't know, fill out your name on the clipboard and settle in. It could be awhile. 

We sat at a tiny 4 top, drink orders were taken, the menu wasn't huge but it all looked amazing. Instead of stressing out about a decision we ordered a couple things each, filling out table to bursting! 

Yeah we had the thrice bacon, we had noodles, we had things I were not sure of, we ate it all. We had no regret... besides the fact that not a one of us are SF locals and it'll be another year before we dine there again. 

Is it fancy? Nope. Is is pricey, meh not really. Is it well known and a foodie destination? sure. Over-rated?? I didn't think so. A solid 4 stars from moi.
author: Trish S.

description:
Not your typical Chinese restaurant...don't come here expecting traditional Chinese food or the usual Americanized fanfare. Mission Chinese is a whole different beast. I think the closest type of Chinese food I would associate it with is Sichuan food for the spiciness. 

The best dishes here are:
1. Thrice cooked bacon
2. Salt cod fried rice
3. Pork belly.  

Minus two stars for being pricier than it should be, the crazy lines (no reservations), inattentive service (servers are ALWAYS running around like chickens with their heads cut off, how dark and dank it is inside, and the overall level greasiness of the food here.
author: Catherine C.

description: A lot of hype but doesn't live up to expectations. The food lacks depth of flavor and taste, it's mostly just pepper, salt and burnt rice and meats. To compare it even to a regular (inexpensive) Chinese restaurant wouldn't be fair, this place is not even in the ballpark. Honestly $16 per dish, I don't get it. Not sure why there's so much hype. Save yourself the cash, walk down to Valencia and a good Chinese restaurant where lunch and rice is $10 bucks.
author: Jin H.

description:
Yes its good.
Yes its worth the wait in long ass line.
Yes the hype is justified.

Favorites - were savory custard, and eel rolls. Aaron V's recs of salt cod rice, and kung pow pastrami were fantastic.  The small plate - pork belly - was a highlight as well.

Non food item favorites were plastic flowers in champagne bottles, a dragon (yes a dragon), a huge poster of Peoples Liberation Army's generals on undersized-yet-regal stallions, and Icelandic Beer.

Cant wait to return!
author: Oleg H.

description:
Yum! I don't feel like waiting in line at the Mission Chinese in NYC so I decided to hit this place during a recent visit to SF. A friend and I shared a few dishes and I was particularly impressed with the pea leaves, which tasted more like a soup. The Mongolian long beans were were very spicy, though they had a funny, almost soapy flavor to them that I didn't enjoy.

We had a couple appetizers, including some pickles, which were okay, and some peanuts, which made for a fun snack, though they're not something I would order on my own.  The place has plenty of vegetarian and vegan options, which was a huge plus.
author: Cassandra B.

description:
I was perplexed by the 4-5 and 1 star reviews but having now been there I can now understand. This is EXTREME CUISINE! It's not off the shelf cooking and is quite revolutionary and also more authentic than American Chinese.  That greasy, oily mess described in some reviews is more like you might get it in Chengdu than Chinatown USA. 
     The Tiki pork was cooked beyond perfection and the cheeky presentation was hilarious until I tasted it, OMG. And I am not sure 8 ounces of pork belly can really be defined as a "small plate." The Kung Pow Pastrami was amazing, but has to be consumed proportionally. The pastrami is a salt lick but enjoyed with the peppers, some rice and scallions is delicious. As a sole diner I could only try the two dishes but next SFO trip I will be back.
author: Rob B.

description:
Will keep this review short as I don't want to spend valuable time on this.
I ordered the kung pao pastrami and the sesame chicken. Conclusions: any cheap and mediocre chinese food joint (which I avoid) can cook a better sesame chicken than the one I had today at MCF. It was saggy, too oily and lacking good flavors. The kung pao is nothing to be impressed with either. This dish is full of MSG and too much meat. There is certainly nothing worth admiring about this overhyped "cuisine".
author: Terry K.

description: This place was not all it was cracked up to be. The food was alright and was definitely an experience but I probably wouldn't go back for a while. The chicken wings were numbing but not in a good way. If you are looking for good Chinese food for a good price this is not the place!
author: Aimee E.

description:
Mission Chinese is a cramped, dimly lit eatery. service is leisurely, casual.

sign at front reads: "sign in" but no one checks on you when you do. half the place is empty.

eats: lamb face noodle soup
-"lamb cheek, pea shoots, peanuts, chilies, fresh shanghai noodles"
-lamb tender, peanuts roasted & crunchy, chili subtle, not overbearing
-noodles just right, fresh., chewy.
-portion looked big. (must be the plate, bowl)

leftovers:
-not sure if this was chinese cuisine or not
-an hour later after eating. i was hungry again. definitely a sign Mission chinese food is genuine chinese.
-flavors unique,
-would return for something different to eat.
author: Victor G.

description: Very hipster Chinese food I must say... I'm Chinese and I had soooooooo much Chinese food in my whole life, this place is like a person wearing clothes with different styles at the same time. I don't even know how to describe with words. The food is definitely not authentic Chinese but who cares when u r in Mission? The taste of each dish is familiar but yet not so familiar. I'm very confused. Maybe because I know Chinese food too well and this place makes it playful as well as confusing..
author: Shaz L.

description:
There are a lot of reviews here that complain about the authenticity of the food, or the service, or the spiciness, so I'll break it down for you: this place is CHINESE FOOD... FOR HIPSTERS.  It's got a lot of creativity in the menu, and a whole lot of spice.  That being said, it's freaking delicious.

The ambiance:  it's loud.  Like, really loud.  For a chinese place, they sure do love their hip hop.  And Mariah Carey.  Which might have been okay if not for the mildly intoxicated hipsters belting out unwanted karaoke.  Anyway, the point is, it's loud.  But hey, it's the Mission.  There are hipsters.  Deal with it.  

The food itself was very good though.  The pork belly was a very interesting take on it (very... pineapple-y) but pretty delicious.  And they definitely nailed the crispy skin, which is my favorite.  It was a little fatty, but not too much more than what i would expect of, you know, pork belly.  People!  if you don't want fat, don't order pork belly!  
We also got the Kung Pao Pastrami which was SPICY.  If you weren't considering it, GET RICE.  It'll help with the spice and and spread out the extremely tasty seasonings.
