Lastly, we got the Westlake rice porridge was tasty, but nothing that you couldn't get somewhere else.  For $12 the portion size was pretty decent though, and there was crab.  not bad.

overall it was a great dining experience, although it was a bit loud.  Definitely worth a swing by on a slow night, or if you're just in the mood for something spicy and chinese.
author: Mike P.

description: Mmm the peanuts. This place is nothing truly mind blowing but it's really tasty and creative and fun. The salt cod fried rice, eggplant, and pastrami were all solid. Worth a try.
author: Amy E.

description:
For some weird reason or another, I have been coming to Mission Chinese food on a weekly basis over the past month. I've gone in person twice but I more use it for their delivery service.
I like their cucumber appetizer. It's nice and fresh, but it's too soggy for delivery.
Chicken wings are great too! 
The thrice cooked rice cakes are wonderful. The combination of spicy and bacon savory flavors really make this dish stand out.
The ma po tofu is great too but not for delivery because I swear it once arrived smelling a bit odd. Also, if you google this recipe, you can easily make it yourself for 1/8 of the price. I've done it before; I just haven't had time recently.
The salt cod fried rice has to be my favorite on the menu. It's my favorite because the flavors are not as strong as the thrice cooked rice cakes with bacon, but it goes very well with the long beans. And those are really saucy and spicy!
Chow mein is bland. I've had the beef and the duck and I just have to say bland^2. 

Now for the experience itself: 
The restaurant has a bit of a hippy vibe. The waiters are very nice and American. 
I've gone in once with my boyfriend and by myself. Both times, the food came out in a timely manner and the servers were very attentive. 

Now the delivery side is really funny.
So after dining in person, I realized that they deliver to Balboa Park! Junky Chinese food is on my list as I crunch down for my exam! However, instead of an American waiter picking up the phone, I get someone who can barely speak English. I mean, there's really only a limited number of times I can repeat my phone number over and over again until someone gets it right. They also can't get the number 62 right. It's not 52 or 42 or 32... it's 62. At one point today, I had to ask them to pass the phone to someone who spoke better English. If you can't get 2 numbers right, forget 10. 

These phone conversations can be pretty awkward. The wait is a little long. I spend 15 minutes ordering a salt cod fried rice dish with a side of long beans for almost $40 and it takes you 75 minutes to deliver it to me. 2 dishes for around $40. 
If anyone calls in for delivery orders, I HIGHLY recommend that you do not order delivery here for lunch. I once ordered the porridge and the crab they used clearly was bad. My boyfriend and I had to dump it out. 

Today, as I was studying away and awaiting my order, I got a phone call from the delivery guy that he left the food outside my door. I went out to pick it up, expecting him to be there so I could sign my receipt. All I found was the dinner placed on the floor at my door.

Mission Chinese Food no more.
author: Aggie Z.

description:
Rarely do I praise hipster joints with a whole lot of 'tude, but Mission Chinese does such a novel twist on traditional Hunan and Szechuan dishes and for such a good cause - 75 cents of every entree goes to the San Francisco Food Bank - that I cannot deny that I really like the food they serve there. Finding out that it made Michael Bauer's Top 100 in the Sunday Chronicle, Jamie W. and I made a beeline to 18th and Mission early on Sunday evening to give it a try before the inevitable stampede. Even at 5:30PM, the nondescript place was getting fairly crowded. 

Unless you knew what you were looking for (the yellow awning that says Lung Shan Restaurant), you'd probably miss it unless you noticed the anxious crowd waiting on the sidewalk. There are abundant temptations on their menu courtesy of the culinary creativity of Danny Bowien and Anthony Myint (see photos of the menu), but be prepared to find out they may be out of certain dishes. For instance, I really wanted to try the Warm Egg Custard with Duck Confit and Sea Urchin, but dammit, they were out. 

Instead, we tried the $10 Lion's Head Meatball in Marrow Broth with Preserved Turnip Greens, Bok Choy and Ramen Noodles (see photo). That was delicious with the ground pork very tasty and moist and the ramen just the right consistency. It easily feeds two on its own, but we didn't stop there. We ordered the $12.50 Sizzling Cumin Lamb because I was immediately drawn to the idea of Salt-&-Peppered Lamb Belly mixed with Chili-Pickled Long Beans, although it looked like there were a fair number of green and red peppers and onions as well (see photo). Regardless, the luxuriant belly pieces were a nice counterpoint to the crispiness of the vegetables as it came in a burning-hot cast-iron pan. 

Our last choice was a scorcher, the unavoidable $11 Kung Pao Corned Beef which came with a warning of of two red pepper signs on the menu (see photo). The generous slices came mixed with celery, potatoes, roasted peanuts, and of course, red hot chili peppers you needed to pick up lest you want to experience a loss of feeling in your lower torso. It was delicious, but the sweat was rolling down the back of my head like that embarrassing scene of Albert Brooks in the anchor chair in "Broadcast News". The audacity of the culinary execution here is what will bring us back regardless of the perspiration challenges. 

FOOD - 4 stars...adventurously funky reinventions of dishes you could find at a Chinese take-out counter only the ingredients here are uniquely unexpected and awfully tasty 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a bit of a dive heavy on the formica, but I guess that's part of the charm here 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...pretty efficient if a bit coolish to offset the heat of some of the dishes, I guess 
TOTAL - 4 stars...totally worthy of your attention and such a bargain to boot
author: Ed U.

description:
Mind-blowing? Maybe, the menu changes. 

Not your average Chinese restaurant. Good music, super friendly wait staff. High-energy place. 

Small beer list. Ask your server what's best on the menu.
author: Marcus C.

description:
This place is the worst.  I have not felt so passionate about a yelp review in a long time.  Too bad, this review is all negative.  

There are just too many things that simply bug me.  The menu is ridiculous because they try so hard to make the dish different from traditional chinese food.  The ma po tofu and egg egg noodle are extremely oily; if you finish both dishes, there are many tablespoons of leftover oil.  The decor is strange and the Christmas lights look so tacky.  The female worker is rude and obnoxious.  She had friends visit and order food to go.  The whole time, she was simply talking to him and not paying any attention to the customers that were dining in.  

The food took so long to come out of the kitchen.  Halfway into our meal, another group of her friends come in and are seated.  She spends ALL of her time taking pictures of them, chit chatting, and bringing out food for them.  Basically, she is waiting on them hand and foot.  Meanwhile she pays no attention to anyone else.  She never once walks by our table or the other tables around us.  When we are done with our food, I flag her down and ask her for a check.  She does not bring us the check.  We wait for at least 10 to 15 minutes.  I go up to the counter and ask the male worker for a check.  He mumbles something and I ask him what he said. I ask him again if I pay here.  He says I can bring it to you or you can pay here.  Not knowing how long he will take (because he could have just given me the check already right after I asked him), I tell him to bring it to the table.  

This is one of the worst places I have ever eaten at.  The service is ridiculously bad.  The food is drenched in oil.  

I bet everyone that eats here is proud to tell other people-- Hey! I ate Chinese food today! Look at me! Look at me!  Take that, lousy mission chinese food.
author: Victor L.

description: Came here 2 years ago and absolutely loved the unique flavors. Came back this week and was really disappointed. Food was overpriced for what we got...I ordered the squid ink noodles which were greasy and somehow salty and flavorless at the same time. Beef brisket with broccoli was not great either, I'm hoping this visit was a fluke! I left wishing I had eaten in some dirty hole in the wall restaurant in Chinatown instead.
author: Lilo S.
Jason G.

description: Way too overpriced for the quality of food you get.  We ordered the Ma Po Tofu which arrived gelatinous and submerged beneath a 3/4 inch layer of grease.  Appearance and taste was reminiscent of pre-digested food.  Mongolian Long Beans were short, skinny, and sad-looking.  This place is basically cashing on on the hype they've received and is milking it for all it's worth while serving sub-par food.  Don't bother.
author: Nick P.

description: This place was pretty busy! Highly recommend, making a reservation. I came here on a Saturday night, a lady name Lindsay helped us out, let's just say se can't handle stress well. If your planning To come here on a Saturday avoid her at all cause. Service is usually better! Th
author: Catrina A.

description:
I know a lot of people love Mission Chinese Food and I totally respect their view but I'm not as big of a fan. I'm obsessed with a lot of types of asian food - vietnamese, thai, japanese, and often even chinese but I think I prefer my dishes a bit more "traditional." Also, eating pescatarian, I wished there were more good veggie and fish options on the menu. I think my expectations were also set very high due to all the rave reviews.

Our group was 6 people and we shared several dishes but none were particularly memorable to me. I liked the hot tea and was impressed with the presentation of a plate full of hot chilies to go with a spicy dish. The bacon was a hit at our table as was a lamb's eye/ear (what body part was it? I'm not sure but I was a bit disgusted by the body part being described) soup. 

I'd be willing to give Mission Chinese a second try since I know so many I trust love it but I'd definitely go in with lower expectations next time.
author: Meghan P.

description:
Definitely lives up to the hype. 

I am glad I finally got to try this place, and it's good!  We had the squid ink noodles, the cod fried rice, and the eel roll. All very tasty. All things I'd order again.

And, I still need to try the pork belly and the duck and a bunch of other things too.  So yes, I'll be back.

Do note that this is somewhat, mixed traditional. It's not Western by any means, just, not what you would normally associate with Chinese food.  The squid ink noodles for example, tasted very Mongolian/Northern to me. Probably was due to all the anise seeds. But, still super tasty.
author: Cindy C.

description: If fast, unfriendly service in cramped quarters, and over salted, over spiced and over dressed food is what you are looking for - please line up with all of the others outside. My wife and I over-ordered for the two of us to try and taste more dished with the plan of boxing up the leftovers and giving a meal to someone in need on the way to our concert, but after tasting the dishes we ordered - Special Lamb Ribs (TOO salty), Steak Tartare (seasoned with some sort of fish roe - disaster), Thrice Fried Pork Belly with rice balls (where's the pork belly?) we decided it would be best to just give some money to buy a burrito to the person we would have given our leftovers to - no reason to have a third person experience this meal.
author: Jp B.

description:
This place lives up to the hype. I was expecting something slightly more trendy considering everyone cannot shut up about this place. They have a bunch of random beers available, and limited wine selection. Beer and Chinese works for me.

The food is very hot and very strange, I love it already. There were 6 of us who showed up early (6pm) on Friday and we got right in. This place is hidden, it doesn't say "MISSION CHINESE" anywhere, so use the picture here or on the website to find the place.

Highlights of the menu and lowlights of the menu:

Awesome must get:
Long Beans
thrice cooked bacon
Sour Chili Chicken

Okay:
Kung Pao Pastrami

So-so:
Pork Dumplings
Tiki Pork Belly
Salt cod Fried Rice
author: Jonah K.

description: Wow, my mouth is still reeling from the salt overload. Every dish was soaked in sodium. I appreciate the take that this place has on Chinese food, but there's no reason to make it taste like a salt lick. We ordered the chicken wings and I only ate one because I don't like the overpowering Szechuan peppercorn flavor, and combined with the saltiness, it was way too much. A little of that goes a long way, and this went way too far. 2 stars for good service and being relatively cheap, but I would not recommend this place. Another overhyped SF eatery.
author: Vince F.

description:
It wasn't bad, but "I don't want no mediocre"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qdsTUfDTEhQ
author: ella k.

description: We came here because it was something you do in the mission. It pissed me off. We waited for ages - our fault I suppose - but when we did eventually get in, it was ridiculously loud. The (rather unpleasant) music was turned way up and people were talking loud to compensate. The food was bad - mostly really greasy and unpleasant, and not all that interesting.
author: Ben K.

description:
It was pretty good.  The service was subpar.  I get you're popular, but you don't need to run it like Ed Debevics.  

This place wins the crown for some greasy fake chinese food at reasonable prices.  They like making it spicy, which is something I love. 

Based on Yelp highlights, I had the Salt Cod Fried Rice and the Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes. These were solid dishes.  By no means 5 star winners, but pretty appealing to the general masses I guess.    I had the pickles.... not very good.    The egg egg noodles were decent.   The other dishes sounded really tasty too.  I'm definitely coming back to try some of their dishes.  I had no idea what to expect when coming here.  It's definitely a different kind of chinese food, one I would definitely want to experiment w again.
author: Richie W.

description:
generally very skeptical with any asian food thats fusion or not your local chinatown joint, on top of the fact that they're a total hipster joint... but we found the food here interesting, fun and actually very yummy... 

cant wait to return and try more of the menu...
author: Donna S.

description: The ambiance is amazing. They play music in the main room and there is a bad ass dragon hanging on the ceiling. The food is just as good. I had the chili chicken and it was very good.
author: Ali Y.

description: Very different! Walked in expecting normal Chinese food and was pleasantly surprised. The service was great and fast. Food yummy
author: Natalia M.

description: Hipster American Chinese food. Cool vibe and interesting decor, got busy easily. Probably not the place to look for authentic Chinese food, like the mapo tofu (with pork) we got, there wasn't much pork and very spicy, numb spicy. Would be great for spicy food lovers though. Also got the sizzling lamb, which we sort of regretted. The meat wasn't very tender and the side veggies like beans were pretty salty. Ended up more than $20 per person for 2 dishes, overpriced for the food but I guess it was an interesting experience dining there.
author: Jaclyn C.

description: Came here Mid-day Monday on a ditch work day. No regrets. We were seated immediately under a giant parade Dragon. I enjoyed the eggplant dish we ordered with garlic and basil. The chow mein noodles tasted very fresh and flavorful. The hot oolong tea was great, they added sliced oranges and fresh mint leaves, great combo -you better believe I took notes on this to recreate back at home. I liked the vibe of this place, I felt like it transported me right back to LA for a second. Playlist was rocking - Yeah yeah yeahs, deerhunter and animal collective songs played overhead, which confused my Mom a bit but whatevs, I was into it.
author: Daniella O.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had. Definitely a scene though, complete with crowds and service that's just ok.
author: Joe D.

description:
Don't listen to these Yelp marks. Who cares what the crowd is like. Go with good company and enjoy yourself. Get it to go if you want. Speaking negatively about a supposed stereotype of people who no one claims to be is a red flag and potentially indicative of a problem with one's self rather than others. Blazing hip hop = something different for a Chinese ish restaurant and nice in my book. Service was enough. Decor was enough. Food was off the hook. Incredible aromas and flavors. Tea smoked eel was great, squid ink pasta with lamb was a stretch to be considered in the Chinese realm but i don't give a .... The 3x smoked bacon with rice cakes was actually spicy and had a slight sweetness as well. It was another win. I am excited to go back. I love the quote by another yelper describing his friend's reaction to the tastes and flavors here. 
"That is not a flavor, that is an emotion."

Leave your overly critical bland ass at home. A little pricy, but if you don't mind dropping a little change, this place deserves way more than the 3.5 stars it currently has, hence the 5 star rating.
author: Swapan M.

description:
Mission Chinese Food embodies the very essence of San Francisco's Mission district...hipsterfication.

This trendy hole-in-the wall restaurant is distinct in ambiance and character. Dim lighting, walls plastered with Christmas lights and loud West Coast Hip Hop music in the background....what's not to love?

Best thing about this restaurant of course, is the food. Order the Ma Po Tofu and Kung Pao Pastrami and you will not be disappointed. 

Fun Fact: The owner, Danny Bowien, is actually Korean.
author: Viennelyn C.

description:
Be prepared for an explosion of flavors! I definitely was not ready, but I was willing!

Notable dishes: chongquing chicken wings, squid ink noodles and the veal rib.

The chicken was crispy and the flavor was very typical of Szechuan/chongqing dishes - spicy. The wings were buried in peppers and chili, if you can't handle spicy, avoid this or get ready to drown in water.

As much Asian cuisine I have had in my short life time, I would say that the squid ink noodles were the most unique type of noodles. Black noodles...what? And did I mention that there was lamb in that mix? Very pleasing and warming in flavor. 

Onto the huge fatty veal rib, it was huge and it was fatty. This was the most succulent dish, your mouth automatically salivates in preparation to devour this piece of awesomeness. Health-conscious people, stay away from this...which means more for me!

I definitely recommend this spot if you're open to this modern type of Chinese cuisine. There is a bit of a wait but it's worth it. 

Oh, by the way, the birthday boy got a bowl of sake, on the house!!
author: Eric Y.

description:
If you love mapo tofu, it's the best!
The most unique is the Kung pao pastrami and Ink Chow fun with cumin lamb!
author: Elpie K.

description:
I loved every single bite @Missionstfood. OKC native Danny Bowien has said, in print, that if he opens a third Mission Street he will do so in Oklahoma City. Oh please, let it be true! 

Salt cod fried rice was worth the taxi ride, the wait, the price, possibly even worth the flight to San Francisco. I literally could have eaten the entire bowl - but with such large portions I probably would have made myself ill. Every bite was perfect. 

I loved the bok choy as well - it's one of my favorite veggies but I don't prepare it properly and I don't know anyone who does. This was perfectly cooked and the baby size made them easy to eat and so tender. I'm not obsessed with pork belly, but I did enjoy the bites I shared with our crew. 

The clipboard waiting list system actually worked pretty well and our group of four did not have to wait long, fairly early on a Sunday evening. Our waiter took good care of us, even placing our bottle of Cava back in the cooler so it wouldn't get warm and then bringing it out to us when he saw we were low. 

Danny, come home to OKC. We're ready for you!
author: Julie S.

description:
Truly contemporary Chinese cuisine, incorporating new ingredients and spices into traditional Chinese dishes. Compared to sleek, cleaned up Lukshon (in LA), Mission has a rich, gritty soul of Chinese cuisine.

Our order:
Squid Ink Noodles - BEST. Thick, flat noodles with a stew of lamb and chickpeas you dress with a separate bowl of broth. Savory, spicy, but light dish.

Salt Cod Fried Rice - Fried rice is one of those things that is okay when it's good, and REALLY bad when it's bad. This was good. 

Cumin Lamb Ribs - Huge, tender ribs with a smoky crust. The cumin and herbs that accompany the ribs really make it fresh, vibrant, and spicy. 

Tea-smoked Eel: This was more of an eel "wrap" in rice paper, along with hoisin sauce, celery, and cilantro. The eel was perhaps a little too soft in contrast to the raw celery, making the texture slightly outlandish. This wasn't a big hit.

I noticed a lot of negative reviews on the service, but we didn't have any problems. Took our order promptly, good attitude, no complaints. Don't be foolish and miss out on this adventurous cuisine! You're here for the food, not for strangers to smile at you!
author: James W.

description: The tall white male waiter is the rudest waiter I've ever encountered.  Somebody should tell home that trendy doesn't mean you get to provide bad costumer service.
author: Efat A.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants. The food is amazing and the atmosphere is fun, even if the quarters are a bit tight. The food is a version of Chinese that I am sure no one has ever had. It is complex and fresh and beyond creative. The chef is simply brilliant. I have never had a bad meal and the place has never failed to impress. I recommend bringing a nice bottle of red to pair with the food. We have actually brought some nice reserves and the food really goes well with it. I was quite surprised. I am addicted to the pastrami and the forbidden rice, I almost cry when i think about the rice being taken off the menu. It was always my non negotiable dish. Truthfully everything is amazing, you can't go wrong. And try the Moscow mule. 

The only thing I wish they would change is the attitude that all the maitre'ds often have. Whoever handles the front/ reservations is often rude. This is strange because the wait staff is always super nice. Last time was even worse than normal and left a pretty bad taste in my mouth. We had a reservation because my in laws were in town. We got stuck in very unusual traffic and were running late. Our bad. I know. I called and asked if it was ok. When we arrived (around the time I estimated on the phone) I apologized again and mentioned that I had called ahead. The host was a little dismissive but told us to wait outside, which we did without complaint. Then when he seated us he was rude again and proceeded to give me a lecture about how normally they would not seat us and then proceeded to intentionally ignore me and my husband throughout dinner while we were trying to flag someone down for water. First of all we were only about 10-15 minutes late, I called, I apologized.  They take walk ins and we did wait a little, we were also the ONLY people waiting for a table so they probably would have sat us at the same time had we just strolled in. It was just really unnecessary attitude. Not too many people know about this place and I take everyone and their mom there and I just LOVE the food so much. They always love it. It's so sad that I've now been kind of avoiding for all the wrong reasons. San Francisco is known for good service and good attitudes and kindness. I get very sad when a wonderful restaurant fails on that point and makes someone feel unwelcome.
author: Sasha D.

description:
We had reservations for 6, and a table was ready when we arrived, so high marks for honoring a reservation on a busy night. But this place was noisy, crowded, hot, and the food is only mediocre or less so.

My favorite item was a dish that looked like a salad, but was composed of wide green noodles with cheese and pieces of lamb. Was delicious and imaginative. But the Kung Pao Pastrami had a cloying flavor and had way too much salt in it. Also, other items (including Thrice-Cooked Bacon) were overly salted and greasy, too.  If salt and oil are your favorite ingredients, this is your place!

Would have been nice to end the dinner with a scoop of green tea ice cream or similar to offset the harshly-flavored food; however, no desserts are offered here.

This restaurant might be OK for hipsters, but for good Chinese food in more comfort, you can do much better than this in SF's Chinatown.
author: IQuack D.

description: I got the salt cod fried rice, a flavor profile I haven't tasted in a long time (since I was a child).  Overall, this was a hit for the group I was with, which included two vegans.  They loved their dish (I can't recall what they had), but I remember the tasting it (it had bitter melon) and loving that too.  We arrived on a Thursday night around 7p and for a group of 4, we waited about 10 minutes.  Hard to find if you didn't read about it and knew to look for the sign behind the metal bars.  Altogether, we sampled 6 dishes and I couldn't decide which one was my favorite!
author: Shirley C.

description:
Came here several months ago with three others on a typical, drizzle-full San Francisco evening. I was excited by the menu, and my companions just wanted to get inside somewhere warm, so I brought us in. 

We took a table and were brought two menus, the usual cheap Chinese menu, as well as the 'restaurant within a restaurant' menu, on which almost everything looked amazing. 

After consulting the waitress, we finally decided on sharing three items:
- A cold buckwheat noodle with cumin, sesame, cucumber, radish, tofu skin, and chili vinegar. 
- A slow cooked char-siu pork belly with soy-cured egg, ginger-scallion noodles, cucumber, and sweet plum sauce. 
- A westlake rice porridge with oxtail, dunginess crab, soft-cooked egg, and 'rice paddy herb' which is cilantro. I was very excited about rice paddy herb. 

All were very yummy. Nom! We also had a Tsing Tao and a Blue Moon. Slurp! 

Also, let it be known that I loved that sneaky feeling I got from eating at a restaurant within a restaurant!
author: Heather P.

description:
Set your expectations now -- this is the most outwardly hipster restaurant that I've been to and to their credit, it is well played.

I admit I was a little hesitant.  I did not fit in with the framed glasses and newsboy hat wearing, messenger bag toting, rolled up jeans folks that flock to Mission Chinese, but I keep an open mind (and stomach) when it comes to food!

I came here with a party of four during holiday Monday peak dinner hours and to my surprise, we were seated after just a 10 minute wait.  Lucky much?

The menu is anything but traditional Chinese food.  It is full of innovative dishes and items that our group got really excited for.  We wanted to order everything, but here's what we landed on:

Chongqing chicken wings (4 stars): spicy, crispy, mouth numbing with a mound of chili peppers to scare ya!
Tea smoked eel rolls (4.5 stars):  really innovative use of ingredients and they play together well.  Always a fan of eel!
Cumin lamb ribs (3.5 stars):  this was the dish we were most excited for.  While the ribs were well-seasoned, the cuts of lamb were really fatty and the meat was hardly fall-off-the-bone. Served on a fajita sizzling plate with plenty of veggie accompaniments to pick at!
Ma Po Tofu (4 stars): okay, so my face basically burned off when I tried the ma po here.  Fair warning!  This dish is great, but not ideal for spicy novices.
Stir fried squid ink pasta with lamb (5 stars):  my favorite dish!  A bit of a stretch from Asian food, but really well done.  Chunks of seasoned lamb, al dente pasta, and fresh greens on top - really good, really innovative.

Mission Chinese is one of those places that I wouldn't mind taking my out-of-town friends to "try something new."  While not all of these dishes are home run hits, it's fun to see what the chef has up his sleeve!
author: Kathleen W.

description: We made a reservation at 6pm but we had to wait outside as they were filming in the restaurant. They should have informed us beforehand about it. They were nice enough to offer us a bottle of free beer. The garlic fried rice and Mapo tofu was not good at all. They were pre cooked and they weren't hot when served. The cumin lamb and porridge were not bad. Not authentic Chinese Szechuan food. We didn't have a good experience there.
author: Shin Nie T.

description:
Hipster Chinese food at its finest. 
We had dinner delivered. 
Below are some highlights:

- wings- delicious. Would order again
- pastrami- tasty but very salty. Really need to have it with rice
- salt cod fried rice- not as flavorful as RG lounge or other Chinese restaurants but thank goodness for it- we had it with the salty pastrami
- bacon and rice cake - would definitely get it again

Would love to check out the lamb noodles at the restaurant
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Good food and a unique atmosphere for the mission. Definitely a hipster feel but unique in the sense that it's Chinese hipster. The prices are reasonable and the service was great. I'd go back if I'm in the mission and in the mood for Chinese food
author: Andrew L.

description:
Okay wow. I'm a huge fan. My friend and I were wandering through mission district in search of something wonderful to eat. He's kind of another level of food snob, so I just let him wander like a blood hound searching for game to hunt... and all of a sudden, his ears perked and I heard him howl with delight (okay, i'm definitely exaggerating... but just play along)... as he pointed to a run down chinese joint that almost looked closed. I raised my eyebrow in skepticism, but decided to trust my food-hound friend. 

What it turned out to be was an old run down chinese restaurant (Lung Shan Restaurant), being used to give real Chinese food to hipsters. Wonderful. We were seated within 10 minutes (super fast for the city!).

Decor- it's like walking into a dark room because all the lights are red. Not good for your eyes... but eh. They did not take away from any of the original cheap chinese restaurant decor, just added little touches. My favorite is the chinese painting that they turned into a speaker cabinet pumping trendy music. 

Being the gourmand that my friend was, we ordered way too much... haha okay, not his fault. Mine. I saw all these dishes I had missed from my time in Chongqing! Tons of huajiao mala junk (numb spice). We got the lamb ribs with cumin, the face numbing noodles, the chongqing chicken wings and the salt cod rice. 

Oh my gosh. I had low expectations. My rule is- if the majority of the crowd is white people, the chef will probably tone down the food for their tastes... But wow. I was proved wrong. i love that the food here says "hell no!" and doesn't apologize for being Chinese and the flavors and textures that make chinese food wonderful. The lamb ribs were wonderful and cumin-y. the chicken wings and the face numbing noodle soup had our mouths in numb fire. The salt cod rice was divine and had just the right amount of salted fish in it. 

Here's my only major complaint (the minor is that it's a little pricey for stuff I could get at another chinese restaurant... but i forgive that complaint for being in the mission district)- the other patrons with didn't seem to understand the food. While I appreciate that the owner/chef is trying to expose real chinese food to the white hipster masses... I couldn't help but cringe as I watched people eat the food. Most actually surprised me and appreciated the culture and the food... but our next door eaters looked at their salted cod fried rice... and without even tasting it, started dousing it with soy sauce. This is a cardinal sin in my book for chinese food. I kind of wish the restaurant would just hide the soy sauce and only have vineagar, lao gan ma and maybe spicy mustard so that it would avoid any situation like what I had just witnessed. It took all my strength not to sock the guy in the face... him pouring soy sauce was like pissing on the graves of my anscestors... okay. maybe i'm getting carried away here haha. Did I tell you I have yellow rage problems? :)
author: Daniel L.

description:
Am I trying to get into a club or a Chinese restaurant? For a minute, I was confused by the crowd of people waiting outside to get in & the hip hop music playing inside, but I was glad I didn't have to pay a cover charge. 

Seriously though, the food was really good and (almost) worth the 35-minute wait.  I really liked the ambience - a little loud, alive with conversation, pretty poppin'...and I really did dig the music.

The people there were friendly and service was good.  We tried a few of their popular dishes and quickly understood why they were popular.  

The Tea Smoked Eel was interesting.  I liked the different textures with the tender yet chewy rice noodle & the crunchy celery & the crispy eel.

I was afraid the Salted Cod Fried Rice would be too salty; and my first few initial bites were, but the more I ate, the more I liked it and didn't seem so salty.

The Slow-Cooked Pork Belly was delicious!  I wasn't really feeling the soy-cured egg but who knew cucumber with oyster sauce would be so yummy?

The main reason why we tried Mission Chinese Food was for the Ma Po Tofu that we saw on Heat Seekers.  I'm not a big fan of tofu but my husband loved it.  He'd love to come back and have it again.

I'd love to try other dishes but I think we'll be ordering take-out next time to avoid the wait-time.
author: Rose A.

description:
After seeing this spot on Anthony Bourdain's Layover episode of SF, it made me all the more curious.  Came on a Monday night, and was surprised that there was a list of people waiting for seats.  We waited about 15 minutes, and were seated at a community table (since all the separate tables were taken).

The food is definitely fusion style Chinese.  We ordered the Salted Cod Fried Rice (needed more salted cod), Chongqing Chicken Wings (buried in dried chili peppers - tasty, crispy outside, moist inside), Kung Pao Pastrami (interesting in a good way), and this amazing special appetizer which included cold tofu, uni, and ikura (they need to integrate this as a regular item)...  

Atmosphere was loud, dimly lit, with an overall hole in the wall feel...  Service was actually pretty quick, and friendly.  I was surprised at how good it was.  Delicious dishes at reasonable prices.  I would come back again.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Saw this place on Anthony Bourdain, and finally had a chance to try! I'm from China, so I don't usually like the Americanized or fusion Chinese food. But this place was amazing! All the dishes are unmistakably Chinese, while it has American elements to it. Like the salt and pepper lamb, so surprisingly delicious with pickles, yogurt sauce, and Texas toast. 
FYI there's no "mission Chinese food" labeled on the outside. Look for the yellow awning that says Lung Shan restaurant
author: Andy D.

description:
I wouldn't say that this place was bad, but it wasn't great.  Perhaps it was the hype -- I'd been hearing of Mission Chinese for years.  Overall, it wasn't bad Chinese food.  Most of our dishes were tasty, but it wasn't something I'd wait in line for either.

People seem a little put off by the nonchalant service.  I'm not terribly bothered by it.  I was bothered however, by our server's failure to advise us properly of the amount of food we actually ordered -- especially after we asked his opinion.  We could have literally ordered half as much and been fine. Instead, we spent $75 extra dollars and gave away enough food for four.

The portions here are enormous.  It's family style, but if you're coming in with less than 6 people, I wouldn't order more than 3 entrees.  Oddly, the items that were listed as being very spicy were not quite as bad as some of the other items.

If we're talking highlights, then I recommend the long beans.  It was the standout, in my opinion. Skip the shark salad, the starters and the ma po tofu.
author: Shamik T.

description: Very creative dishes. We had a pork belly dish that was the best. We also had the tiger salad. That was interesting. The raw beef dish was nice. We enjoyed it.
author: Jeanne m.

description:
This is some tasty and original food.

The Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes is a little spicy, but I couldn't stop stuffing it down: the sweet tofu, the salty bacon, and the chewy rice cakes work together really well.

The Salted Cod Fried Rice is good, but to be honest, I think it's something that one could make at home. The only trick is the salted cod, which you should be able to find at an Asian grocery store.

The Tea-Smoked Eel and Warm Egg Custard are also both great.

The restaurant itself is dark, but not problematically so. This place has gotten quite popular, and we have maybe a half-hour wait to get in, even arriving for an early dinner. The staff is courteous but probably won't spend a lot of time chatting with you because of the business.

Come with a few extra mouths so you can sample as many dishes as possible. I definitely recommend it if you're in the area.
author: Kevin L.

description:
It's been about a week since my husband and I ate here, and I can not stop thinking about it! I think I even had a dream about it last night. It was simply incredible.

We were on a vacation from LA, and the entire reason we went to MCF was because I saw Danny Bowien on The Martha Stewart Show, of all places! Ha. He was making his specialty, high-gluten hand-pulled noodles. Martha was insane for them, I was impressed, and I had to try them. So on we go to San Francisco to give them a try.

First thing I noticed was that they were not on the menu anymore. I shyly asked our very sweet waiter where they were, and he explained that the city made them stop making them. I guess they were making them out on the street, which I hadn't realized. Anyway, the menu looked so wonderful (plenty of veggie options) that I didn't let it get me down.

We started with the smashed cucumbers in sesame sauce. Trust me, this is the most refreshing dish you'll ever find. I love cucumbers and pickles anyway, but my god. Out of this world good. To make something simple this memorable is pretty hard to do. Can't recommend this dish enough. In fact, I'm about to attempt to make them tonight. Got the small chinese cucumbers on the counter waiting for me and everything. My husband wanted to try the tea-smoked eel, which is a wrap. And it has braised pork and chinese celery in it as well. It was outstanding. So many different flavors and crunch.

We were pretty full by the time we hit the main course option, but we both ordered. I had the Egg Egg Noodles (a vegetarian dish).....holy moly! PERFECT. It's very hard for me to explain, but they're hand made egg noodles sitting in a broth with all sorts of fantastic veggies sitting on top of it all. And all of that is topped with a gooey, poached egg. Break open the yolk, and the whole dish changes before your eyes. I liken it a bit to traditional Asian porridge. If you've never had anything like that, this is the best I can recommend. (If you're in LA, give Red Medicine's porridge a try)

Husband ate a fried rice dish that was good and very simple. The rice was rolled in chicken fat and had a texture like no rice we'd ever had. While it was great, this probably the low-point. But, who cares. A low-point here is still outstanding. Oh, and it was a Monday night at 6:30 and we had no wait at all! So don't let the fear of a long wait stop you. And although the restaurant is SUPER cool with very attractive young people serving you, they are all surprisingly nice and helpful and prompt. None of that "too cool for school" stuff here. Did I mention I saw Danny Bowien WALK INTO WORK that night too? He just cruised right by as I was taking photos of the restaurant. Things could not have gone better. Well done, Mission Chinese Food!
author: Bobbie O.

description:
OVER HYPED!!!!

What was I thinking? How did I get sucked into the "trend," why did I waste money, time and my stomach eating here? I've grown up on SF Chinese food, heck all the "trendy" dishes of salted-cod fried rice, I've been eating it since I could chew! Despite my reservations, I caved in and dine here. I was utterly disappointed. 

The food is overpriced and feels like it was sloped together haphazardly. 

Tea smoked eel - rice noodles were cold and not freshly made. If you go to any chinese restaurant in the city (like dim sum) rice noodles are fresh, and hot! These were cold, and luke warm if any. 

Mouth watering chicken - don't let the name fool you. "mouth watering" means so spicy that it hurts your tongue and you can't eat anything. It was completely inedible! There's spicy that adds a dimension of flavor, and then there's spicy where you can't even consume it. This dish is the latter. 

Braised watercress - not bad, but nothing to write home about.

Caramel pork belly - it was good, but such small portions!

Salted cod fried rice - best item on the menu. But you could get some thing more authentic and for less if you eat in the Sunset or Richmond. 

I won't return. When will this trend end people? You hipsters frustrate me sometimes **shakes fists**
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I would give 3 or 4 stars because the food is not bad at all. We quite enjoyed everything we ordered. Started off with the black vinegar marinated peanuts.. very good. Perfect with beer. We ordered white wine cava instead and for $8 is overpriced for the small glass you get. 

We shared small plate of tiki pork belly, which was good. Very fatty though but I like that haha. My partner ordered the westlake rice porridge, which was not my favorite. Way too much cilantro, which overpowered everything. I wanted the thrice cooked bacon.. but they ran out of bacon! Yep this is partly why they get 2 stars from me. I don't think they ran out of bacon.. I think it was almost closing time and they didn't want to make this dish that may take longer to cook. (I ended up ordering the lamb face noodle soup, which was good. The lamb esp was delicious).

To explain further my low rating. There was a couple there who waited 45 minutes but when their name was called, the hostess could not read the lady's name (yes "Ellen" is very hard to read.. I guess). So she crossed their name off the list and gave their table to someone else. So there's that. Why not have someone take down people's names? If you're going to have a policy of not seating people because you supposedly can't read their writing? I made sure my name was legible by the way! 

I think that Saturday night the hostess did a poor job of managing the wait list. I think she was eager to get rid of people from the list because like I mentioned it was almost closing time and there was still a huge line. When we were eating we saw the cook/chef/owner screaming with the hostess. Employees started leaving one by one. And the restaurant was still full. 

So 2 stars for the ghetto situation. Not something I would have ever expected. Don't show up here if it's after 9pm because you may not get seated until 10pm, and they close at 10:30pm.
author: Vol T.

description:
It's really easy to find this place because there's always a sea of people waiting to get in. Add in its reputation, and I think my expectations were set a bit too high. My dinner here wasn't exactly the best.

When I saw the Tea-Smoked Eel in the menu, my eyes immediately lit up because I love tea-smoked duck. I was really expecting the same kind of big smoky pow that you would get from the duck. The rolls themselves were alright - a bit sweet and salty. What really let me down was the eel. They didn't taste a bit smoky to me at all. I still think that there's potential in this dish. The smokiness would've complemented the sweet and salty flavors in addition to the pork. It would've also provided a nice contrast to the fresh flavor of the greens. Without the smoke, the dish didn't really tie together.

I was also really excited to try the Ma Po Tofu. After hearing all the buzz, it seemed like this was MCF's signature dish. It definitely had a decent kick to it, and the bean sauce was thick and rich. However, the bright citrus notes and tingly numbing sensation you'd get from Szechuan peppercorns were absent. That's a big deal. When I eat Szechuan food, I don't even pay too much attention to the spiciness. The defining feature is the presence of the numb feeling in your mouth. In the end, the Ma Po Tofu wasn't really interesting without the citrus flavors and numbing peppercorns. 

The Salt Cod Fried Rice was another dish that looked good on paper. I'm guessing it's suppose to be a play on Chinese salted fish and chicken fried rice (ham yu gai lup chow fan). I thought the fried rice in general was pretty bland and lacked wok hei. The mackerel confit tasted fine, but it didn't hold up when paired with the rice.  The fish wasn't flavorful enough to properly season another component. There's not enough Chinese sausage to really help either. I think something more potent, like bacalhau, would work better in the fusion fried rice.

The price isn't too high, but I think for the wait, I'd rather go to Z&Y for Szechuan food.
author: Nei N.

description:
This is one of those rare times where I can really see both sides of the opinion toward a business. 

For the lovers/supporters, yes Mission Chinese does do fun, creative dishes with traditional Chinese ingredients and techniques. (Not to be confused with fusion, where you use non-traditional ingredients/techniques.) You probably won't find these dishes at other Chinese restaurants and if so, they probably won't be so cheap.

For the haters, I can see how this places seems to "pander" to a hip, Caucasian crowd, with its white, hipster, only English-speaking staff, clientele and music. I can see how the no-reservation system is frustrating and aggravating given the incredible amount of hype surrounding this restaurant.

And because I can see both sides of the equation, I have come to the conclusion that I am completely, 100% ambivalent about Mission Chinese. The Thrice-Cooked Bacon and Bok Choy in Popcorn Broth are delicious and innovative, but also incredibly greasy and rather small in portion. The Smoked Beef Brisket Noodle Soup is a good idea in theory, but the smokiness overwhelms the beef flavor and the giant noodles (about 2" wide) are a pain to eat. The Beef Cheek "A L'Orange" is just....I don't even know what to think of it. I couldn't taste any orange and the pieces were rather over-crisp and greasy.

That said, I'm still glad I chose this as the place to take my visiting, out-of-town friend Nurah M. She doesn't get good Chinese food where she lives, so she wanted me to pick a place to satisfy that craving. Mission Chinese was perfect because it took her request one step further and gave us original, unique Chinese food that even other Chinese restaurants wouldn't offer. So if you're looking to find a Chinese restaurants that meets these criteria, I would definitely recommend Mission Chinese.
author: Josephine L.

description: Worst.meal.ever. The waitress was rude and insulting. Typical hipster bull. Do not go here.
author: Hunter S.

description:
Situation
- Dinner on a Sunday night
- Ordered the Ma Po Tofu ($11)

Pros
- Food
- Portion size

Cons
- Long wait

Overall
- The food was good and worth a repeat visit
author: Dipesh G.

description:
This place is so great, especially if you're into spicy spicy delicious and unique food.

The Mongolian long Beans are packed with flavor and so very spicy and delish! I get this every time.

The Kung pao pastrami was a little salty for me but it was still a win. 4 stars

Cod fried rice is famous for a reason. It's somewhat of an acquired taste but after the first few bites, you'll understand why it's so raved about; if you don't like fish, don't get it. This isn't going to change your mind.

The tea smoked eel rolls are very very good but they aren't necessarily the star dish here.

Schmaltz rice is very garlicky and gingery (almost refreshing) - it's awesome. I get it with the hot sauce on the side.

Kung pao beef. Yes yes yes. Bar far the best and most tasty dish IMO.
author: Nasrin M.

description: "That's not a flavor.  That's an emotion."  That was my buddy's reply after we tried the chicken wings and I asked him "WTF flavor is that?".  Quite possibly the best wings I've ever had, these wings taste as good as they look.  The dishes served here are unlike any other dishes I've ever had at a Chinese restaurant.  Salt cod fried rice, Tiger Salad, Thrice cooked bacon, the spareribs....all delicious.  I've frequented this place at least five times and have never been disappointed.  If you go in the evening, be prepared to wait.  Also, this place blares hip-hop music.  A definite plus for me, but maybe not for everyone.
author: Steve K.

description: Warning place has a line! I waited about 30 mins on a Sunday night. Bathroom is of course gross it's a chinese place! But I like that they have water pitchers for the table. place is good. to be honest i only tried this place because my cousin worked here before she moved to nyc. I loved the tofu and how different the food was.
author: Diane S.

description:
My sf friend (former Texan friend) urged I try this mission Chinese restaurant out. I couldn't imagine that this place would have been better than the Chinatown places in Houston, TX. I came to visit sf to try different food, not Chinese! But as he insisted, I went with it since it was famously known and attracted long lines. Luckily on a Sunday around 1pm, there were no lines but after a while that we were dining there, the restaurant started filling up.

There's no ac inside, just the front doors being pretty open which made it for a miserable and uncomfortable eating environment because it was so darn hot. We were better off eating outside on the floor instead of inside this sauna. They also served lukewarm water. 

We ordered the ma po tofu which to this day, I can't explain the weird tingling numbing sensation I got from this dish! It's not like it was super spicy but enough to make us sweat. Add on top of that with the hot environment, and you're one sweaty, sticky hot mess! We kept asking for napkins to wipe off. The dish was a bit too much. It made it difficult for me to thoroughly enjoy my meal because of the numbing it did to my mouth and tongue. No matter how much rice I ate, it wouldn't go away. The taste was also so different, you couldn't stop eating it either. It was normal when you take a bite then tangy aftertaste? Anyone feel me on this? 

We also ordered the thrice bacon with rice cake. The rice cake reminds me of the Korean ddok, that's probably what it is anyways. Anyways I'm not a fan of bacon but this dish was pretty delicious and flavorful! The bacon combination with the rice cake mochi was so good, I can still taste it in my mouth. I definitely recommend this dish. 

We also family styled, that's the way to go!
author: Jeena L.

description: The food is delicious but the service is less than friendly. Don't come here looking for hospitable waiters and waitresses, but if you're looking for a solid meal, this place will get the job done.
author: Whitney T.

description: Food so spicy it was inedible.. Also, overcharged my tip on a $40 to go order by $20!!!!! (Mind you, I always tip at least 10% on to go).  Read other reviews, I see I'm not the first this has happened to in terms of both the food and over charged tip.
author: Shannon S.

description:
Checked yelp to see if it is open as many places are closed Monday's. Yelp said it is open. Drive all the way there to find a sign on the door saying "closed for Chinese New Year vacation" this is the second time this place has done this to me. Fool me once shame on me, fool me twice shame on you! I will NOT be back. Way too much MSG anyway.
Hey here's a tip.... Assign someone to take care of yelp so the customer gets the proper info. You just lost a customer as this is the second time you did this and just don't seem to care.
author: David P.

description: Every time I visit the city I have to come here!  This time, however, I didn't want to deal with the crowds so I had it delivered to my house.  It came in about an hour which was perfect because i was still driving home from work.   I got the salt cod fried rice and the chongqing chicken wings.  both were excellent!!  the wings had this weird spicy flavor that made your tongue tingle but you can neutralize it with the rice. This time the rice was a little more fishy than I would have hoped but still good overall.  I am a little sad that the prices have gone up but still happy they serve quality food.  Good job!
author: Marisa G.

description:
So finally got to go here after a previous attempt on a Wednesday yielded crickets. Understand being closed on a Monday but humpday?

The outside is unprepossessing  leading to........ an equally barren interior. 

There's a sign up sheet on the outside and then you wait. We came at 2:30 on a Friday, half an hour before closing for the afternoon. They seated us and gave us the short, succinct menu.

There was some vaguely vile gangsta rap playing which wasn't expected and was quite what you'd expect from someone who's gone the world in his food production.

Across the entire interior was a paper dragon, taking up the space of the centre of the restaurant, which happily detracted from the rest of the drab interior.

The food? More spicy, than spice. More heat than a Johnny Mathis / Neil Diamond concert combo. Well, for some, anyway.

Highlights were the Kung Pao Pastrami, the thrice cooked bacon (mostly because it's bacon) and the lamb ribs. Low light was the salt cod fried rice that was recommended by others but was more bland then beautiful.

This is, however, the only place that I would order tofu again as it had been made in such a way that it was actually tasty.

Pricing was reasonable and these guys donate a buck or so for every meal to the food banks, which is pretty cool.

Worth trying at least once a year.
author: Pantera W.

description: The food was good but the service was really bad. The waitresses passed us by every time they got near us. We waited to get our order in for almost half in an hour. One of the waitresses who brought our food out just slammed it on our table. I also noticed that after another guest left she grabbed their almost empty water pitcher and put it on our table because we were out. If only the service was better in the once called Mission.
author: Luisa S.

description:
My mouth went from "ok this is spicy" to tingly numb in under 30 seconds. But everything was delicious and worth it. It was spicy but not "mouth is on fire" hot. It was just numbingly goooooood! 

I recommend the salt cod rice, the mongolian long beans, the chicken wings, and the 3x bacon.  They don't have ice or just didn't have ice this time and after all the spice, all I wanted was an ice cold drink. But the room temp water seemed to do the trick just fine.
author: Laur A.

description: Very, very, very overhyped and overpriced just because they are in hipster Mission District. The food is okay but there is no difference between their food and other decent Chinese restaurant's. The only difference is they cost twice as much or more. We had 6 piece of chicken wings that cost $16. I can have same dish at other place for $7. The thriced cooked bacon with rice cake cost $16 as well. Fair price: $8-$9. Last dish: salt cod fried rice, $13. This is freaking typical salted fish fried rice you can find at ANY Chinese restaurant at $8-$9 the most. They didn't even cook it well. We had pieces of rice that crumped together that wasn't broken properly hence didn't get seasoned. Don't waste your money here.
author: Shinta L.

description:
omg THREE items for delivery $$$$$59??? 
ok i guess its a holiday so i get it but now for flavor
GROSSSSSS omg this has to be the WORST food i've ever ate in my life . chinese food needs to stick with its ORIGINAL recipes and NOT FUSION. my gawd could this food have been any worse! the fried rice tasted like burnt wood chips but with a tang of fish... the beef brisket was noooo beef just fat and the chicken wings tasted like curry and cinnamon sticks? WEIRD!!
author: Jenny P.

description: First location of Mission Chinese! I headed here for a late dinner around 10pm and still had to wait a good 20 minutes or so. It's located in the Mission in a bit of a dodgy area but close enough to the BART so it's not that bad. After getting a table, we ordered the salt cod fried rice and the lamb noodles. The noodles were pretty good- spicy and flavorful. But our salt cod fries rice never came. I had to remind the waitress after a half hour wait. The service overall was very poor as it was hard to get the waiters' attention. Also, you have to step through the kitchen to get to the bathroom which definitely turned me off as I got a view of the cleanliness. It irked me a bit and made me question the sanitary level. Overall food was good but I don't think it was any outstanding Chinese food.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
James Beard Award Winning Dinner

Last year the first time I came here was after Anthony Bourdain's "Layover" San Francisco episode. Throughout last year I've eaten here several times. I haven't eaten here this year. On the Monday when it was announced that Danny Bowein was awarded the James Beard for "Best Rising New Chef" I decided to come here to eat that Thursday. The menu has slightly changed from the last time I went. They didn't have the broccoli beef cheeks, which is my favorite Chinese dish of all time. They did have orange beef cheeks - very similar texture like orange chicken. The other dish I ordered was the chicken wings. As in the past I never had a bad meal here and trend continued with my latest meal. The orange beef cheeks are delightful and reminiscent to orange chicken where pieces of meat are diced, breaded, and fried. The chicken wings were crispy and moist. Don't get freaked out about the chili peppers covering the chicken wings. The dish is not spicy unless you decide to eat those peppers.

My original post stated that you better start eating here before Danny Bowein starts to get nationally recognized. Since he just won the James Beard Award I don't want to say I told you so, but I told you so.
author: Gerald R.

description:
tip: not your typical Chinese fare; at least the music was great (weezer, rhcp, green day) .

Lamb sizzling platter was very fat though not gamey, fried rice portion was on the small side.  Stir fried lin gao was burnt, braised pork was very tender and juicy, but on the fat side, ma la fried chicken was the highlight cuz there actually was some fried gibbets on the plate for the taking.  Very crunchy and spicy.
author: Jacky K C.

description: Subpar food . The only item that I liked was the cod rice. Don't waste your time with the chicken wings are too salty for me
author: Carol C.

description:
You come to Mission Chinese to get some fun, funky twists on Chinese fusion food in a unique environment, at least that's why I loved it the first time I went. At my first visit over a year ago, the food was gratuitous, rich and just a little too salty - but over all really tasty. 2nd time I took my parents, bad mistake, as two 1st generation Chinese immigrants were appalled by what they considered a bastardization of their home cuisine. Though the food was tasty, it even saltier than the first time, to the point where we didn't finish a lot of the food. I'd give that visit 3 stars because the food was still palatable. 

But these two visits are not why Mission Chinese is getting one star from me. Last night, I took some friends visiting here to enjoy some hip, fun chinese food and half the dishes were just seriously inedible even horrifying. 

We got the Tiki Pork belly, which is always a safe bet at Mission Chinese, it's hard to go wrong with deep friend pork belly. It was solid, but as always a little too salty. You can't NOT skimp on white rice and water here, you will be punished. 

Then the Mongolian Long beans, another edible dish, it wasn't great but again it's nearly impossible to screw up. 

Next we got to the Sesame chicken, by this time everyone's tastebuds were experiencing some serious fatigue. Drinking water was such a good relief that it almost hurt. Sesame chicken was not noteworthy - I almost forgot we had eaten it. Thick crust, over cooked, barely any meat... again primary flavors: salt and sugar.

But the last two dishes are why I woke up with my throat swollen this morning, what made a pretty mediocre meal unforgettably bad, why I've probably lost dinner-picking rights among my friends and why I will never go back to Mission Chinese again. 

We got the Vegan Dan-Dan Mein - again nearly impossible to screw up. The noodles came out swimming in this thick sauce, unlike any Dan Dan mein I've ever seen, more like noodle cornstarch soup. There was a hint something weird, herbal, tangy - almost a mix between lemon grass and pinesol that was in the noodles... not only do those two flavors NOT mix with food in general, they especially clash with the Ma La (numbing spice) that laced the Dan-dan mein. That combined with what must have been 500g of salt in this small bowl, the four of us couldn't get through 1/4th of the small bowl of noodles.

Finally, the unforgettable Ma Po Tofu. I had nightmares about this. How the F*(#K do you screw up Ma Po Tofu that badly? Texturally the dish was okay and that's where the good things ended. There was Ma La again, which I expect to be in a good Ma Po, but then you get slammed with the salt and there's this indescribable chemical burning pain. The only thing I can compare it to is Potassium bitartrate filling the inside of your mouth. Don't ask me how I know but that's the closest feeling there is - if you want to try for yourself they sell Potassium bitartrate under the name Cream of Tartar in most grocery stores (have 911 on the ready) OR you could just try some of Mission Chinese's Ma Po Tofu for 10X the cost. At least you'll have a pretty red dragon gracing the saddest culinary atrocity in your life. 

Seriously we are not picky eaters, I'm Chinese and I clear my plates but we could not eat more than 3 small spoonfuls of the Ma Po Tofu. I just kept diluting that chemical sludge with more and more white rice until I realized I was just eating white rice at that point to try to end the pain. I want to emphasize that I grew up with Chinese peppers and Sichuan food, this was not the burning of chilies or Ma La... this was something else, much more sinister. Water hurt, my tongue hurts this morning, my throat is nearly swollen shut. How was this even legal? Were we being experimented on? 

I was between tears and laughing hysterically when our sweet, nervous waitress asked us if we wanted to box our nearly untouched food. Please no.
author: Jing Y.

description:
On a whim, Greg and went out for date night to Mission Chinese on a Sunday.  We assumed that because it was a Sunday night that there'd be a shorter line. Sike.  After putting our name down on the clipboard outside, nervously pacing up to see where we were in line, we ended up walking down the street to The Sycamore for a drink before heading back.  Once we sat down, we decided that we were going to go all out and get all of the "highly recommended dishes" per Yelp.  Here's what we ordered:

-Fresh Rice Noodle with peanut sauce: Definitely fresh, but we got this only because the Egg Noodles were sold out that night.  Our overall reaction was that it wasn't anything out of the ordinary.
-Tiki Pork Belly: Loved the pickled pineapple that comes with this, but like the Fresh Rice Noodle, it wasn't anything that blew my mind.

And then came...
-Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes: OMG. THIS WAS AMAZING!  I definitely have a soft spot for bacon, but this was something my tastebuds hadn't experienced yet!  This was definitely spicy as indicated on their menu, but it was mitigated by the chewiness of the rice cakes.  I would definitely get this again!
-Chongqing Chicken Wings: HOT HOT HOT HOT.  The spice type on this is unreal and nothing that I had ever tasted before.  After scouring the internet for the type of spice that coated the chicken wings, we discovered that it is the Sichuan peppers that give the "I can't feel my face" numbness and the "I need a tub of yogurt" heat in my mouth.  Granted, my spice threshold is insanely small, so if you're sensitive to the spice pizzazz, tread with caution.  Otherwise, this is definitely a must-have item.  I'm told that it doesn't hold well for leftovers, which is why it's only available for sit-down.
-Kung Pao Pastrami: Most definitely a spicy dish, and one of Greg's favorites for the night  This dish came out last, so we were able to take the leftovers home.  The smokiness of the pastrami really came through, and the spiciness was definitely a good kick in the ass for the end of the night.

Overall, while the first two dishes were lackluster, the last three dishes were so insane from a taste perspective, you really had to think about what you could relate it back to.  You knew it was Chinese, but everything that went into it said that this isn't like any Chinese you've ever had before.  Purely because it created a mystified reaction from both of us, this place gets 4 stars.  Cheers Mission Chinese for making my tastebuds ponder their own existence!
author: Lisa I.

description:
I absolutely love Mission Chinese Food. Yes, it is targeted at hipsters to a ridiculous degree. But the food is delicious. I've been a few time now. The first couple of times, I burned my mouth on awesomely spicy food. The third time was not as nuclear-hot but also delicious.

My favorites: veal ribs, chicken wings, green beans.

Gluten-free notes: They have a gluten-free menu! Just ask them for it, and they bring it to you on a tiny piece of paper. Yes, you can eat awesome Chinese food drenched in sauce. No more plain rice, sauce-less meat, or naked veggies. Eat and enjoy.
author: Ellie P.

description: Hadn't read the reviews, didn't really know what I was getting into, waited fifteen minutes for dinner on a Saturday (much to the jaw-drop-shock of friends who know more than me about the SF food scene.) Sauntered in, ordered piles of food and was delighted. The pickles, the cod fried rice and beef ribs were the crazy fireworks-worthy standouts. Not pretentious, just delicious, I would love to be able to dig into these all the time. The decor is old school Chinese restaurant in the Mission, with extra lanterns and paper dragons. Friendly prompt staff were sweet and helpful, and I loved the smart little list of local beers. Walking through kitchen to bathrooms always weirds me out but it's nice to see everything looking pretty clean in this old divey place, and the busy kitchen staff smoothly doing their thing.
author: Risa D.

description: The wait normally i heard is crazy but we went during the weekend right when it opened. The mapo tofu was way too salty. The beef soup was okay but not that i really expected. The nian gao (bacon rice cakes) was good. Overall the food wasn't that unique and more on the oily, just added a lot of pepper to make it taste good and was very very salty. I really like places in china town or western SF where the food is cheaper and not as salted or have as much sauce on them.
author: Lily P.

description:
Definitely not you usual Chinese restaurant!!  

Ma Po tofu : yummy!!!! 
Tea smoked eel : large serving of yumminess. 
Mouth-watering chicken : it's ok. Not remarkable. 
Noodle soup: ewwww!!! Take it easy on salt please!!! This is one of the saltiest foods i have ever tasted in my life!!! (And this is coming from a junk food junkie!)

Service: very good. Pleasant staff. 

I can definitely go back here. But not so soon since Yamo is just around the corner!
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
If a Chinese person were to walk into this place, is that the equivalent of me, the Sushi Nazi, walking into Sushi Bistro/Tsunami/any-other-crappy-ass-white-people-sushi-restaurants-in-town?

There were no other Asian people dining in this establishment, both times that I've been here. Bad sign?

Well, guess what? I grew up on Panda Express orange chicken, and I love it. So, to me, Mission Chinese Food tasted pretty damn good.

Highlights include their tea-smoked eel (an appetizer of eel wrapped in rice noodle with some tasty sauce), cumin lamb, and pig tails. 

So why 3 stars? Most of their dishes seem to be extremely over-salted. I usually like my foods to be saltier, but this place just over-does it for me. Despite that, though, I still seem to enjoy the meal very much.

By the way, the bathrooms here are way out in the back, through the kitchen... What's up with the sign above the doors as you walk towards the bathroom that says, "Bathrooms ahead. Please don't ask anyone in this room any questions"? 0_o?
author: Kazu O.

description: I've had this placed bookmarked ever since I saw it featured on Anthony Bourdain's Layover SF episode.     And was excited to check it out. We decided to be adventurous and take the BART.  When we got out of the station the neighborhood looked a bit rough...this was our first time in the Mission District.  It reminded me of a more urban Highland Park.  We knew we were getting closer to our destination when we saw more hipsters and other gentrified shops.  What intrigued me about Mission Chinese Food is that it is a pop-up in a mom and pop Chinese restaurant.  The atmosphere was cool with red lights for ambience, decorations on the ceiling and hip hop music playing in the background.  We got there at 6:30p on a Saturday and had to wait about 45 min.  We ordered the ribs with coca cola, 3x cooked bacon with rice cakes, squid ink noodles and a soup that I can't remember the name, that had a weird flavor and made your mouth feel numb. I appreciate that the food was very different than the typical Chinese menu, but the food was just ok, I wasn't wowed.  My dad hated it and wished we had just gone to a regular Chinese restaurant. For the price and the long lines, I was expecting better. The service was a bit slow as well.  I am glad I tried it out, but I don't think I would go again.
author: Rochelle R.

description: Interesting salt cod fried rice, service at the end of the day was quick and responsive, no problems; but the menu is very short, and all kinda boutique pricy, not your working coolie's place for a warm filling fried rice.
author: Joe J.

description: I've done twice and look forward to stopping by when I make it out to the city often. My favorite was the beef brisket and the lamb ribs. I'm now pescatarian and there are so many fish and vegan alternatives and so far what I've had has been pretty amazing.
author: Nazee M.

description:
Awesome food!

Visited yesterday during lunchtime.  We had the tiki pork belly (great flavor, excellent sweet/salty tastes), veal rib (roasted perfectly with a nice spicy sauce), ma po tofu (yummy spicy with a good balance of tofu and pork).  Will definitely come again!

Get the Mexican coke with real sugar!
author: C G.

description: When I first got here I was not feeling like it was a Chinese joint because they played American music LOUD so you really cant have a conversation with someone e that's with you as for the food it's OK.  I mean I got the cho mein but it little to much extra  sauce and that kind of ruined it buts alright it's one of those one time stop things.
author: Ivan S.

description:
Paradise for hipsters and people who refer to themselves as foodies. Yes, MCF adds something new to the food landscape and I love that chef Danny Bowien is not held back by normal conventions and is cooking up dishes from the heart and often the gut. Unfortunately I have to say that for me there are quite a few misses on the menu.

We went with 4 people and ordered the Braised Pea Leaves, Chongqing Chicken Wings, General Tso's Veal Rib and Spicy Beef Chow Mein. The pea leaves were actually quite tasty and the broth flavorful and showed some restraint and balance, something that was not the case for the other dishes. The chicken wings are fried well and at first glance look like a typical Szechuan dish, but are coated with a mouth-numbing pepper, which as many people have pointed out here, is actually quite unpleasant. It has nothing to do with how spicy the dish is, but it numbs your mouth and kills your taste buds for about 10-15 minutes. 

The chow mein was extremely over-salted, to the point where it was inedible and the veal rib was greasy, the coating not that special and generally didn't live up to an $18 entree. Which brings me to the last point, the place may look like many other cheap Asian eateries, the prices certainly don't. 

All-in-all we walked in extremely excited and hungry and we left with an overall feeling of disappointment. I don't think we will be back anytime soon.
author: Neil W.

description:
My favorite chinese restaurant. Yeah, it's not traditional chinese, but it's still awesome.

Love the chicken wings, saltcod fried rice, kung pao pastrami and thrice cooked bacon.

Can't go wrong with that order :)
author: Ankur V.

description:
I loved this place!!! We ordered a bunch of dishes to share among 5 people and it was a perfect amount of food. 

Yum: 
-Bejing Vinegar Peanuts (not a MUST but still tasty as a quick appetizer); 
-Mongolian Long Beans (good amount of spice, had left overs, everyone enjoyed); 
- Kung Pao Pastrami (came really late, we were full, kinda disappointing but I think it was good). Sort of forgettable cuz I was a few glasses of wine deep by then...eek!
- Forbidden Fried Rice (YUM), 
- Spicy Beef Chow Mein (probably my favorite or tied w/ the rice).

The Dece: Chonqing Chicken Wings (they're fine; I had 1). The service was fine and the atmosphere slightly loud but fun! Love that dragon! It was a really good experience, and I would certainly visit again if I lived there, or if I come back to the Mission! Bring your friends!
author: Juls M.

description: Great food, you must book in advance and then still arrive well before your booking as they are super busy and booked tables do not last long. Fantastic vibe and decor.
author: Audrey W.

description:
I have had good experiences here! But I think I must wait a while before giving this place another go.

My boyfriend and I ate here last night and ordered three things to share. We decided on the Tingly Lamb Face noodle dish, The Ribs, and the renowned Green Bean dish. As usual, the atmosphere was very lively and engaging. Love the lighting and the dragon floating overhead from the ceiling.

The Lamb cheek noodles came first. The broth was incredibly salty, spicy, and heavy all at the same time. I hadn't known beforehand that they'd be udon noodles which I am not fond of but tried to like anyway. The lamb bits were very tender. We both went through our first pitcher of water like nothing.

Next came the beans. These were also quite salty, unbearably so. They actually tasted almost identical to the soup to me, the only difference being texture. I thought at this point that it was our mistake for having ordered two things that were too similar in flavor and at least we had one more thing to try.

The ribs (unsure if they were the General Tsao or the Cumin ones, as one was out and the other was our backup) came very hot with the outside blackened plated on top of sweet onion slices. While I am a fan of crispy skin and charred meat, this was a whole other level. The outer skin was literally a quarter inch thick of black crust. Once you got past that, the meat was pretty good, but had a pretty straight forward generic "pork" flavor. The onions below were probably my favorite part! They were sweet and crunchy.

Not sure if the MSG in the salt shaker on our table was an indication of the kitchen using a good deal of it in the food, but it would explain the saltiness of our dishes, the tingly mouth sensations, and the excruciating headache I've had for most of the day.

So it's bye for now, Mission Chinese, until we meet again!
author: Megan D.

description:
After Santa Con, we had dinner here which was actually pretty good.

But we accidentally left two props at our table.  We realized that and went back within the hour to retrieve them and found out Mission Chinese Food had THROWN OUR PROPS IN THE MIDDLE OF THE STREET WHERE CARS HAD RUN OVER THEM.

They weren't that expensive (2 x 3.99) but sorry you do NOT do that to a paying customer.  At least wait until the next day to vandalize your customers' items, sheesh.
author: David A.

description: I think this place has a more hipster feel to it than authentic chinese food, but that's just my personal opinion. I liked all the food that my friends and I ordered, but felt like it was really expensive. Overall it was a good experience to go to, but there are other places with similar foods/cheaper prices that I would prefer to go to.
author: Athina L.

description:
Oh, so tasty. I had heard about Lung Shan for the past 2 yrs, upon moving to the Mission, but never got around to trying it. My man and I had just enjoyed Thai massages down the street and decided to grab something light. We ordered to go because it was late and the place was packed, though I would like to go back and dine in. Dim and dirty with great loud music, this is just my kind of spot.

He chose the Salt and Pepper Cod fried rice - his personal favorite from childhood - which was alright. Within the white rice, the cod was complimented by soft scrambled eggs, thinly sliced Chinese sausage, and green onion. My first time having this dish and I don't know if I would personally order it again. The cod had an overly fishy smell, which my bf said was normal for the dish.

The dish I chose, Thrice Cooked Bacon Rice Cakes, was a hit. My man warned me that Chinese bacon is sometimes too fatty and slimy, but I suppose since it is cooked three times, it firms up and takes on more of a meaty texture, like the bacon I am more accustomed to. The dish is very rich and pretty spicy but maybe a little over seasoned, which I loved. I offered a bit to my roommate back at home and she was a fan.

The negative, I must say, is that the customer service seems to be lacking. It's the Mission, I know, which somehow gives waiters/waitresses the authority to be super rude and dismissive. I waited around for five minutes before I finally asked one of the staff walking past me again and again if I could order with her, to which I was told to hold on - she never came back, but another girl came and took my order anwyay. The wait time for the food was probably like seven minutes out the door. Also, CASH ONLY ya'll.
author: Crystal C.

description:
ALWAYS GET THE TEA SMOKED EEL. such a delicacy.
