I've been here a couple times- 
first time, I was floored, raved and raved about it to everyone. 
second time, I was satisfied, but less impressed with the flavors. (got their mabo tofu and beef noodle dish) 
third time, I just figured that the flavors were way too heavy and smoky for me. (ordered tiki pork belly, and another noodle dish) 

I went back a couple more times with friends that have never been to the restaurant, and tried other things on the menu, but I always fall back on their tea smoked eel. 

It's definitely an experience dining here, and you definitely won't find flavors like this anywhere else. I still suggest this place to newcomers into the city for these reasons.
author: Tiffany S.

description: I had heard great things, so I was really excited to try Mission Chinese - but overall it was a pretty disappointing meal. We showed up early on a Saturday night, so luckily had no problem getting seated. We ordered 3 dishes: Taiwanese eggplant, cumin lamb, and classic beef chow mein. The eggplant was the only decent dish, it had good flavor but was slightly overcooked. The cumin lamb was not good - there was hardly any lamb at all and it was covered in a giant pile of sliced onions that we had to dig through to try to find the lamb. And the lamb was kind of dry. The chow mein didn't have much flavor and the noodles were  a little mushy. Also, the dishes are all way overpriced!! Based on this sampling - and the giant line that formed by the time we left - I doubt I'll go back for a second visit.
author: Minna B.

description:
Simply wicked food. We followed the trend and got the local favorite. Smashed cucumber, tea smoked eel rolls, salted cod fried rice and the chicken wings. 

I can't fault any if this unique food. 
As with most people I found the ell to be one if the weirdest things I have ever tasted, your taste buds need to sample this strange adventure. 
The cucumber was a great way to start, refreshing and pallet cleansing at $4 a pop you have to be mad not to.
The salted cod would have been the most flavorsome dish and one that I have a hard time capturing with words. It's a variation on your regular fried rice with the standard Chinese sausage but the elixer of this dish is the fish. The cod helps coax out flavors you wouldn't normally appreciate in such a dish whilst bringing to the table an easy to appreciate but not overpowering fish flavour.
author: Aaron D.

description:
Finally came here last night, and don't expect traditional chinese food, but it was good and something different.  For 8 people, we got to try the Thrice Cooked Bacon with Rice Cakes, Salt Cod Fried Rice, Braised Pork Belly, and the Kung Pao Pastrami (got two orders of each).  I expected a bit more from the pastrami, and my favorite was the bacon with rice cakes.  Well, I like rice cakes in general ... the braised pork belly was also really good, with great crunchiness on the top (minus the layer of fat!).  

Might not come back for a while, but the food was good.  Definitely a lot of people waiting outside, even on a Sunday night, so come earlier if you can!
author: Cal C.

description:
The Tiki Pork Belly is really good!  I usually don't like pork skin fat, but Mission Chinese Food makes it so crispy and delicious that I ate it all.  I also tried the Thrice Cooked Bacon, which was smokin' good as well.  I liked the flavors of bacon, bittermelon, chili peppers, and black bean sauce -- I don't think anyone has attempted that crazy combination before.

1 star off: Everything was pretty greasy.

This is *not* a typical Chinese restaurant.  Don't come here thinking you will get your beef with broccoli or sesame chicken.  This is not General Tsao's territory; it is Danny Bowien's.
author: Ally W.

description:
Having lived in Singapore, I'm a big fan of Asian Food even though the majority of it in the west can be crap. However, the food at MISSION CHINESE is better than most and that's because they take Asian standards and toss them on their heads.

While known as MISSION CHINESE FOOD, the actual establishment is called LUNG SHAN RESTAURANT and its a bit of a dive, and I love it for that. The look of the joint and the uniqueness of the flavors are so different, it works. You would come in expecting Lemon Chicken or Beef Chop Suey but in reality, you get something totally different!

We went for CHONGQING CHICKEN WINGS (with Explosive Chili & Crispy Beef Tripe), SALT COD FRIED RICE (with Mackerel Confit & Chinese Sausage), MONGOLIAN LONG BEANS (with Xinjiang Spices, Horseradish & Chili Oil), BEEF CHEEK A L'ORANGE (with Orange Glaze, Kaffir Lime Leaves, Satsuma & Sesame) and KUNG PAO PASTRAMI (with Explosive Chili, Sweet Peppers & Peanuts). As you can see, Asian standards, tossed on their heads. I am a massive fan of the Mongolian Beans, they have a great kick to them and loads of flavor. I enjoyed the Kung Pao but agree with other reviews that said the meat was fatty and burnt. The Salt Cod Rice had a surprisingly fantastic blend of flavors and the Spicy Wings were top notch, mouth numbing heat yet oh, so tasty. The Beef was tender & moist and probably the least surprising of all the dishes.

You will have to wait to get a seat here as it is always busy and they do not take reservations. Do not go with a large party (more than six) or you will wait for long time. I can see why this place may rub some people the wrong way but not me, it's unique, it's reasonable and it's very flavorful. This was my second time here and I will return for another meal! Solid 3 Stars
author: G C.

description: Dark, red lights and loud music, which was fun. The large dragon on the ceiling added a little something something as well. We ate only vegetarian and really enjoyed it. I loved the little rice cakes! Only thing I wasn't in love with was that everything was very spicy. Don't get me wrong, I love spice, but it was overwhelming with some dishes.
author: Sam A.

description: Some of the best Chinese and just food I've had.  Simple, quality and bold use of ingredients deliver a depth and complexity of flavor in each dish.  Very affordable for the quality of each dish.  The ambience creates a unique experience as well.  Nothing like chowing down on chow mein while Dr. Dre's Next Episode is playing throughout the restaurant.  We ordered the Brisket Brocoli, Beef Chow Mein, Cumin Lamb, Beef Tartare and Wings.  The brisket Brocoli was my favorite and the rest of the group liked the cumin lamb dish, but they were all excellent.
author: Chase M.

description:
We have always wanted to try this place, and we ordered via GrubHub last night. The porridge and fried rice were great. Delicious. The lamb ribs were dry, dark, and old tasting- the fatty parts were unusually greasy and sticky. I am normally a meat lover and semi forced myself to eat three out of four. I thought it was weird but chalked it up to a fluke mismatch of taste buds. Turns out it was more.

After eating we went to bed early; this morning I woke up with an incredible nausea. It wa sickening; I had trouble focusing on anything other than the terrible nausea. Eventually I tried to throw up and almost immediately threw up everything.

I immediately felt better; to me this was clearly a case of poorly cooked or spoilt meat. My gf, who had just the rice and the porridge was not nauseated at all.

I would like to go back and retry one day but it feels like punishing myself at this moment in time.
author: Jeff L.

description: Went here b/c of the hype. Ordered the mapo tofu and bacon rice pancakes. The Mapo Tofu was not edible b/c of the random spices that were in it. The bacon rice pancakes after that tasted the same b/c they either used similar spices or the mapo tofu was just too overwhelming. The only thing edible was the market greens which came at a nice hipster price of $12.
author: Thomas C.

description:
It's pretty funny, I've been wanting to try MCF for awhile now and I must have walked by it a handful of times without even realizing that this was MCF (nondescript Chinese restaurant sign Lung Shan on the outside).

Decor was pretty hilarious although I expected it since my co-worker gave me the low down before we went. Came on a Monday around 11:45am, no wait, the restaurant was pretty empty.

He ordered the rice porridge and I had the cod fried rice. The rice porridge was really hearty and I liked all the ingredients/textures. The fried rice was also pretty good with a nice subtle flavor although out of the 2 the rice porridge trumps. It is perfect for a cold day/sick day.

I wouldn't mind eating here again for sure but wouldn't go out of the way for it. It is a little bit pricier than typical Chinese place with rice dishes running around $11-12. The nice thing is that with every plate 75 cents is donated to the food bank. I like eating at places that give back to the community.
author: Betty C.

description:
BYOB. Yes, I said you can BYOB. 

It's difficult for me to give 5 stars but WOW. From the outside it looks weird, and you walk through the kitchen to go to the bathroom, but don't let that deter you. 

They have amazing food and its BYOB which is awesome. We walked in with 2 bottles of wine, ordered a lot of food and it was only about $25 each. 

Don't miss it.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Some of the best modern chinese food i've ever had. The exploding chili chicken wings were an absolute highlight. They'll make your mouth numb for a couple hours, the heat is a slow burn that'll stay with you, but not overwhelm you or the flavor of the wings. Totally outstanding.

The triple cooked bacon was also just extraordinary. Incredible flavors melding with each other. Did I mention bacon? Even the tofu skin was declicious in the dish.

The salt cod fried rice was also surprisingly delicious. I mean what chinese kitchen uses salt cod?!!! Maybe they should! The dan dan noodles were good, though nothing too special as was the chicken fried rice.

We loved it...gotta get those wings again!
author: David L.

description: this is definitely a quintisential Mission restaurant. we ordered a bunch of different items and love them all. We also got Chinese mojitos but I am not sure what makes it different from a regular mojito... all and all amazing. loved the huge dragon on the ceiling.
author: Angela M.

description: Third time visiting and never had a good meal here. Really reluctant but an out of town guest insisted. Service is terrible - waitress spilled our beer and joked that had never happened before and would happily replace but wow never came back, asked for chopsticks several times, water cups were dirty, and food came out all at once for party of 6 on 2-2 tops. Restaurant was packed, music and blinking lights were a bit too much shtick for shitty Chinese food. Diarrhea town for everyone and this morning still paying the consequences  tmi but really, pass.
author: Grace C.

description: Well fU if you want to come in for take out when they say they are open. Because at 10:22 on a Monday night I could not get them to make me any food to go or to stay. Summer hours I guess. Sure it would have been delicious. 5 stars for being super accommodating.
author: Rye G.

description: Obviously great. Not authentic! Don't go for authentic! Go for delicious, fun, social, friendly, colorful. But, it's not a late night place. They start stacking chairs real fast at closing time!
author: Kate M.

description:
So Michael Bauer downgraded his review of Mission Chinese Food to 1 star. I come back over two years later, and I keep my 4 star review.

Most of the recent Yelp reviews of MCF have been bad... like viciously bad. It makes me feel sort of sad but you know, we spend so much time building things up, and then we tear them down. Human nature! 

Came here with my elderly Asian parents on Labor Day Sunday as soon as it opened. The decor is still as craptastic as any hole-in-the-wall in Chinatown, except with Caucasian hipster waitstaff. My mom was skeptical. She does not like "Asian Fusion junk" as she calls it. She's like, "Give me Chinese or give me American, not this between stuff!" so I was a bit nervous taking her here, especially after reading all the bad reviews.

The good news is - the food is still pretty consistently flavorful. We  three over-ordered of course. 

Bento Box Lunch with Broccoli Beef (the tea-smoked eel wrap was not great, but the Broccoli Beef was da bomb)
Salt Cod Fried Rice (not pungent like if you ordered in Chinatown)
3xCooked Pork with Bitter Melon, Tofu Skin & Rice Cakes (spicy, delicious, a good mix of textures, and very very very minimal amount of bitter melon) 
Grandma's Dumplings (basic)
Pickled Pluot ribs (incredibly flavorful, crunchy exterior, tender interior, the pluots were definitely pickled - we all tried a piece and puckered like crazy)

I was expecting to be sorely disappointed, and honestly, afterwards, I shook my head at all the hubbub of explosively negative reviews. I think the hype will forever haunt MCF, but without the hype, the dishes would be akin to an above-average untypical Chinese restaurant in SF.
author: Joshua L.

description:
Mission Chinese Food is a love-it or hate-it restaurant:  the flavors are bold, unique, and honestly a lot of them don't work.  However if you're adventurous and enjoy over-the-top spicing (not in heat but in strengh), then MCF is worth a visit.

Faves:  Tiki pork belly, salt cod fried rice.

Okay:  Beef Cheek A L'Orange, Kung Pao Pastrami (two people, including me, enjoyed the pastrami but the other two at our table hated it).

Did not like:  Beijing Vinegar Peanuts, Mongolian Long Beans

Get there early -- we arrived at 6.30 on a Saturday and only had a 15 minute wait, but when we left at 7.30 the line was over an hour!   They don't take reservations.

http://pekoepeony.blogspot.com/2013/03/mission-chinese-food-san-francisco.html
author: Alice C.

description:
It pains me to write a bad review for mission chinese but they treated us like crap earlier this week, and I'm not one to let that slide by without notice. It took over 2 hours to get our food after we ordered, and we were lied to about the status of our order more than once. No bueno.

Food is a solid 4 stars: we love that they deliver wings now, cod fried rice is always solid, as are the dumplings. We discovered the chow mein this time and that was  tasty too. It all is just as good (maybe better) the next day too, so order extra!

Now the bad. We ordered delivery and were quoted 45-70 minutes. I've done this many times before, and they're usually spot on with the order. I probably live about 8 blocks, but it was a lazy day, going to pick it up was just another thing on a busy list. After 90 minutes we called. They checked our address and phone number to confirm where it was.

"It's already out for delivery. "

Ok cool, they're busy. It'll be here soon. Maybe they just had a big order ahead of us. Then nothing for the next 30 minutes. At 120 minutes (2 hours), we called again.

"Oh, we misplaced your order, we'll have to fire it again and get it out in the next 20 minutes."

Hmm...so it's NOT out for delivery then. Can we get a discount on this or a future order? It's going to be 2.5 hours since we ordered and the people are hungry!

"No, we're not authorized for that"

Uhh, okay? Great customer service, friend. I love to wait 2-3 times as long for my food and get no apology. Our food magically showed up about 15 minutes after that last call. Too soon for them to have remade the food if you ask me. Never got the true story about what happened on their end. Next time I'll order from someone else...your food's not worth waiting almost 3 hours.
author: Sarah B.

description:
The fourth star is for the egg egg noodle and efficient service alone, and I'll keep returning for those. 

Otherwise the menu is pretty limited for me, as I'm a delicate flower in the spice department. (Maximum one flaming butt symbol for me.) I tried the Ma Po Tofu once but could not finish. Everything else I've tried on the table was tasty, but I don't know if I'd want to order a whole dish of any one thing to myself. 

Lunchtime on a Saturday didn't have any lines the last time I went; I hear others get takeout or delivery to avoid the lines but my prized egg egg noodle is only available in the restaurant. I try to find off-peak times to avoid lines.
author: Krista L.

description:
Let's be clear this place is not authentic chinese food. If you are looking for that you might as well go to China town or some place else, this place has chinese food but it  is definitely Americanized. I ended up sharing the black vinegar peanuts, chongqing chicken wings, ma po tofu and sizzling cumin lamb. Anyone who looks at this menu should realize this is americanized chinese food since chinese people usually dont cook with cumin.

Anyways, I thought the black vinegar peanuts were pretty good, the vinegar actually tasted like balsamic vinegar to me personally and the garlic in it was tasty. The chongqing chicken wings were my absolutely favorite because I loved the crispy deep fried beef tripe. It really isnt that spicy, dont let those explosive chilis scare you off. There is a nice dry heat to it. The cumin lamb dish is also good and not your typical Chinese food. The ma po tofu was okay but my boyfriend loved it and ate it up. This place is definitely on the expensive side for Chinese food and the tables are right next to each other so you could end up sitting next to a complete stranger. 

It was okay, I am glad I tried it but I probably wouldnt make a special trip out here but then again I personally dont care for Chinese food since I grew up with it and I am very picky about my Chinese food.
author: Abigail L.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Sunday. I forget what time we arrived but there we were seated immediately for our party of five. We ordered five dishes to eat family style. We got the thrice cooked bacon, kung pa pastrami, mouth watering chicken wings, westlake rice porridge, and the tea soaked eel.

The thrice cooked bacon and the kung pao pastrami had almost the same flavor profile, so I would maybe just order one of these to try. Both dishes were fairly spicy so be careful if you're afraid of some heat. The mouth watering chicken wings came covered with red chilis. My mouth was numb by the time I finished consuming these. They come served with fried tripe.

The westlake rice porridge was probably my favorite dish. It had a good amount of beef and egg chunks which provided excellent flavor. The tea soaked eel was also pretty good, the eel comes wrapped in rice noodle. The tea flavor is strong and prominent and really shines through.

You got to walk through the kitchen and out the back to get to the bathroom which was surprisingly clean. Overall, a welcome dining experience that provides a nice twist to the usual Chinese cuisine.
author: Kevin N.

description:
I don't know what's up with all the haters but this is hands down the best Chinese food in San Francisco.  Here's what we had:

- Beer Brined Sichuan Pickles
- Sliced Peanut Noodles (AWESOME)
- Spicy Octopus and Lamb's Tongue Salad
- Ma Po Tofu (how great is it that they used pork shoulder instead of just ground pork)
- Baby Bok Choy in Popcorn broth
- General Tso's Veal Rib

I already want to go back to try some of the other dishes.
author: Chad T.

description:
3.5 stars.

Yesterday was the debut of the latest food venture (Mission Chinese Food) by the folks of MSF sharing the kitchen at Lung Shan. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/G5cLIqCQd5QPOEKXl9LAAg/l The concept is "Americanized" Chinese food with a few twists. A friend had warned me in advance about the spicy items in the menu, just in case u can't handle the heat. I didn't feel like eating spicy food this time, so I didn't order those items (will try next time). Another tip: IF u order to go, don't forget to ask for utensils and napkins if u need them, otherwise u won't get any.

Prices are not cheap, but 75 cents from every dish is donated to charity (SF Food Bank). Old news for those already familiar with the MSF concept. I have to admit that my first impression was that I preferred the old MSF creative menu better.

About the food so far, in my opinion most dishes rate in the 3 to 4 stars range, some better than others.

The Peking duck chinito ($8) http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1NybyuwRYYqkFJNYtaAbWg/l is a meat version of a HK dim sum item - duck meat inside a fried dough ("yau tiu" or "oily sticks" in Chinese) wrapped in a rice crepe ("cheong fun"), and served with hoisin sauce. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/CP9KxPfb2GyJJ_4K8HcScg/l Nothing new for dim sum aficionados. - Verdict: it's just okay.

The salt cod fried rice ($10) http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/JIHAl3aA3FoBguVCmW3k1w/l is probably the most expensive fried rice I've ever paid for, but it's tasty and u get plenty of BIG chunks of tender fish as well as lots of sliced Chinese sausage. In a way it's like getting 2 dishes in one (deboned fish + fried rice), not bad at all. My favorite dish in the batch. - Verdict: thumbs up!!

The half roasted chicken ($9) http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/2Es_aFnCVfwHN1ZT5Xa-RQ/l was the most generous portion-wise of all the dishes I've seen. It can easily be shared among 2 or more people, and it comes with a stir-fried rice with peanuts. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/D6_-GVzaUwKOjY76JJCmpQ/l Great crispy skin on the chicken. The pristine grated ginger sauce was neat, and the burnt wine sauce (yes, not soy sauce) was interesting. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8yMWJLI6YmYOCTEmfINHEA/l Most Chinese restaurants have something similar - "chuy pei cay" or crispy skin chicken, New Hing Lung makes a very good version (way better). - Verdict: thumbs down.

For dessert there's a taro pannacotta with honey ($4). http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/35MfXhgCEgsUtsc9BOLGxQ/l I'm sure that it looks wonderful on a plate when dining-in, but the crisp cookies got soggy inside the container with the honey sauce. The taste (mild taro potato) and texture were fine, a good dessert. - Verdict: thumbs up!

The old dining room could use a remodeling. For me the the lure of the original MSF was the changing menu and creativity. I hope that they can occasionally add a new item to keep things interesting. UPDATE: they now add new menu items almost monthly. Some dishes are interesting, some are not. My overall rating remains 3.5 stars. For any future updates I'll just upload my pics of the new food items.

Note that u can also order from Lung Shan's regular menu.
$5 corkage fee. Free delivery available within the nearby area.
Hours: daily 11am-10:30pm
author: Luis C.

description:
How does this place not have at least 1000 reviews?
This place is amazing--I'd give it 4.6 stars. They lose some points for allowing people to smoke outside and leaving the door open letting the cold air in. Also, it has that "dirty Chinese food diner" feel to it which isn't necessarily a bad thing. However, that's not what a 5-star restaurant is to me.

At any rate, about everything on the menu is delicious and worth trying. I was in a party of 5 so we got to try lots of different dishes.

Order:
Slow-Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly
Salt Cod Fried Rice
Thrice Cooked Bacon
Veal Ribs

Beware the beer is served in cans. I was hoping it was on tap or in a bottle. I probably wouldn't have ordered one if I knew it were going to be in a can.

This is a definite place in the city to come see.
Mission has too many good spots.
author: Marlon T.

description:
We had heard great things about this place -- James Beard Rising Star award! Another restaurant in NYC! Wow, right? So we decided to give it a try, and called in our order. We got the Grandma Zhou's Pork Dumplings, Tea Smoked Eel, General Tso's Veal Ribs, and Breakfast Fried Rice -- $70+ including delivery and tip. Where to start?

The eel roll was overly salty and had stalks of totally inedible, tough celery that had to be removed in order to chew and swallow; and there was no braised pork or hoisin in sight. 

The dumplings were bland and doughy, the filling slightly salty, and only two pea tendrils were found in the dish. 

The veal ribs had a good flavor, but a solid layer of tough silverskin between the burnt top layer and meat had to be messily pulled off in order to eat.

The breakfast fried rice was probably the best of it all, although kinda bland -- the ikura was the highlight of this dish, adding little bursts of flavor. 

In short, we have rarely paid this much money for such awful and/or mediocre food. Never again.
author: Davina C.

description:
So this was pretty awful experience. The service was horrible. I know going here not to expect top-knotch service, but this was service was RUDE. I came in last night with my friend from out of town after a sad night watching the Giants game. We were hoping to pick our spirits up with some good chicken wings from Mission Chinese.

We get there and she wants to sit us at the SAME table as a couple. Not the table really close to the couple, literally THE SAME TABLE as the couple. Understandably so, the couple who appeared to be on a nice Tuesday night date, didn't want to be sitting shoulder to shoulder with two girls catching over their forlorn love lives and unsuccessful tinder dates. So doing the appropriate thing, we requested to sit at another table. Nothing against the couple, they seemed very nice.

So we requested it, and the rude hostess at around 7:30 pm last night, said you need to put your name on the board, which we have. Then in a very rude snarky voice, she said "Well I need you to stand outside, k thanks." Ugh! I wish I had gotten her name. We were so turned off, we went to another restaurant. 

Ok, sorry, had to vent. But seriously, Mission Chinese...if you are reading this, I love you guys. You guys have been feeding me since I moved in here as a starving artist but teach that young hostess female to be kinder! I will not be coming back here, and especially with friends from out of town.
author: Lauren C.

description:
It's pretty nerve racking to write a bad review about an iconic SF restaurant. But I'm going to do it anyways.

Mission Chinese was a big disappointment. I normally only dine at restaurants that are on Opentable, but after hearing so much about it (it was in the New York Times for gods sake) I decided I had to try it. A group of my friends and I waited about 45 minutes on a weeknight to get a table.

I'll admit, the dining experience is very unique. There is a big red dragon that goes across the whole restaurant and the music is a great mix of old school hip hop.

The food was mediocre at best. Almost every dish we ordered felt way too salty. The green beens, pastrami, and salt cod dishes were almost too salty to eat. The spicy beef chow mein dish was our favorite.

The terrible service is what made this from a 3 stars to a 2 stars though. We ordered red wine, which was so bad we actually had to send it back. The waitress tried the wine herself, and realized that it had in fact gone bad (why were they serving it then???). For the second half of our meal our waitress was nowhere to be seen.

Has this restaurant gone down in quality since the NY Times Review? Or am I just missing something.
author: Ashwin S.

description:
Terrible customer service. I came in to pick up my food and a waiter abruptly snapped "Move, please!"  I informed a manager but he basically blew me off; no apology or acknowledgement, he just said "ok."

Unpleasant experience and they lost a regular customer.
author: J S.

description:
A couple years of takeout with them has changed my mind as the novelty has worn off. The last time we ordered from them is... the last time. We tried a few new things after growing tired of the usuals and were disappointed. 

Tiger salad is like ordering a bag of mixed greens and rolling it in some rice noodles. Pretty weak and I should have known better.

Kung pao pastrami should just be called kung pao celery. There is hardly any meat in the dish but be thankful for it because what is there is too salty to eat anyway.

Broccoli beef brisket had the "Where's the beef" lady speaking to me from the 80s. Flavors were ok, but $16 for a plate of broccoli is not.

I still like the braised pea leaves though for those that haven't ordered it yet expect to get something close to soup.
author: Easwud C.

description: First time here. Ordered the Broccoli Beef Brisket. Very nice. Atmosphere is great. They play house music!!!!! So awesome! Service was great. Look forward to trying other things on the menu.
author: Claudia B.

description:
this place is AMAZING
i came here for my friends birthday and was warned beforehand that this is a place for carnivores so I had my expectations set pretty low. I was blown away by how great the food was. 
I ordered the egg-egg noodles and the forbidden rice. separately both were amazing, together? Out of this world! I could seriously eat it for every meal. 
My friends ordered the chicken wings, which I understand are a must, thrice cooked bacon and lamb and there wasn't a single bite left on the table. 
Can't wait to go back!
author: Mack A.

description:
I've never rated a place one star for their service. I used to think, "Oh hey, if the place is good, who cares that much about the service anyways?"

Thanks for proving me wrong, Mission Chinese. This could possibly be the worst customer service I've ever had, and I've been to restaurants where there were dead flies on my serving plate. 

Let's start with the ambiance. I get that Mission Chinese is trying to be a cool "hip" Chinese restaurant, but I certainly didn't feel very hip inside a dimly red-lit room (reminds me a little of Chinese brothels) with Drake blasting in the background and a Chinese dragon chillin' near the ceiling. Okay, ambiance aside, whatever.

Let's talk about the servers. Rude, rude, omg, SO RUDE. We had two people come in late because there was an emergency at our company and they had to go and sort it out. So we saved two dishes for them so that they could eat it when they arrive.

One of my friends began to eat, pouring some of the Mapo Tofu onto his plate, and he wasn't even halfway finished with the Mapo Tofu bowl (totally enough for another meal) when one of the servers - a blond girl - just comes over and takes it away. Not a word, not an "excuse me, are you finished with that?". She just comes, and takes it away. WTF? We were all pretty confused, so we asked another waitress - black hair, tattoos, piercings - about it. It was obvious that she didn't believe us when we told her that there was still a huge portion of it left, until the blond waitress who took it away came by and said, "Oh yeah, there was still LOTS of it left." 

Uhm, then why did you take it away in the first place?!?

So, the other waitress with the piercings says, "Oh, I sincerely apologize for that. Unfortunately, the kitchen is closed..." She was not apologetic at all. 

After she said that, we just sort of stared at each other. Naturally, in any restaurant, you would expect the waitress to be like, "Oh hey, since we accidentally took your entire plate of food without asking and just threw it away, we'll leave that dish off the check."

Instead, what she said was: "We can take that dish off the check. Or, instead, if you think 'you had your fill' and think we 'deserve to get paid for the food that you ate', you can 'pay for the entire meal' as well."

I was reading some of the previous reviews, and it looks like this sort of experience - where the waiter and waitresses just take away your food to force you to leave - is not novel. If you close at 10:30pm and would like us to leave by then, all you have to do is ASK NICELY, instead of TAKING AWAY OUR FOOD AND THROWING without asking.

....... I can't even write this review anymore. Getting angry again. 

The experience leaves a nasty taste in my mouth, no matter how good the food was. It wasn't even that great, by the way. You can find good food anywhere else; don't waste your time here.
author: Mandy C.

description:
Finally made it to Mission Chinese. If you get there when it opens there is no wait. I like the low brow decor with the bright Chinese dragon. 

We had the beer brined pickles (which basically is a different type of kimchi with peanuts on top), spicy tofu and the coca-cola pork ribs. Everything was good.

If you like unpretentious food with a flair and spice, then this is a good place for you.
author: Ginger L.

description: Really unique and a must-try! The matcha noodles are one of the most delicious things I've ever had. As expected it isn't as cheap as the generic chinese food you grew up with, but still not as much as a "hip" restaurant on Valencia. Honestly, though, they are kind of heavy with the salt (on all the dishes I've had)...
author: Willy M.

description: I really wanted to like this place, because I made the assumption it would be excellent because of what I read, and by word of mouth. First, the ambience. I realize it's a small place and seats are a commodity, but it doesn't make for a comfortable atmosphere when you're wedged in a corner, with the table a hands length away and no privacy. That's the very reason the young server dumped the appetizers on the leg of a person in our party, and the jacket of the table next to us. It wasn't as if he was incompetent, it's most likely he's not a circus tight roper who can miraculously see in the dark! A little more lights please! Just a little! I'd like to see those paper dragons looming large over our heads before they spray fire. Next, the music. Okay, maybe I'm a bit older than some of the crowd, but EDM in a restaurant that is played in an already small location is irritating as hell! The very fact that I know what EDM is shows I'm not adverse to hip music at a restaurant, but how about background lounge jazz, or something that lends to relaxing rather than trying to read lips in a closet? Next, the food. I had the veggie Ma Po Tofu or is that Po Me? It looked delicious! But I think they borrowed half the salt on the city to make this dish! If I could have tasted my tofu or veggies over the salt, I would have eaten more than three bites. My friend had a veggie dish with pastrami. He loves meat. He hated this! I had a bite, and thought the pastrami tasted like a chopped up baseball glove in salted veggies. Yes, the salt! Ughh! Lastly, I will commend them for their dumplings, even though the sour cream is questionable. That's one step above mayonnaise, so I wouldn't call it creative. Sorry, I'll pass on dragons, cramped quarters, loud EDM, and salted dishes!
author: Rob V.

description:
Stars: 3.5

Mission Chinese Food, is not your typical Chinese restaurant. This place is like a modern hole in the wall; with their dimly lit atmosphere, loud random 90's music that skips a beat literally, and poor ventilation. Our friends, my wife, and I were able to sit around 8:00pm after waiting around 45 minutes. Luckily our friends were able to put our names on the wait list (no reservations) while we tried to find parking (20+ mins).

Food:

   * #9 Tea-Smoked Eel - Fresh Rice Noodle, Chinese Celery, Salted Plum Hoisin, Braised Pork, Cognac Soy [$9]
   * #12 Red Braised Pork Belly - Tender Belly, Broccoli, Sesame, Chickpeas [$10]
   * #18 Thrice Cooked Bacon - Shanghainese Rice Cakes, Bitter Melon, Tofu Skin, Chili Oil [$12]
   * #19 Salt Cod Fried Rice - Mackerel Confit, Chinese Sausage, Lettuce, Egg [$11]
   * #22 Stir-Fried Sweet Peas - Pea Tendrils, Numbing Chili, Red Onion Pickles [$10]
   * Steamed Rice [$1]

Our favorite dishes were the Thrice Cooked Bacon, Salt Cod Fried Rice, and Stir-Fried Sweet Peas (surprisingly). The thrice cooked bacon had a nice spice (medium-hot) to the dish, not too oily and all the ingredients went well together. Let's be honest, everything goes great with bacon! The salt cod fried rice with Chinese sausage was delicious! Who doesn't love Chinese sausage with their fried rice?!?! Last but not least of our favorite dishes was the stir-fried sweet peas. For a veggie dish this one had very nice flavoring to it which kept us coming back for more.

On the other side of things the Red Braised Pork belly was a miss; it was extremely fatty. The Tea-Smoked Eel looked delicious, was good, but not great compared to the our favorites above. Last but not least, the steamed rice was more on the dryer side and did not taste fresh.

Drinks:

   * Einstok Iceland White Ale [$6]
   * Almanac Honey Saison [$6]

Be sure to sit back, enjoy the moment and order some drinks to go with your meal. The Einstock Iceland White Ale and Almanac Honey Saison were both good. My wife liked the Einstok Iceland White Ale more while I liked the Almanac Honey Saison.

Quick Tips:

   * Get there early!

The Good: Fast Service | Twist on Chinese Food

The Bad: Street Parking | Long Wait | Loud Random Music | Coming out smelling like Chinese food
author: Matthew M.

description:
I must say I definitely enjoyed eating at this place a second time.  I really think it's about picking the right dishes here.  I did come across the similar tingly spicy sensation as last time but it wasn't as prominent.  One of my friends was more sensitive to it so stayed away from the mapo tofu that she sensed it was coming from.  But my other friend and I fully enjoyed the spicy tofu dish.  We also LOVED the sizziling cumin lamb dish that had peppers in it but not as spicy to me.  The dish was so aromatic it filled the room and the lamb was absolutely tender..falling off the bone.  Our smaller dish came out later which was strange to us but didnt' disappoint.  We ordered the pork belly which was mouthwatering.  It was strange that it had coconut flakes on top but some how it really worked once you gave it a try.  

Overall I think the dishes I had this time around was a lot better than I had before...and I liked this place better because of it.  And really, I came here because of their reasonable corkage fee and they're ok with you bringing beer in to be "corked" and consumed.  I make my own homebrews so this was a great opportunity for my friends to enjoy my beer and consume some yummy foods while out and about in the city. 

Major tip..we came around 6/6:30 and there wasn't anyone in the restaurant really.  But as soon as 7pm hit it was a mad rush and wait for some.
author: Kim D.

description: What a disappointment. The food was okay, nothing extraordinary in comparison to the millions of Chinese restaurants in SF. What was horrible, was the service. I've never been so poorly treated by a wait staff in my life. Food is not worth the poor treatment, don't go here.
author: Kara S.

description:
Bitter melon hot, 
Bitter melon cold, 
Bitter melon in my mouth--and immediately back on the plate. 

While no one else at our table seemed to mind, and just stared in awe at the speed the bitter melon left my mouth, I guess I've finally found something I just can't eat. It's too bitter. Waa. But the bacon was awesome. Yeaaaaa thrice cooked. So I ate that instead, which isn't too bad of a tradeoff. 

Mongolian long beans were good. If not a bit of a challenge to pick up. The beef cheeks -- orange-y and delicious. Peanut noodles, very nice. The fact that I could walk through the kitchen to the back creepy bathroom -- even better. I like to see what they're slinging back there, and that mile high pile of chili peppers..well good thing we ordered things just mildly spicy, because they're not playing around. 

And you know what was the most delicious...aside from the food that is? Walking up to the restaurant and being immediately seated. Yup. 

Thanks karmic food goods.
author: Nicole G.

description: Cod fried rice, mapo tofu, pumpkin and the wings are all amazing. If you like Szechuan peppercorns you will love the food here. Everything has really unique flavors. Great service, we were seated immediately and the food came out quickly. My only complaint would be that it's a little dark and loud in there.
author: Danielle C.

description:
This place really knows what it's doing w/r/t spices and flavor profiles -- everything I've had here is perfectly balanced with just the right amount of heat, if that makes sense. The vegetarian options aren't bad considering that the menu is pretty small overall (about 1/3 of the menu items are veg). I also like that most of the appetizers are large enough to be an entree for one. This place does get expensive if you're ordering multiple items; with tax and tip, you're looking at ~$30 for one app and one entree with no drink. In that price range I expect a somewhat nicer atmosphere, but I suppose their rent must be through the roof. 

Tip: If you live in the free delivery zone, order delivery! It's usually faster than getting a table and you won't be elbow-to-elbow with your neighbors.
author: Abigail L.

description:
Had to try this place after finding out that Jessica Alba dined at this restaurant. Arrived at the restaurant on a Tuesday night, and was NOT expecting to see a typical-looking Chinese restaurant. Apparently the owner of Mission Chinese Food rented out this space (Lung Shan Restaurant), hence the typical Chinese restaurant appearance. However, when we were seated inside I was very surprised to hear loud, club-like, hip-hop/rap music. We were delighted by this! It made us feel very hip. White Christmas lights lined the walls around the room, and there was even a huge red dragon hanging across the ceiling. Everywhere we looked we saw young, Caucasian hipsters. Typical. I think we were the Chinese group in the entire restaurant.

We ordered the salt cod fried rice (favorite! delicious!), egg noodles (to me, it had a weird, grainy texture to it), tiger salad (very interesting, salad and herbs wrapped in 'fun' (white noodle)), tea-smoked eel (second favorite!), and thrice cooked bacon (superrrr spicy). The salt cod fried rice was my favorite...probably because it was the most normal thing there.

I appreciate Mission Chinese Food for their deviation from traditional Chinese dishes, and I'm glad that I tried this place out! Having grown up in SF I know that there are far better places around the city, but try this place for the experience!

Wait was around 20-25 min on a Tuesday night.
author: Andrea F.

description: I usually love Mission Chinese. We ordered take out and all we could taste was salt and spice. Definitely not the quality I'm used to raving about!
author: Dana V.

description:
Came back in August and the quality is going severely downhill. 

Kung Pao Pastrami has no more dried chili pepper, the very essential ingredient that makes a dish Kung Pao, and the pastrami has shrunken so much...ugh! 

Serious, Mission Chinese, get your shit together.
author: Chi-Chi S.

description: A hidden gem! Its a bit crusty looking but the food is creative with big flavors! Beef rib had a thick smokey bark and was so tender on the inside! Tiki pork belly was sweet, sticky, and melted in your mouth. They're known for the salt cod fried rice which was incredible when paired with charred corn.
author: Christina M.

description: I have lived around the corner from this restaurant for years, but never tried it, despite several recommendations. It always seems super busy, and sometimes I can't find anything on the menu that matches my dietary restrictions. Feeling adventurous Friday night we ordered some takeout vi eat24 however. All in all it was a pretty good meal. I would give it about 3 1/2 stars. After seeing what other people loved on yelp I went with a chicken dish that was pretty good. My complaint, which happens often in Chinese restaurants, is when other vegetables are added or substituted for those that describe the item on the menu. A.k.a. you gave me potatoes when you said it was cauliflower. Potatoes and cauliflower are nowhere close to the same type of item. Potatoes are from the plant family Solanaceae or nightshade, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solanaceae , and many people have an allergic or inflammatory response to eating plants in this family, even if they don't realize it. For those of us who have chronic medical conditions that include inflammation this is something we try to avoid. Don't get me wrong I ate a couple of the potatoes and they were delicious. But why so many? They pretty much where the secondary ingredient to my dish if not the primary one. What I will say is the chicken was moist, I hardly ever eat chicken breasts because it is dry it has no flavor, but this chicken was quite the opposite. My boyfriend enjoyed his Beef and broccoli quite a bit. We both like the pickles we tried but decided they were more of a novelty and something we wouldn't order again. The food certainly had quite a bit of spice even at a mild level, but this was to be expected by me. Luckily I didn't go pick up the food, but with my boyfriend tried to pick the food up I guess they told him they didn't have the order at all, he said the restaurant was very busy it was Friday night, after waiting a few minutes the order magically manifested, it was probably back there all along.
author: Coco J.

description:
The food here is very good and if you know anything about this place already you know that you aren't going to be ordering traditional Chinese dishes here but a nouveau take on them which is something you'd expect from a city like SF.

Our group ordered the tea-smoked eel, kung pao pastrami, salt cod fried rice, and pork belly.  Everything was very tasty (I'd order each item again...and again) but I really enjoyed the kung pao pastrami most which featured very tender and savory morsels of pastrami and had a nice heat factor to the dish.

One other thing I thought was hilarious here were the multiple signs on the top of the door-frames before entering the bathroom (where you have to pass through the main kitchen in order to get there) that read "please do not ask anyone in this room any questions."  It's repeated multiple times.  So funny, especially when you see so many older Chinese ladies gaze at you as you're seeking to locate the restroom.
author: Erich D.

description: Man, it's been a while, but this place still remains my absolute favorite Chinese restaurant I have ever dined at.  Since I no longer live in San Francisco, I've purchased their cookbook so I can make that tingly lamb face noodle soup at home.  That soup is so good, I want to order 12 of them and freeze them.  There is no better Chinese food than this in California.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Haters gonna hate, but my first visit here made me see what the hype was all about.

Here's the breakdown:

Beijing Vinegar Peanuts - UNEXPECTEDLY DELICIOUS! Such an interesting array of flavors. We were hesitant to order this (because WTF are vinegar peanuts anyway?!) but are so happy we did. Plus, you get to eat whole, soft, garlic cloves that come in the bowl.

Braised Pea Leaf and Pumpkin Soup - Meh. I thought the broth was lacking but it did have a very interesting flavor. I really loved what they did with the tofu; they sliced it very thinly so it was like long, wide noodles. I'd skip next time though.

Three Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes (Vegetarian Option) - AMAZING. We actually had to ask the server if we got actual bacon because the fake meat, which appeared to be made in-house, looked and smelled too good to be true. Lots of smokey/spicy flavors, which we loved. It balanced well with the noodles...

Egg-Egg Noodles: DROOL. My husband, a ginger-phobe, loved these. I don't see what other reviewers are saying about this dish having too much ginger.  It was creamy from the egg, fresh and bright from the ginger and scallion, and I couldn't stop eating it. 

I didn't mind the dark, hipster ambiance whatsoever. I actually found myself enjoying the novelty of having Busta Rhymes serenade me through my foodgasm. Who knew?

Try it. Ask your server for suggestions. Don't hate. Enjoy good food.
author: Chelsey B.

description:
I had high expectations for this place based off of my friends who have tried it and raved about Mission Chinese food but unfortunately it didn't live up to its hype. We ordered their long beans, which were far too overly salted and spicy. I can deal with an overload of spiciness but not with an overload of sodium. However, we ordered the cumin lamb dish and my friend and I both really enjoyed it. It came on a sizzling iron platter along with onions and carrots.

We also got 2 beers and the total came out to $42. I definitely wan't to come back and try the other dishes next time. It's not the best but if you're craving a meal with extreme flavor and spice you've found the right place.
author: Angela K.

description:
You know what, I really like Mission Chinese Food.

It's not Chinese food, and you probably shouldn't compare it to the hundreds of authentic Chinese restaurants in the City.  Rather, you should view Mission Chinese Food for what it really is: Chinese-inspired food, with a smattering of influences from other Asian cuisines, all uniquely thrown together in a setting that is 100% Mission.  Take it for what it is, and you may actually enjoy your meal.  But definitely avoid the temptation to compare it to real Chinese food.

As for the actual dishes, here's some stuff I tried and my thoughts:

+ Tiger rolls: a bunch of veggies in a rice noodle roll; this is reminiscent of Vietnamese spring rolls, but with a twist.  Tasty and refreshing. 

+ Szechuan Pickles: nice appetizer dish, lots of spice and kick, the peanuts are a great addition for taste and texture

+ Tea-smoked eel: this is similar to the Tiger Roll in that you have some kind of veggie and, in this case, meat filling in a rice noodle roll.  Pretty tasty stuff.

+ Mapo tofu: super spicy, HUGE portions, but overall just okay. I wasn't wowed by this dish.  Even if I'm not comparing it to "real" mapo tofu, this is still kind of a lackluster dish, one that you can probably pass over.

+ Thrice cooked bacon: now THIS was a stellar dish.  They stir fry rice ovalettes with a mix of vegetables, spices, tofu skin, and more.  What you have is a flavorful, spicy, chewy, and delicious dish that packs a lot of punch into each bite.  Loved this dish. 

+ Salt cod fried rice: now, I know I said I wouldn't be comparing the food here to "real" Chinese food, but a dish like this begs to be compared to the real thing because it IS the real thing.  This is the standard salty fish fried rice that is found in almost all Chinese restaurants, and Mission Chinese Food doesn't try to do its own hipsterized version of it.  Rather, they do the real thing, and it's a decent version, but nothing too special.  I liked it, but it's a pretty standard version.

+ Pork belly: wow, SO fatty, but I liked it a lot.  The crispiness of the skin is delightful, though the amount of fat on this thing is kind of frightening.  But that's also why this dish is good.  But be warned: lots of grease!

I was also pleasantly surprised by how generous the portions are - the dishes are just as big as what you'd find in an authentic Chinese restaurant, which, if you've been to one, you'll know that dishes in Chinese restaurants come with very generous portions.  

What else...food comes quickly, the place has a very "Mission" feel, there's usually a wait but it's not atrocious (we came here around 8pm on a Friday night and probably only waited about 15-20 minutes), it's kind of loud but not unbearably so, prices are fair though a couple dollars above standard Chinese restaurant prices.  

A unique eating experience, and I would certainly recommend this place.
author: Vivian C.

description:
I love the concept of this restaurant! Chinese food with a twist. I had a late flight in so this was the perfect spot to call in a pick up order.

Thrice cooked pork ($11/5 stars) - Chewy rice cakes and bacon practically, but I definitely didn't care for the biter melon. Thankfully you can just remove those pieces without disturbing the rest of the dish.

Salt Cod Fried Rice ($10/4 stars) - Large portion and pretty much what you can expect

Smoked Beef Brisket Soup Noodles ($12/3 stars) - Brisket was really good - fatty and flavorful. Noodles were soggy, but to be fair, we ordered to-go. There were virtually NO stewed carrots (which is why we ordered this dish in the first place). Don't expect typical beef noodle soup, because the flavor is completely different here.

Savory Egg Custard ($12/ 3 stars) - Super small bowl of steamed egg with uni. The boy didn't think the fruit mixed in was very palatable. 

We'll definitely be back to try some of the other items, as I'm hoping that we just ordered wrong.
author: Jessalyn C.

description: Seriously, how long does it take to cook and deliver food? I ordered on their website and waited for 1.5 hours. Called them and they said it's already out for delivery. So I waited another 40 minutes and called again, and they said the driver is going to take another 10 minutes??? Total over almost 3 hours from start and the food is still now here.  Calling my credit card for refund.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
The quality of the food is inconsistent. 4 stars when it is good though. But overall too inconsistent. 

The dishes I like from here are the Mapo Tofu, Chongqing Chicken Wings, and the Salt Cod Fried Rice. I almost never crave Chinese food but when I do, surprisingly it's this even though it's not "authentic" Chinese food. But over the past few years of eating here (mainly ordering for delivery), it's always a hit or miss. Sometimes it's delicious and spicy in a good numbing kinda way, and sometimes it's just bland. I ordered delivery last night and was disappointed. The chicken wings were way smaller than before, and it didn't have the crunchy tripe pieces. The tofu was spicy but bland. Very disappointing.
author: Susan Z.

description:
After trying Mission Chinese in NYC and hearing that it was a copycat of the original in SF, I knew I had to try it when I recently visited for a work trip.  Not only was the wait one-fifth of the time in NYC (and the dining rooms were of comparable sizes), but the food was SO much better!!  I ordered two of the same dishes as I had in NYC (the egg egg noodles and the salt cod fried rice), as well as a few dishes they don't have on the NYC menu and the overall experience and food in SF was far superior.

You can read my other review for Mission Chinese NYC to read my comments on the egg egg noodles (get them!) and salt cod fried rice (skip it!  There's no cod in the dish! We found one measly, minuscule piece, although it was a lot less sweet than the one I had in NYC).  For other dishes I ordered that they don't have in NYC:

1) The tiki pork belly - full disclosure, they have a short-rib version in NYC: MELT IN YOUR MOUTH GOODNESS.  It was perfectly braised, nice and fatty, and not overly sweet. I didn't really understand the coconut shavings on the top though - I could've done without.

2)  the savory egg custard - AHH NYC Mission Chinese why can't you have this on your menu?!?!  Uni and smoked trout roe on top of a chilled egg custard? ZOMG i'm seriously in heaven. I basically ate all of it and my dining partner only got a tiny bite.  I've been really into uni lately, and theirs was fresh and creamy. The roe added some nice pops of salty goodness.

3) The sliced peanut noodles - again, NYC why are you so inferior?! Get these on your menu! Love the delicious rice noodles bathed in rich peanut sauce. So amazing.

My assessment is: shorter wait, better food, less pretentious.
author: Angel H.

description:
A mildly unique dining experience. Having passed by before, once on a Wednesday (closed) and another time (Slammed), some out of town friends wanted to give it another try. We went around 6:45 on a Sunday and the line seemed a lot shorter than usual, and we only waited about 15-20 minutes for a table. 

The restaurant is very dark and the tables are close together, but it smelled absolutely fabulous inside, a deep but delicious spicy aroma. The music was pretty loud and very 80s, and I noticed most of the wait staff were in fact non-Asian which is rare for a Chinese restaurant.

The menu is relatively short and simple which I appreciated. We skipped the cold appetizers and went straight to ordering. The 4 of us shared:
- Thrice cooked bacon
- Mongolian Long Beans
- Wild Pepper Leaves
- Veal
- Chicken wings

The wild pepper leaves are a definite pass but everything else was really good. I should warn you, the food here is SPICY. The chicken wings were literally covered in a bed of those dried hot peppers though were themselves edible and ironically one of the least spicy things we ate. The chicken wings tasted of Chinese 5 spice powder and were meaty and fresh. The bacon dish was very tasty, and I think I liked the veal most of all which was a combination of fatty and well done. The long beans were also quite good and we wish had arrived earlier in the meal. We shared a few rice bowls and some tea. 

A unique interesting and tasty place.
author: Jordan C.

description:
This is a review of dinner with colleagues/friends at Mission Chinese.

The system seems to be; show up, write your name on a board, wait a bit, get a table.  I've heard the wait can be long.  For us, it was about a smoke's worth of a wait.

Our server had a very casual style.  But he was effective and polite.  His personality kind of went with the place.  Everything happens at a pretty quick pace.  This is not a long drawn out dining experience.

The ambiance is kind of something I almost missed.  It was super busy and we were seated in a corner upfront.  From what I did catch,  it comes in just a dime over being a dive. It is also set up to squeeze in as many diners as possible.

http://tinyurl.com/bd3dre2

This is one of those meals where I did not order and I did not pay.  One friend ordered and the other one picked up the check.  I didn't even really see a menu.  Hooray for free food.  However, it does mean I may not be 100% accurate on the names of the dishes.

The food ranged from good to very good.

Kung Pao Pastrami - This was probably my favourite dish.  It just came together very well.  A lot of time strong east-west fusion just blows up in some kind of clash of tastes.  The strong falvour of the pastrami really popped but didn't dominate the dish.  For me, this one worked!

http://tinyurl.com/aargdlz

Beef A L'orange - This was a good dish.  But it was kind of basic.  It was well executed but didn't stand out.  I do like the flavour of orange with beef though.  Plus, the beef was pretty tender.  

http://tinyurl.com/a6rw59q

Spicy Green Bean - If you've read any of my reviews, you will know that I am not the huge lover of greens. But I did dig these.  The beans were cooked perfectly and then there was the heat.  There is nothing bland about this batch of beans.

http://tinyurl.com/afsamo6

Salt Cod Rice - This is another dish that worked against my own personal bias.  I've never been a huge salt cod fan.  But the flavor of the cod was restrained and the rice served as a great platform the dish.  It worked and I really enjoyed it.

http://tinyurl.com/ba3e8y4

Chicken Wings with peppers - I guess this is a Schezwan take on chicken wings.  These are wings buried under a bed of peppers.  They do pick up some heat but it is not too over the top.  I just cried little.  For me, this dish was good but certainly wouldn't make any of my top ten lists for chicken wings.

http://tinyurl.com/bzme2np

Overall, this is a fun and slightly adventurous dining experience.  There is a good energy to the place with lots of folks enjoying their food in a relatively cramped environment.  The food is good and trying some different things.  Most of it works but I am not sure any of it is truly mind-blowing.  It is worth a try and, for me, might be warrant a second visit.  It squeaked out four stars but that was with a little bit of a round up.
author: Mark D.

description:
Yeah....
Shitty increases with age. 
Stupid hipster Asian style food.
Just expire like the chicken you use in your dishes.
author: Mark B.

description:
If you want the types of food that are normally served at American Chinese restaurants (I.e. Orange chicken), this is probably not the place for you. Mission Chinese has more unique dishes, which probably plays a role in its popularity. When we got there (at around 6 pm on a Saturday), we were seated right away. However, by the time we left, there was a decent sized crowd waiting outside for tables. 

We got the tea smoked eel, Kung pao pastrami, salt cod fried rice, & strawberry coconut mochi. Of the 4 dishes, my favorite was the tea smoked eel. I also really liked the salt cod fried rice, & thought the Kung pao pastrami was pretty good too. 
However, I definitely did not enjoy the strawberry mochi. It tasted very coconuty & seemed abnormally dry for mochi. I couldn't get past the first bite.

Overall, I feel that the food was good, but slightly overrated.
author: Cici A.

description:
This is another example of an overhyped SF restaurant. Ordered about 11 dishes to make sure I tried everything and was VERY disappointed with everything.

The food is over salted and lacks much flavor and, for the spicy dishes, spice. 

I would not recommend this restaurant.

Only visit this place if you want to see what the hype is about, just make sure you don't spend much or wait more than a few minutes for a table.
author: Alvaro L.

description:
After working over 12 hours today all I wanted was some good grub when i got home. I waited a whole two hours to get my order and felt like they forgot about me entirely. So I called to ask about my order. It took the women on the phone many many minutes to tell me it was "on the way" which led me to believe that perhaps she had list my order entirely and was just trying to pacify me while putting my order in.

I told her I wanted a refund and you know what? She hung up on me! I can't believe it. I didn't curse or raise my voice. She plain hung up on me. When I called back she interrupted me and told me my order was "5 minutes away" but I insisted on a refund and a cancelation. She wouldn't give it to me. LUCKILY Grub Hub have me a refund no problem.

I've never ordered from Mission Chinese before and obviously I never will again. I've never experienced such rudeness. 

For anyone craving Chinese delivery, please try Nan King Road Bistro on 9th. They are always prompt and the food is always hot and delicious.
author: L B.

description:
My friends and I went to Mission because SO was closed the week we were in SF. Little did we know what we were in for.

As others have mentioned, this is not your typical Chinese restaurant. The owner just took Chinese food and did his own thing with it. I have no problems with that. We also didn't mind that most of the dishes we ordered were so spicy. But it seemed that all of the spicy dishes had the same overall taste; a little more variety in the flavors would have been nice.

Having said that, our favorites dishes of the night were the Thrice Cooked Bacon (great combination of texture from the bacon and rice cakes, though the bacon could have been thicker), Sizzling Cumin Lamb (though a bit overcooked), and the Salt Cod Fried Rice (which we ordered three of to neutralize the spiciness from all the other dishes). The "Explosive" Chicken Wings were pretty good too, but compared to the other spicy dishes, this was actually quite tame, so don't be too intimidated by all peppers that cover the wings.

The Ma Po Tofu, Stir-fried Sweet Peas, and General Tso's Veal Rib were all decent, but again, the redundant spices just made the overall experience a bit uninteresting. If you're in the mood to try something different, come by here. And expect a long wait, especially if you have a large group.
author: Ken K.

description:
Like to bump your head to old school hip hop while you eat out-of-the-box Szechuan food? Well jump your monkey into your scraper and gas break dip all the way too Mission Chinese Food located in the Mission! (duh)

Before I write reviews, I always browse for others. Especially those that gave restaurants 1-2 stars that I think deserves the contrary. I read them, just to live through a different experience. Why? Just because my experience was great, doesn't mean others resulted in the same outcome. Just like buying a shoe or a car. My hybrid may be great for me, but for those that have large families, a van or suv may be the better choice. 

BUTTTTT I digress.

I don't know what to tell ya'll. I effin love this place. Yes I'm a hip hop head, Yes I'm a "foodie". Yes I do cuff my jeans. But I swear to you all, there were no predisposition when writing this review. The food was simply amazing. Not only that, it was very eye-opening. I'm a great cook, so when I decide to invest my time, money, and effort into going out for a nice meal; I want new experiences and sensations. Mission Chinese Food delivers in both accounts. 

First off, there is a wait. But you know what, I kind of like that better than reservations. I'm really spontaneous and not very good at making far out plans. Hence, If i did ever decide to eat a Michelin star restaurant I probably won't have the patience or memory to make a reservation half a year in advance and remember to show up to it. I rather come at 10pm when the place is closing down and try to sneak in a service. 

But anyways, I digress again.I came here on a Saturday night with a group of 5 and waited about 30 minutes for a table. Not bad. We sat in the back table which is boss. Yes, I said "boss". We ordered the pig jowl, veal ribs, beef brisket and chinese broccoli, Mongolian string beans, squid ink noodles, and the chicken wings. All so good! And now to review our winners:!:!:

Most creative dish: Pig Jowl.
Most delicious dish: Sweet and Sour Veal Ribs.
Most weird (and my friend weird is good): Squid Ink Noodles with Yogurt and Lamb.
Most Addicting: Wings with Crispy Tripe.
Most Spicy: Mongolian String Beans.
Best Twist on a Classic: Beef Brisket and Chinese Broccoli.

I like this place. If I haven't made it clear already. I love the ambiance, the Chinese Dragon on the ceiling, the awesome staff. They even gave my friends and i free shots of Sake for celebrating a birthday. 

So the word on the street is: Mission Chinese Food is good and good for you! Or some ish like that.
author: Tung T.

description: it's good food, not traditional which is ok but I don't know about the long wait. You can make reservations so I highly recommend you do this...the mapo tofu dish, ease up on the sichuan peppers or at least make sure to tell people how much goes into this. I LOVE SPICY but i don't enjoy numbing food that aren't spicy.
author: Claire K.

description: Some of the most innovative fusion stuff I've ever seen.  Super weird fun atmosphere.  Had the Kung pao pastrami which was excellent.  And a beef short rib something or other that was the special of the day that was also fantastic.  Upbeat festive atmosphere, wish I could have eaten here a couple more times on my trip.
author: Ben B.

description:
Love the story, and loved the food.

Off the very intriguing menu, we tried the mapo tofu and the kung pao pastrami. Both were spicy as F*CK and my girlfren and I are both natural-born Chinese spicy eaters. Super duper flavorful (maybe too salty for some)... you'll need lots of rice for these dishes. Will definitely come back to try others. It was pretty WHOA-inspiring food so we were stuffed finishing maybe half of it, which meant leftovers for another spicy meal! 

No wait on weekday for lunch, which was a lovely surprise. Hipster front-of-house and Chinese kitchen. Takes credit!

PS when I walked through the kitchen to the restroom in the back, I saw signs posted that said "Do not ask anyone in this room questions." I wonder what prompted that.
author: Vivian H.

description: Came here with an out of town friend of both of us really liked it.  It's a good twist on traditional themes.  I also like the communal seating area in the center.  There you sacrifice some privacy to get a seat right away!
author: Hyek H.

description:
I was drunk from all the beer I consumed while my party was waiting outside so I apologize if the details are a bit blurry. 

I'm Chinese from China so I'm typically not a fan of trendy Chinese restaurants.  $70 including tax and tip for 5 dishes is pretty pricey for real Chinese food but it's considered cheap when you're talking to a bunch of hipsters.

Anyway, we had the Spicy Chicken Wings (best part of the meal), Salt Cod Fried Rice (could have used more cod), Catfish Soup (don't remember much except that it was difficult to scoop into bowls with the ladle they provided), Sizzling Cumin Lamb (bf liked it more than I did), and some veggie dish that was awesome.   

Would I go again? Probably not. But then again, I don't go back to most restaurants.
author: Yi Z.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!!!  I know there is a line but it is TOTALLY worth the wait!
The wait for us took about an 1 hour on St. Paddy's day during prime dinner hour (not smart on my part).  They do not take any reservations.  It's a very small restaurant. 

Love the decor of this divey little restaurant.  Very dim red lighting and played some really awesome pandora rap/hip-hop music.  Felt like I was in a club.  I guess I was in a good mode cause I was really feelin' the music!

Dinner (best to do family style):
-Salty cod fried rice - made the 7X7 list.  This is a must!  This is a good balance for all the crazy spicy food you're about to eat!  I love this dish.  Nice and light and perfect amount of salt.  They made it right (real Chinese way!)

-Braised Pork Belly - OMG so tender with a crunchy surface!  Delightful! (only came with 4 pieces) just beautiful! (MUST ORDER!)

-Thrice cooked bacon - HOT bacon with RIce cakes!  Amazing flavors and good amount of spice! (all I saw was red peppers! yum!) (must get!)

-Kung Pao Pastrami - This was good too but you can skip it.  I like the other spice dishes better than this one.

-Mongolian String Beans - I guess we should get a vegetable. DAMN THIS WAS GOOD TOO!  Large portion.  Perfect for all the spicy pork you will be eating. Great flavors! Love the way it was prepared.  Cooked just right with a perfect crunch!

-BEST FOR LAST... MAPO TOFU! -Damn this was HOT!  So good but so Spicy!  My eye balls was sweating!  This goes perfectly over white rice.  

Warning: you will sweat a lot at this place.  The food was so spicy and so enjoyable that I felt I lost water wait eating these dishes.  Multiple times my friends ask for more water, tea, rice and napkins!  Thank goodness for the awesome service.  I guess the waitress knew we would need  those things cause the food is extremely spicy.    Though the food is spicy its not too much to the point where you won't be able to enjoy it.  Trust me you will love every bit.

Huge fan!! Can't wait to come back again!
author: Ying F.

description:
For many of us, Mission Chinese Food is one of those places you have to try at least once. It's got a long history of being a neighborhood staple that's popular amongst locals. However, it seems to be another example of a place overrun by long lines of hipsters.

After a long wait for a table, we finally managed to get seated in the super cramped, dimly lit, dining room. We shared a few dishes including the salted cod fried rice, beef noodle soup, thrice cooked bacon, stir fried mung beans, Hainanese chicken rice, and their sea urchin custard. The fried rice and chicken rice were really uninspiring and a bit boring. The bacon and mung beans were so spicy that they were nearly inedible. Every bite was like eating fire! The bacon itself was nicely done, although I'm not sure why it had to be cooked three times. I bit into the single piece of bitter melon in the bacon too, which was pretty much raw and killed my palette after that. The sea urchin custard was an interesting concoction but ultimately wasn't special enough or delicious enough to make the meal overly memorable. The high point of the meal was the beef soup, which was served with crepe noodles instead of egg or wide rice noodles. Definitely a pleasant surprise.

All in all, I was seriously disappointed by the famous Mission Chinese Food. Prices aren't insane and I will grant that food quality was much better than at most Chinese restaurants, but otherwise it didn't live up to the hipster hype. I got a pretty good sampling of their menu items and wouldn't bother waiting in line for this again. When in the Mission, stick with the Mexican food!

Food: 5/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description: I've heard that there's a perpetual line out the door here - and I see why. The food at Mission Chinese is hardly traditional fare, but that's what makes it epic. The prosciutto dish is amazing and the vinegar peanuts add a pop of flavor between dishes. They serve sake which is a bit confusing to see at a Chinese restaurant, but it worked. We seated a group of seven on a Sunday night so that seems to be the time to go.
author: Irina P.

description: Loved everything from the environment, to the tasty unique dishes! And the Peanuts!!!  Omg!! So good! How does this place not have 5 stars!
author: Ashley S.

description:
This is a much overdue review -- we've been going there every weekend when we are in town. And, it never fails us. We miss it when we are out of town. It's innovative without losing authenticity. I am Chinese ethnic and me and my Taiwanese friend from New York City think this is *the best* Ma Po Tofu we ever ate in the world. 

Here is the list of our favorites: 
1. smashed cucumbers (it took us a long time to figure out the dressing... so fragrant; garnished with subtle red peppers), 
2. braised pea leaves (love the green, love the garlic, love the tofu -- or thin-sliced vegetarian fish-cakes; love the peppers; love the soup); 
3. Ma Po Tofu -- the best I've ever had: spicy (real Sichuan huajiao or flower-pepper) yet tasty; non-oily yet authentic (we usually get the one without pork)
4. Relatively new on the menu: banquet chicken -- definitely get it if it's available. A true delight.

Oh, I must write about the deco: It's funky, or, kitsch: pink giant dragon over your head (like a dinosaur skeleton in the ceiling of a museum?), a portrait of the General Gao (a legend for American Chinese food?!) guarding over the kitchen door, planked by two sidewalls of kitschy paintings of "the" Chinese cultural icons. If you get a chance, try visit their bathroom in the back. There is nothing special about the bathroom. What's special is the journey through the kitchen on your way to the bathroom: You walk out of the dark dinning room of an Anglo-American setting filled with mostly non-Chinese hipster customers and staff, and find yourself in a totally Chinese working environment -- Asian staff and Chinese characters on the cardboard boxes, and even Chinese music (I think I heard it once). A clash of the world?

The best way to describe the atmosphere is that it's like being in the early movies of Wong Kar-wai, for example, Chungking Express, when Wong was still the most talented. With this said, not everyone likes early Wong Kar-wai. So better warn your prissy friends about the adventure before you go.
author: Julia H.

description:
Sorry, hype or not, this is not good food, Chinese, Japanese or American Knees. I hardly ever crave Chinese food the way I crave other foods, so I had low expectations and hype was not a factor for me.  It might be for you. I do believe good food is good food, even if you want to question it's authenticity.  Likewise, something can be authentic and taste shitty... and be authentically shitty.

I feel like they take essentially traditional Chinese dishes and add some French words--not ingredients--in there; e.g., escolar "confit" for the salt cod fried rice, "mirepoix" in the beef brisket noodle soup.  Don't be mistaken - this isn't Asian fusion.  They're just applying French terms here at Mission La Cuisine Chinoise. ...See what I did there?

While the flavors are primarily Szechuan, you can play a good game of "What Doesn't Belong?" with their menu.  The menu changes, but based on the one currently online, here are some of the answers: sea urchin, eel, cumin, and cardamom.  

Everything was a combination of oily, salty, spicy, or sour, or all of the above.  If that sounds good to you, this is your spot!  

Their website is full of warning signs. Their logo is a rickshaw and there is a ninja delivering a flying kick across the middle of the page. That ninja kicked me in the face and flew away.  IT IS TAUNTING ME.

When it comes down to it, what MCF has taught me is that if I didn't hear about a Chinese place from a fobby relative, I should expect my meal to be an expensive version of Panda Express.  I'm kidding.  That's not fair to Panda Express.

What I can say is that food comes fast.  The six of us ordered a ton of things, and I can't remember them all.  Here's the breakdown, starting with the good stuff:

26) SMOKED BEEF BRISKET SOUP NOODLES - $12
CHEUNG FUN, MIRE POIX,BOK CHOY, CARDAMOM BROTH

Hands down the best dish of the night.  This was actually good and using cheung fun as the noodle was interesting.  I would love if they used hand cut noodle instead.  It couldn't quite redeem the experience, but if I had eaten only this dish, I would've come back for other dishes with high expectations.  It tastes like the pan-fried noodle soup at Turtle Tower (#6 Ph Bò Áp Cho Nc) and Taiwanese beef noodle soup (niu ro mien) had a baby.  And that Taiwanese Vietnamese baby is MCF's smoked brisket soup noodles.  This is the only dish I'd come back for.  


XX) PORK BELLY - $XX

This isn't on the website, so I don't have the exact menu info.  We had their pork belly with pineapple and cucumber.  It was pretty good but way too fatty.  One of the pieces of pork belly was pure fat, zero meat.  That's a ripoff.  And gross. 


XX) SHORT RIBS - $XX

This was okay; a few folks at the table complained that it was fatty, but my piece was tender off the bone and decent.


21)    SHANGHAINESE CHOW MEIN - $12
PULLED PORK TROTTER, ROCK SHRIMP, PICKLED MUSTARD GREENS, NAPA CABBAGE

This was one of the better dishes of the evening, and I feel like all it did was taste like chow mein from a decent Chinese restaurant.  Umm, good job?


22) SALT COD FRIED RICE - $10
ESCOLAR CONFIT,CHINESE SAUSAGE, EGG,SCALLION

This one, I have mixed feelings about.  While the pieces of cod were larger than the traditional dish (a nice change), there was nary a Chinese sausage to be found in the fried rice.  Perhaps they forgot about it.  I don't have a problem with that.  But I ate a lot of salt cod and chicken fried rice growing up.  That was the dish I would order.  It's supposed to be small pieces of cod with pieces of chicken (in this case, sausage).  On its own... it seemed lacking.  This was also one of the better dishes... and this was just just average.


16)   MA PO TOFU - $11
GROUND KUROBUTA PORK SHOULDER,SZECHUAN PEPPERCORN, CHILl OIL, STEAMED RICE

Too spicy and pretty sour.  Not much to say about this dish, because I don't really eat this one often. Enough to have had better. 


23) SIZZLING CUMIN LAMB - $13
SALT & PEPPERED LAMB BELLY, CHILl-PICKLED LONG BEANS

I ate this just because it had been ordered by our group.  The whole restaurant smells like this dish so it must be popular.  Cumin also smells that strong.

STEAMED RICE

Dry as the desert.  It tasted like day old rice, which is perfect for fried rice but not so great for steamed rice.


CHICKEN WINGS
