Straight inedible. So, so salty. Many of us left this after one bite.
author: Erika C.

description:
It was belated galentine's celebration with my gal pals. We wanted to pre game at my friend's house with some vino and Mission Chinese. Thank goodness they delivered to the inner Richmond, though they said if she had lived just a few blocks out, they wouldn't have delivered.

A Friday in Lent called for many seafood dishes and only one that was allowed to have meat: the rock cod fried rice which was adorned with slices of chinese sausage. I begrudgingly set those morsels aside on my plate while I enjoyed the fried rice. Another favorite was the Mongolian long beans. I'm a big fan of mouth burning heat and this was right up my alley. The beans were perfectly sautéed in chili goodness. I ate the little slices of green chili like they were prizes. While I reveled in the delicious, hurts-so-good heat, my counterparts were in agony from the whooshing sounds coming their way - failed attempts in trying to cool their scorched palates.

Another favorite of mine was the shanghainese chow mein. Noooooodles! Big fat noodles that were chewy and absorbed all the yummy sauce filled with notes of shrimp. Loved the mustard greens and and napa cabbage.

I didn't really care for tiger salad. I didn't taste roasted seaweed. What I did taste was mocked Fresh Express mixed greens salad with raddichio added wrapped in rice paper. The chili sauce was mostly chili oil with absolutely no punch. 

Overall, a belly rubbing, satisfying dinner night in. We didn't end up going out that night. But instead, watched our favorite episodes of Glee on netflix with the food within reach. Once midnight passed, I ate those chinese sausage I saved on my plate. Delish.
author: Grace L.

description:
Despite having had two bad experiences with delivery, we LOVE Mission Chinese Food! 

Today was our fourth time getting takeout. My husband and I love spicy food so this Szechuan style is right up our alley. 

Our first time getting takeout we got the mouth watering wings (they were alright, but we prefer the chicken wings from SO), mongolian long beans, thrice cooked bacon $12, kung pao pastrami $12 and salt cod fried rice $12. We decided to ditch the beans and wings and now stick to the last three items I listed. 

If you think this is pricey Chinese food then go enjoy Panda Express - you won't find these dishes anywhere else. They're consistent with quantity, quality and flavor. 

There's a $4 delivery fee for takeout and you can order online. It usually takes 1hr for delivery so order early and be patient. It's worth the wait 
;-)...
author: Marlene C.

description:
I got take-out because my bf was supposed to pick me up from the gym but he got off work late.  I have been meaning to try this place ever since they won the James Beard award, but every time I came by, it was closed.  So was totally excited that I was in the neighborhood and came by.   

Very salty, unauthentic Chinese food.  Eh.
author: C L.

description:
Kung pào pastrami, way too salty, should have bought rice. For $14.14, unappetizing.
Don't order this.
author: Michael L.

description: Four stars for the food and two stars for the service.  It's great that they're in NYC now but too bad they are starting to slack off a little in SF.
author: Patrick H.

description:
This place is an odd combination of food and ambiance types but definitely worth it.

The outside looks like any other hole in the wall Chinese restaurant but step inside and it's completely different. It can get crowded so you may need to share a table. Seems like making a reservation is the way to go if you are pressed for time. We had a 15 minute wait (not bad).

Inside there are some Chinese themed pictures (that kind of look like they date back to the Republic days) but other than that it's unlike any Chinese restaurant I've ever been too. It's a little dark but you get used to it. More unusual is the music. Everything from Bowie to Rap. And it's kind of loud, so you may need to shout a little to be heard. Average customer age would seem to be 22.

The food is really good. We had the Mongolian long beans and the Blue Cod fried rice. Both very good, although the beans were a little salty for our palate. Total cost including a beer was just over $30.
author: Andrew F.

description:
What in the world did I just eat? 

Called in to place an order and took 20 min. as promised. If you call in you HAVE to remember the last 4 digits of the number that called to place the order. Chances are that the person who called in isn't the person who is picking it up, so don't face disappointment when you drive over here and not have the last four digits like the person behind me in line.

Anyways, on to the food. 
MA PO TOFU: I'm not sure if it's just an experiment with Chinese food gone wrong, but I felt I was literally eating tofu cooked in chili oil. There was almost no meat, and hardly any flavor. Probably the worst dish we got.

TEA-SMOKED EEL: Light and flavorful. Eel had a touch of sweetness and the celery gave it a fresh flavor, although the amount of celery was a little excessive. Both interesting and unique with a fun play on textures. Great w/ soy sauce, just wished the celery flavor didn't overpower the dish.

THRICE COOKED BACON: The name is a little misleading. It's basically just spicy rice cakes. You get a lot of rice cakes and a very VERY minimal amount of bacon. However, I did enjoy the tofu skin which was sweet-savory, and the addition of bittermelon slices.

Honestly, I would not recommend and would not be back. The ideas for these dishes are fun and interesting, but the execution needs more work.
author: Veronica L.

description:
The Dragon looms once again over these 2 1/2 men (That's how much we ordered tonight!, enough for-)  Instant seating and ordering, once we got menus @ 6:15 p.m.  Instant water.  Gluttony, thy name is Mission Chinese Food.

We hit pay dirt this time-  miraculously ON the menu tonight (not on our maiden voyage a couple of months ago), the long-yearned for Slow-cooked Pork Belly, 
   hint of 5-spice after the initial gentle warm crunch, Asian pineapple garni; and 

rounding back to our favorite Col. Tso's Veal Rib, a bonus rib this time & gobs of mature onion-leeks AND chili oil- Shall I carve?  

-and, another hitherto unlisted item, the Black Bean Dry fried Clams, dotted with sliced green seeded jalapeño ringettes, with chili oil.  
       
But the TRUE Extreme Picante is the undisputed (guaranteed 7-minute 9-alarm burn*) M. Po DoeFu!, an arrogant slick of bright clear orange sealing its surface.
  Overly abundant, as were the veal and clams.  

*So much so, only AFTER the 7 minute sensation subsided could we taste the great mélange of flavors of the Shanghai Noodles (with extra flair found in no others'). 

We did our worst but still had 5 little boxes of succulent treasures to take home.  barely lifting our goodie bag off the table, deft speedy hands cleared 5 tables for the 7 shivering PACKS at bay on the sidewalk without.  Casual, Classy, Divey, Trendy, but wolf packs just the same.  Coowl.

Service, again, fast friendly accommodating unerring to a fault.
Remember not to order rice becoz it comes free.  No extra charge for the ROCK.

This SURPASSED our first experience.  A+++

Photos by Robert!
author: Clifford L.

description:
Aside from this place being kind of dark, creepy and crowded, the food was fantastic. I'd been wanting to come here for years and finally got the chance! We ordered 5 things - the porridge, the beef chow mein, the pork jowl, the 3x cooked bacon, and the string beans. EVERYTHING WAS DIVINE. And spicy! The spice took me by surprise. I loved the variety of food we got. Prices are decent and music is trendy. What's not to love? 

The 3x cooked bacon had what I believe was bittermelon in it.  A bit shocking to the taste buds. 

The porridge had huge pieces of crab. Amazing.

The beef chow mein was spicy, tasty, well made.

The pork jowl had chicarones and baby carrots with the stalks on them. Amazing.

The green beans were flavored wonderfully and a nice healthy item on our otherwise fatty assortment.

Definitely recommend, not for a fancy night, but for a tasty and satisfying night.
author: Lydia W.

description:
So I'm not sure I love this place as much as I've heard everyone else seems to.  Unless you want really spicy, fried food, there aren't a lot of options on the menu.   I had their egg custard which was actually really good - the waiter was great about making sure I understood that you really have to be excited about the other ingredients - there's a big helping of Japanese style raw sea urchin and fish roe - or else I wouldn't enjoy it.  Luckily I love sushi so I appreciated the dish - but it's a bit funny that it's not even Chinese. 

I also ordered the noodles with mushrooms and my friend ordered the cumin lamb (whoa that was pungent).  My dish was really salty and oily (typical Szechuan) and I wasn't a big fan.  The restaurant is pretty divey, service is good, we didn't have to wait (maybe because it was lunch), but I don't think I'll be rushing back soon.  (FYI You're looking for Lung Shan, not a sign that says Mission Chinese Food).
author: Vivian W.

description:
The Kung Pao Pastrami is a roller coaster of flavor, the pickled peanuts bring everything into harmony.  The pastrami is smoky and succulent, the vegetables are crisp and the chili hot.  The pickled peanuts bring crunch and balance to the dish.
The tea smoked eel roll was also very good. So much texture and flavor.
Call ahead as there was a short wait even on a Tuesday night.  Well worth it!  I can't say enough on how excellent the food was.
Staff was very friendly and the prices are reasonable.
author: Michael S.

description:
There is definitely a "novelty" aspect to this place:  lighting, table arrangement, decor, menu, all pretty much in line with what you would expect in the new Mission.

The menu has interesting dishes on it and we had a few good choices and a few so-so others.
- Tiki Pork belly: meat was plain dry; nicely flavored but dry.
- ChongQing chicken wigs: fried chicken wings with seasonings. I was attracted by the "Explosive Chili" comment next to it.  They were not particularly hot/spicy. Certainly not explosive.  There was an unusual after taste that left me wondering whether it was MSG or some other flavoring that had been generously added to it.
- Stir fried pork Jowl was good.  Adding shrimp flavored rice chips did nothing for the dish which was good all by itself.
- Lamb ribs were ok
- Mongolian long beans were very nice

Glad we went, just not sure I was dazzled enough to return.
For those sensitive to MSG, be sure to ask, I suspect they might be using it generously (judging by how I felt after dinner....)
author: Philippe F.

description: Sorry to everyone that loves this place. I heard so many good things from coworkers about this place. It seriously looks like an authentic Chinese restaurant from the outside, but surprise! I don't even know what kind of food they serve here. It was also super dark which didn't help. They've got all sorts of hippie ingredients they use here that I had to employ Google search to deconstruct the menu. If you REALLY want fusion Chinese food, then maybe this is the right place for you. It's an interesting experience, but unfortunately the food was just OK.
author: Charles L.

description:
Sort of pop-up place....at least that's how it started and they cling to the idea. 

Food:
Pretty good menu, interesting options that you won't find at a lot of chinese places. Dishes are uniformly good, although tends to be a bit overseasoned for my taste, but I'm somewhat sensitive to salt. Last time I went there they were in the process of cheaping out on the menu though, because I noticed a lot of the more expensive ingredient dishes were no longer on the menu.

Side note that doesn't affect the food or experience but makes me shun this place:
Once the owner opened his restaurant in New York, he lost little time pooping all over San Francisco. Can't remember where the interview was printed but it immediately made me not want to go.
author: Bernard F.

description:
I recently came here after reading about the vegan Thrice-cooked bacon in 7x7's article "50 Vegetarian (or Vegan*) Things to Eat Before You Die" http://www.7x7.com/the-big-veg

The first thing we noticed was the white dude walking around in a bandana looking like Ralph Macchio. Wasn't sure what to make of that one. Looking at the menu, there are certainly some interesting options you won't find at any other restaurant. There's only a few vegan options on the menu although they all look tasty. The vegan thrice-cooked bacon didn't disappoint. Although the "bacon" in this case tasted a bit like the yummy tofu wrapper of Inari sushi. Very spicy with a unique sauce. It was delicious although I could do without the bitter melon. 

Not badly priced for dinner, I just wish there was a cheaper lunch option. I think under $10 is the sweet spot for lunch. I wouldn't mind returning to this place for dinner sometime.
author: John B.

description:
BF had heard & read good things about Mission Chinese Food. Saturday night, we put our name on the list, rode around with the rest of the Niner fans, came back 1.5 hours later & our table was ready.

I quickly scanned the menu & between chicken hearts, sea urchin & oxtail, I could not find a single thing that sounded appetizing to me. (Surprise, surprise: I'm the opposite of a foodie.) I left the ordering to the BF.

He picked:
- pork belly: heart attack on a plate. bf likes pork belly but even he thought it was ridiculously fatty. i tried a piece of the crispy, fried end (not at all fatty & pretty salty.) Because I'm opposed to eating obvious chunks of animal fat, I don't see the allure in this dish. I did love the marinated pineapple...spicy & tart!
- chicken wings: sat under what looked like 100 chili peppers. Meat was quite dry, flavor was what you would expect--spicy, peppery. Meh.
- REAL Coke in a bottle
Total: $21 no including tip

I appreciate that MCF is trying to do something different & that they donate $.75 from each entree to the SF Food Bank. The hostess & our waitresses were super cool, very friendly. I loved the dim lights & the huge, orange dragon that snaked the entire ceiling. Loud-ass rap blasted through the place. Total hole-in-the-wall. I can see why people flock here; it's so unlike any other Chinese restaurant anyone's been to. The food just ain't my steelo.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
We had read somewhere that the place didn't open until 5:30 p.m. but happened to get there before 5.  Luckily we did, because we found out they open at 5 p.m. for dinner.  There were already a few parties who signed up ahead of us, so we signed in the clipboard and hung around.  By the time 5 p.m. had rolled around, a larger crowd had gathered, but we were seated right away.  By the time we were halfway done with our meal, the place was packed and more people were waiting outside.  Crazy SF!

Our orders were also taken right away.  I liked that they gave everyone a bottle of water - after we got our entrees, I saw why.  We just got two items, and both were SOOO SPICY!  Both my friend and I do not handle spicy well, so we were downing cups and cups of water.  By the time we were there 20 minutes, we had gone through the entire bottle of water and needed another one!  We got the Pork Belly (Trice Cooked Bacon), which was dripping in chili oil.  Actually, so was the Mongolian Long Beans we ordered.  Dishes were cheap - about $10 each - and a good size.  The pork was a bit fatty, which is how pork belly is, but it was on the soggy side.  I loved the tofu skin that was part of the dish - they were surprisingly sweet like the outside of Inari sushi.  Too bad the dish was just too spicy!  The beans were also hot - possibly even spicier than the pork as it had two dragon signs.  We ended up leaving most of this untouched.  It was hard to taste any other flavor other than chili oil in both dishes.

Service was fine, and I like that they donate $.75 of each entree to the SF Food Bank, but the food was just too darn spicy for our liking.  Luckily, Bi-Rite was within walking distance, so we ended up cooling off with some good ice cream.
author: Caroline K.

description: My previous 2-star review was more on that if I'd go back.  Giving 3 stars for the food. There are so many Chinese (and sub categories) restaurants around Bay Area that may not be vey creative but do use good ingredients and carry good techniques. Missing Chinese can still improve.
author: Meilan O.

description:
Given all the hype around Mission Chinese Food, I was really looking forward to trying it but could never bear the lines and wait at this hot spot. I was pleasantly surprised late one evening at work that we had ordered delivery from them. 

Now I didn't expect complete authenticity; especially since it's a place white friends rave to me as having really authentic Chinese food. It's the equivalent of me telling you that the McChicken here tastes just as good as the ones I had at McDonalds in Asia. It's a hipster take on Chinese food with a mishmash of styles from the different regions. 

The salt cod fried rice was a standout. It's a staple dish that I like at many Chinese eateries but Mission elevates it with the addition of sweet Chinese sausage. The rice cakes in the thrice cooked bacon reminded me of a dish my grandma used to make only saltier. Still, it was a nice nostalgic trip for me.

I thought the mapo tofu was a little too heavy handed on the chili oil and light on the preserved black beans. Still tasty though albeit spicy. The gai lan with beef cheek is a nice play on beef and broccoli. Taste about the same but I like gai lan more so points there. 

We had a couple of other dishes too but I didn't really remember them much. One observation after the meal was that I was absolutely parched. You need water for this heavy meal. Still it's decent. More authentic than neon-colored-sauce-over-fried-meats Chinese food for sure, but still a tad modified. Mission Chinese Food is little over-hyped, but still decent.
author: Jon L.

description:
I immediately think of the Public Enemy phrase "Don't believe the hype!"

So, I had seen Mission Chinese written about multiple times in multiple sources. The last time I read about it was when GQ named it one of Americas top ten new restaurants in an issue two months back.
Having the day to myself and lots of anticipation, I decided to go check it out. 

First impression, hole in the wall spot. Ok cool, I've been to many and lots of the time they're great!

Second impression, the menu...really...Asian food in SF and not ONE vegetarian dish?! Only three that could be "made vegetarian".  From there on I was pretty disappointed. Nonetheless still waited for the food to assess what they made. 

We ordered peanuts in a vinegar. They came covered with about 6 unbeatably large cloves of raw(maybe pickled) garlic. Passsss.

Then came a dish called Thrice Cooked Bacon(one of the three dishes they could make vegetarian, odd right?).  It was ok, but nothing to write home about.  

Lastly was a "dish" that came out more like a soup which incorporated tofu, pumpkin, and a green.  

Aside from the food, expect a decent amount of wait time.  It's not the kind of place that screams romance, or even intimate private conversations being that the tables are painfully close and you have to even share tables.  It varies from moderate to noisy as they play indie rock relatively loudly.  

Overall, I've had MUCH better food with MUCH more vegetarian options and they didn't have to be listed in a magazine.  I suppose if you want a twist on Chinese food with hipster college aged waiters while you listen to the strokes, this is it.
author: Sean M.

description:
Although this took quite some time to find because there are no signs that actually make it noticable on the street. You have to really know where you're going and recognize the big yellow sign above Mission Chinese.

Dining was one other gal and myself. We got there just after 6:30 pm on a Sunday and were lucky enough to grab a table instantly. We like the blonde server, he wasn't as rude as the other pretentious, city, hipster kids working as servers there. ( I will elaborate in a moment).

My friend is a vegetarian and we ordered the spicy tofu with a schezuan sauce, the pickled peanuts, the rice noodles with peanut sauce, and I ordered the beef chow mein. 

Everything was delicious, but the moment we tasted the appetizer of rice noodles and peanut sauce, we were carried away by the momentous and simple flavor perfection. This was definitely worth the servers being pushy and trying to get us out of the way.... which I refused.

The spicy beef chowmein was also fantastic, as was the tofu. We actually poured the tofu sauce on top of everything else and it created chinese food heaven. 

My biggest outrage was how rude and pretentious the servers were. Look it's a wonderful restaurant, amazing food, but it's in hell hole with stained walls, raggedy chairs and wobbly tables. This isn't a five star - white table cloth establishment. The next time I eat there and a server puts his hands all over the MOUTH of my bottle of coke and tries to take it from me in a pushy and unwanted atempt to get me out of the way to make room for more customers before I've finished by drink and dining experience, I will rip his fingers off. True story. I've never been treated like that ANYWHERE from a $200 meal to a $2 McDonald's burger. 

Your food is amazing and my life wont be complete until I can mimic the peanut sauce for myself at home.....but your servers leave a lot to be desired. Perhaps some HOSPITALITY training? Hmm.,,? If it were my restaurant and a server did that to a customer that came 2 hours to eat there as part of a weekend eating experience, I'd fire them in an absolute heartbeat. True Story.

I would give five stars if the hispter gent in the dirty hat hadn't fingered my coke bottle. But I guess everyone has to get their kicks somewhere.
author: Katherine H.

description:
(See pics) Updated review. More of 4 stars because Danny is leaving for NYC and will be rotating the chef there. Also came here because my friend hasn't tried it before. As the restaurant is always presented that this is Americanized Chinese food. It has traces of spices and influence of the spiciness, but it also uses pickled chilies in some dishes while the bigger hotter chilies in others. Most dishes are milder hot comparing with authentic SzeChuan sweating spiciness.

The tea smoked eel salad this time tasted had bigger chunks of eel and the fish was less smoked. Still good fresh taste.

Sizzling lamb cumin is always my favorite and continued to make me happy. Beef tongue (not a lot of it) with daikon (lots and lots) in soup was good and light. Salt cod rice with some Chinese sausage was also good.

Service was pretty good and efficient as usual.
author: T L.

description: This place is so cool. It's my boyfriends fav or close second fav spot in the city. In the mission, close to Bart. Unassuming. Hole in the wall with Chinese New Year style dragon hanging all over the ceiling and deep red lights. We call in the inferno sometimes. Spicy food! Not everything is spicy but if you think it might be spicy, it's spicier than that. Soooo Good. Thrice cooked bacon, wings, pastrami, and salted cod fried rice are the only items you need. And sake and beer to cool the burn. You're welcome.
author: Heather M.

description:
This is some of the best Chinese food around. If the food wasn't so good, I probably wouldn't come here though, because the place is kind of dirty and the last time I went the customer service was less than satisfactory.

I had been waiting for about 10 minutes, having put my name on the list, when a group of 4 walked up and immediately got seated. I asked the kid (wearing flannel and hair that looked like it had never seen shampoo or a brush) why I'm being skipped and his response was "We have plenty of room." 

Wrong answer bro. The correct response is "I'm sorry sir, I'll seat you right away." If you have a wait list, don't skip people. Work it in the correct order, it's a simple thing.

Douchy waitstaff aside, the food is super good.
author: Tyson H.

description:
Saw Mission Chinese on Unique Eats on the Cooking Channel and added it to my San Francisco places to visit list.  Was not disappointed.

I had the Tiki Pork belly which was sinfully good.  It was a little bit crispy on the outside and tender soft on the inside. It was a mixture of sweet and tangy pork, and soy nutty goodness.   The pork belly melts in your mouth.  This is a must have item and for me the best dish of the evening.
Wife had the Broccoli Beef Brisket with Smoked Oyster Sauce.  It was outstanding, large, and juicy.  It was so good; she didn't want to share her plate.  
We also tried the Salt Cod Fried Rice.  Most yelpers rave about it, but for me it was okay.  Maybe slightly on the bland side and left me wishing there was more Chinese sausage or pieces that weren't paper thin.  Maybe, I'll try it next time to make sure.  
I also ordered the Thrice Cooked bacon.  It was S-P-I-C-Y, delicious, and definitely unique in flavor with the bitter melon, tofu, bacon, and hot peppers.  It was unusually good.  

Our waitress was helpful in suggesting what items to order.  She was friendly, cute, and the service was excellent.  It seemed like all of the waitresses had tattoos, super friendly, and helpful.  

The restaurant is in a slightly seedy neighborhood with a couple of homeless people sprinkled here and there.  
The ambience inside the restaurant was hip with some type of cool rock music playing in the background.  The lighting was dim and the trip to the restroom with through the kitchen.  The cooks were working fast and not smiling.  That's fine with me because their food was delicious!  Overall, I definitely recommend Mission Chinese.  It's unique food that's worth the trip.  Plus, they deliver all over SF.
author: Vinh B.

description:
Items Selected:
Tea Smoked Eel Roll - Rice Noodle, Chinese Celery, Salted Plum Hoisin, Braised Pork, Cognac Soy
Salt Cod Fried Rice - Mackerel Confit, Chinese Sausage, Lettuce, Egg
3x Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes - Sweet Tofu Skin, Butter Melon, Szechuan Pepper

Thrice thwarted in my attempts to dine at Mission Chinese Food on previous visits to The Bay area but this time calling ahead to assure no unannounced vacations or leaks it was just after noon on a Thursday when I finally visited Danny Bowien's fabled concept within the confines of Lung Shan, the hype finally diminished with the chef now focused on conquering New York but the food, vibe, and décor more-or-less what I'd expected when I was turned away nearly three years prior.  Somewhere between ethnic and hipster with shabby-chic touches beneath a festive dragon and garbled punk playing a bit too loudly it was towards the front of the restaurant that I requested to be sat and with a brief perusal of the menu my order was set - a mere twelve minutes from seating to the arrival of three plates from a service staff pleasant, though perfunctory at best.  Obviously focusing on the classics for my first bites of Bowien's cuisine it was with the "3x Cooked Bacon" that my tasting began and with a notable burn on my lips even as I avoided the whole Szechuan peppers the dish certainly shined - the pork's saline sapor juxtaposing bitter melon as discs of rice cake soaked up an elixir of fat, aromatics, and heat.  Moving next to salt cod, one of my favorite foods, served in the fashion of fried rice perhaps it was an effect of the dish that had preceded it or simply a case of inflated expectations but overall the whole plate tasted bland - a trend thankfully not carried over to the crunchy spring rolls who succeeded everywhere the rice had not as bold fish flavors played point/counterpoint with notes of smoke, saline, and sweet while raw vegetable added just enough texture to make the whole plate not only fresh, but also surprisingly light - something not exactly prominent elsewhere on the Mission Chinese menu.
author: Michael U.

description:
After all the hype over Mission Chinese I was very disappointed. It's like they take a lot of Chinese favorites and over season and over salt everything. 
We ordered:

Tea Smoked Eel - which was yummy - not $10 worth though

Tiki Pork Belly - yummy but I don't need to order it again

Mongolian Long Beans - so over spiced, they were hard to eat.

Tingly Lamb Face Noodle Soup - it tasted like chemicals, no one at our table wanted to eat it.

We had one other dish that I don't even remember because I didn't eat it either. It was unfortunately a disappointment.. maybe we ordered the wrong things but if you eat authentic Chinese food regularly you will probably agree with this review.
author: Carey T.

description:
Boy, is this place over-hyped or what?

The food isn't bad but it's not something to wait in line for. It's also pretty salty. I love salt but it was still a bit too much for me.

Don't expect to get authentic chinese here, it's their own take on chinese. That being said, I have to say I prefer the authentic stuff.

I think the only thing authentic about this place is the service because the service sucked. We had to wave someone down every time we needed something. They never checked on us in between. We even had to wave them down to take our order and to get our bill at the end. 

Not worth the 1.5 hour wait but you should try it at least once. Go during lunch, it's not as busy.
author: Andy W.

description:
exquisite flavors of the orient imbued with modern influences take your tastebuds on an endless journey

enjoy

kung pao pastrami
general tso's veal rib
trice cooked bacon and rice cakes
author: Ananya M.

description:
They have a heavy hand with spices, they make good vegetable dishes, and they're not afraid to serve strong flavors.  Basically, this is everything I want in a chinese restaurant.  Thrice-cooked bacon was delicious (I love sauteed rice cakes) but not at all what I was expecting.  Szechuan pickles and smashed garlic cucumbers were both extremely tasty, though each was almost too strongly flavored.  The eggplant appetizer was disappointing.  Basically, this is a great place to go with groups because then you can get a few bites of a bunch of strongly flavored things.  Subtlety is not a strong suit.

Also, while I don't normally like loudish music with my food-- they have a remarkably good soundtrack.
author: William B.

description: This place is a nightmare. Mediocre food with THE ABSOLUTE WORST SERVICE. I work in the service industry so I give everyone the benefit of the doubt. Our food was thrown at us along with our check. The attitude at this place for less than average food was bizarre. I recommend Wok Shop Cafe on sutter street over this gross establishment any day of the week. No idea what the hype is.
author: Kelly K.

description: What you probably know already: started as a pop-up at Lung Shan Restaurant, but has taken over entirely, complete with flashing lights, loud music, and hanging dragon dance dragon. Lines are not that long. It's not the most authentic Chinese food, but I like that the dishes use less pedestrian ingredients and introduces people to things like bitter melon and bonito. What I was not a fan of is how salty and oily the food is. What I like is that they are not shy with spice. The thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes, salt cod fried rice, and grandma's pork dumplings were delicious.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
THE place to go. Everything is almost perfect and the food is phenomenal!!

Every dish you can try here is perfectly done, really delicious: pork belly, cod rice, everything is fantastic. You're not gonna be disappointed. The food is terrific and cheap. Food-wise, I would give 6 stars if I could.

Keep this in mind:
- It can be outrageously spicy, ask the waitress if you don't eat spicy food because this can be really spicy. They have non spicy dishes and they are all great as well!
- Kind of dark at night, dim lights.
- The decoration inside this restaurant is so cheesy, lol.
- It can have long waiting time: you can also pick up, you can go after 9pm and you'll get a table right away or go for lunch.
author: Lucia C.

description: Great experience.  Don't listen to the nasayers.  Ribs, wings, and 3 x cooked bacon are all amazing.
author: Tom W.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 4
Service: 3

Came here for lunch with gf during a SF day trip. We arrived around 11:30am and were immediately seated.

1. Sizzling cumin lamb, 12
Salt and peppered lamb belly, chili-pickled long beans
~Pretty good. Somewhat spicy, even though it doesn't have a fire symbol.

2. Westlake rice porridge, 11
Hangar steak, rock shrimp, soy-cured egg, cilantro
~Pretty good. 

Service was disappointing, as I had to try numerous times to get our check.
author: David L.

description:
Love this place. Caveat is that i've burned off all of my taste buds from eating spicy food my entire life. Take this review with a grain of spice.

Delicious, semi-authentic, flavorful spicy szechuan dishes; hot, tall, beautiful servers; and they play 90's hip hop and r&b?! What is not to love about this place.

Mapo tofu - spicy, delicious. Soft tofu squares, hot spicy oil, ground pork, jalapenos, green onions, cilantro. Maybe a tad too salty, but still better than mapo tofu at Chili house.

Salt cod fried rice - big portion! Not too salty, but still flavorful.

Thrice cooked pork - yes, definitely get this. By the time you have this, you'll forget about why you hated bittermelon when you were 6. The bittermelon in this dish balances the rice cakes, the saltiness of the bacon, and all of the assorted spices and vegetables.

Lamb cumin - not spicy, but still tasty. A lot of onions. Meat almost falls off the bone.

Spicy chicken wings - very spicy, not that much meat, but tasty. Expensive for what it is though.

WILL COME BACK AGAIN.
author: Andy J.

description:
Given the famous reputation and high prices, I was expecting more from Mission Chinese. I had a few different dishes, but was not impressed with any of them:

Salt Cod Fried Rice: My favorite dish over the rest; I liked the texture of the rice and how the different seasonings interacted (garlic, scallions, cilantro), but the (2-3) pieces of fish were extremely salty and the egg pieces were mostly burnt. You can get a simpler, better version of this at HK Lounge or normal Chinese takeout places.

Spicy Mongolian Steak Chow Mein: The steak was tender and grilled perfectly, but there was not enough meat and the "Mongolian" flavor was little more than Sriracha sauce. 

Braised Pea Leaves: There were plenty of interesting ingredients in this dish (including pumpkin slices), but I think too much thought went into being "experimental" and not into making a good, solid broth. This dish had no flavor.

Cocktail/Mission Chinese Moscow Mule: I tried it just for fun since it was the "house cocktail," but it was overpriced and very cheap quality.
author: Stephanie P.

description: This restaurant was recommended as a place I couldn't miss while in San Francisco. I was exhausted from traveling all day and decided to order delivery to my hotel. I ordered an appetizer, chicken entree, and rice dish. The food arrived in a reasonable amount of time but I was missing my appetizer. I found it so disappointing. When I called about the missing food the person who took the call made it seem a little unreasonable to have the appetizer delivered at this point. The rice is good but  a little bland and the chicken entree has good flavor but the portion size is not appropriate for the price. Overall the cost was not worth the food or "service". Maybe the dine-in experience would have been better.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Just by the looks of it, this place screams dirty, Chinese, hole in the wall.  The food here is definitely not typical.  In fact, i was pleasantly surprised by the dishes.

We ordered:

1. Tiger Salad ($7.50) - Xi'an herbs, mixed greens, roasted seaweed, turnip vinegar, and chili oil all wrapped in a rice roll.  Super light, refreshing, with great flavor!

2. Chicken wings with explosive peppers - i'm not a fan of the tongue numbing chilis, but this dish was okay. I would skip it next time, just because there's so many other things on the menu i want to try.

3. Thrice cooked bacon ($11) - got this vegetarian and it tasted spectacular. Read on the other yelp reviews that the bacon is too fatty..... if that's the case, just skip the bacon and the flavors are all still there. trust me.

4. Westlake Rice Porridge ($11) - Ox tail, dungeness crab, soft poached egg, cilantro.  Great flavor, but my only gripe is that i don't believe the pieces of beef i got to be oxtail.  oh well. either way it was good and there were generous pieces of lump crab meat in it too. SUPER YUMMM....



Our bill came out to be around $42 pre tax.  Not bad. I would love to come back and try the other unique items on the menu.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I turned to my boyfriend in the middle of my meal and said "I don't get it." It looks like a crappy Chinese restaurant mixed with a bar, has a cool lit up dragon on the ceiling and some Christmas lights, has lots of food hype but the food is just odd random combos and there's hip hop music playing. The lamb dish was fatty and we were expected to eat it with chopsticks (?!?) and the rice cakes were entirely too spicy to enjoy and beyond that it all just tasted kind of..weird. Service wasn't great either-kind of too cool for school and also neglectful. I get that this may be interesting for foodies but it wasn't good-interesting for me!
author: Sydney A.

description:
Here's a little secret for you. I don't come to the Mission for Mexican food - I come for the Chinese food at this place. Specifically, the beef cheek and eggplant dishes. Their dumplings are also some of the best dumplings I've ever had - so fresh it almost has the texture of mochi. Or something. 

So go. Go now. You know I got a Yelp account just so I could write a rave review about this place?
author: Michelle L.

description: We ordered thee kung pao pastrami, thrice cooked bacon with rice cake and tea smoked eel.  Everything were way way too salty here.   If they can just put less salt on everything, these dishes would be actually decent.  I was quite disappointed.  Prob won't come back.
author: Andrew J.

description:
It's crowded, so expect to wait even on a Thursday.

To Order:

Slow Cooked Pork Belly (amazing)

Thrice Cooked Bacon Rice Cakes (heavenly but heart attack worthy)

Mapo Tofu (Super Spicy)

Think super hipster chinese food served to you in the skinniest jeans possible.

See more here: http://exm.nr/pfMAu7
author: Carli F.

description:
The food is nothing special. I was looking for something new and refreshing but didn't get it, I won't be back. The restaurant is rather dirty and in disrepair. The service is great but I've wasted too much time on this review as it is. 

Skip it and you miss nothing.
author: Justin S.

description: Terrible food that I wouldn't even feed my pig. I wouldn't even eat this food if you paid me. In fact, my company ordered this food and I ended up buying McDonald's instead. 0/5 if I could. I am appalled.
author: David Z.

description:
My mission if I chose to accept was to dine at Mission Chinese Food and take instagram it up. The mission was gladly accepted however I think we ordered more dishes than two people can handle.

The Mission Chinese Food menu was like Disneyland! There were so many asian dishes with all my favorite ingredients and sold at reasonable prices. I done lost my figure in an asian foodie's paradise. The BBQ beef brisket was delicious, slow cooked and flavory to articulate all it's goodness. The salad rolls, pork belly, and spicy noodle soup were all good as well. The mission very much satisfied.
author: David N.

description:
I learned of this place from a barista at wrecking ball coffee on Union Street, and decided it was worth a try.  I have to say, I definitely was not disappointed!  The food was delicious, the atmosphere was fun, and I left stuffed with enough left over for dinner the next day.

I liked the party-like atmosphere, with a good selection of strong beers to offset the Szechwan-level amounts of heat in the food.  Everything we got was nice and spicy, just as I like it, but be forewarned!  We got the pickles appetizer, the kung pao pastrami, and the sour spicy chicken, all great.  

Its a good place to rub elbows with other foodies at the communal table, and much to my surprise, about half way through, they turned on disco lights and strobes and I felt like we were in a club, especially after the IPA started to go to my head.

Remember, the bathroom's through the kitchen!
author: Sean F.

description: Service was good, we came before 3pm & had to place our order before the dinner crowd. We ordered a variety of food. Lamb larb, sesame chicken, Olong rice, Singapore rice, spicy greens, I must say everything was great. A mixture of succulent tastes.
author: Pamela B.

description: They increase their price too much and the service is not good.plus the music is way too loud.
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description:
The pork belly is to die for! I think the Chef won the James Beard young chef of the year 2013. Love the Ambiance, the music, the staff, very reasonable prices, wish we had one in the south bay!
Other notable awesome dishes:
Thriced cooked bacon.
Salt cod fried rice.

But in truth its all amazing.
author: Tony H.

description:
I had been so excited to try this place due to all the hype. I ordered the shrimp and pork Fried rice on Tuesday the 25th. I got FOOD POISONING!  I can never. NEVER. eat here again. I know this could happen anywhere and that does not make it right. But 4 days later, I am still not recovered. 

Yes I did report this to the SF Health Inspector.

And yes, you can get food poisoning within an hour of eating tainted food. Apparently this happens a lot with fried rice that has been sitting out all day and not kept at the appropriate temperature. 

NEVER eating here again!
author: Courtney H.

description:
I ordered delivery from this place on GrubHub not realizing that the place was kinda famous and wasn't really Chinese. But that's OK, since it gave me an unbiased taste of the dishes we tried. Here's what we ordered:

Smashed cucumbers in garlic sauce: we loved this - spicy and crunchy!

Tiger salad: totally weird - menu didn't explain that this was more like a spring roll with salad greens and herbs inside. It was OK.

Sour chili chicken: this was my favorite - spicy and the potatoes were a nice addition. Chicken was a little dry, however.

Spicy beef chow mein: spicy and very flavorful but the quality of the beef was average. Agree with the other reviewers that you could get this for half the price elsewhere and it would taste about the same.

Our order took 2 hours to arrive and GrubHub graciously gave us some credit for the delay. 

All things considered, I liken the cuisine here to a stoned American cook's spicy Chinese concoctions after a long night at work. Try it!
author: Aleece G.

description: People with those ridiculous beards who use words like "foodie" won't like this review, but I was finally grossed out by everything I had here. There was a brief window between the first bite and the clashing aftertaste burn in which might have been suggested happier times, but sadly the hipster pretention swamped the entire experience. Hipster is synonymous with arrogant insecurity, and the manic need to be special and unique is stuffed in all the wrong places. If you feel you must be something then you are not to begin with. Incongruous ingredients wooo. Old sock flavored bean paste and rice. Many will love this stuff. Sadly I was recently in china and the creativity of mixing ingeredients there is real and not forced to be hip. Keep the avalanche of sodium too please. Many will love this place.
author: Miguel L.

description:
Mission Chinese really did not live up to the hype. Even after having read that the restaurant has been disappointing as of late, we decided to give it a shot. 

Our table ordered two small plates: 
- Sour Chili Chicken - probably my favorite dish, though still a fairly mediocre one
- Tiki Pork Belly - I didn't try this one but my friends said it was decent

Two large entrees we shared:
- Salt Cod Fried Rice - this really just tasted like a fishy fried rice without any of the tasty flavors you look for in a good Chinese fried rice. We were all supremely disappointed in this one
- Ma Po Tofu - I was personally really excited to try this dish. The idea of shiitakes and tofu mixed with a blend of Szechuan spices seemed very appealing. The first few bites of the dish were promising, however, some ingredient that I couldn't identify left a very strange, lingering, after taste. After a few bites, I found myself chugging water trying to get the taste out of my mouth. It wasn't overlay spicy in the traditional sense but that flavor was just...odd. 

Ambience/Service: the place is dark with red tinted lighting, which made it hard to see the food. Server was fine, though she couldn't answer a question about how much rice we would need with our plates. 

I would not recommend Mission Street Chinese, especially if you're just in town for a few days and don't have time to waste.
author: Saara Z.

description:
I'm over it.  Really.  Not wanting to fight a line of Missionites, I wisely placed an order for delivery.  That works well.  Cumin lamb, pressed tofu, crab porridge, spicy peanuts, spicy pickles (which was basically kimchi).  That was a nice order...came in due time.  Pressed tofu had the bite of a fun noodle.  Crab porridge was delicious.  Cumin and lamb had all the good taste of chinese muslim spices.  All very nice.

A few orders later, and you know what, you get over it quickly.  Kung Pao Pastrami was just kinda an odd mix of spices.  Beef noodles soup was equally as uninteresting.  The egg custard with uni and scallops...ya...um...don't order that one for delivery.  

On top of it all, it's hella expensive.  I guess if you don't know your way around a chinese menu, this place would push you into new areas.  Too many better options to eat from Z & Y which is better for spice, Henry's for a generally nice selection of standards to craptacular American Chinese food at Eric's.
author: David S.

description:
Yes Lung Shan Restaurant is the correct restaurant that you are looking for (Surprise! Mission Chinese Food is actually not the restaurant's official name). 

What to Order Here:
Salt Cod Fried Rice ($12) 
ChongQing Chicken Wings ($11) (Otherworldly crispy)
Ma Po Tofu ($12) (I might skip this one if you are ordering the Chongqing Chicken Wings because both dishes are cooked Sichuan style and the flavors may be too similar. Order rice with this one).

What is my verdict as a Chinese food connoisseur? I've heard about Mission Chinese Food in the past but just assumed it was one of those many restaurants in the SF food scene that was overhyped. But absolutely believe the hype! I loved it!

Many unfamiliar to the variety of Chinese food within China might find the food here to be somehow un-Chinese. Everything here is authentically Chinese. Simply put, you just need to further expand your Chinese food experiences.

Interesting observations: the menu does not contain any Chinese characters, waiters are non-asian, the interior is completely kitch - but the food is good so it's okay.
author: Fei L.

description:
After talking to someone who vehemently told us how underwhelming the food was here, I had some apprehensions, but wanted the chance to decide for myself.

I'm glad we tried it cause the food was good!

We had:

Fried chicken wings - good, but buried under  a TON of dried red peppers
Salt code fried rice - as mentioned in other reviews, not as salty as other restaurants, but still yummy
Veal -  I forgot what it was called exactly, but it was delicious.  Candied on the outside and perfectly seasoned.  Great with the salt cod fried rice. 
Ma po tofu - this was our least favorite.  We actually only had a bite each.  It tasted fishy and there was no fish : /

I also have this thing where I love Asian restaurants that play hip hop and R&B.  Needless to say I enjoyed the music they played too.  It also may have been the gin martini from the Beauty Bar up the street, but hey - it was a good time :)
author: Mrs. N.

description:
I walked by on my way to Can Cun and noticed there wasn't a line. That never happens. I checked out their menu and thought I'd try it and see what all the fuss was about.

I saw the Fried Rice with crab, pork, pineapple and curry. Sounded interesting. $15. Must be stellar. I've got to try this. I ordered hot tea too.

I barely got the tea cooled off when my food arrived. 

Before me sat the most horrid looking dog food I ever did see. The smell was deadly. The crab couldn't have been fresh. The fishy smell was intolerable. The whole plate smelled like old shoes. The pork was overcooked and tough. The rice was bland and not a hint of curry. 

I had to push it away, it was seriously making me nauseous. I told the waitress that I couldn't eat it. She wanted to bring me something else and I said no. 

She brought me the bill. $18. 39. I didn't know what to do. Am I obligated to pay for this crap? I'm terrible in these positions. I have no clue what my obligations are.

I paid. I'm kicking myself. why I didn't just walk out... I don't know.

This place sucks. I want my money back
author: Ty M.

description:
Mission Chinese has received a lot of attention and hype and I've had a chance to visit it a couple times. Don't expect much in terms of decor and ambiance, but their staff is friendly and helpful. Here's a quick breakdown on items I've tried:

Tiger salad - not what I expected, but it's literally greens rolled up within a noodle
Tea smoked eel - unexpectedly wrapped in rice noodle along with ham hock and hoisin sauce, but surprisingly very good; looks like a smaller version of the tiger salad.
Pork belly - fried and crispy, but not as tender as I would have liked
Explosive fried chicken - Fried chicken buried beneath a pile of hot spicy red peppers; only ok
Hot and sour rib tips - Very tender and saucy
Stir fried pork jowl - Nothing special for me
Ma po tofu - A bit too spicy for my taste
Salt cod fried rice - Nothing special
Kung pao pastrami - Nice smoky flavor of the pastrami along with a mixture of spices; this dish grew on me
Sizzling cumin lamb - One of my favorites; the lamb is really tender
Smoked beef brisket soup noodles - The flavor was a bit too smoky.

Overall, I was pretty intrigued by the unique menu items. Definitely some hit and misses. It's a nice place to bring people looking for a different spin on traditional Chinese and Szechuan dishes.
author: Rick T.

description: **Please bring back the tripe in the wings!** I eat here all the time. Although since they changed their recipes I haven't gone as much. This place is perfect when you want something flavorful and strong. The downside (for some people) is that everything is pretty salty. Get the cod rice, it's delicious and perfect with the mapo tofu and wings!
author: Jeni M.

description: This place lives up to its hype man! Came here to eat as a party of 5 and ordered the following 6 dishes that I don't think we would have been able to live without: the salt cod fried rice (the bombbb), the veal (OMG. Order this.. So tender and the sauce is perfect), beef chow mein, thrice cooked bacon, dumplings, and the pastrami. Danny Bowien knows how to make his chinese food unique but still flavorful. The food is pretty spicy so prepare yourself! But I loved it. I'm coming back here next time for a plate of fried rice.. For one.
author: Madalena T.

description: Damn fine meal all the way around. Nice ambiance with the dragon overhead. Friendly, efficient service and we were seated right on time (we were lucky enough to score a reservation, because they they still have long lines even on a Thursday in the rain). I ordered the smashed cucumbers to start which were interesting and tasty even though it made my lips numb. Three main dishes: Thrice cooked pork, very flavorful and the rice cakes were a good texture. The Kung Pao Pastrami was nice and spicy and the dark Matcha noodles complimented the hotter dishes perfectly. Strangely this was my first adventure to this hallowed establishment, and it did not disappoint. Plus we got a cozy seat right in the front window which was kinda romantic too.
author: Gary B.

description:
There are many types of Chinese restaurants. There are some that cater to Asian people and there are others that cater to non-Asian people. Lung Shan falls in neither of these categories. It is more Asian Fusion. All of the dishes are Chinese dishes but with a twist.

The dishes weren't bad. My gf and I had the smoked eel. the 3 times cooked pork with rice cakes, and the gourmet dumplings. All were okay. The smoke eel rolls were good. The celery inside it gave it a nice crunch but did not mix well with the other ingredients. The 3 times (twice cooked?) pork with rice cakes were okay. It was probably the best out of the three dishes. It was very spicy, which was not what I was expecting. The dumplings were flavorless. They put in sesame oil just to make it flavorful but it didn't do it for me. All of these dishes are close to Chinese food but you wouldn't see it anywhere in any other Chinese restaurant. 

The ambiance was dark. The walls were all dark red. I get it, red means money according to tradition but you don't see any restaurants that have dark red walls anymore. I couldn't see much in the dark. We were squished in the corner with another group it was a little uncomfortable. 

The service was okay, it wasn't terrible, but it wasn't entirely very personable. The general crowd was filled with hipsters which is not a bad thing. We were the only Asian people in the restaurant.
author: Tako B.

description: Pretentious servers and the food (being 1/2 Chinese) is not good. Combine that with a long wait and rude staff....PASS. I had a chance to shoot the breeze with some of the cooks. Sweet guys with a love and knowledge for their provincial food but somehow it didn't translate into what we were served. If you're in the Mission do yourself a favor and grab Hispanic food.
author: Alfonse P.

description:
I am Chinese American with the emphasis on CHINESE. I mean ride and die, whenever I go back to China my grandpa makes me fried scorpions and my cousins and I go out to restos with four floor walk ups to eat intestines boiled in hot chili oil with loads of floating chilis on top. Whenever I eat that deliciousness it's seasoned with my TEARS because I'm crying about how I won't get anything like it back in the states. 

But then there was Mission Chinese Food.

Oh, my, sweet, four dragons of PRC this place is magnificent. They cook Chinese SOUL food. Not that it's greasy and rich--- but it actually comes from the soul. Each taste for me is a lyrical memory that makes my mouth sing. 

I sometimes go by myself just to get the congee, there's some delicious strands and pieces of a shellfish, a delicious egg, tons of little crispy, chewy fat pieces and scallions. I mean, I can't remember the exact names of the toppings off the top of my head but I remember being so happy. So happy. SO HAPPY. (Holy crap, I wrote delicious too many times in that paragraph but that's just a testament to my extremely positive emotional reaction to this place). 

This place is always jam packed and the people around me are always emitting moans of pleasure or gasping at the sheer deliciousness of their order. 

My fiance takes me on dates here and we are tempted to order the General Tso's Veal Rib every time. It is so fucking good and comes with a brutal knife stabbed into it that is the culinary sign language for: FUCKING EAT ME and we FUCKING EAT IT. 

The beer and drinks are priced like a real run-of-the-mill Chinese place. I've even seen crappier places charge more!

People behind this place are very thoughtful and not obnoxious. I thought they'd be too kitchy-chic but they're actually just "keeping it real."

Regarding service, Chinese grandmas deliver the food speedily and will give you anything you want as long as you flag them down. It's no bullshit. 

Now that I live in the Mission it's likely I'll be eating here every week!!
author: Lisa Q.

description:
Came here really early on a Saturday (~5pm). Tons of seating available, started filling up around 6.

Very chill, eclectic vibe. The waiter was a bit distracted (it was obvious they were still warming up for the night), but very attentive and pleasant.

The FOOD. We really enjoyed the Kung Pao Pastrami and the Thrice Cooked Bacon And Rice Cakes. Note: this is definitely fusion-y food. Don't expect American Chinese food or an "authentic" experience. But the dishes are well thought out, different, delicious, and pretty spicy. Worth a try!
author: Nora K.

description: This is just a review of the food, since Mission Chinese catered and delivered to our company. This is one of the last places I'd go back and eat at-maybe the hipster atmosphere in the restaurant would have made it better. But everything was lathered in sauce. I ate two bites and already felt uncomfortable, though I avoid anything with this much MSG as a general rule.
author: Thea S.

description:
The tea smoked eel just explodes with flavor. The richness of the eel, the sweetness of the hoisin sauce, and the saltiness of the cognac soy come together and master a perfect dance of complexity.

The sizzling cumin lamb is kinda like the Chengdu lamb dish from PF Chang's... except a million times better and not Americanized. It was some of the tenderest lamb I've ever had, accompanied by a light charred taste (which some don't like but I love), and a hint of sweetness and heartiness with dates. Loved the dates!

Ma po tofu was definitely great, but be warned: it's spicy even at medium. Large chunks of tofu and pork make it a solid dish.

This isn't a place you go to for decor (although it's charming in its own right). It's a grungy and authentic place in the Mission, and it's perfect for what it is.
author: Aninda M.

description:
I think to a certain extent the amount you can appreciate Mission Chinese sort of depends on how much chinese food you eat. I eat a lot of chinese food so let's break it down.

Smoked eel rolls - great, good smokey flavor with that crisp texture cut with the chang fun sauce and soft noodle. Very clever way to incorporate the flavors and textures.

Salted Cod Fried rice - chinese people eat a lot of salty fish but somehow not like this. you'd think after all this time it would have been done but for some reason it hasn't which is weird because it's delicious. Also salty fish is one of those weird chinese flavors that if you're not raised on it, then it get's sort of weird.

Thrice cooked bacon - take on a classic shanghai style dish that normally comes with chicken. The bacon really works with the chewiness of the rice cakes, sort of gets you to chew the bacon longer which means you get to taste bacon longer. Score.

Kung Pao Pastrami - I thought it was over spiced but again the pop of the peppers both texturally and flavor wise matches pastrami pretty creatively and doesn't feel forced at all.

To elaborate on that point more, I used to have this real stigma against asian fusion food. It always tasted forced, like the chef was like ok, I have a western dish, how do i put something asian in it so i can sell this? Mission Chinese doesn't seem forced, in fact it almost tastes effortless, like it was obvious these dishes would work. That's not to say that I don't think they really put a lot of time to nail these things down. Rather it's how you want fusion to taste, effortless and natural, like these things always went together. 

Sadly i've now moved out of SF and just found out they delivered. TRAGIC.
author: Misha T.

description:
Wow, the small Asian guy in the restaurant has some bad attitude and kept spouting off about us strolling in to an empty restaurant with more than half the tables open at 5.45pm without signing our names on the sign-in sheet up front.  Then he proceeds to tell us that we do not need to eat there if we are not happy with their "rules". Who would want to eat there after such an outrageous comment!  

Why would someone with such a pompous lousy attitude be in customer service?  Danny needs to fire this guy! No matter how popular a restaurant is, courtesy should at least be a standard service.  I am embarassed that my out of town guest had to experience such rudeness.  Unbelievable!
author: Anna C.

description:
Wow! Looks like Mission Chinese food was the place to be eating during Christmas week. Thinking everyone would be out of town we showed up with a group of 8 people - good thing one person canceled! Would they really have enforced the 8 person limit? After about a half hour wait we got the big round table in the back. The best thing about coming with a huge group is that you can order a lot of dishes to try. Our original plan, plotted during the long wait, was to order everything on the menu. After seeing it was 25 items we realized this was going to be physically difficult to eat that much food so we compromised and ordered all the cold dishes and selected a couple of hot dishes as well. 

I can't remember what appetizers were on the menu but the things I liked best were the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts, Szechuan Pickles and Savory Egg Custard (though it was too "fishy" for hubby).

For the hot dishes we ordered:

* stir fried pork jowl and winter radishes - wow, woW, WOW! There wasn't that much pork jowl in the dish but the entire thing was permeated with a rich meat flavor. I don't know how they did it. I've never had radishes so good! I had seconds and thirds of radishes.

* ma po tofu - I've had this before and it was just as good and just as hot. I mean seriously hot. I could barely eat a few spoonfuls. A lot of people at the table couldn't do more than just taste it.

* thrice cooked bacon - I like rice cakes and the bitter melon is done really well, but this is not one of my favorite dishes. It just doesn't gel together for me.

* tingly lamb noodle soup - a nice refreshing soup with thick noodles and tender, tasty lamb. It's a pretty big bowl. Enough for all 8 of us.

* wild pepper leaves - another WOW surprise. I don't know what wild pepper leaves are but they are tasty and slightly bitter. I like bitter greens so this was just up my alley. The soup is hot though it didn't stop me from having seconds.

All in all it was $45 per couple for a very full meal with leftovers.

Service was adequate. They were very good at the beginning, getting us drinks and taking the order. However, once the food started coming out it was super hard to flag anyone down to get refills or more rice. The food came out pretty steadily so we always had a lot of dishes on the table - almost faster than we could eat and clear the plates.
author: Jean K.

description:
This was one of the worst meals I've ever had.

I was swindled into eating her by my brother, who likes hyped places that have annoying, paragraph long descriptions of their food. 

There was nothing on the menu that sounded good. The flavor combinations made no sense, and they somehow ruined bacon. Bacon! That should be a punishable crime.

I felt very sick after leaving the restaurant.
author: Albert N.

description:
There's a buzz about MCF. So much so that there's a wait to get in practically every night it's open. Even the famed and revered Ferran Adria ate there after his recent talk in San Francisco. It's a place that I had wanted to try just to see what the hype was all about.

After signing up on the waitlist and waiting an hour in the cold SF night, we got seated and perused the menu on what to order. We chose:

Red Braised Pig Ear Terrine: I'm not a pig ear fan but was willing to try this just because it seemed different. This dish didn't win me over. The gelatinous aspic intermingling with the crunchy pig ear didn't appeal to my taste buds. My gag reflex yes.

Salt Cod Fried Rice: Now this was more to my liking. I enjoyed the bits of salt cod, the thinly sliced Chinese sausage, and the "breath of the dragon". That char and smokiness in the food you get from a searing wok. It wasn't anything too different from what I've had at other Chinese restaurants, but it eased the pain of the terrine.

Broccoli Beef Cheek: Cut up and sauteed Chinese broccoli covering up this huge, buttery beef cheek. There was also jewels of poached oysters spread throughout the dish. It was surf and turf I've never had before. And it is something I'll definitely order again.

Thrice Cooked Bacon: It's a popular dish that's ordered. Sliced rice cakes, onions, chili oil, black beans, and sliced bacon. The bacon was a bit chewy and tough. I expected it to be crispier so it was disappointing.

Slow Cooked Char-Siu Pork Belly: This dish could give you a heart attack. The pork belly pieces were uber-fatty. It's something familiar to me as the Vietnamese have a similar dish to this. Tasty but I would up my Lipitor count before eating this. 

7 Chicken Wings w/ Explosive Chili Pepper: It is deceptive looking. You have these fried chicken wings covered with mounds of red hot chili peppers. You expect it to be mind alteringly numb, but in fact, there is only a mild tinge of heat that lingers for a while. I enjoyed the spice blend on the wings and these would be great to eat while watching any sports game.

Did it meet the hype? I'm not so sure. Some dishes I felt could be at any Chinese restaurant. Some did stand out like the Broccoli Beef Cheek and 7 Chicken Wings. There were some other items we didn't get to try that I would have liked to. It'll have to be a 3 star review for now.
author: Randy T.

description:
As soon as I walked in on a packed night, they told me the trick.  Put your name on the list, come back later, if they already called your name, your next!  We put our name down, saw the brilliant Jonathan Richman up the street and came back to be next in line and get the final table of the night (everyone behind us had to get take out)!!!  

I was thrilled, a little buzzed, and it was a month ago.  With this said, I remember ordering a pork belly, lamb, and veggie dish and they LIVED UP TO EVERY GREAT REVIEW I'VE EVER READ!!!!!!  It was easily some of the best food I've ever eaten.

I never smiled so much during a meal!  My expectations were so high and they were still surpassed.  I read enough reviews to stay away from crazy spicy dishes, but ours was succulent, somewhat spicy, fresh tasting, and prepared with love.

We were the last to leave and while they didn't rush us, I figured it was time to wrap up when the started to play Lady's great song- Pussy.

I tell everyone about this place.  -can't wait to go back.
author: Scott H.

description:
Environment- Looks like any other gelatinous, Kung Pow Chicken place from the street, except for the eager, hipster crowd waiting in front. Inside it's packed wall to wall with people, old school hip hop turned up to bar volume. 

Food-  Like a Chinese chef who got too stoned and tried to make some late night snacks: sometimes weird, sometimes delicious, and totally all over the place. Some of it is amazing (Vegetable dishes, Ma Po Tufu, all the fried rices), and some if it really doesn't warrant another taste (95% fat lamb ribs). Most everything is doused in chili peppers, so come prepared to sweat. 

All in all, worth a trip to figure out if it's your thing, but probably over hyped.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Note to self: do not eat at an Asian restaurant that is overflowing with Mission hipsters and lacks an Asian customer base.  You'll only be disappointed and unsatisfied.

Mission Chinese Food has been on my bookmark list since they opened.  After having an extremely horrible day, my friend told me to choose a restaurant and I came up with Mission Chinese Food because one of my friends also brought it up one time.

RESERVATIONS:
There are no reservations.  Our party of five came here on a Thursday night.  The wait was about an hour or so.  When we were finally seated, we were seated adjacent to another party's table.  Also note, they do not accept parties larger than 8.

FOOD:
*Hainam Chicken Rice ($7) - Not good. I expected it be traditional with strips of chicken placed on top of the rice. Instead there was small pieces of shredded chicken mixed in with rice soaked in wine and lacked the traditional ginger flavor.
*Thrice Cooked Bacon ($10.50) - The bacon was delicious and the rice cake and tofu skin added a nice touch to the dish.  However, there were too much onions and the still crunchy bitter melon wasn't cooked enough.
*Westlake Rice Porridge ($11) - The best dish the night.  The mix of oxtail, crabmeat, green onions, cilantro, and topped with fried garlic was an almost homelike dish.
*Ma Po Tofu ($11) - The dish wasn't bad, but it also wasn't good.  Although there was a generous amount of tofu soaked in spices, the dish seemed like it was missing something, but I can't place what.
*Chicken Wings w/Explosive Peppers - Pass.  Although the chicken wings were mostly moist, it lacked flavoring and was overwhelmed with peppers.

SERVICE:
The males (I'm assuming they were the owners) were friendly and helpful.  The female seemed as if she had a short attention span and would walk off if you couldn't give her an almost immediate answer.

PARKING:
Metered street parking which can be quite difficult to find.

Will I be back? Probably not.  Hipster restaurants are not for me...
author: Nicole S.

description:
For a couple of years, MCF was a regular routine for my wife and I. We'd order the same thing, thrice cooked bacon and the fried cod rice, once a week. We even bought the book and made our own thrice cooked bacon dishes a few times. Tastes change as do restaurants over the years and we felt like we just weren't getting consistent meals there anymore.

It's become a special occasion for us to order MCF for pick up now, probably just once a month or so. The last order we got was the most disappointing yet and I don't think either of us are really in the mood to roll the MCF dice in hopes for a good meal anymore.

The balsamic vinegar peanuts we ordered as an appetizer had no vinegar at all. Instead it was just a little plastic bowl with some peanuts and 4 garlic cloves. We double checked the online menu to confirm the vinegar peanuts were still on there. I guess they just forgot to add it? 

The Thrice Cooked Bacon, the most important part of our order, was almost half the size as usual. We often have enough left over for another small meal, but not this time. The ingredients didn't feel like they were cooked together very long either... more like they were just thrown together without letting the flavors mix. My wife referred to it as "once cooked bacon", which sort of nailed it. The flavor just wasn't there and much of the bacon seemed like it had been overheated and really tough to chew. The noodles were as good as usual, just bland. We'd had hit or miss meals before, but this just seemed like such a waste. It was the first time we'd had to go back out for more food to fill us up. 

The Salt Cod Fried Rice seemed as good as usual though.

I tried a couple times to reach out to MCF to let them know about our meal (there's no email on the site and no response via twitter). I've heard similar complaints from other long time fans of MCF, so I'm hoping the restaurant can make a come back. We really miss that old experience, but now I'm just sounding like a grumpy old person, right?
author: Doc P.

description:
We went early to avoid lines yesterday, and found that 6pm was the best time to go in. But even with the half empty restaurant, we found the service to be highly lacking. Our food came before our sake, but only after I had to ask another server for it. Our server never followed up with us during the meal at all, when we could have had more drinks or food. 

We had the chicken wings, which was the best item we ordered. It was nicely seasoned, and tasty. We also had the egg-egg noodles and salted cod fried rice. The egg-egg noodles had a delicious sauce and it was filling. We could have skipped the fried rice which didn't have any real flavor to it at all. 

Some of the food is good but I wouldn't wait an hour or make this a destination spot. It's overrated considering there are a ton of other great choices for food in the neighborhood with better service.
author: Jes L.

description:
Mission Chinese... How I wish I could eat at you more often... (But I'm not willing to awkwardly stand outside and wait for a table every time I want to).

 Went here with my boyfriend and two visiting friends. The food was really good and the portions massive. I believe we shared three plates but still didn't finish. Good vegetarian options, if you're into that kind of stuff. 

Although it was a great din, there was a big downfall - the Tiger Salad. It's essentially a large, dry, herb spring roll. (Like literally just fresh herbs.) Wouldn't even recommend it to herbivores. (Ha! Puns.)
author: L Stephanie L.

description: Came here for the first time tonight, thanks to my good friend V. Fell in LOVE absolutely amazing and unique food. Great service, fast, awesome music. We got the Bacon plate, and the pork belly and it was BOMB, amongst their fried rice and chicken wings. Can't wait to go back
author: Samineh H.

description:
I thought that if there was one food genre that would remain un-hipsterified in San Francisco, Chinese food had the best chance. But if it was going to happen anywhere, I suppose I would guess that it would happen in the Mission District! 

From the huge crowd lingering and looking at their iPhones in front of the unassuming storefront (we ended up waiting about an hour for a table for 3 on a Tuesday evening), to the 90s slow jams soundtrack to the guy who looks like Steve Aoki making hand-pulled noodles at a station that looks like a DJ booth, this place is a bit over the top. 

Lucky for them, their food is also delicious. A word to the wise - do not underestimate the little pepper signs on the menu! When they say something's spicy, they mean business. 

My favorites were the thrice cooked bacon with rice cake, which was still super spicy for me even though I'm not even sure there was a pepper picture next to it on the menu, the salt cod fried rice, probably because that was the only non-spicy thing on the table and I had to keep eating it so my mouth would stop being on fire, the pork belly with soft boiled egg which was unique and delicious, and the hand-pulled noodles with lamb face, which has the most unappetizing name in the world but is really flavorful and good... and also super spicy!

Would I come back here? Maybe, if I wanted to impress an out of towner with my not-so-insider restaurant knowledge, but when I get the jones for Chinese I'm not sure I'll have the patience to wait in that line or the stomach lining to deal with that heat!
author: Christina P.

description:
i don't understand this place.
withouth reading any reviews i thought it was going to be a traditional chinese restaurant.
but when i got here, i realized it was a hipster spot.

tea smoked eel: overly sweet and salty
tiki pork belly: again. really sweet
thrice cooked bacon & rice cake: really salty
salt cod fried rice: not bad. but it's just fried rice.
chonqing chicken wings: didn't get to try them because I think they forgot about it. we just cancelled it because it took too long.
author: Heejin L.

description: I've only tried delivery from MCF and typically the food is good. However, I got the mapo tofu and sesame chicken a few days ago and was disappointed. I was told the order would take about an hour but it ended up taking 75 mins. The mapo tofu had too much oil and was way too salty; I could barely taste the other flavors. I've had mapo tofu here several times before. In fact, it was one of my favorite dishes but I'm not sure what happened this time (did they change the recipe?!). I hope the chef was just having a bad day.
author: Jen K.

description:
Oh hipsters. So sad.

Go to Mission Chinese because it's where people go, right?  The food is salty, but not too bad. 

Poor service, decent tasting but not great food, crumby decor.  The owners of this place are laughing all the way to the bank.

I'd give it less stars, but I just feel it doesn't deserve all the hate it's been getting lately. The food wasn't terrible, after all.
author: Mara S.

description:
Disappointed. 

It's rare that a Yelp consensus doesn't agree with mine and with so many good reviews, I had been tempted since moving to NorCal to try this place out!

I ordered of course the Ma Po Tofu, Broccoli Beef Cheek and Thrice Cooked Bacon. Of all three of these dishes, the best part was the broccoli (not the beef or the oyster part but just the vegetable stems itself!) and what's sad is, it wasn't even like amazing broccoli to truly yelp about.

I'm not sure why people think this is the best Ma Po Tofu in town because in my opinion, it isn't. I order Chinese take out from a hole in the wall when I'm desperate late nights and I like theirs better. 

The food was so full of spices and condimentaries that I didn't feel I got a representative taste of what the dish was about.

The service was subpar. I mean it wasn't like someone offended me or spilled a drink on me. It wasn't even as if someone didn't bring my food on time or got what I wanted when I asked. It was more the fact no one came to see how I was doing. No one came to ask if I liked the dishes. I mean, I didn't smell that bad right? And there were no smiles found in this place.  And a place without smiles is not the place to be.

Anyone who knows me or has read my reviews knows I am not a food snob and far from any expert...but I didn't like this place and wouldn't return. 

If it's Chinese food you want, head to the Richmond district. If you wanna be in the Mission, then go to Foreign Cinema.
author: Julia P.

description:
HOT, HOT, HOT!!!
I really enjoyed my food. The flavors were explosively good. However due to the extremely dark ambiance, spice and the fact that we did it family style... I couldn't tell what I was eating and everything started to taste the same.

Advice: eat what you ordered. 
(just sample other peoples!)
& bring a flashlight
author: Stefan A.

description: Given the noticeable crowd outside and inside the restaurant during the evening, I was a little taken back by the quality of the food. I got the Sour Chili Chicken which was decent, but a little but too salty in my opinion. We also got the "famous" Ginger Wiskey Mule which was surprisingly great for how simple it was. But overall, food wasn't fantastic, and service was kind of slow.
author: Adi P.

description:
Wow, don't try to get delivery from this place! They will tell you the waiting time only after you place your order. Since for us, 75minutes for our company's lunch was too long to wait, we called to cancel just 3 minutes after ordering. They refused to cancel our order citing that the food was already ready, hung up the phone and refused to pick up the phone again when I called back a few times.
