The extra star is for the Ma Po Tofu that was successfully ordered last time after waiting 90 minutes. The spices were tasty.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Amaze-balls!  I don't usually encounter things I'm unfamiliar with but they use this awesome pepper that makes your mouth numb.  Oddest thing ever.  that being said, their food was AMAZING!!!  Can't wait to go back.  Wish they had on in LA.  Now I need to go to SF more frequently for this place.  Chinese food will never be the same.  I can't even have Chinese anywhere else after this.  There is just no comparison.  

FYI:  their food is spicy so if you have no tolerance for some kick, this may not be the place for you.
author: Jacqueline D.

description:
I give this place 3.5 stars. 
The good: 
Ma po tofu (this is vegan) and marinated cucumbers. Music is bumping, but it can be pretty loud. So don't come here if u r trying to have a conversation. 

The bad:
Salted cod fried rice was way too salty. Mongolian lamb was too dry (according to my friends). 

Overall, this is a Schezuan inspired food and they don't mild it down, so you have to be able to handle the heat. The dishes uses a lot of fresh ingredients and has a interesting twist while still maintaining some authenticity. It's good to try for it's uniqueness, but not somewhere I would want to frequent.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
I recently had a few friends in town and after a long day at Delores Park we were starving.  Having heard great things, we hit the 18th block of Mission and saw a huge crowd waiting outside.

We were a bit discouraged but decided to write our name on the clipboard and have a cocktail at Beauty Bar.  This was around 7 PM on a Saturday and the wait was about 30-45 minutes.

The decor is pretty silly.  It's a tiny spot with tables squeezed into every available inch of space.  There is a red paper dragon that hangs from the ceiling along the entire middle row of seating.  Loud house music drowns out the busy kitchen.

We asked our server to order items for the table to share.  She brought several items coursed out including the Tiki Pork Belly, Kung Pao Pastrami, Stir Fried Squid Ink Noodles w Lamb, and the ChongQuing Chicken Wings.

If you love Asian Fusion that packs a spicy punch this is your restaurant.  The price is mid range and the food is excellent.  The atmosphere is loud and fast paced so if you're attuned to fine dining, I'd suggest take-out.
author: Alexa L.

description: Best Chinese food EVER!!! Truly a religious experience for foodies. Don't miss: grandmas dumplings, egg-egg noodles, thrice fried bacon and salt cod fried rice. Fun casual atmosphere, punk music playing and hip servers. Very friendly staff great at descriptions and suggestions. We had almost all meat dishes, but this is a vegan friendly restaurant too.
author: Srutih C.

description: Food was decent but the host was very rude and I felt very rushed during my dining experience. It is also in a cruddy part of town so I would definitely Uber it there if you are coming from a distance.
author: K D.

description: Wow, I mean first off the food is way overpriced. Chinese food is supposed to be one of the cheapest best bargain foods out there. String beans nor mapu tofu should be over $12. Its all hipstered out to be honest. Kung pao pastrami? Wtf? If you like your Chinese food done properly with bigger portions and cheaper, there's plenty other restaurants that will justify your palate and wallet.
author: Kurtis W.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the bay area.  The food is some kind of Asian fusion; it's kind of hard to describe except that it's amazing!  Most of the dishes are definitely on the spicy side though, and if you're looking for your typical "Americanized Chinese" dishes, you probably won't find them here.  

That being said, all of the dishes I've tasted so far are packed with vibrant and unique flavors and are reasonably priced.  I would recommend the tiki pork belly,  the thrice cooked pork, and the forbidden rice.

Note:  If you're planning on walking to this place from the 16th BART station at night, you might want to go in a group, the neighborhood can be a little sketchy.
author: Joey P.

description:
Was told by a friend that this place was some sorta gem within SF and was like some unique hipster Chinese food. In all honestly, being asian, I don't like my asian food to be messed around with too much, save for the occasional food truck endeavors. She mentioned that this place opens up at 5 PM every day and gets packed within couple minutes. I was pretty skeptical but whatever, we got to that area around 5:10 and there was a line outside the door. wtf right?

Anyways, parking like anywhere around SF, was a bitch, especially in the mission area. Finally found a spot about 3 blocks away and had to walk in the rain and I'm thinking to myself, this place better be fukin' worth it...

On the outside, the restaurant looks real shitty, I'm just being honest. There's a sign that doesn't even say mission chinese food in fact, it's some other restaurant name and no glamorous designs whatsoever and inside the restaurant is very dark and tight quarters. They've opted to go with the traditional chinese lighting technique of using only lanterns and its dark as hell inside.

But out came the food and the waft of spicy dishes made the trip worth it and needless to say, all the dishes were delicious, especially the chicken wings. I don't think I've ever had wings with that particular flavoring, it's hard to describe but it's fukin good.
Quarters are tight as mentioned so you probably be bumping elbows with strangers, but with food that good it's hard to complain, although it is a bit too dim inside. Bathrooms are way in the back and you needa walk past the entire kitchen, awkward.

Would recommend for adventurous folk seeking something different than your typical asian fare.
author: Jason L.

description:
I'm into food fads, and hipster Asian food is a big thing right now. Korean fusion is especially popular, but I haven't heard of Chinese fusion until recently when I read this glowing review of Mission Chinese Food on Serious Eats (http://www.seriouseats.com/2011/08/san-francisco-mission-chinese-eatery-is-the-d.html) and practically dragged my bf here.

The ambiance is cute and the decorations are very classic Chinese (the tables have fake flowers, and a paper dragon hangs from the ceiling) but you won't mistaken this for an authentic Chinese restaurant because there are American waiters and dubstep thumping from the speakers. The chefs in the back must be Asian though because they know how to cook a mean sizzling cumin lamb. This is one of my favorite lamb dishes that I've tried recently. We also got the westlake rice porridge, which was also pretty good but they went a tad too heavy on the fish sauce. We didn't order some of their most popular dishes, so I have to come back again for their pastrami, thrice cooked bacon, and salt cod fried rice.
author: Helen S.

description:
How do I begin to describe my unfortunate experience at Mission Chinese Food...

It was always a mystery to me why I had never been here before until now. For someone who is such a fan of San Francisco's culinary heaven, I decided to finally check Mission Chinese Food off the list. All day I had been anxiously waiting for 5pm to roll around the corner. I had spent some time earlier that afternoon reading the menu and found myself in a dilemma -- I had no idea what I was going to order. It all sounded so wonderful. I wanted to try it all!

We got there right when they opened and managed to grab a table immediately. Took another quick glance at the menu and we placed our order. We all knew we had to try to salt cod fried rice. It's the only thing I ever here anyone talk about it. When it got to the table we all just kind of stared at it. We were a bit confused as we saw zero salt cod in this "godly" dish.

"Maybe it's mixed it there somewhere?" I took my chopsticks and stirred the fried rice around.

No salt cod.

"Well...does it at least taste salty?" It didn't. No salt cod or hints of the mackerel confit. Something that should pack a punch with flavor. We sat there for a bit longer and looked through some photos of this dish on yelp and other sources which clearly showed that salt cod had been present in this dish once upon a time.

I had never been served a dish before that left me so puzzled.

We waved down the waitress and asked her if this was indeed the "Salt Cod" Fried Rice or if we were given the wrong dish. She was quick to reply in the most unfriendly, condescending way and said this dish doesn't actually have pieces of salt cod in it and walked away. No care in the world about our experience at a restaurant that is supposedly one of the most important restaurants in America. 

Then in walks Danny Bowien himself. I glanced at him in disbelief and stared down at the "salt cod" fried rice, moving the rice to the edges of my plate as I'm still searching for this non-existent fish. As he walked by our table, a part of me so badly wanted to introduce myself and ask him to take a bite of this dish and see if he thought this was acceptable. Because I think he would say otherwise. 

We also ordered the tea smoked eel, savory egg custard, and the tiki pork belly. The pork belly was truly the only thing I enjoyed.

I just wish I had some salt cod in my salt cod fried rice. And maybe a server that actually cared.

Farewell, Mission Chinese Food. Forever.
author: Sara K.

description: My wife and I took a walk over here after we found out, that there would be a 3 and a half hour wait to get into Flour & Water. (which from what I understand is quite normal around there) and we did want to try this place. Our last restaurant to dine in SF before heading back home the next morning. The wait time was pretty much 5 minutes, which was shocking for a Saturday night and it was extremely busy in there. The food portions you get are plenty and reasonably priced. We actually had to be moved, to a better table because they needed the space where we were sitting. Which we didn't mind! they even comped our drinks for the "inconvenience" :) It's a young trendy, colorful, noisy place in the mission district. Next time we are back through SF, we'll definitely come back.
author: Peter T.

description:
There's a little bit of an identity crisis here. First, if you're looking for a Mission Chinese Food street sign, all you'll find is a yellow awning saying "Lung Shan" outside. We basically had to ask the host inside if the restaurant was indeed the famed Mission Chinese Food of the Big Eat lists, to which they readily agreed.

Other random notes - we ordered the salted cod fried rice, dan dan noodles, mapo tofu and kung pao beef? (chicken? can't remember. ) The food all seemed pretty standard Chinese fare except for the noodles - these were coated with pea puree and topped with a soft boiled egg. I don't know about other people, but I've never seen my parents/relatives/other Chinese people eat this dish or anything even similar. It was a little weird, since the rest of the dishes were pretty typical. The service was also very Americanized, though all of the chefs and workers in the back were Chinese. It wasn't exactly a dealbreaker but this place was definitely disconcerting to say the least.

The food wasn't exactly spectacular or memorable minus the noodles- those were great! But again... are they really representative of Mission Chinese? Not really.
author: Tiffany C.

description: I only got take-out but I highly recommend the Mapo Tofu (vegan) if you're not a meat eater. Its spicy, flavorful and they give you a good amount for the price.
author: Anish A.

description:
This is a great place for Chinese food if you're tired of the traditional banquet style dinners and want something creative and modern.  The food here is at a different level in terms of uniqueness.  

Things to order:  braised pork belly (a favorite at the table!!!), the fat was soooo delicious everyone wanted more.  i also liked the Salt Cod Fried Rice, just because of the flavor.  Mapo Tofu was pretty good too, my friend's favorite.

Line wasn't too bad (came here on a Thursday night), but they don't let you sit down until all of your party arrives, but you can get a drink at a nearby bar and the hostess is okay with that.  Waitresses are all white!  Pretty hilarious...yet all the chefs in the back are Chinese.  This place is full of hipsters as well, hopefully that doesn't bother you.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Very unique takes on traditional dishes. Low-key, hipster atmosphere. I'd recommend going during the week, because even on a Monday I had to wait a bit around 7. Portions are surprisingly big. Looking forward to going back so I can try more dishes.
author: Kyle K.

description:
Update: 

Returned and tried the sour chili chicken, broccoli and beef brisket, and Mongolian long beans. Came for lunch again, and was maybe 25% full around 12:30 on a Saturday. Great time to go. Service was quick, with all the dishes out within 10-15 mins of us ordering. 

- Sour Chili Chicken: 60% chicken, 20% zucchini, and a little bit of potatoes and peppers. Not particularly flavorful, and somewhat dry chicken. Would not get it again.
- Broccoli and beef brisket: 70% Chinese broccoli, and 30% beef. The chinese broccoli I'm a huge fan of, so that was nice. But maybe a bit heavy on that for most people. The beef was super super tender and juicy, though some of it pretty fatty, with one piece I got being ~entirely fat. Good and simple, likely to please many, but not standout.
- Mongolian long beans: these have changed a little since I last had them a year ago or more. Less leeks now, and almost entirely long beans. Were about as spicy as I remembered them being (not a lot for me, but my tolerance is very high), though my friend had some trouble. There were some chili peppers mixed in there, so maybe that was why. Tasty and a solid staple, though apparently more for those who can stomach it.

So I wouldn't get the two meat dishes again probably, though I would the long beans, and a lesser experience in that way, but I purposefully ignored my favorites for new things, so I'll be back to my favorites (of which there are many) - pork jowl, cumin lamb, chicken wings, veal rib, pea leaves, and long beans.
author: Kris K.

description:
It's not traditional Chinese, but the flavors are simply irresistible.  Spicy cumin-chili seasoning, sweet dates, and scallion adorn a plate of sizzling hot, deliciously charred, juicy lamb ribs.

The rice noodles with peanut sauce are a flashback to my favorite go-to meal on the streets of Bangkok -- wide ribbons of rice noodle, with the chewy, springy texture that comes only with the freshest of noodles.

Don't miss the tiger salad, an explosion of green flavor: mint, lettuce, cilantro, vinegar, fish sauce.  If I could have my salad packaged neatly into an extra large rice noodle wrapper like this every day, I'd probably be eating a lot more vegetables.

I was really surprised, given some of the lower reviews, to find the staff here attentive, quick, and serviceable.  It's a really well run operation, and I'd definitely return.  If you want to avoid the crowd, just come by 6 PM in a small group and you'll be seated quickly!
author: Tracy K.

description:
Today had the cucumber starter along with the kung pao pastrami. Cucumber makes for a "cool" on your tongue alternative to any of the spicy dishes you may order. I liked the kung pao pastrami, but as others have stated it is salty so if you have high blood pressure this one is not for you. Salt level is to be expected,  as it is pastrami, which is cured in a salt brine after all. There are quite a few slices of celery, but I like the crunch and added flavor it brings to the dish. 

A lot of choices on the menu, will be back to try the others
author: INTHECITY S.

description:
Ahh, Mission Chinese. 

A little dingy, a little overpriced, a little too hyped, and little too smoky inside, but I really like some of their dishes and their large portions. Their decor and service isn't too special, so I would even recommend just getting their food to go and enjoying it at home without bumping elbows with strangers.

Food to get here:

SALT COD FRIED RICE
SALT COD FRIED RICE
SALT COD FRIED RICE
Yeah, I said it three times, because it's thrice as good as whatever you are imagining it to taste like right now. Believe. Mackerel confit, Chinese sausage, lettuce, egg. This definitely rings in as my favorite fried rice in the city. 

Cumin Lamb Ribs
I tried this for the first time last week and I was pretty impressed. The spicing was delicious and the portions were generous. The only minus was a couple of the end pieces were too chewy and overcooked to enjoy.  But overall, good dish with complex flavors. I would order again. 

Ma Po Tofu
For all you spice lovers out there, this is a definite must. Just on the threshold of too spicy, this is perfect with steamed rice. 

Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes
So the name of this dish is misleading. It's actually vegan. The bacon is made out of tofu skin, but you could have convinced me otherwise. Great side dish, just a bit on the spicy side, really unique flavor.

Chongqing Chicken Wings
SUPER SPICY and not the enjoyable kind. The wings are decent enough but the dish is covered with red chilis and it makes your tongue go numb. Looks tempting, but I would skip it and go for some of the more delicious dishes.
author: Krithika H.

description:
2 of my most trusted foodie friends pointed me in the direction of Mission Chinese. Don't be fooled-- Mission Chinese is in the old Lung Shan spot, but they have yet to change the signs. 

3 things: super spicy, super salty, super oily. Better skip Mission Chinese if you have a weak stomach or high blood pressure. I got the Ma Po Tofu... the seasoning was good, but intense. Again, if you have a weak stomach/palate, skip this place. The sauce, I speculate, was pure chili oil. Needless to say my stomach/intestines weren't too pleased with me post-meal, but it was yummy. Definitely get rice, and request extra water as you will be dehydrated from the sodium. My mom ordered the combo fried rice, and it was good, albeit simple, perhaps a tad bit overpriced. 

The vibe is... well, Mission hipster at its finest, or worst, depending on who you are talking to. It's dim and the music is loud, good for a casual meal with friends, but if you're looking for something more intimate I'd look elsewhere. 

The service is minimal & the food came out fast. I probably won't be a regular because a. it's quite heavy, b. it's not in my neighborhood, and c. i think i prefer Clement St. dim sum/Chinese (but i'm not sure you could compare the two) 

Try it out! I imagine it's better if you eat meat (I personally don't) as there are only 2-3 things on the menu that are veggie.
author: Caity W.

description:
If I could, I'd give this place 3.5 stars. Pretty solid overall but definitely over-hyped and a little overpriced. I mean, c'mon, $14 for a plate of noodles?

Anyway, from the moment you walk in, you get the distinctive feel that you've stepped back in time to the 90s with the rock music blaring in the background and old Christmas lights strung everywhere. 

Here's the run-down of the plates I got:

Thrice Cooked Bacon - (3/5) SOLID. It was a little too spicy for my taste but overall packed full of flavor and had an interesting texture combo going on with the rice cakes. I was actually surprised that the Schezuan peppers weren't as prominent in the dish as I've normally had them but fine by me since I'm not a fan of those peppers. You definitely need a mild dish to balance this plate out.

Salt Cod Fried Rice - (4/5) Nice twist on your good ol' fried rice. I loved every bite of the delicious fried fish and had the palate to tell the difference between regular Chinese fried rice and this subtle taste. Loved it.

Squid Ink Noodle in Lamb Broth - (2/5) Disclaimer, I'm not a fan of lamb so my opinion is probably biased but this $14 plate was overpriced for what we got. Barely touched it and was a little too gamey for my taste. 

Definitely worth seeing but there are better, more afforable Chinese restaurants in the city like San Tung. The reason I gave the restaurant a "3" was because I'm not dying to go back there anytime soon but it was solid overall.
author: Tran N.

description:
I had heard it all depended on what you ordered here, and while that's somewhat true, i think it was way too hyped up.  My friend was kind enough to get take out for us.  Unfortunately, certain appealing dishes were available only for in restaurant dining (like a squid ink pasta!)

GRANDMA'S SPICY LAMB DUMPLINGS: Slightly gamey, with a kick from chili oil; I could have done without the peanuts but really liked the pickles. 

TEA SMOKED EEL: Reminded me of the dim sum "chang fen," but instead of shrimp or beef, it was smoked eel.  The eel itself was smoky and rich.  The Chinese celery added a nice crunch, but the celery was a little too pungent for the dish.  You definitely need to dip it in the soy sauce.  

TIKI PORK BELLY: Kind of fusion-ish with the pineapple, coconut, and mandarin orange - like a tropical pork belly, with a little tiki umbrella and all. 
 
CHONGQING CHICKEN WINGS: Tons of red chilis on top, as well as chili oil - pretty explosive as they say.  The crispy beef tripe may actually be even better than the wings.  The spiciness can be numbing.

SALT COD FRIED RICE:  Disappointing! I think this dish made it on the 7x7 list.  You can't really go wrong when you combine salted fish, chinese sausage, egg, and scallion with white rice.. unless there's essentially NO cod in the dish.  I had to add salt and chili sauce for more flavor.  I did like the jalapeno in it.

KUNG PAO PASTRAMI: Tons of flavor and textures, nice kick, probably my favorite stir fry.  Definitely on the greasy side.  

CUMIN LAMB RIBS: Done well, hickory smoked, and the accompaniments went well on the rice.  

THRICE COOKED BACON AND RICE CAKES: Stir fried rice cakes coated in bacon fat.  The bacon wasn't as strong as I expected, and it had lots of Szechuan pepper, but I actually hoped for more salt in this dish, too. 

MONGOLIAN LONG BEANS: Good flavor, very oily, lots of spices, didn't taste the horseradish.  

MARKET GREENS: Kind of expensive ($12) for some stir fried baby bok choy, but it was the lightest dish of all, and I really needed vegetables not coated in oil.

Overall, I was expecting for more flavor rather than just pure spiciness.  While I appreciate the creativity like with the kung pao pastrami, I thought they under-performed on more classic, signature dishes like the fried rice.   I think they also use less sugar than the average Chinese restaurant in SF; though they use just as much grease.   It's fun to try the various dishes, so it's better to have more people.  It's by no means a light meal. 

Honestly, I think the concept was cooler as a pop up restaurant.  Otherwise, it's pretty expensive for Chinese food and quite overrated.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
After being invited to this place on a Friday, we turned around and brought a whole new group on Saturday. Paying forward the gift of delicious veggie/vegan (or not) Chinese cuisine. 

The egg egg noodles disappeared within minutes of being set on the table. They were delicious. The pineapple pork belly and 3x cooked bacon (both the regular and vegan options) were amazing.  I will be back about once a month to get my fill of those.  

Of course, I never feel cool enough to be eating there but I do feel like maybe afterward I'm a bit cooler by association?
author: Allison B.

description:
This is not your everyday Chinese food.  

First, because the food is fantastic. The menu is super creative and we loved everything we ordered. You could tell that preparing this menu must have been a lot of fun, based on the inventive play of flavors in every dish. While we weren't busy "mmmmm"-ing at everything, we were scooping more stuff onto our plates. 

We had the Chongqing chicken wings which was so hot, I swear I broke out into a sweat! And oh so crispy! I would have totally hogged the plate if my mouth wasn't on fire. The salt cod fried rice had a good balance of flavor, and if I thought the pork belly was melt-in-your-mouth awesome, then the General Tso's veal rib was a revelation. That was the clear winner of the evening. I'm drooling just thinking about it.

The second reason why Mission Chinese isn't your everyday Chinese food is because the line outside the door is intense. While the food here is totally worth the wait, I don't think I'd want to wait 45 minutes for my meal all the time. I saw a lot of people put their name on the list, go have drinks somewhere else, and come back with an appetite, so I think that's what I'm going to do the next time. Because there *will* be a next time, oh yes.
author: Racquel N.

description:
The food here is not your ordinary Chinese food-it's kind of a westernized take on Chinese dishes but they keep the  numbing spices,  garlic and chili peppers in the mix rather than making it bland for spice wimps. Which is a GOOD thing. 

We had Kung Pao Pastrami-worth it just to pick out the moist smoky bits of pastrami, the Spicy Beef Chow Mein, made with bits of hangar steak, Tiki Pork Belly which is now one of my top 10 dishes, Beer Brined Sichuan Pickles (like kimchi but less garlic and with boiled peanuts in it), and the Mongolian Long Beans (containing the aforementioned numbing spice). 

Everything was excellent but some of it was SWIMMING in oil because of the chili paste and oil used when cooking so don't wear your favorite white garment to dinner.

The only thing that made me give 4 stars rather than 5 is that the restaurant itself is a filthy hovel. We were seated in the window area and I was afraid a cockroach was going to crawl inside my purse. As far as I know that didn't happen, but jeez, could you guys at least clean the window sills once in a while? *shudder*
author: Fancypants J.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend and ordered the following:
Appetizers:
-Grandma's dumplings  :)
-Chongqin chicken wings  :D
Entree:
-Cumin lamb ribs  :D
-Beef chow mein  :(

One thing that kind of peeved me was that there was that the traditional appetizer first, entree when appetizers were completed rule was complete disregarded. We got the dumpling first, and within a minute the cumin lamb ribs came. Noodle entree came third, and chicken wings came last. LOL what? 

Also, no free rice... Ugh.

The dumplings were actually very authentic. It very much tasted like the ones made by my mom. The first thing that got delivered was the dumplings. It was a really nice surprise. Most restuarants get dumpling dishes right, but it was pretty rare to find one that made them so similar to home.

Now the ribs, were amazing. I generally don't gravitate toward ribs, but these were really delicious. The way the ribs were spiced...total winner. I really can't say enough about these ribs. I would definitely reorder these.

The chow mein was actually a big disappointment. I thought it was really unflavored except for saltiness. Such a common dish should really be a no-risk-order. And some more beef pieces would've been nice.

But finally, the chicken wings... So. Good. It wasn't just stupid-spicy. It was tongue tingling, but sophisticated spicy. If you've had ma-la spice before, this is the restaurant's version of it. As I type this I am craving ma-la soup so much... (If anyone can recommend a great place I can have authentic ma-la soup please let me know!!)

In short, the ribs and wings I will definitely be re-ordering, and would recommend without any hesitation. The dumplings were good, but I would rather try something new next time, and the chow mein I would recommend against.
author: Katherine Y.

description: Not authentic Chinese food. Overpriced and the  squid ink noodle or whatever is inedible. We ordered market green + broccoli and beef (they charge$18 for this simple dish) and guess what?No broccoli!!!!they gave us the same veggie...wtf ! Not to mention the west lake porridge...any dim sum place has better porridge than this place. I don't know how other's can give this place such a high score, you guys should travel to Asia and try some real food there.
author: Chloe L.

description: Spicy beef noodle had such soft noodles and was rich in flavor. It was a bit of a wait.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
Another place Helen C. recommended to me. DELIVERY ONLY!

- "Mouth Watering Chicken": I'm not a big fan of random chicken parts, like chicken hearts, but it wasn't too bad. Chicken was flavorful and plenty of protein in the dish.

- Stir Fried Sweet Peas: Lots of chili. I kind of understand why the dishes are divided into COLD and HOT now, and it wasn't because of the temperature of the food. It wasn't too spicy, but I did like the fact that it was actual peas instead of peas in a pod. Very green!

- Thrice Cooked Bacon: I was thrown off of how not bitten the bittermelon was. Also, I wasn't aware that rice cakes were in the dish too. Pretty tasty, and a nice mix of Asian fusion with the bacon, rice cakes and bittermelon.
author: Tom T.

description:
Living a couple of blocks away from MCF left me waiting for the right moment when we wouldn't have to deal with the notorious line to get in. That moment came Thursday between 6 and 7pm. Better late than never? Maybe not. Not all is well in Denmark. Impossible to believe the chef of this restaurant is getting any accolades. Seeeeeeerious quality control issues are at hand. 

Everything looked so good on the menu. With some recommendations from our waitress we still couldn't  narrow and ended ordering a large spread, which appeared in the following order:

1. Tiger Salad: lettuce in a roll. I usually love raw and cooked; this left me wishing we were eating Vietnamese. Raw lettuce, wet rice noodle. "Is that all there is?"

2. Stir-fried Sweet Peas: Was expecting new peas in pod as in "typical" Chinese fare, delicately sautéed and bristling with complementary spices. Instead, a monster bowl overflowing with BB size peas, entirely conjuring a picture of our hero in Woyzeck, tortured with a diet solely of peas. "Did you eat your peas?!? Did you eat your peas?!? Did you eat your peas?!?"

3. Thrice Cooked Bacon: Given the omni-love-a-thon of bacon these last few years, could this dish be considered original in any way? That said, the grease and salt component x-ed out all other flavor, including one of my favorite veggies, bitter melon, which normally serves as such a divine foil to meat.

4. Sizzling Cumin Lamb: another favorite, cumin, completely disgraced by overuse, obliterating the other featured players in this dish, namely a lamb that sported an obese amount of fat over muscle. No sighting of either the figs or watercress that so seductively wooed us from the menu, presumably fatted, salted, charred and cumined to death beyond recognition.

[Two minute warning: the grease and salt in the few bites we've actually eaten so far signal an S-O-S of major indigestion or worse, food poisoning, in the coming hours.]

5. Tea-smoked eel: no tea, no smoke, no eel. Description should read: "salted mush in a slimy noodle nestled in a salty sauce excusing itself as a spirited soy."
...
When we left around 8, still no lines waiting to get in. Maybe the rest of the world has been clued in already.

Conclusion: The worst meal in recent memory. James Beard should be rolling in his grave.
author: Kmc M.

description:
So in the beginning I was a bit skeptical, but MCF is an amazing modern and creative take on Chinese food.

things i loved:
the long beans
the pork belly
smoked chicken
kung pao Beef
beef noodle soup

It's funny that people who don't like hipsters always complain about the Mission, yet they always go back to it.  I don't care if the place is booshie, grimy, hipster, trendster, yuppy...we aren't in High school anymore so please quit with labeling.  At the end of the day this is a fun and refreshing restaurant that focuses on the most important thing: making great food.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Overhyped, overrated, and overpriced not-so-Chinese food specially crafted for the hipsters is what "Mission Chinese" is dedicated to deliver. 

This is a FUSION Chinese restaurant, i.e. you pay quite a bit more for their "fusioning" idea of how to turn a traditional cuisine weird, so STOP being misleading and change your restaurant's category!!!!

Sorry, hipsters, one of the stereotypes that people often refer to you is in fact purely true in this case, and that is it couldn't be easier to rip you off especially when you all carry such "cutting-edge" taste buds which you think make you *ehem* oh-so cool! 

Thanks for always intentionally giving us normal people irrelevant hype these days! I hope you all get massive and explosive diarrhea after you stuff your stomach with this "food" and leave with your nose up in the air indicating how cool you are.

P.S. Mr. Chef, did you coat your pastrami with salt?
author: Miiiiei P.

description:
For all the buzz this place has garnered, both here and at their Lower East Side Manhattan outpost, I was SUPER pumped to give it a try. And wait, what? They give you an option to skip the line and eat from the comfort of home via delivery? Sign me up immediately. 

So sign up we did, ordering a fairly impressive quantity of food for two, if I don't say so myself. Sadly, the magic and excitement died just about as quickly as it started. We opened with the Chongqing chicken wings, described as having 'explosive chili'. I would agree with this description, if by 'explosive chili' one means 'overpowering Chinese 5 spice'. My tongue almost instantly turned numb, and even after brushing my teeth twice mid-meal (another nice benefit of eating from home, though one I've never had to employ before or since), I could not manage to completely get the taste out of my mouth.

To be perfectly fair, the rest of the meal was tainted by this first course disaster. But of the 4 other items we tried (kung pao pastrami, salt cod fried rice, tiger salad, pork jowl), they ranged from moderately decent to completely forgettable, albeit each with another heavy hand of spices that sunk any chances of enjoying these otherwise quite creative dishes.

Yes, you may argue that delivery was a bad choice. Or that the wings were the entirety of the problem. Maybe you're right; I'm just calling it like I see it. I don't say this lightly: this was the worst meal I can ever remember having.
author: Alex H.

description:
The stars above indicate my love.  The description below indicates my favorites.  I'm going to make this brief.

Personal faves: Kung Pow Pastrami, Salted Cod Fried Rice, Thrice cooked Bacon, Smashed Cucumbers in Garlic Sauce, Mouth Watering Chicken (Really makes you salivate out of heat!), and Braised Pork Belly are some of my favorites.

Service is pretty good too, and don't be daunted by the style.  This place is all business!  If you're not prepared to focus on the food versus the decor, then don't come here!

Every time I hit SF this is a place I am guaranteed to go to.

It's too bad the one in NYC is currently closed :(
author: Luke W.

description: This place is in the proud fusion California tradition. What type of food is Kung Pao Pastrami, or Tiki Pork Belly? Salt Cod fried rice? Give them credit for taking a chance and making it a go. Old run down looking storefront. They have some watery tasting Icelandic beer to wash all this spicy food down.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This will likely get me a lot of hate mail but hey I aim to be honest.  Mission Chinese has been one of the most talked about restaurants in the Country recently.  I have honestly not kept up with the hype but finally decided to see what is so special about this place.

Mission Chinese was one of the original pop-up restaurants and appears to be cresting with the whole pop-up restaurant, food truck hype.  How long this will go on? I have no idea, but imagine your hole in the wall Chinese restaurant (and I mean a real hole in wall), add cool beats, turn down the lights, write a book and make some slight modifications to Chinese classic dishes (with varying degrees of success) and voia!  That is Mission Chinese in a nutshell.

Mission hipsters stand in line for the opportunity to be greeted rudely by the hostess who warns you sternly about the restaurants seating policy.  Hint to hostess: there are two ways to express a rule... one is the rude way and gets you a smaller tip and the other way that makes your customer feel that you are doing them a favor that gets you a bigger tip.

The true revolution here is the marketing which one can not dismiss.  The food was decent but not better than any number of local Chinese hole in the walls, e.g. Henry's Hunan.  Putting squid ink to color your noodles truly does not warrant the hype.

Not to leave this review on a complete negative note.  The salt cod fried rice was cooked perfectly.  Whomever executed that dish would certainly earn the respect of a Chinese cook slinging a hot wok with a cigarette in his mouth.
author: Laurence H.

description: This ain't Chinese food, and that's ok. It's a very cool spot and many of the dishes are innovative and/or fun. The chicken wings in particular are a stand out (while the lamb ribs were questionable on a couple of fronts). But the real problem with MCF is the servers and the attitude. Our party of three had a reservation and was seated promptly. As we finished up our meal, enjoying the last of a bottle of wine, our server came over and asked us to leave! Other people were waiting for tables. Um...I'm sorry, if those waiting for tables don't have reservations and/or you've mismanaged seating walk-ins and now have a delay. Totally inappropriate and unprofessional to ask paying customers to get out because you need our table. Would have understood if you prefaced our seating/reservation with the fact that you were busy and we needed to be out by a certain time, but that wasn't the case. I'd welcome an apology from the manager.
author: Kaytee D.

description:
Overhyped. I found their twist on Chinese food here to be pretty unimpressive.  

Tea smoked eel - the eel was rolled in the thin, steamed rice sheets; not much eel, lots of tough celery stalks and other vegetation
Tiki pork belly - Pretty good even though it was a little sweet
Kung pao pastrami - too salty and oily
Salt cod fried rice - the only thing i really liked and would order again
Ma po tofu - i did not like the mouth numbing Szechuan peppers

I'm glad we went in the middle of the day on a weekday because I would not want to wait in line to eat here.
author: Thi D.

description:
Guys, this restaurant is the best, most interesting Chinese delivery service in the city. 

Tips:

I find that I get much better food when ordering earlier in the day--our 5pm order on a Saturday had a larger percentage of choice meat and porridge that was full of scrumptious crab and duck. On the other hand, late night weekday deliveries have not been as perfect--one order of broccoli beef brisket had only two tiny pieces of beef. Order early!!

Also, I think the ma po tofu is vegetarian, so it tastes pretty different than we expected. :)
author: E. S.

description: It was good, but not great. A bit over priced. The food had interesting flavors but left me feeling meh. I had the Kung Pao Pastrami. A bit salty. Also had the pork belly and pork jowel. I liked those, but again, over salted. Shared tables...I'm indifferent about those. Some people didn't like it. I guess I came here with huge expectations, and then left feeling disappointed. If I come back, I'll try something else and hopefully it's not too salty.
author: Michael M.

description:
This is where all the cool kids hang out and the food is unique. However, it is a disgusting hole in the wall, expensive and in a unpleasant section of Mission Street. 

The funny thing is that you forget how gross the street is because the restaurant is even worse!  It is like a soup kitchen or something, but worse because you have to pay exorbitant prices for food and eat at gross laminated tables with torn vinyl chairs surrounded by half burned out Christmas lights and really bad poster art of horses without any service. 

Are people this desperate for a good meal???
author: Jaimie O.

description:
I was visiting from out of town and my friend who lives in SF suggested coming here so I pretty much had no expectations. I thought we were just going to a regular Chinese restaurant. So when we did go, I was pleasantly surprised by the unique menu and combinations.

Hot Chicken Wings - these were definitely too spicy. It was coated with chili powder and I think Anise. The flavor was numbing and didn't taste good at all. All you could taste was the powder. There was not a lot of meat on the chicken wings and they were pretty dry.

Thrice Cooked Bacon - this was my favorite dish. There was a decent amount of bacon bits and it was an interesting combination with the rice cakes. Great flavor. I could've eaten the whole thing by myself.

Baby Bok Choy with Popcorn broth - this was good but nothing interesting or spectacular. Not sure why it was called "Popcorn" broth? Didn't taste like "popcorn" to me *scratching head*

Sliced Peanut Noodles - this was a very simple dish but pretty good. This is a cold dish.

Overall, I think the food was good but some of the dishes were more on the pricey side for food that you can get at typical Chinese restaurants. There were still a lot of things on the menu that I didn't get to try but would like to so curious to see how they taste :)

I thought it was pretty clever how they turned what a normal Chinese take out/fast food type restaurant and took it to the next level. Yes, very tacky and over the top but creative. The service was pretty good as well.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Okay FINE a begrudging update for M. I like the food. It's very, very salty, but I still like it. 

I still don't like hipsters.
author: Mandy H.

description:
WHAT A HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT-_-

I was so excited to finally go to this place and my excitement only grew with every thirty minutes that passed. Waited for about and a half and my excitement quickly dwindled down.

We ordered the pork belly, the roll with the unagi, the salty fish rice, and ma pao tofu. 

The pork belly was super tender, but wayyyy too sweet. I am okay with fat, but if you don't like fat... This is a for sure pass.  First bite .. Not too impressed... On to the next dish

The roll- everyone rants and raves about this.. One bite, and I knew it was going to be a quick downward spiral. It was SO salty, there was barely any unagi in it and i am a fan on Chinese celery but it was just too tough and made it difficult to eat.

The rice- where was the salty cod? If I knew it was going to just be Chinese sausage rice, I would have made it myself. Definitely would not have paid 10 for a rice that costs less than 2 to make. 

The tofu- chunks of tofu in an extremely oily, inedible slosh. We literally took the tofu out and wiped it down with a napkin. There was barely any pork belly in it- max two tiny pieces. No vegetables and seriously what the hell was that sauce? It was disgusting and I have no idea why people  order it... But props to you for tricking me. 

God it was horrible and was such a waste of 2 hours... The only thing I liked about that place was the music. So bravo on the good music taste because you sure as hell don't have good taste in food. 

I think this place... Correction, this place IS over hyped and people have that preconceived notion that it is going to be the best Chinese food they have ever had.... When in actuality, The insanely long wait, caused mild hallucinations from the hunger which probably caused people to just gorge their food down without actually tasting it and/or they went to drink while waiting bc they can and were already buzzed by the time they ate( we saw at least 5 groups in this stage).... Which ever the reason, mission Chinese you succeeded at tricking me to believe you were good, so bravo... I wish I could have just wiped that whole experience from my mind.

Ughh
author: Jenny T.

description: Don't be fooled by the outward appearance.... Step in and the food will not disappoint! Don't miss the  lamb dumplings or the squid noodles.
author: Teresa M.

description: A must-try dining experience.  Very inventive menu with enough choices for everyone.  They use a variety of ingredients you wont see at other Chinese restaurants. To my liking,  they use a lot of spicy peppers as well.  The amount of people waiting for a table outside may be daunting but the list moves pretty quickly.
author: Nicholas P.

description:
This place is definitely getting a lot of attention! Yes, it's a dive but in a really, really good way! You get cozy with your neighbors, listen to some hip background music, enjoy an awesome unpretentious dining experience, and you don't break the bank. Simple in so many ways yet that's not to say the food itself is anything even close to simple! 

It was recently reviewed in the NY Times: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/29/magazine/mark-bittman-san-franciscos-new-pop-up-restaurant.html?pagewanted=all 

My 2 fav dishes were: 
----------------------------------- 
- The vegetarian dish with Korean rice cakes 
- The tofu dish 

Nothing like anything I've ever had before. You really have to try it out for yourself to see what I mean. 

Somehow, I managed to score a table here on a Saturday early evening with 3 other friends. The wait wasn't more than 30 mins. 

Also, they take cards and the service is VERY accommodating.
author: Kathy S.

description:
Tasty Chinese food with a twist. Go early, it gets busy. 

Fantastic pork belly. Excellent thrice cooked bacon and kung pao pastrami.
author: Stan L.

description:
Meh.

Yes, unusual combinations. I can appreciate the creativity. But was this place good? Not really. 

Sorry.
author: Tara S.

description: Maybe this place was just too hyped up for me or we didn't order the right things but it was just OK. Maybe esp. since I am Chinese everything just seems a tad overpriced too. We are in hipster-ville after all. I don't think I'll return anytime soon since I feel like I can get items similar to the menu elsewhere for cheaper.
author: Emily C.

description: I'm a past lover, now a "meh"-er. Certainly was interesting and new for a hot minute, but now honestly it all tastes the same. This is Chinese food with the Asian food angle removed: no tang to offset the richness of pork, no sweet to balance the salty. Just salty and rich. Why not just eat French at that point?
author: Michael G.

description:
A big disappointment. 

I get that they are "different" than the traditional chinese food. They make chinese food with kind of an American twist, but overall the food was just not good. 

The rock cod fried rice was pretty plain, and salty, I've definitely had better in Chinatown.

The ma po tofu was honestly kinda gross. (and ma po tofu is one of my favorite dishes!) It was super oily for no reason, and had a strange flavor that was a cross between mint, basil, fennel, and chili. I dunno it was weird. I've had good weird stuff in my life, and this was not good weird. 

General Tso's Veal Rib, sounds good right? Nope! the outside was hard like burnt hard, but it didn't have the good burnt flavor, and once you got through the hard exterior, the meat was over cooked and tough. To top it off, the entire rib was bone. For $18 there wasn't even 1/8 a pound of meat on it! WTF. 

Overall, overrated and way too pricy for the bad tasting food. Sorry yelp, I know I'm in the minority here.
author: Jamie T.

description: This place is a strange high-end(ish) hipster twist on greasy Chinese food. The whole restaurant is dark, with only glowing red light to illuminate the inside. They have Beach House and your typical dream pop artists playing. Not your typical Chinese place, and definitely not something you expect from the outside. Anyway. Lamb dumplings were great; whodathunk tzatziki and dumplings. Definitely always get the Chongqing chicken wings. They don't lie about the numbing, but it's not from being too spicy. Maybe even order two, because the serving is a bit small. Filipino garlic fried chicken is interesting. It's got the element of grease that you know and love (like, coat your mouth greasy), and the vinegar sauce is super vinegary. Separately they are each too much, but the acidity of the vinegar cuts the greasiness and really adds to the dish. It's a hit or miss, depending on you. About $40 for the three dishes.
author: Jacqueline K.

description: Delicious! Squid ink noodles with lamb, pork rib, broccoli with brisket... OMG!  Will definitely be back! Smooth and easy!
author: Lindsay H.

description:
This place kind of defies definition.  I think that some of the individual dishes are fairly authentic but definitely not a traditional restaurant, as there is a wide variety of dishes, from handmade noodles, to fried rice and southern BBQ.  (err wut?) 

The southern BBQ plate simply must be eaten.  It is authentic texas style slow smoked brisket and sausage... how strange, in a chinese place, but it was GOOD.  My wife, who grew up in Texas confirms, this is sadly one of the better BBQ joints in the bay area, and just for this one dish.  Crazy.  sweet and spicy sauce (a little sweeter than is typical of TX) but yum!  deep smoke rings on the brisket.  

We also had a lamb cheek noodle dish that was pure sichuan style.  YUM.  The bits of meat were all things that many westerners would just toss out or make into head cheese, but they are the best part of the animal, just the choice bits of meat, with the associated gristle, etc torn off already.  PACKED with flavor... this dish was no joke spicy as well.  Both of us were panting but kept going back for more, because it was not only spicy but extremely complex from the cilantro to the lamb, and the pungent sauce... and the noodles.  Perfection.  I could have eaten a whole portion of this, but I think my stomach lining may not have tolerated it.  I like spicy food and this was a perfect example of being spicy and tasty at the same time, not just spicy for the sake of being spicy.

The salt cod fried rice was fantastic too.  I mean, it's called SALT cod fried rice, you gotta expect it to be intensely salty.  This was some of the best fried rice I've had, it had a perfectly chewy texture with bits of crunchy rice and the salty mild fish flavor.  Surprisingly, this had a decent amount of depth to it, not just salty.  You could still taste the delicate cod flavors along with the various spices...  yum!

Overall, I had a really positive experience here, but I can see how things may be difficult as it's fairly busy and service can be a touch spotty (but for the price, you really can't complain!)    

I would probably have given this a 4.5 but I enjoyed it so much, I want to balance out some of the negative reviews...  I mean, you gotta go here with the right expectations.  It's a very busy place, it's a bit dark and cramped and doesn't have a white-table cloth feel at all.  It's got tons of flavor, tons of character and it's fairly cheap, so order a bunch and take home what you don't eat.  I really enjoyed my lunch here and will definitely come back.
author: Kit W.

description: I liked this place!  Their food was unique from cherry coke ribs to kung pao pastrami but everything we ordered was pretty tasty and I would recommend any of it (salted cod fried rice, ma pa tofu, bacon and rice cakes and the previously mentioned items).  It was a little on the spicy side though, and the servers were not the best at refilling our water pitcher.  But I would definitely go back... We went slightly early to beat the dinner crowd and it worked out really well!
author: Sonia S.

description:
In the Ying and Yang of restaurant exploration, there is a balance between expectations and reality.  If the reality beats expectations, then it can be a glorious experience.  Over time and through additional experiences, you reach a kind of equilibrium.  I call it the realm of the "old standby", where although you may not be overly excited by the 10th visit, you are nevertheless never disappointed, and always leave happy.

Then there's the other side, where expectations are so blown out of proportion, there is absolutely no way that reality can ever meet, let alone exceed, that level of anticipation and excitement.  This is quite simply not fair to the diner, or to the chef who may have had a completely different philosophy as to what his/her restaurant was all about.  In this era of fast media, instant gratification, and yes...user developed reviews (Yelp, I'm talking about you), we are all guilty of participating in, and exacerbating the situation.  Of this, I am also guilty.

Chef Bowein started Mission Chinese, from my understanding, to turn the traditional Chinese restaurant theme on its head...but do it tongue in cheek, or with a wink and a smile.  What can be more subversive than taking over a Chinese dive restaurant, giving it a secret name, that's not so secret, and meld Sichuan methodology and spices with non-Chinese ingredients like pastrami...yet give diners a real taste of what Sichuan food is really like.  Wow....my head just exploded thinking about it...

...and that's the problem.  Already the expectations of being surprised or even shocked, it's really unachievable.

I know that in the beginning, this all must have been subversive, if not revolutionary, if not for the fact that, especially in the Bay Area, a good chunk of us have had authentic Sichuan cuisine (or Hunan cuisine, Cantonese cuisine, etc.) so the particular riff on flavors has a familiarity to it that doesn't scream "revolutionary".  Notwithstanding that, I guess the intent was that the way it is all put together, and the "atmospherics" of the dining experience would give it a little cultural kick.  But I'm sure those aspects get enhanced by the 6th Tsingtao.

Trust me, I like dives, but a little more light, and cleaner path to the restrooms, let alone cleaner restrooms, wouldn't hurt the dining experience or the cultural milieu.

So what's the bottom line:  Mapo Tofu:  has that characteristic tongue numbing of Sichuan peppercorns, but otherwise, is not surprising or revolutionary.  The Smashed Cucumbers in Garlic Sauce was surprisingly bland, with hardly a hint of garlic.  The Chongqing Chicken Wings were good...would go great with a couple of beers, but was also on the mild side for my taste (after all, this is Sichuan cooking we're talking about...this is spicy wings we're talking about).

The Kung Pao Pastrami was spicy, but exceedingly salty.  Being that pastrami is brined to begin with, careful salt control is a must.  It must have been missing on my visit.  The same went for the braised beef noodle soup...which was so salty, we had to add about a 1/2 glass of water to the soup...and ask anyone who knows me....I'm not gentle with my seasoning.

I don't know what to say other than disappointed.  But I'm not sure I have the restaurant to blame or the concept itself.  The fact is, Chef Bowein has blown-up, to use a new media phrase, and there's no going back....not even to the nascent days of Mission Chinese's opening.  Whatever was there in the beginning has now been lost in the morass of expectations, and you can't ever get that back.  On the other hand, had this been a restaurant opening in the San Gabriel Valley in Southern California, I don't think Anthony Bourdain would have come calling.  So you got to take what you can take and run with it.  More power to you.

Put it in the Mission, however, call it by a name that isn't really its name, and invite the Mission hipsters to eat there, and you have a cultural phenomena.  I get that....I respect that....but that doesn't mean disappointment can't happen.

I'm hoping Chef comes back...does a little tinkering....and doesn't forget that in this new media world, expectations bring you up, and can make you come crashing down.

And a few more light bulbs can't hurt.
author: James K.

description:
Highly recommend for both dine in and take out. Dining in is more of an interesting experience rather than really well done, but it's a great place to take friends from out of town. Hidden in the mission with a sign that doesn't say mission Chinese, you could almost call it the speakeasy of Chinese food.

The food is the real highlight of this place. Must get the thrice cooked rice cakes and bacon - it's incredible. Delivery is awesome too at only like $4.
author: Milan T.

description: Great chinese food. Not authentic obviously, but very imaginative and delicious. Mapo tofu is fantastic, as is General Tso Veal, and bacon. Love that they deliver, although a little expensive for chinese food. Will be a go to for my friends and family.
author: Anthony D.

description:
I love mission chinese...takeout. The food is very spicy, my preference. Try the chongqing wings, coated with sichuan peppers and other spices and toped with dry, red peppers. You can taste the citrus component as your mouth tingles from the sichuan peppers. The skin on the wings was dry fried, crispy outside and juicy inside. Lovely!
The kung pao pastrami is a nice riff on the chicken favorite, peppers again running the show and married with the fatty pastrami.
The pickles are a sweet/sour flavor bomb, a nice segue between the entrees.
I liked the succulence of the sliced peanut noodles, slippery and saucey.
Call ahead and your food will f waiting in 25 minutes. We had full meals X 3 for about $30! A real mission value.
author: Kelly K.

description: I wanted to say that I'm Chinese and visit asia/hong kong every year. I grew up having very traditional cantonese dishes at home. My parents worked in the restaurant industry and close family friends were experts in Shanghainese dimsum or purveyors or the best roast duck in San Francisco. So... my boyfriend says he wants to have mission chinese and I say.. HMMM okay (after many discussion regarding authentic chinese food). I would have to say it was tasty but it wasn't really chinese food. I coined it "ironic chinese food". This is because I believe it was tasty and very reminiscent of certain key flavors of chinese food (and very authentic chinese food) but they used ingredients that were non traditional. The place/decor was almost like if a Saturday Night Live cast put together a parody skit on chinese food. Hence "Ironic Chinese Food". It was good. Ask for recommendations. My favorite was the the fried hamachi kama.
author: Wanster L.

description: This is the worst Chinese restaurant ever. I ordered  noodles and the food was literally full of hair. I'm pretty sure that this restaurant doesn't pass the hygiene standards (if you want to convince yourself just go to the restroom and take a look at the kitchen). After I complained they didn't even apologize or brought another dish. 100% NOT recommended.
author: Isadora N.

description:
I was told that the Chinese food here better than China. I disagree, but the food is still okay.

+ interesting ambiance - paper dragon hanging from the ceiling; red mood lighting; romantic Christmas tree lights...BUT with Eminem music blaring and cafeteria tables / chairs
+ fast service
+ ma po tofu - very spicy, but quite delicious and well cooked

- kung pao pastrami - I didn't really like the pastrami in the dish; however, I thought the potatoes slices were cooked really well.
author: Margaret R.

description: this place sucks man everything tastes like rubber i felt like i had a mouthful of rubber bands while i was eating the noodles what a horrible sensation!!!!
author: Poop M.

description:
I know very little about San Francisco restaurants, but when I went up for a weekend in mid-March, I had the name "Mission Chinese" rattling around in my head.  I guess this place has some destination value, and I'd visit again if I had the chance.

I came for a late dinner on a Friday night with a party of three.  We put our name down and waited outside in the mild San Francisco cold.  The wait was bearable - I think it was something like 20 minutes, extended because our third took his time showing up.  Once we were in, we got a moderately shitty table in one of the two glass-walled corner pockets adjacent to the doorway.  I sat against a window, presenting my back to the street.  The ambiance was kind of fun.  The restaurant was dim, tiny, and very busy.  The servers were pierced and Mission hip, as was much of the crowd.  Service was decent, fast and available.  We weren't forgotten.

The food was excellent.  We ate family style and ordered four dishes for three people.  It was a lot of food, which we only came close to finishing because of my MVP vacation appetite.  My favorite dish was the salt cod fried rice, which came with mackerel confit, Chinese sausage, lettuce, and egg.  It was fluffy and wonderful, delightfully salty, with bits of fish and sausage to add their meaty substance.  I also loved the thrice cooked bacon.  It was hefty with some great chew, and it was severely smokey in a way that I rather enjoyed.  One of my friends said it tasted like he was smoking a cigarette, but I don't think he meant that in a bad way.  The bacon came with bitter melon, tofu skin, chili oil, and plenty of floppy, supple Shanghainese rice cakes that moderated some of that strong flavor.  The tiki pork belly was another good dose of pig, a sweet one to counteract all the salt and smoke.  The pork belly was cooked soft and fatty with a soy caramel, and it came with mandarin orange, pickled pineapple, shaved coconut, and macadamia nuts.  The only overtly spicy dish we ordered was the Mongolian long beans.  These were quite spicy, but very enjoyable as a side.  They were a little bit doused in chili oil, but I liked the firm texture and the mix of Xinjiang spices and horseradish really delivered a kick.

I washed down this feast with a $4 21st Amendment IPA, which hit the spot.  I think I spent a little under $40 on this meal, which is a lot for Chinese food, not too much for a destination dinner.  I was happy with the food, and would visit fairly often if I lived in the area.  It's apparently great for take-out, and I imagine many San Franciscans have Mission Chinese in their contacts.
author: Steph C.

description:
Having read the articles about the place, watched Bourdain come here and rave about the place, and listened to other glowing reviews, I was moderately disappointed. 

I ordered the tea smoked eel and Mapo Tofu. The tofu contained a gigantic amount of tofu-- which can be a good thing if it is adequately offset with plenty of sauce and flavor. My biggest complaint was that it seemed too tofu heavy and lacked contrasting textures. Perhaps I'm not too big of a tofu by itself fan, so this could be a positive for other people. 

I did appreciate how plenteous the peppers were in the tofu. It was quite spicy-- very much akin to actual Sichuan-style Mapo Tofu. They put the flower peppers in to make your tongue numb as well. 

As far as the tea smoked eel, I thought this dish was one of the most unique items I've ever sampled. The rice wrapper was reminiscent of a dim sum item, the eel evoked the taste of sushi, and the hoisin/peanut sauce flavor made me think it was a Vietnamese spring roll. I thought it was very well done and was almost a tour of Asian flavors in one dish. 

The prices are pretty reasonable for the amount of food that they give, the servers are friendly and the ambience is somewhat hipster. Id come here if you're seeking fusion flavors, not your traditional Chinese.
author: Neal C.

description:
I'm sad to say that Mission Chinese Food did not live up to the hype. I wanted so badly to love this place, after all I'd heard. The tiki pork belly had come highly recommended, and this did not disappoint.  It was perfectly prepared, and the fusion flavors of nuts, cheese, and sweet soy were surprising and delicious. It was the first item that arrived, and I just about squealed when I saw the paper umbrella sticking out of the spicy piece of fresh pineapple. The ma-po tofu, though--bad, bad, bad, bad, bad!  I have been to China several times, and have studied Chinese cooking. Artistic license is one thing--the traditional dish uses ground pork--this version had a scant few chunks of cubed pork that turned eating the dish into a "find the meat" expedition. 

Worse than this, however, was that the dish was completely redolent of Szechuan peppercorns. Yes, the dish was *hot*, but made authentically, that is to be expected. The Gweilo roaming the Mission might have a problem with this, but the heat was not something I took issue with. The extreme assault on my tastebuds by dozens upon dozens of Szechuan peppercorns was inexcusable.  The recipe I have used for 20 years, is plenty hot and seasoned, and calls for *1/2 teaspoon* of crushed Szechuan peppercorns. 

The pickled long beans were just OK. I love long beans, and found that this preparation did nothing for them.

I would give this place another chance, but I would only eat what came recommended by friends and Yelpers instead of playing the menu equivalent of "pin the tail on the donkey".
author: Michele W.

description:
Not bad. A bit overpriced in my opinion-- some interesting stuff, such as the eel wrap (I forget the name), but not really to my taste preferences. 
My friend, on the other hand, loves this place, so maybe it's just me.
author: Alice ..

description: Came here because last time I walked by there was a huge line. Bookmarked it and decided to give it a try. The menu is an interesting take on Chinese food- like broccoli beef brisket, tea smoked eel roll. The food was good and came fast. Portions are pretty big so don't order too much like we did- hard not to try it all. Bill was a little pricey for what it was. Might come back, but more likely to try more new places.
author: Joe M.

description: Asi-asi. Pricey. Good music initially- sonic youth, Tubeway army, the specials...but as we were leavin it turned into some lame Gwen stefani pop crap. Dug the salted cod rice and would get Chinese greens less the meat. Spicy chow mein was tasty!
author: Shi T.

description:
my initial impression of the decor was wow this is great. it looks like an old chinese mom and pop restaurant was taken over and had asian type latern streamers along the ceiling with very stereotypical looking asian paintings that don't look very high in quality haha. i was digging it tho. then it started filling in with people. it seemed like their clientele were mostly trendy hipster types. which is cool, i just thought it was a really isolated crowd. hoped it would be a place for all types. just my opinion i suppose, doesn't really matter.

me and a friend got the chicken wings, kung pao pistrami, eel roll, and salt cod fried rice. first thing's first. you can get just as good of chinese food at a mom and pop for a lot cheaper for the same if not better quality... this is an introduction of real-er chinese food for americans. it's not bad at all, just not up to my standards of chinese food especially for the price. 

so the eel roll was supposed to be tea smoked but i really didn't even get a nuance of tea flavor. the sauce was sweet not much unlike the sauce for eel in the fashion of sush. i think there was also parsley and sticks of celery in it. the celery is a strong flavor but when all components are eaten together i think it really works and is balanced. the part i don't agree on is the "sticks" of celery. they are so fiberous that it's hard to take a clean bite without dragging along the rest of the stick. a little hard to eat. 

the kung pao pistrami is very tastey. it's pistrami so expect it to have a good salt level. i wish it was A LOT spicier and the peanuts were like a fine crumble. wish it had whole peanuts for a satisfying crunch factor. also, i narrowed down a freezer burn taste to these super tender chunks of fat. i wish it didn't taste a little like freezer but piece after piece it was confirmed. they were still tasty haha.

salt cod fried rice salty? yes salty, freaking duh! not overly salty for me. had some thin slices of chinese sausage that i appreciated. like everything i had here it wasn't mindblowing. it was good though, but nothing you couldn't find at a more authentic place not to mention cheaper.

finally the chicken wings. they weren't salty like some reviews i saw. they weren't spicy, despite the pool of dried fried chiles that were scattered around the plate. they had a homemade 5-spice flavor that made every initial bite for me unbecomingly SWEET. too much sugar in that mix. this dish was the most subtle out of all the ones we tried. very "meh" as "they" say.

i also had their custom beer. i was going to get a tsing tao for 3.50 then got sold on their beer that was 9.00. big difference. took a gamble and lost. i wish i got the tsing tao. it wasn't bad, but sour and i would've preferred my first choice.

i'd probably not choose to come here again, but i finally got some closure over a place a lot of my friends have all talked about. i'd still roll through if someone else wanted to go tho.
author: Eugene H.

description: I am never picky with food, but the salt content of the dishes made it impossible to eat even a third of my food. Not authentic, but fusion food. I kept chewing on clumps of salt in a already oversalted dishes. Sadly, will not be returning :(
author: Karen P.

description: Food deserves 5 stars as it was incredible and came out very quickly. My gripe is with the staff- quite rude and when we noticed that they had charged $166 on a card instead of $66 they looked at us with utter contempt instead of apologising for their mistake! Would go back for the food in the hope for nicer staff.
author: Jessica R.

description: Alas, the food was not tasty! It all looked great but the seasoning is so heavy handed we might as well have eaten salt straight up.  We ordered long beans, thrice cooked bacon w/rice cake, lamb rib special and beef tartare. The tartare was topped with so much fish-sauce-jelly that we couldn't taste anything else. It was just icky. Lots of leftovers which we didn't take with us...couldn't bring ourselves to even give it to a homeless person (it would have been mean). And of the 4 women working the room exactly one was not an a-hole. Food came quickly in no particular order but waited 15 minutes for a check. I know they cater to the hipsters but honestly this was just all around bad.
author: Ann B.

description: Incredibly overrated.  The food tastes like the type of chinese cuisine that an asian baby adopted by white parents would produce once that baby was fully grown.  This food is not quite Chinese and not quite identifiable as Chinese fusion.  Confusing, muddled flavor profiles, and overpriced for what it is.
author: David C.

description:
I was very skeptical of entering this restaurant, since it's located in a rather seedy neighborhood and the restaurant entirely lit by red lamps gave it an eerie glow reminiscient of the red light district.  Not to mention we had to endure a 30 minute wait to be seated.

I wasn't expecting very much in terms of food, but I was pleasantly surprised.  I recommend getting the thrice cooked bacon (they have a vegan option as well) and the cod salted fried rice.  They go so well together!  The steamed pork belly was very good too, although I couldn't eat more than one because it was so rich in fat and meat.

I also had a Mexican Coke here for the first time, and I liked it!  They give it to you in the classic glass bottle which is big enough to be shared by two people.

If you like Chinese food with a kick, then you should definitely check this out.  The crowd is also predominantly Caucasian, so it definitely made its news through a diverse population.
author: Caroline K.

description:
Super tasty Chinese food. 

If a friend hadn't forced me to go to mission Chinese I probably wouldn't have gone. From the outside you wouldn't know that this place serves such good food. But after my first bite I knew what it was all about. The dishes are carefully prepared and very savory. Bonus points for seating us next to an Asian woman who was preparing fresh, fragrant herbs throughout out meal.
author: Adam K.

description:
"Mouth Watering Chicken"

I'll say it was, my mouth was watering as I tried to hold back from throwing up from the food poisoning I got from this place. Mouth Watering Chicken was a cold dish unfortunately the menu failed to mention that. The chicken had a weird texture that was similar to liver, dry and pasty. The dish was also had a pungent flavor, not exactly good. The chicken hearts were juicy but pungent as well. 

They did get 1 stars because that is the lowest we could go and in their defense the Tiki Pork was actually good but the presentation was totally cheesy...like paper umbrella cheesy. I could have done without that. 

The other dish was orange chicken, not really Chinese, not like you could mess that up. 

All in all 2 out of 3 dishes were good but my wife and I both ended up sick to our stomachs and could not even make it out the hotel for dinner. Basically ruined our trip. I guess that's what we get for trusting any hipster's review of this place. 

I think it's safe to say we will not be going back,,,,,
author: Oliver S.

description: After reading and hearing so much about this place, I thought I would give it a try.  After ordering online and waiting 45 minutes, my Kung Pao burrito arrived. It was overly salty, missing the home fries, and nothing like I expected. I may try other items off the menu BUT never the burrito.
author: Thomas B.

description:
I know this famed Danny Bowien restaurant has received great reviews from the press, but I just don't understand?!?!  I went into this experience not expecting a legit Chinese restaurant, so please don't think I set unrealistic expectations.  It's just that it was such a confusing experience.  Inside it looked like a cheap Chinese restaurant with its chipped bowls and plates, mismatched furniture and cutlery, but for Friday night dinner they turned off the lights except for some Christmas lights hung around the walls, blasted top-40s clubbing music, and employed some inattentive young hipster waiters to serve us.  

The food was fine.  3x the price of a regular Chinese restaurant, for quality that is only 1.25 times more refined.  I understand that this is one of those places you "have to try" because it's just so damn popular in SF and you need to see what all the fuss is about.  I wouldn't stand in ghetto-ass mission for nearly 2 hours again to eat here again.. Hell I wouldn't eat here again regardless because it's too expensive for what it is.  But if you're like me (curious as a cat) and have to try this place, I would recommend:

- Tiki Pork Belly: solid pork belly portion size, very fatty, tasty tangy, sweet sauce that's good consistency
- Westlake Rice Porridge: big bowl of porridge, great savory broth witha a sizable portion of dungeness crab

Everything else I tried was forgettable or not good at all.
author: Anna T.

description:
The food was interesting, different, and overall tasty. 

My issue is with the service. Two different hostesses were so rude and inconsiderate that my friends and I thought we were on a hidden camera show, because it was so unbelievable. I have never written a restaurant review before but I had to share how nasty these hostesses were. Luckily, we had an apologetic waiter who didn't look surprised when we told him our experience. The positive from this (I won't bore you with the details) is that it has made an incredible story to tell friends.
author: Andrea Z.

description:
The modestly-named Mission Chinese Food offers up some damn tasty Chinese food. That said, in a town where you can get plenty of damn tasty regional Chinese food in settings that range from small dives to hip and trendy eateries with craft cocktails, I'm not sure I'd return here. 

I'm a vegetarian, so take this review as you will. I tried: the spicy pickled peanuts, sauteed baby bok choy and thrice cooked "bacon" rice cakes (props to them for making a vegetarian version). The peanuts have interesting vinegar and spicy flavors and are rather irresistible. The bok choy is cooked well, but I actually had far tastier bok choy the next day at Fang (and I make fantastic bok choy myself). I was really disappointed in the thrice cooked bacon rice cakes which promised my favorite thing to eat in the world: tofu skin (it's impossible to find in New Orleans, so I make sure to hit up places in SF and NY who do have it). The dish contained exactly three tiny pieces of tofu skin buried in a massive amount of oily, oh-so-damn-oily, chewy rice cakes. I'll hold to my initial claim of "damn tasty," but also wayyyy too oily in a bad way. Could this be an isolated occurrence? I don't think anyone else mentions the lack of tofu skin, so it's possible.

Prices are fair and despite the more dark/divey Shanghai den kind of thing they have going on, it's, as you've probably guessed, not a dive at all. For example, divey Chinese restos don't typically serve Cava by the bottle, so yay! Note that they don't serve it in a bucket of ice and the bottle was already not icy cold, so our waiter kindly put it in the fridge and refilled our glasses for us when they were empty. He was awesome, btw, despite having a packed restaurant to work in.

I just wasn't blown away by anything I ordered, though after months of being deprived of damn tasty Chinese food, I nearly devoured everything that was placed in front of me. That happens to me whenever I'm confronted with decent Chinese, let's be real. I guess I'm on the fence. I'm in NYC far more regularly than SF, so maybe I'd give it another try. It's an extremely creative menu for sure.
author: Joi B.

description:
The parking here is horrible, had to spin around for half an hour to luckly find a space 4 blocks away. The neighborhood is dirty, 4 people asked me for money and other stuff just going there. 

The place was packed. Going there we got there early so only had to wait 20 minutes, but as we were leaving could see another 15 people waiting at the door. This place wasn't made for big groups, so if you have more than 4 people go somewhere else or sit separately.

We ordered the picked vegetables which wasn't really anything special but a spicy cabbage with a cucumber and peanuts. We got the pork belly which was like the stuff at other Chinese BBQ places but when bitting into it, all the juices and oil releases into your mouth. 

Our cumin lamb tasted like an Indian lamb plate, nothing special. The Ma Po tufu was really something special. The taste was very different from the traditional no matter how many times one has tried it at how many different places.
author: M C.

description: Always a great takeout! Ordered around 6:30 & food was delivered to our door within 45 mins. We had a delicious combination this time round - thrice cooked bacon & broccoli beef. The spicyness of the bacon was tamed by the broccoli. Yum!
author: Nicole E.

description:
Not only is there food poor to mediocre their service was absolutely abysmal.

Some of their food is passable. The thrice cooked bacon (which mysteriously was labeled as having a vegan option) was edible.
