A chimpanzee could make better mapo tofu than what this excuse for a restaurant managed to conjure. The mouth watering chicken made my mouth water with vomit.

Unlike every other Chinese restaurant in existence Mission Chinese Food does not include a basic bowl of rice with your purchase of an entree. Each bowl of rice is an additional $1.

If the service was passable perhaps I could have excused the underwhelming food. Service as virtually non-existent. We had to get up to get our own water. In the end the waitress refused to split our check her excuse being that it was too much work. Their language was rude and attitude lazy.

After all of this they added a 25% gratuity to the check. That's right: 25% for service even McDonalds could out do.

All in all I would recommend avoiding this restaurant.
author: K P.

description:
I enjoyed this Sichuan fusion joint when it was still opened in NYC. Upon coming to San Francisco, I had to try it because it was the first location right?

We almost walked past it beacuse it doesnt say "MISSION CHINESE FOOD" but a facade as some basic Chinese restaurant.

The menu was the same and my friend and I ordered the usual, salted cod friend rice , smashed cucumbers and the chicken wings.

I wasn't a big fan of the chicken wings because it was fried, other than that it was hella good.

The fried rice was the best off that menu.
author: Danny Y.

description:
Honestly, overated and not worth the money. 

I have been here twice now, and I have ordered the must have dishes in addition to some new dishes they added to the menu. 

The dishes were either really salty or way to overdone with spices...points for innovation and creativity are important, but hey you want to actually enjoy your meal. If the bok choy in miso soup is the best of the dishes, you are wasting money.

Will definitely not be making the same mistake a third time.
author: BostoFranciscan L.

description: I came here for dinner after seeing the restaurant on a travel/food show. We ordered the squid ink noodles and the salt cod fried rice. The noodles were very different from anything we've had before, so it's hard to explain, but we were just okay with it. Not bad, not good, just different. The rice was good, but very little sausage or ingredients, just rice. Luckily, I love rice so I was happy. The ambiance was fun with upbeat music, bright red lighting, huge dragons above your head, and really great service. Glad we tried it once, but probably won't be back.
author: Heather A.

description: Food's good. A bit overpriced, but almost everything in the area is. The staff is friendly and speaks Cantonese.
author: William W.

description:
3.5 stars is the correct rating for this place. Eat for a good cause. Food is up to par.

Venue: A ghetto style Chinese restaurant that serves semi fusion Chinese food. Many times you have to share the tables with another group. Isn't the most romantic place to take a date. Very dim lighting though. Usually packed. Waited only 15min for a table for two on a tuesday night.

Service: Friendly staff. Waiters sometimes seem too busy.

Food:
Tea smoked eel (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=NMIsSWMBcaX-hyDcdJDj0Q) - $9 Smoky flavored eel and chinese celery wrapped in Chinese rice noodles. I liked this one. Something I never had anywhere else. Can't say I loved it.

Thrice cooked bacon (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=GvcIapr5hLNE4I5idq_B0w) - $11 This one was mildly spicy. Thick bacon stir fried with chili peppers and rice cakes. Very few pieces of bitter melon and tofu skin. Flavor was good.

Slow cooked pork belly (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=nUYUHKIdCYA9H5Gh-7TyPg) - This one I cared the least of... It didn't taste very slow cooked. The pork belly was fatty but hard on the outside in a not very pleasant way. I liked the semi spicy pineapples it came with though.

Kung pao pastrami (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sW7WYYrHEvR8yEYxautAgQ?select=dZ1tCvyLOwZCZ1UulJKkbg) - $11 Be prepared for burning and numbing lips. Also, make sure you have a full jug of water next to you... Basically stir fried meat with peanuts (I liked the peanuts), chili peppers, sliced potatoes and a side of rice. If you like spicy, this is the one to try.

Price: okay... Let just say a portion ($.75) of eat dish is being donated for a good cause.

Overall: not sure if I will be coming back anytime soon. I liked it but didn't love it.
author: Jannifer H.

description:
This place is ridiculously overhyped. I always see people check in to this place on Facebook all excited to try it out and it makes me weep.

This is not your ordinary Chinese restaurant. They try a lot of weird recipes that probably cater to all the hipsters in the Mission.

I came here with a group for lunch once and we ordered a variety of dishes. We just went with whatever sounded appealing by description including the ma po tofu, kung pao pastrami, and the chicken wings, among other things. The tofu plate itself was okay, but I cringed listening to the waiter try to pronounce it (he said something like may-poo) yet act like he was an expert on Chinese cuisine. For the pastrami dish, there was hardly any pastrami to be found and we all dug our utensils through it just to dig anything out that we could find. The chicken wings were insanely thin and had no meat in them, yet had a lot of spicy powder splattered all over them which made eating them unbearable with the aftertaste of powder in your mouth. Two thirds of the chicken wing plate was just filled with chili too.

For the small amount of food we were able to pick out from the plates, we still had to pay $13 per person. And with the short staff, it took a while for us to get our bill.

One plus though- we did see a kid here who looked exactly like Harry Potter. That gave us a good laugh while we waited forever for the bill.
author: Allen C.

description:
A hole in the wall Chinese restaurant with unusual cuisine on Mission. Good news is we were able to get a table with minimal wait at 6 on a Friday. 

The decor is typical hole-in-the-wall Chinese -- mini-lights on wall, paper dragon hanging across the ceiling, portraits of wild horses and leaders on the wall.

We had the much touted cod fried rice and pastrami stir fry. Both were good for their uniqueness though I cannot say I prefer either to standard hunan fare.

Worth a visit for its uniqueness but not sure we will return.
author: Brad B.

description: The food is good and I should say "different". You should go, purely for the experience! Loud music (hip hop/ class rock), in a run-down chinese spot, red lighting, cheap beer & 3 choices of wine. Love Mission Chinese Food concept (read about the chef).
author: Ava A.

description:
Named one of Bon Appétit's Best New Restaurants in America, I was instantly curious!  My friend and I wanted to catch up over a meal and she mentioned this place - perfect!  This place must be busy all day everyday - we thought we were getting there early for dinner at 6PM on a Monday evening.  It was packed!  We sat at the end of a long table shared with other small parties, and we ordered up.  

Friends and Yelp had great suggestions on what was good so we got: cold dan dan noodles (woo spicy, made me sweat, could not focus on the taste because felt too self-conscious sitting there sweating, haha), hainam chicken rice (pretty good), salt cod fried rice (one of my favorite dishes of the night, great flavor, wanted more), sizzling cumin lamb (pretty good), broccoli beef cheek (another favorite of the night, yummy lovely fatty taste, a couple of oysters mixed in, would definitely order this again!) and beer (21st Amendment beer with watermelon flavor, very interesting, great with Chinese food!).  Loved the saucy nut mixture they brought to our table at the beginning of the meal.

Service was quick and friendly enough.  The line stacked up pretty quickly after we sat down.  We had lots of leftovers and probably ordered too many rice dishes (a small bowl of steamed rice was also included in our order), and I wish the waitress had recommended that we order one less rice dish (but oh well, they were all good).  My curiosity was satisfied, but I'd definitely come back again!
author: Maile N.

description:
I've been ordering delivery from Mission Chinese Food for over a year now, but only decided to come into eat recently. I'd been always scared of the lines. I'm also lazy.

Delivery is pretty straight forward, but if you live outside the Mission, expect a lag time of 1 to 1.5 hours.

Even though I like the food, I took a big risk in taking my parents here. They're usually all about authenticity, which this place isn't. Nevertheless, we enjoyed the following dishes:

- Thrice Cooked Bacon
- Squid Ink Noodles 
- Egg-Egg Noodles

The last two can only be had when dining at the restaurant, so keep that in mind next time you visit.
author: Huey K.

description:
Sooo I was pretty stoked to try Mission Chinese since I had been reading about it for years.  Finally tried it a few months back. I'm hoping I just got the wrong things...

Beer Brined Sichuan Pickles - a very meh version of kimchi.
Tiger Salad - plain herby lettuce wrapped in plain rice paper with some vinaigrette style dipping sauce - completely bland and not at all interesting.
Mongolian Long Beans - I put sriracha on everything and I couldn't eat these, they were extremely hot. Really greasy too.
Sizzling Cumin Lamb - this is the reason for the second star. This dish was okay, but again, really greasy and they didn't give us much lamb (mostly beans and onions).

I may give it another shot since I live two blocks away.  But it was pretty bad.
author: Courtney M.

description:
So I get that this is not supposed to be your typical Chinese fare, although the ambiance does resemble a dive-y Chinese restaurant where they keep the lights low with gaudy Christmas lights and tacky decorations to possibly mask the rat droppings and roaches crawling all over (I'm not saying that they had this but just what the typical restaurant in Chinatown would have given the decor that they assimilated). 

I also get trendy, hipster and possibly typical Mission establishments of nondescript places. But I don't know what type of fusion food they were going for. Maybe we ordered the wrong dishes. Unfortunately, as a party of 2, we were crammed into the middle tables. There was barely any room for the dishes. Place was loud. I couldn't even see the food as it was so dark (only lit by Christmas lights and the light from the door to the kitchen). 

We ordered the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts (which tasted like regular peanuts soaked in oil - finger food or chopsticks? even the waiter didn't know); Tiger Salad (yeah, a bunch of herbs soaked in vinegar wrapped by a sheet of rice noodle - not much flavor other than herbs and vinegar - blah); Broccoli Beef Brisket (it says it was cooked with smoked oyster sauce but ummm, it literally tasted like an ash tray); and Mongolian Long Beans (this is probably the most edible dish, and that's not saying much, as they used some spice that left a nasty aftertaste, which the beef brisket also had a nasty aftertaste). Even the sake we ordered couldn't drown out the aftertaste. We were scrounging for any mint, gum, etc. that we could find, and ended up going to a bar hoping alcohol would numb the taste buds. 

This is probably one of the worst meals I've had - last one was coincidentally at a restaurant in Beijing, China. I'm really baffled how this place makes it on all these foodie lists!
author: Trang H.

description:
Don't believe the hype! 

By far the WORST "Chinese" food I've ever tasted in my entire life! Even Panda Express does a better job than this barf food I had.... My friends and I had such high expectations for this place, and we were beyond disappointed after the first bite. How can a restaurant that's on the 7x7 list, featured in several magazines, and has 1000+ reviews on Yelp taste that bad, you ask? It's all the hype - and please, don't believe in it. 

My friends and I came on a Friday night (silly us) and waited for about 30-45 minutes in the cold (super windy night) with people pestering us for money. From the first glance of the store-front, I was kind of skeptical of the place. It was very grungy - and my belief was confirmed when I went inside to use the restroom. The restroom was straight through the kitchen and out the door. It was where the garbage and recycling bins were located, and right next to the kitchen. My initial thoughts were, "use the restroom as fast as possible because rats and cockroaches can come out any minute!" I mean, I didn't see any.. but you can only wonder....

I also hated the interior of the restaurant. It was super dark and uncomfortable. My party had to share this medium size round table with 2 other parties, which was kind of awkward. I meant, I'm from HK and I'm used to this whole sharing table concept. But cramming us altogether with so little breathing room is not okay. When the food came out, we could barely distinguish our dishes with other parties' dishes. Not only that, but the table soon ran out of space to even accommodate all our dishes. Ugh... However, the most annoying part of the meal was that my party literally sat under the speakers, and they were playing loud, obnoxious KMEL-like music... Really, at a "Chinese" restaurant?? You have got to be kidding me. 

Okay, the most important part of the review... the food....

1. Char Siu Pig Ear Terrine
Weird texture and taste. What grossed me out the most was the little pieces of hairs still stuck on the pig ears... Even with the limited lighting, I could see those hairs stick up. Who would serve customers food with animal hairs still on it?? That's just disgusting.

2. Tea Smoked Eel
This was a cool concept, but just didn't work. It would have been okay with just the rice noodle, eel, and celery, but there was this fishy tasting minced paste thing that just tasted like barf. I literally felt nauseous immediately after eating that. It was just a weird taste.. I don't even know what it was. I read the menu, and it says that there was "braised pork" in it.. but it definitely didn't taste like pork to me.... 

3. Salt Cod Fried Rice
Probably the only dish that was "acceptable", and only because it didn't deviate too much from the REAL salted fish and chicken fried rice Chinese people traditionally make. However, given the quality of the food, it still wasn't very good as it lacked in flavor. I've had way better fried rice at Panda Express... But I'm glad we ordered this...since this was the only dish that was edible lol

4. Egg Egg Noodle
Came with a raw egg, which I think ruined the entire dish. How can they ruin such a simple dish? I think it literally consisted of noodles, scallions, ginger, soy sauce, and the raw egg. But it was just disgusting. I can't pinpoint why (weird texture and taste?), but I could only take 2 bites before putting it down. 

5. Kung Pao Pastrami
Were they trying to kill us with that overly salty pastrami?? I've never tasted anything THAT salty... My friends and I were even joking about how this should be called "Morton Pastrami" given the extreme saltiness of the dish. I had one bite of the pastrami and couldn't handle it. Though I enjoyed the peanuts.......?

My friends and I ate about half (or less) of each dish and didn't even bother to take the leftovers home. It was THAT bad. I mean, I felt bad for wasting food like that and considered giving it to homeless people, but I think it would do more harm for them than help... Where are they going to find water to wash down that disgustingly salty pastrami? Worst $70 bucks ever spent on food. The table next to us also left half their dishes untouched and didn't take them home either.. That's saying something.

I should've known this place would be a disappointment given that there were no Asians waiting in line to try this place. This place is super "Hipsterized" and gives Chinese food a bad name. I feel sorry for people whose first experience with Chinese food is at Mission Chinese Food. If this was my first experience, I would probably hate Chinese food. If you want REAL Chinese food, go elsewhere, preferably somewhere in Chinatown, Richmond, or Sunset.. NOT the Mission, and definitely NOT Mission Chinese Food. 

The only redeeming factor about this place is that they donate 75 cents per entree to SF Food Bank. Other than that, I could care less if this place closed down.
author: Michelle L.

description: From the outside, it seems like an obscure little place lost amongst the sea of small restaurants in the Mission. But when you see a horde of people waiting outside to be seated, you know that this is a place not to be trifled with. When I went inside to have a meal with my friends, I had resigned to my vegetarian fate that I would end up eating only some variant of cooked rice and maybe a few boiled veggies thrown into the mix. Turns out that Mission Chinese has this amazing dish called Mongolian Long Beans. It was absolutely delicious -  Indulgingly oily, spiced to the right level and quantity that can beat my fiercest of hungers! I've been to this place two times and I've had the same dish on both occasions. Unfortunately, I can't visit this place too often `coz if I do, I'll lose interest in those long beans and I wouldn't have anything else to eat.
author: Srivatsan S.

description:
The waiter at Gary Danko referred me here, so I had to try it.

The reason why this Chinese restaurant stands out (and makes you stand in line), is because of some special chef. However, upon leaving, I felt it was not much different from most Chinese Restaurants except for several dishes and the waitstaff (tons of hipsters from the Mission!).

I loved the dumplings, and the pork belly. I wasn't a fan of the lamb soup, but that was very unique - first time having it on a Chinese menu! The mapo tofu was pure spice and zero flavor. 

I would come back maybe for takeout for the value; but doubt I will be standing in line again to eat in.
author: Jess C.

description:
Mission Chinese Food, you had me at hello....well actually you had me at my first bite of the Ma Po tofu.  

I walked in not really knowing what to expect but told myself to keep an open mind.  We ordered the tofu, Lion's Head Meatball and the Westlake rice porridge, three dishes that I order often at Chinese restaurants and thus could use as points of comparison.  

The tofu dish is spicy, as it should be and was meant to be.  You will not find a "dumbed" down version of this dish here, as so many places have done.  The pork and silken tofu dish is rich, luxurious and comforting.  The green peppers and Szechuan peppercorns provide just a hint of sweetness. There seemed to be more pork than tofu in the dish.  Hint: for those of you that aren't used to really spicy food, rice is a must to accompany this dish.

The Westlake rice porridge is so good!  The ratio of crab, oxtail and cilantro to the porridge was perfect!  The soup was so flavorful and light.  My preference is for the Cantonese style preparation of this dish, where it's thick and creamy, but the porridge here, where the rice grains haven't completely broken down, opened my mind to other interpretations.  All I can say is "Please sir, I want some more"!

The Lion's Head Meatball comes with vegetables and ramen noodles in a marrow broth.  The meatball is light and fluffy, as it should be, and the broth is rich and unctuous.  The pickled turnips provide some needed crunch.  I found the dish to be on the salty side and a bit too rich but would recommend it to others.

While waiting for our food to arrive, I noticed the kitschy decor....gotta love the dragon hanging across the entire length of the ceiling and the two beer cans in its mouth!!  If anyplace could be described as a dive, this place absolutely fits the bill. Christmas lights hang from the wood paneled walls, the plates are mismatched and tables/chairs are straight out of a bygone era.  However, don't let that distract you from the reason you came to eat here...the food.   The space is small and the wait can be long as there are few tables.  It does share the space with an old school Chinese restaurant and the wait staff is from that operation.    I found the staff to be nice, especially the chef, who was awesome.

Portions are very generous.  Prices are pretty reasonable, especially given the quality of the food.  An extra star for their donations to one of my favorite charities - the SF Food Bank.  Their interpretations of standard Chinese fare maintains the integrity of the dishes but adds a twist that makes it special.  Don't come expecting to eat standard Chinese fare.
author: Melissa L.

description: Just had lunch today in this place. It's generally okay, just they put a little more salt in several dishes.
author: Arthur Z.

description:
Long wait

F the service, the girl with the tattoos was terse, snappy, and mean

Thrice cooked bacon was way greasier than expected and if you are not a fan of onions, do not order this dish

Cha Siu was tender and fatty, like stewed pork at ramen places, but certainly not worth the price for 4 measly chunks

Eel Rolls was fresh and vietnamesey - 2 stars for that
author: Tina A.

description: I hadn't been here in about a year and used to really love this restaurant but recently realized it's not the same anymore.  We had the classic chow mein which was a bit cold, the stir fried pumpkin which was more raw than cooked, and the hamachi which was also quite disappointing.  Felt like a waste of time and $60.
author: Amy K.

description:
I will NOT go back!
1. The food is attempting to be creative, but it is confusing and over complicated.
2. Prices...are you kidding me!
3. The spice combination numbed my mouth abd made me violently ill last night. 
I will say service was attentive.
author: Troy C.

description:
This is the place for you if you love SPICY food!

Please order the following for your own good:
Thrice Cooked Bacon
Mapo Tofu
Hainam Chicken Rice

I first heard of Mission chinese food from an article in SFgate. I gathered from the article that it's a small place with really great food but not a place you'd want to sit down and eat at. Sounded like a typical hole in the wall restaurant.

It did not disappoint and it lived up to the positive reviews from the article. The Thrice Cooked Bacon is salty, comforting, spicy, and one of my new favorite dishes. The Mapo Tofu is even more spicy and even better when you eat it with the Hainam Chicken Rice to soak all the flavors up.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I'm definitely glad that I finally tried Mission Chinese but that's about it. I love the idea of turning a shitty Chinese food restaurant (but really it looks like a shitty Chinese food restaurant) into a really cool place with amazing food but I don't think I'd come here again for the food.

We ordered:
Tiki Pork Belly: favorite dish! If you're gonna get anything order this!!
Kung Pao Pastrami: yummy but really spicy (in a good way)
Combination Fried Rice: tasted like fried rice but the bits of pork and crab were a good addition

The food comes really fast but service is really bad - as in no one will take your order or give you the bill unless you ask for it. In the end, it's Chinese food and it's not worth the price or the wait.
author: Alli Q.

description:
Mission Chinese Food certainly doesn't lack flavor or character. All the dishes are packed with heat (and sometimes too much salt), but they are all tasty. The decor and ambiance of the place though feels a bit tacky and cheap. The price does reflect this so you do feel like you are getting a good deal.

The major downside is the wait but they have a pretty fair system. You can write your name down and if they call your name and you aren't there, they won't automatically bump you off the list.
author: Victor W.

description:
Honestly, given all the hype over Mission, I had pretty high expectations.

Seeing the long line of people waiting impatiently outside the door; the sound of hustle and bustle and drunk hipsters clambering around plates of pork belly and spicy bean beef, scents of chinese food fusion and kimchi hotdogs and ramen wafting through the air. I was pretty damn turn't up.

Luckily, I managed to finagle a table for two before closing and happily scoured the menu for good looks.

Pork belly with pineapple glaze, etc etc... sounds divine.
Spicy beef and string beans... good times
Marinated lamb? No brainer.

The server told me that these were her fav dishes, so with peer affirmation and all, we put in our orders and waited for the feast.

Time to get real concise.

- Pork belly (5/5: Plump, fatty, huge cuts with ample glaze. Delicious)
- Spicy beef string beans (4/5: Tasty, spicy, but incredibly greasy)
- Marinated Lamb (2/5: Huge letdown. We barely ate any of it; it also made half the restaurant start choking and coughing due to the heavy spicing.)
- Service (3/5: Hustle and bustle type of environment. What you'd expect of a popup in the mission.
- Decor (4/5: Fun place for an informal date; stupid casual, hipster vibe)

#Protip: Putcho name on the table list ASAP. List closes at 10PM or before!
author: Roy C.

description: Not you're average Chinese place. Great spin on traditional Chinese food, and besides the hype that surrounds the culture its really good food. Worth traveling to across town.
author: Juan G.

description:
"This Tongue Is On Fire"
To be sung to Alicia Keys' "Girl on Fire"

She's just a tongue, and she's on fire
Outside line so crazy, longer like a highway
She's living in the Mission, and it's on fire
Feeling the hipster hate, but she knows the food is great

Oh-oh-oh-oh-ohhhhh, I only go here for lunch
Evening line is a crunch
Oh-oh-oh-oh-ohhhhh, Chinese food with a twist
Mapo tofu has kick

This tongue is on fire
This tongue is on fire
My love will not tire
This tongue is on fire
author: Christopher Y.

description:
This place is overrated.  Like others said, I heard alot of good things about this place and was thrilled to try it out.  My friend and I came in at 1:00pm, no wait and was escorted to a table immediately.  We took a look at the menu and decided to order: salted cod fried rice, Taiwanese clams, and Kung Pao Pastrami.  

The food: 
Salted cod fried rice was delicious.  I am Chinese and I can tell you that this is not the traditional minced chicken with salted fish fried rice.  They have their special spin on this dish and the flavors are very unique. Taiwanese clams was a disappointment.  I love clams but these were the tiniest manila clams and on top of that most of the shells were empty.  The sauce is good but nothing special, based on what I remembered it is a cross between XO sauce and black bean sauce with a little bit of Chinese bacon mixed in.  The worst dish of all was the Kung Pao Pastrami.  I love Pastrami sandwich and I love anything Kung Pao but the combination of the two is one hot mess.  The flavors are weird it was spicy and smokey with slices of potatoes and celery.  

The service:
Well, the service was better than expected.  Yes, they leave you with a jug of water so you have to service yourself.  However, I prefer this because you never run out of water and you don't have to wait for refill.  The dishes were brought out one at a time.  The servers were friendly, quick and efficient.  Our waitress was a tall blonde who spoke Mandarin, pretty impressive.  The service was pretty decent for this sort of place. 

I did not come here expecting authentic Chinese food, in fact I love Asian fusion cuisine.  I am really glad that I was able to try this place out.  If I am in the area, I will definitely come back for the salted cod fried rice, however, I will not wait in line or go out of my way to eat here.
author: Eva E.

description: So, so, so good! Everything we tried was delicious and a unique, delicate flavor. A truly extraordinary gourmet experience!
author: Georg K.

description:
Firstly, don't look for "Mission Chinese" - this is code. This place is disguised with a yellow "Lung Shan" sign on the outside. 

I tried to explain to a non-Chinese-food-loving-friend, this isn't really "Chinese" - it's something all on its own. 

We over-ordered and look a lot of food home. I gladly scraped every last bit of incinerated pork belly, date encrusted hoisin sauce goo out of the frying pan.  You'll get over the garlic. Now, if only they made milkshakes...

For kids, order the black squid noodles - milder, great eating and story-telling.
author: Kathryn S.

description:
After reading a lot of the reviews on Yelp, it seems that many people think Mission Chinese is over-hyped so i tried to lower my expectations before going.

Our group of 8 waited for a little over 1/2 hour. I remember seeing that they don't serve groups of 8+, but it's actually 6+. The server informed us that one of their tables can fit 8 and we should expect to wait around an hr and a half. Lucky for us, the table opened up much sooner.

The place is small, dark and crammed. It was also very hot.

But the food was pretty darn good. Authentic Chinese/Szechuan cooking. Try the numbing lamb noodles (delicious, even though i'm not a huge fan of lamb), string beans, pork belly, ma po tofu, & tea smoked eel.

FYI - the signage does not say Mission Chinese food.
author: Terry C.

description:
Why is this place famous again? This is incomprehensible to me. SF Bay has an abundance of quality Chinese food restaurants of just about any variety, and this place isn't even worth mentioning. The food is heavily flavored but with no purpose, and completely one dimensional. It is blasphemous for this to be even considered as Chinese food. How extraordinarily disappointing that this would be a Chinese spot with widespread fame enough so that people make specific trips out just to try it.

Sure, the atmosphere is hipster/awkward/inauthentic asian-influenced trashy - is that what people look for in restaurants nowadays? Please. Don't bother.
author: Jocelin L.

description:
Mission Chinese is truly a hit or miss kind of experience. 

If you go at that right time, order the right things, you'll likely really enjoy it. If you wait in a long line and order the wrong things, you'll leave questioning your faith in humanity.

I've been there a couple of times now, and ordered delivery as well so I feel I can safely recommend the kung pao pastrami (if you're ok with spice). The salt cod fried rice was also excellent and not quite as salty as I feared it would be. 

That's about all I can confidently recommend though as I'm pretty sure that some of the other dishes are solely designed as a "F@#k you" to the hipsters that would pay this much for greasy chinese food. One night we ordered a Tofu dish that was literally inedible due to the egregious amount of Sichuan (spelling?) Pepper that was put in it. I enjoy spicy food as well but couldn't take more than a couple bites before I had to tap out. I looked around and saw that no one else in the place was touching theirs either. In fact, there was so much pepper in those dishes that we noticed that everyone in the place was coughing whenever the oscillating fan blew the aerosolized pepper/toxin their way.

On the plus side though, when you order over the phone, you get the traditional hard core, limited-english speaker. Which is, you know, fun.
author: Baron C.

description:
Came in a little before six on a Saturday, and didn't have to wait (though there was a line when I left). I got the kung pao pastrami. A few things to note here.

- It's really quite good. The pastrami is smoky, tender, and slightly spicy. The fattier pieces melt in your mouth, and the edge pieces have a nice little bark on them, like barbecue.

- Lots of vegetables -- red peppers, celery, and paper-thin potatoes, all lightly cooked to stay a bit crispy. I liked the meat-vegetable ratio; the pastrami would have overwhelmed the dish with salt and smoke if they'd used more. The potatoes were an unusual choice, but I've got to admit, it works.

- It was light on the peanuts -- looking at pictures other people have uploaded here, they seem to be pretty inconsistent with the peanut dosage. I honestly don't remember getting any peanuts in my dish; maybe they just forgot.

- No Sichuan peppercorns either, as far as I could tell. Pity; they would have worked well here.

- I didn't think it was actively spicy, but the folks next to me ordered the same thing and gave up due to the spice. Not sure whether this was due to inconsistency in the kitchen, or I've just burnt off most of my taste buds.

- A large pile of not-quite-kung-pao and a bowl of rice came to $14 or so. Along with an appetizer, this would probably feed two not-so-hungry people. I was starving, so I ate the whole thing and the chopsticks. Sorry.
author: Nath A.

description:
I had heard a lot of great things about Mission Street Chinese, and it did not disappoint. I've been traveling to San Francisco for 4 weeks and was finally able to check it out last week. I tried going a couple weeks ago on a Wednesday, but unfortunately, that's the one day it's closed....strange but I had heard such good things that I had to go back.

Met a friend for dinner last week...I had the thrice cooked bacon with rice cakes. Holy sh%t that was good. Succulent bacon, bitter melon, soft, creamy rice cakes, crispy tofu skin, and the chiles. We also shared the Mongolian long beans which were beyond spicy but delicious.

There were so many great options on the menu like kung pao pastrami and brisket and broccoli that sounded amazing, but I couldn't have the first time.

I was back in San Francisco this past week, so I made it a mission to head back to the mission.

I went back again for the Sichuan pickles and pastrami. The pickles were delicious, almost like a Chinese kimchee. The pastrami, although unique, was on the salty side, especially when paired with an IPA. It was delicious and tasty but needed something sweeter to balance it out.

Since I wasn't completely satisfied by the pastrami, I went back again for the brisket and broccoli and had to have the long beans again. This time was amazing...the dish had a lot more broccoli rabe than brisket, but it worked really well with the brisket adding a salty, smoky accent to the crunchy broccoli. 

There's still the General Tsao's lamb ribs that I need to try so I'll be back my next time in San Francisco. And oh that bacon, I will be seeing you later.
author: Tony B.

description:
Food is interesting, but not great.  

What stands out most is the fact that our waitress and the host made us feel completely unwelcome from the moment we arrived.  Had my boyfriend not been looking forward to Mission Chinese specifically, I would have suggested that we leave.  I found myself wondering what we must have done wrong to warrant such dismissive responses, no eye contact, and not so much as a pause when our dishes hit the table.

I don't go to dinner in hopes of being treated poorly.  So the next time I visit SF I'll skip this spot.
author: Danielle W.

description:
1. Most items on the menu is HELLA spicy and HELLA oily
2. HELLA expensive
3. Worth the wait? Only for your first time. Otherwise order to go or delivery.

Mapo Tofu - so spicy your nose will run and all you can taste is spice. Your tongue will be on fire and you'll feel s numbing sensation on your tongue for several minutes.

Thrice-cooked bacon w/ shanghai rice cake - now this I would go back for. Also super spicy but the bacon has a really nice smoky flavor and I love the chewiness of the rice cakes. The dish also has biter melon which gives it a nice flavor and crunch.

Salt cod fried rice - NOT spciy. I've definitely had better. I don't taste any salted cod in there and there is nothing really special about the fried rice. I hate chinese sausage in fried rice and surprisingly even though this dish has chinese sausage in it, I don't really taste it. 

Kung pow pastrami - interesting. The pastrami is really good but I don't care for all the veggies in it (celery, tomatoes, onions etc.) I found myself picking for the pastrami instead of enjoying the dish as a whole because again, HELLA spicy.

Beef noodle soup - definitely not as tasty compared to shanghai or sechuan restaurants. 

Overall, I'm glad I got to try it several times but 4 dishes for $51 is not worth it. Hopefully more late nights in the office means more free Mission Chinese. Then I won't complain as much :)
author: Terry D.

description: Don't do it. Don't believe the hype. After listening to the hype and reading all the Yelp recommendations we had very average, very greasy Chinese food located in a dive location far out in the hood. We ordered Mabo tofu very very oily no taste, chicken wings so so good but seriously the tingling sensation on your tongue is so distracting it tastes like the feeling when you put your tongue on a battery as Wikipedia said about Sichuan peppercorns. The thrice cooked bacon is burnt bacon with rice cakes no big deal. We had the worst seats in the house which was a tiny hole in the corner with very dirty walls. And don't even head through the kitchen to get to the bathroom in the back. Not getting the hype but good for them to get people hooked on this place, don't understand it. But here's my truth, tried it, but never again.
author: Ponty P.

description:
It was my turn to pick the monthly dinner club resto last night and this was my choice (first timer). I've been wanting to try this place for a while and am soooo happy I finally got to try it! Since they don't take reservations and we all get off work at different times, I placed our order online.

Order Review Rating: 5 stars: The online order system was super easy. The best part is you can choose the time you want it delivered, which worked out perfectly. The delivery was precisely on time - loved that!! Also, when I placed the order online, there were a couple items not listed on the form so I called and the guy who answered was super helpful and got the online menu updated quickly!

Food Rating: 4 stars: Since there were a lot of us, we were able to order quite a few items from the menu.

Some of the highlights were:

Thrice Cooked Bacon - The bacon pieces were okay but, my favorite part of this dish are the mini rice cakes - so good and I loved the chewy texture!

Kung Pao Pastrami - This was my favorite dish of the night. I have a pretty high tolerance to spice and didn't think this was very hot - very tasy though!!

Combination Fried Rice - Super flavorful and I loved the pineapple with the crab - YUM!

Mongolian Long Beans - These, I LOVED! they had the perfect amount of spice and were just super tasty.

Some misses:

Chongqing Chicken Wings - They look dry, they taste dry. The coating/breading - very strange, I can't really explain it. The taste - I couldn't tell you, my tongue was numbed. The contents of the package were 2/3 red chilis and 1/3 chicken wings. I'll be avoiding these next time.

Cumin Lamb Ribs - Dry and hard to eat; the end.

All in all - a super solid spot and I would definitely want to get delivery again (or eat here)!
author: Catherine A.

description: For spicy wimps like myself, BYOB can mean bring your own milk carton. Amazing food (esp the bacon rice cakes and squid noodles), and a great atmosphere.
author: Abby B.

description:
With over a thousand reviews on this place, here's the executive summary:  

- Menu offers high highs and low lows 
- Service will be spotty at best, served with some attitude / sass
- Nearly all dishes will skew towards being extremely salty 
- Bottomline:  Worth trying once, but will not be repeat customer

Run-down of menu: 

- Very good:  squid ink noodles (rich, savory, perfectly cooked noodles), chongqing chicken wings (explosion of flavors in its dry rub) 
- Acceptable: mapo tofu (a little too saucy, but spicy and numbing), mongolian long beans
- Over-rated and try at your own risk:  tea-smoked eel (a teeny bit of overcooked eel with three stalks of celery in one bite - brace your teeth), kung pao pastrami (way too salty)
author: Julie H.

description:
Was so excited to get to come here while in San Francisco on vacation.  Showed up about 7:30 on Thursday, put our name on the list, waited about an hour and got seated.  The place is small, cramped and loud.  I'll endure almost anything for great food, just wished they delivered on it.  Szechuan pickles, like another said, Meh version of kimchi.  Pork belly, good flavor, just wish it wasn't burnt on the bottom, took a whole layer off the belly that we couldn't eat.  Veal ribs, completely burnt, the entire outside of the rib was black, dried and inedible, we picked it apart and got a few bites from the middle that were good, but come on.  This is basic cooking technique.  Last dish was beef cheek a l'orange.  Good flavor, but AGAIN, cook to shit.  Dry chewy pieces of meat, some of it I couldn't even chew up, was so overdone.

This was the most over-hyped place I have ever eaten at.  I don't know where they lost there way, but they are lost.  To miss on what is such basic cooking technique it was a huge disappointment.  Only reason they got 1 star was the flavors were good, not great, but good.
author: Steven H.

description:
I had high expectations of Danny Bowien due to the foodie media being all over him and he delivered, in my opinion. This is a chef that can satisfy the need for umami and salty tastes. 

The savory egg custard with uni and scallop was one of the most unique dishes I've ever had and kind of reminded me of the Two Spoons of Happiness from Koo (which is, side note, out of control amazing) - but maybe it was just because it was uni mixed with other goodness. So good! 

The wait was not as long as I feared and ducking into Hog & Rocks for a quick drink definitely helped the situation. The food came out of the kitchen super quick. The dim lighting combined with gawdy hole-in-the-wall decor was oddly romantic. 

My only complaints - there was barely any cod in the salted cod fried rice and barely any shrimp in the chow main. But both dishes were delicious and overall the dollar to tastiness level did not disappoint.
author: Yevi A.

description:
Although I've heard of Mission Chinese, I definitely wouldn't have popped into this generic-lookin' American Chinese parlor if I were just strolling down Mission, especially since the awning still says Dragon Mountain Restaurant. The place is appropriately dingy and dim, though there is a huge lit-up dragon flying over ahead. 

We got the little hot plate of tea-smoked eel as an appetizer. It definitely wasn't what we had envisioned, but it was a nice surprise. My mental pic had strips of unagi on a bed of rice noodles and drenched in soy. Instead, it was eight little tubelettes of rice noodle wrapped around Chinese ham, big hunks of eel, celery, and it was lightly wet with soy/cognac with a sprinkle of black sesame seeds on top. Pretty presentation and clean flavors, and I could have definitely eaten a few more. I've been wondering about making unagi dumplings for a while now, so seeing how rice noodle and eel flavors interact nicely is a good sign!

Our two mains were the cumin lamb, which comes with a side bowl of chili-pickled long bean dices and the thrice-cooked bacon. Both dishes reminded me of Ethiopian cooking in that everything was a caramelized onion explosion. The lamb smelled amazing since it came sizzling on a platter and had a cloud of cumin spewing from it. Big slabs of belly meat, so lots of burnt fatty bits to savor. The onions soaked up all the meat juices, so it went great with rice. I wasn't really sure what to do with the pickled long bean, but it was a nice counterpoint to the meatiness. The thrice-cooked bacon was probably my favorite of the two mains since it had a lot of interesting flavors going on. The inari flaps gave some sweet while the peppers threw in the spicy. Rice cakes and onions again soaked up everything.

Will have to come  back to try their ma po tofu and their bbq!
author: Kevin L.

description: Woah I totally forgot to review this place. Damnit, it's been a year so I don't remember every detail but the wait was EXCRUCIATING even though we were there ridiculously early. Some ladies started cooking up danger dogs and we were so tempted to skip dinner and eat those instead. Anyway, the food exceeded my expectations. I definitely thought this place would be overrated but it wasn't. The chicken wings were as numbing as they say, it's truly a shocking feeling if you've never experienced sichuan peppercorns. We had this awesome pork jowl and radish dish that I will never forget. We also tried the orange beef and a few other things. Everything was good. I would love to order takeout in the future... will never wait like that again.
author: Jessie M.

description:
Come here expecting authentic Chinese, and you'll be disappointed. Come expecting a unique, impossible-to-repeat culinary experience, and you'll go wild!

Knowing the lines are long, I came on a weeknight over peak dinner hour and didn't have to wait more than 20-30 minutes. I had the cod fried rice, mongolian beans, and vinegar peanuts. All were delicious! Service was minimal but got the job done, and the dark room and sketchy area outside added to the fun.

Mission Chinese is not a fancy, gourmet restaurant, but it's an outstandingly funky place to dine.
author: Denise B.

description: Disgustingly overseasoned, very heavy, basically uneatable. We ordered the cucumber salad, twice cooked bacon and the spicy green beans and they were all pretty disgusting and absurdly overseasoned... Not sure why this place has any positive reviews, I'll eat most things but each bite of this stuff was painful. Also got the strawberry Mochi- pretty bland and gross
author: Ben G.

description: Lots of hype. Twist on the traditional. Some dishes scored high for me (eel roll, squid ink)..others were so-so (brisket/broccoli, salad). And it gets really hot in there.
author: Howe L.

description:
This place totally confuses me... Upon hearing the name, I expected typical Chinese food. 
After one long BART ride, and a sketchy walk to the restaurant from the station, I realized ... I was not about to have typical Chinese food. 

Arrived around 05:30PM on a Monday, no one was there... thought I was in the wrong place because the obvious restaurant name displayed didn't say Mission Chinese (but trust this address!). The rest of my party was not there yet, but they let me sit and wait inside, which was nice of them. While I waited for my friends, I spent half the time trying to decide what to eat, and the other half analyzing the place. 

-Pretty dark restaurant, which makes me nervous because I like my restaurants well lit so I can at least be more convinced they are cleaner than they actually are. 
-The menu was pretty exotic.... 75% of the dishes made me go O_o 
   = What the ?? Chinese restaurant charging for rice?? So not typical.. 
- Somehow ended up ordering a more tropical dish instead of chinese; the braised pork belly? with a side of rice. Filled me up, really flavorful, but nothing I find myself ever reaally CRAAVING for, you know? 
- On another note, my friend really enjoyed his general tsao veal ribs though.

The staff was really young and hip and laidback, so that was pretty cool. 
Overall, I don't think I'll ever really crave this place enough to WANT to come back on my own, despite the hype. 

- REALLY GOOD PIE PLACE NEAR HERE THOUGH if you're looking for dessert..
author: Ashley N.

description:
This is a modern, hip and young "Chinese restaurant" which included black lights in their interior design and played old school hip hop music throughout my whole meal. Music choice? Loved it. 

I've got to hand it to them. The food was amazing! It was more than amazing, it was the best "Chinese" food I've had! 

What we ordered with some Einstok beer
Smashed Cucumbers (refreshing)
House Fried Rice 
Tea Smoked Eel (unique!)
Broccoli Beef Brisket (UHMAZING)
General Tso's Veal Ribs 

***ALL GREAT DISHES!!!**** 

From 6-9 PM there is a constant crowd hovering in front, but don't let that scare you away, the wait isn't that long.  

The servers were very attentive, had positive energy and were very helpful. We originally ordered more dishes all for THREE people, and she warned us that we had too much food. thanks for the tip! I'll most def be back. Next time will try the Cumin Ribs though!
author: Shirley D.

description:
I'm really sad that I'm not giving this place anymore stars but at the specific night I went, I was not satisfied. 

I knew there would be a wait so even the one hour wait wasn't bad. The food was not at all as its cracked up to be. The salt cod fried rice was good but not amazing. The Kung paso pastrami was good but very spicy. The tea smoked eel (which is really pork) was ok. Menu is limited but other rushes looked better like the ma po tofu. 

I don't think I'll come back.
author: Vicky Q.

description:
I ordered for delivery and had a good experience with Mission Chinese. 
Ordering from their website is straight-forward and easy (though some items on the regular menu are not available for delivery; so it goes). The food arrived within the hour+ quoted. It was all only a little warm but, again, so it goes with the convenience of delivery. 
Our order included the crushed cucumbers, peanut sauce/tofu rice noodles and the broccoli and brisket. All were deep with distinctive flavors, aromatic and a little salty.  

I definitely want to dine in the restaurant, as I am intrigued by the crazed level of malevolence in the negative reviews. I suspect the hype surrounding this place leads people to walk in with impossible expectations.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Mission Chinese Food: Where the only thing saltier than the food was our waitress' attitude. Our group was very disappointed in this restaurant, especially after reading so much about it. The service was poor and the food overall was salty to the point of being inedible. I would not recommend this place for dinner.

More detail:
We arrived for our Sunday evening reservations and were seated promptly. The decor is very fun and lively, with a big dragon covering the ceiling. Our waitress seemed rather annoyed that our party took more than 5 minutes with the menu. To appease her on the second check-in, we ordered a few items and said that we'd order a few more in a minute. She huffed and took all but one of our menus (was she worried they would run out?). We ordered the cucumbers, sesame chicken, dan dan noodles, mongolian long beans, and the chicken wings. The dan dan noodles were good, but the sesame chicken, long beans, and chicken wings were all absurdly salty. We hoped to order some plain white rice to eat with the meal to maybe tame some of the salt, but our waitress was nowhere to be found. I wondered where she had gone until one of my dining companions remarked, "Oh there she is, she's twerking in the kitchen..." The price tag of over $100 for three people felt like way too much to pay for salt and apathy.
author: A T.

description:
We've all suffered through meals at upstart hipster restos attempting to fuse our childhoods and gourmet with a pinch of irony. You know, the places that try to re-invent the peanut butter and jelly sandwich; places where ideas are served, not dinners. I hate those places.  When I read about the Kung Pao and pastrami mash-up at Mission Chinese Food I figured I'd hate this place too.  

There's definitely a large helping of hipster on display at this divey, Chinese-American joint: Marc Bolan blasting through vintage speakers, cool-kid servers, cliché decor and menu items with names and descriptions determined to poke the bear. I put my bias and hipster fatigue aside because I was hungry and because something smelled good coming out of that kitchen full of very non-hipster Asian moms and daughters.

We started with the Black Vinegar Peanuts.  They were tangy and soaked long enough to leech some of the crunch out of the nuts, infusing them with lots of drink-it-up flavour.  Paired perfectly with our beers.

Next up was the aforementioned Kung Pao Pastrami. My dining partner ate one of the smoked chilis on her first mouthful and this left her on the sidelines as I picked through every smokey, spicy, crunchy, soft and meaty bit of this delicious plate.  It truly is a signature dish worth writing down.

Rising to the challenge, the Squid Ink Rice Noodles took us to another level of amazing taste, while the Sour Chili Chicken lost out only because the other two dishes were so damn good.  The SCC did, however, improve dramatically overnight once all of its ingredients were able to bind into a lunch-time leftover treat.

There's so much more on the menu we were forced to skip, but no matter since we'll be back.
author: Paul K.

description:
Let me start by saying that being raised in a Chinese household, I am used to eating damn good legit Chinese food. Attempting to come to Mission Chinese took a bit of convincing because it held a "Chinese fast food" vibe in my head, but I ended up very much enjoying everything we ordered, which was the tea smoked eel, kung pao pastrami, and squid ink noodles.

Tea smoked eel: Probably my favorite dish out of all of them. Eel was perfectly smoked and not overpowering to the rest of the roll. Other misc meat in undistinguishable paste form very nicely balanced the roll out.

Squid ink noodles: Your typical stir-fried flat noodles, but with something extra that I really enjoyed. Worth a try!

Kung pao pastrami: A little on the heavier side, but I liked that the pastrami gave an extra saltiness. The spiciness of the chili oils paired well with the saltiness though.

We also ordered the MCF Mikkeller collab beer. At first it seemed to lack taste, but the Sichuan peppercorn really hits after 20 seconds or so. It's a unique flavor you have to wait for, but I do suggest ordering it with the food since it goes so well with everything!

So I guess MCF lived up to its hype! Will come back again.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
3.5 stars to be exact. This place is so interesting. I love how they kept the gaudy, uber-Chinese decor, from the red dragon that twists above on the ceiling to the colorful and random Chinese paintings of army generals in uniform. But the food is made with authentic ingredients with a twist. It's not fusion, but it's quarky. It's Chinese Food for city hipsters! 

Word of caution: this place is usually pretty packed. You're supposed to put your name and party number on the clipboard outside and wait to be called. On a Tuesday night, my two friends and waited about 20 minutes, where we were then lead to and squeezed into a table in the back. After oggling at the menu this was the result:

1) The Slow-cooked Pork Belly was pretty awesome - the tangy, fruity pickled pineapple (it was slightly fizzy, whoo!) complimented the salty, fattiness of the pork. 

2) The Mongolian green beans were exploding in garlic and pepper flavor. 

3) The Thrice Cooked Bacon isn't the smoky bacon one is accustomed to. This tender bacon absorbed the flavors of the dish - mostly garlic, black bean and soy sauce. Bitter melon, rice cakes and tofu skins accompanied the bacon. Could've had more bitter melon. 

4) I wasn't too big a fan of the Sizzling Cumin Lamb. I see what they are trying to do with piling on the spice, but all I could taste was CUMIN. Could've used something to round out the flavor a bit.

5) Westlake Rice Porridge with oxtail, dungeness crab, poached egg and cilantro.  I think after all the explosive flavors of the other dishes, this seemed even more subdued and tame. This was a little more watery than the rice porridge I'm used to, but still very well done. 

All in all, I had a nice time here. But it was a little on the salty side. I think when you put Mission Chinese Food in the grand scheme of food in SF, I can only give it the 3.5 stars. I mean, just a ways over in China Town lives some of the best Chinese food in the Bay. They may not have slow-cooked pork belly with pickled pineapple, but it's hard to argue when the streets are lined with eateries owned by folks from the Mother Country who know what they are doing.
author: Amber M.

description:
Ordered four things and $16 dish wasnt there.  Went back month later and lazy ass waiter says 'sorry ' and does nothing like call over manager.  So i wont return i dont like being robbed.

Some dishes seem like circus attempts at style, like eel appetizer.  Awkward and unpleasant.

Spicy stuff is absurdly so, even to those who like spicy food from southeast asia.

Despite this whining from me there are excellent dishes here for westerners, i cNt speak for asian tastes.   Dumplings are very nice, for example, almost exemplary for me in a way.  Beef and broccoli thing i bought twice and got once was good, also.  Because of these impressive dishes i dont give two stars for ripping me off.

Hipsters will probably like the setting, you could make a movie in this place.
author: Eric L.

description:
I had the ma po tofu and I tried the thrice cooked bacon. The thrice cooked bacon was good but not life transforming. It tasted as good as about all things that are a combination of pig fat and fried rice cake. It was done well but did not live up to the hype.

The ma po tofu was okay. I'm not very familiar with the dish and I didn't quite like how many little bits and pieces were in it- as in more tofu please! But then again - that might just be ma po tofu.
author: Gee H.

description:
I have been hearing about this place since I moved here.  Now that Bon Appetit included it as one of the top 10 new restaurants in the country, I had to get to it before it got out of control.  The title is 100% accurate, though - the place definitely deserves to be on the list.

For a party of 2, the wait wasn't too bad, and on a mild night, it's no big deal.

Of course we had to try the famous Ma Po Tofu.  Holy cow that dish is spicy!  But so good!  I couldn't stop eating it.  My mouth was on fire, but I still wanted more.  I wish we had taken the leftovers, but they just wouldn't have gotten eaten this week.  The tofo was soft and silky which went well with the chunky sauce.  We also ordered a sweet and sour pork dish - with pickled pineapple and pork belly.  It was smaller than we expected - but it was 4 perfect bites.  To round out the order, we got the pickle dish, which really helped counteract the spicy Ma Po Tofu.  

I think MCF has taken over the entire place, so it's no longer a restaurant within a restaurant - which was kind of cool,. but MCF was delicious and why we went there in the first place.

The entire place was bustling and had a great energy.  The value is amazing, and I'll definitely be back - there was a tiger salad that looked interesting, and I'd like to try some of the other dishes that we skipped knowing our eyes were already bigger than our stomachs.

The staff was friendly and helpful (giving us a heads up that we were ordering some pretty spicy stuff...whatever.  bring it on).  Smaller parties usually end up sharing tables with strangers, which is fine and gave us a chance to check out some of the other dishes.  A great gem in the mission.
author: Lilly N.

description:
I ordered delivery on a Tuesday afternoon, and it arrived surprisingly quickly.
I ordered the pea leaves, which was more like a soup, with a subtle flavor, and the chow mein, which was rather interesting and certainly has more bits-to-noodle ratio than most.  All in all my impression was it's rather expensive but the food is rather a step up and more interesting than just about any other Chinese delivery.
author: Joe M.

description: My buddy has a thing for fusion food and wanted to come here for months. Got here Sunday around 7ish and got a table at 8. The people working here are nice and attentive. We ordered the pastrami kung pao, chicken wings and the gerneral ribs. The pastrami was really spicy but had nice flavors and the chicken were ok nothing special. The ribs were pretty good. I owners of this restaurant did a great job at making a couple of special dishes but over all there aren't enough dishes that would warrant a return for me. I guess growing up in San Francisco and being Chinese my expectations  are really high
author: Dennis K.

description:
A mixed bag. Two of the appetizers were really great, and unique in their preparation. The pork belly is almost a Trader Vic production, complete with pineapple slice and paper umbrella, and delicious, and the lamb dumplings really good, stuffed with tasty minced lamb.

After that, you're on your own. I couldn't find one main course that I could whole-heartedly recommend. You can pan for pastrami nuggets in the Spicy Pastrami entree, real great for your taste buds when you find a few, but then what to do with those left over vegetable shards. And the Cumin Lamb Rib dish is merely cumin sprinkled on some bone, gristle, and fat. Should have sent it back.

I guess this could be 4 Stars if you choose right, but it's just too hit-and-miss for me
author: Cliff L.

description:
I don't get the hype.  Sorry, I don't.

I came here suppppppa excited to finally try this place out.  We lucked out and got front row VIP parking and missed a seating rush, so we got a table right away. Score!

I ordered the chicken wings and the pork belly.

The chx wings were helllllla salty.  I don't know if we just got a band batch but they were terrible.  I mean I felt I had gnawed on a salt lick.  I had to order a second glass of water to double fist as I ate.  Sorry Mission Chinese, but San Tungs wins the wings battle hands down.

The pork belly was amazing.  The winner by far of my two dishes.  It was so juicy, bursting with flavor.

Service was ok.  She wasn't very warm and inviting, but she got the job done of getting our food and drinks.  

I don't think I'll come here again.  I think I have much better Chinese in my hood and across the park in the Richmond.
author: Jen K.

description:
Service has gotten much niceer over the last couple of years, despite what a crazy scene it its.. 
The food still is evolving and getting better.
I love this place.. I think its either a place "you get" or don't.. it hits the sweet spot on my palate.
author: Jason C.

description:
This is not a typical chinese restaurant, more like Asian  fusion.   I like the way they combine different ingredients, very interesting.   Foods are tasty.  
Price is a little high, portion is not big.  A fun place to try.
author: Lucy J.

description:
It's a new rendition on classic Chinese food that thankfully doesn't taste like your typical Asian fusion restaurant.

Salty cod fried rice: 4, surprisingly good since I don't usually order or eat fried rice
Thrice cooked bacon: 3.5, I ate alot of this dish because I like the rice cake and bacon combo. Reminds me of the itzakaya dish, yakinikudon.
Pork belly: 3, disappointing. Nice flavor on the pork belly but I found the skin too hard (maybe it's personal preference but I prefer no skin on my PB) and the dish could have used a starch to balance the dish.
Lamb dumplings: 3, probably great if you really like that classic lamb flavor.

Three stars for being better and more authentic tasting than your average Asian fusion restaurant.
author: Andy W.

description:
MCF gets a 2.5 star * * rating from me.

It seems that anything about the Mission(definition = Hipster, Classy, Trendy, "Cool" and such.....) ought to be fantastic. I disagree. Some places are 100% hype!!

I walked into MCF a.k.a Lung Shan for dinner. Neat hipster decor, nice looking seating hosts/hostesses, Americanized Asian food, not much on the menu for vegetarians even though they boast of vegan foods, or customizing some.

The whole spice thing is an OVERKILL!!!!!!!! R.E.A.L.L.Y!!!! Food is spicy, ought to be spicy, or at least showcase all kinds of flavors. But, here, all you see is DRY RED CHILLI PEPPERS!! And then some food buried under it. 

I got seated and the seating hostess showed up after 20mins to take our order. I asked if they could customize the noodles for me, I was told NO! So, I ordered rice. My husband ordered the chicken wings - he grinned when his order was placed on the table. He had to rake through the red chilli peppers to get to his chicken!!! Scream!!

My order of the bitter melon with tofu skin and something more was utterly disappointing. I also ordered the Mongolian Beans - blah! 

WAY TOO OILY!!!!! The food lay in oil.

Dress in layers - I don't think they heat the place sufficiently. Of course, the spice will warm you up and given how tiny the place is, the crowd too will warm you up.

Parking is a Pain! 

Delivery - I'm guessing they don't go distances. Ask!

You know...............if you want spicy food, I recommend you go to Spices. Better food, lot more options and not a wanna be "cool" joint!
author: Me Iz S.

description:
Really, I had no idea this place was as popular as it is. A friend of mine swore up and down that it's one of her favorite Chinese places, so I had to find out for myself.

Showed up with a group at 6pm on a weeknight and waited.

And waited and waited and waited.

And waited.

And then we were seated and served by hot, hipster chicks. Random, but awesome.

Ordered:
+A bucket of rice: good. Tasted like rice!
+Thrice-cooked bacon: yum
+Ma po tofu: yum
+Rice porridge: Ew, no thank you. Not yum. Odd texture. And yeah, so what if we kept saying, "please sir, I want some more"?
+Chicken wings with explosive peppers: Holy crap! Was there a sale on peppers or something? The entire dish was COVERED with them, to the point where you wondered if there was any chicken was even there. There was and it was spicy. Really spicy. Like, makes-your-lips-tingle-for-hours spicy.

Service was a tad slow. Food was fine. Not sure why it's so hugely popular. Yeah, I'm looking at you, NY Times.
author: Adena B.

description:
Like previously stated, this is not your typical Chinese food. It definitely has a unique spin. Spices encompass your senses upon first entering. The same happens for your taste buds. There are so many different flavors being thrown around it's quite interesting to try and follow. The food wasn't bad or especially fantastic.

Why the 2 stars?

I was shocked when I went to the back to go to the bathroom. I witnessed so many disturbing health issues. Firstly, the kitchen's floor is a bunch of old dirty cardboard strewn about. The tubs of fresh veggies used for cooking are kept a foot off the ground by other old pieces of cardboard, nothing covering them. 

While I was in line 3 cooks took smoke breaks right outside the kitchen without closing the kitchen door, letting the cigarette smoke waft straight in. I could visibly see the smoke mingling with the open containers of veggies, which also happened to be right next to the open door. One of the cooks put out his cigarette in a little holder right outside the door  on the ground (which happens to be 2 feet away from the open veggies just on the other side of the doorwary) and, I kid you not, beelined straight to the stove and continue to grease up a pan with his bear-hands without even washing them!

Unfortunately I witnessed all of this before I even got my food so it kind of ruined the whole experience for me. Yes, I still ate a few bites.
author: Annette D.

description:
This place has amazingly tasty food.  Wow!  Squid Ink Noodle stir fry & pork belly were so good.  Service is fast.  Best food, ok environment.

GOOD:  we had so many dishes, and they were all really good. Great prices.
BAD:  It is in an area of town that is a bit sketchy.  4 blocks from BART.  Environment is simple and kind of dive-bar like for a restaurant.  Usually a wait.
author: Peter S.

description:
I'm surprised by all of the bad reviews. We really enjoyed our meal here. We had the salt cod fried rice, which was delicious and unique. But the standout was the squid ink noodles. The lamb dipping broth was the perfect complement to these noodles. 

Be prepared to wait, especially if you have a larger party. We arrived at around 6:45 on a Friday and waited about half an hour for a party of 2. Once you get in, the service is fast and friendly!
author: Diana G.

description:
2.5 stars..

Overhyped and the food was meh. 

Braised pork belly- fatty fatty fatty... I thought this was just average... not worth the $10 in my opinion. 

Cod fried rice- This was pretty good- flavoring was spot on.

Lamb soup (can't remember the exact name)- this was odd... the broth was sour and the flavors didn't fit the udon noodles. 

Oh and its true... if you're Chinese... you'll be a minority here haha.
author: Emily C.

description: If you're in for some greasy Chinese food, Mission Chinese Food is the place to eat, specifically their twice cooked Bacon and Chongqing Chicken Wings. Throw in some chow mein and it's an oriental feast
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
Come early if you don't want to wait for a table.  By 6p.m. the place was completed full.  Restaurant menu at night is Mission Chinese; however, you can also request the Lung Sang menu consisting of your typical Chinese food.  Storefront name is only that of Lung Sang so it can be confusing.  Inside is somewhat dark with strands of holiday lights strung all around.  Kind of a greasy spoon feel to the place.

My friends and I ordered various dishes to see what all the hype was about.  We enjoyed some dishes more than others.  The dishes offer a different twist on popular Chinese food.

The mapo tofu is worth the $.  Huge huge bowl of it.  We also liked the beef cheeks with the Chinese broccoli.  Westlake porridge was good.  Usually only minced beef in it; but this version included shredded crab meat.

The lamb cheek with lamb sausage dish was super super fiery hot.  One friend just couldn't eat it.

The cold custard dish was very refreshing.  The Beijing peanuts so so.

The cod fried rice tasted mostly of Chinese sausage.

The char siu pork belly was a winner.  Tasty pork skin and nice meat to it.

Tax & tip came to $100.00.
author: Shirley N.

description:
My friend to waitress: --Do you think you could turn that music down just a little bit?  The speaker is right above our table.

Waitress: --It is turned down.

Mission Chinese service motto: Customer Second.

Food: tasty-different.  But not tasty-different enough to warrant a return visit.  And CERTAINLY not tasty-different enough to warrant a cold sidewalk wait.

Handy Tip: Use a bathroom before you go so you don't have to suffer the walk of shame through kitchen and storage before you eat.

Overall Rating: Tres Hip Emperor's New Clothes
author: Russell ..

description:
A very interesting place. First it's not actually called "Mission Chinese Food"; it's under a big sign that says "Lung Shan". But there will be a group of people waiting outside to be seated, so you can't miss it. The place is packed with no space to move or breathe. The food is definitely on the spicy side (even if you ask for mild), so be prepared. Also, large portions, so that's a plus.

The food itself was strange --- unlike anything I'd seen before. The noodle appetizer I think had jalapenos and cilantro in it; seemed more mexican than chinese. It was delicious though! Most of the dishes don't have familiar names or combinations of ingredients. So yes, it's an adventure. In my opinion it wasn't really worth the wait, but maybe I didn't order the right things. I'll revise my review if I ever eat here again.
author: Laurent L.

description:
This place is really good if you like salt.  I looooooove salt so it works for me.  The beef cheek with broccoli was amazing.  The meat was cut with a spoon tender and the greens crunchy.  Perfect.  Pork belly was tasty (salty really) but a bit on the dry side.  

It gets packed and the place is really cramped so either take it to go, or go during off hours.
author: Scott C.

description:
Dropped by MCF to see what the hype was all about. After standing in line for about a half hour for a table of two (no biggie) we got seated. Service was pleasant and friendly. I figured I was gonna try out the Ma Po Tofu because it's the hotness on Yelp and Foodspotting, and we tried the Egg Egg Noodles (a variation of Dandan noodles, plus egg). Two main points to make here:

1. Ma Po Tofu. Whoa. I mean this not necessarily in a good way -- just whoa. The spice totally confused me, threw me for a loop. The initial flavor was amazing, rich, round and savory. The pork was done just right, the sauce LOOKED just like yo Taiwanese mama (or mine, at least) threw em together but when it hit your mouth I was just flabbergasted. Something about it was wayy off balance. Highly peppery and leaving a bit of a sour, punchy aftertaste, I just kept tasting Ma Po in everything I ate that night. Did something go wrong in the kitchen? Am I just a sensitive taster? I'm confused. Help me Yelp! Do I just not get the hype? Am I not cultured enough? My advice to you is do NOT come in here with expectations of authenticity.

By the way, the Egg Egg noodle was pleasant, rich, and delightful.

2. MCF is making Chinese food sexy. Like date-night, libido-revving sexy. Deep pulsating bass-y music, and dim lights, this place is like someone took a chinese restaurant and started pushing it toward a lounge-ish feel, but didn't change anything about the restaurant except the lighting. (Which is exactly what it is). For that, MCF, we salute you for raising the profile of Chinese food into the rareified air of hipster and foodie circles.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Sure, I guess if you're into liquid smoke, heaps of salt, and MSG then this would be a hit.

We had:
* smashed cucumbers
* ma po tofu
* mongolian long beans
* westlake rice poridge
* beef brisket soup

Except for the tofu, every single one was over salted or over spiced.  And I don't mean "too hot".  

The beef brisket soup was a few (dozen) dashes of smoke away from being actually edible.

Total bullshit!
author: David R.

description:
With all the hype, I don't get it. Lines out the door. Portions big, inexpensive...Yes, but poor execution. 
Pork Belly-all fat, sauce faint flavor of star anise & greasy. Eel Wraps - greens have a weird fermented flavor. Served to cold to taste eel. Beef Brisket Noodle Soup-Competing flavors of ashy smoked beef vs cinnamon vs fish sauce. Doesn't work.
Lamb rib- full of fat & tendons with a powdery pepper rub that disjointed the dish. 

Full of first timers indulging in the hype. Service mediocre at best. Huh?
author: Deborah C.

description:
Mission Chinese is quite possibly the most overrated restaurant in San Francisco.
We waited in line for an hour to sit in a place where the music was blaring and the non-asian servers weren't knowledgeable about the food and cannot pull off the indifferent attitude of real asian servers elsewhere in the city. 

The ghetto fabulous feel is really 'a try-hard' type of atmosphere.
And its really made popular by transplants in the Mission who've never had a real Chinese Szechuan.

The best part were the prices and the green beans.

Fried chicken? Really? Spicy for the sake of being spicy.

Go to Eliza's instead.
author: M P.

description:
AARRGGHH!  What happened?!  Did this place get a new cook?  

I ordered my killer combo last night (ma po tofu, salt and pepper shrimp, and kung pao corned beef) and 2 of the items were different!  The ma po tofu had an off-putting, sour smell and tasted very vinegary.  It was ok, but I wanted the delicious ma po tofu I'm accustomed to.  Also, the shrimp no longer had attached heads!  The heads were the best part!  And the shrimp were overcooked and slightly smelly.  *shakes fists towards the heavens*

I need more consistency, man!  
And it gave me rocket poo!
author: Vicente G.

description:
The food here is great - especially if you're drunk. That's partially because although the flavors really stand out (from the fresh ginger to the fennel-covered squid ink noodles) it's all a bit greasy. Beware of that, special dietary people.

The decor here is great. I love the paintings and the dragon. This place has more bass than my car... I don't understand the dubstep, but whatever! To each their own.
author: Sterling D.

description:
So Saturday was my 4th visit to MCF this summer and I even though I've had great dishes there on previous visits, I'd have to say the pork cheek w/ broccoli is my new favorite dish.

Then again, I love the salt cod fried rice. So fluffy, savory, and fresh all at the same time! All the dishes I've tried are good to excellent.

The food is easily 5+ stars. For the price, quality, and creativity you can't really beat this place. The only negative star would be the ambiance. I know, it's a bit kitschy but I just can't give the full 5 star rating for the restaurant w/n a restaurant thing.
author: Art O.

description:
After a wonderful day on the coast, we were craving some delicious chinese food but we wanted spicy and not a ton of msg. Came across this place on yelp and headed that way. 
We arrived at 6:30 on Saturday night and were lucky enough to get the last open seats at the community table. We ordered 4 dishes to share. Best decision ever. They brought them out as they were finished so we were constantly being surprised by what was coming next.

First dish: beef and broccoli. Such tender meet and the best cooked broccoli I have ever had the pleasure of eating.

Second dish: dumplings. slightly vinegary sauce but complemented the delicious dumplings great

Third dish: mongoli string beans. warning these are REALLY spicy but they are so good you can't stop eating them....just avoid eating the red chili peppers if you don't like it really spicy

Fourth dish: beef, potato dish (can't remember the name). The beef was absolutely delicious and the vegetables with it were just as good.

Our service was great! My only complaint was how loud the very odd music selections were. Sometimes you thought you were in a club. I would suggest getting there early as well. When we left there were about 15 people waiting outside for a table.
author: Caron L.

description: Really good food. But it's salty and Pretty much the same flavoring.  Everything is cumin  pepper, and garlic.  Try thrice cooked bacon,  squid ink noodles,  lamb.
author: Helen L.

description:
OK, I am Chinese so you know I have to be picky about my Chinese food.  I am particularly skeptical of Americanized Chinese food.  I think their website even used the word "oriental."  Gasp!!  I remember an Asian friend telling me 20 years ago that rugs are oriental and people are asian...

But given all the write-up's and my NYC foodie friend wanting to try the place, I finally acquiesced.  We tried a handful of dishes and found a few that were good.  The porridge was wonderful and it had an interesting flavor.  The smoked eel dish that everyone seems to like in the Yelp reviews, I did not care for.  I thought the smokiness of the eel overwhelmed the flavors of the other ingredients.  The pork belly was delicious but as my manager pointed out, it was just like what you would get in a Chinese restaurant.  The egg egg noodle was nice from a mouth feel standpoint with the soft-boiled egg.   There is actually a Chinese term that perfectly describes the silkiness.  I have since been able to replicate this dish at home.  :-)))
