Lastly when I went to use the restroom, I couldn't resist but peak inside to see if there were actually Chinese people cooking the dishes.  lol  I was happy to find some nice Chinese ladies doing the food prep and talked to them in Chinese.  Somehow that gave me the warm and fuzzy to go back for some more.   (Honestly i was initially  kind of turned off by the caucasian only wait staff.)
author: Silvia K.

description:
Worst case of cottonmouth...EVER. I keep smacking my mouth in the hopes of generating ONE drop of saliva for relief, but alas, I'm shriveled like a raisin. It's THAT salty. 

- Mongolian long beans - kinda spicy, but I didn't notice because I was shoveling rice and water as if my life depended on it to cut the salt and grease. 
- Thrice cooked bacon - NOT Chinese thrice cooked pork belly, but actual bacon, greasy and salty, but the rice cakes helped make it palatable.
- Salt cod fried rice - Excellent, ironically, the least greasy and salty.

Going at 2 in the afternoon on the weekend is key - no line and therefore, non-stressed out wait staff so you can actually get OK-ish service.

Yes, this is catering to hipsters - trying to look like a dive when its really not that divey, and wall to wall with kitsch - when did Communism become cool? But the fairly cheap prices (~$20/person) and enormous portions did appeal to my inner Chinese cheapskate. The food would have been pretty tasty for pseudo-Chinese comfort food if they just would just ease up on the salt and oil, like, 30%.
author: Snuffles B.

description: This place is WAYYYYYY over rated.  Was visiting SF and decided to eat here after my husband and I saw the yelp reviews.  It was a big disappointment.  Terrible parking, a long wait, dingy interior that was trying to be passed off as hipster and Chinese food that not only wasn't good, too salty but were strange fusion dishes that I have never, ever seen or tasted.  Save yourself the trouble and go to Panda Express.
author: Ellisa S.

description:
Came on a Sunday night. Restaurant wasn't busy (no line out the door) so you'd expect the service to be attentive.

Wish I could give a better rating on the service...but I didn't get any. It was nonexistent. The waitress checked up on us once...when she gave us our bill. Thanks...for nothing. 

Guess they figure the food is so mind-blowing that there's no need for the waitstaff to watch over the dining room to see if anyone needs anything. All the patrons are going to be cracked out of their minds on a food high so what's the point?

So the food comes out. First a lamb dish...but no rice. Too salty to eat on its own. 10 minutes later, the veggie dish...weird, didn't realize this was supposed to be set up like a tasting menu?

By now, I'm hoping that I can catch one of the waitstaff to check on the salt cod fried rice we ordered...they all seem to be hiding in the back and I can't really see that well because the place is so dark. 

So another 10 minutes and the fried rice comes so I guess I can start eating now. 20 minutes later, I start asking everyone if they think the waitress forgot about the last entree we ordered. Naturally, she's nowhere to be found. 10 minutes later the last entree arrives. 

Not sure what's up with the timing of food coming out. Doesn't make much sense to me. Food itself is mediocre, at best. Meats were overcooked and charred to oblivion...but I guess that's for texture? I need to ask a hipster to confirm.
author: Trung V.

description:
I am not a Chinese food expert. 

(I live in the Mission vs. the Richmond or Chinatown. I get some weird nausea trip after MSG and thus have a general paranoia. I grew up in the Midwest and thus incorrectly equate Chinese food with canned baby corn and water chestnuts in either "white sauce" or "brown sauce.")

But with that disclaimer, I dug it. The waitress took the time to sit down and tell us the history of the restaurant and business arrangement, love behind the food. We ordered a tofu appetizer that came with an awesome spicy peanut chutney. Chinese soy-marinated tea eggs, szechuan pickled vegetables, garlic and ginger eggplant, a glass of decent white wine. 

Also, Ratatat remixes. (I love 90's hip-hop.)
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Thankful that this was part of the Mission walking food tour. Had the Kung Pao Pastrami which was a bit salty but creative and delicious. Would return to taste more.
author: Joe M.

description:
The dishes were a disaster of over seasoned proteins. I had the pork belly, the cumin lamb, salt cod fried rice, tiger salad, chicken wings, twice cooked bacon and the long beans and while a few of the aforementioned dishes were decent I couldn't get the awful taste of their spices out of my mouth. Imagine blending chilies, jalapeños, cinnamon, lots of salt and cumin in a blender and cooking everything with that concoction. Eck. We had leftovers and no one wanted to take them home! There was no balance in the dishes it was all too seasoned. The chicken wings were served under a heap of red chilies and were coated in that horrible salty/spicy  seasoning. 
And it's so unbelievably hot in that restaurant- no a
A/C. It was an experience to say the least but I'll never return.
author: Gaby H.

description: Food is good but I don't understand what the hype is all about? It's supposed to be a fresh take on Chinese food but I didn't find that very appealing. The flavors were powerful with lots of Szechuan influences from what I can tell. It's not that cheap either, especially for Chinese food. Service can use improvement because they don't take orders according to when you're seated, just whatever they feel like. We had to ask multiple times for water refills since they don't care to do it without being asked. We were lucky to score a table without having to wait. I'd give it another shot, but I wouldn't wait in a long line for it.
author: Mindy D.

description:
This place gets it freakin right for a number of reasons. I will review their delivery service as my girlfriend and I have actually never dragged our lazy butts over to their storefront in the mission, despite the fact that we live shamefully close. Their delivery is just *that* good.

You call and usually someone picks up that speaks decent English. Orders are placed without any hassle in less than 5 minutes.
*BONUS POINTS* you can order your food gluten free. YES!

The food:
Thrice cooked bacon: amaze-balls
Pastrami beef: my favorite item on the menu; however be careful as it's very hot!
Cumin lamb: cumin-ey!
Ma Po Tofu: OMG I could feed my whole extended family for days. Serving size is very generous.
Salt Cod Fried Rice: tasty although I wish there was more cod.
Mongolian Long beans: spicy, tasty, a good choice for some greens in your diet.
Stir-Fried Pork Jowl and Radishes: a bit too salty, and the food stinks (literally)
Tea Smoked Eel: not my favorite. Fishy.

Also, $1 steamed rice is a win in my book (why restaurants charge any more than that unnerves me to a great extent).

If I were to come up with a gripe about Mission Chinese, it would have to be their use of cheap cuts of meat in their dishes. Sometimes the Thrice Cooked Bacon or Pastrami beef will come with big chunks of fat and hardly any meat at all. It's still tasty. Mmmmm fat.

I applaud Mission Chinese for doing Chinese food in the right way. By this I mean their flavors are authentic, despite using some unusual ingredient combinations. Something looking foreign yet tasting so familiar is really a treat to be had.
author: K L.

description:
This is a review for takeout.  I heard so many amazing things about Mission Chinese, so I was super stoked to try it. Man, was I underwhelmed.

We had the thrice cooked bacon: I was most excited for this. Who doesn't love bacon? But the dish was not good. There was a noodle like disc shaped thing that came with the bacon. It was sticky. Gummy. Totally unappetizing. The bacon was super fatty chunks, and not int he flavorful way.

Pastrami: There were barely any pieces of pastrami, and the pieces that were in there were so laden in fat that it was kind of gross. Don't get me wrong, fat is fun in some cases. But this was not in an appealing way.

Ma Po Tofu: It used the peppercorns that make your mouth tingle when you bite them. But it used so many that you no longer had the ability to taste. So you just had food in your mouth + tingling. No taste. Pretty terrible.

Cod Fried Rice: This was the best thing we ordered. Seriously, the only thing I wanted seconds of. IT was tasty. But it couldn't save the rest of the meal.

I wanted to love this place. I'm bummed I didn't. Maybe dine-in would be different?
author: Shanee B.

description:
This place is pretty cool. The food here is so tasty but its so freakin spicy that it actually takes away from the flavor of the food. I mean seriously that is some spice. Anyway, i really love the idea of this place and will no doubt be back. I just gotta stay away from anything that is labeled spicy. Well done tho, love this place.

and yes, the wait is pretty terrible. I think it was close to an hour wait when we got there on the early side around 6, on a Tuesday...clearly the word has gotten out so make sure to put your name in early.
author: Derek S.

description:
This place came highly rated by some friends, so our hopes were set high on this first visit of ours.  

The triple-fried pork belly was so overspiced with red and green chiles that it was painful to eat, and we really couldn't taste anything but the heat. We both eat spicy food every day, but this was clearly an accident in the kitchen.

The stir-fried pork jowls was very greasy and salty. The salt and greasiness drowned out any subtlety the dish might otherwise have had, like the radishes were flavorless. And what is up with the shrimp puffy chips on this dish? That didn't help, and they soaked up some of the grease, which made the chips less appealing.

The tea-smoked eel rolls seemed like a good idea, but they were actually really bland! We didn't notice the eel flavor. Those fat white noodles didn't seem so tasty, kind of stale.

Overall, a disappointment. Maybe this was once a great thing, an experimental, punky Asian fusion joint, but the execution left us feeling, well, ill. Offensive food, really, that has certain flavors cranked up so high like the chef is tripping balls on meth and just can't taste anything ao s/he dumps more and more of it on until finally it's strong enough to reach their addled senses.

So, don't eat here unless you don't care about the food and are just looking for a hipster scene, which this is. The punky dishes might appeal to inexperienced, younger diners, but anyone with expectations of, say, pleasure or subtlety will be very let down.
author: Kevin P.

description:
If you're looking for standard Sezchuan Chinese food this is not the place to go to. However, if you are looking for something different and amazing this is a great place. 

The tea was pretty flavorless. They also played rap music pretty damn loudly. Maybe they were trying to get my family to leave. It was also really dark so it was hard to tell what you were eating. 

The best dish by far was the squid dish. It had delicious pork in so I don't know why they called it squid. Maybe the dipping sauce had squid.
author: Adidas W.

description:
I think this place is totally overrated hipster bullshit.

I had ordered cod rice for to go. Took them 10 minutes to make (extra star for that).
 The place itself is super dark with Red Chinese lights around, so you feel like it is Chinese New Year but all year around. The interior idea is great but under the darkness you are unable to discover how dirty the place is, unless you really pay attention.

My cod was real disappointment, did not feel any cod and mainly sausage, which in my opinion was too salty.

You can find better fried rice on every corner of Shanghai and Hong Kong and maybe that's why I did not see a single Asian person in the restaurant except for the lady who works in the back.

So if you want to see some Hipster place with an average food and you care more about the name rather than how authentic and delicious the food is, go for it and pay $10 for the portion of rice with mainly rice and nothing else, remember you get to watch hipsters in addition to rice for free:)
author: Nadia A.

description:
Yelpers are having a hard time categorizing Mission Chinese. People think it's inauthentic because it's not take-out. People think it's authentic because it's not take-out. All the spices and scallions must have culinary compasses spinning because this place is being touted as "traditional," "non-traditional," "Americanized," "non-Americanized," and "salty." In truth, it's all of the above and none of the above at the same time. From my perspective, the most apt way to describe Mission Chinese is "western style Chinese food interpreted with a heavy hand by white people." It's pretty much peerless, and it's not bad. 

Ma Po Tofu and Cumin Lamb were both enjoyable, albeit overly spiced and rather salty. I was thirsty for literally the entire next week. I did notice that the tofu dish had very little pork in it, the lamb dish was dominated by onions, and the salt cod fried rice was mostly rice. This place may be run by hipsters, but they're stingy like Asians are, I guess.

Even so, I reject the notion that people cannot like this restaurant solely because it isn't what you would find in Chinatown (or China, for that matter). Why should we limit ourselves to food prepared the same way it has been a thousand years before? Be adventurous! Or like, shut up.

Also, I kind of like the idea of being waited on by people who look and act like they should be on Gallery Girls.
author: Jeff T.

description:
This is a tough one.  Have to clear my head of all the hype and Yelp reviews - over 1200!  I think for sure this is a polarizing place - hard to leave without an opinion.  It's a challenge just to get started - waiting 45 minutes for table outside in a somewhat shady part of the city and then sitting in a retro-tacky dimly lit room with cheap Chinese art, Christmas lights hanging from the walls and a long paper dragon suspended from the ceiling.  This place is Michelin Guide recommended?  I don't think it's for the decor.

The menu consists of about 20 items organized into starters, entrees, rice/noodle dishes, and vegetables.  We had a party of 6 and everyone chose 2 different items so we were able to try more than 1/2 of the menu.

So what about the food - did it live up to the hype?  In a word, yes.  This Chinese food is different.  It's taking traditional Chinese dishes and twisting them up.  There's nothing subtle about this food.  It's a punch in the face and if you're up to that, then there's plenty to enjoy.  If you're a traditionalist or purist when it comes to your Chinese food, you won't like it.  Hedonists, however, will be rewarded.  This is not food for the timid!

Hits: 
Squid ink noodles with cumin seed and chick peas - lot goin' on here!
Tiki pork belly - love the burnt ends.
General Tso's veal rib - huge portion and delicious sauce.
Radishes with pork jowl - unctuous jowl and sweet radishes.
Tea smoked eel - beautiful presentation, great smokiness and oiliness.
Rice cakes with bacon - OMG this is so simple but so killer.
Vinegar peanuts - good snackin'.

Misses:
Szechuan pickles - ironically bland.
Ma po tofu - an oily mess.
Fresh rice noodles - nothing to write home about.
Chicken wings - nice numbing spice but way too salty.
Salt cod fried rice - again, rather tasteless.

The food opinions are my own - all the dishes had at least one admirer at our table, well maybe not the pickles.
author: Eric Y.

description: I wasn't impressed with Mission Chinese.  We ordered the ribs (not much meat, but decent flavor), the bacon fried rice (way too smokey tasting), the broccoli with braised beef (also strangely smokey, not great), and the long beans (the only dish we liked).  For $75, I expected better flavor and bigger portions.  I'd be willing to give it a second chance, but not in a rush to eat here anytime soon.
author: Bud L.

description:
45 minutes to an hour for delivery (longer today, I'm sure, because of the rain). Broccoli beef was my favorite dish - Chinese broccoli with one huge piece of braised beef cheek that broke apart easily and was very tender. Great with the salt cod fried rice, which alone, may have been a bit less than impressive. The lion's head meatball (also one huge piece - this place is all about big, single chunks of meat!) came in a soup with ramen noodles. Interesting take on the dish, which I usually have dry, with rice. By the time it was delivered to us, it was a little lukewarm, but I'm sure fresh from the pot, would've been 10x better. The marrow broth was the star of the dish, super flavorful and perfect for the rainy weather outside.

Food is about a 3 or 3.5, but I'm bumping it up to 4 stars for the convenience of having Chinese food (with menu items more unique than chow mein and General Tso's chicken) delivered to my door, and for the ninja that zooms across the page on their website.
author: Kathy L.

description: The thrice fried bacon was so hot that I couldn't even eat it at all.  The pork belly was wonderful, but peanuts were over-dressed and the noodles were just ok.
author: Hillery G.

description: I've been here about a dozen times. I've never had a dish that even remotely disappointed me. My favorites are the sizzling lamb, thrice cooked pork belly, and whatever veal chop variation they have on hand.
author: Huey N.

description:
Got to say three things
1.  My wife found a bug in the forbidden fried rice who is pregnant right now (It was her idea to try this place thank God for that)
2.  Same night I got food poising and spent the past 10 hours in the bathroom
3.  Besides these it was great.
author: A K.

description: Great find for lunch in SF!!! My Kung Pao Pastrami was hotter than hell, with tons of chili and jalapeños. My boyfriend's beef brisket with broccoli was good, but we both thought the flavor was a tad weak and that mine was better. My only major complaint was how shockingly fatty the meat in both of our dishes was. We both had cubes of pure fat in our dishes which had no meat whatsoever on them, which was completely gross. Otherwise, a great meal!
author: Mindy S.

description:
I loved the food! You come here to chow down on some grub. Come hungry because the portions are large and great for sharing! The wait is long but worth it. And once we were seated and ordered the food was at our table in lightning speed. Bumped snoop dog on the speakers.

The reason I gave this four stars is because they seated people before us when we were there before them. We weren't sure if it was because they knew the owner or the manager, but when my fiance asked the seating staff he just looked at us with a stupid face as if he didn't know what we were talking about and actually had nothing to say. I'm pretty sure the dude felt dumb that my fiance was calling him out. It was just rude for them to try and sneak another couple in before us and try to act like they did nothing. Whatever...we liked our dinner. Maybe next time we can just order delivery.
author: Ally V.

description:
The MOST hipster Chinese spot ever...w/ slow ass service...

Continuing from my quick tip...this place was quite the disappointment. We stopped by just to pick up a togo order of their Salted Fish Fried Rice since my sister from OC wanted to see what all the hype was about. I was dropped off to "run" in and grab the food but I ended up waiting for forever for them to ring me up and pass me my bag of food. There was 1 guy in the kitchen, one food runner, one cashier and, per usual, an old Chinese lady picking vegetables at the table. While there were only 2 other tables being served as I came in to grab our togo order, the guy asked me to wait as he slowly went to the back to chat with the other works and moved slower than a snail to get my food. I had asked him for some spicy sate sauce and no joke it took him at least 5 minutes to go find a sauce cup, fill it up and bring it out to me. I definitely won't be back.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Awful food that does not match up to all the hype. First of all, the service was terrible. The host and our waitress both had sour faces on and were rude. I took my parents here and I know that older people like to ask lots of questions, and sometimes take a while to articulate themselves, but the waitress was not having it. She also forgot to bring utensils and my drink. She didn't charge for the drink and rightfully so. It wasn't a particularly busy Sunday and there was not a huge line out the door, yet the waitress made us feel like we were bothering her. RUDE

Second, the food is awful. I love spicy food, as does my family, unfortunately something we all ate made my mom very sick...the next day..all day long. 

Cucumber salad in what looked like watery tahini? Bland, slimy, looked like baby vomit.

Seriously, what the hell are those chicken wings. The were dry and tasted like god knows what, leaving a terribly numbing feeling in our mouths at the end. What a waste using all those chili peppers on that plate, you can't even eat them! Garnishes are supposed to be small. The wings left that a numbing sensation for a good few minutes. Just in time for...

Kung Pao Pastrami, what a freaking joke! There was barely any pastrami in there, basically looked like pieces of dog food sized meat in some spicy vegetable concoction that was subpar.

Shanghai Lamb and Noodle Soup, was that a lasagna noodle in my broth? So much fat left on the lamb and the broth was so-so.

Fried Rice was the only good thing, but not worth the price/sickness/disappointment.

Frankly, the fact that my mom got sick and everyone else had funny feeling stomachs has sworn me off from Mission Chinese forever. Sorry hipsters, but you all are WRONG! This Chinese food is the worst.
author: Sonya S.

description:
Another SF institution in the heart of the Mission. This may look like a run dingy old Chinese restaurant from the outside but it is so not!! This place has the most eclectic and awesome Chinese food. Must try the ma po tofu (spicy) and the salt cod fried rice. Props to the service as well. They are super efficient and nice. 

Be prepared for a wait though..
author: Aditya J.

description:
Mission Chinese Food

So the first time I ever heard about this restaurant, my non-Asian friend told me it was the best chinese food he's had in a while. Given the fact that I am chinese and grew up eating chinese food at home, who was he to tell me what was good chinese food.

Fast fowardard a couple of months. I was looking for the restaurant but didn't realize that "Mission Chinese Food" wasn't the real name. 

I went with 3 friends during lunch on a weekday so there was no wait. Usually, during dinner, you can wait up to an hour. It's a tiny place.

I get seated and realize that the crowded is pretty mixed. The music threw me off because they were playing Usher, Justin Timberlake, etc. 

My friends and I ordered these three dishes

Ma Po Tofu- You definitely need rice with this

Thrice Cooked Bacon

Mongolian Long Beans

The food was so delicious! So I'm not big on spicy food so I was dying. BUT I do it to myself every time I come back. The food is so good and well worth it.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Theres always going to be a wait for good food, waited an hour, grabbed beers and hung out outside. 

Get the rice cake thing, pork belly, and the peanut thing. AMAZING.

the food is spicy! the music is just as hot!
author: Courtney H.

description: I don't even know where to start! Either the food here is mixed with an addictive drug or it's just that amazing! The chicken wing appetizer was ridiculously awesome! I mean it was awesome to the point where I was mildly getting upset that I had to share with the buddy I was dining with. I don't recall the entree I had but I did order the forbidden rice which was also amazing. I can't wait to eat here again and bring in other people who haven't tried it. The only problems here are location and atmosphere. Is not in the best and not in the worse area. This place can get cramped at times and has sort of a cafeteria style seating where you possibly could be sitting next to someone you didn't come with. That's okay though because the food will make you forget about who's next to you anyway. Lol.
author: Ashton E.

description:
I'll caveat this review by saying that we went the non-spicey route for this meal, as I DO like a little spice but have heard it can be a bit excessive here. Everything tasted great, no regrets.

Me and my date waited for about 20 minutes, not bad at all. When we entered, the ambiance was pretty fun. Juicy J playing in the background, dim lighting, random decor. We brought our own bottle of wine- $10 corkage fee. No big deal.

We started with the smoked eel which was my favorite dish. Great texture, awesome, loved it. We also ordered the cucumber small plate which was nice and refreshing. Recommend both dishes.

For my entree, I ordered the squid ink noodles. They were really good with the lamb broth for dipping, but there was a licorice-like after taste which is why this review is only 4 stars. A head scratcher for sure.

My boyfriend got the pork jowl, and as a native Alabaman, he loved it! People complain that the dish is too salty but what they don't realize is that hogs jowl is a cured meat, meant to be that way.

Overall, really really great. Great experience, unique flavors I had never experienced before, and pretty epic people watching. 

DOOOO itttttt.
author: Hope K.

description:
Seriously this restaurant was amazing.. I came with a group of 7 hungry people. We had a number of delicious plates: the salt cod fried rice which was amazing, the mongolian green beans, sizzling cumin lamb, stir-fried sweet peas, stir-fried corn and peppers, ma po tofu, westlake rice porridge. 

Every dish was pretty spicy but the flavors were amazing. I can't wait to visit SF to stop by and eat here. You need to run and try this place.. It's amazing!!!
author: Beverly C.

description: Got takeout for a surprise picnic date. The food was a bit cold by the time we ate but it was still delicious!
author: joel a.

description:
I've never been able to get into this place because there's always a giant line and never really want to wait to eat there.

BUT they deliver! And it's a pretty good delivery (expect 50 minutes though, yuck).

The Kung Pao Pastrami is great, though the textures provide some strange balance. The pastrami is chewy, the nuts are hard, and the vegetables vary from soft to kinda crunchy texture. I thought it was pretty interesting. 

The Salt Cod Fried rice is where it's damn delicious. That shit was some of the best fried rice I've ever had.
author: Rohan D.

description:
We went to Mission Chinese Food for dinner last Thursday night.  As an Angeleno, I had never heard of the place, but I could tell it was popular.  We arrived at 9:15 and waited 20-25 minutes for a table for 5 on a Thursday night.  It did help knowing that the sign was from the last occupant of this space, which is a different Chinese restaurant.

We really enjoyed our meal.  The food was freshly prepared, and the service was great (always a smile, excellent food knowledge and lots of advice).  The establishment is a total dive, with formica tables jammed together and crappy banquet chairs, but that is the point of pop-up restaurants, no matter how long they last.  It is about the food, not the ambience.

To eat, we had the:

Szechwan Pickles - basically kimchi or pickled cabbage.  Excellent heat level; loved the addition of crunchy peanuts for a salty crunch.  Delicious appetizer.

Szechwan Long Beans - this was the one dish I would never eat again.  It says spicy, but it should say initiatory.  The beans are crisp tender, but their natural sweetness is drowned out by such a hot sauce that you will lose all feeling between your mouth and your chin.  Food should not hurt.

Pork Belly with Tea Soaked Egg - the restaurant was out of noodles, so this was not prepared as it usually is.  It was still fantastic.  You pop the yolk, and it oozes all over the chewy belly with a crunchy sear.  Talk about rich!  Salty pork in creamy egg goodness.

Beef Cheeks with Chinese Broccoli - hands down the best beef and broccoli that I have ever eaten.  The beef cheeks are rich and tender (a bit reminiscent of marrow), and the chinese broccoli is crisp tender, the sweet offering a welcome compliment to the butter beef.  Sprinkled with sesame seeds, this dish appears traditional but has exceptional flavor.

Thrice Cooked Bacon - VEGETARIAN?!?!  This dish was made with tofu skin, which tasted like the most perfect braised bacon without the heavy after feeling.  The korean rice cake is a brilliant, chewy cross between rice and noodles.  The veggies were plentiful and crisp.  I think that this was the best dish of the evening.  A great smoky, sweet, spicy mash-up.

General Tsao Veal Rib - a huge beef rib with a crisp sear encapsulating rich red meat served in a fermented black bean sauce.  I love black bean sauce - salty goodness.  This was an excellent dish.

Steamed rice accompanied our dishes and was welcome to sop up the sauce.  I would definitely recommend Mission Chinese to a friend.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
This place has a ton of hype and I'm not here to argue with that whatsoever. My friends and I put our name down on a weekday evening and didn't wait that long at all -- definitely no more than 30 minutes -- which we expected anyway, so we went to the liquor store to booze up. When they called us in we sat down with our beers (yes, you can bring in your own booze if it's brown-paper-bagged) and proceeded to explore the menu. As a trio we ordered the thrice cooked bacon, their insanely spicy chicken wings (more on that later), and the salt cod fried rice.

It was either before or as the chicken wings came out, a man came over to us to give us a freakin' advisory -- hahahahaha. But I'm glad he did. He basically told us that we were going to experience a tingling feeling on our lips because of how hot the wings are and he was absolutely right. My other 2 friends couldn't handle it so I gobbled up the wings myself -- mmmmmmm and we didn't even get the spiciest of them all!! I'm actually too afraid to try that tier now hahahaha!

The thrice-cooked bacon was mmm mmm good. It's a bunch of things if I remember correctly: bacon (which is cooked, freezed, and then recooked, am I right?), bitter melon, tofu, sun dried rice cakes, and a bunch of other things -- so not JUST bacon, but a bunch of other things complimenting it as well. Loved it.

And then there was the...drum roll...salt cod fried rice! This thing is crack. I've never even had cod before but something about all of the flavors in this made it just melt in my mouth. Again, another dish that I ended up finishing -- well, most of it considering that tall can of beer sitting in my belly.

The service was outstanding -- truly nice folks everywhere. The environment? Well, it's a pop-up but everyone around you is so damn cheerful and excited just like you, so it makes it a very happy dining experience. I'm going back ASAP.
author: Jonny A.

description: If you've had a lot of Chinese food, I would recommend not going here because it's not what you would expect. It's more of a fusion, but not entirely fusion either. During my visit, I ordered the tea-steamed crispy eel roll, the salted cod fried rice, and the spicy chicken wings. The salted cod fried rice was bland, the rice was clumped together which isn't supposed to be in authentic fried rice. I also think more salted cod could have been added in. The eel roll wasn't bad. The watercress they had made it a bit bitter which was a nice twist to it, though I prefer the traditional thick rice noodle dish to be filled with shrimp. Lastly, the wings were my favourite of the three. The batter wasn't thick, salty, flavourful, and had a really good kick to it.
author: Jessica D.

description:
What is Danny trying to hide by over spicing his food with chili peppers?

The service was fine, the delivery guy was nice ... BUT the food is terrible.  I've tried this place twice, and I don't understand why there's so much hype about this place or why Danny Bowien is even bothering to bring MCF to New York. 

I guess its cool to eat food in a hole-in-the-wall-style Chinese restaurant with a mom n' pop environment while listening to hip hop playing from the speakers, but its bordering 'trying too hard' and it really doesn't matter when the food is sub par.

The food is either bland or way too spicy.  Or worse, spicy and bland. I don't recommend the ma po tofu (fire) or pastrami (bland fire) or the salt cod fried rice (rice was overcooked and became soggy).

Their only saving grace is their financial contribution to the SF food bank.

It's not hard to find good Chinese food in SF.  It's just not here.
author: Cheryl C.

description:
Finally we had seats! Food is good! We had:

Mapo Tufu: the spices they use are very unique, different from the rest of Chinese restaurants. Excellent!
Mongolian Long Beans: Good.
West Lake Rice Porridge: it contains lots of stuff: chopped  beef, Dungeness crab meat, egg, etc. A little salty, but still Excellent!
Salt code fried rice: Good
Pork belly: the best in SF bay area. I love pork belly. This is the best you can find in Bay Area. Crispy outside, tender and juicy inside, and just right amount of sweetness. Cannot be better!
author: Emmy P.

description:
I'd heard about this place and it intrigued me so I gave it a try.
I really wanted to like it. The place looks like a typical Chinese restaurant until you open the menu and see the prices.  I new it was supposed to be special so I didn't let the prices  dissuade me. I ordered the forbidden rice and the veal rib.

The rice was nothing special. Mediocre at best.

When the rib arrived it looked very impressive on the plate and was delivered with a fork and knife. In fact the knife was a serrated steak knife.

 I've been in the construction trade for over 35 years with a background in carpentry and am considered to be good with my hands. Trying to cut and separate the meat from the grizzle and cartilage was extremely difficult for me. When I did get what I thought was an edible piece of meat I found that it contained cartilage or grizzle that was inedible. In fact I had to spit so many pieces of cartilage back into my napkin I had to eventually dump it out  and I'm afraid some of it ended up on the floor beneath the table. To their credit, the sauce was excellent. Unfortunately it was wasted on a lousy piece of meat. The price of that dish was $19.00 so I really expected better.
author: Adam H.

description:
One of my favorite indulgences. Worth the wait. There is usually a wait. Personally, I'd try the Thrice cooked bacon without the bacon (the tofu skin makes me melt inside) and the fresh rice noodles. Was not a fan of the Ma Po Tofu. The tofu was too soft and the dish left a weird numbing feeling in my mouth...which is strange because it didn't actually taste very spicy to me. And I love spicy.
Also a big fan of their staff. They have always been very sweet and very on top of their game.
author: Leigh S.

description: Went here yesterday with myself and  3 other chefs, blown away with the food they put out of the confines of such a small place !!! Simply put AMAZING !! You will not find flavors like this anywhere else in San Francisco... If you have not been this place is a MUST!!! A MUST!!!! Great job to everyone there!!!!
author: Zachary I.

description: Mission Chinese food is great if you know what to expect (i.e., fusion vs. authentic Chinese food)! We ended up spending $150 for 5 people, which is pretty expensive for Chinese food, but I think it was worth it. I especially loved the veal ribs, pork belly, tea-smoked eel. I didn't try the cumin lamb (personally not into lamb) but heard from everyone else at the table that it was delicious.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Very frustrating because of the wait. I don't mind waiting if the parties before me are actually there and waiting as well. Many times the guy would call multiple names 5 times and then an hour later if they showed up and he'd call their name again he'd still take them! It wasn't a good way to do business. People that we're waiting beside us and just as long as some of those groups would be next if those other groups were passed. 
Just not a great way to do business. 
We did enjoy the food though. 
Thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes - my favorite dish, bacon cooked perfectly, rice cakes were good 
Other dishes were just ok nothing special.
author: Naomi J.

description:
My wife and I got delivery of this hyped-up Chinese food on 5/12/13 and were both disappointed. As far as Chinese food goes, this was on the expensive side and not very satisfying.

I had the General Tso's Veal Rib. While there was certainly some tasty bites in there, overall it wasn't that great. There was a lot of fat in the dish and it does not come with rice or anything on the side. I wish I had known that because my entire meal was just a big hunk of meat. (Yes, I could have taken a closer study of the menu and realized this, but I figured for 18 bucks it would include rice).

My wife had Thrice Cooked Bacon. I had a few bites and while the bacon was pretty good, overall the meal was very spicy. Again, it did not come with rice which made it difficult to eat since it was so spicy. I should note that my wife is Korean and is used to eating spicy food and still found this dish on the spicy side.

Finally, they did not deliver any utensils or napkins with the meal which was annoying since we were staying in a hotel and didn't have any readily available.
author: William Y.

description:
As many other reviewers have said, Mission Chinese Food doesn't serve up your typical Chinese cuisine. All of the dishes are very flashy in terms of marinades, sauces and seasonings. 

What I ate: Ma Po Tofu, Chili Pickled Long Beans, Salt Cod Fried Rice, General Tso's Veal Rib, Tea Smoked Eel

All in all, MCF is a "nice to try" but I wouldn't be a regular here because....

1) Salt. Please do not eat here if you have blood pressure problems, because every dish here is extremely salty or spicy. Chili oil is used a lot here. Be sure to have a gallon of water handy. After a while, it was hard for me to taste the difference between the dishes I ordered because all I could focus on was drinking enough water to power through all the saltiness. 
2) Prices. For the prices, I'd rather pay the same amount and get 5x more Chinese food AND have delivery/tip be included in that price. 
3) The wait. Given points #1 and #2, I don't find much value in waiting 45+ minutes for the aforementioned dishes. SF is a big foodie town and there's a plethora of restaurants that I'd happily camp out to try, but MCF isn't one of them. For better Asian Fusion grub, I prefer The House in North Beach.
author: Helen W.

description:
ok, dark and raise the red lantern-y. 
Food is very good if you're Asian, and maybe great if you're not Asian and didn't grow up with some of this? Granted not with the saffron threads and cilantro, but it's better tarted up versions of things you ate as a kid, with some new and interesting dishes. Definitely worth a trip, maybe two. 

The wait is preposterous. So bring a snack.
author: Lily K.

description:
Came here around 8 or 9 pm on a Thurday night and waited about 45 minutes to get a table. The wait time did not seem unreasonable to me given the popularity and actual size of the restaurant.

We ordered the chicken wings and pork belly to start. While I was a huge fan of the pork belly, the chicken wings were way too spicy for me. In fact, I have never felt my lips tingle from spicy food until then.  I guess they don't mess around with the 2 fire symbols.

For our entrees we ordered the Ma Po Tofu which was just okay to me because I felt that it needed a bit more flavor. I did really like the Kung Pao Pastrami, but I felt that it needed more pastrami pieces and to ease up on the overabundance of celery.

Service was great. Our waitress was very attentive and helpful even though they were packed for dinner. 

Overall, I wasn't blown away on my first visit but wouldn't mind trying some of the other things on the menu at this place.
author: Valentina M.

description:
Mob scene waiting for a table on Saturday night.  Well worth the wait.  
The Long Bean Dish was fantastic.  SO was the Green Pea dish.  The rice as to be expected was mediocre at best.  Service was fast and good.  All in all I will go back.  Not sure if it is wise to go with a large party.  Deuces were getting seated quickly.
author: Christopher F.

description:
I love this place, but last night I was disappointed.  I think they've become complacent with their popularity and are not putting in as much effort in their food.  

The past many times I've come here, it has been a solid 5 star event.  Last night, the food was 'meh' and the service was 'meh' and the order which they brought out food was annoying.

My go to - the ma po tofu was bland, not spicy, and lacked meat!!  It was a shadow of what it used to be.

The server's suggestions were not very helpful and she seemed to say 'that is good' to everything we asked about without describing the dish or giving us any other information required to make a good decision. 

The veal ribs had like zero meat on them, and I think the main part was the burnt skin?  Not worth $18.

They brought out the chicken wings about 20 minutes after we finished eating the other 4 dishes; it is something I would have brought out first.  Not sure why they did that, and quite annoyed as I was full by the time the "appetizer" came out.

Hopefully they will focus on the food again.  For an $80 meal, I was disappointed.
author: reza n.

description: We always have a great meal here. It never fails. It may not be the most authentic but it is creative and interesting every time. Definitely try the Ma po tofu. It has those great numbing spices that I have only ever had in China. Go early as it can be busy and you will have to wait outside since it's a small restaurant. But it's worth the wait!
author: Jennifer S.

description: We went here to celebrate my best bud's birthday and absolutely loved it! We ordered basically everything (all excellent) but our favorites were the chicken wings, squid ink noodles and the veal ribs.  Highly recommended!! Just make sure to have a reservation. :)
author: Maggie B.

description: I placed a delivery order after reading reviews and now wish I hadn't. The beef chow mein was completely boring. Average greasy junk, except there were only about three morsels of beef in the whole thing. The pork belly was nearly tasteless. This place seems to be very polarizing, you either get a great experience or a bad one, and I got a bad one. Given the way the food tasted, the price of it was insulting.
author: David S.

description:
Okay, let's not be idiots and compare this to traditional Chinese food. This is not even trying to be traditional people to calm the hell down. Yes it doesn't taste like traditional and yes it is more expensive than a typical chinese restaurant.

Here are some valid reasons to steer clear:
1. Way too salty. I love salt, and this was ridiculous. There are other flavors in the food besides salt, but the salt was completely overwhelming.
2. 3 out of 4 people in my party experienced some severe pooping problems following the meal (great group text conversation that was)

Other comments:
The menu is confusing when it says vegan or vegan optional...its just not clear if you have to ask for to be made vegan or not...so basically just ask if that's what you want. While we did not have to wait (surprisingly), we were smushed in against a billion other people. There is no way that this restaurant would pass a fire inspection with their table layout.

Bottom line: there are better places to eat in the mission and most of them don't have god awful lines.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Ridiculous food. Extremely salty eel roll and the beef with orange basically consists of  fried dough. The fusion concept looks good on the paper but simply doesn't work on the palate. Our cumin lamb was the only somewhat redeeming dish and we still couldn't finish it due to the combination of heavy use of spice and  fat-dripping lamb ribs. The guy waiter was a joke- no service throughout and we saw him making some takeout customer wait outside for thirty minutes without telling him that his dish was ready for pickup all this time.

I'm native chinese and had plenty of first-class chinese-peruvian fusion  food while living in south america. Mission Chinese is not a good fusion execution. Don't bite into the fad.
author: Adam X.

description:
Overrated! Cheesy interior, bad service. The food was okay, but the menu is 90% one chili (hot) or two chils (goodbye taste buds!) I don't mind some spice, but I don't want a whole menu of spice. 

It's like a four minute walk from BART. I wouldn't recommend going. But if you go, BART it.
author: Karen Z.

description:
Loved the Ma Po Tofu, it was rich and spicy and the gravy was amazing 3 hours later eating standing at my kitchen counter.

It was cold out so the porridge sounded like a good idea and it was a perfectly, delicately balanced garlicky comfort food.

The tiger salad was good but I'd not bother with it again.

Hose made pickles were a terrific start.

Looking forward to going back!
author: Mason C.

description:
The food is fantastic.
But my last experience, the staff were jerks. 

It's raining, it's 9:45, they close at 10:30. 
"Hey, are you guys still open?" "Well, technically, but we're redoing the back room, and if we seat you we'd have to stay another hour."
"... OK...."
Server leaves, seats a table of four.
"I don't understand, how come you seated them, won't that cause you to stay longer? Are you open or closed, the hours say you close at 10:30."
"Well, we'd have to stay another hour..."
"So... can you seat me or not?"
"Well, I guess not."

It's a real disappointment to have passive aggressive service. I wouldn't mind them saying "Sorry, we can't seat you." but to only respond with leading statements while serving another customer was crushing.

I loved eating here before, now I'll just order delivery. At least the delivery guy is nice.
author: Felix S.

description: One of my friends would always come over after work. Before heading to my place he would pick up 2-3 delicious boxes of takeout from Mission Chinese Food. Portions are good and very flavorful. Their lamb is very delicious and I can eat with rice as my daily meal. Have yet to to actually try it inside the restaurant but I would be surprised if it didn't taste the same or better.
author: Kelly N.

description: This is a very, very, confused place.  Some of their dishes, like their fried rice and cumin lamb are good, but things like kung-pao pastrami does not taste that good.  It wants to be hip and trendy for hipsters in the city, but some things just simply do not go together, no matter how ironic you are.
author: James S.

description:
This quaint hole in the wall in the "hip" mission district accepted our 6 person party with ease.  The service was both friendly and fast.  They gave recommendations on how and what to order for such a large group.  

After being to China twice, the food here was the most authentic I've had in the states.
author: Chris K.

description:
I came here not expecting to get authentic Chinese food and with pretty low expectations, but still the food was very disappointing. We arrived around 6:30pm on a Saturday evening and were seated about 40 minutes later. The vibe in the restaurant is pretty cool, but definitely caters to a younger crowd. There was visible grease and bits of food stuck to the wall right next to where we were sitting, which wasn't terribly appetizing. Once we ordered, the food arrived quickly. 

Tea-Smoked Eel - This dish was overly salty, and the hoisin sauce completely overpowered the other ingredients in the roll. We could not even taste the eel.

Grandma's Spicy Lamb Dumplings - These dumplings were just okay. The dish and the dumplings tasted overwhelmingly of cilantro, which I didn't enjoy.

Broccoli Beef Brisket - The Chinese broccoli was pretty oily, and the beef brisket had an overtly smoky flavor. 

Overall, we did not enjoy our dining experience at all and would not return.
author: Teresa H.

description:
I went back with a couple friends who have never been to MCF, and I left the restaurant vowing never to come back.

We started with the peanuts, which were good but on the very salty side. We also ordered the mouth watering chicken, mapo tofu, and sizzling cumin lamb.

Um...despite the name that mouth watering chicken is not mouth watering at all.  The three of us agreed that the name is really deceiving and we left a lot of it untouched. I don't know what seasonings they use, but it had a funky smell to it and not a great texture either.  It was completely unappetizing.

The sizzling cumin lamb was maybe the highlight of the meal.  Actually, the grilled onions and peppers that come in this dish were the highlight of the meal.  Seasoning on the dish were good and flavorful, but the "meat" we got was probably like 85% lamb fat.  One big chunk I took was entirely fat.  I literally could not find any lamb meat on that big chunk at all. I thought it was an anomaly but my friends also had similarly predominantly lamb fat pieces.  What a disappointment!

The absolute lowlight of this meal was the mapo tofu.  We asked for it to be not as spicy as normal because quite frankly we all knew it would be too much for us to handle.  Not surprisingly, it took them a little longer to make us our dish since they had to make it from scratch rather than just scoop up whatever they have simmering away in the back.  It.. Was. Awful.  There was a huge pool of oil across the entire bowl and the mapo "sauce" tasted essentially like glorified ketchup, which makes no sense because there are no tomatoes in mapo.  The pieces of pork shoulder were tender but otherwise I thought this dish was a complete failure.

I am also now convinced that MCF makes their food extremely spicy because they don't want you to actually taste any of their food.  Combine the crappy food with the fact that they're still trying to pass themselves off as a pop-up restaurant, the ridiculous wait, and awful interior of the restaurant, I honestly don't know why people like this place so much.  Good news for all the MCF fans is that they now have one less SF diner to compete with in the future for dinner.
author: Naoko M.

description:
Atmosphere fits the food. We had the fresh rice noodles which was good, although they should explain that if it's under Small Dishes then the server should explain that it's actually good for two people and maybe too much for one person. Maybe that's just me. Ma po tofu was okay, very spicy to those who enjoy mild spicy, definitely past that. Mongolian Long Beans was tasty and very very very spicy.

Service could have been better, our waitress wasn't as attentive and friendly as the blonde hostess was to us for some reason. In total, it's an okay fun spot for groups, but as for the quality of food and service I still prefer the NYC LES spot more.
author: Fashionista M.

description:
Before you walk into this super-hyped restaurant or place a delivery order, take a deep breath and repeat to yourself this very important note:

Mission Chinese is not typical Chinese food.

Say that five times. Now wait in line. Or come in during non-meal hours, because the wait during lunch and dinner can go up to an hour or more.

Sit down in the dim interior and stare at the paper dragon overhead while someone's Pandora station* plays in the background. Soon, a nice waiter comes by and asks in perfect English for your order. Repeat to yourself a second equally important note:

Don't order more than a combined rating of three chili peppers.

Make your order. If you're eating during normal meal hours, try to hear your companions over the noise of other patrons, or if you're eating off-hours, take a look around.

See that couple with the hefty bowl of ma-po tofu (two chili rating), half finished? They're staring at it and seriously considering taking it back home**. Between them sits a plate of thrice-cooked bacon (one chili rating). They scrap away the copious amount of jalapeno slices and thus are able to enjoy the tender bacon and chewy rice cakes***. The girl laments about too few bittermelon pieces and too much onion, and laughs at her partner grimacing at the taste of bittermelon.

The third plate on their table contains a large heap of Szechuan peppers. They shuffle through them and fetch out small fried chicken wings (two chili rating). The wings are sprinkled with what looks like paprika and black pepper. Altogether, the plate contains about 6-8 wings. They finish them all, and the heap of peppers awaits cleanup. The girl licks her fingers and smiles in approval****. She then wonders aloud, "Throwing them away would be such a waste. I mean, they're so spicy, you can reuse them." You hope they don't for sanitary reasons, but you are more concerned about your own tolerance of them on your chicken wings than the destiny of theirs.

The man of the couple looks red in the face, gulps down his water, and comments that he is full. The girl spoons more mapo tofu onto her plate and slurps them up with rice, before taking a sip from her glass of water. She must be a saint.

Satisfied, the thrice-cooked bacon now just onions and jalapenos, the ma-po tofu spooned into a container, they leave. The girl says on the way out, "My lips are numb from the tofu."***** Meanwhile, your own ma-po bowl thumps down in front of you and your companions, and they whistle in disbelief.

Good luck, have fun. ^_^

* I actually don't know if it's Pandora, but I heard an odd mix of songs when I ate here, mostly 90's alt rock.
** Don't get me wrong, the ma-po was quite good. The spiciness isn't so much hot-spicy, as it is numbing-spicy. Big difference between the two.
*** It's a good thing I'm not a strict vegetarian, because I couldn't help eating the bacon and rice cakes. The least spicy of the dishes we got. Quite a few onions, and be very careful you don't mix up the cilantro with the jalapenos.
**** The wings had a good balance of crispiness, salt, and spice. But what were they expecting us to do with the pile of peppers? Eat them?
***** Although I give this place just three stars, I'm willing to come back and not be so dumb about getting too much spicy dishes.
author: Hannah H.

description:
Decent dinner out. Food was good but flavors got kind of old after half of the dish. Definitely worth trying, but the environment and wait make it a little less than desirable. Its always hard when a place has so much hype, its almost destined to fail. Maybe I will find myself back here and have a better/more enjoyable dish. 

Will say that the squid ink noodles were pretty tasty, just on the salty end so definitely share it with another. I would also try something other than the Thrice Cooked Bacon. Bacon was very tasty but way too many rice cakes.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Was strolling around with my cousin from the east coast to show him around and stumbled upon this place. It was pretty poppin for a wednesday night, seemed like a chill spot. Wait time was about 10 minutes. 

Environment was cool, young crowd, hip hop music (which seemed wierd for a chinese restaurant) which is why we stopped by lol but overall the food was pretty good. 

I ordered:
Tea Smoked Eel - 3.5/5 Not bad, but I think there was like a chinese spinach or something I wasn't really feeling after the second bite
West Lake Rice Porridge - 4.5/5 pretty good
Salt Cod Fried Rice - 5/5 I never had fish in my fried rice which I thought was really good. 

I'd definitely come back to try the thrice cooked bacon. 

Con: bathroom is way in the back, have to go through the kitchen and all. Not sure how they keep the place clean with all the people walking through the kitchen but just an inconvenience as a customer.
author: Kevin R.

description:
Loved Mission Chinese. Got the salted cod fried rice, mabo tofu, pumpkin and pea leaf vegetable and the cold cucumber with peanuts. 

Every bite was delicious. Well worth the wait.
Definitely coming back whenever I'm in SF.
author: Chris C.

description:
Okay. I'm Chinese (duh) so I had to see what the great hype was about. Even a pal in Florida had asked if I have ever been to MCF because GQ magazine named it a restaurant you must dine at in San Francisco.

Here's the thing. Certain dishes are good, but definitely not worth waiting 45+ minutes for.

salt cod fried rice - I really liked this. Usually salted cod fried rice is pretty plain in my opinion but Mission Chinese food adds a good amount of cilantro (ew.. I scraped all of it off my portion), green onions, Chinese sausage, etc. My friend thought it was too salty but I really enjoyed this. 
pork belly - I hated this. I really really really wanted to love this, but I just couldn't. Initial bite had crunch from the crispy skin, but after I sunk my teeth all the way through, I felt like my mouth was full of greasy mashed potatoes. Yeap, it was all fat. I actually forced myself to finish one whole piece but my friend couldn't even stomach it after his first bite. No bueno man, no bueno. 
Taiwanese clams - winner!!!! very similar to Chinese style clams in black bean sauce but had some heat to it. I would have to say this was a favorite (obviously) but I guess this gets rotated on and off the menu. Same friend who dined with me ordered for pick up on Mother's Day and it wasn't on the menu. So if you're here and it IS on the menu, go for it.
thrice cooked bacon -  really liked this even though it can be overwhelmingly spicy after awhile. the heat settles and kind of kicks you in the mouth, phew! loved the salty smokiness of the bacon, sweetness from tofu skin, doughy-ness from the rice cakes (you know, those Korean ones. ddukbboki?) and tons of onions and peppers. this can also get salty if you continuously eat it so I highly recommend mixing it with rice. 

So to reiterate..  I wouldn't wait. BUT if you're in the area by chance right when they open and there is no line.. well by all means, go for it! 
But if you are trying to come here during dinner hours...FORGET IT! Your wait will definitely be an hour+
author: Susy C.

description:
Great grub.  Everything we ordered, we mowed down fast.  

The seating is kind of tight but I think that's the trend in the City lately.
author: E L.

description:
*Review is only for takeout. Owing to a complete lack of patience for lines, this is the only way I'll be able to eat here for the foreseeable future.

Very, very good, I thought, for a great price and just a couple negatives.

Kung pao pastrami was a scorcher, in that my head was sweating and it was difficult to eat. I would have eaten much more in one sitting (I had the rest for leftovers) otherwise. But what I did eat was delicious and a unique way to prepare something so commonplace.

A second time, I had a tiger salad (good) and smoked beef brisket noodles, the noodles being my favorite so far. I had a much better experience the second time, since I wasn't so uncomfortable trying to eat.

I'd like to stay and eat at the restaurant one day, but I'm good with takeout for now.
author: Tara R.

description: Im not saying I'm a huge foodie but this place is no goodie. If you feel like burning off all of your taste buds then try their chicken wings. It's a mouthful of confused flavours that when you try to wash it down with your water, your water will taste like Yellow River of China. The tea smoked eel roll, tasted nothing like any of the adjectives describing it. Too all of the Chinese food lovers over there...go elsewhere.
author: Alisa D.

description:
After reading all the reviews and seeing him on tv, I was intrigued.

Got there at 6:30pm wait was 3 minutes. Line was slowly forming though. 

Ordered the pork belly, salt cod rice, smoke eel, and the peas.

Won't go into super detail. Overall ok experience with what I ordered. Would go back to try other things but take out maybe as you know parking in the mission isn't the best and was not keen on the tight space.

Liked the eel but everything else was overly salty and pedestrian.
author: germaine n.

description:
This isn't just our favorite spot in San Francisco. It's one of our favorite spots on the globe. We have waited two hours in line to eat at this pop up restaurant in San Francisco's Mission district, and it was worth every minute. If you go on a Friday or Saturday, expect to wait a while. There is a corner store next door, so grab a couple beers and wait on the sidewalk. That alone is pretty fun.

Earlier in the week we were able to walk in with no wait at all.

All the food is amazing, but the thrice cooked bacon is especially amazing. Elizabeth often eats the vegan version, and yes, even its amazing.
author: Wesley D.

description: Wow, it's been a long time since I been this disappointed in a meal.  The pickled veg small plate and vinegar peanuts small plate were, literally, inedible. Pure raw vinegar flavor,  no seasoning,  except the 3 cloves of "confit" garlic laid on top. What the heck? The *famous* chicken wings were so overcooked that there was not a drop of moisture left in them - and while they came buried beneath a ginormous pile of dried chilis, the wings themselves were not flavored other than having a thin sprinkling of seasoning on the top side of the skin. (The seasoning reminded both of us of Larry's Seasoned Salt).  Okay, now regarding the "shrimp dumplings" on a bed of picked veg.  It's the same inedible raw vinegar "pickles"  referenced above. People, I love pickles of all types including quick pickles, however there is no way that you can fairly describe completely raw veg submerged briefly in pure vinegar &  a splash of soy sauce as  "pickles".  The dumplings were more like small tortellini than dumpling,  and again, seasoning was not there.  Lastly, the drinks. We ordered one of the specials ($12) that was vodka and ginger beer with kaffir lime.  It wasn't as bad as the food, but unimpressive nonetheless.  The bill for this regrettable meal was just under $60 before tip.  With so many fantastic and inexpensive options for Chinese food in the area, I do not understand all the rave reviews for Mission Chinese. I'm writing this negative review in the hope that some foodie tourist (like me) doesn't fall for the hype and waste a meal and $$$ at Mission Chinese.
author: Vero C.

description:
Is it possible that the hype for Mission Chinese has died down a little?  Our wait for three people was 30 minutes max on a Thursday night at 7:30. I was very surprised (not to mention grateful). 

It's dark inside - not "candlelight at your table, dim lighting" dark, but more like "typical mission dive bar" dark.  The atmosphere is not particularly classy and the service is nothing to write home about (we sat at our table for 15 minutes before anyone came to check in with us).  

Now that I've said all of that - let me tell you, the food is delicious and makes up for all of the above.  Food items I'd order again:  (1) Ma Po Tofu - yes it's spicy.  It's a reddish sauce + tofu, no veggies or anything else.  Our mistake was not ordering a side of rice with this dish - you'll want something to soak up all of the delicious sauce.  (2) Kung Pao Pastrami - the pastrami was amazing (I don't even like pastrami normally!) -  it's not deli meat slices, but rather chunks of fatty, flavorful goodness.  

Not as big of a fan of: (1) Bok choy in popcorn broth - it's a big bowl of mini bok choys in a miso sauce (still not sure why it's called popcorn broth).  Nothing particularly unique or flavorful; I guess if you are looking for veggies in your meal, this could be a good choice.  (2) Mouthwatering Chicken - chicken thigh and heart with vegetable noodle.  The noodles were cold which I wasn't expecting (it also turns out that I'm not a big fan of chicken heart).

Three things to note: they deliver; they take credit cards; and they only serve beer and wine.   I definitely plan to come back and explore other food options - it was a wonderful first experience!
author: Kimya P.

description:
My husband and I watch the food channel and somehow this place ended up on it... We went to SF yesterday to drop our daughter off at the airport and decided to eat here first... 

Can I just say... NOT what I expected... The place is dim and the staff was not exactly the friendliest but ok... we can put that aside. It just looked far more glamorous/cleaner on the show. 

FOOD... 
I knew what I was going for and it was the Thrise Cooked Bacon, it did not have the HOT symbol in front of it so I thought it would be good to share with my family (husband is not a spicy kind of guy) Well... I think they got my meal and daughter's meal mixed up. She had TWO flames next to her Kung Poa Pastrami (sp) and mine was WAY spicier than hers... whoa...

Baby Bok Choy with Popcorn sauce- Good... I actually enjoyed this a lot

KP Pastrami- WHERE'S THE MEAT? What little there was was totally off the hook but could I get some more? It's like I was vegan and someone threw bacon bits in... GIVE ME SOME MEAT MAN!

Mouthwatering Chicken... Well.. I saved this one for last. My husband and I are foodies and my huaband who loves just about anything he puts in his mouth absolutely HATED this... He said it tasted like dish soap... I felt horrible for him as he just ate some of the peanuts in the dish and then proceeded to eat some of the food we ordered. My daughter then tasted it and by god she said the same thing... rummaging through the livers and other chicken pieces he found one for me to try... GROSS... AND IT WAS COLD! 

I'm asian... I love everything... our orders other than the Mouthwatering chicken were OK... but I'm not going back there... SO NOT WORTH THE WAIT...
author: Sue N.

description:
Come to this place drunk!!! Amazing food, hip place, very nice portions.  Just a very fun place to be at.
W
author: Sammy S.

description: I would come back here again for the thrice cooked bacon and smoked brisket noodle soup. Overall the food is a little on the salty/oily side. Some of the other dishes (the ones marked with fire) are too spicy for my taste. Kind of a divey place so if ambience is your thing, then this place is not. Communal seating and so-so service.
author: Bowen J.

description:
thrice cooked bacon is as addictive as always
ma po tofu is a spicy and a killer dish still
where are the rest?
author: Linda L.

description:
we ordered 6 dishes and it came to about $107.00 with tip

we came on a friday night at 6pm and it wasn't crowded.  6:45 rolls by and there's a crowd outside.


smoke beef brisket noodle soup: highly recommended

skip the bok choy, chongqing chicken wings, stir-fried sweat peas, some sort of fried-rice.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Had such a hard time deciding what to get, everything looked so intriguing, combinations of things I haven't seen before. Ended up trying the Tea-smoked Eel. So good! and lots of interesting textures.

Will be back to try more!
author: Lilian K.

description:
Came here on a weekday and to my surprise the place was packed and there was a line outside. I just thought this place MUST be that good if people are willing to wait... 

Quick summary - walk up, put your name on the wait list, wait, get seated, don't expect to sit in a booth or anywhere private), enjoy the random music & eat great food!
author: Mich G.

description:
I was a little leery of this place based on the love it or leave it type of reviews it seems to get.  Alas, Betty and I had to try it out and judge for ourselves.  It passed the test for us.  We got the eel rolls which were pretty good.  The wings were Betty's favorite and were awesome because they made our lips tingle with spice.  I loved the thrice cooked bacon with chewy little rice cakes.  The tofu skin and smoky bacon were very satisfying.  We also got the beer brined pickled veggies which sadly was light on the cucumbers.  Is it the best Chinese food I've ever had, no.  Is it interesting and flavorful and worth trying for yourself, yes!

I liked the mix of rap/indie music in the background and it was not crowded at all during lunch time on a Thursday.  Good service and enjoyed my 21st Amendment brew.
author: Bob B.

description:
I so wanted to like this place. The service was good, waiter helpful in ordering. I'd read and heard all the hype and really wanted to check this place out for soooo long. And the Egg Egg noodles were good. But....
With that being said we had some "Mouth Watering Chicken" which is a cold dish, okay no big deal there...but it had some kind of spice on it that after a while coated your mouth. And when I went to drink some water it made the water taste weird. And it really overpowered the dish. I'm all for trying new and different flavors, but I just felt it was so overpowering that the chicken and other ingredients got lost and became disinteresting. We also had the long beans which were not bad (also a cold dish) crunchy and spicy. I guess if we had tried maybe some other items, I just wasn't that impressed for all the hype around the talk. 
I guess it's just not for everyone.....Note: I did try making Danny Bowien's Tea-Infused Poached Chicken stuffed with rice from a recipe that was posted in a magazine. Though the chicken had a really great flavor, the rice didn't cook (twice I tried this recipe??) and had to pull the rice out and cook separately. And this recipe is not on the menu, so I wasn't able to try it to see if I was close to making it right.
author: Susan D.

description:
If you like hot peppers sauteed in hotter peppers sprinkled with some finishing pepper salt for good measure then the Thrice Cooked Bacon is something you have to try. I warn you though the thick smokey bacon is addictive and the 3 kinds of chili peppers will light you up like a MoFro!!

This place can throw down some awesome home cooking just prepare yourself for downscale decor and service with a frown. Although on the bright side if that weren't the case you'd have to wait hours for food this good.
author: R J.

description:
"Fire! Fire!" Yes, that's right, my tongue was on FIRE!!!  We have been passing by this place and each time there's a crowd waiting to be seated.  So, we decided to try it.  
I just want to say that this place will probably get a 5-star from someone who loves SPICY food.  I just wish there was a warning sign at the front door.  

Here are what we ordered:
beef ribs - it was ok, but had I known this was the least spiciest, I would have eaten more of it
chicken wings - okay, this is the dish that needs a warning because this will burn your taste buds for the next 24 hours...well, it did mine. No joke.  The plate is served with an abundant of chili, so much so that I couldn't see the chicken.  That should have been the first sign that I should have never even tried it.
mongolian beef - we asked them to make this mild, but at the first bite, I swear, something bit me back.  They said it was mild, but it still stung my tongue.
sweet peas - this is the only dish that I could eat and enjoyed eating.  It was still spicy, but in comparison with the others, it was the only dish that did not burn my taste buds. 

The next day, my tongue was sore and burnt that I could not taste anything.  Maybe this place should start a diet program...because after one visit, you wouldn't be able to taste anything and therefore have no desire to eat!
author: N A.

description: The wait here is long the seating is bad and its kinda pricey~ but all that said the food is great~ I recommend the brisket soup~ the pork belly and the Eel ~ The brisket soup alone is worth the wait. Show up early for seating minimum wait for me has been around an hour n parking sucks so cab it or take muni/ bart.
author: Duke Of Frisco X.

description: Not bad for a chef that likes to eat cold Chinese food (???). More atmosphere here than taste of the food.
author: Nora X.

description:
Pricey for Chinese food. $ 70 for 5 dishes, two beers, rice, and tip. 

I like the laid back, hipster atmosphere.  Food...eh.  Way too greasy for me.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Great non-traditional Chinese food. Great rock and roll. Great crowd.
Cumin baked lamb ribs...yum but fatty.
Pork jawl
Rice noodles with peanut sauce
Rice with schmaltz
author: James M.

description:
I've been a big fan of Mission Chinese since day one. I've recommended this place to everyone and their mother. My favorite dish has been the Kung Pao Pastrami. I have waited in line, made the trek to the mission, ordered for delivery...and at first  it was awesome. Lately..not so much. I was really excited to pick up my order tonight. Kung Pao Pastrami, Cucumber Salad, and Tiger salad. 

I was stuck in traffic but looking forward to my dinner and I was really disappointed. My Kung Pao Patrami lacked pastrami and the little it did have consisted 85% cubes of fat, it lacked flavor and honestly it was a mess. The Tiger Salad was meh...and the Cucumber Salad was tasty but looked horrible. 

Now had it been just this one time...I would have said...Everyone has an off night, whatever. And at first that is what I thought but then I realized the last few times I kept saying...maybe they were too busy... maybe the regular chef had the night off....I was making excuses for them.   This isn't your $10 chinese food. My dinner was about $27, just for one! No drinks, just food. 

 If I wasn't in the TenderNob I would totally walk over there and show them. It's going to be while before I return. 

 I'm quite sad.
author: Lidia Z.

description: Pretty decent weird Chinese food. They make the food spicy as requested so I gave them extra points for that! :) Only got delivery from them so my bet it is always better to eat at the restaurant. Will do a follow up review !
author: Drew W.

description:
Worth the hype and the delivery wait!

I ordered delivery from here on a cold, drizzly Friday night. I am in the marina and they said it would take about an hour and ten minutes, not bad considering a pizza from down the street normally takes about an hour in this weather on a Friday night. 

Food arrived in about an hour and twenty minutes and was plenty hot and smelled fantastic! Our favorites were the Westlake Rice porridge (I did not taste any crab but overall taste was amazing!), the Kung Pao Pastrami (super spicy!), the thrice cooked bacon (bacon happiness) and the Stir Fried Sweat Peas which complimented the spicy food perfectly.

I only wish they brought chopsticks with the food. Luckily I had some left over from previous delivery. I can't wait to order from then again.
author: Janell H.

description:
I'm generally perplexed by the heated responses to this restaurant on Yelp. I didn't find everything incredibly spicy, and nor was I overwhelmed by the rudeness of the staff. It's possible that those who found it unbearably spicy may have made the mistake of biting directly into the hot peppers in their meals, which I carefully avoided. Overall, I thought the food was pretty tasty and unique, if extremely salty and more oily than I typically care for.

I probably wouldn't wait in that line again, but it might worth going for take-out or at a less busy time in the future.
author: Michael B.

description: Really poor quality ingredients. I had the congee and everything in it taste really old. They also delivered to a hotel room with no utensils.
author: Yasmine M.

description:
While I am not a "Connoisseur" of Chinese food, my girlfriend (who is Chinese) and I decided to see what the hype is with this place.  We walked towards the location and was caught off guard by the restaurant's name on the awning, as it was different from the name on Yelp.  However since this was the only Chinese place around and also due to the long line, we came to the conclusion that this was the place.   

Initial Red Flags of this restaurant's authenticity:
- The menu outside was all in English with no Chinese characters
- The person who was seating people was not Chinese
- The price of the food was extremely expensive (over $10 on average per dish)
- The restaurant's name was re-branded "Mission Chinese Food"
- Majority of the people who gave this place 4 to 5 stars where not Asian, which skews the ratings. 
- Some of the cooks were not Chinese
- Most of the people eating were not Asian
- We asked the waiter if they had menu's in Chinese, who then looked startled by the request. 

However, we decided to not jump to conclusions and let the food have the final verdict.  

Food Results:
Pork Belly - Decently crispy but not stellar.  Dryer than usual. 
Green Beans - Not bad, reall spicy and a good portion.
Chicken Wings - A person with no arms could probably make better wings.  Really dry with a lot of peppers to seem as if you are getting a lot for the price you are paying, but really you're only getting 5 to 6 wings.  
Coca Cola - Tasted good, however I am unable to confirm its authenticity.  
Tap Water - SF tap, just how we like it. 

Conclusion
We determined that it would be unfair to compare this place to other Chinese restaurants, besides, it's in the Mission and they have to cater to the hipster crowd if they wanted to make money.  But my overall experience and with all the hype on Yelp, I will give this place 2 stars, to offset the overrated reviews by many.
author: Shad B.

description:
AMAZZZINGGGGG!!!!!!

I waited about an hour to eat here, and my friend and I were completely starving. It also didn't help that there was a hotdog stand right next to us where we were enticed by the smell of bacon-wrapped hotdogs. But I had to resist and believe that MCF was worth the torture....and it was! 

Smashed cucumbers in garlic sauce - A refreshing light appetizer! Because we were so hungry, we decided to have something to munch on before our real meal came. Subtle flavors and again, really refreshing. LIKE!

Ma Po Tofu - Hot flavor! I loved this tofu dish, but I've been obsessed with tofu recently. I just also loved the sauce. It was warming and so tasty. The chili oil and bean paste? UGH - DIED. 

Pork Belly - BEST DISH! I don't even like pork belly that much because I always feel like I'm going to die of high cholesterol, but I definitely didn't care after taking a bite of one of the four pieces they give you. 

Salt Cod Fried Rice - Perfect carby complement to our dishes. Perfectly cooked and well-seasoned. No complaints here! 

I know people say this isn't "authentic" Chinese food. As someone who isn't Chinese, I can't argue. But in my opinion, the food is just delicious. The flavors speak for itself. I understand that people walk into restaurants sometimes in hopes of tasting something of familiarity to them. Food, after all, isn't just connected to the human instinct of survival. It brings people back to comforting memories. But if you strip yourself of those expectations and just open yourself to what these dishes are (and not what you want them to be), I think you'll enjoy it far more.
