Or maybe people just will never see eye to eye on food. Whatever. MCF has bomb-ass food. I'll move to the Mission just to eat from this place all the time.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
3 stars for the food overall. 4 stars for the creative twists on classic Chinese dishes, most notably the lamb face noodles and the dried fried general tsos ribs, but -1 star for the unnecessary heat in some of the dishes, e.g the Kung Pow Brisket. 

The service left nothing to be desired. 3 stars for the service. Our main server was fine, but the check-ins were minimal as I was in need of extra napkins and water to combat the spicy food. And there was one gal there that gave me the stink eye for asking her to get me an extra tea cup. 

I wasn't a fan of the way our food was brought to the table either. Instead of bringing all of the dishes out at relatively the same time, they were brought out every 5-10 minutes which really broke up the flow of the meal. 

I'll probably check out MCF again as there are some other interesting dishes on their menu I want to try. I'll take it to go next time!
author: David D.

description:
Whoa, we got the Ma Po Tofu and it was way too spicy to be enjoyable for us, and we love spicy food. We took the leftovers back home, and it was better the next day.

The Kung Pao Pastrami dish was incredibly salty. My wife liked it, but I did not.

The dish I like the best here is the peas.
author: Jang K.

description: Delicious, really fresh food with excellent flavors. It is noisy and crowded, but that's part of the experience! Will definitely revisit this place.
author: Yael S.

description:
I eat a LOT of Chinese food. I like my food super super spicy, have traveled the edges of the world in search of good spicy food (and did I mention my Mom was born in Sichuan?)  yeah, so I have serious cred in the spicy, Chinese food area.

I give MCF serious props for attempting to innovate Chinese food. I had some serious reservations about the place, fearing a painfully hip, P.F. Chang's in the Mission. But to my surprise, they for the most part, kept the food true to its roots.  Yeah, so they don't have pastrami in China, but the kung pao pastrami, at it's core, was authentic and tasty.

The thrice cooked bacon was delish. Unlike cheap bacon, pork belly served in Chinese restaurants (which is stil tasty mind you), MCF uses good quality bacon that is smoked to such perfection that even the bacon fat was delicious.

The rice cakes in this thrice cooked bacon was truly the highlight of the evening. Those chewy rice cakes were the hit of the evening - perfect in their "q q" (Taiwanese for mouth feel, chewiness) with just the hint of sweetness.  We could have eaten this all night long.

The long beans were extremely tender ( again good quality ingredients), and was fairly good. Not a home run but very good.

Sweet peas was good, if not simple. But a good counter to the over-the-top spiciness of just about everything else.

So what was a fail?
The lamb noodle soup was unfortunately disgusting. Seriously, wAAAAAy too much cumin. I swear I was eating lamb chili with fat udon noodles.  yeah, it tastes about as disgusting as it sounds.  Could not get past the first bite.

Cold appetizers were disgusting as well - kimchi (ick), peanuts (swimming in salty soy sauce), cucumber salad (no flavor despite the hummus topping)....  avoid!  seriously, avoid.

The food is extremely spicy and salty, so make sure you have water readily available. Don't eat the hot peppers - you might have to use your iPhone to pick out the edible pieces (it's dark in the middle).

The nice thing about MCF is that if you doggie bag it, you have the foundation for some bad *ss leftovers the next day, just throw in some fresh veggies to mix with the MCF leftovers.

Though there were some misses with the food, I have to give them 4 stars because I love the concept, I want to encourage further innovation in Chinese food and the old school rap is awesome.
author: Madison W.

description:
I tried to give this 3 stars (I don't want to be a social pariah for not liking Mission Chinese) but I really didn't like the food very much so here we are.
Perhaps it's just not my personal taste but I don't get the hype on this place.

Rachel says avoid the wait and eat somewhere else.
author: Rachel R.

description:
MISSION CHINESE FOOD
Serves 30-60
Prep time (waiting outside) 1h.  20m more until you are eating food

Ingredients:
1 Cup traditional chinese cooking
3 Tb weird shit some cook came up with
1 typical hole in the wall chinese restaurant venue, replace CFL's with black lights and christmas lights, replace traditional music with fun pop and and alternative music

The results:
-Experimenting of flavors quite successful.  Kind of like a soccer shot that looks like it has no hope of making it but then just baaaaarely bends around the keeper and into the net!
-Lighting so dark I could not see what the fudge I was eating
-5 stars for fun atmosphere
-Minus 1 star because food was way too fatty/heavy.  Props for doing what they do in an intense way but much too rich on the fat side for my taste
author: Kurosh H.

description:
Did I not write a review the first time I came here? Shame on me. Anyway...

I guess this isn't very nice, but my first thought upon reading the first page of reviews here was, "Geez, what a bunch of whiners!" Wahh, it's not authentic enough and it's like totally obvious they were trying to be authentic because of the huge paper dragon. Um.. what? No. Did you even look at the menu? I'm no authority on the authenticity of Chinese food, and I'll be the first to admit it. But the way the menu was written screams hipster foodie cache.

Now, I'm not a hipster. Interestingly, neither were most of the people in the restaurant last night. We got lucky, showing up at 6:45ish and getting seated in five minutes. But I think it's hard to blame a restaurant for a wait. It's like, wahhh, the restaurant is too popular! Well, it's small. And although the waitress can take a bit of time to come around to take your order, the food itself is on your table in under ten minutes.

So let's talk about the food. I call BS on the reviewer who said she "loved her salt" but practically couldn't eat the stuff here. Just as unconvincing, I suppose, to you all who don't know me, I actually happen to be somewhat sensitive to salt. Last night only the long beans were a bit overly salty, but I still ate them and they were good. Spicy, but good. We also got the rib tips (good), rice porridge and fried rice (so good that we demolished both dishes between the two of us).

We came specifically for the rice porridge, actually, and it was everything I remembered. Highly recommended dining.
author: Amanda P.

description:
So you get a bunch of yuppy hipster kids flocking to a dive Chinese restaurant with "edgy" food, and I suppose after awhile, you start believing the food you're shoveling in your mouth actually tastes good. 

Throw in the fact the the chef is some long haired hipster who got to drink along side Anthony Bourdain on the 24 hour Layover, and you're like, "Damn this place is f'ing awesome."

So this place doesn't suck, but it's certainly hella far from what I'd call awesome. 

Ordered the Salted Cod Fried Rice, Thrice Cooked Bacon and the Ma Po Tofu - all which have been highly recommended by yelpers. 

The Salted Cod Fried Rice was missing my little fishy friends - the salted cod... which for a red blooded Chinese kid born and raised on the mean streets of SF is a total must. Why'd you hide my fishy friends, Danny B - were you afraid it might freak out the yupsters?

The x3 Cooked Bacon was aiight... but I didn't think the over-salted meat balanced well with the otherwise spicy dish. Plus it was supposed to be served with Bitter Melon... but I only found 3 tiny pieces. What the Hell, Danny B - where's my f'ing bitter melon... My buddy paid $11 for this S#*T.

Last, but not least, was the much anticipated Ma Po Tofu everyone talks about. It was drowned in chili oil and red pepper sauce with 1 Szechuan pepper... Danny B - aren't you Korean...what happened to the heat?

At the end of the day, it's like whatevs! I'm thankful I can afford overpriced Chinese food when so many other people in the world are starving. Plus, I finally made it out to try this totally overhyped restaurant with a bitchy waitstaff... and now I can move on...
author: Peanut S.

description:
Even on a Monday night, we had to wait 20 minutes to get into Mission Chinese.  Everyone and their mother have been talking about this place, and this hipster mecca even spawned another restaurant in the East Coast hipster mecca of Brooklyn.  The smell coming from inside the restaurant (as we waiting outside) was very enticing.  Visions came to mind of chilies frying in oil, with massive pots and pans sizzling with cumin flavored meats and noodles....my mouth was watering when we finally sat down.

Unfortunately, this place turns out to be MASSIVELY overrated.  We started with the beef brisket soup, which was packed with rice noodles, bits of fatty brisket, scallions, and a few other goodies.  The soup was really flavorful, and definitely not what you would normally expect from soup at a Chinese place.  It was more earthy, with kind of an umami aftertaste. It was a promising start to be sure.

That was followed up by the Mongolian cumin lamb, lamb rib tips, and peas.  The Mongolian cumin lamb had a lot of promise too.  The smell coming off the platter was onions and cumin.  It looked spicy and almost seductive the way the lamb was falling off the bone.  Surprisingly the meat itself was pretty bland, leaving only a slight aftertaste of cumin.  The cumin covered onions, however, provided a potent hit of flavor.

The rib tips were much the same.  Super tender boneless lamb (though a little fatty) covered in what promised to be an explosion of spices, and yet again very bland.  The smell was there, and it looked good, but alas, all it did was make me thirsty.  

The peas were the best part of the meal.  Nothing particularly special, but a healthy serving of fresh peas mixed with garlic and chiles.  

The service and prices are good.  We got a lot of food, and it was only about $40.  But I can't imagine circling for parking in the Mission, then waiting 20 - 45 minutes out on the sidewalk for Chinese food that is just so-so.  This place was like House of Nanking but with less flavor and better service.
author: Adam E.

description:
UPDATE 01/20/2014:

I am sorry to say I must take two stars off the original 5-star review. Here's why:
(a) They changed their mapo tofu recipe and now it contains only mushrooms and no meat. Not that I don't like mushrooms, but I think the new recipe is not as good as the old one.
(b) The last time I dined there, I found a RUBBER BAND in my fried rice. I am not kidding. I was very sad about it but was still hopeful it was a one-time incident...so...
(c) I ordered mapo tofu & congee from them a week later. The delivery came swiftly. However, this time I found a PIECE OF PLASTIC in the mapo tofu. 

This is inexcusable. The restaurant clearly has some sanitation issues to address :(
=======


Very strange Chinese food that is always worth at least one visit whether you are Chinese or not. This is not your typical Chinese food. Hell, I mean it's not even typical authentic (i.e. real food that real Chinese ppl eat) Chinese food!  Sure, the dishes are somewhat recognizable --- there's fried rice, noodles, ma po tofu, and porridge (I call it congee), but it's made *just so slightly differently* that it brings out an interesting sense of creativity and tasting experience. 

It doesn't matter whether you end up hating the food or not. It's still worth going there once.

Service: I have had better luck getting take outs and delivery. Delivery has always been on-time (exactly 40-45 min), if not faster. Strangely, service at the actual restaurant appears to be worse. The place is ill-decorated, ill-lit, with awful music, mediocre service, and unforgivingly long wait times, should you decide to dine in. But hey, come for the food, not for the mood.

Spiciness: yes, a lot of dishes here are more-than-your-average-wimpy-American spicy. Not "Man vs Food" level crazy hotness, but fierce enough that I won't be surprised to find a few unjust bad reviews based on that. There's no stars for you to tone down the spiciness level. Bottom line -- if you can't handle spiciness, order non-spicy food on the menu.

Dishes: here are my reviews for each dishes I've ordered

Ma Po Tofu --- GET IT! unless you can't eat pork, which would be a huge shame. it's a very thick, savory sauce filled with soft tofu and pork chunks.

Braised watercress --- interesting blend with pumpkin, peanut, and beans. I would count this as fulfilling enough as a standalone vegetarian entree. Healthy, too.

Baby Bok Choy in popcorn broth --- I saw a review complain the broth was too bland. Not true. The broth was LIGHT flavored. I don't think it's supposed to be a heavy dish. It's just some nice chicken broth with bok choy. Very healthy and a good companion dish to ma po tofu.

Mongolian Long Beans --- spicy spicy spicy! But goooooood. A giant mound of spicy long beans will serve well as a standalone entree, if you can handle the hotness, that is.

Kung Pao Pastrami --- sorry, but this was a meh to me. I simply did not like the overly smoky flavor of the meat, and did not really find the blend of red peppers and peanuts to be all that interesting.

West Lake Rice Porridge --- a very standard, homey congee dish, as a congee shoudl be.

Tea-smoked eel --- the name was better than the dish. Sorry, just more gimmicky than tasty to me.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I don't get it.  I really wanted to like this place and I kept eating hoping it would get better.  Maybe we caught the kitchen on a bad day but my wife and I agreed this was the worst meal either of us ever ate, so we won't be going back.  It took two days to get the taste out of my mouth and we left most of the food on the table.  Maybe we were hoping for too much.  We both love spicy and Asian inspired food so we couldn't wait to give this place a try, but the food was ridiculously fatty and over seasoned.  None of the plates we tried were even spicy.  Someone must be making a killing selling the meat out the back door because all the "meat" on our plates was basically fat trimmings.  I don't even know were to start so I'll just leave it at the plates we tried:

Kung Pao Pastrami: I thought this was odd but the most palatable dish.  However, I was turned off quickly after biting into a solid piece of pastrami flavored fat.  Overall, the pastrami was way too fatty and way too salty.

Sizzling Cumin Lamb: What wasn't fatty was overcooked and dry, but my wife thought this was the most palatable dish.  I couldn't get past the cumin.  There must have been an entire bottle encrusting the dish.  It wasn't too appealing to bite into solid chunks of cumin.

Braised Pork Belly:  I realize pork belly is really fatty, but there was almost no discernable meat on the three mushy salted chunks of pork belly served.  The dish basically tasted like clumps of over salted lard served in a bowl of salt water.  

Brisket Noodle Soup: We agreed this was the worst dish either of us ever had.  The brisket was too fatty and too salty, noodles were clumsy, and the broth was inedible and ruined anything it touched. My wife and I actually argued over whose side of the table the bowl had to stay on because neither of us wanted to have to smell it.
author: Greg L.

description:
This is another place where the wait is physically painful. I somehow always end up here when I'm already starving, and the two-hour wait is not particularly pleasant. 
I love the salt cod fried rice. Nothing else I've had here has even come close. 
The smoked beef brisket noodle soup was also tasty. The broth was flavorful and the noodles were chewy and delicious. 
The chicken wings are spicy in a really unique way. They started off sweet, and then the burn came. It was painful. Don't rub your eyes. 
The atmosphere is fun! The music is loud, the people are fun, the place has a good energy.
author: Cami J.

description:
Accidentally (but actually intentional) hipster Chinese food for the win.

Definitely a place to try for the SF foodie. Caution: if you're looking for kung-pao-chicken-esque Chinese food, this is NOT the place to go. Yes, the wait is long. Yes, you may wonder why there's a giant dragon hanging from the ceiling. Yes, the food is spicy. Yes, depending on the time of the month and server, staff can be a little negligent (but most are complete homies). All in all, however, I love Mission Chinese. 

Mapo Tofu - very, very spicy, but extremely nom-able (I get this every time)
Beef Brisket Noodle Soup - flavorful, noodles are rolled up in a strange, but hipster fashion
Cumin Lamb - Love!
Kung Pao Pastrami - NOT RECOMMENDED. Too spicy even for the spice lovers.

Most who frequent the place are casually-trendy, young people who love semi-authentic Chinese food. Flavors can be unusually strong and pungent, but don't let this stop you from trying. 

Word to the wise: try hard to avoid the bathroom - you must journey through the kitchen past the "chefs" chopping Chinese broccoli to reach your destination.
author: Sijia W.

description:
I recently ordered out so I can't comment on the type of service you get when you eat in, but the dishes I got were delicious and it was ready exactly when they said it would be. 

We got the chongqing wings which can be difficult for some people to enjoy if they are unaccustomed to the "numbing" feeling that szechuan food can have. I thought it was spicy, savory, pleasantly numbing and slightly sweet, which was a nice surprise. 

We also got the salt cod fried rice which was delicious. I do have to point out that there are no chunks of salt cod in the rice. Anyways, it tasted great and actually was much lighter than I expected. Most of the time friend rice tends to be a greasy heavy dish, so I was definitely surprised. 

The third thing we ordered was the cumin lamb, which was tender and really tasty. 

I can see why people coming here thinking they were going to get authentic Chinese food might be disappointed, but because I had prior knowledge of the place since there has been so much buzz about it, I knew that this place never really put itself out there as an "authentic" Chinese place, but as a place where Danny Bowien (don't know how to spell that...) wanted to serve delicious Chinese-esque food that he and other chefs would eat and make on their days off. The food is totally unpretentious and is just straight up tasty.
author: Yishian Y.

description:
The food was worth the hype but I was starting to doubt it during the 1-hour wait. Def get there early. They require you to sign your name on a clipboard and wait outside...which I would imagine could be uncomfortable during the colder times of year. Once inside it is cozy but a little noisy. The music selection was terrible but the food made it all better. 

We ordered the lamb dumplings (they were OK nothing too special), the thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes (unreal and I'm still thinking about it), salt cod fried rice (very good but I didn't see too much cod in it, sausage pieces were a nice touch) and the squid ink noodles cooked in lamb fat (one of the most memorable dishes I have EVER eaten). 

If I lived in SF I would make this my go-to delivery/takeout place for sure.
author: Meg H.

description:
I'd give this 3.5 stars, but I rounded up.

My family was looking for some Chinese food after dropping someone off the airport, so based on a few people's recommendations, we went to Mission Chinese.  We arrived at around 6:30-45 on a Saturday night and were very lucky since had no wait at all!  

So if you plan to go here, arrive before 7:00 or else there'll be a massive line and you'll have to wait outside.

The atmosphere was interesting.  It had the kind of tacky decor that usual Chinese restaurants have, but the whole place was dim and was only lit up by a giant dragon latern on the ceiling and some fairy lights on the side.  I like the quirky feel.  However, I did not see one Chinese employee at all; the whole staff is made up of young hipsters!  I guess that's what made the place "hip" or "trendy" as sad as that sounds.


Egg Noodles:
I really liked the noodles and the sauce was pretty good but it didn't really live up to the price for me.

Thrice-cooked Bacon and Shanghai Rice Cake:
My favorite dish of all.  I usually love tsao nian gao and was not disappointed by this version.  It's definitely spicy, but totally tolerable.  And I loved how they added tofu!

Kung Pao Pastrami:
I loved the chunks of pastrami and the crunchy celery.  This is my second favorite dish.  It could've used some more meat, but I enjoyed it nonetheless.  It's spicy, of course, but wasn't too bad for me.

Salt Cod Fried Rice:
I didn't see how different this fried rice from other fried rices, except maybe this has Chinese sausage.  I didn't even really notice the salt cod; it kind of just blended in with the rice.  And when I was eating this and chomped on some stray piece of bone or something hard.  I could've broken a tooth!

Westlake Rice Porridge:
I was pretty impressed with the porridge.  It had minced beef and fish in it, which is a modern version of congee.  I wouldn't get it again, but it's not bad.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
Holy flaming amazing sauce!  This place is the real deal -- I think that other people may be rating the "look" of the place and that's just not what this restaurant is about.  It's about the FOOD.  Food is even in the name of the restaurant.  

If you like SPICY, you are in luck.  They really mean it when they put the double pepper next to the item.  Don't play play.  Extremely hot and extremely delicious.  We usually get the Mongolian Green Beans (wow!) and the Pork Ribs (wowza!) but everything is unique and good.  The Cod Fried Rice is actually pretty delicate compared to the rest of the dishes.  And the cucumbers in garlic / tahini dressing is a great palate cleanser / cooler if things get too hot.  

While I may be a white farang, I've traveled extensively in Asia / South East Asia and this place stands out when it comes to flavor of Chinese food here in the US of A.  Chin-chin!  

Oh yeah, and if you're not big on Chinese food then I suggest not dining in a restaurant that has the word Chinese in it.
author: Anthony V.

description:
Wanted to like this place more, but found it to be pricy Chinese fusion from the 4-5 times I've taken out from here. With as much praise as the cod fried rice gets I found it to be too much rice and too little cod/other goodies. 

However, I do love their Westlake Rice Porridge (especially for those hangover days). Plus they deliver too!
author: C W.

description:
FOOD HIGHLIGHTS: 
Salt Cod Fried Rice - Fried rice is always my favorite at Chinese restaurants and this one is no different. The best part is the chicken sausage disks that are like mini pepperonis on a pizza. 

Grandma's Lamb Dumplings - Bite size dumplings in a wonderfully seasoned broth and then crunchy peanuts. 

Mongolian long beans - Spicy!

EHHH:
Cumin Lamb Ribs - Too smoky for me, but Dan liked them. Had more of an Indian flavor than Chinese. 

Egg Egg Noodle - Needed more ginger and spices - too plain for this place!
author: Brittany B.

description:
On my last trip to SF, I was drawn in by the hype and the glowing reviews on Serious Eats and from my friends for Mission Chinese and made it one of my must sees while I was in town. I was treated to a unique concept, delicious dishes and I wasn't disappointed at all.

We got lucky and got a decent parking spot within short walking distance of the Lung Shan Restaurant right on Mission St and walked down the stairs around lunch time to a sparsely filled dining room with everyone there ordering off the Mission Chinese menu.

We ordered the hot pepper wings, triple cooked bacon (two of the well known dishes) and a basic noodle dish (don't remember which one or if it is still on the menu). The wings really opened my eyes to Szechuan pepper as a major seasoning and were spicy, mouth numbing, salty and very enjoyable. The bacon dish featured bitter melon and rice cakes and when eaten together made for a unique taste experience. Definitely one of those situations when the sum of the parts was greater than each one individually.

Mission Chinese may be over hyped but it lived up to it and made a big impact on what I knew about Chinese food.
author: Chris L.

description:
Entering mission Chinese, one can immediately notice the vibrant atmosphere and the young and hip vibe. Although the wait can take a very long time, Mission Chinese has a fun vibe that makes both locals and suburban denizens looking for a hip restaurant crawl to  Mission Chinese. 

The servers are all very nice, and the food definitely comes quick. It is incredibly crowded at all times, however, the ambiance is festive and colorful enough to make up for the lack of space. 

Now why did I rate this place three stars? Simply, the food was not as good as it has been hyped ( in my opinion.) It was too expensive for the lack of quality. 

The ONE dish I can definitely recommend is the delicious Salt Cod Fried Rice. Order it, and eat it just by yourself. However, everything else is just a little off in my opinion.

The pickles are almost too sour, and have a very bitter taste.

The Ma-Po Tofu had no balance to it whatsoever; the peppers completely overwhelmed the dish and left a very strange sensation to the mouth. You couldn't even appreciate the flavors because of the intensity of the peppers. Not too spicy, just completely wrong proportions. 

The cumin- lamb was flat-out disgusting; full of fat with a dump-load of cumin, this is absolutely no enjoyment for the taste buds. There is no elegance to this dish, and it seems like it has no thought to it. 

The dumpling dish was passable; the dumpling itself is good, however, the sauce that the dumplings were served on was sour and not appetizing.

The egg noodles were tasteless and had a very strange texture.

I highly recommend the Ginger Beer, however, Quite delicious!

All in all, I was very disappointed by the food. The lack of thought or foresight in the seasoning was unfortunate. The lamb dish is an abomination, and needs to definitely be rethought.

HOWEVER, the service is fantastic and the nice servers definitely deserve a good tip. The food needs work.

3/5.
author: Dhruv D.

description:
This is the first meal I had when I moved to SF. Super yums -- the food is definitely on the heavy side, but good. Everything has A LOT of flavor. 

The dishes are all pretty unique as far as Americanized chinese food goes and that was kind of half the experience... ordering 'sizzling cumin lamb' and 'baby bok choy in popcorn broth' is waaaayyy more fun than 'general t'sos with fried rice'. 

We brought lots of wine. I would suggest doing that also and drinking it on the sidwalk while you're waiting to be seated.
author: Helen S.

description:
Super big crowd gathering in the mission!  Was there a shooting?  Was there a Bourdain sighting? No its Mission St. Foods!

This is the restaurant Chef's eat at!  Of course if you hear that, you want to be immediately weary.  Chef's consume two things: cigarettes and liquor.  But  I thought this place lived up to the crazy expectations Yelper's usually arrive with.

I love the broken down Lung Shan Restaurant space that Mission Chinese occupies.  Twice during dinner the electricity went out, and all of us were left to eat under the ominous glowing red light of the dragon lantern that is strung along the ceiling.  

Here's what we ordered:

Thrice cooked bacon with rice cakes. -- This dish was my favorite. Spicy rice cakes give it a Korean taste, the bacon was more like thinly sliced pork belly, rounded off with hints of bitter melon.

Uni egg custard.  -- Another very interesting dish.  The acidity gave it an almost  ceviche quality.  And who doesn't love a generous topping of uni. Al Qaeda, that's who.

Mouth watering chicken with hearts. --  Not too mouthwatering imo.  It had a definite Southeast Asian flavor, served ice cold.  You can skip this one.

Turnips with pork jowel. -- I think this was my gf's favorite.  The pork jowels were cooked perfectly tender, and we loved the turnips that were cooked sliced, but with their hats left on.

Do yourself a favor and don't come on a Thurs/Fri/Sat night with a group larger then 2.
author: Lam N.

description:
This is going to be a blasphemous review for MCF against my Chinese heritage. But I must preface this review by the fact that when you Google this resto the description under the link reads "Mission Chinese Food serves Americanized Oriental Food and is located at Lung Shan Restaurant in the Mission." Yep Oriental! The only things Oriental are rugs and instant ramen, and if you call Jeremy Lin Oriental you'll likely get fired from your job. Long story short, direct your expectations away from "Chinese Food." If you must, think "Americanized Oriental Food." 

Me and an eater buddy of mine had decided on a few dishes, but we wanted to GO BIG. The menu is a bit daunting because you can't get a real feel of the eclectic and eccentric dishes like Kung Pao Pastrami. We were fortunate to have a very helpful, nice server by the name of Ellie C. that helped us dissect the menu and offered her "must try" dishes. I then realized the service at MCF, while at times frantic and rushed, is very friendly, helpful, and efficient. 

Our targets:
- Salt Cod Fried Rice
- Char Siu Pork Belly
- Taiwanese Clams

Our server Ellie suggested:
- Szechuan Pickles
- Chicken Wings w/ Explosive Chili Pepper
- Kung Pao Pastrami

Everything was a winner. The pickles our server suggested cut the spiciness of the chicken wings well and provided our only "veggies." The wings were crispy, damn hot, left your tongue with a slight tingle on the back end, but was a great way to start the meal. As I've said before, best damn Salt Cod Fried Rice ever, period. Pork Belly was fatty and tender encased in a crispy, lightly fried exterior. Clams were just plain good. The Kung Pao Pastrami, a strong suggestion by Ellie, was good, but weird, and weirdly good! The smokey pastrami had great flavor on its own, but when stir-fried in with the usual kung pao components yielded a very eclectic dish. 

We devoured everything, but did leave half a plate of Pastrami due to lack of room.  I think we did well with the 6 dishes between 2 stomachs. Add 3 beers and our grand total was $58. Not bad at all for Americanized Oriental Cuisine.

TIP (re: Wait Time): Sign up, go for a drink, and come back. One page of names is about 45-60 minutes. If you leave and they've called you, they'll put you back as returned.
author: Al L.

description: We heard from more than one person that we absolutely had to try this place on our San Francisco visit.  And I am SO glad we listened.  Unassuming from the outside and totally fun/funky/kitschy on the inside, Mission Chinese served up by far the most inventive and delicious Chinese food I've ever had.  Love that the menu is all family style- highlight was the thrice cooked bacon- SO good and really no way to explain it- do you like pork? just order it, the Tiger Salad is really more like a gigantic spring roll and was an unexpected wow, the cumin lamb (a spicy, minty take on Larb) was delicious, sesame chicken, like regular sesame chicken but just BETTER (how? I don't know! Only Mission Chinese knows!) ... I would really like to try everything on the menu.  Only thing that was a miss for me was the beef tartare, just too much of a fishy flavor to it likely due to it being topped with a heaping helping of roe- if you dig roe you'll love it.  Worth the wait for sure.
author: Bessie C.

description: I have three things to say about Mission Chinese Food.... Awesome Food, Awesome Service and Awesome Music!
author: Dustin G.

description:
Mission Chinese is a great restaurant if you go with the right expectations. This is not traditional Chinese food. It's very oily, salty and spicy, and not particularly refined. The interior is divey and almost tacky. And waits are inevitable (unless you get there within the first 15-20 minutes of opening).

The dishes were hit or miss - I was able to appreciate some, while I just craved the traditional Chinese version of others. The Mongolian Long Beans dish was the surprise winner. While ordered almost as an afterthought, it was extremely flavorful without just being salty/oily. The Thrice-cooked Bacon was also great, though I would've preferred the vegetarian option - the tofu skin was delicious and soaked up a lot of flavor, while the bacon was just too fatty for my taste. I would pass on the Chongqing Chicken Wings. I wasn't a huge fan of the spice rub and would've preferred the traditional version.

Mission Chinese is unique(ish) and worth a visit, but not sure I'd call this an improvement on traditional Sichuanese food.
author: Linda Z.

description:
So I was visiting San Fran (which I do often), and a friend wanted to take me here for lunch. This restaurant was a 'pop up' that just kind of stuck because of popularity. It is apparently a word-of-mouth gem. It has no signage, it's a run-down hole in the wall, and it's ridiculously popular with the locals. The idea here is clearly to infuse some novel, inventive flavors into Chinese food. Things like "baby bok choy in popcorn broth" and "salted cod fried rice" are on the menu. 

I was less than impressed. We started with the pork belly and the peanuts--not bad on either front. Nothing to write home about, but not worthy of purging either. 

We got the beef a la'orange and the thrice cooked bacon as entrees. They too were just OK in my opinion. The bacon dish was insanely spicy and, based on the other reviews I've read, so are most of their dishes. If you're into spice--I would definitely recommend giving this place a try. You'd likely have a better experience than I. 

Overall, the service was decent and the menu was so novel it was worth a try. I don't think I'd go back. But I also think you should try it. Odd, I know.
author: Bradley B.

description: Dark room and 90's hip hop playing. I wanted to like this place but i couldn't see my food and it was packed to the max. The food portions were super small, and the waiters are all to happy to let you know that what you ordered wont be enough to satisfy your hunger. I left still hungry after running up a tab close to 100 dollars, not worth the price or the hype. Better to head to San Tung in the sunset or even R&G lounge in Chinatown.
author: Phillip J F.

description:
This is essentially a hole-in-the-wall Chinese place, but with rock music blaring so loud you can't hear yourself and lights turned down so low you can barely see your food. Yes, there are some twists on traditional Sichuan cuisine, but not enough that I would say the wheel was completely reinvented. Still ... I give major kudos to the owners for doing something different with Chinese food that isn't the typical fusion.

My favorite dishes were the salt cod fried rice and the porridge. The porridge in particular was really flavorful. I kind of wish I wasn't eating family-style with five other people so I could have both of these dishes to myself.

I was not a fan of the explosive chicken wings, or whatever they're called. The chefs essentially ground Sichuan peppercorns - you know, those kernels you pick out of your food and curse if you accidentally eat one, because it makes your whole mouth numb - and dredged the chicken wings in it! There was no escaping those peppercorns. I couldn't handle it, and I'm half-Sichuanese!

I'm also not a fan of their mapo tofu. The pork shoulder they opted for instead of ground pork was not a good substitution, I thought. There's more flavor with ground meat - the sauce gets in there better.

I didn't try the lamb or veal dishes - the former because I don't like it, and the latter because I'm morally opposed. But my fellow diners raved about both.

If I lived in San Francisco I probably wouldn't come back - it's not worth the wait more than once, but I'm glad I tried it!
author: Betsy T.

description: Okay food, a little creative. Small portions for the price, long waits, and average service. Plenty of better options for either Chinese or fusion.
author: adam b.

description:
I finally went here the other day with my boyfriend after countless times of passing the place (and the huge crowd outside) by. We were both impressed. There were about 12 parties ahead of us, so we put our name on the list and went and got a beer across the street. It was about a 30 minute wait, which actually wasn't horrible considering it was a Saturday at about 7:30.

Nearly every hot dish on the menu is spicy, but that was fine with us. We got the ma po tofu and salt cod fried rice. Both were great! Extremely flavorful and reasonably priced at about $10-11 a dish. 

I liked the ambiance. It definitely has a hipster vibe; dark with string lights, a huge dragon on the ceiling, and  Radiohead and Joy Division playing in the background. They pack as many people in there as they can, but it feels intimate rather than uncomfortable. Service was very friendly. 

Excited to go back and try their other dishes.
author: Alana G.

description: Great vibe, always fun inside, decent beer selection, and order the pastrami Kung pao - so much food, I was eating it for 3 days afterwards.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
EXPERIENCE IS FUN AND UNIQUE
A great idea for a restaurant.  
Take a cheep chinese restaurant, keep some of the grunginess and highlight it with a bit of hipster freestyling creativity (strange combinations, more spice than is balanced, super fatty meats) and you get a unique,  amusing and yummy novelty. 
Everything on the menu is heavy, oily and over spiced - which can really hit the spot sometimes....  

FOOD IS GOOD
Don't worry too much if some menu items sound too adventurous (tongue, heart,  tripe, lamb face, soy milk poached tofu),  i found that the flavors to be within my narrowish window of being grossed out .
 
SERVICE IS LAME BUT TOLERABLE
Most servers lack manners but that can easily be ignored - just chalk it up to being part of the experience, besides every-once in awhile its fun to have a reason to leave a minimal  tip . And if if your lucky, you may get somebody cheerful who you can over tip.
author: Puffy P.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had. Yes, I know its fusion, but still, its amazing.
author: Ernie S.

description:
Four stars for the savory egg custard.  If you like sea urchin, you'll definitely like this dish.  

My cousin always orders the thrice cooked bacon and salt cod fried rice.  I like the tofu skin in the bacon dish.  It's sweet and tangy.

Don't forget, if you don't want to brave the crowds, delivery is fast, friendly and convenient.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I went here for a quick bite and it left a lot to be desired. 

Had the chow mein with hangar steak: too much garnish, overly spicy but points for the visual presentation. 

The biggest trouble I had was with the service. No one greeted me for the first few minutes. A server said hello and he had me seated directly behind the host counter/barrier (without asking where I would prefer to sit). I found it to be very offensive. I asked to be seated as far away from the door as possible and he yielded - a table where I have a view of the front and the kitchen. He then served my lunch in a very tardy manner but what concerned me the most is his lack of hygiene: he had dropped receipts on the floor where there was heavy foot traffic, put them in the counter and then proceeded to handle food after. It was my lunch that he had soon served. 

Waiting for the check was longer than eating the meal and nothing memorable came out of it... until this review. 

The hype is a hype and again it leaves a lot to be desired from first impressions. They can do better.
author: Dean I.

description:
Please don't expect authentic Chinese food. I've been here twice, and on both occasions, made clear to my dinner guest that we would be going to a fake-Chinese food restaurant.  Once expectations were clear, the meal could be enjoyed properly.

Yes the servers are not Asian. Yes the decoration and ambiance is a mix of grungy Mission with obnoxiously tacky Chinese stereotypes.  But the food is quite good!

The thrice cooked bacon and cumin lamb are outstanding; the westlake rice porridge is very good; the fried rice is overrated (taste just like normal fried rice...maybe a little less oily); the lamb face noodle soup is weird.

I do wish the place could be a little cleaner, a little less crammed, and I don't think the fake-Chinese + dark ambiance combination works.  But the again, great, innovative food that I would come back for.  And for what it's worth, I've come here for a late Sunday dinner (around 8ish?) and also a 6:15 Saturday dinner and didn't wait any longer than 15 minutes on either occasion.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Once again I decided to follow the lead of my fellow people on yelp and try out a different place every day in the mission district. 

Today I was finally able to find the highly reviewed mission Chinese food restaurant ( not the name on the sign outside) the place is old inside with dark decor and a bathroom walkway that runs next to/inside the kitchen. I was not seated right away and had to wait 5 mins to approach someone(not busy at all when I went). The table was freshly wiped off and the smell of the dirty rag carried onto the table.   

I was approached by the server and was given a menu. Few minutes later I asked about anything that was offered from off the menu which he replied no. I asked for his recommendation on a small portion and entree. He recommended the lamb dish and peanuts. I guess my taste buds are not "hipster" because the food was "different". Not that it's a bad thing but when I see Chinese food I expect traditional American Chinese food. This place requires a certain taste bud that I just don't have. 

Going to this place expect a unique menu with one off food. For a whole I felt like The guy from bizarre foods. 

Service -2
Decor-1
Cleanliness- 1
Price -1 (25 dollars and I had no drink).
author: BayAreaFoodGuy Y.

description:
Foods is fantastic. Not effing around with the spicy-hooray!!!
Numbing lamb is totally flavorful. Resist eating the noodles for a few-let them lap up the numbing broth. I have had numbing spicy things before and this could have been a bit more spicy. 

Pickles are perfect. The peanuts are such a surprising element that I was completely disarmed by the dish-in a good way. I know peanuts are often included in Chinese dishes but I never got "it" till this dish.

The drawback is the service(thusly 3 star). I had paid the bill but had leftovers to pack up & half glass of wine. I got a nice rag thrown on my two top. AND the new plates for the next guests. Boooo! Just relax. Its lunch.

They are on vacation now but go. Ignore the people who complain its too odd/spicy. Its just right. Expect meh service and laugh because its kind of funny. Foods damn fine.

Menu
http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/restaurants/mission-chinese-food/menu
author: Michelle M.

description:
I just ate here for the first time tonight, and I have to say that after months and months of hype, it certainly lived up to expectations. Although not in the way I expected.

The flavors were BOLD. There's nothing delicate about the tastes here. Everything is big, and powerful, and in your face. It's like all the characteristic notes on traditional Chinese food got plugged into a stack of Marshall amps and played a power chord with their hair on fire. The chicken wings are probably the best example, but even the spicy cucumber appetizer is out for blood. 

The drinks selection is excellent, and inexpensive ($3 for canned 21A), which is good because beer isn't an add-on but a necessity if you're one of those people who likes a breather amidst your bouts with culinary intensity. 

Add to that the "churn & burn" dining tempo that gets you in and out as quickly as any hole-in-the-wall spot, blaring music from the 80's and 90's, and a big paper dragon looking down hungrily at you from the ceiling, and you get something that is as much a satire of the Chinese food world as a radical evolution of it.

I give it 4 stars out of 5 because it wasn't necessarily an experience that was entirely pleasant. It's like an amusement park ride. Really fun every now and then, but not something I'd do every week, or every day. But it's certainly An Experience (TM), and a massively unique and original one, at that. The architects behind Mission Chinese are to be commended.

Finally, If you have a friend coming in from out of town, I recommend you bring them here for some "traditional SF Chinese food." Be sure not to tell them anything, and have a good story about why there's no chow mein on the menu. Executed well, this reviewer feels it's the only way to introduce a visitor to SF properly.
author: Will S.

description:
This place has every possible stereotype of what the Mission used to be, say 12-18 months ago- hipster, filthy, super trendy, a bit over priced and definitely overrated. Now, from the looks of things, the Mission is becoming the next Marina, with the city's best restaurants and wine bars. I never thought I would see it happen, but it has! 

The food we ordered resembled Chinese food with a half quart too much of motor oil poured over everything. You got the feeling you were eating some very unhealthy like the food you would find at a Hometown Buffett in the South. Very greasy and fatty, and showed a resemblance of Chinese Food. It got better once you drain all the fatty stuff off...
author: Jim B.

description: I would literally give this place a zero if I could. Horrible wait, then the worst service possible. Took me 10 minutes to waving my arms to get utensils after our food came, and the waiter gave me attitude like I dare ask for an eating implement while my food got cold, which wasn't an issue because my two follow up dishes came cold. Then I had to ask for my wine. I need to drink more wine to stomach this meal. Never again.
author: Cece C.

description:
My thought leaving this place was: Meh, not really my thing.  I had been wanting to try this place for a while but with so many complaints about the wait time I never really wanted to wait that long.  We showed up early enough so that our wait time was only about 5 minutes (for a "table of 2", air quotes are appropriate since we just sat at a long table with a bunch of other people).

The menu was much too exotic for me.  Frankly, I just don't like or want to eat pig jowls or some of the other strange kinds of meat.  We ordered the chicken fat friend rice (which tasted a bit salty to me), the pork belly (which was ok but a bit burnt), and the goat (which was also a bit burnt).

The food was just ok, not amazing in any respect.  I should disclose that as soon as I entered I was already not feeling the place - it was filled with non chinese folks which to me already said it probably wouldn't be all that good chinese food.

Also, the lights/music kept going out the entire dinner :(
author: Banana S.

description:
If you are looking for a laidback/hipster/cool place to get your sechuan fix (spicy chinese for you round eyes out there), this is the place. 

Sure all the foods designated as spicy do deliver the kick that we sometimes so desperately yearn for, but unfortunately, at the price point, the quality of dishes may not qualify this restaurant for a revisit.

Let's be honest, the reason we are are here is for the food. I don't need the blaring music , the low lighting and chinese lanterns. Even though I ate here pretty recently, nothing was very memorable. I find it difficult to pinpoint any dish where i thought was awesome. I think my favorite thing here was the mapo tofu. A lot of the meat dishes were a little on the dry side. I just assume this is one of those cases where food quality goes downhill after a place get's a little too popular. 

But hey, Mission Chinese does give an interesting dining experience. Not worth going out of your way for, but if you are in the area... sure, check it out.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Awesome food. Real burst of flavors in every dish. Unique ingredients and none of the post-Chinese-food sickness :) . We tried the Cumin Lamb which was my favorite, the vegan version of thrice cooked bacon which was great. The chicken wings were some of the best Chinese chicken wings I've had. The fried rice was just OK. I didn't find a single piece of cod in the salt cod fried rice. 

What sucked was we and all the 'normal' diners were waiting for over an hour when there were a lot of chef's friends, chef's roommates and chef's friend's roommates cutting the waiting list and getting a table ahead of us pretty much as and when they arrived. I guess a few chef's privileges are really not a bad thing at a great restaurant. But too many of these when the wait is over an hour is a real dick move. I'd totally still order delivery from here, but i don't think I'll dine in again.
author: Karthick S.

description:
I'd like to give 3.5 stars, but with the option of 3 or 4, I just can't give it 3 stars, so four it is.

Know what you're getting yourself into before you go here! It's hipster-Sichuan fusion. Sichuan food is SPICY. your dishes will be served with lots of red chili peppers. That's chinese. It's hipster because there are some pretty...unique...combinations on this menu which I don't think are quite Chinese.

You will wait for a table. That's just how it is.

Family style is a must here.

Start with the pickles!
Brisket soup, short rib tips were the standout dishes this time around. The short rib tips just fell apart in our mouths. just amazing.

I can see how this is an acquired taste, but if you're looking for something pretty darn original (and tasty, and fairly priced), you should really think about stopping here.

All in all, Mission Chinese is a really good restaurant, but I feel like it's maybe a bit overhyped? I could only come here 2-3 times a year. But maybe I'm just not hipster enough.

C'mon yelp let us do half stars :)
author: Conrad B.

description:
My dining experience at Mission Chinese food left me puzzled. There's been so much hype and so many people are convinced that this place is something really special. I can't help but wonder what I missed. 

I went there with a party of six on a Sunday evening, and fortunately we didn't have much of a wait, or I would have been even grumpier about my experience. We ordered a number of dishes, including some peanuts and pickles to start, coriander lamb, chow mein, chicken fried rice, chicken wings, salt cod fried rice, long beans, and mapo tofu. Most of those dishes felt like a big, salty, spicy slap in the face. The place is so dim that you can't really see what you're eating, and you also can't really hear anything due to the loud Pandora blaring from someone's laptop and the huge crowd, so it was really hard to tell what I was putting in my mouth (well, I'm pretty sure that what I was putting in my mouth was a lot of salt and spice with some fatty bits mixed in). The chow mein was probably the best of the dishes, but it basically tasted like any noodle dish at any decent Chinese place. 

I keep trying to figure out if I was, in fact, at the same place that everyone's been raving about. I wondered if I ordered the wrong things - but we ordered a pretty large percentage of the menu, so I think we got a good representation of what Mission Chinese has to offer. Well, at least now I know that it's not worth my time to go and wait there next time.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Terrible, terrible "Chinese" food. It's the type of food your non-chef friend cooks for you after too many drinks at home with leftovers and an over-abundance of hot sauce. The food here had no taste.- and hot sauce should NOT be the main flavor. I can't believe people can say the food here is even anything close to good. Have they never had chinese food before? Especially with ALL the really good Chinese restaurants all over SF... I think this is the worst chinese restaurant in the bay area. 
Tiger salad?? Can't believe I paid money for this.. Just leaves with a sheet of rice paper wrapped over it. Nothing else. And the dressing? Hot sauce...
Mabo tofu- mediocre. Kungpao pastrami-- overdid my salt intake for the entire week. 
I don't understand how this place ever made a name for itself..
Hipster nonsense...

If you would like better chinese food, please try anywhere else in sf.
author: Grace L.

description:
Entranced. Before even looking at the menu.
Blame it on the music or the blur of dragons flying overhead in the dimly lit space. Either way, you had me.

The music alone warrants all five stars, but I'm sure plenty of you think it's too loud or droppin' too many beats for your dinner. I want a date with whoever mixed the soundtrack.

The food? I'm not even sure I was hungry when I arrived (or was I?), but the entire menu called to me. Soup, salad, stir-fry, meaty tofu dish (yea, that), Icelandic White Ale (that, too). Spicy and in-your-face; I'm not even hungry and I want it all.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Ahh Mission Chinese.  It's definitely a place that everyone's heard of in SF, and want to try at some point.  I believe I gave this place a fair shake, but think it is only A-OK.  Not a bad experience, but just... over-hyped.  

I came here with a friend and tried the Mapo Tofu, Slow Cooked Pork Belly, and Cod Fried Rice.  While I applaud Mission Chinese for its innovative approach and interpretation of Chinese food, I think it's not anything to wait in line for an hour to have.  The food here is definitely better than your average hole in the wall Chinese restaurant, with good variety of food and beer/wines.  The service I found was better than expected, since there were so many reviews that talked about the bad service.  Mapo Tofu had a good solid kick to it so only get it if you enjoy spicy foods.  

Overall, if you're asking yourself if you should try it, I'd say go for it.  The mix of electronica and hip hop they play, the atmosphere, and the off-the-beaten-path approach to Chinese food here is worth seeing.  I don't think I'd be back here anytime soon though.
author: Leo C.

description:
When I was a kid in NYC, Taco Bell was the stuff. My friends and I knew that it wasn't technically Mexican food, but it was tasty and we loved going there all the time. However, when I got older, I made friends with actual Mexicans, traveled to South American a few times, and now live in California... I no longer frequent Taco Bell (sure it is still tasty in a nostalgic, processed comfort food type of way... like Kraft Macaroni and Cheese).

I love fusion food, I love Zantes Indian pizza, I love HRD Coffee Shop's Kimchi burritos/Mongolian cheesesteaks, I like chocolate with chili peppers and bacon, etc... but fusion doesn't automatically mean "awesome", it means someone is experimenting with new flavor combinations. Some flavor combinations are awesome and become new "authentic classics" and some are forgotten.

Unfortunately, overall Mission Chinese Food falls a bit on the wrong side of "awesome." Some of the dishes were tasty in a raw sort of way, but chefs are a little too enthusiastic with their spice rack. We went there for lunch on Sunday (no line! yay!) We had the following dishes (in order of best to worse).

Salt Cod Fried Rice - this was pretty tasty. A good blend of chinese sausage and scallion. I didn't notice the mackerel confit, but overall it was good.

Stir Fried Sweet Pea - decent, but forgettable.

Sizzling Cumin Lamb - the lamb was tasty, rich and fatty. A bit salty though (as was *everything* on the menu). Also surprisingly light on the cumin flavoring (which was surprising, given the BOLD, INTENSE flavoring the rest of the menu seems to scream). Most people in the group like it.

Kung Pao Pastrami - I like pastrami and it was tasty, again a little salty. Most of the group thought it was too weird (I didn't find the sweetness of the pastrami that distracting though). However... it wasn't good enough for me to want to order it again.

Szechaun pickles - ok, these were terribly one-dimensional, they basically blindly dumped vinegar, salt and sichuan peppercorns over cabbage.

Overall... everything was overly salted (even one of my friends who likes to salt her ketchup said this was too salty and had to eat a lot of rice), and the flavor/ingredients weren't balanced well. Also surprisingly the heat level was very tame (despite all the red chili peppers they add... they've intentional made it very mild for our American palates... just like Panda Express). I would consider going there again to try some other dishes (someone like the Westlake Rice Porridge)... but I would never recommend a friend to go there.

For the best Sichuan food I've had outside of Sichuan province (that is including spending a summer in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Beijing). Try Sichuan Fortune House in Pleasant Hill (near Walnut Creek).
author: AT C.

description: Just ordered 60 dollars of fried rice, ribs and vegetables for take out. They charged the same price as sit-in, but provide WAY smaller quantity for take out orders. Unbelievable. So I called them and this Cantonese lady picked up and after couples minutes of confronting her she finally admitted them their take-out portion is smaller because "they can't fit it inside the box" (It was a tiny box). Ok then don't charge us the same price if ur gonna give us half the portion! Unbelievable. Never coming back here.
author: Ann C.

description:
I am late to this party but I'm totally on board now.

I've known about MCF for a while now but never went because I'd always heard the wait was awful. Showed up on a whim with a friend on a Thursday, around 630ish, and got seated right away!

Vinegar peanuts and smashed cucumber apps were tasty. I want the peanuts as a bar snack wherever I go.

Salt cod fried rice is f***ing amazing. I couldn't get enough of that stuff.

Cumin lamb is also good. Really rich though, because it's all cut from the belly.

Friendly service, and reasonable prices. I'm totally a convert. MCF for life!
author: Sam K.

description:
Vicky L. and I came here on our most recent lunch adventure. 

We put our name on the sheet outside the door and only had to wait a few minutes while they cleared our table off. 

There is no way I would loiter outside this location in the dark. It's sketchy even in the daylight. 

Plus, the food isn't worth any sort of wait. 

+Hot & sour cucumbers. This was the best dish I tried but I love cucumbers.

-Thrice cooked bacon. Judging from Vicky's plate this item should be named 'thrice cooked onions'

-Broccoli beef cheek. This was my main and what I got was 2 big pieces of beef cheek and a bunch of broccoli stems. I had to go on a safari to find the beef since it was hiding under the broccoli and once I found it, half of it was fat anyway. The broccoli desperately needed seasoning too. 

Some of the other menu items sound intriguing so I may come back for those, or better yet, have it delivered!
author: Sara P.

description:
Three words: Salty, MSG, trendy.

Not sure what all the fuss is about this place.  Tried it after hearing great things but was highly disappointed.  It's not Chinese food at all.

The vibe and customers inside are very trendy.  Trendy hipsters.  You can have a beer with your meal and apparently they stay open late (great for party goers).  Prices weren't too bad and the wait staff here is friendly.  They play rock music in the background which keeps this place crackin' and pretty loud because no one can hear what the person across the table's saying.

It's extremely dark inside (on purpose!) and we couldn't really see what we were eating...The cool part is Lung Shan utilizes a black light so you can read the menu, but overall I'm very skeptical of what I actually ate.  

They have a lot of spicy dishes, but the bulk of the dishes are hot peppers...you're paying for hot peppers.

Food was soooooooooo salty - like unbelievably salty and so much MSG that my stomach was in pain that night. As a group of seven Asians, we were the minority (actually the only ones in here) in a Chinese restaurant.  That should've been the first signal because if Asians don't eat it, what does that say about the food?!

Wish I could say this place was terrific, but truth is they're not.  They've got the hipsters addicted and more power to them, but this just ain't my style.
author: Dee H.

description: Great food and concept, but sometimes a little too asian fusion-y for me.  usually this means too much ginger or five spices.  We usually get it for take out since the lines are too long and there's some great dishes.  I would not recommend going at the very end of the night since the food was a little dried out the one time we did that.
author: Aaron W.

description: Not sure why a food critic put this resto in his bucket list. The place is so cramped ( calling SF fire marshal and warning to claustrophobics) loud and appetite killer . After we were seated , the guy immediately told us that we only have 1 hour and 15 minutes to finish dinner---seriously ?!!!?We haven't even placed our orders yet. None of the dishes we ordered were real stand out . Their famous ma po tofu was just okay and in fact had tried a much better version in  other chinese restaurants. All the dishes we ordered were really SALTY especially the pig jowl dish and the sour chili chicken. The tiki pork belly appetizer was not worth $13. Am I coming back ? Nahhh...I rather explore some other chinese restos in Clement /Geary  or at Chinatown with better food , service , reasonably priced and with much better space to breath .
author: Jed D.

description:
Well. Finally hit up the famous Mission Chinese Food and....it really wasn't that great. I've been excited to try it out for awhile now given the hype and recent appearance on Anthony Bourdain and sadly it didn't live up to the expectations.

The wait for a table was over an hour long and even after we were seated it took awhile before someone came by to take our order.

We got the mapo tofu, peanut noodles, green beans, chicken wings, and the fried rice. Everything tasted delicious initially, but all of a sudden I was overwhelmed by how SALTY everything was. And I normally like salty foods, but this was just too much. I couldn't taste much of anything because it felt like my tongue was drying up. I did however enjoy the fried rice (it was the least saltiest) and the chicken wings (I actually  wished this came out earlier so I could've ate it before the other dishes). The mapo tofu and green beans, usually some of my favorite Chinese dishes, were quite possibly the saltiest dishes.

I give it a three stars because everything did taste good for the first few bites...and I suppose it's an interesting concept overall. However, there is WAY better Chinese food out there, especially in SF (come on, now). If you're into your hipster/trendy/omg -I'm-eating-in-the-Mission restaurants, you might enjoy this place. Everyone else should look into another Chinese restaurant.
author: Cynthia Y.

description: What happened to Mission Chinese food?  The pickles, the Westlake porridge, everything was totally different.
author: Tam P.

description: My first 1 star review and it's sad to say it's for chinese food. (yup, i'm chinese). But I ain't one that is so blind to see that they're 'transforming' traditional dishes of chinese cuisine to become utterly despicable nonsense. yes, i said it. i had such a horrid experience here with many things other than the quality of food. for instance, the wait was ridiculous! if it wasn't for my curiosity (screw this!), i'd be flying out the door in an instant. the waitress was so impatient with us and gave us the 'dirty' look when we had only ordered 2 dishes (1 main and 1 appetizer) for my friend and I. then we wanted to stay after the 'meal' to chat, and she came over and gave us a dirtier look (like get out of here, chinese people... since everyone else is clearly NON-chinese...). the dish (vermicelli wrapped with pork belly?) that everyone raved about - that was a disaster. It was cold, harsh in taste and then the celery inside....it was so gross. For being a starving customer, I had to force myself to eat that thing despite my heart calling me ... NOOOOOO!!!!!!!! there, i said it. again.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Hyped,.. but a bit over hyped. 

3 of my coworkers and I decided to come eat here after work.  Came around 6pm and was seated quickly, lines got long after 7pm.  Not your typical Chinese restaurant, where you are served tea or tons of Chinese families and kids running around. it's a very hipster crowd, with loud music. But one thing that bothered me the most was our waitress with the OX nose ring, she was extremely rude to our party and just didn't have the friendly attitude that most HIPSTER restaurants have.  It's like we bothered her when we had questions or needed service. I guess Mission Chinese is a restaurant where they don't need reoccurring customers since it is such a big hit, with the publicity and supposedly Anthony Bourdain dined here.  

FOOD however was delicious.  Ordered 8 dishes and the TWO must have I would recommend would be the salted fish fried rice and the ORDER IN ONLY veal ribs.  

The salted fish fried rice had thinly sliced chinese sausages in it and it wasn't greasy like most fried rice I have eaten.   The rice dish went well with the other shared dishes we ordered. The veal ribs was the last dish to be plated on the table, but it was soooOO good. It was sauced with sweet and sour sauce and the meat did fall off the bone; when we used a fork and knife to tear it off,.. but the meat was fatty and juicy. Def recommend that dish! 

Mapowtofu,. I know they are known for this, but it tasted like every chinese mapowtofu I have eaten

Brisket soup,. coworkers loved this dish,. it had a smokey taste to it, which my coworkers stated brisket should have that taste. my taste buds didn't like it

Spicy chicken wings,. deep fried chicken wings topped with tons of red chilly peppers and topped with red dried peppers. ehHh,. looked cool in the yelp pictures but didn't taste that good. 

The tealeaf wrapped salad,. I dislike bitter salad,.. only order if you like eating noodle wrapped bittered lettuce

Two cold appetizers,. one with cucumber and the other was kimichi?! good starters, but could live without. 

Food came out fast, after a few minutes ,. the whole table was filled with all the dishes. Most dishes in the yelp photos, the restaurant didn't serve anymore.  Supposedly the dishes changes often. Parking is tuff, recommend taking bart, get  off  on16th street and walk over. Dislike the service, thus, the most I will do is order take out, but DEF will not be dining in and having to deal with servers giving poor service and poor attitude. I am taking my TIP elsewhere and spreading this to the foodie community.
author: Chanel L.

description:
I hate being a victim of over hyped food.

$11 for jook is unheard of. There is only so much you can do to jook (porridge) to make it taste like it's worth $11, aka there is only so much MSG you can add to it. There was a lot of crab meat in it though. But also a lot of ginger strips. If you're not a fan of ginger, definitely tell them to ease off on it. 

Shared a savory egg custard with my co worker. Basically it was egg, water, salt, apples, uni & trout roe. Interesting taste? Yes. Interesting doesn't mean good, it was mediocre. When I was eating it, I was more thinking like.. who thought of putting apples on top of egg, but more importantly, who decided to have the balls to advertise this as a bomb.com dish and charge $12 for this? Savory egg custard is a common PLAIN dish in the Chinese home. Easy to make: crack 2 eggs in a ceramic dish, add salt to taste, beat the living hell out of them, add water, and steam. Generally eaten with soy sauce, mix it in with your rice. "It tastes different in the restaurant"...that's because I don't use MSG at home. Don't be fooled by the apples!  

Definitely a hipster place. Combining ingredients to be different, with a pair of thick rimmed glasses on the side. Many of these reviews are probably by non asians, or non Chinese. Probably because Chinese people really wouldn't pay this much for Chinese food, because we know how Chinese food is made. Not because we're cheap. But because we're not easily fooled by hipsters. 

And honestly when my co worker asks if I want anything from there, I have to look at the menu over and over before I even find something I might consider. That's not a good enticing menu.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Delivery here disappoints me every time; I don't know why I keep giving them more chances. My food was burnt today. I ordered the chow mein and the eel rolls. The chow mein tasted like bland ashes. Definitely not worth $15. Last time, there was a hair in my tiger salad.

I'm mostly just writing this review to remind myself not to order delivery from here again. :-(
author: Ella U.

description:
I've unfortunately had mostly mediocre or bad Chinese food throughout my life, so I sometimes forget just how amazing it can be. Luckily, my friends thought to bring me by here this weekend, and I was quickly reminded!

We showed up at about 5:45 pm on a Sunday, and even though we had a large stroller with us, we were quickly seated near the door and offered a generous space to place the baby gear. The hostess was helpful--initially offering a bigger round table near the back, but then suggested that we could have this front table when she realized the current diners were paying.

The decor is sort-of non-decor :) But I'm fine with that--people are here for the food. It's a mish-mash of dragon suspended from the ceiling, Christmas lights, and old school tables and chairs. I made a trip to the restroom upon arrival to wash my hands, which necessitates that you walk through a prep area. I thought it was funny to see a sign above the door in that room ordering "Do not ask anyone in this room any questions." I guess that's their way of saying "these guys speak Chinese."

Food came out quickly, as it was ready. We ordered the Szechuan pickles--a spicy cabbage/carrot/peanut dish, served cold. It was interesting combo, and tasty. Our hot wings came out next. Served under a bed of chili peppers, they weren't especially hot, but definitely made your lips tingle a bit. Honestly, I'm not much of a wings fan and could have done without them--and because they are only 7-8 to an order, it wasn't a great buy. The salt cod fried rice was the perfect complement, though, balancing out the spice in the wings. The words "fried rice" do NOT elicit excitement for me, but it was amazing. Finally, the slow-cooked pork belly is divine--served with pineapple and cucumber for a sweet and sour taste. It has a crispy exterior but was melt-in-your-mouth wonderful.

I had a Back in Black (21st Amendment Black IPA) and one friend also got a beer. For the three of us, with 3 entrees, an appetizer, and 2 beers, the total was just under $50. Not bad at all, especially for some really awesome food.
author: Meredith D.

description: The staff here treated us like dirt. The waitress was so mean that it would have been funny if she didn't make our experience so uncomfortable. The host as well. The food, however, is fantastic, which is likely how such terrible treatment continues. Five star food, one star everything else.
author: M G.

description:
MCF has been on my to-try list forever. With the somewhat newer option of delivery, I was sold. I love that part of the profits are donated and the prices are completely normal. 

We ordered the cold noodles (and received the seaweed salad in addition... so sorry if we accidentally ate your dinner that night). Both were delicious - fresh, spicy, sour, tangy - yum! Next up the vegan delight soup - totally tasty although a small portion, so I'd wished we'd made it a double order. Our mains were the ma po tofu (100 things to eat before you die) and broccoli beef. The former was awesome - sweaty spicy. The latter was so unique with oysters and super fresh broccoli. 

What a refreshing take on Chinese food! I am by no means an expert, but it was so nice having food that wasn't oily without reason, that contained crunchy veggies and distinctive flavors.
author: Mac M.

description: This place was excellent.  I have dined at multiple Michelin starred Szechuan places in NYC and I could not be more satisfied.  The lamb and lamb dumplings were sublime.  The squid ink pasta was great too.  Although the salt cod fried rice was lack luster, it was still tasty. All the negative reviewers have no clue what Szechuan cuisine is all about.  If you don't like this place, you may be retarded.
author: Shaun C.

description: Does anyone know what happened to the smoked beef (fat) noodle dish they used to serve? That was the best ever!
author: E T.

description:
3.5 stars.

Came here on a Sunday afternoon around 2:10pm. Don't be confused by the Lung Shan Restaurant signs! We were seated immediately; I think the waves of people from the ridiculously good press a while back has died down.

Pork belly - Comes warm. Very fatty and delicious.
Thrice cooked bacon - I would have liked thicker bacon pieces / more meat but this was very good
Kung Pao Pastrami - The meat pieces were a bit dry but it had very good flavor
Mouth watering chicken - A cold dish. Good flavor but overall just ok.
Beef cheek a la orange - Like orange beef! Pretty good

Service was fairly good. Price is reasonable. It was very good Americanized Chinese food, just overall a bit too greasy and salty.
author: Michael W.

description:
OK...I have to review this bcz I just read another rave internet review.
Very possible, I was there on an off night....but this is frat house cooking at best.

This is the kind of place that should appeal to me on every level. Pop Up restaurant turns into a grown-up restaurant. Inventive menu with paper lanterns hanging from dingy ceiling. 

My first attempt I arrive at 6p bcz I have an 8p show. After an hour wait, there had been only three tables sat and there were still five names ahead of me. I abandoned and had an awesome dinner at Radish.

I return on a week night at 6p. I love love love the shabby hole-in-wall chic scene. I tend to like those places better before they start getting reviewed in local media.

We had kung pao pastrami (not too spicy, greasy, salty), 
White Tiger Salad (messy presentation and conflicting bitters)
and chow mein (greasy and salty). 
Fat and Soy Sauce seem to be the main ingredients.

This is how I used to cook during College after the bars. I would stumble home drunk and open the fridge and throw what I saw into a wok. I think there is so much potential here for a future asian fusion menu...but I think it has to grow into it still. So not really worth a 90 minute wait...unless you're just tumbling out of a bar and need some intense flavors and don't want to raid your own refrigerator.

But for now...I love the Spirit of this place, not the food.
author: Monster B.

description:
Always yum, always hipster, and always flavorful.  Service is okay, prices are high for traditional Chinese dishes, but the flavor and quality of the food makes up for the complaints.

I have been hitting up Mission Chinese since its first month and am always happy upon leaving.  Favorites are ma pa tofu, salt cod fried rice (also on the 7x7 Magazine Big Eat SF Top 100 Eats), and pork belly.

Just beware they are closed on Wednesdays!
author: Chad S.

description:
Ate at MCF last night and what a major disappointment after all the hype. 

Trying not to be too harsh, but we started with this appetizer of chicken wings buried in chili peppers that was just awful. Dried meat and tough flavorless skin finishing with the numbing sensation of the peppercorns and chili peppers. Wow. So far the food matched the storefront. 

Next up decent longbeans although super spicy, which normally I don't mind. I enjoyed the custard with uni, scallop and melon, especially after the wings rendered my taste buds useless. However, the Broccoli Beef Cheek lacked any cohesion. Ok, place tough broccoli stems on plate, add poached oyster and overdone, chewy, stringy beef, then serve by surly server. Why?  Just too be weird and "cutting edge"? Pork jowl and winter radishes?  You mean cubes of fat mixed in with about 40 halved al dente radishes with green stems attached?  What?

The real tell tale sign here was the rice. Dried and hard like it had sat on the counter for hours. I really don't get the hype on this place at all. Has anyone been to Momofuku to see how this can really be done??  David Chang has nothing to worry about in NYC. Don't waste your time here.
author: Vito A.

description: Wanted to like it, but my Asian friends and I found this to be some of the worst Chinese food in San Francisco. I guess it's fine for those who want a new kind of Americanized Chinese food featuring salty stir fried pastrami, etc.
author: Dennis W.

description:
I'm confused about why people like Mission Chinese so much.  I've now eaten here twice, and both times most of the food was so incredibly spicy, the spice overpowered the rest of the dish by a long shot.  I've had the ma po tofu, pastrami, beef cheeks, chow mein, salted peanuts, eel, and green beans.  The beef cheeks are quite tender and tasty, but friends found the dish boring overall.  The eel was strange and goopy.  The chow mein was fine for chow mein.  Everything else was super spicy!  And if you try to eat family style and mix dishes, the spicy dishes will overwhelm the flavors in all the other dishes too!  The ma po tofu was also swimming in red oil, which I found gross.  We took the ma po tofu and green beans as leftovers.  I literally rinsed them in water to wash off the spice, and they were still spicy!

I grew up eating Chinese food all over the city, and spice, not complexity or flavor, is the only thing that differentiates Mission Chinese from regular Chinese food.
author: Pearl L.

description:
I've died and gone to hipster h377.

The food is a mishmash of different Chinese cuisines with that awful fusion twist in a dark "ambiance" at high hip prices.  (I do give props for donating $0.75 per dish to the SF Food Bank.)  Any and all these dishes can be had for much better and cheaper at authentic Chinese restaurants all over the city, albeit not at any one place.

I love my spicy food, but the over-reliance on spice made the non-spicy dishes seem bland in contrast.  The tea-smoked eel lacked the strong eel taste and texture.  Ditto, the salted cod fried rice needed more salted cod - don't skimp on what makes the dish delicious!  The sizzling cumin lamb had the distinct lamb taste but not much else for flavor.  The spicy dishes were a bit better - the ma po tofu was just standard fare, the Mongolian long beans were good, and the "mouth-watering" chicken was the best because of the mound of red peppers to chew on.  Spiciness is good, but it goes even better when there are other complementary flavors.
