Are the dishes worth the wait and $10-ish per plate?   Let's just say that my fat butt won't be squeezing into overpriced, overtight skinny jeans to eat here anytime soon.
author: Kevin W.

description: I was so excited to FINALLY get to try Mission Chinese after all of these years (I absolutely hate waiting in line). Sadly we were all very disappointed. We ordered the Mongolian Long Beans, Broccoli Beef Brisket, Salt Cod Fried Rice, and the Spicy Beef Chow Mein. The beans were good but the only flavor you could taste was fire. Yes, we were told it was spicy but I was expecting a lot more flavor (and really didn't want to have to resort to putting soy sauce on everything). I thought the beef brisket was the best thing we ordered but the main flavor is definitely some sort of bbq sauce, which is a little overpowering. The beef and broccoli were cooked perfectly though. The fried rice was fine, nothing special, and pretty fishy tasting. The chow mein was a huge disappointment. The entire dish tasted burnt/smoky and you couldn't taste any of flavor. Plus it was pretty dry. I only ate a few bites of it. My fiance said that the flavors were pretty authentic but everything was underwhelming. The meal was really expensive for what we got, and there are a lot of better Chinese restaurants in the city.
author: Regina L.

description:
I'm guessing the reason this place has a three-and-a-half star is because it caters to hipsters.  And ohhh, how the hipsters love it, but ohhh, how they hate to let you know they love anything, so they'll dole out two and three stars while mentioning (offhand, of course) that they're bound to be back.  Jerks unlimited.

Look, I may wear Hudsons, but I can't abide that shit. This is crazy good food, like crazy delicious, and you don't have to take my word from it. The chef from El Bulli made it one of his *two* restaurant stops in the bay this year.  And if Ferran Adria wrote Yelp reviews, you'd know he f'ing loved it.

(Order anything with the words "pork" or "eel" on the menu. Order the tall blonde model for your waitress. Rinse. Repeat.)
author: Melody D.

description:
Ordered delivery to financial district on a weeknight and it took less than an hour. Pleasant surprise since they estimated an hour and 20 minutes (it was a large office order). Nothing was missing from the order, so their delivery service gets 4-5 stars from me, though I'm not sure if this quality of service is consistent. 

Wasn't a fan of the ma po tofu, it just wasn't very flavorful. Nothing really stood out to me from the order, but if I did another order from here I would go with the fried rice, long beans and thrice cooked bacon. 

I wouldn't drive all the way to the mission for this, nor would I wait in line for the food, but I would consider ordering delivery again if I am ever in the mood for Chinese food. If you're trying to avoid heartburn and you want Chinese food in the financial district area, I'd probably stick to R&G lounge.
author: Melissa M.

description:
All the hype from this Anthony  Bourdain layover fever has been disappointment, and mission Chinese food has been no exception. I will not go there again. It's just another Chinese hall in the wall w increased price range due to all the promo on TV.

Mission Chinese food may be good for mission hipsters, but this Asian girl who eats Chinese food regularly will not return. I'll stick to taco and burritos for lunch in mission!
author: Mika G.

description:
Don't hate me, but I am not sure what all the raves are about here. I mean, Bourdain hangs out with the owner and it's widely featured on NYT, am I missing something?

I've been here a few times, and actually ordered for delivery once (which is pretty awesome) but eh - I think all the foods is just too greasy for me. Even for chinese food, this stuff is too greasy. I also LOVE spicy, but again, it just doesn't hit the spot for me. From cod fried rice, ma po tofu, lamb stew, mongolian long beans all pretty blah and super greasy. Yes, there is heat to the food but the heat is just heat and doesn't really add that extra kick and flavor some spicy seasonings can add.

Overrated, and in a city with tons of fusion options and choices, you won't be disappointed going somewhere else.
author: Laura H.

description: It was tasty but did not live up to all the hype. Was kind of loud, and so dark it was hard to see my food. Also I really didn't like that they brought all the dishes -- appetizer, mains and rice -- out all at once. That made it impossible to focus on each one and also meant that half the dishes were cold by the time I got to them. Some more attention to pacing would be better. I kind of got the feeling that this place is just repeating what has worked rather than continuing to innovate.
author: Naomi G.

description:
Very, very, tasty, inventive hipster-american Chinese food. Awesome nontraditional creations which culminated in my favorite Chinese food experience. It was great not to feel like hell after scarfing our dishes down, as is the case with most Chinese food.

My girlfriend and I shared the pea and rock shrimp dumplings, the salt cod fried rice, and the kung Palo pastrami; all three were fantastic. The pastrami had just the right kick. 

The flavor profiles shone in all three. Will definitely be back.
author: Steve B.

description: It really take too long on my delivery order ... Over 2 hrs and I called 3 times, the woman answer the phone still say my food is on the way ... Come on , I am just 8 blocks away my friend , end up she hang up the phone..... Stay away
author: joe c.

description:
How is it possible that both " melissa's" chinese food in the richmond and "Mission" garner the same rating (3.5 stars)?  Melissas is poor poor poor quality while Mission is EXCELLENT FRESH GOURMET.

I suppose this indescrepancy highlights the major issue with yelp;  It is completely subjective, and i can only assume that because of mission chineses "hip, trendy" status, folks judge a little harder.

Well lets prentend that we are judging all chinese food to go joints, on a scale of 1-5.  Mission Chinese is AT LEAST a four, without a doubt. 

The food is of a much higher quality than most neighborhood chinese food spots.  The menu is certainly less than what we are used to, which is fine by me because how many times can you order mushu pork and steamed dumplings? HOW MANY TIMES?!?!

And finally, they deliver all over SF for an additional charge, which means i never have to order from Melissas again!
author: Bret O.

description: Just another TV over hyped joint serving shitty food. Soo much Sichuan pepper was used that completely numb your tastebuds. After 3 bites of the 5 dishes we ordered, everything tasted the same and extremely salty.
author: Diesel M.

description:
Why did it take me so long to get to Mission Chinese?  I suppose I thought it would be too crowded and overly hyped.  Oh was I wrong!  I went on a Tuesday night -- only waited 15 minutes for a table.  

What I ordered:
Tiger Salad -- fresh, very salad-y, felt similar to a Vietnamese noodle roll with lots of veggies and fresh herbs
Tea Smoked Eel -- tasty and even had corn flakes sprinkled on top!
ChongQing Chicken Wings -- okay, these blew my mind!  The Szechuan spice made my tongue feel like it was on drugs!
Kung Pao Pastrami -- flavorful, but a little too salty for me
Thrice Cooked Bacon -- this dish was my second favorite

The flavor combinations at Mission Chinese are amazing, creative and delicious.  I can't wait to take more people here so we can all revel in this fabulous food.
author: Irenka P.

description:
While the tale of Mission Chinese is a textbook Cinderella, the lineup on a weekend is atrocious and I don't believe it justifies the price or the quality of food. 

That being said, the dishes we tried were done well. In particular, the smashed cucumbers with a garlic sauce that will make even your mother salivate was so good I can still taste the spice, and the beef brisket soup has a smokey taste that kicks a traditional soup up a notch. 

The cumin lamb was disappointing. It's more onions than meat and lamb is an impossible thing to overcook, but they managed to do that as well. 

Check it out if the line is short and your hunger limit is long. Otherwise, another hole-in-the-wall Chinese spot in Richmond will suffice.
author: Sharon F.

description:
Mission Chinese is so different from your average take-out Chinese place. If you want good old favorites like chicken and broccoli or steamed pork buns this is SO not your place. But if you're into trying interesting and creative takes on Chinese dishes then MC is worth checking out!

I thought the food was really fresh and the quality was good of everything we ate. There were a lot of dishes on here that I had never eaten before, so it was fun to order a bunch of stuff and experiment. We had the Hot and Sour Cucumbers, Szechuan Pickles, Ma Po Tofu, Mongolian Long Beans, and the Hainam Chicken Rice. The Mongolian Long Beans were my favorite, although they were super HOT (but delish!!) and the Sour Cucumbers were a really nice cooling counterpart to the spicier dishes. The texture of the chicken rice with the nuts and cilantro was really good too.

I think the value for the money is great, especially being able to get delivery pretty much anywhere in the city.
author: Britt M.

description:
Every dish was pretty good - although VERY salty, oily & fatty.   I'd give it three stars for that, BUT i'm giving back one star for the sheer creativity of the dishes.

I could do without the way-hipster attitude.
author: Jaina S.

description:
NEVER AGAIN.
My boyfriend and I ordered the food for delivery as it was raining and we didn't want to slog through the weather for dinner.
There are only two things I need to say, the food was delivered to us TWO HOURS later after being told it'd take one hour. No apology or explanation. It was just ok. We ordered broccoli beef cheek, lamb, and rice porridge.
I went to sleep and snapped awake at 1 am feeling quite queasy. I made my way to the bathroom and puked up the entire meal. 
Thanks for the food poisoning, Mission Chinese Food! Maybe I can get a refund since I technically didn't get to eat the food?
author: Allie F.

description:
This is one of my favorite dinner spots in the Mission! Go early though, by which I mean right when they open, so you don't have to wait too long to get seated. If you don't you might be stuck in a long line, as the seating is relatively limited and the restaurant really popular. If it's too long though, you can still order to go so you can satisfy your Mission Chinese craving. And I've never tried the service before, but apparently they also deliver.

None of their dishes are "authentic" Chinese dishes. It's definitely Asian fusion, but not the upscale, more westernized Asian-fusion you see at more expensive restaurants. I feel like it's more "Asian" on the fusion scale, and like it because of that.

I've had and highly recommend the Shanghainesee Noodles, which were full of flavor and perfectly pan fried. The broccoli beef was some of the tenderest and delicious meat I've ever had and the beef noodle soup was amazing.

The salt-cod fried rice and pork belly were also delicious. Actually, almost everything on the menu is great!

A few personal exceptions though: some people really like the tea-smoked eel, but be warned that there really is a strong smoky tea flavor to it, which I was not a big fan of. The thrice-cooked pork was also a little salty for me.
author: Phong Q.

description:
I've finally found a Chinese restaurant in the city that I can get genuinely excited about. It's legit spicy too. I don't have a whole lot to add other than to say that this place was just named the #2 best new restaurant in the US for a reason. Definitely worth a try if you like spicy Chinese food and they do free delivery too. 

My favorite dishes so far are the salt cod fried rice and the kung pao pastrami.
author: Aaron V.

description:
How can people eat here? And they have so many great reviews too! My co-workers and I ordered 6 different things:

Tiger Salad: just a salad in a rice roll with some soy sauce and chili oil. Nothing special to be raving about. Edible but I would not pay $7.50 for this. 

Beijing Vinegar Peanuts- YUCK!! I guess when they say it's vinegar peanuts they meant VINEGAR! The peanuts are pretty much soaked in them so the vinegar taste is VERY strong! If you LOVE vinegar then go for it. My coworkers and I couldn't eat it after one bite. Basically it became trash. 

Hainam Chicken Rice- Worst case of Hainam chicken rice I ever had. The rice is all mushy and the whole dish was sour. And the chicken...what chicken? There was barely any meat and if there was, it was tiny pieces. I tried mixing this dish with regular white rice and it just couldn't be helped.

Sizzling Cumin Lamb- They must have left it sizzling for quite a while because the lamb was dry like jerky. This was a little below OK type of dish. 

Wild Pepper Leaves- Probably the best one out of everything we had. Still not a great dish but at least better than the rest. Nothing too special about the taste but for sure I can at least finish this dish without problems. 

$62 for all these with delivery is not worth it AT ALL! Don't know why it took them 1.5 hours to cook this crap up. Guess there must have been lots of customers.
author: sidney c.

description:
can someone tell me why this place has 2 names on Yelp??  it is listed at "Mission Chinese Food"  but the actual restaurant name is "Lung Shan Restaurant".....

why not just list it as "Lung Shan Restaurant" ??? this little detail screwed us up when trying to locate the place.  my fellow diners.... be aware of this. 

this place is a small operation, but an effective one.  the food comes out pretty quickly, and you're seated as soon as they can get you a clean table. 

we ordered: 
 - "Married couples beef"  = beef tongue, heart and tripe
 - "Chicken wings with explosive chili pepper" = self explanatory 
 - "Salt cod fried rice" = with mackrel confit, lup cheong, egg, scallion

the married couples beef is a cold dish consisting of beef heart, beef tongue, and tripe.  normally, i don't like tripe b/c of the texture, but i figured i'd try it again.... THEIR TRIPE IS GOOD.  this is by far the best tripe i've ever had in my life.... no joke.  this dish alone has made me change my mind a little about eating tripe. 

the heart is nicely beefy, and rich.  good thing the portions are slightly smaller for this dish b/c too much of the heart would have been.... well.... too much. 

the tongue i could have skipped.  it was oddly soft, with practically no "bite" and did not have much flavor. 

the chicken wings were also my favorite.  EAT THE CHICKEN WINGS.  they're spicy, perfectly seasoned, and delicious.  my brother thought they were too hot, but i thought they were perfect, so if you're sensitive to spice, maybe only try one piece..... 

the salt cod fried rice was not spectacular.  my brother cooked some fried rice while i was in SF, and his was way better than this one.  the cod pieces were practically non-existent, and the lup chong was also sparse.  

a solid 3 - some good dishes, some meh ones..... but definitely try those chicken wings!!
author: Trish P.

description:
Thank the lord I called in to pick up my order!

I walk into the dimly lit ornate room filled with musk and humidity, probably from all the wall to wall hipsters sweating their faces off from the spices they throw into almost every dish, and go straight to the back counter for order pick ups and exhale. I get that it's a Chinese restaurant, but damn if it really didn't feel like a Chinese mess hall of some tiny military building.

Aside from the atmosphere, the food is pretty tasty. The combination of their refreshing steamed eggplant with their explosive crispy well-seasoned chicken wings (with sparse fried tripe) was enjoyed in the comforts of my abode. Their version of spicy chilli oil? is more like cyanide if you ask me..something to use to play a good practical joke on some unsuspecting victims. 

Great treat for Chinese take-out.
author: eVa J.

description: I had diner my family tonight (6 people) and horrible experience. The worst Chinese food in the bay area! Food is quite expensive! I suggest you go other Chinese restaurant. You will pay less and get better food.
author: T Z.

description:
Not going to lie when you walk into a Chinese spot and you don't see 1 asian person you get a little worried and wonder if the food can actually be that good. Also its in the mission not sunset or chinatown.  Then the wait staff are all non asian and you really wonder if you made the right choice.

But the food was great
Had the veal rib which is kind of like sweat and sour sauce. takes a while to cook.
Pastrami was spicy but good with the rice
Cod fried rice. not bad 

Room is limited so be cool with sharing a table with others if you want to be seated quickly.

Front room is dark and plays hip hop.  when you go toward the back where the bathroom is at. you discover china.  chinese cooks playing loud chinese opera music just like sunset.

Def recommend trying when in a small party
author: Justin I.

description:
I've been waiting to go to this place since it opened but the long lines have always deterred me.  I finally tried to go recently only to find out that they are closed on Wednesdays.  Third time was the charm luckily.

1) Broccoli Beef Cheek - Seems like your norm broccoli and beef dish but so much better!  The beef is so incredibly tender and just melts in your mouth and there are oysters.  Plus since all our other dishes were spicy, this really helped cool down our palette.  One of my favorites.
2) Ma po Tofu - What they're known for.  Very good and very spicy.  I could only handle  one spoonful of this.  Too bad :(
3) Kung Pao Pastrami - Another great dish but I don't think I'd ever crave this.
4) Sizzling Lamb Cumin - I think I almost choked on the cumin-flavored smoke.  However, after the smoke had settled down and we started to breathe normally, the lamb belly was delicous!!  Would DEFINITELY get this again.
5) Salt Cod Fried Rice - I'm not sure if it's because there was too much of a spicy party in my mouth, but I didn't really taste anything special about this dish.  Everyone else seemed to like it a lot though.
6) Westlake Rice Porridge - Another favorite of mine!  There's oxtail and crab and one huge ostrich egg.  Usually this is supposed to come out first but I'm actually glad it came out last since it was a nice end to our meal.

There's always long lines for a reason but you'll come out smelly and sweaty and full of "gourmet" Chinese food.  Only wish this place was bigger and/or better ventilated.
author: Jane N.

description:
I don't live so close to the Mission and this place is always full so I rather order delivery, wait 20min, and pay a $4 delivery fee. The food here is good, not amazing.  For some weird reason it tastes very Mexican and everything is really spicy!!  I've tried most of their entrees, and here are my top three:

Salt Cod Fried Rice
Lamb Face Noodle Soup (you will want to eat it all!)
Broccoli Beef Cheek (tastes just like nopalito's carnitas)
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I heard soooo much about this even from out of towners and I read about it in NY Times.  I just had to try it.  It's NOT chinese food!  Veal, uni, beef cheeks, eel rolls?? These aren't typically found in chinese dishes.   And the clientele and servers there were mostly non-asians.  Four of us ordered a bit too much food: 

- Pork belly: 4 big pieces of crunchy-on-the-outside, melting hot and fatty on-the-inside pork belly.  
- Uni with egg custurd: first time i ever enjoyed uni
- Veal ribs: some fatty boney mess -- don't get this
- Tea-smoked eel rolls: disappointing. Not a lot of flavor. Still pretty unique.
- Mouth watering chicken (that's the name): probably my favorite. So salty but in a good way. Chicken hearts were yummy.
- Chicken rice: nothing special
- Spicy chicken wings: the peppers were too numbing. Couldn't eat more than 2 wings. It wasn't very spicy. It was just numbing.
- Beef cheeks with gai lan: beef cheeks were tender but this dish was nothing special in flavors.

One of the male caucasian servers was quite rude, but it's ok.  I go there for food, not for service or ambiance.  They play hiphop and american music.  The dining area was too dim, i couldn't even see my food very well.
author: Jessica N.

description: I've been so excited to eat here for months, hearing all the hype. This was the WORST Chinese food I've EVER had! The lamb was pure fat and grease - hardly any meat. The egg noodles were weirdly bland yet too hot, thanks to a proliferation of unadvertised jalapenos in the dish. Chow mein was eatable but unremarkable. Wait staff was harried but friendly.
author: Rob S.

description:
Upon moving to SF, I relied on the 7x7 list for foods that i needed to try.  Mission Chinese was on the list for its salt cod fried rice.

Determined to try this must-eat, my cousins and I ordered the fried rice to go since the line was so long!  We placed an order and waited 20-25 minutes for one order of fried rice!  Seriously?  So I thought, this better be freaking good.

To be honest, it was decent.  But where the heck was the salt cod?!  It tasted more like pork fried rice to me, and not the best one I've had either.  Disappointing.
author: Tanya P.

description:
This is Chinese foofd for white people who have never had real Chinese food. Sure it is family style recipes like Mapo Tofu that I enjoy so much when my Wife's family makes it, but sadly all the dishes aren't done very well, it is not bad, just fair.

This place is so over hyped with huge lines always, but really how many Chinese people do you actually see eating there? 
There is so many good places in the Sunset that blows this place away and some of the best in the country (comparable to my many trips to China) But I have no interest in having a bunch of people blowing up my spots where I'll have to wait like Mission Chinese to get seated, so your on your own, just remember a golden rule  when eating any ethnic food, go to the places that are serving to there people if you want to find the real deal.
author: dub g.

description: honestly this place should not be called Chinese food. its completely over priced, the food was seriously the worst, it was just not appetizing. We went to this restaurant assuming it was Chinese food but its far from it. please trust me and do not waste your time and money.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Haven't had the pleasure of going to the actual restaurant front but I've tried their delivery a few times and I've gotta say it's pretty tasty stuff. Usually when I see "asian fusion", it's pretty lazy stuff but this place has come up with some thoughtfully bold dishes. The Kung Pao Pastrami and Tiki Pork belly were particularly tasty imo. If you've got a craving for some very bombtastic Chinese food and can spare an extra buck or two then this place Is for you.
author: Jason L.

description:
I really, really wanted to like/love this place.  I went there quite a while ago - probably over 10 months and wanted to put in my two cents and hopefully save some people from the trouble of waiting in line to eat here.  The food was TOO spicy.  I know that's what gets some people hot, but it was rather obnoxiously spicy.  Everything felt too heavy-salty-greasy.  Selection limited (for a chinese menu).

I guess it's superior to "cheesier" chinese foods, but I have a hard time recommending this place taking into account its ambiance, price and quality.  = (
author: S.T. C.

description:
Great food, far from authentic, hipster atmosphere, crowded, good music.

Went with a group of 6-8, brought our own wine (3-4 bottles), had a fantastic night, cheap corkage fee (~$15), will be back!
author: Mitchell W.

description:
Walking in, it looks like your typical hole in the wall Chinese restaurant. But the room full of hipsters is the best indication that this is not your typical Chinese food (and not in a good way).

We ordered: tingly lamb soup, spicy wings, mongolian string beans, ma po tofu and pastrami. Everything (esp the wings) tasted like a salt lick. I also love spicy food but this was overkill. All the dishes just tasted like salty burning after a while. 

I didn't like the tingly feeling from both the lamb soup and the spicy wings. It felt like going to the dentist and that weird tingly feeling that you get while he's injecting novocaine. Definitely not pleasant for me. 

Ma po tofu had a few extra spices (cumin, I think) to make it not like your traditional variety. I was definitely not a fan of their version of it. 

String beans with leek were the only thing I really enjoyed. 

BYOB with no corkage fee is the only plus of this place. 

Definitely not worth the line. Save your time, there are much better Chinese food to be had in SF.
author: Lena N.

description:
Cruised by MCF with my boy on a gorgeous November evening. Wait, where is everyone? Oh right, waiting in line at State Bird. Name on list, 6 parties deep. 15 minutes and we were in. This place is super hyped so of course I came in ready to talk sh*t. 

Smashed Cucumbers in garlic sauce - Good crunch to start the meal, if not the most inventive.
Sizzling Cumin Lamb - Loved how the spice-crusted lamb was braised-tender then fried crispy.
"Mouth Watering" Chicken - Flavor brought me right back to my time in Sichuan two years ago. Thin strips of daikon added a welcomed CRUNCH.
Stir-Fried Sweet Peas - A gentler flavor profile, the natural sweetness from the peas was delectable.
Explosive Chicken Wings - Crispy but too salty, and I can handle me some sodium.

They definitely don't shy away from flavors. Nothing watered down up in here. Lots of salt and sichuan peppercorn, remember to chase with beer. I like what they've got going on, and I'll be back to try some different dishes. Not sure why it took me so long to get here...I'm such a hater.
author: Anthony R.

description: Eaten there twice. Been told that it is good. Read the book and was impressed by the quality of food. Also liked the Icelandic beer, and the food is surprisingly Chinese and American. Salad was inventive and I liked the rice noodle wrap execution. I'd eat here over and over again, though friends are not into Sichuan peppers as much as I do, and line is always long. May try again at 9:30 PM when the line dies down.
author: Victoria E.

description:
For all the negative reviews Mission Chinese Food (MCF) has been getting on Yelp, I did not have high expectations for this place. I chalked up the less than stellar rating to the Bourdain syndrome (Bourdain hits up a restaurant-It blows up-people expect to be blown away and are disappointed), but I really enjoyed my meal here. Here's why:

1) Price: The entrees were priced between $10-12, but HUGE. We ate till we were full and had leftovers for 2 full meals. MCF - wallet friendly! 

2) Ambiance: Dragon hanging from the ceiling. Red, dim mood lighting. Christmas lights accenting the walls. Empty Cristal bottles filled with fake flowers. MCF - Kitchsy, but hipster-cool in a way that would only work in the MIssion!

3) Taste: DELISH! We ordered the (i) Thrice Cooked Bacon; (ii) Broccoli Beef Cheek; (iii) Li Bao Dry Braised Noodles; and (iv) Salt Cod Fried Rice. MCF - "American Oriental food" at its best! 

The noodles were my least favorite dish. They were lackluster and kinda tasteless. Thank goodness the other dishes were standouts! The thrice cooked bacon was sinfully satisfying: chewy discs of korean rice cakes were an interesting contrast against the smoky, savory pieces of pork belly. I really enjoyed the cheeky play on broccoli beef: tender pieces of beef cheeks and chinese broccoli. I LOVED the salt cod fried rice. I could've had that dish alone as an entree. My bf thought it was salty, but I have a salty palate. 

Overall, don't let the 3.5 star rating deter you. It's definitely not authentic Chinese food, but it's an interesting, delicious, and innovative take on Chinese food, nonetheless.
author: Monelle A.

description: Over the weekend we both came down with a fever, so delivery was the best bet.  We took a chance with Mission Chinese Food and ordered the Thrice Cooked Bacon and the Broccoli Beef Cheek.  My boyfriend loved the former and I loved the latter.  The "bacon" dish was too oily in my opinion.  The Broccoli Beef Cheek was relatively healthy (not swimming in fat), and the beef was actually really tender.  That would be my go-to dish.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Chinese food in the mission?

Kinda random, no? But then, it is SF so maybe not so random at all. 

Food is good, if you like Chinese food. I'm just not that big on Chinese food as to me all the dishes (sauces/spices) taste the same to me. 
It's kinda like: do you want broccoli in this flavor or green beans?

Fast service, small, dirty looking place. But I guess good Chinese food.
author: Helen D.

description:
Pretty good food and decent prices.  I think this place is hit or miss with some folks because of the price point (for Chinese food), but it wasn't really any more expensive than a Chinese banquet restaurant; plus, the quality of meat was better.

We came shortly before 5pm (when dinner starts), so we were seated right away.  We ordered the kung pao pastrami, broccoli beef cheek, tingly lamb noodle soup, tea-smoked eel, and salt cod fried rice.  Our favorite dish was the broccoli beef cheek - incredibly tender.  The kung pao pastrami was indeed spicy, so I didn't try very much of it.  The tea-smoked eel was probably my second favorite dish, and the salt cod fried rice added a nice complement to some of the heavier dishes.  I did enjoy the lamb in the tingly soup but I hated the tingle - it just lasted too long for me to enjoy the dish.  I think next time, I'll skip the tingly soup and just order the sizzling cumin lamb.

Ambiance is entertaining, very hipster SF.  I think for a while, we were the only Asian people dining at the restaurant, which is normally a bad sign but I suppose Mission Chinese pulls it off alright.  Service was fine, though this would not be an appropriate restaurant for non-English speaking families.

Overall, everything was pretty good and we enjoyed our meal.  It wasn't necessarily go-out-of-your-way amazing, but I do recommend if you are visiting SF and passing through the Mission District.
author: Amanda N.

description:
Did not live up to the hype. Vegans don't bother.

It's been a couple months since going, but knew, as soon as eating, that I needed to write this review and so it kept dogging me....Here it is. Can't remember what we ordered but we requested the Vegan version of them. Food was interesting and new tasting, that's all. Not great tasting unfortunately. Never mind the cafeteria style eating, I actually like that communal feeling. And we appreciate it even more because a stranger sitting at the same table let us try his leftovers. It was tastier than ours, but still not hype worthy.

Bottom line. Vegans don't bother, there is much better food for us out here.
author: Key T.

description:
downgrading a star... but still a fan.

What to expect that you haven't already read:
One waitress at lunch hustling all the tables so don't expect excellent service.
Also don't expect any rhyme or rhythm with spacing out your food; it comes when it comes.

What to try:
Tiger salad wraps (4 cold noodles with very tasty mixed greens). pretty amazing.
Cod fried rice, a little salty but worth trying.
Again, ma po tofu!  This dish is fantastic.

The thrice cooked bacon is tasty  but not exactly packed with bacon.  It tends to be very spicy, mix that up with the fried rice and you're golden.

Neighbor's pastrami dish looked pretty yummy today.  So did he.

What not to try: 
ANYTHING if you're a vegetarian.  Don't bother here. A friend and I split a couple disappointing 'veggie' dishes last time.  The company made up for the fact that this palce missed the memo that there happens to be lots of vegetarians out there.

Also, don't try to hit up this place if you're in a hurry.
Having been here a few times now, it's hit or miss on the wait.
author: Athena S.

description:
Ironically in a city that seems at times TEEMING with Chinese people, you won't see any of them eating at Mission Chinese! Actually the most ironic thing about Mission Chinese are the t-shirts covering the hungry hipsters waiting in crowds outside in their raw denim, staring silently downward into their iPhones.  It's hipster fusion pop-up food, with a small menu that's very good but not particularly great on taste.  

After seeing the crowds waiting outside for two nights straight, decided to order in for delivery.  One cool thing is that they deliver...all the way out to the Sunset!  I highly recommend delivery over eating in so you don't have to stand in line.

Food? We ordered the Beijing peanuts, the pickled vegetables, the Thrice Cooked Bacon, Westlake Rice Porridge and the broccoli beef cheek. I love Taiwanese-glazed peanuts! Unfortunately the Beijing peanuts were kind of nasty and gave me gas. Do not order.  Pickled vegetables were ok. 

The Westlake porridge was good at face value but wished it had more of the oxtail and crab flavors in it.  The Beef cheek was a winner, not over-seasoned and fall off the bone fatty meat (I like my cheeks this way).  I thought the thrice cooked bacon with the chewy rice cakes and smoky flavoring was interesting and tasted pretty good and worth the order. 

For these few dishes, it took about an hour to deliver and came to almost $60. For takeout, I think it's worth it as you won't find much unique Chinese like this for delivery. But is it worth the crowds and the waiting?  Not really.
author: Emily Y.

description:
I was warned and still gave it a try.  Why am I so stupid sometimes.  Basically what you get is greasy over season over spiced food.  I like spicy but I also like to taste the quality of the main ingredient.  

I came here with a buddy and he said he felt sick afterwards.  

I was thirsty for more than half a day later.  MSG???

I broke a cardinal rule coming here.  Don't eat at a chinese restaurant where you don't see chinese people eating.

I think people go here just because they think its a hip hole in the wall.

I'm all for good hole in the walls.  But I'm not hip enough to eat here again unless a large group wants to go here.  Then I'll make the sacrifice.  

Just because a certain sfgate food critic likes a place doesn't mean you have to.
author: David L.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy in my tummy! Okay, the accolades are correct,  and all that has been said about decor, chill factor, noise volume etc. is true--but, as with all good restaurants, we go for the most important thing right? The food, duh, stay with me here.

The portions are actually a lot bigger than I would have expected:

*Salt cod fried rice has just enough saltiness to balance out the light, fresh cod. *Curried buckwheat noodles are dang good. They were served cold, which was an unexpected treat. I wanted to eat the whole bowl. 
*Mongolian long beans were tasty as well, but not as memorable. 
*Bottle of red was decent at about $25 buckaroos.

If you haven't been, stop you're holier than thou "I'm better than any over-hyped Chinese restaurant self-indulgent schpeel" and just go already. You can thank me later for the pep talk.
author: Shira O.

description:
Finally found it this time...after taking lessons on how to spot and locate a divey restaurant gaining worldwide notoriety....Ignore the actual signage and spot the waiting list clip board.

After finding metered parking and hiding assets from plain vehicular sight, we waited just about 10 minutes for a 4 top at around noon thirty on a Friday, not bad.

Decor is Chinese cheesy with a colorful paper dragon and white holiday lights strung along the walls, cheesy but I'm writing about it, so effective.

I noticed a couple of 'rules' 1). Write your name and # in party and wait OUTSIDE 
2). Need to wash your hands before dining? No problem, head to the bathroom by walking through the working kitchen, but DO NOT ASK ANY QUESTIONS

Everyone has written about the food and service...the spice on the chicken wing with 'explosive spice' was not a joke....eat this before any tongue piercing procedure...somehow the spice numbs the tongue actually allowing you to enjoy the wings without the pain of 'heat'.  Cleaver!

We enjoyed our beef cheeks, veal rib (stabbed and served with the actual weapon), tongue numbing wings and the thrice cooked bacon (why don't they just say triple cooked?).

I can now check this off my list and find restaurants with matching signage.  I'm too lazy for fancy marketing!
author: Randall F.

description:
We saw a write-up in the Delta SkyMagazine and decided to check it out after our SF friends gave it high praise when we asked if they had heard of it. 

Food here was solid.   Not in the most picturesque part of SF and from the plastic-oldish feeling decor  it looked like they overtook a crumbling Chinese restaurant and made it their own (note main sign out front says not Mission Chinese but Lung Shan Restaurant on a big yellow banner.  For a moment I thought my GPS had led me astray).

We went for an early-ish lunch on a weekday and had no wait to sit down.   We had the:

(1) hot & sour cucumbers:  just okay, not crispy.  
(2) smoked beef brisket soup:  tasty - hubbby liked the smokiness, my brain associates that smoke more with BBQ so I had to wrap my mind around this Asian version
(3) Stir fried sweet peas - OMG, pea crack !!
(4) Special pork belly - nice interpretation of pork belly. I say special because it is on their "eat-in" only portion of the menu.  

As others have noted they deliver which might be nice if you don't want to wait at dinner time (as I hear happens) or want to eat your grub in classier surroundings.
author: Lisa M J.

description:
This place was all that I heard it was and more. Definitely worth the drive from Sunnyvale. 

I got the Mongolian long beans, MaPa Tofu and salt cod fried rice. The fried rice was good, but I agree with the other reviewers, needed more fish. The Tofu was spicy yummy goodness...however, the stealer of the show was the long beans. So, perfectly crisp, super spicy and saucy. 

Parking is very hard to find and the place was packed. Be prepared to wait. I recommend ordering take out. You will be in n out in 20 mins.

I will absolutely be back.
author: Parag V.

description:
Definitely not the kind of Chinese I was expecting.
Americanized Chinese I guess? Hmmm...

Anyhow, the food was good but the saltiest food I have ever consumed.
(My god, it was salty!!!!!)

Tiger Salad- was great, reminded me of Vietnamese Spring Rolls
Salt Cod Fried Rice- was great but SALTYYYYY
Wild Pepper Leaves- boring and SALTYYYYY
Broccoli Beef Cheek- was good but almost 80% Gai Lan and little meat

The best part was the experience of using the restroom, where you 
have to walk all the way through the kitchen to get to it. 
Everyone grins at you because they get a kick out of how confused you 
look and how awkward you feel as you walk though as people are preparing 
food around you. 

Not to say it was bad food, but this place has been officially stamped as 
"Hipster Hype" by me.  Perhaps I will give it a second try in the future.
author: S. M.

description:
The line was long here but our party of 4 arrived early enough to skip the line.

We ordered:
- Two bowls of lamb face noodles
- Cod fried rice
- Mapo tofu

To put it simply, it was ALL delicious! We ate family style so I got to try some of each. In fact, one of my friends loved the Mapo tofu so much she ordered another one to go.

I absolutely loved the Cod fried rice (which was my contribution to our table's order). The only thing is I wish there was MORE! I suppose I'm not used to going to a Chinese restaurant and not leaving with leftovers. :P But maybe that just speaks to how good it was... and how we devoured it all in one sitting?
author: Melody S.

description:
So sorry to say you have lost my business.  
We've come here since you started out slow. Saw it get good where you had to choose which menu you wanted, either Mission Chinese or Lung Shan. Enjoyed the good will when Danny would come out and talk to patrons; which he did twice with us, way back when. Watched it become basically all Mission Chinese and have supported your hard work by bringing multiple guests to dine, and recommending your place by word of mouth. I live here. I'm a local. 
So I was shocked, angered and embarrassed when the young man playing host (and first representative of your restaurant) treated us, not just rudely, but with contempt! Our egregious offense? We walked in and tried to sit at a table in a half empty restaurant. He talked over the crowd to us. He scolded us by repeating no less than 5x in a row "the rules are very simple" and told us there are many other restaurants in the area and we could eat there. Add that he got into a staring contest with me before shaking his head at us in disgust. This all happened in less than 1 minute of our arriving. My out of town guest then saw him talking to the kitchen and gesturing our way, which prompted her to say "I'm not so sure they aren't going to spit in our food. We'd better leave."  WHAT?!  We could have been a drunken homeless crowd off the street and NOT deserved this abysmal attitude. 
I feel amazed that all the hard work and dedication the kitchen and wait staff put into this restaurant has changed to this turd's arrogant bull.  Here's a few OTHER rules to remember; COMMON COURTESY!  RESPECT YOUR ELDERS! or how about an original "The customer is always right!!??"  Amazingly poor form.  
Have him try that attitude with your TV friends Martha Stewart or Anthony Bourdain. OR EVEN BETTER, send him to work at your new NY restaurant. If he pulls that with some nice Italian ladies in NY, he'll be deaf in one ear and walking 'funny.'  Good luck!  p.s. I did bring my business elsewhere, and they treated us like gold. The way it should be.
author: B B.

description:
If my body felt better this morning, I would bump my review up one more star.  However, the the spice at MCF has done a number on my system.  Yet, the wonder of the flavors last night are not forgotten.

The Thrice Cooked Bacon was stellar despite not having enough bacon.  I'd eat those rice cakes for the rest of my life and never tire.

The Stir-Fried Corn and Peppers might have been the best corn dish I have ever consumed, which is saying a lot because corn is my favorite indigestible vegetable.

The Hot and Sour Rib Tips were a good way to start, but didn't hold a candle to the above dishes.

The Ma Po Tofu was not worth the damage done to my insides.

That being said, I am a big fan of their unique creations and look forward to many more trips.
author: Jeremy G.

description: The 12 dollar "mixed greens" is basically a bowl of steamed broccoli stems.
author: Hello D.

description:
Honestly, I thought lunch was just A-Ok, but I probably won't come out of my way to come back. 

The ma po tofu was good, but SPICY. I thought the tofu was a little on the rubbery side.

The cod fried rice was fine, but not mind-blowing.
author: K. D.

description:
It just so happens that I stumbled into my house which smelled like Chinese food only a mile away to find tons of bags of take out which my room mate and his gf picked up.  Now, I've heard a few good things about Mission Chinese Food, and have been wanting to try it for some time now.  How fortunate of me to not even ask for it, but have great friends just show up with food.  

Although this place exceeds regular chinese food joints, it doesn't do so by far.  While some dishes add a little  extra something to set it apart from the others, some simple things like chow mein are far beyond reach of the real thing.  Therefore, while a 3 star seems short, its more appropriate for a 3.5 stars.  Not quite a fan, but admirable for some of the flavors and creativity.

Let's start with the bad:
-Chow Mein - granted it was takeout, but even with that, the chow mein shouldn't be so mushed up and soaked in sauce.  Sure I like my sauce, but when the noodle itself starts losing its consistency and almost mixes in with the consistency of the sauce, that's a big NO thank you.  Even the nice pickled greens which offered crunchiness to the dish was unable to save this

-3x Cooked Bacon - pretty much just thicker slices of bacon cooked perhaps stewed, broiled, and then stir fried into the rice cake.  The rice cake was too hard, and there was too much salt in this.  Bacon and Pork Belly are the same thing people.  Don't be fooled when someone throws out a miraculous dish with the words: P-o-r-k B-e-l-l-y

-Ma Po Tofu - I know lots of people usually like this, but over here, its just like any other restaurant IMO.  It wasn't bad, it wasn't great.

The good:
-Rice Noodle with Unagi - i like rice noodle, and I like unagi.  However, the rice noodle wasn't fresh enough and tended to be too thick and hard right against the soft unagi.  I think what works for rice noodle dishes is a contrast in texture such as shrimp or the chives in the ground beef, or the bbq pork in some dimsum restaurants.  While the texture just didn't work for me, I did like the flavor and the marry of japanese cuisine in a chinese twist.

-West Lake Porridge - so simple, yet it amazed me how good this was simply by changing water and cornstarch roux with congee.  The flavor is still there but instead of a thick soup, you get a thick hearty porridge.  

-Uni and scallop over steamed egg and roe - perhaps my favorite because it twists so much japanese influence on a traditional chinese dish, steamed egg.  Roe could have been excluded, but the uni and raw bay scallop definitely gave it a different flavor that was appreciated.  

-Salted Cod Fried Rice - let me say, when you order this from ABC, from those other chinese restaurants, it does not fail you.  It's a go to kind of rice since the fish is perfectly salty and everything else in the rice just goes well with it.  But here that salted cod tastes different.  It could be (I don't know) that they cure their own cod, but theres a nice richness and no overpowering flavor in the  salted cod that's presented in the rice.  

Overall, its a fairly interesting experience and worth checking out again because having eaten the same chinese food years and years, its nice and refreshing to see some new ideas applied to it.
author: Vincent K.

description:
This is a great place to take your 19 year old hipster date, especially if you're a cheap bastard, because it's cheap. But remember, just cuz there are a bunch of sheeple outside waiting interminably, doesn't mean it's good. 

Every sensory experience at Mission Chinese, from the smell, to the taste of the food, to the loud hip hop, is like a sledge hammer to your sensory organs. If that sounds good to you, then you're probably under 20, or you're some kind of masochist. 

...and mainstream gansta rap background music? This is not edgy, this is just plain bad taste. To quote Milan Kundera: "How can you eat food, and listen to shit?"
author: El G.

description:
We ordered Mongolian long beans and lamb ribs. It was amazing, a great blend of flavors. They were spicy enough for us and we were so fascinated by the ingredients used to bring the flavor. Amazing job!

For those who don't prefer red meat, choices here are very limited.  We wished we ate red meat. 

The ambience could have been a little better/brighter,for those who prefer to eat in. We will go here surely next time (for the same stuff:-p) but a take out.
author: Su R.

description:
As far as I can tell, this isn't authentic Chinese food (I lived in China for a while).

Instead, it's riffing on American-Chinese food, e.g. Kung-Pao Pastrami. 

It's a little weird, and a little gut-bomb. But I love it for that.

Cheap, too. Delivery go-to joint for when I've got the itch.
author: Ben M.

description:
I LOVED the salt cod fried rice.
I LIKED the tiger salad - wished the side of vinegar was fish sauce or some other condiment.
I am GLAD that this is pretty affordable and so close to my casa.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I don't understand the criticism that Mission Chinese food is "too hipster." What the fuck does that even mean? Do you know what a hipster is, marina trash, bridge and tunnel ppl, yuppie fucks? When i was there, the laptop hooked to the speakers was playing  a hip hop channel on pandora. Is that hipster, you fucks? STFU about this place being hipster, and write about the god damn food, you fucks. 

I wouldnt go back to MSF again. I know it's schezuan, which is categorized by spicy food, but my stomach is hurting after eating the following dishes: ma po tofu, chinese pastrami, open face sandwich (shitty), pork belly, and trice cooked bacon. Of these dishes, the best was the porky belly, a dish that's like slow cooked bbq with the crispness of chinese bbq. A bit chewy on the skin, but the fat and meat was oh-so-delicious -- soft, almost liquidity, and packed full of flavor.

Everything else, however, was meh. Ma po tofu was so junk...I could taste a weird initial taste in the ma po tofu. This is not the grandma's tofu you would expect; it's something worse, way worse. It's spicy, weird tasting, and pretty terrible. The bacon? Eh. whatever. It's white ppl hyping up asian and western fusion. Terrible, and a waste of ten dollars. 

I wonder if half of the reviews are positve from white ppl, while the negative reviews are from asian people. I would rather eat good asian food than this bastardization of asian food. Real talk. 

PS: I guess im a hipster. Does that make my review any less credible?

PSS: I'm asian, btw. I should know my shit, right? 

PSSS: From my profile pic, i eat dog with hot sauce.
author: Richard L.

description:
Mission Chinese is for the adventurous eater.

Proof:
"Married Couple's Beef" (sliced beef tongue, heart, tripe..)
"Stir-fried Pork Jowl And Radishes" (pork cheek)
"Sizzling Cumin Lamb" (lamb)
"BBQ Pig Tails" (yes, pig tails)

Food is not exactly authentic Chinese but still pretty yummy and worth a try.
author: Sarath S.

description:
Worst food ever.

We couldn't even finish one of our dishes. Odd flavors left our mouths feeling tingly. And one dish that was spicy was somehow just hot without having any flavor.

We ended up eating white rice with soy sauce to avoid starvation.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I think the food here is good, and I find the "creativity" in their menu interesting, but guys, this place is way overhyped.  

To start with, this is not real Chinese food, and I don't think it pretends to be either.  (If it does, then it is no better than an average Chinese restaurant.) So let's accept this and move on and think of this place as a "modern" and inventive cuisine, albeit in a jarringly mismatched Chinese restaurant setting.  But the dragon in the ceiling is pretty awesome!!

The use of western ingredients in Chinese preparation is a cheeky twist, for example, Kung Pao Pastrami and Savory Egg Custard with Sea Urchin.  Such pairings are creative and refreshing and opens a new perspective on how to re-invent traditional foods with new ingredients.  Hats off to the chefs for their creative genius.  

However, the execution of such new dishes at times falls short of expectations.  
Slow-Cooked Char-Siu Pork Belly - this just has "yummy" written all over it (I mean, what part "slow-cooked", "char-siu", or "pork belly" does not make your mouth water), but here's where 1+1+1 equals less than 3.  The resulting dish did not achieve the normal tenderness of a slow-cooked pork belly, nor does it have the awesome smoky, savory-sweetness of a classic char-siu.  The flavor of the meat was less developed than it should have been.  The consolation prize of the dish was the soy-cured egg - smoky and salty with a soft melty yolk - makes you want to have more.

Broccoli Beef Cheek - I suppose this is the upscale version of the ubiquitous Chinese take out menu item #54 "Beef with Broccoli" - turned out ok.  The beef was tasty, and we were pleasantly surprised to bite into a whole poached oyster, which adds so much richness to the dish.  However, the quality of the Chinese Broccoli was quite poor - several pieces were fibrous and tough.

Salt Cod Fried Rice - turned out to be the dish we couldn't stop eating.  Salt Cod is usually quite salty, but they did a great job toning down the salt here, and produced a tasty fried rice.  The rice was cooked well - dry but tender.  The salt cod and the Chinese sausage both contribute to that savory goodness that only preserved meats can provide, rounded out by the freshness of the scallions and softness of the egg.  

I would go back for the Salt Cod Fried Rice, but may have to think twice about some of the other dishes, and waiting in a long line outside for a table.
author: Thomas L.

description:
The amount of positive press (a la SF Chronicle's Bauer and NY Times) had me overlook the fact I waited outside on a Saturday night at 7pm for over 40 minutes to get seated. I was fine with that- considering Bauer's rave.

Plus it's supposed to be the "best non-Chinese Chinese food" in San Francisco, at a really chintzy Chinese restaurant in the "cool" part of town.

I'm down with that. I'm all about a good gimmick and a great chef story.

FOOD: The Tiger Salad was amazing. Fresh herbs and wrapped with cold sheets of  pasta in a fantastic seasoned sauce. Great starter- although huge portion size. You'd think there wouldn't be complaints in that department, but I'm a traditionalist: starters are to whet the appetite, not become your whole meal.

I followed that up with the General Tso Veal Rib. I love me some ribs, but I've also given up pork a decade ago, so this opportunity had me frothing. Huge slab of flesh with fork and knife dug into it, swathed by an assortment of onion/pepper slivers in Tso sauce. The big hunk of veal looked tempting so I started gnawing happily, until I realized that the majority of it was fat. Ever realize that you're masticating fat directly? I got nauseous from that thought, despite the meat portion (what little there was) tasting great. Took the bits of meat and veggies home in a to-go.

SERVICE: Great, tall blond server who knew her shiz. She gave great recommendations and was quick. The one unsmiling Asian guy? He gave my table attitude when we asked what a certain dish he plopped on our table was. "Do you want it or I'll take it away," he said. He reached for the bowl. We repeated our question of what it was and he just stared at us and said it was what we ordered. He needs to be clued in that the put-upon attitude isn't synonymous with no-frills aesthetic. 

AMBIANCE: It's the hole in the wall Chinese restaurant, complete with white plates, plastic chopsticks, and regular carafes of water. Decor is standard for this type of restaurant: Paper dragon across the entire restaurant hanging from the ceiling while top 40 hiphop blasts out of the speakers (need to be replaced, btw- one receiver was going in and out my whole meal).

Overall, I'd go back, because I saw more things on the menu I'd want to try. The food is pretty good. Hyped, but good.
author: C. P.

description:
My incredibly recent, and incredibly ridiculous, conversion to a pescatarian lifestyle has left me craving my old meat goodies, and thus I am revisiting every San Francisco joint that has supplied me with delicious, juicy, MEATY goodness in the last few years. 

I am no stranger to Chinese dives. I'm one of those Chinese people who believe the dirtier, smellier, and closely packed it is, the better the Chinese food (note: this works for Chinese restaurants only). So I really had no expectations when I walked into Mission Chinese Food. I barely noticed the metal and plastic chairs with riped vinyl seats. I could barely feel the stickyness of the table. And the dingy, musty, dark room around me didn't faze me. What DID surprise me was my very pristine, very hipster, very skinny jean wearing friend sitting across from me at this unassuming restaurant. Even more, I was befuddled as to why HE was the one who brought me here. In true hipster fashion, he always brought me to trendy eateries in the gentrified Mission and upscale food spots downtown. What were we doing here??

One look at the menu and I knew: we were not in for an ordinary Chinese experience. How did I know? The prices. Not your mom and pop Chinese restaurant with $28 meals that serve 4. Nope, here each plate is $10-$15 and they sound like amazing dishes that could be served in any upscale restaurant. And they're written in English. 

We ordered the Tea Smoked Eel Roll, the Salt Cod Fried Rice, a Scallop Custard, and the Pork Belly. Everything was AMAZING. Again, I am not a high class Chinese food type of girl, but cheap Chinese doesn't compare to the progressive dishes they have going on at Mission. While I didn't LOVE the Tea Smoked Eel, it was really interesting and unique. The Salt Cod Fried Rice wasn't anything special--it was a typical dish that you can order at any Chinese restaurant, but here it just sounds fancier. The Scallop Custard was soooo delicious. But the Pork Belly was the star of the show for me. Crispy and crunchy on the outside and moist and tender and juicy on the inside. I love the Hoisin glaze and how it slightly sticks to the back of your teeth. So good. I wish at still ate meat. :[ 

Overall, this place merits 4 stars for me. Half a star off for crappy parking and another half off for the prices. But the food is delicious and well worth the trip out to the Mission District.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
It's cold and rainy and I have a bit of a cold.  I think to myself that a nice warm bowl of soup would hit the spot.  So I go over to Nombe, but apparently it is closed on Mondays.  I figure I should just try out Mission Chinese Food.

I walk in and it looks... a bit dingy.  Not unlike many hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurants, except that it is staffed by hipsters.  I ask for a table of one and they ask if it would be okay to seat other parties of one with me.  That's fine.

I take my seat and they put a plate, a spoon, a pair of chopsticks, and a paper napkin in front of me.  They top it off with the one page (laminated, front and back) menu.  I look through the menu to pick my soup.  They put a glass of water and a large bottle of water in front of me.

I will have the porridge.  I also see pork belly on the menu.  I'm such a sucker for pork belly.  My hipster waitress comes over and I order.

I sit for about 10 minutes.  Someone else is seated diagonally from me.  They bring out the pork belly.  It's larger than I thought it would be.  It was described as a "small plate."

It looks delicious.  

It's not.

They are obviously trying to do something interesting.  Overwide cold  rice noodles wrapped up like gauze bandages.  Cold crisp cucumber discs.  Cold hard-boiled eggs sliced in half.  Hot crispy pork belly cubes.  Sauce and sesame seeds drizzled around.  Sounds good on paper.  In practice, it's not.

The pork belly is a bit over-fried on the outside.  I enjoy the contrasting textures, but the flavors don't mesh.  I'm not impressed.

Next up, the rice porridge.  Solid rice porridge.  Lots of rice porridge.  The oxtail and the crab go well together.  There is a the strong taste of ginger and cilantro.  Very nice, but not spectacular.   I'm happy with it though in this cold rainy weather.

Overall, I guess it's okay.  Nothing blew me away.   I could see it being a hit or miss kind of thing.
author: Michael N.

description: The food here is blech and overpriced. My boyfriend likes it (but he's a white dude). Even for "fushion" food it's at most average. Salted cod fried rice was bland - a total disappointment after all the hype. The meat in the porridge tasted rancid. The pea shoot dish was super greasy. Next time I'll just cook it my damn self!
author: Alice Z.

description:
The food was good for what the type of restaurant is- Chinese fused with American.

I went for lunch on a Thursday with 3 coworkers at around noon and we were seated immediately. We ordered the lamb noodle soup, Mo Pa Tofu and the pastrami dish. 

The food is on the salty side so if you're sensitive to salt watch out (especially the pastrami!) 

The lamb noodle soup was delicious so definitely get that. The tofu was equally delish and spicy but you have to order a side of rice to soak up the sauce. 


All in all a satisfying experience!
author: Georgina G.

description:
Slow service and rude staff. My friend who is vegetarian ordered a vegan dish. I got my food and all the tables around us got theirs even when we got there first. His food finally comes out. He starts eating it and then he asks me, "is this bacon?" It was some chinese ham and he wasn't given the vegan version of the dish.

My food was so salty that it was inedible. MSG, salt, in a dish that had a lot of salty components like Chinese sausage. Why is this joint so popular? Maybe I ordered the wrong dish, but I have been to other highly rated restaurants and its hard to find something that's almost inedible. 

Also don't try the spicy wings. It's dry and it's on a bed of dry chilies that add no flavor and it only makes your lips numb. I've had dishes like that before but the food had flavor before the numbness comes in.

Left feeling very disappointed and just don't see why there are so many people loving it.
author: Barry K.

description: I used to love this place because of the squid ink noodle dish, but they've changed it!!!! :( whyyy would they change the best thing on the menu?! anyways, i've only been back a couple times after they've changed the squid ink noodle..their dishes are creative, good portioned, and very flavorful (sometimes too salty) they have off days but on average are pretty on point.  i like to explore the menu and try the unique dishes.  I will continue to go back but do really wish they would bring back the squid ink noodle (now they serve a dry version with a different sauce that just doesn't compare)
author: Christina K.

description: Hype that has spread across the country. Unfortunately the reality falls short. Immediately felt as though they were trying to get us in and out as fast as possible. We had 4 servers throughout our meal, meaning lots of attention but very annoying when they kept coming up asking what we'd like to order. Then somehow our drink order was left forgotten and we had to reorder it. Tuna roll appetizer did not even make it into the "decent" rating. Pork belly was great. Egg noodles were good, but nothing special - Ginger overpowered it and the advertised vegetables were non existent. Cherry pork ribs were just ok, but I was a bit overwhelmed and turned off by the massive quantity of the serving. Would've enjoyed it more with half as many ribs. Overall, left quite disappointed.
author: Jeff C.

description:
We got lunch delivered this past Tues and ummmmm WTF?!

-Chilled buckwheat noodles: almost edible because the noodles toned it down a bit but the horseradish was gross with it and it was already too vinegary & salty and then there was the salty roe too

-Stir fried pork jowl: the pork was tough, the radishes were a bad combination with the black bean and mint and I love fermented black bean. Again too much vinegar

-Stewed beef tongue soup: totally disgusting, tendon/meats fine but again wtf is up with all the vinegar and poor flavor combos?

In general probably the most revolting food I've ever had sorry...I LOVE adventurous food so i was very excited. It's the best when I get something I never thought of combining and its delicious, but this is like -nobody's done this for a reason, and it shouldn't be done again. All the flavors were unbalanced. I feel like this place must be really douchey  filled with people who want to be cool but it's a flavor failure hands down.
author: Monica H.

description: This is a typical example of what doesn't live up to the hype.   Tiki Pork Belly was just ok.   Eel roll wasn't great.     The hole in the wall idea with a fresh new menu and crowd is great but it's supposed to have amazing food if it's a hole in the wall- but it doesn't.  So I honestly don't really understand why it's popular.  I guess it's ALL Hype.
author: Joey C.

description:
Mission Chinese Food takes Chinese food to a different level (in a good way).  

We arrived around 5:30 on a Sunday and was sat immediately at a shared table; which is fine with us.  But I feel that I totally annoyed the host/server when I had to ask him/her to repeat what they just said bc I couldn't hear.... I can't help it if I'm getting old, but its hard for me to hear when I'm really into the loud music thats playing, there's people on all sides of me having their own conversations, and the server/host can't speak up.

On to the food... the husband and I ordered:

Szechan Pickles:  reminds me of a milder version of kimchee, except with peanuts.  Will have to order again.

Chicken Wings:  The husband says these may be the best chicken wings he's ever had, to me they could have been a tad crispier.  But the generous amounts of salt, pepper and red roasted hot peppers are a perfect combination.  

Westlake Rice Porridge:  This was my favorite of all.  Big chunks of dungeness crab; although I only got the bits of oxtail for texture rather than taste.  Regardless, I devoured that like a teenager drinking Boones Farm for the first time.

Salt Cod Fried Rice: meh.  Love that they add Chinese sausage to it.  But being half Asian myself, my mom makes it better.  My old man really loved this dish, but what does he know, he's haole as all hell.

Kung Pao Pastrami: This is something the husband really wanted; as he hearts pastrami.  I think they forgot that we ordered it, because we mentioned it twice that we were still waiting for it (to two different people).  Finally, we told someone that we didn't want it if they haven't cooked it yet, and a minute later it was brought to our table.  It was way to smokey for me, so I just took a nibble, and by this point we were ready to leave so the husband took it home and ate the leftovers the next day.  He wasn't crazy about it.  However, the staff was very gracious to take this item off of our bill; and we were very pleased that they showed customer appreciation (which takes away the annoyed server/host experience).

Yes, we will be back.
author: maggie m.

description: On a Monday night after 9pm might be the ideal time to eat here because we sat down right away and the food arrived to our table within five minutes. The pork belly appetizer was incredibly tasty and succulent, which I guess you'd expect since it's mostly fat! The shrimp dumplings were mild and tasty too, and the smashed cucumber with sesame paste and chili was most delicious. I sampled a bite of all the entrees on the table: veal, tofu, brisket beef, and noodles with beef. All were exceptional. I would describe this food as a more fusion-y version of traditional Chinese food. And it all tasted "clean." As with other restaurants in the SFO area in my experience, the staff is helpful and friendly, and doesn't seen bothered when you ask them for menu recommendations or extra water, napkins, etc. I'm a fan of this place.
author: MariAnne J.

description:
I liked it, you may not. . .Try it more than once. Lunch is busy by 11:45 AM. Get there early, but not too early. It's closed on Wednesdays. 

Expect a wait. Hang outside among the wacky storefronts in da Mission, behold the sad sack exterior and marvel at the street folks trudging by as they make their way from 16th & Blade Runner aka 16/Mission.

The food is splendid and my taste buds smiled. MoPo Tofu and Baby Bok Choy in Popcorn Broth were hit at our table.

Oh yeah, the interior makes you think that you landed in an early Jim Jarmusch B&W movie. If you've never seen a Jarmusch flick, see one and then come for dinner.
author: Russ C.

description:
Luckily didn't have to wait much at all, but definitely not your typical Chinese restaurant. My friend recommended this place and it had an interesting selection on the menu. Really good food for a reasonable price for the most part. I had the Tofu which was definitely spicy, but good. Did get the try the salt cod fried rice which was really good as well, but not really out of the ordinary flavor-wise. Fair warning, salt is not used lightly!  

Worth the trip to try it out and for an interesting meal out.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Dude: JUST GET IT TO GO. 

Unless there is no wait and 30 people on staff, it just isn't worth it... the food's good, but not THAT good.

Before I begin my review, I will acknowledge: I have only eaten here once and my expectations were decidedly not in line with reality (I blame Alan Richman.)

Nevertheless, I give two stars, taking all of those things into consideration.

We went on a Monday evening. 

After a 25 minute wait, the host called us to our table. As we approached the door, we watched him disappear into the back of the restaurant.   Minutes later he reappeared and immediately began chatting familiarly with a table in the back without ever *actually* seating us.  

Long story short, 15 minutes later, we still weren't at a table. 

Then, our server was an awkward teenage (I think?) girl who was practically wearing a sign that said "I AM AFRAID OF CUSTOMERS AND ALSO AFRAID OF CARRYING PLATES".  Which, you know, was kind of an obstacle.

The food is good. It's not Chinese food as you know it, which the chef is the first to admit-- he's a Korean guy who grew up in the midwest. However... I can't say that I LOVED anything I ate, or would even really order it again? Needless to say, maybe I'll grab a little takeout sometime, but I left their dining room positively drained by frustration.
author: Laura F.

description:
After hearing all of the hype surrounding this reastaurant, we were excited to visit!  Now we are glad we never have to go back!

We arrived around8:30 and were told the wait was about 45 minutes, so we went to Commonwealth next door after putting our names down on the menu.  The review for commonwealth will be next.

We went back to Mission Chinese around 10 and were seated within a couple of minutes.  It was really dark inside and was a bit hard to read.  We asked the server what she would suggest, so we went with her suggestions.  We oredered...

Pickled Vegetables
Braised Pork Belly
Veal Ribs
3 Cooked Bacon
Kung Pao Pastrami

First the pickled vegetables.  Hot and sour.  Could only eat a couple of pieces.  That should have been a warning sign.  C

Next came the veal ribs.  This was two attached ribs with a 3x3 inch square of meat on top that was BLACK on a bed of stuff.  The stuff on the bottom (vegetables) were HOT!  The rib was completely charred (not in a good way) and tough and inedible (at least I tried to eat it).  We cut away the burnt outer area and inside was tender and juicey.  It didn't have any flavor unless you put it into the HOT stuff at the bottom of the plate.  Complete  Fail!

We then got the Kung Pao Pastrami.  We love pork.  We always order pork.  I will never order pork again here.  When you think kung pao, you know there will be roasted chiles in oil and it will be hot.  What you don't expect is a dish with a blended chile sauce that covers everything and is so HOT that you can't taste any part of this dish, even the pastrami.  We all had two bites (that might be stretching it a bit) and that was it.  We were done.  No balance, no flavor, no pastrami tastiness, just unbearable HEAT!  F

The thrice cooked bacon.  The same as the kung pao pastrami.  No balance, no flavor, no bacon tastiness, just unbearable HEAT!  F

Finally the pork belly came.  Yeah.  No red HOT sauce smothering it!  Our salvation has arrived!  We tried it.  Braised pork belly slices, no flavor of any type.  As though it was braised in water.  Then it was sliced and fried with no sauce or seasoning.  Tender, fatty, no balance, no flavor , no pork belly tastiness.  

Come on!  Really!  Not one dish with flavor, balance or tastiness?  I guess this is another example of once a restaurant gets some good press, they feel they can rest on their laurels and make food without heart, passion or integrity.  It is a bummer because I was so excited to come here.  

And after we got our last dish, instead of the server asking how everything was and if she could get us anything else, she said "do you want to go containers?"  Wow, great service to boot!  Nobody mentioned to us that the kitchen was closing (last call).  Really nice.

On the way out, one of my friends let out a muffled cry.  What's wrong?  She saw a large cockroach on the front table where the waiting list book rested on.

Enough said.
author: Zed K.

description:
I love that they deliver!! 

Their mapo tofu is a modern twist on a classic as is their broccoli beef. The mapo tofu has a great balance of spicy with some spicy black bean texture. Broccoli beef uses high quality beef flank that easily comes apart served with crispy Chinese broccoli. The dishes aren't as greasy as many other Chinese restaurants, but with the same low price. If you're in the Mission and don't feel like Mexican food, Mission Chinese Food is the place to go. Another great find in the city!
author: Angela L.

description:
This could be one of the most overrated places in San Francisco. The food was either kinda bland or just too spicy and not in a good way (hint..hint...mapo tofu.) The pork belly was a bit too dry for my liking. It wasn't juicy and it was cold. My friend ordered a salad and it never came. We tried so hard to get the waitress attention to ask about the order. It seemed like they were doing something, but not really. I suspected that they were equipped with a sixth sense, "I think someone might need something. Quick! Avoid eye contact and turn the other way around!" 

Finally when we got one of them cornered, her reaction was just 'u-huh' and she carried away with her business. Needless to say, we never got the salad and they were just too busy apologizing 20 minutes too late when we got our bill. 

It's not worth the wait and it's fitting for white people who think "Oh, this seems different than regular Chinese food, hence it must be good." Eh, it's all yours!
author: Perry S.

description:
Let me start by saying that the food was great. I got the Mongolian string beans and my friend ordered the pork belly. Both of us were blown away by the flavor, and especially by the balanced spiciness: the food was really spicy, but the spice was just part of the flavor; it didn't take over the experience.

As for the rest of the experience, there was a lot left to be desired. They had terrible music blasting for what would have been the entire time had the power not kept going out. It was like being at some awful hipster dance party with worse music and eating instead of dancing. They were slow to bring us water when we sat down and slow to take our order. When we finished, there was no "Would you like another round of beers and a look at the menu?" They just dropped the check on the table with a perfunctory thank-you and that was that.

Like I said, I really enjoyed the food, but the atmosphere and service were deal breakers.
author: Charles P.

description:
A random Chinese place in the middle of Mission. Heard lots of great things, but was a bit disappointed by the service.

The food was good! Don't be deceived by the non-asian wait staff haha! It tasted very authentic, almost like my mom's cooking or like when I was in Asia. 

The only thing was that we already waited a long time for our food, and then they forgot our Mapo Tofu, so we had to wait an extra 30+ minutes for them to make it. I liked that it's SUPER (painfully) spicy, but considering we already finished the rice, none of us could eat the dish.

The bathroom was an adventure in itself, but it was interesting to see the insides of the kitchen. If I'm ever in the area and have a lot of time to kill, I may come here again!
author: Jess C.

description:
Went here with a few friends recently and it was sort of not what I expected. I don't know if it's authentic or not but whatever they made here was really good.

Decided to do a full up family style tasting (SCORE!).
Tea leave smoked eel, thrice cooked bacon, explosive wings, fried rice with chinese sausage, and a lamb and greens dish. Everything was really good. I have to say though that the smoked eel and the thrice cooked bacon were by far the winners though. Very flavorful and oddly enough with the bacon, it wasn't the bacon that was the reason why it was an awesome dish. It can even be ordered vegi, is how good it is. The explosive wings were an experience to try once, but nothing special. They did happen to achieve a taste that wasn't all heat, but at the same time, it didn't have any flavor either. The unanimous opinion at the table I think was, they are numb tasting. Like that's all my mouth was after ... and tingling.

Sort of a loud spot and cramped but it's the mission so I have sort of gotten used to that. Large dragon light is put overhead stretching across the whole restaurant. I noted the music selection because it was like a throwback to highschool. Da Brat, Ja Rule, The Fugees all loudly playing through the stereo in the back. Not that I didn't like their song selection, but given that we were seated by the stereo, it was a little too loud.

Service was really awesome too. People kept coming by and checking on us. Any request we made they were super friendly while accommodating.
author: Greg G.

description:
How to get a 1 star review in 10 minutes, without having to serve food:


Have it be a cold rainy day.
Have free tables.
Insist on a sign up sheet.
Insist on not seating a party of 2, unless both are there.
Despite having free tables, and no one in line.
Seat a party of one, at one of the empty tables.
Refuse to let the person sit down and order drinks and appetisers while waiting for the rest of his party ( note: there is still no line, and open tables ).
Make the person wait in the rain, while having free tables.
Argue that this clearly is the only fair and just way of doing things.


Why would someone want to put up with this, when there are dozens of
great options within easy walking distance?
author: Max R.

description:
What's the hype? What's the big deal with the high rating on Bon Apetite? This is just an ordinary Chinese restaurant with ordinary bad service, crowded unclean surroundings,  and overly salty food. If I were to ever go back there (and I am really not sure I would ever), I would just get the rice porridge. That was the best thing. Stay away from the chicken wings. They were NOT spicy hot like it says and you might as well just take a tablespoon of salt and pour that in your mouth and call it their chicken wings. 
Very disappointing indeed.
author: Paula L.

description:
First impressions: what the.........where did I just walk into. Untouched chinese restaurant setting from at least 20 years ago, dim lighting, with biggie playing in the background. This is some unique experience to say the least, haha. Ambiance is a little tough to adjust to, but has an overall charm to it.

Then, the food came, damn those are pretty big portions--will def have some leftovers for lunch the next day right?

Wrong. Food was so freakin delicious that two of us killed 3 entrees. The flavor combos were amazing.
