1) Salt Cod Fried Rice. Salted fish grid rice is one of my ultimate have chinese dishes and this was pretty damn good. Not very greasy, but really flavorful--just wish there was more salty fish

2) Thrice Cooked Bacon. Oh yes...tasted like homemade "lahp yook" but smokier. Loved the chewy rice cakes, tofu skin, bitter melon....interesting mix i'd never think to throw together yet I could see my mom making at home.

3) Cumin Spiced Lamb Belly. LAMB BELLY. I am a fan of belly anything, so I may be kinda biased. But this was awesome. Super tender, but crispy on the outside. 

I'm really impressed by Mission Chinese! I appreciate how its def got some homecooked-style with their own little twists.

PS. I only had to wait ~ 5 mins on a Monday night.
author: Jessica h.

description:
I put off eating here for a long time because I did not want to deal with crowds.  I decided to go for lunch on a Monday and arrived when they opened.  No crowds.  I thoroughly agree with Madison W.'s 11/24/12 review.  The food is really solid.  I think the prices are more than fair for what you get.  I don't understand people's criticism about price.  Comparing MCF to a regular cheap Chinese place on price is comparing apples and oranges.  Like maybe a bruised red delicious to an in season mandarin.  

The thrice cooked bacon was a star because of the chewy rice cakes.  Awesome.  The other star for us was the cod fried rice.  The texture of the rice is outstanding.  I also really liked the cat fish soup.  I was disappointed with the cumin lamb.  The lamb was cooked really well, but the cumin strength was a bit much for me.  I knew that from reviews going in and I ordered it anyway.  I view that as my error.  On heat level, nothing was overwhelmingly hot.  I thought things could have been more hot and will negotiate on my next visit.

Dishes like the ma po tofu are really salty, but who cares.  Eat more cod fried rice and drink some beer.
author: Amber B.

description:
If you are looking for Chinese with a twist this is the spot for you. Non traditional dishes which are delicious and pack a punch if heat. 

If you are sick of different Chinese places that basically taste the same come here. Even if you aren't I highly recommend checking mission Chinese out.
author: Ryan J.

description: Chinese food but elevated and with a twist, is how I would sum up Mission Chinese Food. Came here last night with some friends, we all shared the Tea Smoked Eel, Cumin Lamb Ribs and Egg-Egg Noodle. Everything was super delish and the flavor profiles were insane. We were seated pretty fast and the service was great. The only negatives are that it was a little to dark and I didn't like having to walk through the kitchen to use the restroom and having to stand next to the trash while waiting.
author: Natalie B.

description:
just under 4
yes, seated right away every time i've been.. no long lines for this girl..

ordered:
-beer brined sichuan pickles: chinese cabbage, cucumbers, peanuts, chili oil, szechuan pepper

-tiki pork belly: soy caramel, mandarin orange, pickled pineapple, shaved coconut, macadamia nuts.. still love pork belly.. a fav

-chongqing chicken wings: chili, crispy beef tripe.. holy moly, hurts so good. not only spicy that your mouth is tingly and numb but my tongue started tingling too! sickeningly addictive to the burn..

-mapo tofu: braised shitake, aged chili paste

-kung pao pastrami: peanuts, celery, potatoes, chili

-thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes:sweet tofu skin, bitter melon, szechuan pepper

-salt cod fried rice:mackerel confit, chinese sausage.. one of my fav dishes

-mongolian long beans: slightly overcooked.. i like my long beans crunchier


side notes:
-if you're here expecting authentic chinese food you'll be disappointed, what they do here are interesting takes on dishes.. so be open minded!
-danny opened mission cantina in nyc so check it out.. and hopefully their mcf ny will reopen too
-with nearby hi lo bbq closing in the next few months I wonder where mcf will get their meat smoked
author: Raquel T.

description:
Damn. This place was way too hyped up. And McSweeney's book to go along with it?  I knew what I expected, but I just wasn't sure if the reality could live up to the fantasy.

I was blown away. 

This restaurant represents the new wave of chefs and eateries. Non-elitist, unpretentious, reasonable, but exciting food. It's American. It's American in the way that most of us are first generation half-somethings and ______ American. It's about taking what we've learned from our parents, who speak broken English, and adding our own twist, brining a fresh perspective, trying to recreate comfort food from our fondest memories.

We got the Pork Belly, the Beef Cheek, the Pig Ear Terrine, and the Rice Porridge. Each bite was tasty and unique, while still maintaining a familiarity of Chinese food. It felt luxurious and exciting, without the fuss and obnoxious price.

I thought about living in the City for the first year I moved to SF. Cold, lonely, still without many friends, ordering up chinese food and taking it to my first apartment. It was that moment of my first bite, the nourishment, the realization that there was a lot to look forward to. 

Dramatic? Definitely. I don't care.

The Beef Cheek was extraordinary. A meal I will always remember.

Well worth the wait.
author: Josh P.

description: Who knew you could mix pastrami and chinese food..... This place is awesome!
author: Marc S.

description:
My boyfriend has read about this place and received a couple recommendations to try Mission Chinese, so we decided to feast here for lunch. A little too much hype. I know this place is supposed to be a twist on traditional Chinese food-- I get the irony of the typical sit-down Chinese restaurant, but the food served is actually more modern and twists what people usually expect from Chinese food. The thing is, the food isn't executed well enough to pull the whole thing off, IMO.

First off, the only impressive dish that we tried was the Savory Egg Custard. This was more like cold broth, uni, & cooked egg whites; not an actual custard. It was good & very different, but I felt like there was something missing from it to really make the uni stand out. I would order this again solely based on the fact that I haven't seen a dish like this anywhere else. 

Slow-cooked Char Siu Pork Belly- I grew up on Chinese pork belly stews (you know, the kind that looks like the meat has been dyed by broth & soy sauce) so I know what to expect from the texture of "slow-cooked" pork belly. This was not slow-cooked, it was deep fried. Biting into the meat, it still smelled a little unclean (the way that fresh pork smells at a butcher shop.) The soy-cured egg was incredibly salty and after eating the noodles with hoisin sauce, the egg seemed ten times saltier. I expected a lot from this dish and I was rooting for it, but overall, the preparation just wasn't appetizing. Not a great combo. 

Ma Po Tofu- I knew this was going to be spicy, but it seemed less creative & overpriced when I saw that Sriracha was drizzled on top of the dish. I don't think I could taste the flavor of the pork or sauce because all I ever got in each bite were HUGE pieces of different spices. It felt like I was eating tree bark and wood chips with tofu. There was too much star anise and the whole thing tasted like black licorice to me. 

I would be open to returning here and trying other dishes, but only with a group of 4-5 people because it'd be better to share these overpriced items.
author: Janette H.

description: Loved the forbidden rice and mongolian long beans. Would definitely order both again.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I've never ever had a bad food experience in San Francisco that's why I was extremely and beyond disappointed with my experience here. It was around 9:30pm on a Sunday night and my friend was craving Chinese. Since we were in the area, Mission Chinese was the only restaurant that could accommodate us at this late time frame. The menu lacked excitement and "ooohhs and "aaaahs" so I decided to go for something familiar with MCF's twist. I ordered the Hainam Chicken Rice and my friend ordered the Open faced "Chinese BBQ" Sandwich. Yes, I gave my friend a funny look for ordering that granted he wanted Chinese food.

So the rice, it had more damn peanuts in there than chicken and it was waaay too salty. My friend's meal was just unappetizing. It looked great when it came to our table but the taste was just BAD!! There was nothing Chinese about this dish. I thought the "Chinese BBQ" implied that the flavor would be like the meat in char siu bao. This was straight up American style BBQ done badly!! My friend had maybe 2 big slices of the meat and ate my salty rice with it. 

This dining experience is definitely regrettable and I don't understand the hype. Never ever coming back here again.
author: Somera R.

description:
I came back here again, and ordered the same 3 dishes that I did from my first visit.
-- kung pao pastrami  
-- cod fried rice
-- ma po tofu

The ma po tofu though was horrific.  It was like a completely different dish had been served to me.  This one was a lot more watery and bland - the only flavor was the overpowering spice of peppercorns.

The saving grace was the kung pao pastrami, which I had been lusting after since last time.  It didn't fail me.  It's the only thing keeping the review of this restaurant at 4 stars instead of 3 stars.

FYI:  Ordering 3 dishes for 3 people is overkill.  I have enough leftovers for a couple days.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
I was expecting and I was hoping for crazy hot and spicy food. what i got was good tasting food with some heat which is a very fair trade off. I had the string beans and the tofu and enjoyed the 80s music pumped in for dining enjoyment.
This place is a bit too hip too be honest, typically I like my Chinese food to be served by regular people not hot chicks with piercings and tattoos. Actually . . . that's not really true as much as it is a weird thing to say.
There was a bout a ten minute wait at 6:30PM on a Wednesday, so it's not always a pain in the ass to get a seat.
I would come back here again and I would order the same meal. I would also like to try some of the other items as well.
author: Alexander R.

description:
I used to love this place, but the last time I ordered delivery from them the cumin lamb was so charred that it felt like I was eating a pile of charcoal. The quality is normally amazing.

I want that $25 back :P
author: Jason H.

description:
Sorry, folks - but a glowing New York Times review can't make Chinese food good in the Mission. Jesus probably couldn't pull that off either.

A year ago when this pop-up first opened (pretty sure we can't even call it a pop-up anymore at this point), this would occasionally be a spot for picking up some mediocre Chinese food after a night of heavy drinking. It was "take-what-you-can-get-in-the-Mission, faux-Chinese food," and it's still that way today, only with a long wait and pushy waitresses who insist on taking your plate away when you clearly aren't finished eating your food yet. This place was just OK before, and now the undeserved hipster hype has made it even worse.
author: Brian C.

description:
So, the food is really good. Like, really good. It's interesting and unlike anything you can get anywhere else. The thrice cooked bacon (veggie option...I don't really understand it either) is incredible, and the bites I've had from other people's dishes are always really good.

My issue is that it's kind of not fun to eat here. There's almost always a wait, the service is weak just because they're always so busy and they don't have time to check on you. The food is really spicy so the lack of water can sometimes be an issue for a white boy like myself. 

Mostly, though, it's really overcrowded and you're often sharing a table that should probably be used for two people, not four. The music is usually loud which, coupled with your neighbors' conversation which is around five inches from your ear, makes it difficult to hold a conversation.

If you're going out to stuff your face rather than have a conversation, this place is totally acceptable. Otherwise, maybe find somewhere else.
author: Justin S.

description:
Parking in the mission is a fail, but we got lucky and found a spot that was literally right across the street. The wait to Mission Chinese is typically a fail as well - we waited just over an hour on a random Sunday. The food, is amazing!

If you're looking for authentic Chinese food, this is not the place. It's more of a Chinese-American fusion, but it's DELICIOUS! If you can't handle spicy food, then don't order anything that's spicy - I didn't find it to be *that* spicy, but some of the people in our group kept getting their water refilled, hah.

Mongolian Long Beans were good, so was the Sizzling Cumin Lamb. My favorite would have to be the Kung Pao Pastrami. My least favorite were probably the chicken wings.
author: Sami A.

description: I thought this place was pretty damn good. Unlike some reviews suggest, the service here is super friendly and professional. I never felt rushed at all. The food is inventive and tasty. It's not the San Gabriel Valley, but for a spot in the middle of the city, it does the trick.
author: Brent A.

description:
This place does not serve chinese food.  Again, this is NOT chinese food.  Rather, it's something more like chinese inspired hipster food. What is hipster food?  Things like bacon or salted caramel ice cream from bi-rite.  You know.. regular food that is for someone reason become increasingly popular and "hip" or "cool" to be eating. You know.. the kind of food you wait in line for. 

And in that category, Mission Chinese does not disappoint.  Sea urhcin? Broiled Lamb? Pork belly and huge slices of bacon? Yes, please, and well executed, I will add.  No, it's nothing fancy but it is high quality ingredients presented in a unique way with HUGE flavor-- and that's where this place gets 5 stars. (in addition to the decor and ambiance which I will get to..)  All of the dishes I had here from the salt cod fried rice and ma po tofu to the bacon chow mein and the sea urchin appetizer everything had amazing flavor.  Just packed to brim, completely mind- numbing spice and flavor.  You want spicy? you'll get spicy. Oh, and did I mention most of the giant portions are only 10-13 bucks?  Yeah. Hella worth it.  These people know how to cook, I don't care what genre of food this is.  P.s. they offer vegetarion versions for a lot of the dishes.

The ambience: more hipsters.  Hipsters are half the reason I hate and love the mission.  Fun to watch, fun to hate on, annoying to be around constantly.  Luckily the dubstep/hip-hop/pop that is BLASTING from the speakers makes this place feel like a club pre-game, and I love it.  It adds a level of excitement and fun that no other restauarant is brave enough to do.

The decor: dim lights, red lights, and a giant dragon - I'm assuming this is a current decoration in honor of the year.  Oh, and it's half way to a sauna-- super steamy inside.  I will admit this kinda grosses me out at first but after waiting an hour  you're begging to get into that sweaty mess.

And yes, I did wait an hour, and yes it was on a Tuesday Night.  And yes, it was worth it.  I cannot wait to go back, and even weeks after this meal I am still salivating.  Believe the hype.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The food was pretty good. Possibly over hyped and not worth the price, but we still enjoyed ourselves. 

The server sort of made us feel bad for wanting to move off a shared table to a private table. We were by the door and there were three open tables around us, so we didn't see why she was discouraging the move. So one star for that and another off for the price not exactly reflecting the quality of food.

Also, the wait can be long and it's just a list and you wait on the sidewalk, FYI.
author: Allison H.

description:
I have heard such mixed review of this place, particularly from my fellow Chinese Americans, that I came here with lowered expectations (madtv reference ha) and hesitation. Boy was I pleasantly surprised.

The menu at first glance appears honestly odd, my significant other and I were feeling adventurous. We tried the following 4 dishes:

- Chilled Buckwheat Noodles - delicious, but because I don't like parsley this was my least favorite dish of the day. 
- Savory Egg Custard - an absolute revelation and a 5-star favorite - it's a steamed egg with big bites of sea urchin, trout roe etc, and it was an interesting mix of flavors and textures, and it has a refreshing feel, much like a gazpacho. It's worth the trip just for this dish (but that's maybe because I love uni so much)
- Lamb Face Noodle Soup - delicious and just the right amount of spicy. The lamb definitely smells a little gamey. My question was how do people tell regular lamb and lamb face apart. We certainly couldn't. It just felt a little gimmicky. 
- Smoked Beef Brisket Soup Noodles - the brisket (I think) is smoked American style. It definitely has a southern feel/smell to it. That's the main thing that made the dish an interesting fusion, coz it's definitely no ordinary beef noodle soup that you can get at any other regular Chinese restaurant.

This is definitely a hole-in-the-wall, questionable decor kind of place. Personally I find that charming and an good indication that the chef's focus is on the food on the plate, not how pretty the place looks. Having said that, dirty windows, dead flies, strange decor like plastic piranhas and antique Paris maps might give you pause.

Parking is supposed to be difficult. You're in San Francisco.
author: Timothy I.

description:
Wow. Just wow. Thrice cooked bacon. Red Braised Pork Belly. Ma Pa Tofu. Chongquing Chicken Wings.

Spicy, flavorful, relatively fast, and waiter was very responsive and quick to react. Just Wow.
author: Kevin T.

description: FIve stars for the food but one less star for the ambience (sticky tables, ratty carpeting).  The food was excellent and flavorful and the portions were family-sized.  We had the tea smoked eel, beef noodles, tofu and spicy chicken wings with tripe.  Wish this restaurant was in a less sketchy location.
author: Coco B.

description:
This is the only Chinese food restaurant I've ever eaten in that has played (loudly!) Nirvana. The music was as unusual (relatively speaking) as their dishes. Unfortunately most of the food didn't appeal to me, but it was very original. I got the Mongolian Long Beans, which were labeled as double spicy (2 peppers). They were the perfect amount of very spicy: very hot but not burning my mouth uncomfortably. (I like food fairly hot too, but not habañero hot.) They were good and flavorful and thankfully cut into bite-size pieces.. I've never seen anything close to anything on the menu in any other Chinese food restaurant, so if you're looking for some adventure, check it out. 

I would have given this more stars, except hardly any of the food appealed to me. 

Atmosphere was great, but as noted, a little loud.
author: Kevin B.

description:
GOOD LORD! I'm so over this place. I've tried it twice--a valiant effort to try to like it!! No way was I going to give it a third chance. The first time I had the Ma Po Tofu, the Kung Pao Pastrami, and the Sizzling Cumin Lamb. The ma po tofu was not spicy whatsoever and they use too much star anise or chinese five spice. Something in the seasoning was weird--I can see why people could like how sweet it was, but this wasn't a good interpretation of what ma po tofu is suppose to be for me. The Pastrami was forgettable. I liked the idea of it, but really, it was salty and heavy without any redeeming taste and also not spicy whatsoever. I don't know who has control of the spices in the back there, but they must not have a good gauge as to what spicy is...

The second time I visited, I tried the ma po tofu again after talking to a friend who said she liked the use of the spices, but ughhh I still did not like it. So there's twice!! that I tried, but still just couldn't stomach the weird combination. I also tried the Broccoli Beef Cheek and again, forgettable for me. I really can't even comment on it because i've forgotten it, which is sometimes worse than disliking it for an overt reason.
author: Victoria J.

description:
There is a VERY long wait. 

We were the only Asians there ...  that usually tells me "DO NOT EAT HERE" .. .but against my better judgement ... I decided to give a try.   

Everything was salty, overly spiced and greasy.  Now I can handle spicy ... but I think Henry Hunan's is still, BY FAR, the winner.  Another common theme throughout all the dishes we ate ...  overpowering smokiness!  Perhaps too much liquid smoke?  Twas not pleasant.  

The chef, however, gets an "A" for trying to create a fusion Chinese joint, hence the 1 star.  The portions are huge and the price tag is not.  So it is a really good deal.  They did have some  cool beer options as well.

Maybe if the restaurant's name had something other than "Chinese" in it ... I would have had a different reaction?  Not sure ... but I will not be dining here ever again.  Just not my cup of tea.
author: Mihae T.

description:
If your street cred runneth low, come to Mission Chinese Food to refuel.

MCF is quite the scene, but it's the best tasting scene ever. Who knew that scene could taste so good? Super spicy scene. Mmm. Toto, we're not in Lung Shan anymore. 

I didn't mind the wait. I'm a very patient person. A less patient person might get verklempt and/or irate. That's not necessary. Don't stray too far if you do wait. Much like medicine, prognoses about time are wrong. 

We sat down soon enough. What a cramped restaurant! So many more seats than when it was Mission Street Food. More opportunity to eat and see and been seen in the scene. Maybe they wanted it to be like a Shanghai subway? So crowded, but I liked it. Lots of cute boys in plaid and pretty girls in pastels. Pastels must be coming back into style. Note to self.

The food is wonderful. Spicy! When I was twelve I swallowed some crazy peppers in the International District in Seattle and I've been somewhat of a jock since, trying to outdo my personal best. Good amount of spice here, especially on the chicken wings which are dry rubbed in five spice. Yum. Not for chapped lips after a long hike, another note to self. Ma po tofu was my favorite dish, made with kurobota pork and sichuan peppers. The tingly lamb soup with shanghai noodles was my other favorite. Can I have two favorites? The menu said that the lamb broth was numbing. Not so, but it was a really interesting flavor that I can't place. My friends loved the thrice cooked bacon with rice cakes. Can't have three favorites, can I? Definitely not in Lung Shan anymore. My friend's boyfriend called him during dinner and asked him to order a General Tso's for him, to which Nicho responded, "I don't think they have that here." No General Tso, but there is Kung Pao with "explosive chili". I must try this chili. 

It's so loud inside because of all the pretty people laughing and Dr. Dre rapping about having bbqs everyday and driving fancy cars. We weren't really using our words, so the sound was okay. Occasional grunts and lapping up water, and some pointing, nodding, and smiling.

Words are a hindrance. Just go and taste for yourself. And please save a seat for me.
author: Joanna M.

description:
So excited to have finally try this place. This resturant is inside of another restaurant. The wait wasn't too bad. Got here around 6:15 and waited for 10 mins.

Tiger Salad-my least favorite dish. The rolls were huge, but the lettece was bitter

Ma Po Tofu-Super spicy, but goes well with the rice

Salt cod fried rice-comes with chinese sasuage. Loved this dish. Stir fried to perfection. YUMMY!

Thrice Cooked Bacon-Rice cakes...oh so yummy. Excellent flavor with a touch a spicyness.

Slow cooked pork belly-Tender and flavorful, but the pineapples that came with it is kind of random.

I don't like how they play super loud rap music. It's already noisy enough in the restaurant and to add the rap music on top of it is even worse.
author: Karen H.

description:
Went at 5pm on a Tuesday so there was no wait.

They were playing a remix album of old Wu-Tang songs and it was louder than you'd usually hear at a restaurant.  I was ok with that.  The ambiance and restaurant is definitely no frills and dark and maybe a little dirty.  I was ok with that too.

Ordered the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts to start.  Pretty good.  The peanuts had the skin still on them which I like.  Nothing too crazy though - it is what it sounds like.  A small bowl of peanuts with vinegar and some anise seeds.

Thrice Cooked Bacon.  Not a huge fan but then again I don't like smoked meats too much.  Strong smokey flavor.  The gummy rice cakes were good.

Sizzling Cumin Lamb.  Thought it was pretty well done.  I think they were short ribs (?) and the taste and consistency was excellent.  They were a bit fatty but I don't necessarily think that's a bad thing.

One note: they don't bring out any rice by default and we didn't ask for any so not sure what the deal is there.

I would return and try some of the other dishes.  

Solid.  Interesting.
author: Michael S.

description:
For such a hyped-up restaurant, Mission Chinese was rather disappointing. Perhaps all the press I had heard about the place made my expectations too high, or perhaps it was due to the limited selections they have for vegetarians. In any case, though, the food was decent but not amazing, the service was lackluster, and the experience was certainly nothing to write home about.

Mission Chinese is buried in the heart of the Mission district, looking just like a typical "hole in the wall" place. A group of five of us came for Sunday lunch; we were prepared to wait for a little bit (given all that we had heard), but were pleasantly surprised that the place wasn't too busy, even at the noon hour. The layout and decor inside is somewhat tacky and kitsch - think cheap plastic tables and chairs crammed together, with random ornaments - a huge paper dragon, for example - hanging from the wall.

Service was pretty spotty from the beginning. I noticed on their menu, too, that some of the dishes were noted as "vegetarian option available". When I inquired to our waitress what exactly the vegetarian "thrice cooked bacon" entailed - a perfectly reasonable question, in my opinion, given the title of the dish! - she brusquely told me to read the description in the menu: "description provided in the menu" was her entire response. If I had been known what the vegetarian option of the dish was based on the description, I wouldn't have asked her in the first place!

As it turns out, the vegetarian version of the dish is basically cooked rice cakes mixed with bitter melon, other vegetables, and chilis. The dish itself was actually pretty decent; I enjoyed the rice cakes, which were sticky and flavorful. The other members of our table ordered a couple of the meat dishes, and also reported similar results - each of the dishes were decent, but they said none of them was particularly great or amazing.

I would have considered giving Mission Chinese four stars, but the poor service and atmosphere knock it down to three stars. Tl;dr version: decent food, lackluster decor and service, and certainly overhyped.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
I've eaten here three times.  The first time I would have given as a four star experience - good food, decent service, and mellow atmosphere.  The second time was a solid three star - the food was not as good and the service was still ok and the atmosphere was still mellow.  

This last experience is definitely a two star. My boyfriend's sister came to town and we talked about this Chinese place in our neighborhood that had gotten rave reviews.  Then she and I go there - we order two things to split, I order a tea and she orders a Mexican coke.  I got my tea somewhat fast and then after a somewhat long wait, our first dish.  Our out of town visitor reminds the somewhat ditzy acting waitress about her coke that she had ordered, which she brought over about five minutes later.  After about fifteen or twenty minutes after finishing our first dish, the waitress came over to prove it wasn't just an act.

"Here's your check!"

"Um... we never got our second dish."

"Do you want me to take it off the check then?"

"No, we love paying for food we don't eat...."

Really, service this bad should get two stars just for the humor.  

And the food this visit was only about a star.  Not super imaginative - more like what my Asian friends cooked up in college before they got tired of eating the same thing every night and bought a cookbook.
author: Jana T.

description: I guess this is a restaurant with an identity crisis. Is it Americanized Chinese or Chinezed American? Whatever it is, the food is just pretty weird. Not bad though. But weird, just weird. Very, very, very slow and distracted staff. Might try again some time.
author: Karlijn V.

description:
Had I seen what the bathroom looked like before I ordered I would have gone someplace else. It was totally trashed like a nasty gas station in the middle of nowhere.  This is the same bathroom where the kitchen staff  washes up.  I'd need to wash up after using that bathroom. I tossed my takeout container once we got outside.
The food itself was okay- We ordered 3 dishes the Kung Pao pastrami, greasy - Some noodle starter - no flavor. And a chicken rice dish.  I thought  it was just rice but my friend pointed out there were a few tic tac size pieces of chicken in it. Also it's very loud. If you like screamers and bring your own purell.. Give it a shot.
author: Marga G.

description: Their most famous dish is the salted cod fish fried rice but it wasn't even good. I've had better in So-cal.  The other dish I ordered was the kung pao pastrami.  It tasted like the thanksgiving ham that people buy, just in cube form and some celery and peanuts.
author: Danny N.

description:
I find Mission Chinese to be a "must try" restaurant when visiting San Francisco.  It truly reflects what the 2011 San Francisco hipster strata is all about:  a creative, aloof, innovative, young, third world, fast-paced, laid-back melange of California urban culture mated with really good food.

This is not your grandmother's Chinese restaurant.  You see sesame seeds actually used here to add taste rather than texture.  I've been here twice with my husband, who loves spicy Chinese food.  I don't.  

He had the most provocative thing he saw on the menu, Kung Pao Pastrami.  Both of us thought it was really good.  But there's no way I could have eaten even a quarter of the whole dish because it was so spicy.  And you can't pick out the spices, either. They're everywhere mixed in with those aforementioned sesame seeds.  If you love spicy, it's definitely worth a try.

That same evening, I ordered the Salt Cod Fried Rice.  It was really tasty, and a large enough portion for three or four, but I wouldn't want to make a whole meal out of it.  The salt cod was perfectly prepared, moist and not overcooked.  The rice was flecked with lots of green onion and probably cilantro, and onions, I think.

But neither one of these dishes alone really makes a meal.  The pastrami came with a bowl of rice, but still the meal was off balance, not enough greens.  So to try to balance it, I ordered the Dan Dan Noodles.  Cool, cucumbers, peanut sauce, greens, etc.  But labeled as a 'small plate', it was still too large to match with the other dishes without having a slough of leftovers.

Unfortunately, we got no guidance from our server.  She was barely interested in our presence at the table.  She didn't seem to be too interested in anything, so it wasn't like she was distracted.

I find it interesting that the so-called "hipsters" who love to slam a restaurant for poor customer service and bad food (see previous reviews below) are also from the very same ilk who provide it.  Maybe it's a generational thing.  But the service at Mission Chinese is cold and nonchalant at best.  This is something (social skills) they need to work on instead of their tattoos.

Our second visit garnered a better result for me.  Husband again ordered the pastrami.   I ordered the 'small plate' fried pork belly with noodles and cucumbers.  I thought it had all the elements I was looking for in the description.  But this time, the server cautioned me that this was more of an appetizer and that I might find it wanting more.  So taking her advice I ordered a 'small plate' Hainam Chicken Fried Rice.  It came first.

It was good, but again, it wasn't a meal.  Bits of chicken mixed with fried rice, a bit of chicken fat for flavor and some vinegar to cut the greasy feeling.  I'd order it again, but I was anticipating the pork belly appetizer.  

This is where I should have started.  It was remarkably good.  The pork belly was fried to the point of caramelization on the outside and it was like butter on the inside.  Eye-rollingly good.  It came resting upon some wide rice noodles rolled up with cilantro and scallions, a few pickled cucumber slices, a soy cured 'soft boiled' egg and hoisin sauce.  Yum!  This was everything I was looking for and I would have been very satisfied (and had more change in my pocket) if I had ordered only this.

Both times, I topped it off with their Ginger Beer from Australia.  I love it.

If you're feeling adventurous, make sure you take a trip to the restroom at the back of the restaurant.  You get to walk through the food staging area, see huge cuts of barbecued beef, lamb, pork prepared expertly, workers checking their iPads for orders and reviews (I surmise) and finally arrive at an adequately clean (for a very busy small restaurant) out the back by the dumpsters, where the air is amazingly refreshing.

This place could certainly benefit from a nicer piece of real estate, but I think that would somehow cheapen the whole experience.  This is raw San Francisco - heart of the Mission District, heart of the economic crisis from which it sprang (good out of work cooks looking for a cheap way to ply their wares) and really innovative food.  Be sure to check out the beer cans resting in the jaws of the giant dragon suspended from the ceiling.  

Oh yeah, and if you're in a hurry, tell them you're willing to share the big table at the back.  Just be prepared to experience the loud rap and hip hop music emanating from the ghetto buster iPod in the back.  Remember, this is not your grandmother's Chinese restaurant.  '-)
author: Marty R.

description:
We went for lunch and go there at 11:30 right when it opened. The restaurant filed up in about 30 minutes. 

Corn and Peppers were out of this world. Charred, smokey, spicy with corn's sweetness. 

Rib tips? an order-in item. Great flavor and the meat was just falling apart.

Tasty! Yeah it's run down looking and service isn't too fast. Just a place where the food is the main attraction.
author: Phil L.

description: Hit or miss, and when they miss it's the worst, most inedible thing. My last meal was gross.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Either the most "Unusual" Chinese, or the most "Authentic" Chinese food found in San Francisco, I can't really tell - haven't spent enough time in China to know for sure.

This little pop-up has received instant stardom, and for the most part, earns it's reputation - but I must admit I have some struggles with this place.

For the Great:

1. The food is very unusual, and you won't find it anywhere else;
2. The food is clearly made from the freshest of ingredients, and the menu is as eclectic as it is interesting.
3. The "Lamb Meatball" became one of my favorite dishes!

For the Meza-Meza:

1. The Lamb Meatball, along with some of my other favorites, have been removed from the menu.
2. Some of the staff members, one in particular, just NEVER SMILES, and it's never fun to be around someone who always appears to be in a perpetual bad mood, but this is countered by another waiter, who just NEVER stops smiling.  We always try to have him serve us!

For the "Not-so-Great":
1. The place is in dyer need of a complete makeover.  The atmosphere couldn't be more mundane mid 70s dive bar, with it's drop-ceiling and tired banquet hall/church basement type chairs.  It's not a place you'd bring a first date, or it could quickly turn into your last before entering the premises.

2. You couldn't get another table or chair stuffed in the place.  It's cramped beyond what I suspect is their 'legal' capacity for fire purposes.

3. Don't use the facilities while there, sort of like a gas-station bathroom you'd expect to find on Rte 66 in some backwater Texas town.

But with all of my needless and whiny complaints, and disappointing observations, the FOOD still makes the experience positive, and I'm most likely going to be returning within the next week or two, for my 5th or 6th visit, before they remove that yummy veal dish they've been sporting on the menu for the past several weeks.

PS:  Arrive early (like 5:30pm early) to avoid the LONG LINE that you'll see when you're exiting the place!
author: Jeff G.

description:
Finally succumbed to the hype and made my way here last week.  After all the rave reviews, I can't really say I was impressed.  

Strike 1: No dumplings

Food
1) Chicken Wings - jeeezus this was spicy.  They went nuclear with the white pepper.
2) Kung Pao Pastrami - Pastrami served in a sea of red pepper.  Different and tasty once you could find the minuscule amount of meat in the dish.
3) Cumin Lamb - Not a typical Chinese spice and tasted like something I could get at a local IndoPak restaurant, except not as good.

The food that we did get was 'unique' but not in the way that is awe inspiring. It was overwhelmingly spicy, a tad over-cooked, and not up to my standards.  

My bottom line:
All in all - like many places in SF - over-hyped.
author: Aasim K.

description:
I don't like being a hater, but I feel compelled to write a review so other people don't end up at this restaurant misguided by all the hype.

The food was at the best mediocre, the service was decidedly unfriendly, the atmosphere dingy and the bill felt like too much for the experience.

I like dive places, but one of the best thing about them is that they are not pretentious, in general.  

Mission Chinese Food is pretentious and doesn't deliver on it.  My two cents.
author: vanessa s.

description:
Definitely disappointing.  I was excited for Mission Chinese because I thought I was going to get eat some interesting, different Asian food + get to listen my hipster music at the same time. 

This was...just well...bad.

I am definitely not a picky eater. While I die for authentic Chinese food...I enjoy non-authentic stuff too. We had the pickles which weren't really quite pickled. Didn't really pack any punch. The peanut was good though. The Ma Po Tofu was just ordinary and the Beef Cheek just a hair better. Ma Po Tofu was just boring other than it being fairly spicy. Beef Cheek was ultra breaded so kinda lacking in the meat department. Rice is a MUST. Everything is pretty salty. 

Waitress was nice and friendly. I would try some other menu items just because I'm curious.
author: Dian X.

description: If I could give it 0 stars I would. By far the worst service and "Chinese food I've ever had. We ordered the beef and broccoli which was covered by sauce and salt so you couldn't even taste what you were eating. The lamb ribs were just lamb fat and nobody in our party could really stomach them. The breakfast fried rice was the best thing we ordered, but still highly oversalted and without much flavor. After last night all 3 of us decided we will never come again. By the way it took the host asking our drink order after 20 minutes to get our drink order in and that was for warm water and beer.
author: Dragana B.

description:
Sea urchin, toe, custard, shiso ... oxtail crab egg porridge ... pig snout radish eye of newt pepper alien rump ....all ruined by too much spice and salt.

All 4 of the dishes I had come with either too much salt, too much cumin, too much hot spice, or all of the above. AND - afterwards I got a headache and ringing in the ears and a kind of dissociative feeling ... I've never had an allergic reaction to MSG before but I think judging from the savoriness of the food and assuming they are as over the top w/ MSG as salt and spice, that I actually had my first ever MSG allergic reaction. They really need to include MSG - a known allergen - as an ingredient. Not cool.

Very disappointing; I was ready to like something so eclectic and potentially flavorful. Occasionally in the pile of flaming salty heat I'd taste something wonderful, like the pork cheek nuggets in the mussels dish, otherwise way over salted. I love very spicy, but when it's so spicy it starts to inflame your cheeks nose and tongue you lose the ability to really taste anything, everything is too inflamed, so it's just monodimensional taste, you only taste spice and feel mouth puckering from salt, it ruins the food, it sort of "tastes" the same as say a college contest over wings and hot sauce.
author: David A.

description: This place had cool atmosphere. I really liked the vibe.  The wait was 20 minutes or so on a Tuesday night. I was excited to try this place as Ive heard a lot about it in the media.  I was underwhelmed.  I've had better modern Chinese food.  3 out of the 4 dishes we ordered were Too spicy...I don't mind spicy food but when spicy was the dominating flavor with little else to counterbalance it.  The best dish we had was the salt cod fried rice.  That was delicious and an interesting spin!
author: Linda R.

description:
* very old dive restaurant  
*very over priced for simple Chinese food 
* wait service lousy attitude
*not worth the wait to get in
author: charlie s.

description: Ummm. An Americanized take on already-Americanized Chinese food? While staffed by hipsters? I'm not sure it works. The squid ink noodles were good, but whatever green beans that we had had a very strange aftertaste. In the end, I'm not sure the experience was worth the wait or the money charged, especially when there are plenty of Americanized Chinese food places around that charge acceptable prices for tasty food.
author: Gleb P.

description:
I went to MCF with the ex as one of the first places we were going to meet post break up. I was primed for trying something new, thus why I had already agreed to go to the Mission. I had just returned, or I was just about to go, to China and was all about Chinese food. Plus, I love spice.

We read all the reviews. 
We ordered the sea urchin custard (gross)
We ordered the thrice cooked bacon. (It was the best thing on the menu- WAIT, the BEER was the best thing)
We ordered the Kung Pau spicy ass thing (It seriously was TOO hot for both of us)

So, our service was fantastic, but I am like in doubt of some of these other reviews. I think these people like to be tortured and really like even more that they can handle what other people can't. That was my take, hipsters taking pleasure in other's misery.
author: Danielle V.

description:
If you want authentic Chinese, this isn't the spot. If you don't mind the lack of authenticity or you're very generous on how you define "Chinese Food", you've come to the right place! Also, be prepared to wait for a table. A table for three on a Tuesday night took over an hour. Total cost per person after tax and tip was about $30.

Here's a recap of our dishes - each dish was big enough to share with a group.

- Westlake Rice Porridge - Pretty tasty and very clean. One order is good enough for 4 people.
- Salt Cod Fried Rice - Soooo good. Delicious! Couldn't get enough.
- Young Mustard Greens - Decent. Nothing to rave about.
- Chinese BBQ Platter - Decent. Seemed like a dish you would find at a soul food or bbq place rather than Chinese restaurant. 
- Slow Cooked Pork Belly - Highlight of the night. Huge pieces of pork belly and very meaty! Too bad it was served last so we were too full to finish. Uh yeah you best believe we packed the rest to go.

Two dishes we really wanted to try but they were out that night - heard both are good but can't recommend on a first hand basis.

- Savory Egg Custard
- Lamb Face Biang Biang Mien
author: Steve O.

description: Great food, great atmosphere, staff were friendly but not overbearing, and it's BYOB.
author: Laura M.

description: Weird Chinese or Chinese fusion food, no idea what to say, but won't visit again.
author: Tian W.

description: Came here today for the first time, absolutely delighted! Ordered the spicy wings and the 3x bacon along with the salt cod fish fried rice. The bacon was the star of the table and would come back for it in a heartbeat. The fried rice was nothing special- small pieces of fish but complimented the other entrees well.
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Well, this is a pretty beat place. Dark, low light, loud edgy music, black-haired waitresses...very beat. This would be the place to come late at night and in beatnik mode. It is not your usual Chinese restaurant by any stretch. 

It's also not easy to find if you don't know what you're looking for. It is in a Chinese restaurant storefront that does not at all say "Mission Chinese." I walked by it twice, only registering that it was the right place by (a) noting that the address across Mission was 2235, and (b) finally seeing a small menu with "Mission Chinese" on it in window.

The food is totally unusual, top to bottom. You will not find the familiar Chinese items here. I picked up to go the 

- Sliced peanut noodles. Pretty good, actually take on a traditional fat noodle dish. Not sure I'd order it again but if you are in the mood for fresh fat noodles with a drizzle of common peanut sauce, go for it

- Chili pickled long beans. Actually, I ordered this but they forgot to put it in the bag. So, I paid for it but didn't get it. I do love long beans though, so I was sad to see it missing. They owe me one.

- Thrice cooked bacon. This was excellent, although my partner complained that the bacon was fatty. I loved it.

- Stir-fried pork jowl and radishes. Also excellent and very unusual. You have to be in the mood for radishes though. (Radishes not clipped or cut at all, but relatively soft)

So, I'm anxious to try it again, although not to-go. Would rather sit inside and enjoy the odd ambiance.
author: Mister K.

description: Holly balls! This place is great! Taking Chinese to a new level! New great take on food! Nom nom nom! Got the squid ink noodles and Kung pao pastrami.
author: Boston J.

description: Let me start off by saying if you are someone who is so concerned about lighting or the arrangement of the tables or parking or any other type of dumb needy customer bullshit DONT GO!!!!! Just don't go, get out of the line and head down to the nearest PF Changs where someone is going to coddle you and try to care that your appetizer came out a little to close to your entree...This place is for people who don't mind going out of there way to experience great food from a great Chef who (here's the best part) is doing everything exactly how he wants to!!! The result, everyone wants a taste. So if any of that interests you GO AND ENJOY ALREADY !!! Embrace the fact that you have to wait in line to have amazing food in the mission. Enjoy the fact that it's untraditional and different. Have an Anchor Steam and an eel roll and sing along to the blaring  90s hip hop!!!! Also please help me in the fight against unexperienced yelpers
author: Deon G.

description:
When my mom told me about this Chinese place she went to in the Mission, I was a little skeptical.  I've grown up eating traditional Cantonese food in the Sunset, Richmond, and Chinatown, so I wondered how good a place in the Mission could be.  

We got to MCF a little after 7:00 pm on a Tuesday night and unbelievably there was a hefty list of people waiting outside.  We put our name down on the list (make sure you check that your party is completely there) and proceeded to wait for 45 minutes for a table.  When the host told me this was actually a slow night, I really couldn't believe it.

When we finally sat down, we ordered the dan dan noodles, the ox tail porridge, spicy chicken wings, pork belly, and ma po tofu.  All of these are dishes I've eaten many times before at other Chinese restaurants so I already had some expectation on what they would taste like.  

The decor of this place is very interesting.  It's a cross between the hole in the wall places you'd find in Chinatown (but cleaner), and the hokey Chinese Restaurant you'd find in Idaho, or somewhere in the Midwest (red lanterns, Christmas lights on the side, a vase of fake roses).  It's a little retro, but I think it definitely fits the Mission.  

Service was pleasant and the food came out fairly quickly.
Here's a quick review of a few of the dishes:

Ox tail Porridge - Definitely our favorite.  It wasn't as thick as your typical porridge, but it had a lot of additional ingredients that made this a very satisfying dish.

Ma Po Tofu - More flavor than you would get at a typical Chinese place.  The cumin powder and the whole pepper kernels gave it a different taste, but I prefer the more traditional version.

Spicy Chicken Wings - It comes buried under a pile of red chili peppers.  The wings by themselves are not too spicy, but they are loaded with seasoning.  If you don't have a beer or drink a gallon of water with these, it'll feel like you've just swallowed a mouthful of salt water! 

With the upbeat oldies playing in the background and the hip vibe of the Mission, it makes for a lively eating atmosphere.  The food definitely tries to be different than the original dishes, but somehow it lacks in the things that made them so good in the first place.  The food I would give 2 stars, but the experience grants MCF a solid 3.
author: Neil W.

description: Ordered 3 dishes and thought the dishes were just okay. It's all too salty and not very authentic. I was disappointed bc I came with high hopes. The restaurant is also very dark during dinner so it's very hard to see what you are eating. Not going back for seconds.
author: H H.

description:
3 stars because food is average and minus 1 because due to over-hype, long wait, and hipsters.

I have tried eating here a couple times (e.g. cod fried rice, won ton soup) before but was never impressed to make this place a worthwhile destination. After reading an article, and hearing about the recent buzz, I decided to give it another try, focusing on new additions on the menu.

I ordered:

Savory egg custard - interesting but won't order it again, too salty; and the slimy custard plus the slimy roe plus the slimy uni make an imbalanced combination with respect to textures. I love slimy and briny food in the right contexts but the combination of these three ingredients did not work for me.

Thrice-cooked bacon - Good stir fry. I would order it again. However, it's not worth the hype. It's like any good stir-fried rice cake dish that one can get at a decent chinese restaurant. I speculate that the hype is due to reviewers who rarely encounter rice cake dishes.

Mouth-watering chicken - average. Might order it again if I'm lazy to make it myself. It's a little too oily/salty for me. I prefer my homemade version with cloud-ear fungus, celery, sichuan peppercorns. I speculate that all the hype is due to reviewers who haven't had the real version or think chicken hearts constitute an innovative ingredient.

Red mustard green - my favorite out of the dishes I have had. Not too oily, well stir-fried. Will order it again. However, it's unlikely I will make this place my destination just because they can stir-fry some Asian veggie well.

In conclusion, average food that is a bit too salty and fatty. Spiciness and flavor in the dish are too one-dimensional. For a place that has this much hype and this long wait, I would expect not only innovative combination (which some dishes do have) but also a delicious spin off from the traditional sichuan cuisine. However, the dishes either do not rise above or fare worse than the traditional dishes. If you just want some good chinese food in the Mission without any wait, go to Heung Yuen. If you want serious Sichuan, Mission is not the right place.
author: pH R.

description:
This place is so dark! I guess it's supposed to make it a cool dining experience since you don't usually eat in a completely dark restaurant, but it's a little uncomfortable at a Chinese restaurant because of what light can reveal about cleanliness. Nonetheless my friends and I enjoyed our Americanized Chinese food. 

Rice cakes with bitter melon & bacon - I really like rice cakes, but the dish was too greasy.

Pork belly - this is the best thing I ate! It was so fatty and tender!

Chicken wings - I didn't like the peppercorn flavor and sensation after taking a few bites, but apparently my friend thought it was very good. The wings were nicely fried, but how about sticking with salt & pepper?

Chow mein - why are the noodles cut short? I didn't enjoy this too much. I'm not a fan of chow mein, but if I would prefer to get it at a Chinese restaurant.
author: Cindy H.

description: This food was pretty much one of the best non-authentic Chinese food I have ever eaten. If you're looking for a little twist on Chinese cooking, this is the first place I would recommend. The thrice-cooked bacon was unbelievable, along with the lamb that just wanted to melt in your mouth. Portions weren't exactly what I was hoping for, but the taste in itself was enough to keep me completely satisfied with this place.
author: Patrick B.

description:
1. szechuan pickles - like good pickled, chili appetizer...taste good. 
2. egg custard - blend of roe, egg, shiso, uni - unique and delicious, very unusual flavors. . 
3. ma po tofu - extremely spicy, so spicy can barely taste the flavors of the dish. when you use your kung-fu to taste the dish's soul, all your taste buds are overwhelmed with the flavor of star anise...taste no so good. 
4. pork dumplings - dumplings were dense and the broth too salty (and didn't mesh well together). skip this dish. 
5. salt cod fried rice - when you finally get a dish that is called salty and don't gets what you order it's then called disappointed...skip this one too. 

Mission Chinese Food (MCF) is like the recent Star Wars Trilogy. You want to like it because the original Star Wars trilogy was epic, fantastic, life changing. Unfortunately, the recent trilogy was a bust. Yes, certain Star Wars fans will be upset, but y'all know it's true. MCF is just like that. How can you not like a place that gives some of their proceeds to the SF Food Bank? 

I closed my eyes; cleared my mind; dispelled all that I knew of Chinese food. I used the Force located deep in the confines of my belly. Alas, this place just didn't do it for me. 

Save your time, eat at San Tung, D&A cafe, Golden Mountain, even Yuet Lee and give directly to the SF Food Bank yourself.
author: Harvey C.

description:
My first update to an update.  But with the constantly growing menu at Mission Chinese and getting to try new things, I thought it appropriate to comment on new dishes I've tried.

- Best dishes in my opinion remain the fiery mapo tofu and the amazingly tender beef cheeks.
- Kung pao pastrami is an interesting take on a standard but it was pretty good.  Also with a nice kick and served with thinly sliced potatoes and roasted peanuts.
- Sizzling cumin lamb was good but kind of got lost in the mix with the other dishes.
- Tea-smoked eel - not what I was expecting; wrapped in rice noodle like a spring roll.  A hit at the table.
- Cold dan dan noodles with sesame and cucumbers were just ok; too "peanuty"
- Salt cod fried rice was delicious; like the small, thin Chinese sausage that's added.

Is it deserving of a #2 ranking on Bon Appetit's Best New Restaurants?  Not quite sure I'd go that high (definitely surprising) ... but the unique combos and use of fresh, top shelf ingredients probably boosts its appeal. 

Plus, they donate part of their proceeds to the Food Bank - even the haters can't find fault with that.
author: F. P.

description:
I wanted to like this place. It's been on my to-try list for so long.

But, alas. No luck.

While the dishes here served a nice twist on classics (instead of the usual westlake soup, they created a porridge with oxtail and dungenness crab), it lacked a depth of flavor -- surprising, as these dishes have so many choice ingredients. 

even the uni (i love sea urchin!) egg custard (i love egg custard!) just tasted very one note. and at $12 for one itty bitty small bowl - that was unbelievable.

will i come here again? probably not.
author: Lily L.

description:
If you're going to eat at Mission Chinese, you'd better be a fan of spicy food. That's not to say that they don't have their share of tasty dishes for non-spicy-people -- but [wo]man cannot live on salt-cod fried rice alone. If you can't take the heat, you probably won't understand the hype.

Their menu also changes a bit every season, so some things may disappear or be modified based on demand and customer feedback (or kitchen whims) -- be warned!

Here's my favorites, in no particular order:

Thrice Cooked Bacon -- Get this. Are you vegetarian? Get this without meat. Contrary to what the name suggests, the bacon is only a small part of the flavor, and one of the least important. Dense rice cakes soak up the sichuan flavors, and the bacon adds a mild searing of smoke.

Kung Pao Pastrami -- Are you feeling lucky, punk? If you are, you should order this dish. Huge chunks of pastramai, seasoned with a mouth-tingling collection of spices (mmm, sichuan peppercorn), are accompanied by peanuts and peppers and potatoes and crunchy celery. The entire thing is tossed in a spicy, sinus clearing sauce. The only downside with the dish is its inconsistency. Sometimes you'll get the perfect balance of ingredients, but other times you'll have a celery salad with a few pieces of pastrami.

[anything] Fried Rice -- These guys know how to do their fried rice. The salt cod version is a good bet, as is the breakfast fried rice (the most recent iteration comes with salmon roe -- woah). Comfort food, with a pleasant twist.

Five stars for the food (and that's probably all that matters), but four stars for consistency and probably fewer for the ambiance (dark, loud, and crowded) (but remember, the food is all that really matters).
author: Chris M.

description: I called to order and the woman hung up on me after I asked a question about the menu. I figured it was a fluke and ordered via grub hub. The food was 50 minutes late on top of the atrociously long estimated time, my son and husband were cranky, the food was lukewarm and subpar. With so many other options, it's a wonder they stay in business.
author: I. C.

description:
My mouth is still on fire, the day after... 

Again, the only token Asian in the restaurant besides the workers... I feel like this is a theme I've expressed over and over again at various establishments I've reviewed on Yelp.  Long lines but time that is given to you is generous - so 30 minutes could mean around 20ish. Keep that in mind if you decide to wonder off... 

LARGE portions.  I really wished I had read some of these reviews before ordering the spicy dishes. We ordered the mo pao tofu, cod fried rice and long beans. All of the dishes were freakin' HUGE.  The IPA comes in a can... not quite what I was expecting. 

CRAMPED space.  Large groups will likely have to wait a while to get a table... and do you do end up smelling like the food afterwards. 

I'd come back to try the other items - but only if I'm REALLY craving Chinese food... and even then, nothing compares to a home cooked Chinese meal.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Was in SF for business and I opted for delivery since my hotel was in Fisherman's Wharf, got lots of work to do that night, tired all day, heard about the wait for the table at this place, and figured the delivery fee ($4) was a lot less than the taxi ride back and forth. Food came in 45 minutes, even though the lady who took my phone order said it would take an hour. 

I ordered the tingly lamb noodle soup and hainam chicken fried rice. The lamb noodle soup was tasty at first, but then my mouth began to feel numb similar to the sensation prior to a dental procedure. I swear that broth is lidocaine-infused - and the dish was not spicy at all! What's the point?? The hainam chicken rice was forgettable. From the online menu desciption, I visualized a dish similar to Singaporean chicken rice. But, hell, no, chicken came in tiny bits like you get in a Nissin noodle soup and the main protein in that rice  is roasted peanuts. I know there's supposed to be some wine in it but that gave the rice a slightly mushy texture and sour taste. Almost like eating pickled rice or, worse, spoiled fried rice (my tummy was fine the day after so the latter option was thankfully not a reality).

Oh, one more thing, with the food price + delivery fee I'd expect at least there would be chopsticks and/or plastic spoons & forks. Sorry, my delivery did not come with those either. 

I'm still baffled with all the hype and good reviews this place got. A number of well-known food reviewers say that it really is not Chinese food - then why the term "Chinese" in the name and the claim of Szechuan influences? I quipped to my colleague the next day to never trust non-Asian revierwers to judge and rate Asian cuisine. 

Go to any "real" Szechuan restaurant to get an appricaition of glorious spicy food from the Szechuan region of China. If dives are your thing, stay with the authentic Chinese cuisine (not the usual American Chinese takeout type you'll find around your neighborhood corner!) you would find in SF's Chinatown - just observe or ask around on where the native Chinese speakers eat. Sorry, MCF, I don't get why the food critics like you.
author: Pat C.

description:
This is good Chinese food.  When I read this was great Chinese food in the NY times I had to try it out and see for myself.  Usually my parents would tell me the top Chinese restaurants they've been too and this wasn't even on their radar so, I had some doubt about what the NY times had said.  

The reason why this place gets 3 instead of 2 stars is the fact they have a lot of spicy dishes, which is a plus in my book.  Since I have been eating Chinese food all my life this place doesn't really do anything new for me.  It's good Chinese.  Now if I were not of Asian descent I could see how this place is spectacular to the unasian tongue but having eating food all over Asia and even china town...this isn't the best and does some injustice to a lot of Chinese restaurants in the bay area which are comparable and even better without all the fanfare.

Dishes ordered for two people...

Salt cod fried rice - you can find this at every Chinese restaurant and nothing was really different.  I could have picked this up for $7.50 at 5A in Millbrae

Ma Po Tofu - Again, pretty regular dish you find at most Chinese restaurants and nothing really spectacular

Sizzling Lamb cumin - good dish because they actually added chili pickled long bean which gave it a nice sour taste to contrast the cumin.  Although the dish wasn't labeled as spicy they did have sliced jalapenos mixed in with the onions.  Best dish for the night

Fried chicken wings covered in chili peppers - I really liked this dish even though the flavors were the same as other Szechuan restaurants but they actually fried whole chicken wings.  Traditionally all other restaurants that make this dish cut up the wings in small pieces without a whole lot of meat.

Szechuan pickles - good, but ordinary "pao tsai"

Tea smoked Eel - Something about this dish that just didn't work for me.  Either the Eel was too heavily smoked in Eel or the taste of hoisin sauce that just messed with me.  I think you do have to try this since this was probably the most creative dish we had. 

All in all, good food and I will go back to try other dishes that I missed.  Definitely bring a larger party other than just two people so that you can try more dishes and not have to bring back bags of leftovers.
author: Frank L.

description:
Best Chinese food I've had in a while.  Came with two friends, we had the beef brisket soup, lamb noodle soup, congee, and two orders of hot wings.  All of it was great, no joke, ALL of it.  I was very (pleasantly) surprised at how awesome everything tasted.  Just the right balance of saltiness and flavor.  Soulful, not too oily and just the right amount of kick at the back of the palate.  Meat was super tender too.  I'm a fan.

Minus one star for the wait, and the cheesy decor of christmas lights, paper dragon with cans of beer in its mouth, and specifically, at our table -- dusty fake flowers inside an old cristal champagne bottle. hmm...

Well at least I'm paying more for the food and not the decor and ambiance.  Will come back!
author: Jessica S.

description:
Whenever I'm sick, I dream of their Westlake Rice Porridge - I'm convinced there is nothing in the world that would make me happier or cure me faster when I have a cold.  It is probably one of the best things I've ever eaten at a restaurant.

I think the most important tip here is, when MCF calls something spicy, they mean it.

* Mabo Tofu: *Really* oily and very spicy.  Lots of savory flavor, not just heat.

* Thrice Cooked Bacon: My favorite ingredient is the thin sliced rice cakes.  And bitter melon really is quite bitter ;)  It's light on the bacon pieces and largely vegetables, specifically onion.   Again, really spicy.

Portions are big, service is good, and it's a fun, dive-y (albeit in a trendy way) place to go.
author: Janice J.

description:
Even though I'm a Bay Area native, 10+ years on the East Coast has rendered me a functional nube to San Francisco and its wild, Birkenstock ways. Luckily, the Mission is a comfortable analogy to Williamsburg; I don't feel too out of place among the fixies and the Waferers. 

Even though my parents are twenty-five+ years natives of America, twenty-five+ years of preceding residence in Asia has permanently closed their minds to nouveau cuisine concepts like molecular gastronomy, fusion food, French food, dairy products, Indian food and alcohol. Luckily, Mission Chinese is the perfect way to introduce conventionally-minded Chinese parents to out-of-the-box eating; they didn't feel too confused or put off by the unfamiliar anagrams of Xi'an-style dishes like Tiger Salad (wrapped in liang pi noodles and served as cool summer rolls - an inspired rendition), deconstructed pork belly tsa shao, or (gently) reimagined cold vegetable noodle soup. 

To boot, plates between $5 - $15 left everyone feeling very comfortable, indeed!
author: Liz C.

description:
The food is fresh and delicious. Their limited menu is their greatest strength, and also their biggest shortcoming. I ordered Mongolian long beans and thrice cooked Bacon, and both were delicious. But honestly, they could expand the menu by about 20%, add two more creative vegetarian options and that alone would bump them up to 4 stars. 

Their bathroom however, receives -4 stars.
author: Jordan Z.

description:
3.5 rounding up to 4 stars.  I am glad that I finally tried it.  The food was good but I would not be willing to wait for a long time to eat here.  The best dishes were the eat-in dishes though so I would be willing to eat here again if there was no wait or if a friend was dying to try it.  Overall I think it's worth a try.  There were some stellar dishes and some that tasted like standard Chinese food-fare.  You may like it if you especially enjoy Sichuan food, spicy food, peppercorns, and cumin.

Must gets:
Squid ink flat noodles
Egg-egg noodles - very spicy but very tasty

Very good:
Mapo tofu 
Salt cod fried rice

Good/Ok:
Fresh rice noodles w/ peanut sauce, tofu skin, pickled mustard greens
Cumin lamb ribs - Fall off the bone meat
Braised pea leaves - A little bland but a nice break from the other dishes
Grandma's spicy lamb dumplings
Beer brined sichuan pickles
Chongqing chicken wings - It looks like a plate of peppers with a side of chicken wings.  My mouth was a little numb from eating this dish
author: Justine L.

description: If hipsters have a heaven, it probably looks, sounds and tastes like Mission Chinese Food.
author: Mark P.

description: "Table for one." Maybe it was just travel-based ennui, but I can't remember ever eating an entree better than the thrice cooked bacon recommended by my server. The salty, sweet pork belly and mochi-like rice cakes played in a salty/smoky/spicy black bean sauce, accentuated by scallions, cilantro, jalapeño slices, and the occasional piece of "tofu skin" or bitter melon. I gluttonously consumed the whole dish, just barely excluding the showpiece  Tien Tsin chili, under the indifferent gaze of an overhead dragon while the restaurant started to fill around me. It was a delight of flavors and textures that I would gladly repeat.
author: Richard G.

description:
If I could use one work to describe the food at Mission Chinese, it would be imaginative. While I can't say that I know a lot about traditional Chinese dishes, several within my party had only good things to say about the Pork Belly and the Rice Porridge with Oxtails. My personal favorite dish was both the Cumin Lamb, with the Long Beans and Thrice Cooked Bacon coming a close second. I also really appreciated the speed of service and helpfulness of the wait staff in helping us choose a good family style menu. Do note the Mao Po Tofu is REALLY spicy, so beware. 

One dish that I did not feel was up to par was the Hainan Chinese Rice. It was a little bit too salty for my taste and didn't match the originality of the rest of the menu. 

Overall a great dining experience. Perhaps not to the extent the NYTimes article described it, but still pretty darned good... and CHEAP. $15 per person with tax!
author: Mark T.

description: Hectic and tight environment but the staff handles it well.  Calling in an order for pick up would be my suggestion.
author: Pinky V.

description:
My boyfriend and I couldn't wait to try this out based on the glory of reviews.  After waiting on the sidewalk for almost 1/2 hour, we were seated at the big table next to strangers.  That's OK if the food was as amazing as we heard it was.  BUT the vinegar peanuts were just that - peanuts drowned in vinegar with bits of roasted garlic.  The lamb curry soup thing was good for the first spoonful, then became overwhelmingly over spices.  The worst was the mongolian long beans - how could you go wrong with green beans?  This chef managed to do it by dousing them with so much red chili flakes and red peppers as to render it un-edible.  And all I can say about the "mouth watering chicken" is it's the kind of mouth watering you get right before you vomit.

I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE.
author: Laura M.

description:
If you asked me what this place is like, I would answer "Hipster Chinese food." Then you would just have to go and see for yourself because I don't know how else to explain it.

They played early-mid 90's hip hop music, and if you are in a party of two you will possibly share a table with strangers. This was the part that was kinda fun.

The food here is pretty good but some of the items' prices were a bit higher than what I would like to normally see for Chinese food. It's a place you must try once if you're in the Mission though.
author: Anna V.

description: Great place if you want super innovative food. I like experimenting with food, and I like Chinese food, but I just didn't like the taste of what I had. The brisket+broccoli was the tamest dish, but tasted the best. The cold noodle appetizer had great hand-pulled noodles and yummy tofu skin but the sauce--which almost tasted like homemade mayonnaise--was cloying after a few bites. We were warned that the lamb cheek soup would "tingle" from the peppers and it did, and that was fun! But the soup itself tasted like tamarind mixed with burnt vegetables, a very odd sour taste that none of us found appetizing.
author: Jo Ellen K.

description:
This review is for dine-in only, which you just shouldn't do.

The food is very good.  Not great, but interesting and good enough that I'd want to eat it again.  It was grimy enough inside to be hipster/authentic, but I really don't care about a restaurant's decor.  The best part of the experience was the couple who shared our cozy table.  They ordered so much food, the guy just gave us one of their West Lake Beef Soups (arguably best I ever had).  Kind of awkward, very gracious, absolutely delicious, much appreciated.

I normally never write reviews, but the restaurant was unforgivably hot--not from spiciness, but in a sweating profusely like it's a steam room in Cambodia kind of a way.  I struggled to pay attention to the conversation because I couldn't stop looking outside, longing to be out on the cool, piss drenched streets of the Mission rather than stuck inside sweating like a prize fighter cutting weight before the match of his life. The pungent food prevents you from noticing BO, so I can't complain about that.  I CAN complain about the utter lack of ventilation.  I'm fine with having to order off a crappy drink menu because there's not even an ice machine for the water, but at least serve the beer cold!  

This restaurant is basically a dining + wet shirt contest in one.  Let me clarify the reviews on here that complain about saltiness.  The food starts off just fine...it's the sweat pouring off your face and splashing onto your plate that does it.
author: Allen K.

description:
Finally a place that lives up to its hype. The food does not have that greasy, heavy taste like typical chinese food. Its still by no means a light and refreshing meal, but not your typical chinese food. I think the important part is you need to have your expectations in check for this restaurant, its chinese fast food, you have to compare it to your typical chinese places, and not compare it to something out of its league. 

I had the smoked eel, kung pao pastrami, thrice bacon, lamb soup, hot and sour cucumbers, and wild peppers.

They sure seem to like to smoke their meats, its not a bad thing. The eel was wrapped in a rice paper and was very very good. The pastrami was good, it had a nice spicy kick to it. The thrice bacon surprised me bit. I didnt expect the bacon to be smoked, but it added to the flavor very nicely.

The lamb soup would hit the spot on a cold day, good quality noodles and the soup base was full of flavor, what I did was add some of the sauce from the hot and sour cucumbers to the soup base and what started out as a good dish ended up amazing!
author: Teddy N.

description:
My pickled salad was the highlight of my meal.  I order spicy mo-po tofu but when the dish arrived, it was more ground pork than tofu. I ate about 3 bites and realized that I had ordered the wrong dish.  No one asked me how my lunch was, and finally a waitress came over to take away my bowl which looked almost untouched.  When she asked me if I wanted it to go, I said "no."  Didn't ask if I wanted something else. The only other item that I wanted on the menu is not offered during lunch time, so I paid and left.   One big turn off was the old smelly carpeting and lack of fresh air which may have contributed to the strange taste of ground pork in a sauce and a red colored oil. I might give it another try and see what all the hype is about.  Some of these hole-in-the-wall dingy places test the threshold of one's dining sensibilities.  

despite my experience, I am glad for the family that they are enjoying such success.
author: blaine s.

description:
This place has the best food deliciousness unit per dollar spent ratio in San Francisco by far. Nothing else compares.

Yes, you may have to wait several hours for a table. Yes, that table may be cramped and/or shared with strangers. Yes, the service sometimes leaves something to be desired. But where else can you find such interesting, delicious food for such a low price? Mission Chinese Food is consistently the place that I recommend to out-of-town guests, and I happily eat here regularly.

I haven't loved every dish that I've tried (e.g. I'm not a huge fan of the pork belly or sizzling cumin lamb, although I know several people who are), and there does seem to be some inconsistency in preparation between visits (e.g. sometimes the bacon is missing bitter melon), but overall, the food is always intriguing and it makes you want to keep eating. Even when your mouth is on fire from liberal use of szechuan peppercorn.

If you only get one thing, get the thrice cooked bacon without bacon. Trust me. The bacon detracts from the dish, but when you get it without bacon, they had more tofu skin, which gives you wonderful sweet, tofu skin-ny bites to contrast with the other flavors. The dish is also misnamed because it's really shanghai rice cakes with other stuff. This is the dish that I get every time I go.

After the bacon no bacon, it's really up to you. The salt cod fried rice is delicious, so much better than any other fried rice that I've had; the westlake rice porridge is so comforting; the mongolian long beans WILL defeat you with their immense spiciness.

Just go here and eat. No, it's not like any other Chinese restaurant that I've been to, and if you go expecting that kind of food, you're going to be sorely disappointed. But if you go expecting interesting food that might kick you in the mouth, I'm sure you'll be happily satisfied.
author: Edward C.

description: Staggeringly good.  Delivery to the Inner Sunset in 45 minutes or so, and the food was all hot.  Everything is PERFECTLY seasoned and spiced (far too uncommon in this town), with some truly unique flavors and execution,  I'd go on about every dish we ordered, but frankly, everything was beyond exceptional.  It takes a lot to impress me, but Mission Chinese Food is really doing something special here.  One of the few trendy places in this town that truly deserves all the hype.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I dont get the 3.5 star rating for this place... whats not to like?

Everything i tried was off the f'ing charts. 

Egg custard was delicious and unlike anything i've ever had, i couldn't stop eating the rice porridge, the pastrami was hot as hell but delicious as well (that was fun), and those pork dumplings were one of the highlights of my life.  I went to bed giddy and I woke up hungry for more.  

I will be back.
author: John B R.

description: A seriously fresh take on our American version of Chinese food. The  Tea Smoked Eel Roll, Ma Po Tofu, and the 3x cooked bacon and rice cakes are my go to. When with a group a good rule of thumb is to order one dish per person there: the servings are healthy. Also, cheap, cheap, cheap! With no booze, dinner for $20 per person is awesome!
author: Laura D.

description: I've been to the restaurant a few times. Service has always been great, the restaurant is gritty and not pretentious, and every once in a while you might hear a Smiths, Misfits or Wu Tang Clan song. With all that said, lets talk about the thrice cooked bacon, I had an easier time kicking my cocaine addiction.
