My hangover sundays consist of me pile driving 2 orders of thrice cooked bacon and 2 mexican cokes straight to my face. I order it online and it usually takes about an hour and a half, worth it. I see a lot people complaining about "hipsters", you're in the wrong neighborhood if that's your only beef. Oh and remember every meal ordered $.75 goes to the SF food bank. I can back a good recent with good food, ran by good people supporting a good cause. Keep up the good work.
author: Jason L.

description:
We were on a mission in the Mission to try what we heard was 'the best' ma po tofu in town. I don't know if it was the best, but it was darn close and we stumbled across some other delicious eats with a flare that took the classic, conventional chinese dishes for a ride.

Lung Shan carries your typical hole in the wall atmosphere. No frills and ruffles. Just your dowdy tables, plates and utensils. You don't expect much, but you get treasure.We ordered the salt cod fried rice, ma po tofu and westlake rice porridge.  Each dish had it's own exclusive quality that held a unique flavor and sometimes, desensitizing heat that you will never forget.

As indicated, the Ma Po Tofu is spicy enough to make one feel febrile, but once you take enough bites to become numb to the heat, you realize that it's a pretty good dish. With a side of rice, I managed to eat quite a bit!

The salt cod fried rice and Westlake porridge were also a hit! The porridge actually had real chunks of crab. My fave! They have great ingredients for a reasonable price. I've never walked out of a Chinese restaurant impressed and anxious to return for other items. Can't wait!
author: Kelly S.

description:
3 for food - 0.5 for service = 2.5
This place is actually called Lung Shan Chinese Restaurant on the outside. Different style of chinese food sorta fusion but not out of this world amazing and more of hype. They have a dine in only menu selection in addition the take out one. All dishes are relatively more expensive than your typical chinese place and expect to wait 40+ minutes to sit down. No parties greater than 8 and they have a strict no-add on policy/entire party must be present before seating. Club hip hop music is playing in the background in this very small and compact restaurant that uses non-matching utensils (probably on purpose)

Char Sui Pork Belly (9.5 - dine in only)
4 pieces of spiced and crispy pork belly that is high fat but tastes almost as good as the ones they serve at santa ramen. Served with pineapple and cucumbers. Its alright but theres only 4 pieces ... 

Thrice Cooked Bacon ($11 available dine-in and take out) 
very fatty bacon pieces with rice cakes mixed with a ton of onions, peppers, and jalapenos. This dish is pretty spicy and tasty although the spice really overwhelmes your taste buds. Overall I would recommend getting this dish if you can handle moderate spice since its pretty unique.

Tea-Smoked Eel ($9 available dine in and take out)
Kinda like rice noodle rolled sushi with eel. Came with 8 pieces and by far was the most healthy dish of the night. Pretty tasty and recommended to try.

Other notable dishes on the dine-in menu that if we had more people in my party we would have considered ordering Taiwanese clams and the lamb ribs.

Overall our party was a little disappointed with the fact we couldn't add another person to our party but restaurant policy i guess... anyways the food was different but nothing to go gaga over. If you dont mind waiting 40+ minutes and having an adventure finding parking, then come on down to mission chinese food. Ill probably wont be back.
author: Robert Y.

description:
The menu here is seriously limited, and unfortunately, they are not willing to make any substitutions or offer sides not listed on the menu. We waited about half an hour to be seated (on a Thursday night), and it was packed inside - hardly enough room to breathe. Clearly, most people enjoy their experience here more than I did. 
They had zero vegetarian dishes that weren't tofu based. I wanted veggies - broccoli, carrots, radishes, bok choy, lotus root, whatever - I'm not that picky. They were unable to serve any sort of vegetable-based dish without tofu. 
All that aside, when the food we ordered came, I tried to keep an open mind...but it still didn't do it for me. The food was not bad by any means, but it just wasn't great either. The radish-tofu dish we ordered was the most enjoyable thing for me, but the whole garlic cloves in it were very crunchy (maybe they're supposed to be? either way, it was not pleasant). 
Not a terrible experience, but I also won't be going back or recommending it to anyone.
author: Leila-Anne C.

description:
If Toucan Sam could smell hipsters instead of Fruit Loops and just followed his nose, this is where he would end up.  After months of hearing the nation-wide hype, we gathered a group worthy of a United Colors of Bennetton photo op and headed over afterwork dinner.  As expected, there was a bit of a wait to get a table but it wasn't too bad (30 mins for 6 people).  I liked the ambiance of the place albeit a bit crowded with the communal seating - the gigantic dragon overhead is unexpectedly awesome.  

Food-wise they serve small plates, which is interesting concept for Chinese place (that isn't dim sum) - given the size of our group, we probably ordered half the menu and tried a range of food.  Unfortunately I thought the food in general wasn't very good - with the exception of the soup, every dish was too oily and super spicy without much flavor or complexity.  Strangely enough, the United Colors of Benetton agreed on this assessment, including those of us that were Asian, liked Chinese food, and/or had a high tolerance for spice.  No more following Yahoo!'s suggestions on the top 10 restaurants in the US - from now on I'm sticking to reputable unbiased sources like the Hemispheres magazine for all my dining needs...
author: Rosers M.

description:
After hearing about all the hype and discovering that a sister restaurant had opened in NYC after I had relocated from there to SF, my friend and I were pretty excited to check this place out. Arriving at a little after 7 PM on a Tuesday evening, we stood outside with the crowd on the street and waited for 45 minutes as assorted homeless indigents encouraged us to "help them out". When our table was ready, we found the interior of the restaurant to be somewhat dilapidated and decorated in a weird mish-mash of cheap Chinese restaurant decor (a few red "scrolls" and lanterns), Chinese gift shop (specifically, the extra-large blow-up dragon hanging from the ceiling) with a college dorm room (namely the white Christmas lights strewn around the restaurant). On top of that, they play hip hop not too inconspicuously: chowing down while listening to Bone Thugs and Ludacris, I was left unsure as to whether or not I should be getting up and busting a move.

Food items:
Beer-brined Sichuan pickle: pickled napa cabbage that was moderately salty and just a little sour from the beer, a decent starter that would've been better with rice.

Smashed cucumbers in garlic sauce: essentially fresh smashed small cucumbers served with garlic hummus and fresh minced chilies. Delicious, but only vaguely Chinese.

Tiger salad: some assorted bitter greens encompassed by a single layer of wide rice noodle, with a mostly unidentifiable and totally forgettable vinagrette (?). I feel somewhat ashamed for having ordered this, but to our credit, some prior Yelp pictures had us mistaking this for the beer-brined Sichuan pickle.

Savory egg custard: a new dish per our waitress, it is essentially a egg custard (almost like a chilled version of what you get at Korean BBQ) served in tomato water with a decent amount of uni, trout roe, and minced shiso leaves. Separately, all these components are actually delicious. Together, they formed a cold hodge-podge with no common element, a sum that is less than the individual parts.

Sliced peanut noodles: perfectly cooked wide rice noodles served with a slightly watered down peanut sauce. I like my peanut sauce actually heavy on the peanut, but the effective cooking of the he-fen left me envious.

Thrice cooked bacon: holy cow, is this dish smoky. Crispy and yet not completely dried out pieces of chewy bacon are stir-fried with slightly numbing chilies, thin slivers of bitter melon, all in chili oil. A potent combination that was hard to resist picking at even when full.

Sizzling cumin lamb: for those of you who cannot handle gamey meats, this dish brought the barnyard along with the lamb on the plate. The meat is certainly tender and well prepared, at least. I was looking for a heavier hand with the cumin; I may in fact stir-fry my leftovers with more cumin.

Salt cod fried rice: our favorite dish of the night. A very delicately prepared (if that is possible for fried rice) dish with good balance of salt, sweet from the chinese sausage, and starch with just a tiny shred of lettuce to keep it tasting slightly fresh. It honestly reminded me of late nights of post-clubbing Chinese food back in Boston, a cleaner and less funky version of salted chicken and fermented fish fried rice served in venues like Chow Chau City.

Verdict: apparently we came to this restaurant looking for Chinese food, and what we found was...50% something else. At over $40 a head for this level of meh (even though we have a boatload of leftovers), I'm actually very surprised that Danny Bowien won the James Beard for Rising Star Chef. The one caveat is that 1 of the more famous dishes, Biang Biang Mien a la Xian Fast Food of NYC fame, was sadly nowhere to be found on the menu. I'll try that for take-out or delivery next time (and maybe my last).
author: Gene C.

description:
I like the food that we had here this afternoon.  I just wish they weren't so salty.  Why do they have to go and ruin otherwise perfectly tasty dishes with so much excess salt?  The only reason I can come up with is that they got a boatload of salt at a discount and have to use them up before their expiration date is due.  We had the lamb noodle soup, the salt cod fried rice.  We also received a dish of fried chicken wings that we didn't order and they ended up letting us have it for free.  The lamb was so delicious and so tender.  The broth has so much flavor.  The fried rice has a very unusual, but pleasantly so, taste with the Chinese sausage added in.  The wings have the perfect crunch which I would have loved to have more of if only my lips didn't go numb from being coated with so much salt!

The other dishes we ordered that showed more restraint with salting were the mussels (perfectly cooked and well sized mollusks) and the egg custard (the least favorite of all the dishes we had in overall taste).

Would we go back?  Maybe, but not anytime soon.
author: Yvette F.

description:
BUENA COMIDA CHINA!

I can get used to this place because SF has way too many Chinese American food. You really have to dig around to find regional Chinese food. This place does not seem like it placates to the "I want Chinese food, but I want Orange Chicken" crowd.

 I would suggest going during non busy hours such as 2-3pm for lunch or 5-6pm for dinner. It can get crowded.

Lamb Noodle - awesome, it was packed with szechuan peppercorn that left a tingly feeling on your tongue. If you drink water, the sensation will intensify. Try it, you will like it.

The prices are affordable for what you get. I will mos def come back to try other dishes on the menu.
author: Tony N.

description:
Y'all are suckers!  You line up and wait 40 mins to an hour for this place?

Do not get caught up in the hipster hype. This place is no good. The food was just bad.  Too spicy to eat is not "hip" just stupid.  We ordered 3 dishes but were brought four (the peanuts, #14 and #17. I have no idea what the dish we didn't order was but it included beef, broccoli and mussels). I tried them all enjoyed none. 

I would like to note that the people who work there were all great.  Really friendly and the service was good.
author: Tara W.

description: Decent food if you can tolerate the wait.  Our group tried about 6-7 dishes.  While most were fantastic a few were just okay.  The "okay" dishes lacked seasoning.  The general theme of all the dishes we ordered was that they killed everything with spiciness and the hoofed animal proteins tasted the best (lamb, beef, etc.).  Even though I love spicy food, I was a bit surprised at the intensity of some of the dishes and switched from wine to beer as soon as the burn took over.  Our waiter (2 stars) was really unprofessional (held glasses with his fingers touching the inside of the cup, and never checked in on us).  I'm interested in going back to try some of the dishes I missed but perhaps at an hour that is not so busy.
author: Darin E.

description: Taste better coming out than in... My dog eats better than this... Why does this place ft 5 star review... Depressing
author: Lauren S.

description: It should be there mission to taste good. It feels like I ate a brick of salt and and grappling with what there are so many five star reviews. Nasty food. Pretentious servers. Ordered 9 dishes and all were nasty
author: Jeff S.

description:
My friends have ben recommending this restaurant to me, however, i really don't see why and how.  The experience overall was not a good one, both the food and the service.    The food was over-salted and showed poor chinese food cooking techniques.  The service was BAD.  The restaurant was dirty when my friend and i were there.

We didn't order much, but we both could not finish eating as the food were not outstanding.  We ordered only 3 items: Szechuan pickles, fried chicken wings/roasted chillies, and numbing lamb Mien.  The pickles were way over-salted and the quality of cabbage was not good.  This was one of the worst pickles i have ever had.  The chicken wings were also over-salted and super dried, and the roasted chillies favor did not really penetrate into the meat.  Most of the chinese people will only over-fried the chicken wings when it is frozen and not fresh.  A good fried chicken wing  should be crispy on the skin but juicy in the meat.  We were disappointed with the way that the Mien being cooked as well.  The Mien dish was over-salted and the Mien portion is rather small and not being cooked correctly.  It ended up the Mien was over-powered by the salt and spices.  

My friend and I will not go back.
author: Preston D.

description:
You know it's been all over The Layover, and it almost started the whole "pop-up" movement in San Francisco. I appreciate the menu, and it's SUPER spice. 

TAKE AWAYS:
- Get there early. Hipster central just moved. 
- It's "high end" Chinese food, so expect to drop some decent paper here. It's not your local Panda Express is all I'm saying. 
- The Ma po Tofu is the biggest takeaway item from this place. Everything else can be tasted elsewhere in some other shape or form better/cheaper. 

Bottom line, cool place to take out of towners, but I haven't gone back since.
author: Abel L.

description:
Cilantro on EVERYTHING!  I'll admit it, I am one of those people.  But if you don't list this divisive ingredient on your menu, bad reviews ensue.  

Delicious, loved what little I could eat around.  We ordered the Thrice Cooked Bacon (cilantro), Salt Cod Fried Rice (cilantro) and the Smoked Beef Brisket Noodle Soup (cilantro).  

It was different, inventive and delicious otherwise.
author: Jared H.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place but haven't had a chance until last nite we ordered take out.  I must say, I was somewhat disappointed.  Additionally, they forgot an order so when we called to let them know the woman on the other end of the phone said: "What do you want me to do about it?" -- Really?  How about: "Oh we are so sorry, we can either redeliver it right away or we can credit you back the money." -- so much for customer service.  And I insisted they re-deliver.

Ok, onto the food review.  

What was good:
Smoked eel wrapped in rice noodle--nice flavor and balance.
Salt and pepper shrimp--this was quite good.
Sizzling Cumin Lamb (our missing dish)--good flavor, somewhat salty.  Not very Chinese at all except if you count adding scallions to it.  What could have made it more interesting if they added tofu skins to it to absorb some of the flavor.

What was bad:
MaPo Tofu--no mapo spice taste and was way, way too spicy hot.  I've made this dish before and theirs was really lacking and needed salt

Hainam Chicken Rice was awful--it was wet and gummy.  No Chicken flavor and the chicken was barely even present.  And I think they put in basil instead of cilantro.  The dish was terrible.

So, all in all was not that impressed but do give them some credit for the fusion of food.

The take-out left me not wanting to go to the restaurant now at all.
author: Nancy H.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the Mission. I always order the mapo tofu (I am hooked real bad) and the Westlake rice porridge. The sizzling cumin lamb is also delicious, and I think everyone should try the kung pao pastrami, szechuan pickles, and salt cod fried rice at least once. The prices are reasonable, the servings are generous, and the food is meant for sharing. 

The wait is never much of a problem during lunch, but the larger your party, the longer you may need to wait for a table. They are closed on Wednesdays.
author: CQ N.

description: I love what they are doing here. Takeout chinese with a custom spin. Everything here is traditional takeout staples with a brilliant take on flavors and western influence. The wait is worth it, the setting is perfect, and the food is unique. I recommend the kung pao pastrami, thrice cooked bacon, the salted cod fried rice, and a Heineken to wash it down.
author: Jake C.

description: Who would have known a Chinese place would be smack in the middle of the Mission that offers big portions and great food. My friend introduced me to this place and told me the tofu dish was the best. We came here on a Saturday around 6pm and did not have to wait too long. I heard the waits can be very long at this popular place. The service was excellent, very attentive servers and they refill your waters without you asking. A plus in a Chinese restaurant because the ones I have been to they seem to forget about refilling your water. My friend told me the portions were huge but I didn't really believe him till the dishes came to our table. We ordered the peanuts, tofu, some dish I cannot remember the name but it had bacon and the tiger salad; all of the food was delicious. Would I go back? Yes.
author: Matthew L.

description: Thrice cooked bacon and salt cod fried rice. No other words need to be stated. Go, now!
author: Olivia D.

description:
Here's the thing:  What Mission Chinese Food does well, they do AMAZINGLY WELL.  Excellent.  And what isn't amazing?  Well, that's the unremarkable or "so remarkable for the wrong reasons.  

The good:  Shrimp with head on (last time we went it wasn't on the menu), Cumin Lamb (OMG SO GOOD), nuts and pickles, Ma Po Tofu (note that I'm the only one in my party who loved this), rice... SO GOOD!

The bad: the lamb soup... waaaaaaaaay too salty.  The kung pao pastrami - so so tasty if only it wasn't hot to the point of obliterating all taste.  The thrice cooked bacon (the tofu skin was amazing but the bacon was all fat, not a piece of meat to be found... it was over-smoked and tasted more like lardo than bacon).  The bbq.

Um, and the hipsters... the crowd who believe that this restaurant can do no wrong. The funky owner / chef guy with the long hair and hipster glasses seems to be passionate about what he is doing and creating here and probably wants honest feedback, not just mindless adoration.  Um, I'm assuming.  And the waitstaff - yes, you're all overworked and have too many tables, but please don't drop a SPICY HOT dish on my table and never come back to see if we need our water refilled (we did).  The waitresses are nice, but it was hard to get their attention each time I was there.

Oh, and did I mention the hipsters?  Yes, I think I did.

All in all, creative cuisine with room for improvement... This restaurant fascinates me and I want to watch this chef continue to get better.
author: Melanie K.

description:
Quality Chinese food with creative twists. Talent in the kitchen - the rich pork-y goodness of the Shanghainese Chow Mein infused even the napa cabbage.  

Awful rap and pop music blasted with such volume that my ears were ringing after dinner. Who was responsible for that meal ruining decision, and can someone break his kneecaps for me? Requests to reduce the volume were met with snarls (or maybe they just couldn't hear us over the noise). Quarters so cramped you couldn't move, an icy wind from the always opened door chilling both you and your food, and a goofy bridge and tunnel crowd (hipsters? Maybe those of the Livermoreian variety) didn't add to my dining pleasure.
author: Nick C.

description:
Really great Chinese food.  Kung Pao Pastrami and Pork Belly were especially good.

Small, tight space = fairly long wait.  But, there's a reason people wait.  You should, too.
author: Keith K.

description: I loved mission Chinese in NYC my first time I went and was really excited to try the originale.  Regardless of the fact that some dishes ended up not being my favorite, it's pretty awesome that Danny b is experimenting with flavors and pushing the limits. Pretty cool. Recommendation time-general tsos beef, pea shoots in broth, thrice cooked pork belly and rice cakes. All are solid, flavorful dishes.  Chicken wings are tasty for a crowd, but don't order if more than 2 per person as they may be overwhelming. Skips - squid noodles with lamb are overwhelmed by the lamb flavor and grease. Fried rice with salt cod is good but not unique tasting in any way.  So fun to try east / west coast mission Chinese. Such a fun concept. Go Danny b!
author: mary l.

description:
After hearing all the hype surrounding this place, I was super psyched to finally get to try it.  On a lazy sunday afternoon (after a hard night of drinking), a friend and i decided to have it delivered.

Maybe that was the first mistake, b/c delivery is always a different experience than actually dining in.  After calling in our order, it showed up 45 minutes later (which is how long they told us it would be)

We ordered  the "Tiger Salad" (some lettuce/greens wrapped in a rice paper coating) that was very underwhelming, and wasn't terribly special.  The same can be said for the Guilin Rice Noodles which erred on the side of bland, and sounded at lot better than they actually were. The Hainam Chicken rice came with hardly any chicken, and was way less flavorful that I'm used to for Hainam Chicken.

The best part of the meal was definitely the Westlake Porridge--"zhou1" for mandarin speakers.  As I was still hung over, this magical concoction made me feel better with every bite.  And this porridge was exquisite; all the flavors combined together made for a tasty and nourishing treat.  

All in all, I think Mission Chinese Food (for me) was a victim of the hype...another one of those situations where it probably would have been way better if I had no expectations.  However, I'm willing to give it another shot, granted I visit the actual restaurant next time...as for delivery I'll stick to my local greasy Chinese joints.
author: Michael C.

description: The food is legit - Chinese legit. It is flavorful and spicy. We ordered mapo tofu, sour chili pepper chicken and pickles. The price, however is not so friendly, and its portion is comparably smaller to your other casual authentic Chinese food places. It has an American bar vibe and your traditional Chinese restaurant interior decor. I'm again spoiled by all the cheap tasty Chinese food around SF already, so here won't be high on my list.
author: Vivienne Z.

description:
It's a little deceiving passing by, especially with all the hype and talk about this place it's still a little run down chinese restaurant, not a problem but unexpected.

Other than a couple of key dishes, the food is alright. I don't think it's worth the hype of being such a great restaurant with amazing food as it fails and succeeds just as much as any other 'alright' chinese restaurant. The pork belly and cuming lamb are usually good but everything else has been alright to eh. 

The bbq platter was not good and not very meaty, while the dumplings were average at best and most of the dishes come out bland but spicy, if that makes any sense at all.  The service is awkward as it is somewhat stand offish and non existent, but not rude. Food comes out when it comes out and there's little communication between staff and customers. You just order, get your food, and ask for your check.

If you're curious, definitely try but if you want to find an experience go elsewhere.
author: Sam H.

description:
I am obsessed with this place! The food is so so so delicious, and so cheap. We had a table of 5 and spent around $70. 

While we were waiting outside the chef brought out food for us to try. That's great service. Also love the charm and the ridiculous soundtrack.

I've been telling everyone I see to try it.
author: Jessi P.

description:
A reminder on why life in SF rules, brought to you by MCF:

Savory Egg Custard 
Westlake Porridge 
Thrice cooked bacon (veg)

*delivered
author: J C.

description:
Came here on a whim with a couple of friends who wanted to try this place out. I've heard soooo many good things about it but was sort of disappointed.

We ordered:

savory custard--good, really small portion for 12 dollars
westlake porridge--good flavor, but not anything AMAZING.
thrice cooked bacon--pretty good... but the amount of meat in there was miserly.
veal rib--by far our favorite, but it was pricey for the amount of meat we got
mapo tofu--heard SO much abou this but it was WAYY too spicy.

to summarize... pricey for what you get and a lot of their dishes are a lot more spicy than most people can handle. basically, it was okay for no wait, but there is no way i would wait more than 10 mins to eat here.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I use to think this is the last resort for asian food.  Now I don't even consider it.

My last experience here was pretty bad.  Had the salt cod fried rice that ended up like dried up congee.  The cold noodles tasted like it was made a week ago.  And the ma puo tofu tasted like tofu drowned in overspiced oil.  Horrible.  Almost felt like barfing even t hough i didn't finish any dish.

How can you mess up fried rice THAT bad???
author: Jonathan C.

description: This place is awesome. The egg egg noodle is the ridiculous. It goes perfectly with white wine. It brings the dish together. We also ordered the Mongolian long beans which were greasy but delicious. The mapo tofu is spicy and taste. The thrice cooked bacon is remarkable.  The people next to us got the flaming lamb ribs and they made us cry. Literally, they were so spicy that we were crying and dying laughing that we were crying. We were also kicking ourselves that we didn't order it. Looking forward to returning so I can order it next time.
author: Kelly C.

description: I love Asian food so I was pretty excited about eating here after a friend recommended it to me. We had a party of three and ordered the tea steamed eel, Hawaiin pork belly (?), cod fried rice, and mapo tofu. I thought everything was okay, nothing special, except I loved the tea steamed eel. I had never had anything like it and the texture made it even more delicious. It was partly crispy inside and wrapped in rice paper. So good. I might come back just for that, but I'm hoping their other items are better than the ones we ordered.
author: Vi P.

description:
Arguably one of the worst kept secrets in SF. 

If you can look past the hipsters and often cramped seating situation, this is one of the best places to come for great, cheap eats and refreshingly creative Chinese food.

I've grown accustomed to getting take out here instead of dining in. It's pretty fast and reliably excellent. If you don't like spicy food, keep on walking, because that's their specialty.
author: Laura K.

description:
Man I really really was looking forward to enjoying and liking Chef Myint's food.  But actually everything except for the salt cod fried rice was way too overbearing with seasoning.  It just showed that the kitchen just didn't have any control.  I was thinking that maybe they were just stoned or high back there.

What I ate:
Slow Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly - score: 3 of 5.  The pork was tasty and chewy but it was no big deal.  The only thing I really liked with this dish was the salty egg.

Ma Po Tofu - score: 2 of 5.  Way too much cumin.  I couldn't taste anything else.

Hainam Chicken Rice: score 2 of 5.  No big deal.  I've had better in Chinatown.

Salt Cod Fried Rice: score 4 of 5.  The savior of the night.  Tasty!  You could taste the salt cod in every piece of rice.

Chicken Wings with Explosive Chili Peppers: score 3 of 5.  I've never had that much szechuan peppers and I didn't know that it makes your entire mouth numb!  Chicken was crispy.

I know that MCF is going for a more fusion, eclectic style of Chinese to draw in the more hipster crowd, of which are obviously mostly Caucasian.  Nothing wrong with that but overall there was no consistency in the menu.  Either it was bland like the Hainam Chicken Rice to the almost inedible Ma Po.

Sorry.
author: M V.

description:
For all the people who are ranting and raving about how it's too hipster and "There is no way the chef cooking these loads of shit is Chinese!," you're right, he's not Chinese! Is that such a crime?

Check out this NYT article for more background before judging so quickly:
http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/29/magazine/mark-bittman-san-franciscos-new-pop-up-restaurant.html
author: Chris P.

description:
If your attitude toward flavor is best described as "more, please" you'll love Mission Chinese Food. Here, everything meaty, salty, fatty, and spicy is tossed together and dialed up to 11. 

Mission Chinese was described to me as Momofuku-esque, and that's not wholly inaccurate. The kitchen definitely gives off the same "we're cooking what we want to eat, and eff you if you don't like it" vibe of the early Ssam Bar late-night menu (it also manages to be even more tightly packed and less conducive to lingering than Ssam Bar).

Fortunately, everything can be delivered, and knowing I don't have to brave the crowds of hipsters for my next hit of Thrice Cooked Bacon means I'll be eating here a fair amount in the future.
author: Amy L.

description: Going here is usually a lesson in patience. So I was really happy when the friend I was meeting for dinner suggested meeting there early. We walked right in and got seated, which was a first for me. I feel like the menu options the day i was there were really limited, partially because they were out of a few things. I still managed to find something though. My "mouth watering" chicken was so delicious I was popping chicken hearts like candy. Since I generally avoid all organ meats, that's really saying something. The pork belly was also good, but not a standout. I just wish they had been serving the thrice cooked bacon. Their vegan version of that is my favorite dish on the menu. The service was fast and until the very end, really attentive, which is a big improvement over previous visits.
author: Nicole M.

description: What's the hype all about?! The food is way too salty -- I found it borderline edible.
author: Shivani S.

description: Went to this restaurant with few friends. Love the cool atmosphere. It's definitely not your typical Chinese restaurants. The place is more for pre-bar crowd or with your friends. The food is good. Menu selection is simple. The pork belly is my favourite. Definitely worth to check it out!
author: Danny L.

description:
forget all your impressions and memories of Chinese Food.  Mission Chinese will break all traditions.  Been here twice and both times, we have not been disappointed.  in fact, we can't wait to go back.  Beijing vinegar peanuts to start was smart move.  first trip, we have hainam chicken.  scary good.  Rice cake with pork - try it!  and if you like hot, get the chicken wings.  HOT.  but oh so good.  And definitely get the smoked beef brisket noodle soup.  Out of this world good.
the second time, we started with the peanuts again (couldn't pass those up).  Salt cod fried rice...seriously, i would have ordered another.  Shanghai noodles...the preserved vegetables were so, so good in the dish.  really gave it a unique flavour.  and the kung pao pastrami...yeah...no need to describe further.  WOW.
just be prepared for a place to eat...not dawdle.
author: Sonia C.

description:
It's almost been two years and I totally love this place now, I'm still scared of the Mapo, but the heat and flavor of everything else here is amazing. I've recommended Mission Chinese many times to anyone looking for something different. You're not going to find anything else in SF under chinese like this.

Order here often for office and home delivery and they always do an excellent job. 

Keep it up, you guys rule
author: Shawn S.

description:
I went there again after i saw few more articles on this restaurant  & chef and after making the top 100 list.  Im very sorry to give it a 1 star but i felt that I wasted another $40....  not much but still a waste.

We ordered the chicken wings appetizer, cod fried rice and sizzling lamb.  The fried rice came 1st and then 5 minutes later the lamb and 10 mins later the appetizer chicken wings.  HUH??  We nibbled on the rice while we waited for the lamb.  when it finally arrived, it was NOT sizzling as the name suggests.  the meat was low quality lamb.  80% fat and some meat covered with LOTS of onions which surprisingly tasted better than the actual meat.  The cumin taste was a bit over-powering.  when the APPETIZER chicken wings came (last) it was covered with PLENTY of smoked red chilli peppers.  it found it to be such a waste of good chilli.  i took it home and made myself a nice hot sauce.  But I cant imagine them throwing away that many chilli peppers.  $$ down the train.  But back to the wings.... it was dry and too salty.  it needed a dipping sauce of sorts.

I really dont get it.  Do you guys really like this place THAT much?  I'd rather spend that hard earned $ at YAMO or GRUB or any of the 7/8 restaurants on the same block and have a better experience.

I left this place very unsatisfied & disappointed again.
author: Marcia B.

description: I have heard a lot of good things about this place and was excited to finally try it. Wow what a let down.
author: Amy P.

description:
I don't know why this place doesn't have all and only five stars, but it does in MY book. And my book is full of delicious food stuffs. 

I went there, finally, with a couple girlfriends of mine and we are all blown away. Although none of us have ever yelped before, we all agreed this was one restaurant worth breaking the cycle for. Plus...we got there five minutes before it opened at 6, so we had one of the first tables. I would recommend this as it seems like this little place gets a crazy wait. (Decidedly WORTH waiting for, though.)

FABULOUS, delicious, gourmet with a hint of funky, and the only chinese place I would recommend for visitors. Plus, I love the atmosphere. They are playing a great variety of hip 'dance/ambient' music...Don't worry, they aren't blasting 90's techno, it's more like the band "The Knife' has a musical lovechild with 'Purity Ring". Very fun while you're eating. The lighting is also super low, your table lit in red glows by the awesome paper chinese dragon that fills up the upper tier of the room. In my opinion it's perfect for groups of 2-4 on a casual friend dinner. 

But the food...lemme tell ya. I give thumbs way up to all of my dishes. 
1. Peanut noodles.....it's like they bred lasagna pasta and mochi together and dumped delicious peanut sauce on top. The texture was different and perfect. 

2. The orange beef tongue....another WINNER. If you like beef tongue, which is close to beef with just a slightly gamier flavor, covered in orange saucy goodness....go for it. This is a slightly more traditional style chinese dish, but with that special flare. 

3. And finally....the piece de resistance....LAMB CHEEK soup. Do it. Just......go order it right now. Thick, seemingly handmade, long noodles on top of a bed of cilantro and spices, pickled veggies and melt-in-your-mouth, fallin' off the bone like nana's famous ol' pot roast, finger-lickin' good lamb. Drop some of the spicy sauce into the broth and it's pure heaven.

So if you can't tell already, I'm a fan. If you were visiting me, I'd totally take you there.
author: Sloane E.

description: Very interesting place. The ingredients are different than normal Chinese restaurant. Good try.
author: Dandan L.

description: Rude!!! I wanna try this place for a while. Finally, I called in and got some delivery last night. The lady who picked up the phone, is sucked. Not polite at all. Food wise, the chow mien is blended. I could not enjoy it. The eel rice roll is a little better but it's overpriced. Not an authentic Chinese restaurant!!!
author: MC K.

description:
Waited for 45 minutes just to see what the hype was about. Even brought my mom and grandma since I heard its really really good chinese food. Well, I heard it from one person but I took her opinion quite seriously. I had the pork belly....super dry and bland. The clams....that was good (not great). Shanghai noodles, probably the best dish we had but might be a bit salty for most people. Tiger salad....ugh really overrated dish, basically spring mix with a ginger type dressing wrapped in rice paper. Fried chicken wings...that was pretty decent. Ma po tofu....not good, very sour and I've had authentic ma po tofu before since I am Chinese. 

I just assumed it would be authentic Chinese food, but once I walked in, it was dark with really obnoxiously loud music, so my mom and grandma was horrified. I wouldn't wait 45 minutes to eat some american-washed Chinese food. It's not bad tasting food, but just not worth the wait or the price. I thought they would have more choices on their menu as well. I gave an extra star for the service, our waitress was very nice.
author: Chris L.

description: Yum! Really interesting, different food from what I am used to with Chinese food. I will definitely be back for the kung pao pastrami and the egg-egg noodles. The beef chow mein and dumplings were also very tasty!
author: Natasha F.

description:
Ok so now I get why there is always wait for this place! Always walked by, always curious, but never enough to wait for Chinese food....However, when my friend suggested and we looked at the menu, now I see...a chinese restaurant with not so usual chinese ingredients i.e. jicama. Curiosity scale has gone up. 

Ambiance - A+...Appears to be a hole in the wall chinese restaurant but feels like a typical Mission spot and I loved how Weezer was blasting when we walked in. This place was packed...so good sign!

Service - A....The wait can be long. We went across the street to Mayhem for a drink as we waited and we waited about 30 minutes. They don't take reservations so you put your name down on a list. I like how you don't lose your place on the list if you get missed from the call. Our waitress was pleasant, attentive, and friendly.

Food - A- ...We didn't order anything totally unusual - fried pork belly, beef/brisket noodle stew, spicy chicken wings, and spicy green beans. All the different flavors were fantastic. I LOVED the pork belly - of course anything fried anything pork in book is deelish. Pork was perfectly fried. The chicken wings wasn't quite what I expected but it was still pretty tasty. Food gets an A (-) because it was a little too salty for me, especially the green beans and the noodle stew. 

Would I come back...absolutely....
author: Jen R.

description:
ok, so I've had my share of Chinese food in the bay area. This is something else, and really special. Covered in traditional tacky 'authentic Chinese' decor, you'd guess that this is just another fairly decent Chinese restaurant. You're wrong. The Ma Po Tofu tastes both authentic and yet a little better than authentic. West Lake Rice Porridge - again, authentic regional Chinese flavor, and yet, much more special.

I started missing this place a few minutes after I walked out the door. And next time I step foot in the city, you can bet I'll be here again, stuffing my face on deliciousness.
author: Jeni Y.

description:
OK, this place is unique in that it is Chinese food in the dark, with hip trendy music, and non-Asian servers. Place is too hip for me - If I want good Chinese food, I'd rather go someplace where I know I can see what I'm eating. The wait was 1.5 hours. I think I would never wait ever again to eat here but it was worth the experience. 

We shared the Shanghai noodles (really greasy and too salty), the wings were spicy (but small), ma po tofu (probably most authentic given the black beans and really intense spices), and the best was probably the beef + Chinese broccoli. The meat was great - melted in your mouth. So, I've gotta say, it was a fun experience dining with friend and his friends visiting from out of town. But, I would not wait again for Chinese food for 1.5 hours.
author: Jamie T.

description:
We had heard the buzz about this place and decided to try it for lunch on a weekday. From the moment we walked in, things didn't seem right. Dark, crowded, unfriendly, and not so clean.  We ordered using the number on the menu and were told "just tell me what it is". Why is there a number by each item if they don't want us to use it?

We ordered the # 21, which was sizzling cumin lamb with chili pickled long beans and #10, which was supposed to be 7 chicken wings with dried red chilies on them. 

We only got 5 wings buried under the red peppers. They were salty and had a slight vinegar and spicy taste, but the dried peppers seemed to be there just for show because they didn't seem to flavor the wings much. We asked what kind of tea they had, and our waitress said "just Chinese restaurant tea". I asked is it black tea or oolong or what? She didn't know. She brought a half pot of weak tea.

Our lamb was buried under a heap of sauteed onions. Again, we didn't see the point to so many onions except to hide the fact that the lamb was mostly bones with the meat fried down to a crisp. Some cumin flavor, but mostly a salty flavor. There are other places that serve better cumin lamb with better cuts of lamb and at a lower price. 

Also, there were no pickled long beans with it. We told the waitress. She had to check the menu, went to the kitchen and came back with a bowl of the pickled beans saying " they told be to just give this to you" and then she walked away, never to return to our table.

We never had a chance to tell her that there were only 5 wings instead of 7. There was no rice on the menu and none was offered. We saw her bring rice to other tables, but not ours. Getting eye contact from any of the staff was impossible. They all had dead pan expressions as if they wished they were somewhere else. 

A bill was just dropped off at our table without anyone asking "how was everything?"

This place represents the worst of what a restaurant should be. Maybe they have some unique menu items like "kung pao pastrami", but that will only make this place a passing fad.
author: Reid T.

description: I actually came here for a second dinner!  I was in the neighborhood, and decided to just get the salted cod fried rice to share as a snack, just to see what all the hype was about.  There were so many people outside and they were all talking about how great the place was.  I actually really liked the fried rice.  I thought the seasoning was good, and there was a lot of flavor in the dish.  But it is good enough to be $10 for 1 dish and on the 7x7 list?  Probably not.  Overall 3.5 stars probably.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
MEHHH.

Why this place is so poorly lit I have no idea, because they must be making a fortune from all their slightly overpriced food. I will say that the salt cod fried rice was as good as advertised, and all three stars basically are for that dish alone. Generous serving, too. But the rest of their dishes, especially the Szechuan "pickles," the peanuts, and the bacon rice cakes were nothing to write home about. I mean, really -- nothing special.

Unless my friends want to check out this place, I won't be coming back. Sorry.
author: Albert L.

description:
1.5 stars. 

Let me preface this by saying I was not expecting traditional Chinese food. But in fact was excited to see what kind of twist this place had on the flavors I'm so used to having. Alas, what I did try didn't intrigue me enough to go back. 

Beef Cheeks - solid, cheeks were very tender
vegan delight - don't do it, honestly the most disappointing dish. bland.. and really just lacking. 
spicy chicken wings - dry, overcooked, bland, dry.. did I mention bland?
westlake rice porridge - flavors were okay, eat it with the peanuts.. it adds flavor and texture

Bathroom was questionable. I really don't understand the hype.
author: tessie n.

description:
I had high hopes for Mission Chinese -- where else can you get decent Chinese food, not dumped on a plastic platter, with no formica tables or fluorescent lighting in sight? Seemed like a pretty good deal to me.

But Mission Chinese ended up being a paper tiger. They have a collection of small plates, meat dishes, vegetable dishes, and noodle/rice dishes. The food was decent-but-overpriced at best, inedible at worst. We had:
-Pork belly appetizer - this was actually pretty good! Crispy on top, with a thin layer of fat and juicy meat. It was served with a dark savory sauce and some canned pineapples and mandarin oranges (which was a little wtf? I would've preferred pickles or cucumbers).
-Thrice-cooked bacon - Looked delicious! Rice cakes and juicy, marinated bacon bits. Unfortunately, our dish was SO SALTY I had to ask the waiter to take it back. He claimed there was no salt in the dish, only salty components, so I made him try some at our table to see how salty it was. He was nice enough to offer us a new dish.
-Beef, broccoli, oyster sauce - The beef was tender but sparse. I could only find about 10 cubes in the whole dish. The oyster sauce was again on the salty side, but not unbearably so. The broccoli was actually broccolini, which was pretty good. I like this creative interpretation and only wish it were better executed.

I might be able to accept this quality of food if it was hole-in-the-wall cheap, but it wasn't. Main dishes ranged from $12-$16, which is an unacceptable price range for mediocre ethnic food.

I might let one of my friends convince me to come back and give this place another shot. It has a lot of potential, it just wasn't executed well the night I was here.
author: Cathy S.

description:
So my boyfriend and I well more so my boyfriend heard great reviews and how everyone was raving about this place. The line wasn't very long so we were like why not. Well one thing for sure I am glad I didn't wait very long to get a seat since I don't feel like it was worth the wait Burma Superstar however is. The food wasn't bad but it wasn't rave worthy either. 

Tiger Salad- wasn't that bad but too much basil for me (but I am not one who likes it anyways so don't take my advice). It was still tasty and a lil spicy which was nice
Cumin Lamb- the onions tasted really nice and same with the pickle stuff (very pickly) however, the lamb was fatty and bland. We took home the onions. 
Stir fried corn and peppers- it wasn't that bad but eh. There was a lot of it so we took it home and it will probably be great leftover.

If you want to go here, get here before the crowd because from what people say you'll be disappointed. At least I was. Food was good but not worth the wait. Only like 10 mins worth of waiting.
author: Tina D.

description:
If you must try this over hyped popular stop in the Mission, don't mind the long wait or order to go and eat on the sidewalk (why not- it's the mission) or at Dolores Park (4 blocks away) with a view of SF.

My first try here reminds me of a Northern Chinese taste similiar to my mom's cooking, especially when I walked into the interior decor of a Mainland Chinese influence, i.e the red posters, large print calendars, etc.

The Cumin Lamb is authentic but the meat a bit fattening. Heard they are opening another location in NYC. True?
author: Jackie G.

description:
Wow, I feel like I am really missing something. I ordered Mission Chinese whilst hungover from Vegas due to all of the reviews and recommendations it has been getting. Delivery took ages (fine bc it's in the Mission and we are in SoMa) but when the food arrived it was cold. I ordered the tofu (as per 7 x 7) and couldn't eat more than 3 bites. it was incredibly oily and mushy. 

Needless to say I was really disappointed- did I order the wrong thing? Or is their delivery quality way below their restaurant food?
author: Seema M.

description: Update.  Round two as I needed a spot in a hurry and it was close.  Hostess on the night of 12/15 was quite lovely (180 from the first horrific hostess).  But the food...nothing to write home about. This place is all hype.
author: Nicole M.

description: Amazingly good food!! Be aware though, some of the food is VERY spicy. If you don't like it hot, tell your waiter/waitress. The service could be a bit more hearty but this seems to be part of the image. Worth it for the food though...
author: Adam L.

description:
I'm sad to say that Mission Chinese was a little hit or miss for me last night. Tried the salt cod fried rice for the first time, which was FANTASTIC. So tasty and not greasy, and the wisps of ginger add the perfect crunch and freshness. Mapo tofu was good as always, but the sizzling lamb and thrice-cooked bacon, while really really flavorful, were also really really tough. Like, chew-until-you-have-to-spit-it-out tough.

I don't know, maybe it was an off night. But I was le sad.
author: Lisa W.

description:
The best Ma Pa Tofu I have ever had.  This is the new benchmark.  Cinnamon stick, fennel seed, Szechuan peppercorns, Ghost Chili and who knows what else with Kurobuta pork!?!  The flavors are incredible.  In the end, it's only eating the fresh serrano chili that will set off the four alarm in your mouth and sinuses.  

What other Chinese restaurant is going to feature Coca-Cola smoked brisket with home-made pickled cukes/onions and white bread with crusts cut off?  

How can peanuts in black vinegar and fennel manage to knock one's socks off?

Just when you think you're heading towards the Mission to grab a burrito, you instinctively and inexplicably find your way back here every time.   

PS 4pm is the best time to go here on the weekends.  Beat the dinner crowd, BBQ items are available, and the bodegas are still open to do some post-eating grocery shopping.

PS 75 cents from each entree goes to charity.  Woo hoo!
author: K W.

description:
After dinner at Commonwealth last year, my mother and I dropped in to get some takeout for the rest of the family. I didn't get a chance to try any (or see any of it), but the words "terrible" and "awful" were both used in their description of the food. I was totally shocked, but I knew I'd have to try it myself.

Not surprisingly given the hype, lines are a frequent occurrence outside the no-reservation restaurant; there must've been at least 20 people waiting outside this past Saturday night at 9pm. However while everyone else was still nursing their Thanksgiving food coma, my mom, dad and I dropped in for lunch the day after Thanksgiving. What do you know - there was no line!

Westlake Rice Porridge oxtail, dungeness crab, soft-poached egg, cilantro

This was a sort of a hybrid between a Westlake beef soup and a traditional congee (rice porridge). The lineup of ingredients was an all-star cast so I had to order it. Served piping hot, small pieces of crab and oxtail were scattered throughout the bowl filled with bits of soft rice, strands of egg and a clear soup. The dish was fine, somewhat disappointing. I expected the oxtail and crab to play a more prominent role, maybe with a little bit of oxtail stock incorporated into the soup. In actuality, the soup was very mild in flavor and the oxtail/crab really didn't bring a lot to the bowl. Don't get me wrong, the soup was tasty but it didn't live up to its all-star cast of characters.

Salt Cod Fried Rice escolar confit, chinese sausage, egg, scallion

I thought this was another fun dish using salt cod instead of Chinese dried fish. Its effect was similar, adding a fishy flavor to the rice to pair with the sausage and aromatics. However, we all thought this plate was a bit heavy-handed with the salt.

Smoked Beef Brisket Soup Noodles cheung fun, mire poix, cardamom, turnip, broth

Whereas the rice porridge was served hot amid wisps of steam, this soup was served warm. The brisket here was very tender and incredibly smoky, infusing the soup with that flavor. Rice roll noodles added some additional substance to the full-flavored dish.

Kung Pao Pastrami explosive chili, celery, potato, roasted peanut, steamed rice

A familiar preparation of pastrami was stir fried kung pao style with something called "explosive chili." I was fearful but actually found the heat to be present but not unbearable. The meat was tender and flavorful, and I thought there was a pretty decent balance of ingredients. My dad wanted more meat and less "filler" ingredients though.

My dad said this meal was definitely better than his previous experience, but the meal still did not live up to high hopes. I thought the food was "just okay" (definitely not awful), with flavors not really coming together as well as I had wanted. The menu is incredibly intriguing, integrating Chinese food with Western techniques and ingredients. I so badly want something like this to succeed and elevate Chinese food on both the local and national scene. Although this meal failed to impress me, Mission Chinese Food seems to be doing just that.
author: Darin L.

description:
Holy Year of the Dragon! 

You know, one of the cool things about eating at a Chinese place is that they kinda all have the same menu, the average ones anyway, like a BK or Taco Hell. Anywhere you go, you can find some chicken fried rice or some General Tzo's. NOT HERE. Good god, took me like twenty minutes to decide on some dishes to try. I must say I was actually nervous. Wow! The flavor combinations are intense. Needless to say, the food was incredible. Some of the most flavorful chinese food I've ever had.

It was Lin-tastic! (Wait, is that racist? Wait, is that even a pun?)

Good eatin'.
author: Robert M.

description:
Well, this shit is white hot right now. It gets play on food TV. Bauer writes it up and gives the food 3 stars. I should have known before I ordered delivery.

So I call in my order...Cold Noodles, Beijing Vinegar Peanuts, Hainam Chicken Rice, their famous Ma Fo Tofu, Braised Mongolian Beef Cheek and Sizzling Cumin Lamb. One hour. OK. Sit and wait. One hour fifteen and I call. No answer. Over the next thirty minutes I call maybe ten times. No answer. One hour and forty-five minutes later the food arrives. Something spilled a bit in the bag. Food not very hot now. I.should.not.have.ordered.delivery. Never again. But the food?

Cold noodles were excellent. Flavorful and firm. Peanuts were so-so. Interesting but overpowered by the vinegar. Hainam Chicken Rice was very good. Rocked. The tofu is famous for a reason. Just super but I wish it had been hotter. The beef cheek was not so good. More fat than beef. The lamb was also not very good. If this was lamb belly it should have been better cooked. It came as a gelatinous, fatty blob. Again, not hot enough.

So service sucked really bad. The food was mixed. Unlikely to return any time soon.
author: Gary C.

description: Not worth the hype! For a city with such wonderful Asian cuisine, this place falls short in my book. The wings were the best thing we had, and even they were just odd. The flavors of the wings were generally good - though they had some spice that made it feel like your tongue had pop rocks on it. The broccoli beef was average, and didn't have that much meat on the plate. The General Tso's veal rib flavor fell short, and was super oily. I'm much more used to this sauce being thicker and more full of flavor. Overall a disappointment. I won't be back.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Perhaps all of the hype had me anticipating an earth shattering food epiphany. What I experienced was nothing outerworldly, but rather average. The slightly innovative twist on Chinese classics was evident by the menu. While the menu terms were standard classic, the ingredients were paramount. The use of great braising techniques were employed with finesse. 

My major critique was that all of the dishes were overly salted and sauced. Now I like my sodium intake as much as the next gal, but I felt my hands swell to the size of lobster paws by the end of the meal. The sauces seemed to all have a slightly "heavy" texture and while I am a firm believer that fat equals flavor, the sauces lacked the unctuous flavor that is usually coaxed out by hours of cooking was lost on our dishes. 

Out of the eel roll, Hainam chicken with rice and the chinese broccoli with braised beef cheeks, the latter won out on taste. It was truly the standout dish of the evening and we'd be back just for that. A generous portion of perfectly braised beef and plentiful Chinese broccoli with a few fresh oysters thrown in for good measure. Great stuff. 

Mexican coke and cheap Tsing Tao doesn't hurt either.
author: Stacy T.

description: Well i really wanted to like this place but when i arrived i saw the chef out front, sitting on the sidewalk talking on his cell phone, smoking a cigarette.  (remember its the sidewalk in a busy city) came back in to cook and never washed his hands.  Who cares if the food tasted good or bad, this was gross.
author: Tim M.

description:
It's a bit overrated. I was really excited to try this place seeing that it was reviewed by everything from the NY Times & Bon Apetit. But I'm a bit disappointed by the taste and price of the food.

Pros: The food is quite interesting and unique. I only tried three dishes and would've loved to try more but dishes were a bit pricey. 

Cons: Flavor. Ma Po Tofu (decent, good flavor, spicy, tasted like it was microwaved though), Spicy Chicken Wings ( SPICY SPICY SPICY! I felt like my lips were tingly and everything was so salty. Something about the spiciness made everything so salty), & Salt Cod Fried rice (This was the most decent dish of the ones we tried. Flavor was okay but bf thought it was microwaved and it felt cold)

Overall, it's way overrated for the food. Spicy overkill. I don't understand why my 7 pieces of chicken wings needed to be covered in 50 pieces of red peppers. Such a waste! Everything was really salty too. Lets not talk about it being authentic either because that's not what its going for. 

Service was okay. Cool music (Oldie rap & hip hop from the 90s!). Dark interior. Smells like a typical chinese restaurant.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Great energy, fun music, kitschy interior design, hit or miss on communal tables. To one side were four college students from New York, who talked surprisingly loudly, both inside and outside the restaurant. (Yes, everyone waits here, even on a Tuesday.) To the other side was a couple with good food knowledge.

Service at Mission Chinese is collective and thus can be indifferent because no personal connection, or accountability, exists with any given table. This led us to not have as much alcohol, or fresh plates, as we'd desired. 

A return visit might be a good idea. My friend and I didn't order well because a) the egg custard with sea urchin and scallop was 86'ed and b) she also doesn't like fish, so we didn't order the salted cod fried rice. 

The pickles were good. The wings very good, but their taste was difficult to determine. We ate them after the Mouth-Watering Chicken, which was fantastically spicy, and might be uncomfortably spicy for some diners. By that point in the meal, we were skittish of the long beans, probably unnecessarily so. 

Due to the mediocre service, we didn't try asking for new plates. The remaining incredibly spicy sauce overwhelmed the taste of the following entrees. Oh well.
author: Mike H.

description: unedible!!. This was the worst Chinese food I have ever had.  Barely touched the food. Our tiger salad I was about to tell the inattentive waitress that we were returning it. Before I could say one word, she said I will take it off the menu. Funny as she recommended it. Never go back!!!!!
author: jane g.

description:
After coming here regularly for the past few months and experiencing the different menu rotations, I really "get" the food here. Take someone like Danny Bowien:  trained in NY and then few stints all over SF (winning Pesto World Championships while he's at it), but now makes Chinese food.

You're gonna get some cool shit going on.

Mission Chinese combines what you think about Chinese food and plays with it. Let's take Mongolian Beef, and put a tender beef cheek into it instead. How about cumin lamb? Let's make that with lamb belly instead.

It makes sense in my mind because he's taking your Chinese flavors and playing around with the cuts of meat or introducing a different technique. A good example of this is the Ma Po Tofu. When you get it, it's Ma Po Tofu in a truly authentic form, but he steps it up by using ground Kurobuta pork shoulder. This isn't your weird goopy messy at a run-of-the-mill Chinese joint. This Ma Po Tofu tastes like what you get in China.

I went yesterday to try out his new dishes using a smoker for "Chinese BBQ". It's funny because he's pairing a Mexican coke/hoisin sauce bbq sauce with a Texas-style BBQ meal. The brisket tastes like a BBQ joint brisket with an Asian twang. You even get the slices of white bread like in Texan BBQ joints. It wasn't my favorite, but the Xian Lamb Cheeks and Pork Trotters were crazy good.

The Kung Pao Corned Beef was my favorite of the night, combining sliced potatoes, chinese celery, roasted peanuts, tossed in a spicy concoction with his house-made corned beef. It sounds weird. It tastes great.

I continually enjoy the food here, and I'm never bored of it.
author: Charles L.

description: I made my first pilgrimage to Mission Chinese on Halloween. The power kept shutting on and off, and it was kind of freezing on the inside. But I think that delicious Chinese Fusion food I've ever eaten. I tried about a little bit of everything on the menu and it was all good. And on the bus or accidentally cleared our food on the table they made us new orders to go. If the line isn't too long you should definitely go and give it a shot.
author: Simonne K.

description:
Thumbs down!! It was loud, dark and hot.  Food is over-rated & over-hyped. What was the food critic smokin? I was so excited about dining at this restaurant after reading the reviews and its high rating from Bon Appetit's. But I was highly disappointed by the 4 entrees I ordered. The Numbing lamb w/ noodles was very salty. Cold Dan Dan noodle was average. Mouth watering Chicken just average.  Everything was just OK nothing spectacular.  The service was somewhat helpful I requested that the fried wings be cooked w/o the red peppers and waitress said it couldn't be done. I ordered anyway because I was curious to try it. Turns out it wasn't hot at all. What was supposed to taste like cilantro didn't taste like it. Won't be returning.
Oh and another thing bathroom was  dirty.
author: Betty F.

description:
There is hype over this restaurant for good reason.
I gathered my foodie friends and drove from Napa to enjoy dinner, I was a bit apprehensive due to a few negative reviews.
Much to my delight the meal was stellar! My friends who all have been involved in the restaurant and wine industry were blown away.
The pork belly - done to perfection
Cumin Lamb - Awsome
Tea smoked eel - I can not wait to eat again
Egg custard - TO DIE FOR
We pretty much ordered the whole menu as we were unable to choose just a few. There was just three of us so we gorged ourselves and had plenty of left overs.
The waitstaff was attentive and fun, our waitress was a cute blonde with a great personality and guided us threw an amazing experience.
We are already planning our nest visit and who we will share this great find with.
As for the negative reviewers, there is always PF Changs!
author: Curtis H.

description:
One of the most interesting things about this place is that it started as a pop-up restaurant from the kitchen of Lung Shan Restaurant in the Mission. Slowly overtime, MCF has essentially taken over the entire restaurant, resulting in lines out the door on a nightly basis.

The second most interesting thing about this place is the food. It's a very unique and traditional take on Chinese food you would find in the Schezhaun region of China. Unique flavors, intense heat, and interesting dishes. Their spicy Chinese wings dish (literally covered in 100 dried chilis) literally made my lips & mouth go numb, but it was soo tasty. Other dishes we very flavorful and the overall cost was pretty low.

Definitely recommend trying this place out at least once. And if you're lazy, they even deliver within most of the ciy.
author: Raza M.

description: This is a real treat. The Kung pao pastrami is my favorite. There are so many really great dishes. The wings are super and give your lips a cool tingle from the spices. Overall it is fun but a bit pricy and seemed to be trying new things. Must go back soon.
author: Leigh S.

description:
Mission Chinese seems to be popular with folks in the Mission so I got delivery. The person taking my order on the phone was helpful, as was the delivery dude. The food arrived quickly, approximately 30 minutes after placing my order.

Ma Po Tofu: Generous portion size. Tender chunks of pork and tofu. Lots and lots of chili peppers. I enjoyed it, though it was unlike any ma po that i've had before. The sauce had a nice peppery flavor, but could have used a touch more salt. I don't know if my spice tolerance is crazy crazy high, but the spice factor (for me) was only a 3/5. Nice, enjoyable burn....no water chugging necessary.

Cumin Lamb: Another large portion, with lots of veggies and chunks of lamb on the bone. The lamb was very tender, but really quite fatty. Its delicious, but prepare yourself for the fattiness/greasiness.

I'd give MCF about 3.5 stars. I'll be back, maybe.
author: T. C.

description:
A little spicy and a lot delicious.

I had a great experience here with Kristin P. and crew. We came on a Friday evening with 4 people and just had to wait a few minutes - come early! We ordered almost everything on the menu, and definitely every veggie option they had. 

The food was great - a little spicy for some dishes. Just be sure you ask for vegetarian items if that's what you're looking for - the tofu is made with fish sauce... things you want to know.

My favorite part? We could bring our own wine. They also weren't eager to kick us out while we sat there to drink the entire bottle. A nice change for the Mission.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Salted Fish Fried Rice. Hands down, the best friend rice I've ever had. It would be tied with Eastlake's salted fish fried rice but what I love best about this dish are the chunks of soft, but not too salty, fish. It's delicious. It's mouth watering. I'm practically drooling over my keyboard just THINKING about it. Whatever you do; whether you stop by for a visit or want to try something or even because you are ravenously hungry, order the salted fish fried rice. It will change your perspective of the world... okay maybe not but it's pretty damn good.

We also ordered this pumpkin vegetable soup dish and it was delicious as well. Really light and earthy which is a favorite texture of mine. Why isnt this place 5 stars? Because its small and gets really crowded... not to mention stuffy. Customer service is great though; definitely meet new people and chat about the rice! Yes, I mention the rice again... rice rice rice. I think I'll drive up there now and get some.
author: Kathleen R.

description:
I walked in a broken man. Body hurt from lifting weights. Mouth hurt from dental work. Brain hurt from a massive meeting.

I walked out still a broken man. But very nourished.

We ordered four dishes and were impressed with each. Not "this is good", more "this is fantastic". Our dishes, all strongly recommended:

- Tiger Salad. Served not as a traditional salad but seaweed and herbs bundled in a thin crepe.

- Fresh Tofu with asparagus. Cold, spicy, perfect.

- Lion's Head Meatball. Pork parts. Chicken parts. Bok choy. Ramen noodles. Marrow broth. Damn.

- Lung Shan's Vegan Delight. Mushroom dumplings, tofu and seaweed. Good for the stomach. Good for the soul.

An awesome dragon runs along the ceiling. Holiday lights are still strung along the walls just like at their previous incarnation, Mission Street Food. Food arrived before we were even done ordering. House wine is smooth and better than you'd imagine.

Sometimes fives stars is awarded not just on food. Or the experience. It's the intangibles, like you just enjoyed something that is uniquely San Francisco, uniquely Mission, uniquely this moment in time. This was a five star meal.
author: Jason B.

description:
Don't believe the hype.

I found the various dishes to be very salty and overly spicy. I once visited Chengdu, China (Sichuan province) - and the cuisine in general was very comparable with that prevalent salt/spicy combination...so if you like that, you might like this.

Also, the menu sounded creative (Kung pao pastrami, etc.), but the flavors left me distant from the Far Eastern euphoria I had been led to believe I would experience.

The service was very friendly in the beginning and in the end, but AWOL throughout, so I never had a chance to notify anyone my drink never came.

It is a neat little spot (decorated well, trendy) in not the greatest of neighborhoods. But the prices were certainly tolerable.
author: Robert B.

description:
After eating here twice, I don't need to come back. I've found the food to be overly flavorful and salty. I was raised on Cantonese style and everyday American cooking and don't get me wrong, I love flavor. That's why Filipino cuisine is one of my favorites. The food here is like no other Chinese food I've eaten! I'm not even sure it's really Chinese. It's definitely interesting and worth trying, since it's different and cheap. You'll wait up to 45 minutes at dinner time to get a table, but once you're in and have ordered, your dishes come out in 10 minutes! Plan to write your name on the list long before you're hungry, go to a bar for a drink or stroll the Mission alleyway murals, then come back after about 30 minutes. 

I've had:

-Tea-smoked Eel: like Chinese sushi with flat rice noodle as the wrapping. Tasty but too much sauce, couldn't taste tea nor eel

-Pork Jowl w/Winter Radishes: Kind of tart and the radishes are super-mini gumball sized. I enjoyed eating them but hardly recall any pork, let alone jowl.

-Chicken Wings: they're actually drummettes, served swimming in a bed of chilies. Spicy and had a real strange slightly citrus, cooling, numbing effect on the tongue. We were wondering if they accidentally dropped something into the seasoning bucket because the sensation in our mouths was so unusual. Bothersome. 

-Salt Cod Fried Rice: it's fried rice, whatever. You could get fried rice in Chinatown for probably $2, not $10. This is one of there least flavorful dishes, meaning it's good to have on hand to balance out everything else. Still, I would save money by ordering plain rice.

-Sizzling Cumin Lamb: very tender, too salty, too much fat, mostly bone.

-Lamb Noodle Soup: a brown broth (think Thai), quite opposite the pale, cooling chicken broth-based soups served in most Cantonese establishments. Flavorful like everything else but nothing to take note of.

-Chow Mein (please pronounce it "meen" w/ a quick, downward tone not "main", because that's incorrect in any dialect!): not bad, good to balance the more flavorful plates but again, I  could get this for a few dollars in Chinatown.

Service: they do not have time to check on you and probably won't refill your water. 

Ambiance: the only lights are white Christmas strands flanking the walls at table height; so dim you squint a little to take a good look at your food. They play kinda loud modern pop/ hip-hop music. And there's a long dragon lantern hanging overhead (because "lung" from the awning outside means "dragon").
author: Kimberly D.

description:
Too spicy, too crowded, and mexican chinese fusion at its worst.

I should have stuck with my guns on not eating at a non Mexican place in the mission....

As much as I tried to like this place, the spices overwhelmed everything we ate.  I have this weird tendency to have scalp sweat when I eat something spicy, and I dont think this place was worth the discomfort.
author: SF Diner A.

description:
Oddly, the standout here for me was the barbeque menu - in a city that has terrible barbeque places, the "chinese" bbq here was probably actually the best I've had in SF and could have easily just passed for "texan." 

Agree with other reviewers that the food didn't seem to have the "umami" one expects with Chinese food but maybe that's due to the lack of MSG.  They seemed to compensate with an abundance of chili peppers in everything.

Fun place for a group, fun place to try oddball dishes, fun place to sweat while you eat.
author: Anthony L.

description:
This past weekend, my roommates got delivery from Mission Chinese Food. We ordered two orders of the Mapo Tofu and one serving of the Salt Cod Fried Rice. It took around an hour for our food to come. We were in the $4 delivery charge area. When I was ordering the Mapo Tofu, I asked how many it could serve. The person on the phone said that it was usually for one person, who would end up with some leftovers. But--I KID YOU NOT, that's NOT true. Well, it's not true for me and my roommates. One serving (tub) of Mapo Tofu served all three Asian girls. FYI, I eat A LOT! 

The Mapo Tofu was very spicy, and I really liked it, actually. I was expecting it to be alright, especially since it didn't seem authentic. I'm great with spicy, but man--it was super spicy! Maybe, it was also because my roommates and I had champagne with it (bubbly and spicy DO NOT MIX, note to self). I wish the tofu were cut into smaller pieces so that it could soak up more of the sauce flavor. The meat (pork) in it was very good as well.

The Salt Cod Fried Rice was good as well, but not amazing. I probably wouldn't order it again, and try other things. I liked that it wasn't overly flavorful. Actually, it was closer to bland (in a good way). Still, like I said, it wasn't amazing. You could taste the small cod pieces, barely.

Well, another 7x7 item crossed off my list!
author: Vera W.

description:
I'm thinking it's more of a 3-1/2 stars. But to preface, when I went there, I was suffering from hanger (hunger which made me angry). I get real irritable when I'm hungry so it may have influenced my review a bit.

We got there a little after 9 pm on a Thursday evening and we had to wait about 40 minutes to be seated and share a table w/ two random people who got seated before us. The place is crowded with hipsters.  I'm not a big fan of hipsters, but if you are one, you will fit right in. Side note: I don't come to SF often anymore but I can't believe how much the Mission has become gentrified and I assume restaurants like this are a sign of that. 

But to the food, we ordered the egg custard, pork belly, and mapo tofu. The egg custard came out first and was delicious. It had all my favorites in it - egg, uni, and ikura. Yum. I wish it had come out last b/c it was almost dessert like.

The pork belly and mapo tofu came next. I liked the pork belly. It was very fatty but cooked well. I liked the mapo tofu the least. I like spicy food but it was too spicy to enjoy. 

The servers were nice, so not a typical Chinese joint. I may try it again when I'm not hangry and see if I like it better.
author: S L.

description:
I want to start this review with a quote from GQ food writer Alan Richman: "The place I'd want to eat once a week. I couldn't stay away. Everything I eat here is a fantasy fulfilled in how I want Chinese food to taste. Next time I'm going to San Francisco, it'll be one of my first stops." Richman has not always enjoyed Bay Area food, but he is a man I trust when it comes to food recommendations. That being said, I checked out this talked-about restaurant the other day - let's just say that Mission Chinese (and Richman) did not disappoint. 

The food is terrific and the flavors are bold (not to mention all meats and vegetables are local organic). Many of Mission's dishes are precisely as "Chinese" as its owner Danny Bowien (who never cooked Chinese food until he opened his restaurant). 

Food to taste: 
- Westlake Rice Porridge - is a perfectly-hearty, simple yet deep-flavored dish - braised oxtail, dungeness crab,  and hints of cilantro and ginger.
- Thrice Cooked Bacon - a "must" for any bacon lover. Thick, mouth-watering strips of bacon, rice cake, scallions, chili oil.
- Kung Pao Pastrami - If you enjoy spicy food, this has a kick (and then some). Slices of pastrami with explosive flavors of poblano and serrano chilis.

Also recommended:
- Escolar and chinese salad
- Chinese custard

Things to note:
- Cheap prices (accepts plastic)
- Dress casual (think diner / dive style)
- Get there before 6pm to avoid the line
- No reservations
- Don't be fooled by its awning - Mission Chinese Food is housed inside a pre-existing, old-style Chinese spot called Lung Shan.  

As Richman said, "I think Bowien is a secret genius." I absolutely agree. His story is fantastic, but his food is even better. This is a must try for any San Franciscan with an appreciation and love for food.
author: Alex H.

description: I hardly ever write bad reviews. But seriously, I don't understand. I'm hoping I just came on a "bad night" but this place was less than mediocre. As in, not good. Like, I'll probably never go back to give it a second try.
author: Krystal A.

description: I've heard alot of hype around mission chinese food and had to give it a whirl.  Always tough to revert to Chinese when you pass 15 burrito shops along mission street, this place was Impressive. On a Friday night, we waited all of 10 min to get seated.  The Menu was not traditional Chinese food and it felt like each item had a bit of a twist that made the choices intriguing.  Also, with blink 182 playing in the background, it didn't feel like a traditional Chinese restaurant. They start you off with fried chick peas to wet the whistle and we started off with the cucumbers that were refreshing. We got ma po tofu and the cherry glazed ribs. The tofu was very fresh (not too much oil) , and had a spicy kick to it that required a side of rice. The ribs were fantastic. They fell right off the bone and and the dark cherry glaze was perfect.
