The best Chinese  place I've been to in the mission.
author: Steven G.

description:
Another disappointment from the 7x7 list... I was excited to come here to try out some good chinese food. We didn't even have to wait, because we came fairly early (around 11:45) on a Sunday. 

We tried the pork belly, beef cheeks with chinese broccoli, porridge, szechwan pickles, dan dan noodles, and the smoked eel roll. All the dishes were ok, but nothing really stood out. Everything is quite spicy and flavorful, particularly the dan dan noodles (spicy).

I did like the porridge, and I think I might come get takeout porridge the next time I'm craving it. Otherwise, I wasn't that impressed, maybe I'm just not as into that style of chinese food (szechuan?), but I probably won't be back to eat here, especially if I need to wait.
author: Erin Y.

description: Passable. Got the Ma Po Tofu, fried rice, a noodle dish, and the vinegar peanuts. Don't know what the big deal is. Wasn't that delicious. Was edible.
author: Courtney C.

description:
M ethod Man blaring as you eat Chinese
I t's that type of restaurant
S etting is hipster-friendly
S ervers are hipsters themselves
I t kinda smells hipster, too
O rders don't come as fast as in traditional Chinese spots
N ot complaining, though -- food is made well

C ome for the Salt Cod Fried Rice
H ave to, have to, have to, have to try it
I t's flavored perfectly and isn't greasy
N ot getting Ma Po Tofu again -- wayyy too spicy
E nded up with a burning mouth all night
S low-cooked Char Siu Pork Belly is nice
E xtra crispy and juicy, the way it should be 

F ound the Thrice Flavored Bacon interesting
O ozes with flavors of bittermelon and, um, bacon 
O nly liked the Brocolli Beef for its tender braised meat 
D idn't care for the rest of the dish
author: Anthony N.

description:
This isn't how grandma used to make it! 

Started the meal with the ma po tofu. The flavors were pretty damn good from what I could taste other than the burning of my mouth. I like my food spicy but not so much it makes it hard to taste a dish. So basically with this dish you have a few seconds for your brain to recognize some flavors before the heat comes in. 

Next came the slow-cooked char sui pork belly. Should've been called slow-cooked pork fat because the dish consisted of a fatty cut of pork belly that hardly had any lean meat. 

Last came the "one pound" of salt and pepper shrimp. Definitely not one pound of shrimp unless u count the mountain of onions it came with. This dish wasn't exciting at all. Shrimp with curry powder dumped on it. 

Service is worse than an authentic Chinese restaurant. Had to ask for my soda three times before it came and another table of two that sat 5 minutes after us got their orders in before. 

Menu items no doubt have a flare on chinese food which was a good experience but not for the best.
author: Eric L.

description: This place really disappointed me, so I thought I would leave some feedback. We called ahead and were instructed that we were on the list, but when we arrived the employee managing the list would not talk to us and we did not seem to be on the list. I understand that he was very busy, but he did not have the common decency to speak to my friend and I at all. I eventually decided to go into the restaurant to speak with someone and spoke to a nice employee that instructed me to go back outside and she would inform the man managing the list that we needed to speak with him. We waited for another 15 minutes and finally the man came outside again and I tried to speak with him. He absolutely ignored me. I'm sure the food may be good (full disclosure I haven't tried it), but I'm not sure any food is worth this type of rude behavior. I could tell this is a restaurant that does not value its customers as highly as it should, and has employees that do not have the common decency to even speak to people who are not being pushy and are only seeking answers as to whether or not they are waisting their time. I will not be going back.
author: Miles W.

description: I hate to do this... but this food was such a fail.  Caveat:  experience was for take-out (but promptly eaten) food, not dine-in.  Online ordering is a cinch, though and food was ready on time.  All selections were extremely oily, greasy, and overspiced with meat(s) that were too dry and meagerly portioned overpowered by breading and coatings.  I have heard that Mission Chinese is hit or miss depending on the evening and on which items, but trying nearly half the menu, I'm not impressed.
author: Rachel A.

description:
A friend from Chicago sent me a review of this place ages ago, and last week, he finally made it out here to try it -- you can imagine the months-long build-up. We went for lunch on a Saturday afternoon, fully expecting a long wait, but much to our surprise, we were seated right away. 

The ambiance of the place leaves something to be desired - if you want to use the restroom, be prepared to walk through the kitchen and stand next to trash and recycling bins - but the food was solid, and reasonably priced. However, if you're looking for traditional Chinese food, this is NOT the place. If you're ready to try some combinations you've never had before, you're in for a treat.

The two dishes we had that stood out were the thrice-cooked bacon and kung pao pastrami. The bacon dish was light on the bacon, but the perfect flavors and abundance of rice cakes made up for it. The kung pao pastrami was ridiculously spicy but completely worth it. Just order a beer and you'll be fine.
author: Jane H.

description:
Lung Shan's Vegan Delight, Hainam Chicken Rice, Slow-Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly, Braised Mongolian Beef Cheek, Broccoli Beef

We'd had an interesting conversation about it on the way back from Napa the day before. When I'd floated the idea of Mission Street for dinner, she went looking online for their menu and via Yelp came across not only a rather ordinary looking Chinese food menu, but some equally bland "what's the big deal and why do people love this place?" reviews. I was perplexed since I'd been looking at a menu with some rather authentic-sounding and exotic dishes and the reviews to match. We soon puzzled out that they actually have two menus. I assume one is meant for the mouth-breathing Gwailo and the other for the locals. We ordered from the interesting menu and were rewarded. I have to admit that for every dish we got, there were two others that we were closely considering. We'll have to try an all new assortment next time.

We're told that the order will take an hour to arrive and are glad that we put the order in early to accommodate the girls when they get off the show floor. Half an hour later we hear a knock at the hotel door. Props and an extra star for sheer speed in San Francisco rush hour.

I tasted only a spoon of the soup, it having been ordered by Katelyn, a semi-lapsed vegan who I figure might be trying to avoid the rest of the meat-heavy order. It's tasty miso broth, and she assured us all in strident tones that the mushroom dumplings were good as well.

The group agreed that the absolute favorite was the Hainam Chicken Rice. Something about the combination of bits of chicken meat, peanut, and heavy application of chicken fat made it irresistible. Even after I was full, I found myself going back for another fork of that rice.

My only disappointment was the pork belly. In general when I think of pork belly and slow cooking, I figure that the result will be a great deal of the fat rendered out over time and tender, succulent meat left behind. The cubes of pork belly in our order are 90% fat. I excised the meat from between the fat layers and there is a nice-sized snack. I will admit, however, that this is likely the result of my own expectations and that this presentation may well have been perfectly pleasing to the intended native palate. Both the soy-cured egg and the ginger scallion noodles that came with it were delicious, though.

We went beef heavy on the other two dishes. Had I realized that Janelle's Broccoli Beef contained the same beef cheeks that the other Mongolian dish did, I might have opted for one of the other dozen or so dishes that were in the running, just for the sake of variety. The meat was delicious and tender in both preparations. I loved the fresh horseradish flavor in the Mongolian version, and the inclusion of actual poached oysters in addition to a smoked oyster sauce and Chinese broccoli signaled that this was not the beef broccoli that I'm likely to get from my strip mall sweet and sour joint at home.

I really enjoyed this food. Add in the possibility of delivery and I'm pretty sure that Mission Chinese will become a staple of our future visits.
author: Ryan C.

description: Inventive food, good atmosphere with decent music and nice beer. The sour chilli chicken I had was really interesting and I ate it all, but it could have done with more flavour, as could the dumplings, but again, nice. The highlight weirdly enough was the vinegar boiled peanuts with garlic, really interesting and delicious. Kind of hipsterish, but I'd go back to try some of what seemed on the menu like other cool taste combinations.
author: Chris M.

description:
3.3/5 get yo paawk dumb-lings!

this is an interesting spot--i mean this is what i get for going to the mission for chinese. don't get me wrong, the food isn't bad, it is different though. you are not getting traditional chinese, not getting fusion either. it is more..a different interpretation. get the pork dumplings, the broth is quite tasty. if i were to go back, i'd order that just for myself and not share!

you may want to ask your server what other folks have ordered, and considering getting/avoiding that. we had to wait about half an hour for some fried rice--which is ridic for a chinese restaurant. that should always be on hand and ready to go. the server was great about it and docked it off our bill though, since it was so delayed. so overall, it was still a good experience, considering that courtesy.
author: Alvin D.

description:
I love this place. I crave it when I don't have it often enough. Jared and I have been coming here for the last six months or so, every few weeks, and I'm in love with it every single time. 

I also have a solid chef crush on Danny Bowien, but that's neither here nor there. Ahem.

I usually get the eggplant, which is magically unlike any other eggplant, anywhere. It's spicy and lovely and the texture isn't that weirdo thing that eggplant sometimes is, but is rather perfect. The cold noodle salad is pretty delicious, as well, with lots of spicy goodness paired with little slices of sweet tofu. Jared is pretty devoted to the ma po tofu, but I keep encouraging him to try the bbq (full disclosure: this restaurant is perhaps the only one that repeatedly makes me a little sad to be a long time vegetarian) so that he can rave about that, too. 

The place is a dive, but I appreciate its charm as such. There is always, always, always a good play list going (last week it was mid-90's hip hop, the week before that old metal). I like going there mid-day, when it's not quite lunch and not quite dinner, and have some tea and listen to Biggie and eat some yummy food. Word.
author: heather c.

description:
While the food was tasty (ma-po tofu and sizzling cumin lamb), my friend and I agreed we wouldn't dine in again,but would be open to take out or delivery.

The ma po tofu was seriously hot (but not enough to give me the hiccups), but still had enough flavor apart from the spice.  I wouldn't recommend it if your stomach is really sensitive to spicy hot food.  The sizzling cumin lamb dish was good, although there were quite a few grisly bits and we had more onions than lamb and green beans combined, leaving a serious pile of onions behind.  

The atmosphere was just bizarre for us. It looks Chinese owned and run (except for the servers which I can only assume was to cater to the hipster patrons) with Nicki Minaj and reggae blasting through the speakers so loud you could barely hear each other talk, while you sit elbow to elbow with a bunch of other kids. It's definitely a scene.

When I eat spicy food, however, I want room a little to breathe, and you don't get that here (go figure, it's the Mission).  I had a coughing fit because a pepper flake got stuck in my windpipe; and having two strangers elbow to elbow with me at the same table just isn't a good situation for anybody. And maybe I felt I was in the Twilight Zone since I haven't seen many (if any) Chinese-Chinese (- assumingly) establishments having a white American front of house - no feelings one way or another other than saying it feels like I'm in a parallel universe. :)  I guess if you're going to see it anywhere you'll see it in the Mission.

Overall, it's pretty good food but the atmosphere dominates.  If I want to enjoy the food, it'll be take out next time.
author: L K.

description:
Is the food worth all the hype? The short answer is no.

The crowds of people hanging around outside the unassuming Lung Shan Chinese had piqued my interest in this Mission Street eatery, but the crowd hovering around outside had always dissuaded me from trying it out. After a few attempts to make it when the list wasn't 10+ people deep, I finally came at 6pm on a Monday night and there was no wait. We were greeted by a waitress that must have been just about to get off, as she wasn't helpful answering questions about the food and after we ordered we never saw her again. But then again no one comes to Mission Chinese for the service or ambience, the vibe is all about the food here.

We ordered the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts, Salt Cod Fried Rice, and the Catfish ala Sichuan Soup. The Beijing Vinegar Peanuts came in a small bowl and were a decent side but not really sufficient as an appetizer. The anise and vinegar seasoning on the roasted peanuts made my taste buds smile. The Salt Cod Fried Rice was tasty enough but it was really difficult to identify any cod bits actually in it. Sichuan usually implies spicy and the soup was pretty plain and had a strange bitter/sour taste, especially the marinated pinto beans floating around in it. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing, but I'm really not sure why GQ's Alan Richman named Mission Chinese Food on his annual list of the 10 Best New Restaurants in America.

If the place is packed when you stop in I recommend Dante's Weird Fish, seafood deliciousness, or Reaction, cheaper Mexican fare with great inexpensive drinks, across the street as alternatives.
author: Carrie G.

description:
The first time I tried this place, I simply had a take out order of the salt cod fried rice, and I must say it was delicious and that dish itself deserved a 5 stars.

However, the second time around it was also take out and my boyfriend ordered more dishes (7 total) I believe, and I must say, the overall dinner experience was just okay. Some stuff were too spicy for me, others barely had any meat, and if it did, it was just fat. I don't think my boyfriend's dad even touched that particular dish. Oh, and they forgot our order of chow mein, we had to call in for them to deliver it back to us, and that single order took over an hour, and by that time we've already ate everything else and was already cleaning the dishes. I also found the chow mein EXTREMELY salty, kept chugging water to wash down the saltiness on my tongue. 

Maybe I grew up eating Chinese food my whole life which is why I particularly grade harsher on it, but still, I wouldn't go back for anything else but the salt cod fried rice.
author: Harriet W.

description: Other than Burma superstar, this is the one and only other restaurant I'm willing to wait in line for.  There is something about Chinese comfort re-interpreted and made with amazing ingredients along with some French techniques thrown in.  Don't come here if you want old school dimsum or traditional flavors.  That isn't the point of this place.  The point is to try and have inventive Asian flavors (all in a really traditional Chinese restaurant setting) while you're there.  The flavors are in your face, nothing subtle about it.  And the price point is more than fair given what you are paying for.
author: Melissa H.

description:
This is a great place. Inventive menu, friendly staff, everything prepared to the highest standards.  The specifics: salt cod fried rice: my Chinese friend found it only ok. To him it needed more chinese sausage (i respectfully disagree)but we agree that it was very good. The squid ink paparadelle with lamb sausage and maybe pea tendrils was ridiculously good. I could take a bath in it. 
the slow cooked pork belly with roasted pineapple. Very heavy but very good--in moderation.  Actually i thought the roasted pineapple could have used more roasting.  The braised beef and chinese broccoli was wonderful. The beef was very tender and the broccoli had a simple but great flavor.  I thought the dish would be improved if the meat were not smoked. It was slow cooked and that would have sufficed.  I had a unique and great Japanese beer I've never seen. Overall really cool place. Oh, its loud and fast, so not a quiet romantic hideaway type of place.
author: A W.

description:
I mean...

3 things...

1) Over-rated
2) SOOO EFFING SPICY!!!!
3) Poor service

So... Here's the thing... I LOVE spicy food... When I go to thai restaurants I order things 10/10 on the spicy level... If a place is super gangster I'll take a 9 or work my way slowly back to an 8 until they can prove to me that they bring the heat...

I love to sweat from spiciness...  Get it?   I like spicy food... I love it...

This place... Was ALL SPICE... We had the:

Thrice Cooked Bacon (3 star)
Numbing Lamb Face Noodles(2 star)
Tea Smoked Eel (2 star) 
and 
Szechuan Pickles (5 star)

The only thing that wasn't super spicy was the Tea Smoked Eel and it was nothing to write home about... The taste of the Eel was lost in too much rice noodle on the outside, although I thought it was pretty.

All of the dishes looked good coming out... I would be willing to wager that the VAST majority of people that eat here can not tolerate the massive amounts of spice that is used...  

Our service was poor, waited the entire meal for the opportunity to order another beer to put the flames out in my throat, but was never given the chance...

If I had waited more than 10 minutes like some people say (1 hour) I would be very upset...  

Honestly don't think I'll be back... The combinations are unique, the menu looks great on paper, but in practice, they are missing the mark in my opinion... Cut waay back on the salt, waaay back on the spice, or at least don't make your standard spice atomic, and give people the option to opt in, instead of out...

Definitely a hipster place through and through... 

Better options at Big Lantern on 16th...
author: Will W.

description:
This is definitely not your normal chinese restaurant. Loud music, dim red-lighting, hipsters.

The atmosphere was cool but the food was at best, just OK. My friend and I got the pork belly and the kung pao pastrami.

The waitress let us know that the pork belly was an appetizer but the portion was big enough for 2. This dish was pretty good.

The kung pao pastrami was so spicy I couldnt even really taste the flavors.  I think if it wasn't as spicy it would have tasted a lot better. It was also too salty for my taste.

I would go back to possibly try other dishes but I think this place is more about the hype than good ole chinese food.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Been wanting to come here for years and finally made it. What a big disappointment. Don't know what the big hype was all about. The salted cod fried rice was bland and under seasoned with no salted cod flavor to be found. The Chinese broccoli beef was over cooked (because the broccoli was not cut into even pieces but just hacked up) and the beef brisket should not be used as it is too dry of a cut. The so called "pork jowl" was simply roast pork and not from the jowl of the pig. Not worth the high prices. I should have read the 1-2 star reviews before because they are all accurate.
author: Mr S.

description: Good pork-belly, but overall this place is over-rated & weak. Despite the attention from NYT- this place is mediocre food at best
author: Gary T.

description:
The pregnant fiancé and I were craving Chinese food, so we left Japantown/Lower Pacific Heights hood to try Mission Chinese. Fortunately, the wait was short. We stood outside for ~ 20 minutes on a beautiful January evening, before we were seated. While waiting we studied Yelp reviews and the menu to decide what we wanted for dinner. 

Once seated, we put in our order Bundaberg Ginger Beer, Tsingtao Beer, Pork Belly appetizer, Salty Cod Fried Rice and Cumin Lamb. The fiancé is not normally a big fan of pork belly or lamb, but she loved both dishes; polishing off most of the lamb by herself. She also found the pork belly to be really good because it was cooked to crispy perfection. Normally she can't handle the fatty bit of the pork belly. Me, I like lamb, but I am not a huge cumin fan, so I found the cumin lamb edible, but not my cup of tea. We both loved the Salty Cod Fried Rice. I know other reviewers have mentioned that there was not enough salt or cod in the fried rice, but we thought it was seasoned well. We do however agree, that it could have used a little more cod. 

What really impressed us was the service personnel. From the perky hostess to the amiable waitresses, they deserve a 5-star rating. The food was delivered quickly, and at the right temperature. 

My recommendation is that our buddy Chuy from H&B visit this establishment with his familia. 

We'd happily dine at Mission Chinese again, should we be in the area, but wouldn't make special trip to dine there.
author: Jaime R.

description:
The very best delivery food, ever.   I had so much fun eating everything because all the dishes were unique and exploding with unexpected flavors.  After eating almost the entire menu, here is the list of what to eat and what not to eat. 

EAT. 

Salt cod fried rice - must eat every time. 
Tiger salad -  a vegan/vegetarian's dream roll!  Its loads of dark green veggies wrapped in flat rice noodle with sauce drizzled on top.  
Tea-smoked eel - same idea as tiger salad but with tea-smoked eel.
West lake rice porridge - if you like porridge, this is the very best with beautiful boiled egg and huge chunks of crab and oxtail meat.

SKIP.

Pork Belly
Lung Shan Vegan Delight

SO-SO

Taiwanese Eggplant
Salt and Pepper Shrimp 
Szechuan Pickles
author: Wakako U.

description: There is a reason why there's a line out the door and why they have a 3.5 star review...this place is amazing...and the staff isn't warm cuz they've gotta turn the table so please don't hold  the place up...I'm probably waiting for your seat outside ;)
author: Yadira A.

description:
Guys, I like hipsters.  I really really like hipsters.  Especially hipster girls who look adorable in their glasses that are way too large.  BUT SERIOUSLY, STOP TRYING TO MAKE CHINESE FOOD.  

Now Ian H and I live nearby, and we were always curious about the place as there are typically long lines trying to get in.  Fortunately for us, last week, we decided to have dinner late, and came in on a day where only a couple of tables were full.  It being Chinese food, we decided to order family style.  We got...

Chinese Pickle - Fairly standard cabbage and nuts combo.  This was the highlight of the evening because I actually finished it.  Still, I wish that there was more than one slice of actual pickle in the portion.  You know, just in case I wanted to share it. 

Mapo Tofu - Ian H really likes Mapo Tofu.  I am okay with.  This was TERRIBLE Mapo Tofu.  Actually, the tofu itself was okay, but the sauce was way too viscous and tasted off.  We could barely finish half the portion before setting it aside. 

Lamb Dumplings - I love dumplings.  LOVE DUMPLINGS.  I would eat them all the time if I could.  BUT NOT THESE DUMPLINGS.  Cause seriously, the skin was too thick and starchy, and the lamb filling was so strong in taste that it drowned out any other kind of flavor, so even the liberal dose of the soy sauce with ginger could not be felt.  Eew.  Eeeeew.  We each had one and then didn't try to eat any more. 

So, in conclusion, if you want Chinese food, stay away from the inner mission.  Go to the Richmond.  Mmmm, good Chinese food.

2 Hip-stars
author: Leon K.

description: Just ate there for the first time a couple days ago. I love it. They have plenty of vegetarian options. The dishes are original and modestly priced. They also have their own beer that has pepper in it - a surprisingly delicious beer.
author: C S.

description: Monday night, last night in San Fran before heading back to NYC, I'll admit, I came to Mission Chinese Food with pretty high expectations. People rave about it so I figured I'll try the original location before the NYC one. After asking the waiter for his recommendations, he recommended the Kung Pow Pastrami and the Tiger Salad. Also ordered some beer that arrived "cool" at best. The wait was much longer than expected, especially not being busy (5 tables) and being a "Chinese" restaurant. The tiger salad was wrapped in a sheet of soft rice paper and a decent portion. The dressing was flavorful, but almost too flavorful. Until I tried the pastrami... Salt x 10000. The pastrami is well made and the vegetables stir fried decently but the sodium level was off the charts. Also, there was barely a hint of kung pow seasoning, or maybe it was completely overpowered by the pastrami. The rice that I imagined would had to have come with it never appeared. So I ordered a bowl of rice that came with majority of it piled above the bowl. Overall, it wasn't that good. Maybe I ordered the wrong dish, but still, way too hyped up.
author: Ray H.

description:
I've been hearing about this place for days. It was advertised to me as a late night eats aka beer munchies, but I came here for lunch to avoid the wait. This place is pretty much in the ghetto part of Mission and it's definitely not the cleanliest place in the world. Despite all this, this place is damn good. Here's what my boo and I had:

- Salt cod fried rice: Rice was delicious but it def seemed to be fried rice sans salt cod. I love how they chopped the chinese sausage in super small slices, because the sausage is pretty salty otherwise. 
- Cumin lamb ribs: This is a must order dish!!! It's a pretty unique / fusion type dish. The cumin lamb comes out on a sizzling plate w/ tons of onions. The lamb is incredibly tender and falls off the bone. They also throw on some pickled onions on top of the lamb to cut some of the richness of the lamb. Disclaimer: the lamb was incredibly fatty which is an awesome plus but can put some people off as well.
- Kung pao pastrami: Another amazing dish. The pastrami comes out in lil chunks that burst of flavor. It is accompanied by red bell peppers, celery, and topped off with sesame seeds. Again, you can't eat a ton of this at a time because it's pretty rich / greasy but if you love spicy food then you'll love this dish.

Oh yes, and I want to mention that you will be paying about a $2 hipster premium on every dish. This place ain't cheap, but I'd definitely come here again!
author: Grace Y.

description:
I was utterly baffled by this place. The confusion started when I was reading reviews and half of the crowd called it "too" authentic and therefore unpalatable, and the other half called it inauthentic but great. It only got worse when I found two menus at the restaurant serving completely different food. Long story short: not good.

I opted to order entirely off the Mission Chinese menu, since those dishes seemed a bit more specialized and unique. 

My friend and I got the wontons (you just can't pass that up when you see the guy making them at the dumpling stand in the window), the spicy chicken wings, and the Chinese broccoli with braised beef cheek. The spicy chicken wings were buried under a mountain of dried red chili peppers. The wings themselves were coated in the numbing Sichuan peppercorn that gives ma po tofu its name, and were a treat to eat. I've never lost sensation in my tongue before, and I loved it. It still makes me laugh when I think about it.

The meal was just downhill from there. The wontons themselves were very good, but came in a ham hock? broth that was salty and smoky, and only masked the flavor of the freshly wrapped wontons. The braised beef cheek had that exact same smoky flavor, and although the meat was perfectly tender, that flavor just completely threw me off. In general, the individual components of everything were very good, but somehow combined to become one great big disappointing flop. In the end, I left with the impression that the restaurant was just trying too hard to make it look like..well, like they weren't trying at all. 

The haphazard decor, casually dressed waiters, and unsuccessful mock fusion food, while interesting, make this a been-there-done-that experience for me. Hipster Chinese - at least I can say I've tried it.
author: Lucia C.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night thinking we'd avoid the crowd. It wasn't so bad at 7pm but by the time we were halfway through dinner, there was a huge crowd outside. Ridiculous! 

Ordered the spicy chicken wings, salt cod fried rice, and the pork belly. Not too shabby. 

The spicy chicken wings come out covered in red peppers so it's a wow factor. Spice level was alright, didn't really live up to the "two peppers" on the menu. But the chicken wings themselves were really good. Extra crispy, not oily. Yum! 

The salt cod fried rice was all right. I've had better for sure. A lot of people say you can taste the salted cod in every bite, I had the opposite experience. It just was like fried rice with a few bites of salted cod. 

The pork belly dish was completely random based on it's plating. The chef decided to get super fancy eh? Not too bad. I wish the pork belly skin was crispier and not so chewy, but it was still good. 

All in all... I'd come back to try out a few more dishes, but I don't really understand the hype or the wait time...
author: Jeannie L.

description:
To me, all Chinese restaurants are the same.  They only vary depending on the amount of MSG they use in their dishes.  So that's the expectation I had coming here.

It looked like a regular Chinese restaurant, untidy and small.  But there was a wait.  The only time I've had to wait for a Chinese restaurant was for dim sum.  The wait wasn't that long though - 15 minutes for a party of two.

My friend and I ordered three dishes - Salted Cod Fried Rice, Spicy Ma Po Tofu, and Cumin Lamb.  All three dishes were delish and the portions were ginormous.  The Ma Po Tofu was the size of... ma head.  Our order could've fed about two more people.  And all under $40 while gangsta music plays in the background.  Love.
author: Linh V.

description:
I understand that I am a white girl and that my understanding of authentic Chinese food is lacking, but I love the food here. In fact, this has to be my favorite Chinese food spot in San Francisco.

I love the Char Siu Pork Belly, the Sizzling Cumin Lamb, and the Veal Ribs.  I could have passed on the Chicken Wings w/ Explosive Chili Peppers (way too dry).  Mission Chinese does have vegan/vegetarian options, but this place is really known for it's meat dishes.

Despite the amazing food, I don't know if I'd go back.  The seating is really cramped and music was too loud to hold a conversation without straining the vocal cords (I won't complain about the wait because this is San Francisco and any place that's good has a line). 

Luckily Mission Chinese delivers and does take-out.  I can't wait to eat some pork belly in bed on a rainy day.
author: Lara O.

description:
This place has nasty tasting food. Reminds me of really bad chinese food in Chinatown.

The only saving grace is their ambiance is unique and the music selection is pretty dope.
author: food y.

description:
I've come here twice and the wait has been over two hours. (Never would I wait this long!) So I came for lunch (there wasn't a wait at all) and ordered a of couple things. 

I had the Spicy Chicken Wings: way too spicy which is all that I tasted. No salty or savory taste but just spiciness. Skip.
Mongolian Long Beans: spicy with more flavor, I'd get this again
Thrice cooked bacon: to die for. must have

Service: completely terrible. I saw my server twice - once to take our order and the second time was to drop off our food. No water refill, no extra napkins, nada. Oh, hipsters.
author: Joy A.

description:
Here is my very own S.A.T. analogy:  "MCF is to the Mission as Bettlenut is to the Marina".  (Aaaahhh, Mission and Marina in the same sentence...gasp!!!)

So, my officemate *raved* like a lunatic about the ma-po-tofu and other dishes, yet it took me months to check this place out.  Fear of hipster chinese food.  The verdict: the tofu was alright, sorta spicy, not jaw dropping.  The salt-cod fried rice was tasty, but salty and rice usually is good.  I've wouldn't go out my way to return.

Bottom line: It may be "wow" and "different flavors" if you haven't really been to a chinese chinese restaurant.   If you have, skip MCF and head to clement st. 

Note: I ain't no Chinese food expert, but a red flag was that the menu had dishes from 3-4 different provences in China and also Taiwan. China's a big place....the food varies tremendously by region.
author: Caroline I.

description:
Damn, haters!!!  "It's too hipster...wah wah wah...why so much love...wah wah wah."  

It's delicious.  It's completely different from 99% of the Chinese restaurants in the city.  It's not insanely priced.  It's got great music.  

My beef with the hot wings is that they taste amazing but they were a bit too dry and the presentation, while impressive, annoys my green sensibilities: there are 7 wings on the plate served on a bed of fried red chilies.  So basically, the entire plate of chilies are garnish.  What a waste.

The rest of the food:  phenomenal.  Get the Tiger Salad (kinda like a soft Thai roll but amazing flavor and a delicious spicy dressing), the hainan rice, the bok choy (hands down the best bok choy - perfectly cooked, delicious sauce, succulent mushrooms...ummm....) The Chinese BBQ platter had the most tender, perfectly cooked brisket served with a Coca-Cola BBQ sauce.  The Mongolian beef was a bit too spicy for my tastes but very flavorful and perfectly made.

We went at 6:15 and had no trouble getting in.  Just go.  You'll love it.  Don't listen to the haters.
author: A S.

description:
There are so few restaurants in the city where I actually feel my mind getting blown.

I came here the other night with some friends and got a chance to order a few of the options I've never had before, and here's the rundown (from memory, several days later):

* thrice-cooked bacon: tasted very odd to me, but everyone else at the table adored it.
* salt cod fried rice: the most "normal"-tasting entree we got, it was just a kick above what you'd expect elsewhere.
* ma po: holy effing jesus, I don't know what they did to it, but I think I spotted some cloves in there. I was glad I was the one who ended up with this one to take home.
* some other fried rice thing: super good. We all agreed it was our favorite.
* seven wings chicken: spicy as all get-out and a complex flavor to boot. Highly recommended, but there's not much chicken under that pile of chilies.
* tingly lamb noodle soup: the lamb was tender, but I felt no such tingle. One tablemate disagreed.

I'm pretty sure that was it. I'm sorry I can't remember what that super good other fried rice thing was, but I promise when I figure it out I'll edit this review.

You're probably going to sit really close to people you don't know, and whether you like it or not, you're probably going to listen to metal. Just deal with it and enjoy your food. It's REALLY good.
author: Amy Z.

description:
This place has way too much hype than it should be. It's very hipster!

Szechuan pickles -okay but spicy, 

Thrice Cooked Bacon - bacon very salty and dish oily and spicy, would have liked this over plain steamed rice instead of rice cakes

Numbing Lamb Face Biang Biang Mien - This dish was truly numbing to the point I couldn't finish. My tongue was singed and acidified. That taste stayed with me sooo long, I wanted ice cream for dinner. 

I think I had toooo many dishes with heat back to back. It IS a very popular restaurant though. The wait wasn't too bad to sit down but the wait between dishes was longer than it should be. I noticed almost every table ordered the salted cod fried rice dish and mustard greens BUT why order those?? Those weren't special enough for me to try. I had to try something different. Heck, maybe their fried rice is out of this world. Just try it out and have your expectation in check.  It's definitely a hole in the wall type of place in a shady area. Be sure to balance your dishes with plain stuff too otherwise be prepared for an overload of bold and spicy flavors. The place knows it because they give you a jug of  tap water when you sit down
author: May B.

description:
Hidden gem in the Mission.

My boyfriend and I watched the making of several orders of dumplings from the front window while waiting for our name to be called. The wait was not extremely long, but some people were turned off by the long list of names.

We had looked at the menu online while we were waiting and already had our dishes picked out. We ordered salt cod fried rice, sizzling cumin lamb, meatball soup (can't remember the name of the dish), and dumpling soup. Yes, we had to ordered 4 dishes knowing we would not come close to finishing it.

The cumin lamb was by FAR our favorite dish. The spices and flavoring were amazing. Our next favorite was the fried rice, but as many mentioned the amount of cod in the fried rice was a bit disappointing. The other two dishes were unmemorable even though the dumpling guy making the dumplings looked super cool.

We took the leftover lamb and fried rice home. The lamb was not as good the next day, but the rice was still very tasty.

It was great experience but don't know that I would fight the parking in the Mission for this place.
author: Hannah C.

description: Shady neighborhood, hipster crowd, great music inside, pricey, but unlike any Chinese food you'll ever have. In the era of overly smoked meats on menus that give many places a gourmet edge (akin to overoaking wine), Mission Chinese packs the smoke but also balances that smoke in their dishes with subtle dressings, fresh vegetables, and balanced spices. Their chicken wings may be the best dry rub wings anywhere.
author: Joseph H.

description:
Called in the order and picked it up. Definitely the way to go if you don't want to wait. Here's what we had, in order of how I liked each dish:

- Cumin Lamb: Excellent. Terrific flavors. However, there isn't a lot of lamb in the dish, but certainly a whole lot of onions.
- Salt Cod Fried Rice: Good, but nothing too different.
- Ma Pu Tofu: Very good. Very spicy.
- Pastrami: Very good. I really liked the pastrami, celery, peanuts. Very spicy.
- Beef Brisket Noodle Soup: Good but too salty for me. Brisket is flavorful, noodles are large, rolled noodles. But the salt killed it for me.
- Mongolian Long Beans: Okay. Again too spicy for me. Nothing special.

Overall, the spiciness of some dishes was a little too much, so it affected my ability to taste the flavors. I also felt that all dishes were too salty, some way more than others.

I probably will not order or eat here again anytime soon unless someone else really wanted to. I just wasn't too impressed.
author: Veronica H.

description:
Probably more of a 3.5 star review - but definitely not worthy of being on a "Best of" list - either locally or nationally.

Had the salt cod fried rice (good but not exceptional), the Westlake porridge (best dish by far - very tasty), thrice cooked bacon (not exactly bacon the way you imagine and pretty spicy; liked the rice cakes, though), and the lamb (good but very smoky - as in made my throat itch/cough).

It's more Northern Chinese, which is admittedly not my favorite.  It was decent but not worth a long wait.
author: B. Y.

description:
Absolutely love this place. come early as there is often a wait to get in. Small plates so you might want to get several and share.

They recently added BBQ to their menu which did not disappoint. Anything with the 'tingly' pepper is fun. It lives up to the name.

my favorites: chicken wings, tingly lamb soup, mongolian beef
author: Doug H.

description:
From the front it looks like just another Chinese restaurant. But then you might notice the gaggle of cool kids waiting for their table out front, and if you peek at the menu on the window you'll spot dishes like "stir-fried pork jowl and winter radishes", or "stewed beef tongue and turnips." And then you'll understand why this is not your everyday Chinese place. 

Mission Chinese offers interesting gourmet takes on classic, spicy Chinese dishes, but with VERY reasonable prices for food of this quality. 

I had the Mongolian Long Bean entree, a fiery assortment of crisp beans, leeks, chilis, horseradish garlic shoots and steamed rice. Fantastic! Also tried the Guilin lamb noodle soup, which came in a delicious broth with big hunks of gamey lamb cheek, rice noodles, pickles, peanuts and pea shoots. The Tiger Salad and Szechuan pickles make great appetizers, and all portion sizes are generous. 

The restaurant only offers three bottles of wine on the menu - a malbec, a savignon blanc and a persecco - but you can bring your own and pay a modest $10 corkage fee. 

Expect to wait for a table, but even on a busy Monday night it took no time at all to get called for our table for two. Larger parties may have more trouble.

The servers are kind and efficient. They really aim for turnover at this place, given the fact that it's so small. Nonetheless, I never felt rushed while eating.
author: Andrew K.

description:
The menage-a-trois of fixed gear bikes chained to the front of this place should have been the first warning sign for do not enter...a sign I regretfully ignored. The second warning sign was how over-hyped this place is in various national magazines, blogs, etc...undeservedly so.

Thrice Cooked Bacon - 5 pieces of fat and rice cakes. Apparently the bacon was thrice cooked to the point where all the meat disappeared. Such blatant disrespect and poor preparation of the almighty pork belly is sacrilegious and there should be a law against it.

Ma Po Tofu - this dish tasted okay but was way salty and I grew up eating MSG! In addition the heat (read tongue-numbing hot) simply didn't compliment the tofu at all.

Tingly Lamb Noodle Soup - tingly indeed...couldn't feel my tongue after this dish. Perhaps I'm allergic to bad tasting soup.

Tea-smoked Eel - they're close to creating a good dish with this one. The texture combination is nice, but none of the individual ingredients come together cohesively....there was one particular ingredient (some herb) that had a very off-putting flavor.

Fried chicken wings - not even in the same class as a number of wing dishes found elsewhere in the city....SO's is a short-drive away...head there instead.
author: David H.

description:
I have had a sour stomach since after last night's dinner at Mission Chinese... it's the next day and I'm really not happy about it.

Do not go here if you don't eat land meat. There are literally three or four things on the entire menu that are vegetarian and they're not amazing:

Thrice Cooked Bacon (without bacon) - Actually really tasty (albeit incredibly spicy and greasy), but it's ruined with large pieces of bittermelon that taste like rotten bell pepper. The excessive use of garlic, spiciness and ginger are tasty though.

Taiwanese Eggplant - Good, not amazing, not bad, but good.

Lung Shan's Vegan Delight - Not bad. Oyster mushroom dumpling soup. The broth was a little bland, which was actually a really nice contrast to the other two dishes. 

I'm honestly not clear why my stomach is totally wrecked today. I eat crazy-spicy food all the time with no problem. I am wondering if the food is just too heavy and over-spiced. It really didn't taste bad (besides that bittermelon wtf).

Oh, maybe it had something to do with the COCKROACH INFESTATION problem they have? Within 5 mins of sitting down, I had a lil guy scamper across my table. I assured my date that it's probably pretty normal for most places to have roaches, and I really do believe this. You just normally don't see them. 

I found the service nice, music was bangin, and the sweet giant dragon hanging overhead kinda made up for my stomach ache and lil roach buddy.
author: Jono K.

description:
Total fan.

Large portions of DELICIOUS, strong-flavored food. Exactly what everyone needs for dinner after a long day of thrifting in chilly weather. 5:30pm on a weekend proved to be RIGHT before the mad dinner rush.

Tacky decorations that include a huge yellow dragon hovering over half of the room and communist-flair paintings: Check.

The perfect amount of spice and equal amounts of meat to tofu for Mapo Tofu: Check and check.

Salted Cod Fried Rice (really, do I need to say anything more than the NAME of the dish??): Check.

Moist, spicy, succulent Lion's head: Check. (Ah, however, I had expected to be a dish of only Lion's heads, but it turned out to be a noodle soup with only one meatball... Gulf this baby down quick before the noodles kill all the broth.)

Ordering too much food for everyone and being pleasantly surprised of the cost: Check.

One thing that's missing: Hot Tea. Did I need to ask for it in a Chinese restaurant?? 

Definitely coming back for a Thrifttown + Mission Chinese extravaganza!
author: Bona K.

description:
Had dinner here after a day of hiking about the city, so I was hungry. Consequently, I over ordered from the menu, but it the price wasn't bad. Tried the mouth watering chicken (tasty, though I'm a spice wimp), chicken rice (mmm) and some pork belly. The pork belly was not memorable, unfortunately. Beware the spice levels if people in your group have low tolerance. 

I liked the adventurous walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom in the back of the building. It's cool to see everyone in action.
author: Theresa S.

description:
So this place is hyped up. And I have to say it lives up to only part of it. The atmosphere is unique - with the hipster crowd and waitstaff compared to the actually very authentic Chinese family in the back, the kitschy decorations, and the music. And I do think it works well together.

When my boyfriend and I showed up here on Sunday around 645pm, we probably were seated around 7pm. The place was busy, and the line was getting long behind us. We ordered:

Tea Smoked Eel
Broccoli Beef Cheek
Pork Belly
Ginger beer and Mexican Coke to drink

We both loved the Tea Smoked Eel. It had such a surprising crunch to it - and it was really well balanced. The pork belly was sort of disappointing to me. Maybe because my mom makes amazing braised pork belly, and this wasn't even close. While some pieces were fatty and well-prepared, others were dried out and chewy. The sauce is similar to the hoisin sauce they serve with peking duck. If not for the mildly pickled cucumbers, the dish would have been too salty. And lastly, the broccoli beef cheek was overwhelming broccoli, with three pieces of beef cheek. They were admittedly very tender, but again, a bit too salty for my taste.

The service was also pretty slow. We had to remind our waiter about our drinks - he literally didn't remember that we had ordered them because he reached for a menu when I brought up drinks, and I had to correct him and say that we had already ordered them. Our food also came at odd intervals, the pork belly followed the tea smoked eel pretty quickly, and then we probably had to wait another 15 minutes for the broccoli beef cheeks. I think they actually did forget about us.

All in all, this is an experience to be had. Maybe a just one time so that I can say I've eaten here. It's not overly expensive, but since I don't live in the Mission, I won't make a trip there just for Mission Chinese.
author: Alison C.

description:
So much has been said about this place already and this is just another review heaping praise and adoration for chef Danny Bowien.

The place is definitely not what you think it looks like. It would be very easy to miss if you didn't know what you are looking for, if it wasn't for the usual crowd of people waiting outside to get in. It looks like any other general chinese food place in the mission, but good god is it something spectacular. 

As soon as you get an ear-full of Skrillex and LMFAO you know that something is different about this place. The crowd ranges from professional looking young adults out for dinner or  a late lunch, hipsters, to traditional Asian families and couples that just know whats good. 

The food is fantastic. Don't settle for the usual chow mein fried rice generic meal here -although it will be good. Go with a beef cheek, or the fried pork belly -talk about melt in your mouth deliciousness. This place is for people that enjoys eating food and every dish is cooked just right, to bring out that fatty, glossy, "cartlidegy" succulent textures Asian food is so well-known for. 

The reason that it doesn't get five stars? 
The food deserves six, really, but the place is just too common and divey-looking to be serving such high quality food. Thank the gods for them doing so, and bless their menu and prices, but i have to be true to my dining experience. The best "i know this great little place for Chinese" place you will ever find!
author: Chad B.

description:
Summary: Excellent Chinese food with a twist.

Really enjoyed coming here. One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the area for sure. 

Food was well put together, with bold strong flavors. Inexpensive, generous portions. Reasonably large selection of interesting dishes. Fast friendly service.

Definitely coming back again soon to try more dishes.
author: Gary Y.

description:
Listen, the food has always been something I look forward to. The mixture of flavor combinations, is really a treat for the mouth. I enjoy the food here thoroughly.

BUT. And I write this because really... it could happen to you.

I ordered my food at 7pm, yep prime time. Was told an hour. At an hour and 1/2 I called, was hung up on twice. Called a 5th time, the phone was just placed down, when I told them I was hungry, and I have waited now an hour and 45 minutes. At the two hour mark I called, was rudely told it was on its way, and I said you know, forget it. She replied with, oh you want to cancel your order okay! and hung up on me.

End of story. 5 stars for food. Nothing for any type of respect for customers.
author: A. And M.

description:
MA PO TOFU=MIND BLOWN

Definitely worth $12. After eating their ma po tofu, nothing else compares!
author: Brian M.

description:
Everything I ate was like a smack in the face with flavor...  Great presentation and diverse menu options.

The pickles with peanuts are amazing, kind of like Kim Chi!

The noodles were perfectly cooked and dressed with tons of spice and flavor. 

Can't wait to eat there again!!!  Totally worth waiting in line!
author: William G.

description:
No need to pass the salt.  Got my delivery, (Ma Po Tofu and Kung Pao Pastrami,) and I'm pretty sure I didn't receive the correct order.  But after waiting an hour, I didn't much care, but food was near inedible anyway, ya' know, the salt. 

Stars for accepting credit cards and for their delivery... guy came right to my front door which most delivery people don't bother doing.
author: CeeLo L.

description: This place is fantastic, especially if you like spicy food! I haven't disagreed with a single thing I've eaten from this place, I only wish it were closer to me!
author: Rylee R.

description:
Love that this place is not what it seems, but unfortunately, everyone else knows it too. I came here with my sister after already chowing down on some fresh oysters and apps down the street. So despite not being extremely hungry, my mouth was still watering when I entered the joint. Really smelled like Mom's home cooking!

We had the Char Siu Pork Belly, which was 4 pieces of crispy-on-the-outside, tender-on-the-inside goodness! Then there was the Rice Porridge, which had a good portion of dungeness crabmeat and would be a perfect comfort food on a cold rainy night. Should've stopped there, but had the Yellowtail Dumplings as well. By that point, I don't know if I was just too full, but I couldn't taste anything at all. It felt like a ball of flour in my mouth.

I'd definitely go again, but I'd probably get the same things, minus the dumplings. Everything else on the menu was either too spicy or too standard for my taste.
author: Ai S.

description:
Went here a couple weeks ago with some friends for lunch and although the food was decent, the service was horrible at best.

   When we arrived, we notified the waiter the number of people in our party, and once we were seated, things began to go down hill from there. 

   We waited quite some time for our waiter to give us menus, and once we decided on what to order, a member of our party (J) tried notify the waiter that we were ready to order, but the waiter just ignored J and continued to service other patrons. This occurred 3 times before the waiter finally acknowledged J and came minutes later. Once our waiter came to our table, he greeted us with attitude while he took our order.

   I really don't know what all the hype is with this restaurant, the food is decent at best. Even if the food was good, the horrible customer service outweighs how good the food would be.
author: K Y.

description: Don't go here if you want Chinese food.  Too hipster.  Service is bleh at best.  My friend and I ended up going to Whiz Burger up the street cause we couldn't stomach what we ordered.
author: Durty D.

description:
This was our last stop on my trip to San Francisco. We went for lunch before we hopped on the BART back to the airport. Bags in tow, we were able to get a seat and study the menu as we waited for our friends. 

When we were all seated...we discussed...strategized...made a game plan, We were then waited on by Danny Bowein himself...who was super cool and very cute to boot. He walked us through the menu and suggested dishes to go with the ones we had agreed on (miraculously). 

The eel roll..wow..Danny said it a roll that was meant to replicate the popular greasy yummy dim sum treat - the chinese doughnut rice roll (I love this dish but it's always soggy by the time it hits the table). He wanted to get the crunch and texture...which he got...spot on. 

The savory egg custard was slippery and salty and delicious.

The Westlake Rice Porridge was the perfect dish to balance out the fierce hotness of dishes like Numbing Lamb Face Noodles and the Thrice Cooked Bacon. We also got the pork belly which was fatty goodness. We fought over the soy cured egg. I'm not going to lie...it was a haze of eating...with good company...and hotness...so hot...

It was lucky to have come for the relative mellow lunch hour as we got detailed descriptions on how each dish was prepared. Lots of attention and love of food and the journey from NYC to SF for Danny Bowein seems to have worked out well! What a special place Mission Chinese Food is...unassuming with terrific food.

We also got some tips for places to eat in NYC too...some upper west side joints (say what?!) for Chinese food. We'll have to investigate.

Until next time SF....you treated us well.
author: Anita C.

description:
This place is great!  Came here last night w/ a group of friends.  The wait took a while (1.5 hours) but was well worth it!  Not really feeling the ultra super i-am-awesome trendy hipsters that come to this place, but the food is goooooood!  When you order something spicy... you get it spicy.  Another plus  is that this place is BYOB!  Corkage fee for wine is $10... for large beers $2 and small beers $1.  The liquor store is just around the corner.  LOL! I recommend trying the following...

- Sizzling Cumin Lamb
- Ma Po Tofu
- Slow-Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly

I will definitely come here again!  Shout out to the Sue Chef, David!
author: Rogel C.

description:
I would give it 4 stars for the eclectic creations, but my wife wants 2 stars since she thought it was "too bizarre" for her. I do think everyone should try this place once to see if it's worth the hype or not, but the wait can be daunting. Luckily that part of Mission has some interesting stores to look at while you wait for an hour plus. I would go back if the wait was more reasonable, but that would be hard to peg.
I tried all of the favorites listed here, and I really liked the salt cod rice and thrice cooked pork belly. The sauce on the pork ribs was amazing, but we didn't like the chewy exterior so we had to pick that part off. Our jaws just couldn't take it. Too bad, it could have been the best rib in The City (sorry Roadhouse BBQ!).
author: Scott G.

description:
A relatively surprising and innovative restaurant. Not your typical Chinese joint. Rather than your beef & broccoli or salt & pepper pork ribs, you'll find interesting items such as braised pork and lamb belly and cod fried rice. 

Mission Chinese Food is definitely not for everyone. In addition to some of your unique dishes, the flavors are very strong. The Cumin Lamb Belly is quite delicious, but if you don't like cumin, it might not be your cup of tea. Otherwise, if you really flavorful dishes, a unique take on Chinese food, and a few hipsters to boot. Mission Chinese is definitely a place for you!
author: Justin L.

description: One of the best experiences of our whole trip.  A fun, lively, casual, quirky environment with great food.  We loved the eel roll and fried bacon dish.  Everything is also quite reasonably priced.
author: Brooke J.

description: Hyped, unimpressive food. I'll never understand why it's so popular, except that it's a good place to see and be seen. But if you actually care about food, this isn't the place.
author: Chuck K.

description:
Hi there Yelp fans. By now you should trust me. You do trust me, right? Ok, great. Please go to Mission Chinese food and order the following:

--Egg Custard served with chicken confit, hokkaido scallop, chrysanthemum and winter melon consommé
--Pork Dumplings poached in ham broth
--Slow Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly with a tea smoked egg
--Thrice Cooked Bacon with rice cakes

The Egg Custard was quite possibly the best menu item I've had in any restaurant this year. And as my ever expanding waistline can attest, I eat out a lot.

The three pork dishes gave me a full on swine-gasm (note that the dumplings can't be ordered for take out or delivery) The dumplings were perfectly cooked and served in a lite broth. The thrice cooked bacon, well, it's bacon cooked three times. Duh. And the pork belly delivered on all accounts - don't sleep on the egg, it's an integral part of the dish and delicious on its own.

We were able to get a table for two 7:45pm on a Saturday night without a wait but within minutes there were people milling about, waiting for a table. 

The prices at MCF are ridiculously cheap considering the quality of ingredients and care that go into each dish. Speaking of cheap, you can bring your own wine for a $5 corkage fee.

Mission Chinese Food is firmly entrenched in my rotation of restaurants that I will gladly return to without hesitation. Go ahead, try some of the dishes that I listed. You can thank me later.
author: phil h.

description:
Ate here last night after it was rated one of the top ten new restaurants in SF by Eater.com

The trice cooked bacon was arguably the best Chinese food dish I've ever tasted. Food was fresh, spicy and delicious. Seating was quick, but they also asked us to leave the table a few minutes after we paid.

One warning: listen to the little "flaming butt icons." Our group thought we could handle spice. I wouldn't recommend anything more than one flame.

I'll be back.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
After years of wanting to try this place it was so mediocre. Even after specifically requesting the dishes to be mild they were ridiculously hot. Really?
I think the chile chicken was good but I could not tell as the heat overpowered it.
The hangar steak noodles were burnt, not sure if that is the intent of the dish or today's cook fell asleep.
At least this place is off of my list and I can move on to the other 4,800+ restaurants that SF has to offer!!!!!!
author: Eric Z.

description: I really don't know why this place is listed on 7x7's list.  I tried their salt cod fried rice and it was WAY too salty.  There wasn't even a lot of cod in the dish.  I also tried their orange beef cheek, which wasn't too bad, but a little too tangy for me.  The best dish we ordered was their tea eel rolls.  They were presented nicely and had a good amount of eel inside each roll.
author: Kristen T.

description: Amazing food. Great ambiance. To get to the bathroom you cut through the kitchen which might strike some as weird but which I like. The food cones quick...service is great...love it.
author: Dani Z.

description:
This place is interestingly ironic -- high quality, modern Chinese food served in a dingy restaurant that is the epitome of "hole-in-the-wall." I suppose that the irony of it all is partly what makes this restaurant so popular (well, that and the ridiculously good press it's been getting lately). My sister and I came here last night for dinner, and we had to wait about half an hour to get seated.

The food here is definitely EXCELLENT and for a very good price. My sister and I ordered the following:
-Slow Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly - $9
THIS DISH IS AWESOME. The crispy pork belly was so delicious. I would come here again and again for this dish.

-Westlake Rice Porridge - $10
Another awesome dish! The only thing is that I wish that the chunks of oxtail were bigger; they were cut up so small that I couldn't tell what it was. There was also a generous portion of crab in this porridge, which was excellent.

-Dumplings with yellowtail - don't remember the price, but I think it was around $7
Unfortunately, this was my least favorite dish. It was awesome watching the chef make dumplings while waiting outside, but unfortunately, these dumplings were a little bland. The dumpling skin was also too thick, in my opinion.

In short, the delicious food and the reasonable prices make me want to come back again and again, despite the long lines.
author: Wendy S.

description:
When 7X7 named MCF's ma po tofu the best dish in all of San Francisco, how could it not shoot up to the tippy top of our "Must do!" list of Bay Area eateries? With an endorsement like that, we were ready to be blown away with what must certainly be the areas most delicious, ingenious and satisfying Chinese food. 

Not so much.

The ma po tofu was... okay. Best dish in San Francisco? Hardly. Actually, let's be real. "Not even close!" To be fair, it was good but just that -- good. If I'm being uber critical, it was too hot to actually taste any spice and a bit to greasy for my particular taste. But as far as authenticity, I suppose this was the real deal. Subtract a little red-hot pepper, and maybe it'd rank as one of the best ma po tofus in town. But again, City's Best Dish? 

No. 

We also ordered the slow cooked pork belly which was actually quite delicious. It sounds really, really gross, but there was something about the way the skin molded to my teeth as I chewed, the way the fat (yes, the yummy pork fat!) melted in my mouth and the pork itself was delicious too. This was a great dish -- far better than the tofu. 

Except one... small... exception. There in the middle off the pork was a cold, soft boiled, curried egg. It looked interesting, but tasted so gross that I actually had to compose myself from yacking at the table. And I, as may people would tell you, am not afraid to try *any* food. This, my friends, ruined the experience. 

No matter how good the pork was and even if the tofu had been the star it was billed as, after taking a bite of this egg I was ruined for the day. No amount of differently-spiced food could erase the yucky texture and taste from my memory. 

Food aside, the restaurant was... a sight to take in. In the dining room it had the typical charm of a hole-in-the-wall Mission Chinese restaurant. I suggest doing yourself a favor though, and going no further. To use their bathroom (outside in the back) takes you through the kitchen and adjoining... rooms? At best, the kitchen is tolerable to those with a strong stomach, at worst probably enough to ignite a firestorm of health code violations and raised eyebrows from patrons. 

Taste in food is subjective, so take what I say with a grain of salt and feel free to try it yourself. But I'm not likely go to back 

As for 7X7 magazine's endorsement of this place? Apparently taste isn't just subjective, it's headless, blind, without scent and lacking in taste buds.
author: Jeff Z.

description: HOLY STIR FRY BATMAN! I had dinner with my foodie pals last night and was blown away by the creativity in the eight plus dishes we tried. This place is really busy so be prepared to wait for a table. Also be prepared to dine on some of the most unique flavors in San Francisco. Our server Anne was really helpful! I could not help but think back to when I used to dine at the original Slanted Door in the Mission......
author: Raymond L V.

description:
We had our second fantastic meal from Mission Chinese this past weekend. Ma Po Dofu, salt cod fried rice, tea smoked eel, lion's head meatball and westlake rice porridge.

Everything was outstanding.  The eel, lion's head meatball and the rice porridge were firsts for us and I would order the very savory porridge  and meatball again.  The eel dish was made a little funky with inclusion of the overly crunchy Chinese celery.

We are looking forward to the next time we are not in the mood to cook.
author: Tony G.

description:
In a nutshell:

Overpriced, small portions, conflicting flavors and herbs, and a minuscule menu where you have to look over it 3 times to reluctantly choose your meal.

"Fusion" food should stop right before it gets to this point.

Only positive thing I can say is that the meat (lamb) was cooked very well.
author: Zack G.

description:
Ten stars for the vibe of this place! I felt like I was in some strange magazine spread, surrounded by hipster models and eating beautifully plated dishes inside a dingy Chinese restaurant. The communal tables gave the place a lively atmosphere, although I'm not sure the couple next to us would say the same after being subjected to hearing what my friend and I were discussing...

The two of us came in around 12:30 PM on a Saturday and were seated immediately. 

We ordered:

Eggplant and Smashed Cucumber: Came with a yoghurt sauce. A good starter, but it didn't really stand out and there are a lot more interesting dishes to choose from.. We only ordered it because I'm sort of eggplant obsessed

Salt Cod Fried Rice: Tasty, but slightly overrated. It's like a less greasy version of the fried rice you'd get in your average Chinese joint. The Chinese sausage was a nice touch, though. And it still tasted good when I reheated the leftovers for dinner!

Slow Cooked Pork Belly: Highlight of the meal! Crispy on the outside, tender & juicy on the inside. Soft boiled eggs were salty and creamy, mm... 

Every dish that passed by looked fantastic. I kept kicking myself, thinking, "Argh, why didn't we order that??" Can't wait to come back and try some spicy stuff and the thrice cooked bacon.. I'm in luuv
author: Liz M.

description: One star for the Bang and Olufsen speakers, no stars for food quality since it was horrible.
author: Richard L.

description:
I don't know how this place is Americanized Chinese food. Tastes like regular ol' Chinese food to me. Portions here are huge. Enough for 4 people per order. 

If you come here on an off day (came here on a Monday at 9pm), there will be no line. I came here on Thursday at 8, saw the hugeeeee crowd and left. 

Some items definitely too salty. I like things that are too salty except that they shouldn't be mixing their super salty meats with the veggies. 

We had the Broccoli Beef Cheek which has oysters, gai lan and beef cheek. These items should be savored separately especially since the meat was salty like salted fish and therefore could and would be eaten with lots of rice but even then would be too salty.

Also got the Westlake Porridge. Really yummy. Tastes and looks just like the porridge my grandma use to make except my grandma would never put oxtail and THE HEAPS OF CRAB in the porridge. She also use to give us an option of adding ginger or not. If I could, I would love to have grandma's porridge again. The massive amounts of crab makes the porridge here soooo worth it.

They have beers from 21st amendment including their watermelon beer and their IPA. Both are really good. Watermelon beer is kind of girly though.

Overall, pretty good and super hyped but I think I rather go to Fat Wong's. Cool crowd with friendly staff though.
author: Margaret S.

description: We had a dinner of all vegan options here. Did delivery so no idea of how good their service is. The three fried bacon with no bacon was good, beans and spicy tofu were also very tasty. Beware - the food can be spicy!
author: Jisha A.

description:
I don't get it. This place is so highly rated and raved about all those real food magazines and blogs... but I don't get why. :( I really really wanted to like it, and I've tried, several times.

The food is alright, but nothing AMAZING or worth the raving reviews. I don't like ordering anything spicy here, because I've found that the spice overpowers all other flavor in the dish. No actual flavor, just chemical spiciness.

The only way I can describe it is... the food lacks... depth.
author: Uyen D.

description:
I was doing my monthly vintage-shopping in the Mission when I thought I'd try this restaurant.  I had read about it, and thinking that I'd see a sign for "Mission Chinese Food,"  I kept walking around in circles trying to find it.  I finally thought of looking up the address (great idea, by the way), and found myself in front of Lung Shan Chinese Food.  

I went in, and saw christmas lights on the walls.  And paintings of horses and General Mao on the walls (I think that's General Mao).  I thought, oh.  Just another typical Chinese restaurant.  I also noticed a lot of non-Chinese in the place.  I thought, oh.  Just another typical Chinese restaurant that's not authentic.  But I was there, I wanted to give it a try, so I gave it a try.  

I'm so glad I did!  I noticed all these strange dishes (like Savory Egg Custard, which has sea urchin in it) and got excited, because who doesn't love trying new food?!?!?!  I wasn't feeling the sea urchin for lunch, so I opted for the Thrice Cooked Bacon.  It came within ten minutes, and looked very appetizing.  I never knew I could enjoy rice cakes so much!  There are some things in this world that cannot be described, and that bacon is one of them.  I'm just going to say it tasted wonderful.  

In addition to that, service is friendly and efficient.  Although I didn't see too many Chinese patrons there, I firmly believe this place is the real deal.
author: Kai C.

description:
The 90s gangsta rap soundtrack alone gives this place a nod from me. We had a lot of fun singing along to Snoop, Tupac, and Mobb Deep lol.

The freshly made dumplings had thick doughy skins but I preferred the pork ones that come in a broth, than the plain lamb ones.

The spicy beef cheeks are tender and beefy, plated with plenty of onions, scallions, cilantro, jalapenos, and dried red chiles. I ilked this dish a lot.

The ubiquitous Sichuan dish, thousand pepper chicken, was fine, but the portion of chicken wings was lacking. Nicely seasoned and plenty spicy though. I liked that it isn't as oily as I've had. Spices in the Richmond does this dish well.

The egg custard was complex and savory with nicely cooked scallops, and tasty broth. Well executed.

The mapo tofu was probably some of the best I've had, really spicy and beefy. Excellent over rice.

The sizzling cumin lamb seemed more of onions than anything, but good fresh cumin seed flavor and I think they used lamb chops so that would explain the small portion. Z&Y has a spicier one on their secret menu that tops this though.

The pork belly with rice noodle rolls was pretty nice, although really fatty (obviously), but the combination was genius. The tea smoked egg didn't seem to add to the dish, but it was soft boiled, very nicely done.

I'd come back for certain dishes, but I wished they'd offer more than just Tsing Tao, Heineken and Bud Light. But then again, with the gangsta rap soundtrack, the beverage selection might actually be a smart thing.
author: Derrick V.

description:
First time here, we didn't wait because were told the queue is 1.5 hours! Came during Christmas week for lunch and managed to get in at opening without wait. 

Pork belly : crispy, soft and totally yummy
Mapo tofu : very spicy with twist 
Lamb : not too gamey which I like
Thrice cooked bacon : very salty even for me, will pass next time

Will definitely come back again to try other dishes if the wait is reasonable.
author: Agustinus T.

description:
Wasn't too sure about this place being where it is in the Mission and not taking reservations. But ya know what? It's frickin awesome. The wait isn't even that bad.

And the food. Well, the food is delicious. Just unbelievable flavor. Smokey, salty, spicy. All the beautiful things I want Chinese food to be. 

I'd only add that the lack of Asian staff is somewhat suspicious. But whatever! If you like delicious Chinese food, or just delicious food, you need to go here.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Yelp's current 3.5 stars for this place is an injustice--but I guess that's what democracy's about--there're no voting test.  Everyone gets a say.  At least the ones with cultivated palates and extensive dining experience--the critics--are heaping on MCF the praise it truly deserves.

Mission Chinese Food serves a tasty reinterpretation of Sechuan cuisine.  If you don't eat a variety of food, don't like spicy food, or have never tried Sechuan, you may be disappointed.  There are lines here (because the food is good and the place is popular).  The decor is cheesy and the service lukewarm in the way traditional Chinese restaurants have bad decor and bad service.  It's not about the decor and service, or the wait.  It's about the great food--a delicious Mapo Tofu, congee, pork belly with pineapple, cold uni with fish-eggs and custard. Yum!!
author: Alex S.

description:
Welcome to San Francisco, where you can find places like this.Typical Chinese restuarant? I think not. Yes it's Asian, the taste, the ingredients...it's very Asian...but with a different flair.

This place is cool. Upon entering a shabby restaurant front, besides the typical Chinese restaurant decor, you immediately see a huge red illuminated red dragon strung throughout the ceiling, Christmas icicle lights on the walls left and right of you, a little corner on the right upon entering where the bbq orders are being precessed, and the tune of 90s hip-hop playing. Tight...dinner tonight is gonna be good!..how fun!

The food here is good. I was thinking kinda like creative (additional) Asian twist to an already Asian menu. Asian....comfort food...hip. The menu is short, filled with what seems like your typical Chinese restaurant items"...but wait, the ingredients...now that's a little different!" And it all works out too! The ingredients...they get creative with the items, adding some extra Asian flair (not American flair) to the menu items.

My friend and I ordered four items between the two of us: Ma-Po Tofu, Salt Cod Fried Rice, Hainam Chicken Rice, and BBQ Beef Brisket. All items were good stuff! The BBQ brisket was super tender and super fatty..has a sauce made from "Mexican Coke" (I think it had a little hoisen going on in there too?)...served with onion/cucumber(pickled?) on the side, and three slices of white bread with the crust cut off (kinda like peking duck with the little bun that it comes with). The two rice dishes were plenty yummy/tasty (approved by my friend who is a fried rice fanatic!). The Ma Po Tofu was not your typical either, as it reminds me of something that taste like something from the restaurant Old Mandarin Islamic (it's good stuff!).

The only thing negative I can say about this place is the price of the items are a little more expensive then expected. Not that it's super expensive, but more then usual. You can justify the prices though with the creativity of added ingredients to each menu item. I think it's worth it though, knowing that you will not find that type of taste at another Chinese restaurant. (The other negative thing, and not that it's the restaurant's fault, was the drunk homeless person that strayed in. He was going to each table mumbling....16oz. plastic $3 vodka bottle sticking out of his back pocket. It's the type of area though. If going here at night, try to go with a group.)

Paolo says: Good spot for good Chinese food with a flair. Chinese comfort food that's hip! Wu-Tang! Tu-Pac! Biggie!..."super nintendo, sega genisis...you gotta try this place mang, you'll never figure this!!
author: Paolo V.

description: Am I allowed to admit I'm underwhelmed and still be considered semi cool?
author: Lauren V.

description:
MCF is definetely "as good as it gets!"

That day my friend and I sampled the Mapo Tofu, Beef Broccoli and pork belly.

Wow!  I was blown away by the food I found on the Mission.  Mapo tofu as made to perfection.  The beef in the Beef Broccoli was beef cheeks; oh so tender; and did I mention they add a couple oysters too.  The pork belly was crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  Great presentation with hoisin sauce, thinly sliced cucumber, scallions wrapped in wide-noodle and a soy-marinated medium-boiled egg.  

I recommend this place to anyone and everyone!  Thank you Bradda Rich for this recommendation.  See you again MCF!
author: Chris V.

description: We ordered egg egg noodles and mapo tofu. The noodles can get cold real fast and once you mix the sauce and egg up, you can barely see or taste the egg, so it was kinda pointless to me. The mapo tofu, on the other hand, is bomb. The hell with Z&Y crap. My tongue is numb alright. I don't think it's that spicy but it's great. Will come back but hate where it's located. We were lucky to arrive right before they opened.
author: May G.

description: When they say spicy it is SPICY!!! I've never been in person as I hear the lines are super long. We just get delivery and they add a surcharge depending on how far you are from their restaurant. I live in the Marina and it's a $4 surcharge. I liked the thrice cooked bacon. The mongolian string beans. Just about everything I've tried so far.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Finally, I made it.  It wasn't that crowded on a Sunday for a early supper~4:30p.  Considering all of the city's events I thought there'd be a line out the door.  There were only 4 tables full out of maybe 20.
