Luckily I was able to go with 2 of my friends so were able to try a bunch of different things.  I didn't look at the Lung Shan menu and they just offered the Mission Chinese - so you may need to ask.  

Egg Custard - my fave consisting of uni and cured trout roe.  WoWzers, packed with flavor and made to perfection.    
Dumplings w/ xo sauce - a eat in only dish.  Had a Chinese mushroomy flavor that I didn't love.  But very fresh!
Slow cooked Char Siu Pork Belly - also a fave the accompaniments are worth it alone.  
Lamb Noodle Soup - super fresh noodles and strong lamb/anise/something flavor.  Super "tingly"!
Westlake Rice Porridge - good but never heard of $10 jook.  Homemade but I'd pass on this one.  
Broccoli Beef Cheek - Lots of veggies but overall just ok

I will definitely opt for the delivery option the next time - a good deal.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Yummmm.

I've wanted to try this place ever since I saw it featured on the Food Network.  We were in the city and decided to call in and take it back to the burbs.  This place has a lot of workers and TWO people on the phone taking call-in orders.  Here's what we had and my thoughts:

- Chilled buckwheat noodles. I like the mixture of horseradish and roe.  The flavors are subtle (compared to the other dishes) but mixed well.
- Ma Po Tofu. Okay this one was the bomb. Very tasty and a good sized portion.
- Thrice cooked bacon (because I ordered it vegetarian).  There's no bacon in this. It was tasty but I'm not sure if I'd order this again.
- Salt cod fried rice.  My kids loved this. My mouth was a fire from the ma po tofu so I didn't taste much of the salt cod.  i trust this was good.
- Sizzling cumin lamb.  This was probably my second favorite dish. Chinese cooking doesn't use much cumin but this was awesome.  

All in all, I think the food lived up to the hype.  I would love to go back and try some of the other dishes.  I'm not sure if I'd eat there tho, mainly because I don't like to wait (a long time) to be seated.
author: kewlby x.

description:
To quote Mugato, "Am I taking crazy pills????"  I mean seriously, if Mission Chinese is supposed to make me happy, I'll have to ask my shrink for a Prozoloftaxilbalta cocktail, like, yesterday.

That being said - the pork belly they have, while not really chinese, is really tasty. Their BBQ look good too, and some chef I met through the internet says the cooks there are legit, and the internet never lie. 

"omg, but they have sichuan pepper corn which was like a banned substance or something and the shit is awesome and it's on EVERYTHING and you're a bad foodie if you don't like them!!!!!!!!1one" Seriously, Get over yourselves. That's like saying soysauce makes everything better.

(okay, soy sauce does make everything better, touché. But my point stands. fuck you.)

Everything else here is pretty standard bullshit. 

Btw, have you noticed that they do their lights a nice shade of red? I hate that - it makes it so much harder to take in the visual of the food. (but then again, if your food look like chinese garden mulch, maybe it makes sense to live-instagram the spectrum.
author: Lynn T.

description:
The best non-authentic chinese food in town.

To be honest, I am just fine with places that take the idea of Chinese flavors and make something new from them. Some of the dishes I have had here and loved include the Thrice cooked bacon, Mapo Tofu, and Hainam Chicken Rice. The rice is a special treat for me because it is based heavily on a dish which is popular in LA's Hong Kong style cafes. The dish is Hainan Chicken and I have been unable to find it done well in SF. Even though this dish is presented differently, the flavor is all there. It was a major treat. 

Wrap all of this into the fact that the staff truly takes pride in the menu and portions of the cost of the meal go to the SF food bank. This is very good food at a low price. 

After writing this i sort of wonder if this is my favorite place in town.
author: Eric G.

description:
Shared many dishes with friends Tuesday.


I couldn't stop puking and sh!ting all day yesterday and part of today (Weds and Thurs). Today my abs feel like a rock.

Never, ever, ever again.

Service: Curb the 'tude. If you don't like being in this industry, do everyone a favor and quit.
author: Jesse R.

description:
my first san francisco review.  hey i won rotd for my mission ny (which sadly closed) review so why not write one for sf.

lets do a comparison review, ny vs. sf. 

pros of sf:
no wait
it's still open
more menu items

cons of sf:
its in san francisco
no beer while you wait
one of my chicken wings was a bit bloody (ate it anyways) 
atmosphere was better in ny

thats about it for the difference.  i still loved the spicy wings, thriced cooked bacon and some veggie dish that i forgot.  i think i ordered the same thing as in ny.  i sure do branch out a lot huh?  everything was spicy, just the way i like it and had a very strong taste.  

so if the ny mission was still open, ny beats out sf.  just like everything else.
author: Steve W.

description:
*Service: Of course this restaurant is very popular among youngsters, what youngsters like is not about services but it is FOOD. The service here is very horrible, not even one star. Waiter and Waitress here must get paid very bad or they don't realize what they are doing, so they are not there to serve you. They are their to JUST take order, bring the food to your table after the kitchen make it. They wait until you are done, they bring the bill to you. While they are walking in the restaurant, they look at the floor or focus their eyes to the kitchen. Don't waste your energy to wave, to send any signals, it won't work. If you really need anything, PLEASE help yourself by STANDING UP and go to them, then state what you want. The restaurant is very dirty, floor is not even using the DIRTY CARPET to cover it. Table lay-out is very dangerous for the FIRE Emergency. If you are sitting inside and there is fire from the kitchen, you must clam down and don't run and hurt yourself through the chairs and tables including other customers. You will all be blocked and stuck inside. 
*Place is convenient to come by but it's SUPER HARD to find a parking spot and meter is very expensive: one quarter for 6 minutes. The area is not great, Mission between 18th and 19th, so safety is on your own any way. 
*Price is moderate not cheap but towards more to expensive such as $12 for Salted Fish Fries Rice-not entree, $16 for Lamb Rib Grilled, all entrees are over $10 even some vegetarians are made from TOFU.
*Products (food) are very delicious; thats why this restaurant can still survive.
*Promotion: None

I hope this review help you to decide if you want to go to this restaurant.
author: Johnny O.

description: 3.5 stars. We ordered the sizzled lamb dish, cold sesame noodles, veggie dumplings and the cold egg custard dish. The food overall is a bit too spicy for me, nice flavor though. Noodles are good, but I wasn't big on the pickles and I hate shiso in. It would have been nice otherwise.
author: Yoko S.

description: I used to love this restaurant - I've been several times happily but I won't go back. Our server asked us to leave at the end of our meal because they had an hour wait. We had been sitting just about five minutes after the server had taken our bill. Bummer.
author: Lucy M.

description:
This is my wife's favorite place to eat.  Everything is pretty delicious, although some unadventurous diners may have trouble with spiciness, textures, etc.  

Dining there is an experience, as the wait can be lengthy, but it is totally worth it.  Don't expect to have intimate conversation, as east-coast hip-hop is a staple of the dining room.  They have a small but diverse selection of bottled and canned beer, which definitely helps in handling the Szechuan spices.

Mission Chinese also delivers all over the city for a nominal fee, although there are several items that are only available for dine-in. It usually takes over an hour, but is always hot and delicious when it arrives.  Overall, my recommendations would be:

kung pao pastrami
ma po tofu
sizzling cumin lamb
thrice-cooked bacon
pineapple pork belly (or pig tail) - dine-in only

the chili wings are overrated IMO (too salty, not that hot), as is the salt cod fried rice.  Everything else has been very good, but the list above is what really sticks out.

Also an FYI, they do not accommodate groups of over 8.
author: Jeff M.

description:
For delivery chinese food, this place certainly shatters expectations.

On a cold rainy day ordered some Mongolian Beef delivery and it was great! Great, but not amazing, as there is a distinction.

Great in the sense that the flavors were on point, it wasn't super greasy like all other Chinese Food tends to be, and it arrived piping hot. The veggies were cooked really well, cooked without being mushy or al dente, and spicy but not overwhelming. Quick note though: they use some of that pepper from Schezwan that makes your tounge numb/ tingly, so if that's not your thing this place is probably not for you.

The downside? There isn't a whole lot in the terms of beef to veggies ratio, so if meat is your thing, one order may not satisfy you so to speak.

Pros: Good quality chinese food that delivers. Delivery charge isn't a whole lot

Cons: Maybe more expensive than you normally pay for delivery chinese, but the quality more than makes up for it.
author: David H.

description: My guess hipster is a dirty word? I defiantly am not but i like different and to put it mildly this is one of the places that I would consider one of the great places to eat in America, not traditional Chinese buy a long shot but as time goes on people will recognize this as a mission treasure. It doesn't suck and as far as hipster restaurants in the mish that says a lot!
author: joseph g.

description:
I passed by this place several times before but never gave it a second look, because from the outside, it just looks like a regular hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant. But after reading about it on 7x7 and all these other food blogs, decided to give it a try. And ZOMG it was amaaazing. It's like cheap gourmet Chinese food at it's finest. Here's what we got:

- MaPo Tofu - as good as everyone says! I loved the flavor of this dish... it was spicy, but not in a dump-in-a-shit-ton-of-chiles kind of way. It had lots of other spices in it like cloves, cardamom (I think?), and other things that made it very fragrant and delicious. I can't really compare it to 'real' mapo tofu because I've never had it before, but this dish was delicious.

- Hainam Chicken Rice - light and refreshing. I was hoping it'd be a bit tastier, but this one was just okay. Next time I'll probably get the cod salted fried rice instead.

- Cha Siu Pork Belly - the presentation for this dish was pretty amazing. Pork belly was delicious! Though it comes with 5 pieces.. so if you're by yourself or with one other person, you might have a hard time finishing this one because it is super fatty. 

- Cold Noodles - was expecting a bit more out of this one, because I'm a huge fan of the leng mian served on the streets of Shanghai. Texture was a bit weird for me (buckwheat soba noodles?) and I would have liked a more vinegary flavor. But it was still decent nonetheless. Probably wouldn't get it again though.

So overall, 4 stars. Ambiance is nice too. I can't wait to go back and try everything else on their menu!
author: Rhea K.

description:
Letting go of my preconceived notions of "Americanized Oriental Cuisine", I kept an open mind when I came here for dinner--as long as the food tastes great, I will not criticize it for its lack of authenticity. Unfortunately, Mission Chinese fell a little short in the taste department. Nothing was bad, per se, but the majority of my food was just bland.

I had a really hard time deciding what to get since so many items on the menu appealed to me. My friend and I ended up sharing:

*SIZZLING CUMIN LAMB: The flavours were great but the lamb belly pieces were a lot fattier than I'd expected. There was barely any meat on them (some people may be into that but I'm not one of them). My favourite part of this dish was all the slivered onions that soaked up all the yummy flavours.

*TAIWANESE EGGPLANT: This would've been a great dish if it was more flavourful (it was almost,  but not quite, there) and the eggplant was more well-done (but that's a personal taste). Loved the sprinkling of fresh basil on top though.

*WEST LAKE RICE PORRIDGE: I'd expected the use of oxtail, addition of Dungeness crab to, and the congee aspect would make this a good variation on the Chinese classic. But instead I got a big bowl of bland and watery rice porridge with not enough beef, crab, or cilantro. It was salty enough, but something was missing.

*STEAMED EGG CUSTARD: A very light and simple dish with the addition of shaved scallops on top. The flavours didn't blow my mind but it was satisfying in a I-would-like-this-if-I'm-sick way. Portion-wise this was also a lot smaller than the other dishes and I barely noticed the confit chicken that was supposedly in there.

I'll still come back to try all the other dishes that caught me eye if only to satisfy my epicuriosity. Hopefully I'll have better luck next time...
author: Steph L.

description:
I have to admit, I kind of don't want to like this place.  The hipster ambiance, the hype, the crowds... it would be easy for me to write a bad review about this place... but the food is good!

We ordered the fried rice (excellent), the kung pao pastrami (a bit salty on its own but great with the white rice to balance it out) and the pork belly (everyone's new favorite part of the pig).  All the dishes tasted great, and one of Mission Chinese Foods greatest asset IMO is it makes the dishes standout from regular Chinese fare (kung pao pastrami?!?!?! tell me more!) without coming across as "fusion food."  In other words the food at this place really feels like the idea came from a person who cooks authentic Chinese food but is well versed in other cooking styles/techniques, rather than a person who just wants his food to appeal to the masses.

Give this place a try, hopefully you won't have to wait too long in line for a seat.
author: Brian A.

description:
GET THE WINGS!!!   Yes this place has tons of hype and you might have to wait,  but all that should say something about how crazy good those damn wings are.   
Yes it is greasy... get over it or go somewhere else.  This place has a cult like following that multiplies everyday.  You won't be finding sweet and sour chicken on the menu and if think that is real chinese food I feel sorry for you.  However this is not real chinese food either.  The chef is actually Korean.   Its a crazy blend of flavors that explode inside your mouth and possibly your stomach the next day....  You have been for warned.    If you are a vegetarian your choices are limited but if you eat meat prepare yourself for a meat bonanza.  This place also remains cheap for how popular it is.  Get here early and you can bypass the wait, and they wont take party's bigger then 8.


The Highlights:  The WIngs!  Thrice cooked bacon,  Pork belly, Salted Cod fried rice, Wild harvested tea leaves, mongolian long beans,  you really can't go wrong.

Cons:   The smell of those wings while you wait to hear your name called.  The dirty look from the outside.  Very crowded on the inside.   Call your order in ahead and eat on the sidewalk  if your starving.

Could you imagine how crazy crowded this place would be if it looked nice from the outside and they spruced up the inside.  Thanks for all the one stars and bad reviews hopefully it will cut down on the wait and make it easier to eat here when I want too.
author: Duke B.

description:
this place gave me renewed hope in chinese food.  i sort of wrote off the cuisine just because so much of it is generic and low quality to me.  every once in a blue moon, i will head on over to Great Wall, but other than that, it is not a cuisine i will generally choose over thai or indian.  this place might change that though.

we ordered delivery.  it takes an hour to get there, so if you are hungry NOW, dont bother.  we had:

-smoked brisket noodles:  really tasty.   noodles tasted fresh.  the smokiness of the brisket really came through in the overall flavor

-thrice cooked bacon:  again, really smokey and tasty.  nice spice and the rice cakes were something i have not seen before

-porridge - i tried my friends and it was really tasty.  you could really taste the crab.

-pickles - kind of like a fresher tasting version of kim chee.  at first, i didnt like it much, but then you start tasting all the different spices in it, and it becomes kind of addicting

-mongolian long beans:  REALLY spicy, but still really good.  i would order these again.

This place is a breath of fresh air.  i cant wait to go back and try some more stuff on the menu.  beware....spicy means SPICY here!
author: Christian C.

description: I was here a year ago and thought the food was too salty and greasy. This year I still think the same thing. The wait wasn't too bad for us because we got there right at 515, close to opening time. I know the list was much longer when we were leaving (no reservations either). This time the thrice baked bacon was fantastic and the fried rice was a good fried rice, but the pork belly was dry and crusty. So dissappointing. The whole place made me smell like fried foods when I left and the service was ok. I don't really know what the hype is. Maybe you should just order the delivery cause eating it at home may have been better.
author: Alissa N.

description: Traditional Chinese? No. But to hell with tradition! This place is very fusion-y and sort of hipster-ish, but surprisingly it works. The General Tso's veal is a real treat!
author: Devon N.

description:
I love the neg reviews because they're obviously oblivious to the essence of the joint. This is not a fancy spot. It is neither a cheap take out. Nor is it an authentic ethnic eatery. It is a SF, Asian-American interpretation of chinese fast food. That's it. 

There are a couple misses, (salad) but overall, Myint and his crew do a fantastic job. The Maopu, the wings, the Hainan, dumpling, all kick ass. 

Go there with an open mind and a hungry stomach. And leave the fancy silverware and grandma's cookbook at home.
author: Rich B.

description: Not a huge fan. My friends ordered the thrice cooked bacon, the super spicy green beans, and the super duper spicy tofu, and honestly I didn't really like any of them. I mean, the spiciness was enjoyable, but the taste itself wasn't anything to write home about. Beats me why this place is so hyped.
author: Grant M.

description: I couldn't even finish 50% of my meal today. The lamb ribs were 90% fat and the ma po tofu was didn't taste much except REALLY spicy. I walked out still feeling hungry. Such a disappointment and waste of money.
author: Marcus S.

description:
I eat here once a week. 

Food is intense, in a good way. Not the bland, oily Chinese food you find most places, lots of bold flavors and interesting ingredients. 

The pork belly is ungodly good. 

Extra bonus points because Danny is super nice and they always play 90s RnB. Nothing like some braised mongolian beef cheeks with some Biggie.

Oh, and they deliver!
author: Kelly Kate W.

description:
Food: 4*
Service: 4*
Ambiance: 3*
Cleanliness: 2* 

Yummy Chinese food with quirky $ store decorations. Mushroom dumplings, crispy pork belly, and salt cod fried rice are delicious dishes.
 
I'm surprised by the neg. reviews. Perhaps they were expecting porcelain dinnerware and gourmet plating but got plastic flowers and a giant paper dragon hanging from the ceiling instead. Order take out next time your highnesses.
author: Ani O.

description:
I've only been here once, but the food was great.  Ordered Westlake Rice Porridge, Ma Po Tofu, Braised Mongolian Beef Cheek, and Tiger Salad.  Everything was pretty damn good and unique except the tiger salad could have used something...it was a bit bland.  

I told a lot of people about this place and a common question is "well is it authentic?"  Who freaking cares, the food is delicious.  If they were trying to be authentic then perhaps they miss the mark, but in being creative, inventive, and making food that tastes good they are spot on.  I'll be back for sure.  Price is right too.
author: Matt S.

description:
This reviews of this place, is living proof why most of the people should not be yelping.

I am not being racist, but you know there is a problem when a majority of the people dining there are non-Chinese and saying how great the food is. I don't think you have the right to say what is good Chinese food, unless you have had good Chinese food. Regardless, yelper has taken me to some hipster Panda Express and made me eat something I don't even believe is Chinese. Just because a Chinese chef created it, doesn't mean it is Chinese food!!

I go there before my flight back to LA because all you yelpers say it so awesome, get there and the line is long and that was to be expected, the parking is horrible in that area, but that was all stated and you can't hold MCF responsible for that. We put our name on the list and it moves quickly and I am willing to wait for good food. 

I don't know if people were drunk or high when writing the reviews on MCF, but the place is dark as a night club, the tables are fold out tables with no table clothes, and every plate seems to be different. The water they served was probably straight from a garden hose with no ice and brought to your table with busted up carafes. I guess this is a good reason to order tea or alcohol. The interior was dark, I would keep it that way because the place is dingy and I am sure you wouldn't eat there if they turned on the lights, it's like make-up for your restaurant. This fact alone should scare people and no one in their right mind should be giving them 5 stars. After all the reviews of this place, I am seriously tempted to open a place there and furnish everything from Home Depot 

Because some idiots said that the cumin lamb FAT, the super SALTY long beans were good, and the wish there was cod-fried rice, we had to give it a try.

The food:
Overall everything was salty, very salty, and probably loaded with MSG as well.
 
The Lamb fat was just that, the onions and veggies were decent, but there were so few pieces of lamb and the few pieces that were there was all fat. People on here say that the lamb is tender, but most fat is tender, I have no idea how people think they are actually eating lamb, it's called lamb FAT!

The long beans were decent, they weren't overcooked, but they were just so salty. I am surprised more people haven't complained, I wanted some salt with my beans not beans with my salt. I enjoy spicy food, but I was a bit surprised, because it was much spicier than typical Chinese food, but regardless, it was decent, but not good. I rarely see Serrano peppers in Chinese food, but they were all over it btw.

The cod fried rice, that was the only decent thing on there. Honestly, nothing that special, I am sure a panda express cook could easily cook this dish, probably make it taste better a half the price. I am not endorsing panda express, but if you don't want real Chinese food, might as well get it there, because at least you don't have to wait long, it's half price, the tables are clean and the place has a clean atmosphere and just bring your own mp3 player to blast music so loud you think it's a club. 

Overall it's worth trying, but not worth the money or the wait. The whole vibe of the restaurant is pretty low class and nasty, but if that is the appeal, it doesn't attract me. I like when a place is eclectic and clean, but not dark/dingy. It was worth trying, to know that people can make bad Chinese food and be successful because yelp says it's good. So people if you want authentic Chinese food, this is not the place. If you want to try funky dishes created by Chinese people, then try it, but make sure you are ready because it ain't pretty inside. If the place feels dirty in the dining area, I can only imagine the kitchen.

Good luck.
author: Eddie K.

description:
Disgusting and gross.

Terrible experience overall.  I don't understand what the hubbub is all about.  This is a crappy chinese place in the mission, nothing more.

I really wanted to like this place but with the first bite it was evident that wasn't going to happen.

Ma Po Tofu - terrible over-spiced tofu, mushy, mouth numbing spice, gross

Lamb Ribs - fatty ribs, hardly any meat, mostly fat, gross smokey flavor, on a bed of chopped onions, served with a few dates but grossed out by all the fatty mush I didn't want to put more mushy consistency in my mouth

We spent nearly $50 on this meal, (no beer or wine, just the food and a pot of tea) and were terribly dissatisfied.  We couldn't wait to get out of there.

At least we got there when there was no line and no wait.  It would have sucked even more to have to wait any amount of time for that lousy meal.
author: T L.

description:
This place would have been tastier, cheaper and cleaner if it were a dodgy Chinese restaurant instead of a chic hipster joint.

Wash the table.

Make sure the glasses don't have chunks in them.

Stop being pretentious.
author: Ima D.

description: Beef cheek ok and thrice cook bacon was good
author: Jesse B.

description:
Mission Chinese Food seems to have a cult following ever since it morphed from the pop-up Mission Street Food to a permanent establishment. Naturally anyone should be curious how something as ubiquitous as Chinese food in a city that has a Chinese eatery on almost every block can win over the hearts of those picky Mission hipster eaters. 

First off, the appearance had to be a hole-in-the-wall mom n' pop kinda place. The dirtier the better: because obviously the more energy you put into making delicious food, the less you should have to worry about interior design. However, ironic objects are a charming must: fake flowers, posters that look like they were directly imported from Red China at least 20 years ago. Also, you want a good mixture of authenticity and hipness: a family photo of the staff including unaculturated grandmas is endearing but it also doesn't hurt to throw in a younger dude named "T-Bone. " 

Onto the food. Based on yelp reviews, we ordered the salted cod fried rice which was a huge bust. I don't get it at all! I don't see how this is different from any other Chinese fried rice I've had in my life. Maybe the two pieces of cod made the difference, but I am pretty sure if you blindfolded me and give me a $3 fried rice from any generic Chinese restaurant, I won't be able to tell the difference. 

The sesame noodles were different from your traditional Chinese sesame noodles. Lighter in taste and texture, it's almost like a lightly creamy noodle salad. The smoked eel dish was pretty fantastic. The presentation and taste resemble unagi rolls, but instead of rice, eel is wrapped in silky rice noodles and the whole texture/taste balance was perfect. 

I definitely want to come back and try some other dishes---many sound very enticing and interesting. Do come here early: we had no issue getting a table around 11:30, but by the time we were leaving an hour later, the restaurant was full and bursted into chaos where we had to ask for our bill twice and each time it was forgotten as soon as the waitstaff turned around and got involved in some other tables' business.
author: Candice B.

description:
If I could give five stars for the food and 1 or 2 for the service and ambiance I would would.

Because I was in SF on business and dining alone I ordered two dishes so I could try a couple of things. It is so loud in the restaurant that my server couldn't hear me and only brought me one. When I figured out what happened I didn't feel like waiting so I asked her to box it up; it's one of the dishes they don't do "to go." 

This was really quite annoying since I can't go back easily and easily remedied if they would just turn the volume on the hip hop down to levels not akin to live music venues, or perhaps just hired servers who gave a shit. Also, the communal seating was fine until the heavily perfumed couple sat down next to me and there was no where to run. 

The ma po tofu was worth the hassle, but know you're in for a wait and sensory overload.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I work in the restaurant industry. I have been going to Mission Chinese Food since the Mission Street Food days and I really like what these guys are doing. I tend to eat there once a month or so. I've waited two and a half hours for delivery, I've waited in the line to get in. Over the last few times that I have eaten there or had take out I have been completely let down. The consistency is completely off, sometimes for the better sometimes for the worse.  For the amount of hype/press Mission Chinese Food gets I would think that they would be more on it to preserve their place in the spotlight. Not every restaurant is named "One of the top 10 restaurants in America"!!!
I can only hope that they will regain my loyalty because I really like this place...And I liked them before the rest of America did.
author: george p.

description:
I am super bummed! I've been to Mission Chinese a few times before my last visit and it was always an awesome, mystical experience. The food was so imaginative and unexpected. Whenever I was in the Mission and had the chance, I would go there. During our visit yesterday, however (at least a year since the last time I was here) 2 out of the 3 dishes we ordered were so spicy we couldn't even eat them. I brought my boyfriend and we ordered the Ma Po Tofu, the thrice cooked bacon, and the egg egg noodles. We had to send the Ma Po tofu back because it was painfully hot. I think by the time we made our way to the bacon dish, our tastebuds were so numb from the heat and we had so much endorphins coursing through our veins that it didn't seem as hot, but as I am writing this review, I just heated up the leftovers and I couldn't eat more than 2 small bites without running to the kitchen to grab some milk. I want you to know that we are no wusses. Habaneros and jalepenos are regular ingredients in our homemade food and cocktails. But the food was so over-spiced that we couldn't enjoy the subtle and complex flavors that I have experienced on previous visits.

On some positive notes: this restaurant carries my favorite beer in the world - 21st Amendment Watermelon Beer (omg so good), and when we explained to our server that the tofu was too hot to eat, she was very nice and took it back and comped our beers (so we basically didn't pay for the dish and got an additional 4 bucks off the check). She also mentioned that the chef has changed the menu in the past few months and made the spicy items even spicier. I think this is a huge mistake. I can't imagine why anyone would want to change anything about the menu when Mission Chinese has been so hugely successful the way it was. But oh well. If you are looking for a psychedelic, out of body experience, the dishes with the peppers next to them on the menu should take you there. 

But if you can't handle the heat...stay out of Mission Chinese's kitchen.
author: Jessica G.

description: Holy smokes! My best friend just flew in mission chinese to Austin tx and it's off the charts. Omg serious takeout foodgasm
author: Alina P.

description: The place was too dim and the food was way too spicy and I wished they would have warned us. Other than that, the food was okay.
author: Charles Z.

description: If you want legit Chinese food, take a short taxi to china town. The seating is crammed and the food was overpriced for what it was. A longer line doesn't mean it's worth the wait.
author: E R.

description: OMG!! The flavors are still popping in my memory.  Love the texture and taste.  Spicey when it needs to be with a sweet kick.  I had this delivered for only $2. Delivers anywhere in the city and this is a must try if you live or just visiting SF.
author: A J.

description: Unique Chinese place, must try for people who are not that into Chinese food but wanting to like it. Like me! Tried the Kung Pao Pastrami (yes, you heard it right!) and was delicious. This Chinese place is co-located with Lung Shan restaurant, so the outside board says Lung Shan.
author: Mia C.

description:
I have a tremendous dislike for most Chinese food, the first words out of my mouth when choosing restaurants are anything but Chinese. Yes I know this isn't traditional fare but I'm using my like for it as a catalyst to possibly enjoying Chinese food...occasionally.

We chose the Tiger Salad, the Szechuan Pickles, the Taiwanese Eggplant, the salt cod fried rice, the egg custard, lamb dumplings and chicken wings. The eggplant was my favorite on this round although everything was very tasty although I probably wouldn't get the egg custard again just not my style. I've also tried their now infamous Ma Po Tofu, Pork Belly and Porridge on delivery. I loved the tofu so much so that cooked up some veggies and used the left over chili oil as the sauce. Yes it's spicy but so good.  The porridge was good as well and I've had numerous porridges from Clement, Irving, S SF and China town.

I'll be calling them for delivery again for sure...
author: Kacey H.

description: Finally braved the line with some Silver Lakeans whom insist we eat there. Glad we did and nice to see the Chinese culinary universe in action. Started with cold apps-- something that gets overlooked a lot in the West but is ubiquitous all over China. Garlic cucumbers drenched in a nice sesame sauce. Then had the smoked eel. It was rolled up in rice rolls and tasted great, highly recommended for the experience. The mapou tofu was the best I've ever had in the United States. It's ashamed how misrepresented this dish is in the States, but if you've never been to China, try it here and you can get as close as it gets to authentic-- complete with the awesome tingling mala numbing pepper. We also tried their fish fried rice. This dish actually was brought first, a big no-no in Chinese eating culture--rice comes later, as a filler. The cumin-flavored row of bones (ribs) had some Western Chinese influence and flavor, and the Hunan chicken wings are not to be missed merely because of the phenomenal presentation. This place is rad and totally disproves the fact that paler folks can't find good Asian restaurants. Hallelujah!
author: Brian J.

description:
Visceral. Gritty. Gourmet.

There is no time for eloquence at MCF or in this review.

Sound - heavy metal/rock/punk (not overwhelmingly)
Sight - grandmas christmas lights still runnin' since '94
Smell - the HOUSEMADE SMOKED OYSTER SAUCE on the broc beef
Feel - the submissive, savory-sweet pork belly against your molars

Side effects:
- i had it for dinner, then i had it for lunch the next day.  lunch was not leftovers from night before....
- desire to share this place via yelp after many month hiatus...and i went to Quince last night

MCF is:
ingenius
locally sourced
true love served on a plate
best bang for your buck

DON'T JUDGE A BOOK BY IT'S COVER: broccoli beef ****
LOOKS/TASTES LIKE MERCEDES, COST LIKE COROLLA: char sui pork belly
UNAPOLOGETIC: cumin lamb
I'D GO VEGAN FOR YOU: garlic eggplant


****do not pass this up!!!!!
author: Jane L.

description: After 1 1/2 hour wait for mediocre food. The porridge missed it's mark for missing the gelatinous texture. It was too watery. The string beans was mostly salt and red pepper. It just overpower the beans.
author: A Z.

description:
This is a review for delivery that included: 
Hainan Chinese Rice
Kungpao Pastrami
Mao po tofu
Thrice Cooked Bacon and Mongolian Green Beans

1) What I disliked most about this takeout is that it was so SPICY that I couldn't eat it.  If you want spicy tasty Chinese food go to Z&Y in Chinatown.  This is so spicy it hurts. 

2) Next, each of the 3 dishes TASTED THE SAME.  Smokey, peppery, salty, chili.  

3) Food was salty

So much hype - I thought the food would taste better if I wiped off the chili but by then, my tongue was already numb and my nose running.  

Unfortunately, not good enough to place another order or try at the restaurant proper.   If I did place another order, I'd order everything again except tofu - and I'd ask for NO CHILI.
author: Alias A.

description: Not a fan. Would love to support what the owners are trying to do, but the food just doesn't live up to the hipster hype. People, try some old school ma la. Please.
author: Da Wei S.

description:
After all the press coverage and acclaim, I was pretty excited to check out Mission Chinese Food. Sigh, the consequences of high expectations.

Here's what we ordered, and what I thought:
-Tea smoked eel rolls: Probably my favorite thing we had. Nice salty ham hock with tender eel and some bitter greens.
-Cumin lamb: Super tender but super fatty lamb with a flavorful char along with too many raw tasting onions on a sizzling platter. If you love fatty meat, then consider the lamb. 
-Thrice cooked pork belly: Again, with the raw-ish onions. Oily and non-memorable sauce flavor. Basically uncrisp bacon. I'd skip this one.

I think we may have just ordered poorly with too many stirfry style dishes; next time I'd get a soup and neither the lamb or pork belly were good enough to order again (the leftovers sat in the fridge 2 days before we ate them; that's pretty telling because something yummy would have been gone the next day).

Note the largest group allowed is 8 people and expect a wait. If you can, takeout would be the way to go.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I LOVE this place because the chinese food is eff-ing GREAT and well executed. The flavors are well-balanced and well developed; aggressive when it needs to be such as in the ma po tofu or controlled when it needs to be like in the rice porridge and broccoli beef cheek. My opinion on the dishes I've tried:

Westlake Rice Porridge - soooooo good and flavorful

Ma Po Tofu - soooooooo spicy, soooooo luscious, soooooo gooooood

Broccoli Beef Cheek - well-balanced, not too salty, crispy greens, tender, gelatinous and flavorful beef cheeks

Pork Belly - one of my favorites! crispy exterior, tender fatty moist interior

Fried Chicken Wings - not sure if this is still on the menu, but I had it a few months ago and despite being under a thick layer of dried fried chilies, i found the wings to be under-seasoned and bland.

Mongolian Long Beans - beans were a bit overcooked. found this dish to be boring 

Come during lunch to avoid the long wait for a table. Can't wait to come back to try the other dishes.
author: Robbie R.

description:
Hell yes this is the spot! After our delivery guy got a little lost (we had to hunt him down on the street - literally) we were pleasantly surprised by the HUGE order we had.
That said, I was heaven trying most everything we had.
My top picks were definitely the Tofu (spicy!) and Kung Pao Corned Beef (Yu-UM). The lamb was perfectly tender and bok choy was delish. We also had some asparagus that was really good and an egg roll that was fresh and HUGE. 
We did have some spring rolls that were too green & lettucey for my taste. 
Overall, this spot delivered in both senses! It was a fresh and delicious take on Chinese. I loved and will definitely have them deliver again.
The delivery guy forgot our soda, but he was very lost and flustered, so we cut him some slack.
author: Francesca F.

description: Interesting spin on your typical greasy chinese delivery. We ordered the tea eel, kung pao pastrami, green beans, and rice porridge. My favorite was the porridge but the rest were really delicious. A little heavy on the salt, but that's what you get with pastrami. I was expecting the delivery to take 2 hrs and they came in about 45 min! Overall enjoyed the meal and will order again.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Quite possibly some of the best spicy Szechuan food I've ever come across in these 27 long, difficult years.

My life before Mission Chinese food was like a colorless void.

My life since the Thrice Cooked Bacon, MaPo Tofu, and Sizzling Cumin Lamb has been more vibrant than a thousand supernovas.

Review 101!
author: Anthony K.

description:
OK so I have to admit that I was a little apprehensive after some of the reviews but being here fo rthe week, I decided to give it a whirl anyway as the menu was intriguing and a colleague in the area wanted to try it as well.  SOOO... we drug 6 of our colleagues out into the Mission to dinner around 6:30 on a Tuesday night.  Thankfully we were high on the list and the nice host agreed to seat us pretty quickly even though two of our folks were walkign form the BART station at Mission/19th.  We sat at one of the large tables in the center and our ever so charming host got us drinks quickly and then walked us through a list of "must tries" for us to enjoy family style.  The interior was as expected, funky and dark with club music playing in the background which got mixed reviews from our crowd (I loved it and others described it as maddening - lol).  The good thing was that as it grew darker outside, the interior was brighter.  We ordered the following and shared and had the associated impressions:

Vinegar Peanuts - Yummy and vinegarry while still crunchy (hone your chop stick skills young Jedi!).
Tea Smoked Eel - AMAZING - I am a huge eel fan and the dumpling wrap was awesome and the seasongin of the eel was not overpowering.
Pork Belly - YUM YUM YUM.  Not too fatty with a good "rind" on it.  It was a melt in your mouth not too salty experience
Ma Po Tofu - Really good an da favorit of more than one.  The tofu was a little slimy fo rme (but that's tofu) but the spice was magical!  Not too much just enough to make it interesting.
Kung Pao Pastrami - Patrami was so tasty - the amount was fine it was not greasy.
Broccoli Beef Brisket - Amazingly tender brisket with tons of CHinese broccoli in a good sauce.  REally nice annise notes.
Salt Cod Fried Rice - Yummy though nothing really crazy good.  I couldn't really discern the taste of the salt cod.
Squid Ink Noodles - SO GOOD!!!  The noodles are HUGE and were very well cooked and were quite tasty.  Not sure if there really was any add from the ink but it was really tasty and enjoyed by all.  
Long Beans - AWESOME but VERY SPICY!!!  I got a jalapeno by accident and WOO HOOO.  
Thrice Cooked Bacon with Rice Cakes - The bacon in this was SOOO nice and the small rice cakes were awesome (think quarter or 50 cent sized discs).

And the best part we had 8 folks for dinner who drank beer and the tab was a little over $200!!!!!  This was an amazing feat and everyone enjoyed it massively and we were all absolutely stuffed.

In conclusion - take this for what it is... a very positive review from someone that can be picky but that can also embrace a TWIST on a particular type of food (be it nouveau southern, fusion, whatever).  One thing we wondered is how the chef came up with all this stuff and how long it took in the test kitchen to refine all the flavors.

Be a little adventurous (the peeps in the Mission don't bite - much), loosen up and eat up y'all!
author: Shane J.

description: Believe it or not, the thrice cooked bacon is vegetarian - I have no idea why it has the word bacon in it.  It was a good selection for me, and I specifically liked the little rice cakes in the dish.  This had been on the "must try" list for quite some time so now that it is crossed out, I feel like "i came, i saw, I conquered" and don't really have a strong desire to go again.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I've heard a lot about this place so I can only assume my expectations were too high.  This place has an old school Chinese restaurant feel with hip hop from the 90's playing.  Hipster Chinese cool, I guess.  
Anyway, I had the pork belly that everyone seems to talk about and it was meh.  It was good - crispy exterior, melt in your mouth fat but not worth the hype and I've had better pork belly at other random Chinese restaurants.  Maybe I ordered the wrong thing for myself and should have opted for something else...
author: Tanya N.

description: I've avoided this place due to hype and the usual line out the door, but the other night we were walking by, hungry, and walked right in. Szechuan chicken wings were AWESOME. Double AWESOME actually. Those along will have me back for more. Also good people watching, plenty of well-dressed older tourists with Fodor's guidebooks in hand.
author: Bowen D.

description: Danny Bowein is a genius in the kitchen. After coming in today and witnessing the experience, I have this memory of these fusion style ingredients embedded in my tongue that'll stay with me for years to come. It's something special when a person who isn't even Chinese can create these dishes out of ingredients that nobody can ever expect and turn them into "Traditional Chinese" style cooking. I came around 5pm and there was already a small line outside. I was stopped by a clipboard outside of the shop presenting the crossed out names from each customer that already stepped foot inside. I must've been #20 something but was escorted inside within minutes. As I entered through, I noticed the dim lighting that darkened the room, the red Chinese New Year dragon hanging across the restaurant ceiling, the yellow walls, a crowded room with people talking and eating up, and the smell of Chinese food streaming across the room. It was a sight to see. The restaurant isn't that big anyway..tight pathways for people to walk through. I ordered the mouth watering chicken which contained smoked chicken, chicken hearts, and sichuan peppers. I had their famous Kung Pao Pastrami which was salty but was very unique. They used up whole slices of pastrami and created this traditional dish using celery and roasted peanuts. The cumin lamb was off the charts. The meat was tender and full of that cumin flavor which also arrived sizzling to our table. My favorite was the Cod fried rice because it had a different type of taste to it. The mackerel confit mixed well with the rice and eggs. My experience here was great! I'd like to come back again and try more! Thanks Danny.
author: Allister D.

description:
Chinese food had become predictable and honestly was no longer on my take out list... But we have fallen in love with Chinese food again!!! Where to start... is it the heat that assaults your senses with every bite, or the fact that you can still pick
Out all of the subtle flavors beyond the heat, the salt cod fried rice is subtle and balances the heat from the ma po tofu, the long beans are to die for, and Kung pao pastrami... What a brilliant combo!!! We did take out and were happy to avoid the line and the cramped quarters. So chineses is back on the take out list, but only the Mission kind.
author: Laurence B.

description:
The tiger salad was decent. The custard was quite good, though I'm disappointed that I didn't come here when they had sea urchin in the custard (as my friends told me they did) because that sounds amazing. The pork belly was quite good and made me wish it was in a bowl of ramen.  The thrice cooked pork was awesome though some of my friends thought it was too spicy.  It was nice to eat chinese food that wasn't exactly like every other chinese food place.

The downside is that this place doesn't take reservations and you either have to wait outside for quite some time (or put your name on the list and go hang out elsewhere for a while) or order the food to go. Despite the inconvenience (not to mention bad parking in the area) I still want to come back because the food was really good.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I wanted to like this place. Actually, i wanted to love this place. Before I criticize, I would first like to say "thank you" for showing that Chinese food can be unique. You won't find things like fried rice or typical Chinese fare here. Additionally, you can tell that the food is good quality. Here comes the "but"....

However, I had to take away a star for each of these less than desirable issues with the cuisine. (1) Although the dishes were unique in terms of combination, the added spices/flavors made everything taste pretty homogenous (2) Regretfully, the food gave me and my 5 companions the runs pretty immediately after eating (3) The food was far too spicy to isolate and enjoy the flavors of the meat and veggies. 

Unfortunately, my dinner companions and I found these points (especially #2 - no pun intended) to be enough not to give it another try in the near future. I do hope that the head chef reads this and integrates some of this information as I would like to see such a unique restaurant thrive.
author: sarah m.

description:
A cool idea, super nice chef, fun vibe and yet I had a terrible dinner. We were feeling adventurous, but all four dishes were a let down. The noodles in the sea weed salad were undercooked and whole thing was flavorless. The eel dish with cornflakes had a smokey sweetness which only hit one note and seemed tired at the second bite. The egg custard held promise, but under the fishy pudding were two chunks of mystery white meat, sad, flavorless and dry. The pork belly was dry despite the huge chunks of fat -it could have been delicious if rendered down. The soy sauce egg was uneatable.

I wanted to like this place. It was my second time there. But if things weren't going bad enough with the food, we were hit with a nauseating and lingering body odor bomb from our sweet young chef. 

Hipsters seem to love this place. It's great that it's accessible, down and dirty. But the dishes need a lot of work. All four of our dishes had the same level of sweetness and even mild taste. Where were the high notes? At least a little spice and there...

I'm keeping my fingers crossed the chef will continue to grow, experiment, refine and tighten his repertoire.
author: Suzanne L.

description:
I don't really think you can call this a pop up anymore, since they appear to be operating 6 days of the week out of Lung Shan. But that's alright with me, because they undoubtedly deserve their own home. 

The vegetarian/sea food options are not as plentiful as expected, but the braised green beans were FANTASTIC and the portions were enough for double leftovers. The steamed rice comes without a lid and got cold over the course of lunch. 

For two entrees, rice, and tea we paid $22, just the price you should pay for the delicious and oh-so-San Franciscan experience.
author: Rita C.

description:
...And as he noded from the meal at hand, a glorious vision dawned: 

Diamond glass pork belly - kissed lightly in the morning by it's soy love! 

Sacred trinity of egg, pork, and crab manifesting within the universal Congee. The alchemical yolk fused with each individual molten rice grain, and matter knew that it was spirit. 

Out into the cool crisp expanse, the buckwheat noodle joyously extended its infinite tentacle, aided in its quest by radish chili and vinegar...

Glutenous noodle-y goodness, wrap me in your ever accepting folds of cucumber-ish profundity.

And he arose from his transcendence, well satiated and provided for.
author: Zizzle f.

description:
Lung Shan, you are the bright spot in my hectic and stressful life. 

With beef  and pork that literally melts in your mouth to the wonderful seasoning and fantastic thick and delicious noodles, what is not to love? The mere mention of your name is enough to send me in a food frenzy. Each time I have eaten Lung Shan, I have never been disappointed. 

I highly recommend the stir fried pork jowl and winter radishes and the smoked beef brisket soup.

Big plus: you deliver out to my neighborhood, can it get any better? Possibly... if they took out the trash for me, too.
author: DeLune Avec DeBussy B.

description:
First time here! Went with my friends, 4 people in all. We were celebrating the return of a friend from overseas. It was just before 1pm when we arrived not hard to get a seat. 

Mouth Watering Chicken - I like this dish, but weird that they loaded a lot of peppers. I mean a lot on the plate with the chicken. It came with 8 pcs of chicken. Very crisp taste, that really got your mouth watering for more so be prepared with some water. 

Stir-fried Pork Jowl and Winter Radishes - Nice taste and the radishes went well with the pork. The jowl (cheek/jawbone) of a pig is probably the best part when it comes to eating anything off the head of a pig. The texture was awesome, very tender and juicy. 

7 Spiced Beef Tendon - Another one I enjoyed. The spices were even and you can distinguish most of the spices as you take bites into some really tender beef. Again a lot of peppers were in the dish, with more onion too.

Thrice Cooked Bacon - I love bacon, but this isn't your average bacon. It's a bigger cut but with the cooking process the flavor of the natural pork comes out even more. The flavor isn't genuine though just average with the oil and black bean. The bitter melons didn't really do justice maybe for something else to bite with the meat? 

Hainam Chicken Rice - I liked this rice, but with the ingredients it was just a little above par from your average chinese stir fried rice.

I might have to go here one more time. Because they didn't really hit the spot with some of the flavors I give them 3 stars. I liked the difference in dishes they offer which shows they try to do better than your average chinese restaurant. They did deliver on the flavor and the variety of dishes. I believe with this combo the price is great.
author: Rob D.

description:
I have to come back because I was with a friend who is vegetarian and I have a feeling this place might shine brighter with their meat dishes.

So with the vegetarian point of view, this place is OK but the service is 4 stars!

Our menu:
Salt cod fried rice - hmmm, not sure if I actually saw cod in our dish but it was good fried rice :)
Wild Pepper Leaves - yum!  the pressed tofu strips were so good!  Lots of pepper leaves, broth was excellent, wish there was more tofu.  Dish comes with a bowl of rice.

Mongolian Long Beans - love the concept of this BUT this dish uses the szechuan pepper that numbs your tongue -- hate that!  We asked the waiter to take it back, not as an insult but we couldn't eat it and there was no room on the table....they totally took it off our bill!  We were expecting to pay for it and they were gracious enough to take it off....that alone warrants 4 stars.

Waitstaff was nice and surprisingly, the wait for a table on a Friday night wasn't so bad....20minutes.
author: S K.

description:
Mission Chinese is in its own category when it comes to Chinese food in San Francisco. You can't experience flavors like this any where else in the city, that's why I feel it deserves all the hype. I never thought cumin and lamb would be such an impeccable combination but it sure as hell is. The Mao Pao Tofu was also outstanding, I'm a heat fean which may explain my love for the dish.  The thrice cooked bacon was also another home run, the smoky pork and the yummy rice cakes was another delightful combination . The Tiger Salad I thought was alright, nothing crazy. All in all, I think Mission Chinese is one hell of a place and I will be returning very soon. 

Btw: try to get their early on a week night to avoid the long waits.
author: Jonah G.

description: Delicious dishes - I had the Chinese broccoli beef brisket and my husband had the Tingly Lamb soup. Great flavor. Atmosphere definitely hipster and fun.
author: Allison V.

description:
I read about Mission Chinese Food in Bon Appetit over a year ago (it was featured in the top 10 best new restaurants in the U.S.) and have been looking forward to eating here ever since. I opted to get take out, so my review is strictly focused on the food, and not the atmosphere of the restaurant itself, which was loud and crowded! 

We ordered the salted cod fried rice, ma po tofu and mouth watering chicken. The salted cod friend rice was hands down one of the best Chinese/Asian dishes I have ever had. The cilantro on top gave it a nice flavor burst. The ma po tofu was SO spicy but in a good way. I opted to pull out the chili peppers but if you like the heat, leave 'em in. This MUST be enjoyed with rice. The mouth watering chicken was... interesting. This was my adventurous dish and I decided I don't like chicken livers, nor do I want to see 20 of them at once. The rest of the dish was delicious, but I was turned off by the livers. I went into this knowing I might not like it, but if you know you like chicken livers, the other flavors in the dish - cilantro, peanuts, cucumber - are quite refreshing. 

I wish I could bottle up Mission Chinese Food and take it back to Boston with me. Or at least some of that Salted Cod Fried Rice...
author: Sara N.

description:
The veggie chow mein was delicious, yet SPICY. Large portions so you could easily share. 
I'd skip the tiger salad the next time though, just some fresh herbs wrapped in a rice paper(ish).
author: Nora G.

description:
Food stand? Is this a food stand? I don't know why it's under this category on Yelp. Maybe they have a food truck I don't know about.

Anyway.

Dear lord, BRAISED BEEF CHEEK beef and broccoli. Hands down, made the entire trip to the Mission and the odd not-the-name-of-the-restaurant-but-serve-a-secret-menu experience worth it. Melt in your mouth beef. Real Chinese broccoli shoots. Oyster sauce. Not too spicy. Perfection.

Salt cod rice was a good complement, although I wish it had more visible fish.

Sizzling lamb cumin was just okay. I thought the addition of cumin was misplaced on a Chinese menu, but apparently it's a very common dish! It tasted good... just... didn't really complement the other dishes we got.

I didn't try anything with flaming chile oil, or anything that had little fire icons by the title of the dish, so I can't talk about the level of spiciness... but I hear it's dangerously hot. 

Next time, I'll go to sweat.
author: Hannah L.

description:
The Mission is a hipster place in the making. It's dotted with restaurants that are clearly meant for those who are foodies like Foreign Cinema and now Mission Chinese Food. Part of the gentrification of a neighborhood that is mixed with Asian families, Latin American families and every so often, William Rast wearing pork pie hat sporting hipsters. Mission Chinese Food is situated in Lung Shan Restaurant in the middle of the block. So you see a kind of run down storefront in a line of storefronts that are run down. 
    Because the foodie set have discovered it and they don't take reservations for this tiny place, you have to get there early. They have a list that you write your name on so you can get a table when one opens up. My husband and I arrived a half hour before they opened and stood at the gates waiting. More people started arriving around 1120am and about 1130, a young man walked up and before he wandered into the restaurant, politely apologized for how late they were opening.
   We were let in around 1140am and told to sit down anywhere we wanted. We sat down and then once most of the people were seated, were given menus then our place settings then glasses of water. The waitress was aloof, as if she just wanted this day over with already. The young man was trying to make sure everything was running smoothly, serving, taking orders. 
   The decor is in keeping with an old restaurant with kitschy choices. The dragon hanging from the ceiling, the red lanterns and the faded walls. There are no apologies that the place looks like a time capsule from the '60s. The modern music was an odd juxtaposition but amusing. 
   Our order was simple: the chicken schmaltz rice, thrice cooked bacon rice cakes and the pork belly. Our waitress took the order efficiently and went to the next table. We saw orders come out within about 15 minutes being delivered to other tables. Within about 20 minutes we got our rice cakes and pork belly. Between ordering and getting, we also got a carafe of cold water which was much appreciated. It took another 15 to get our rice.
   The rice was very nice, subtle in flavor with ginger notes. It was quite good but not the best of the three dishes we chose. The rice cakes - which I'm a sucker for when my Mom hits the Korean market delis - were cooked with chiles, bitter melon, onions, tofu and of course, the bacon. It was really lovely. The sweet rice cakes with the salty porky bacon... I drool thinking about it. But the pork belly. Oh the pork belly! Soy turned into a caramel that attacks your teeth and won't let go - in a good way. The pork belly is meaty with bursting fat that embraces the soy caramel. It's decadent.
   As for our waitress. I saw a couple reviews referring to the indifferent service. Yes our waitress was as I said, aloof. But I noticed after about the third time I said politely, thank you and please, she was wiling to crack a smile and warm up a tad. 
   The meal over all was really good. It made us very happy. The fact that before we walked in we had someone who was politely apologetic that the place was running behind schedule was quite nice.
author: Kim S.

description:
The Chinese food is more authentic than P.F. Chang or Panda Express. However it's too unhealthy for me: too salty and too heavily flavored (the above baselines are much worse). What I did immediately afterwards was drinking a whole bottle of coke to balance it out (there is a reason why unhealthy fast food restaurants offer cokes together with their fatty foods).

This restaurant deserves easily 4 stars if its not in San Francisco but hey it's SF!
author: Lo Y.

description: Thought the food was good and authentic! The only complaint I have is that all the meat had A LOT of fat on it! I know the fat has a lot of flavor, but when 1/2 to 3/4 of the meat is fat what am I supposed to eat? But it was really good and delicious ! Great flavors! The combination rice is really good! along with a lot of other things too.
author: Nick N Parker S.

description: Loved this place. For a vegetarian the menu looked a little sparse, but what I had was some of the best Chinese food ever! The rolls were some of the freshest tasting pasta I've had and the green beans were the favorite with even the carnivores in our party. My wife had the pork belly and loved it. The service was friendly and fast, even though there was a huge line, looking forward to our next visit.
author: Steve L.

description: Absolutely the best Chinese food restaurant I have ever been to. I absolutely love this place.
author: Henry R.

description:
The spicy food is actually spicy. You would think that this didn't have to be noted, but I've been disappointed by so many dishes claiming to be spicy.

I love the spicy wings. Nice crispy exterior with a nicely cooked interior.

The kung pao corned beef might be my favorite dish. When I first tried it, I described it as "interesting," then quickly changed that to "multi-faceted," since "interesting" is the sort of word someone uses when they don't really like a dish. Spice, smoke, texture--it was all good.

It's veggie/vegan friendly, if that matters to you.

There are quite a few restrictions on the menu that perhaps could be explained better, but it's all around a good place worth coming back to.
author: Diana O.

description:
I've been a foodie in SF for 6 years, so I'm used to waiting an hour for a table, bitchy hipster service, and even can deal with the hip-hop mix that I swear they stole from my 6th grade boom box. (Actually, haha, it actually made being there for almost 3 hours very amusing, to the disappointment of my boyfriend... ) 
But the service was the worst service all four of us have ever seen. 

And I don't even want to burn the sweet waiter and waitress! they just looked so tired, I wanted to give them a hug and a break. So I'm going to burn the owners!!! 
Give your employees some happiness/a break and for fuck's sake... hire some more people. They were doing the best they can, and this is the owners' mismanagement. I had to ask for our water twice from Both waiters, I asked for my drink twice, they took forever to take our order,  and once in... 

We received each dish one by one, with at least 7 minute intervals between each dish. Two vegetarians, two meat eaters, random dishes coming without things like Rice or the appetizer, it was a very uncomfortable food moment. 
We told the meat eating boys, please, eat before it gets cold. But no. They had manners (or the sense to wait for their own rice?) and then the food was cold when we had all the pieces. The cold food happened to be DELICIOUS, and I just kept wanting to give the workers more hugs.  And just as we had begun to feel fed and let go of any dreams of eating Soup, our Soup came! We had hoped to get the soup  Before the cold food we had just ate... but whatever.... it was warm. 

When we realized we were going to miss any movie plans because we had been there for so long, we tried to subtly wave the waiter & waitress down for the check. Ignored, I went up and asked for it. I got the worst evil eye from the hipster waitress, and immediately felt compelled to give her a hug and explain that we wanted to catch this movie... (we didn't)... but instead, I just glared back and wrote this yelp review. So, I'm sorry, and I hope you got your hug. 

& Damn. The food was so good.  (ALSO, they have a delicious second menu you have to ask about, but is soooo good)
author: Regina E.

description:
After much hoopla, I finally caved and tried Mission Chinese.

Aside from the wait, it was a great experience. Most of the food we had was good (not amazing, but good) - the General Tso's Veal Rib on the other hand, was blow your mind - melt in your mouth, outstanding! Even the dishes I didn't love, made up for their shortcomings by keeping my interest. The Kung Pao Pastrami was mostly tasty, at times odd and had a spice that flirted with painful - but somehow worked. The wait staff was attentive and friendly. The atmosphere super dark and super loud with a huge paper dragon snaking along the entire ceiling - a bit contrived, but cool.

If your expecting typical Chinese food or a refined dining experience - either check your expectations at the door or go somewhere else. There is no shortage of great places in the city for that, but if you want to try something different - check this place out.
author: Dean B.

description: Believe the hype. The two times I have eaten here, the food was fantastic. I am rarely impressed by noodles, but the vegetarian chow mein is delicious. Likewise, I will have a hard time not ordering the chili chicken every time I go.
author: alli K.

description: Love what Danny has done here. Very very unique and satisfying experience, and this is coming from a Chinese guy who grew up on Szechuan and Cantonese food. The menu and food definitely pays homage to the tradition as well as attempts innovation that has paid off. Love the hipster ambiance and the gangster rap too.
author: Sam K.

description:
Here's what Alan Rickman says about Mission Chinese Food in GQ's July 2011 issue, "Smoked Beef Brisket - So soft, I was sure it was braised. Not so. Just an old-fashioned way of cooking. twelve hours of low heat. Beats most Texas brisket."

Really if it's good enough for Severus Snape and Hans Gruber, isn't it good enough for you?
author: Javier S.

description: Way too spicy to eat. Food is not good and not impressive. Why always so crowded? I'll stick to Hunan on 16th
author: Becca S.

description:
Personally it may have been a bit too authentic for my taste. If you like to experiment or if you are more adventurous than the average Jack, I'd definitely give it a shot. 

I love spicy food- really spicy food. I mentioned this to the waiter, and the chef made me an AMAZING ghost pepper sauce. The produce seemed very good and the meat was tender, a lot of good stuff to experience. Perhaps if the cuisine were different, I would have liked it better.
author: Vivek N.

description: I love this place. If I had one negative thing to say it's that sometimes the food is a little bit to oily.  But  over all its great.
author: jeff c.

description:
We were recommended to this place by a friend who described that this place offer good quality chinese foods.

We didn't eat in as most of the reviewers who gave good reviews to this restaurant did. We had the food delivered to us.

We ordered pork belly which was ok, but it's hard to swallow everything else when we saw a blob of big giant fat on the beef broccoli dish. We were so disgusted by it. The ma po tofu was borderline ok, but super oily and spicy. At the end we didn't eat much of the foods. We ate alot of the white rice. As that was the only things worth eating.
author: Christine W.

description: Nothing original...Lots of dishes are inspired from authentic chinese dishes and are poorly executed. For a party of 8, portion sizes require at least 2 order of apps, which is unacceptable considering that many of the ingredients aren't that expensive and they're charging quite a high price for them.  We had a reservation at 730 and at 845, we were told we needed to leave to make room for other guests, which is ridiculous. They also brought us rice, which we didnt request and they chrage for. Initially, they also tried to give us 2 tsingtaos, which no one at our table ordered, and they promptly placed back into their deli fridge to serve to some undeserving hipster flat beer...Overall, this place is overhyped and pretty much not worth patronizing. The interior is also very dark so you can't see the dirty glasses and dishes and they play really loud music to dull the rest of your senses so you think their below par food is even fit for consumption.
author: Roger S.

description:
3.5 stars.  Got the mapo tofu, szechuan pickles (spicier than typical kimchi by the way), salted cod fried rice, and the char siu pork belly.

What?  Girl's got to eat!

Shared it for dinner with the bf but they gave so much mapo tofu that we have enough leftover for lunch and dinner tomorrow.  My favorite was the the ginger scallion noodles that came with the pork belly and the fried rice (like the smoky taste of it).  Mapo tofu was good but thought it could use a little bit more salt.  I liked the fried crispy fatty portion of the pork belly - the only time you'd see me eating pork fat!  I am Filipino after all and we can't say no to fatty stuff.  Bf really liked the pickles.  Ordered for delivery and food came in exactly 45 mins.  Nice delivery guy too!
author: Sherielyn G.

description: Amazing food. Spicy. Get fried chicken wings, pork belly, dumpling.
author: Shabab G.

description:
I went here with a group of friends (6 people total) on a Saturday night.  We had to wait probably 45 minutes or so, but not too bad considering the place is fairly small.  Only downer is outside of the bizarre people watching, there is not much to do right nearby while you burn time.

One of us was a vegetarian so we split our dishes between five of us.  We ordered four entrees, as well as a few small appetizers, and it was an appropriate amount of food.  

The Beijing Vinegar Peanuts and Szechuan Pickles were interesting and pretty tasty; certainly a fun snack while you wait for your meal.

The Tingly Lamb Noodle Soup was only ok; the consensus seemed to be that the lamb meat chunks did not really fit well.

The Kung Pao Pastrami was excellent (but be prepared for the spice!).

Thrice Cooked Bacon is another spicy but delicious winner.

I also enjoyed the Open Faced "Chinese BBQ" Sandwich, which is a fun take on a bbq sandwich (literally served on top of white bread).  However, others in the group seemed a bit more apathetic about it.

Overall, the food was excellent.  The only real downsides to the place are that it is INCREDIBLY dark!!  It was actually a bit frustrating as it was so dark and the tiny bit of light that was there was orange.... so it was actually difficult to figure out which dish was which at times!  

Also, be prepared that the soundtrack was almost exclusively 90s/early-00s rap/hip-hop hits.
author: Ryan H.

description:
First and foremost, I am an American Born Chinese. I know what real Chinese food and American Chinese food taste like. This place has it's own category of "Chinese," and it's not a good one.

My boyfriend told me there were lots of talk about how this place was "the place to eat" in San Fran at the present but I have no idea why. We both didn't have high expectations for the place but you can't believe how disappointed I was.

Chili oil, salt, and MSG was all I could taste. Oh and the charred meats were black, hard, and not edible. The majority of the dishes were so salty, I couldn't keep eating. We had the buckwheat noodle, veal, pig tails, kao pao pastrami, a cold chicken dish of some sort, can't remember the rest of the boring overly salted dishes. I love chili but seriously there aren't any other spices noted. Innovative and creative my a**. 

The Fried Rice was the only thing that was half way decent. 

Hip? If you like loud, dark, and dingy places. It really needs to clean up a bit unless you want someone to come back and sue if they get sick. 

Yes service was lacking. Why do you have 3-4 people standing in the back looking confused. 

Sad sad sad excuse for an "American Chinese" restaurant. I have no hope for this place and will surely not be revisiting it again.

Beware, don't waste your time or money on this place.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Ordered the salt cod fried rice and broccoli beef cheek to go.  

The salt cod fried rice was pretty good, except they were stingy on the cod and the lap cheong (Chinese sausage).

Broccoli beef cheek was WACK!  The beef was braised and that just made it all wrong.  It was pretty tender but it wasn't the delicious tenderized beef that I'm used to at normal Chinese restaurants.  Why mess up a classic?  Also, the gai lan was pretty bitter...

The food is pretty pricey!  Took an hour to get the food delivered.
author: Melissa W.

description: I feel like this place is a bit overrated. I only tried the mapo tofu, cod fried rice and thrice cooked bacon. The thrice cooked bacon was just salty bacon. The cod fried rice lacked any flavor. The mapo tofu was decent but not amazing. I remember their peanut appetizer being good though and maybe the cucumbers.
author: Eric S.

description:
I love everything about MCF.  When I worked at MSF it was amazing but when it closed i was so sad!  Danny and Anthony have done something incredible here and even though i no longer live in SF I still direct people here!  I also visit every time i am in town and have brought my whole family here from sacramento.
get the bbq!  you won't be dissappointed.

If you don't like it, oh well.  more for the rest of us.
author: Logan M.

description: I've been a few times and I love it! The Smashed Cucumber Salad is really nice and refreshing as a starter. The Salt Cod Fried Rice is one of my favorite rice dishes ever. It can have a really strong salt/fish taste, so if you dislike either of those flavors it may be a bit too much for you; but it pairs nicely with the Thrice Cooked Bacon. I wasn't a big fan of the Rice Pudding.
author: Kelso H.

description:
Service: The spunky hostess with the tattoo sleeves was fabulous, getting people seated as quickly as possible (which was no small feat considering the HUGE crowd waiting to eat and the tiny seating capacity of this joint).  The servers were all friendly and helpful; I think 3 of them took turns with our table.

Food: It smelled amazing inside.  Every plate I saw looked appetizing.  We started with the pickled veggies, which were tasty.  Then came the Mongolian Long Beans.  WOW.  Spicy, flavorful, perfectly cooked, and a generous portion.  Amazing, you must order them!  The "Tingly" Lamb soup was really unique.... strong and different flavors combined nicely in this broth cumin-herby-savory-meaty soup.  The pork belly with pineapple was also good; with cold vinegary cucumbers to balance the fatty savory pork belly, all in a delicious plum sauce. 

Atmosphere: It could be off-putting or an adventure, depending on your personality.  The food was fine-dining, the place had a funky-diner vibe.  Empty "Crystol" bottles with fake roses on the table.  You have to walk through the kitchen/prep area and out the back door to the bathroom (mind the sign that says not to ask anyone anything when walking through the kitchen).  Icicle lights strung along the walls and a giant lit up red dragon on the ceiling....  I appreciated the funky, unpretentious feeling.

I will definitely go back to try other things on the menu (and to eat those long beans again.... yum!)
author: kasey c.

description:
I came here the first time about 4 years ago with a friend when the place was just open on certain nights. Back then I thought it was novel idea to run a comfort chinese food restaurant out of an otherwise ordinary greasy chinese to-go place in the Mission.  Flavors were different and blended together well in many cases.
 
Well jump to  4 years later, I am back with some friends and parents. I didn't expect my traditional chinese parents to get the twist on the dishes, but at least they would experience different ways of preparing traditional chinese comfort food and get a kick out of the flavors.  The wait is about 1 hr long, even for a Sunday night.  We ordered about 9 things off of the menu.  The highlight was the egg-egg noodle ( which was not salty), and the low light was between the mongolian long bean and sizzling lamb served on a sizzling platter.  The mongolian long bean was salty to the point of inedible.  There was some chinese spice in the bean that made my mouth tangy and numb, and whatever salt was in the beans was magnified about 100 times.  I could not eat a bite of food for about 5 minutes while I waited for the taste in my mouth to clear away.  The sizzling lamb had a very small about of  lamb in it and it tasted dried and way over cooked, plus it wasn't sizzling (not sure why it is served on the sizzling platter).   We also ordered a kung pao pastrami.  The pastrami meat itself is salty to begin with, and the other kung pao ingredients were also salty.  The beef noodle was very different than any other I've ever had. It has a smoked beef brisket in a soy sauce broth which was a nice mixture.  But because there was so much salt in the other 3 dishes, I had a very negative reaction to the entire meal, and I couldn't wait for the meal to end this night because this is the second place I've brought my parents where I was very disappointed (the other being michelin rated Commis in Oakland which I have not written about yet on Yelp).  After dinner, we stood outside the restaurant for about 10 minutes discussing why this place is so successful. 

 I don't want to pan the place too much, because it is creative chinese food. These guys work very hard and they are super busy. But it was a not a good meal this night
author: James W.

description:
My wife and I went here for the first time aware of the hype surrounding this place.  We're both seasoned foodies and do not suffer mediocre food gladly.  We both left this place with big smiles.  

The food.  Amazing.  Chicken wings, thrice-cooked bacon and the salt-cod rice.  Wings spiced just right.  In fact, perhaps the best wings EVER.  The combination of the rice and bacon flavors was just right.  The food arrived hot and right off the stove.
