Service.  On it.  The waitstaff were friendly, attentive and busy.  No attitude.  

Price.  The value/price ratio off the charts.  

I've heard some talk this place down.  Perhaps the hype doesn't live up to the expectations of some.  For us, it exceeded ours.  Well done.  

Oh, we'll be back.
author: Michael H.

description:
Came here about 7-8 PM and we had about a 35 minute wait. The place wasn't that big so we had to wait outside.

When we were being seated, it was hard to maneuver around and sit comfortably because it was obvious that they were squeezing people in to accommodate as many people as possible.

The food was good, expect more of an asian fusion than authentic Chinese food here. We had the spicy tofu, westlake rice porridge (which had a little too much going on), and I just loved the tea-smoked eel. I would come back here just for that.

The place was pretty busy so don't expect the fastest service, especially since it takes a while for the waiter to make their way towards you. And if you don't like being in a restaurant filled halfway with hipsters, I suggest trying someplace else. Besides that, it was a good place to talk and catch up with friends for dinner as it was pretty loud so you didn't have to worry about the next table overhearing your conversation.
author: Jayme N.

description:
Are you looking for authentic chinese food?  If yes, don't come here. 
Is ambiance a key factor in your enjoyment of a restaurant?  If yes, don't come here. 
Do you mind waiting in line during normal dining hours?  If yes, don't come here. 

If you're still with me, and you think cheeks and belly are the most delicious part of animal, I think you'll like place.  Sure it's full of hipsters.  Sure it's overpriced.  But anywhere that I can have inventive, delicious, and suprising food is always a win.  It's not perfect, but it's pretty darn good.
author: H. M.

description:
It truly is the best Chinese restauran in the city! It is definitely not your traditional Chinese restaurant. So, if you are expecting to order Kung Pao Chicken or the many common ho-hum dishes we run into at "Chinese" restaurant, you will be left to seek an alternative dish--and love it! 

The inherited decor from Lung Shun is perfect because then we are not distracted by interior design. You can't buy the energetic ambiance that is just buzzing from happy diners and happy workers, because it's all about the food..fresh ingredients, cooked creatively.
author: Genie H.

description:
COME EARLY or BE SORRY~!  

Tip: when they spicy, they mean SPICY.  The spicy green beans, although tasty, was SUPER spicy.  The dish looked like they dumped a whole bottle of spicy pepper oil onto the platter.  It was pretty ridiculous, but good....almost unedible though.

Crab fried rice - perfectly season.  Probably a TON of salt...but hey, it was HELLA good and a favorite

the cubes of pork - I think it's in the appetizer section was my favorite!  Comes with a slightly undercooked hard boiled egg, some flat rice noodles, and cucumbers.  DA BOMB

Another fatty/meat dish was the baby cow - huge piece of meat served with a knife stabbed into it.  

Get at it!
author: Janet L.

description: Came here for lunch on a Sunday...no wait! Ordered mapo tofu and salted cod fried rice. It's not quite traditional Chinese but the flavors are really rich! Food also came out really promptly and prices were fair - so all in all I read a solid place!
author: Bonnie S.

description:
Had the Kung pao pastrami it was decent. Meat was limited and if there was more then it would be top notch. Flavor was on point and the other pieces blended well with my ipa.

Menu is very creative and price was standard sf. 

I hope they don't get too uppity after the gq article
author: Chris A.

description:
Excellent Chinese Food. The tea smoked eel is delicious. For spicy food lovers.
Service is fast and attentive.
Even during the week there is a line to get a table. It can be very noisy inside.
Overall a decent place, however overrated for the wait.
author: Anne C.

description:
Totally loving it. Had lunch here today with my friend Leah and we totally hipstered it out. 

Walked in, grabbed a seat and Anthony came to our table. We asked him what we should order and he gave us a few really great options. So glad we asked, because he pointed us towards some delicious grub!

We shared 3 plates and a side of rice: pork belly (you can never go wrong). This dish was freaking kick-ass. Speaking of kick-ass, Anthony is kinda cute. I digressed. 

The other two plates were pork dumplings and thrice cooked bacon. The bacon dish was redick and the dumplings were so-so (maybe on off day for those). 

I loved the food, Anthony was incredibly nice and forthcoming with information (Leah loves to know it all; in a good way!), and I love the charitable aspect of the restaurant. 

I look forward to coming back, trying more dishes, and chatting it up!
author: Art A.

description: I don't understand how this place is so popular. We order a bunch of random things to try (their specialty) because we saw it in t.v.... wow, I was shock, I actually didn't like anything.. maybe I had too much expectation....Sorry, this place is not for me
author: Trinity L.

description:
My hipster foodie friend can't stop talking about this place.  So I gave it a try.  Actually, two tries - both time take out.

The first time I ordered Mongolian Beef Cheek.  It was a chunk of roast quality beef with an larger chunk of fat connected to it.  And a ton of chilis and onions.  Total let down.  My mouth was on fire and my arteries were quivering at the site of so much animal fat.

Second time I get the Lamb Breast Soup (lamb breast?  who comes up with this shit?) and was pretty disgusted.  The "Lamb Breast" was strips of fat about an inch thick with a small skin of actual meat.   I had to resort to picking off the meat with my fingers because there was no way I was going to eat that much fat.  Total quantity of meat would probably be about a tablespoon - though it was pretty tasty lamb (then again, I was famished at the time).  The broth, noodles and bok choy were a yawn.

This place sux and the fact it is popular is just another example of how completely stupid most hipster faux-foodies really are.

AVOID!
author: Jude G.

description:
Does your level of expectation color the result/experience?  Perhaps.

I have been dying to go here because so many of my friends have raved about this place.  But somehow, it took me a whole year to finally have dinner here with 2 friends.  I love spicy.  Spicier the better.  So, seeing spicy and extra spicy options on the menu was love.

Our favorite was thrice cooked bacon (while most love bacon, I'm not a big fan but I loved this dish!).  But, I gotta say, many of the dishes missed the mark.  Mapo Tofu was one of those as well as the Curried Buckwheat noodles.  With so many restaurants to try out in the city, I don't think I'll be able to make a revisit here which may help balance out this experience.  Oh well.
author: Amy Y.

description: The food was not great and they charged almost 24% gratuity for terrible (read: almost nonexistent) service. Would advise everyone to stay away from this place.
author: Andy W.

description:
i would go so many miles for this restaurant. wish they had one in LA or anywhere in southern California. i absolutely love this restaurant. their menu is just amazing. I have a hard time deciding what to get because everything is very tasty. 

Thrice Cooked Bacon
West Lake Rice Porridge 
Chongqing Chicken wings
Sizzling Cumin Lamb
Tso's Veal Rib 

love the decor, hipop & indie music in the background!!
author: Karmen H.

description: This place was memorable for me only because of how crazy the interior design was.Went in for dinner with three other friends. The service was good and the interiors kept you amused/distracted. I admire the creativity on the menu (and interiors. Yes, I'm mentioning it again!) however, the food was nothing too exciting. I felt like it was overpriced for what it was. I guess the place just really threw me off and my taste buds were in a constant state of confusion - is the food legit Chinese food or was it some sort of play on the "mission hipster" food? That's a great question that can be asked about many other restaurants. But I'm not trying to discredit the chef - the food was good and tasty, for sure. I was just expecting the awesomeness of flavors that usually comes with a "hole-in-the-wall", dingy type of restaurant.
author: Cara S.

description:
I was lucky enough to eat half of their updated menu. Everything I ate was delicious and a few of the dishes were really and truly superb. 

All MCF's ingredients are fresh, very fresh. They use all local produce and meats, and one can really taste the difference in a dish like Tingly Lamb Noodle Soup. The broth is clear; it's rich. The lamb tastes like lamb, but without a game-y aftertaste. The meat has no gristle. The soup is delicately spiced with raw, shaved ginger and scallions, which creates just enough brightness. He uses thick, hand-made Shanghai-style noodles, and the consistency is satisfying and chewy, not dough-y or sticky as hand-made noodles can be. 

I also loved the Char-Siu pork over rice noodles with shaved scallions and ginger... perfectly charred and sweetened pork without sacrificing tenderness. And the rice noodles are coated with shaved ginger and scallions and lightly topped with a sweet vinegar. It melds sour, tangy, and spicy while allowing the pork to be savory without erring on the side of salty. 

And the Salt Cod Fried rice is amazing. It just has to be eaten carefully.  It's a little different than the dish that inspired it, which is a classic Salty Fish Fried Rice. Traditionally, the fish is very salty and smelly, and mixed into the rice. But in this, he skips the smelly, and the cod is fried and placed as a whole piece on top of the rice. And this is amazing, because it's palatable for more people. 

The key to getting all the flavors in this dish is to fill your spoon with a piece of the perfectly-prepared fish as well as some of the rice and sausage. Eaten this way, it's revelatory. The sausage is thinly sliced, because it's a traditional sweet sausage, meant to be a complement to the sweetness of the rice. And if you look at your spoon or notice what is happening texture-wise, you'll also see that the rice is broken-up to create that texture, which is a good way to get at how sweet the rice is all on its own. 

Finally, if the Szechuan pickles are the diced long beans in chile oil, then that is also, absolutely delicious. It's Chinese long beans, which are like a longer version of American green beans. They are cut-up and then soaked with thinly sliced chiles and chile oil. The final product is crisp and the chile is piquant. It's really, really good. And it actually reminds me almost exactly of the pickled sides I actually had in Sichuan, years ago.

The one thing about the place is that it was a little hard on my ultra-sensitive stomach the next day. But I'm a plain rice and veggie eater when I'm not going all out. So my suggestion is for any eater at MCF to think carefully about what you want, maybe ask if they'll comp you a bowl of steamed rice to go with your main dishes (if you get something like the Taiwanese eggplant, for example), and go slow. Eat spoonful by spoonful. The food is quality. It's authentic Chinese basics using great, local ingredients and prepared with care. And if you eat slowly and thoughtfully, you'll find you've never had a better meal. 

I thought my my meal was genius. More of my MCF love can be found here: http://hyphenmagazine.com/blog/archive/2010/08/love-mouthful-review-mission-chinese-food
author: Joy T.

description: The decor reminds me of what you would dream of if you had a hangover and an MSG overload from chinese takeout. The food is OK. I've had better salt cod fried rice elsewhere. There weren't any lines during lunch. Eh.
author: Giang L.

description:
I enjoyed it. I won't go as far to say that it's the No.2 restaurant of the year. But it's a clever and well executed spin on Chinese food. 

By no means is this a traditional menu. While dishes are more Chinese than anything else, they borrow flavors from cuisine throughout East and South Asia. One could argue that if dressed differently, these could all be dishes on a more contemporary Asian-Am tapas menu. 

The food is really rich, so you might get satisfied really quickly even though portions are huge. I say go with a group. Try the Pork Belly, Ma Po Tofu, Sizzling Lamb (heavy on the cumin), and Salty Cod Fried Rice. There are better places to have renditions of the Savory Egg Custard, so pass on that.
author: Jonathan V.

description:
Interesting flavor combinations and types of dishes make this place stand out amongst your typical chinese restaurant. We enjoy the salt cod fried rice both times we were there and really liked the lamb dish despite only getting 3-4 pieces of bones with almost all the meat shaved off, probably for use in another dish?... All the other dishes we have tried thus far (pork jowl and turnips, broccoli and beef cheek, and brisket noodle soup) were good with very different  and unique flavors, but were all too salty and greasy since the dishes all had very fatty cuts of meat. We felt the pork belly was fried too long and didn't like the taffy-like texture. 

The place is cramped and dingy and the staff don't seem to be the most sanitary (I wonder how clean they are in back when they felt comfortable putting new napkins that had accidentally fallen on the floor in the clean pile in front of customers). I got knocked several times by the wait staff and was lucky the soup didn't drop all over me.  The plates and chopsticks weren't clean either. 

Although I did enjoy the taste of each dish and am still curious about some of the other dishes on the menu, I don't think we will return again for a long time since both times we've been there, I have felt the dishes overall are just way too salty. And on top of it all, they are very expensive for this type of restaurant.  I noticed some other reviewers felt this place is cheap or reasonable.  Either they've raised their prices now that they've gotten so popular (and have changed to a trendy new name) and are catering to a more Americanized crowd or else over $10 entrees for lunch is considered cheap.
author: Christine W.

description: This place is over rated and caters to people that may not have eaten much good Chinese food. They put way too much salt and spice into almost everything. Heck, if I can barely feel my tongue, anything will probably taste good.
author: Missy X.

description:
Definitely worth checking out... if your wanting something outside the "norm" of Americanized Chinese Food.. then this is place is a must.  

The Salted Cod Fried Rice is incredible. 

The decor could have used some work
author: Chris L.

description: The place is certainly overhyped. The food was no different than that at any other average chinese restaurant, and the service was acceptable at best.
author: Anurag B.

description: So busy on a Wednesday night!  But I don't mind waiting 50 minutes for my table of two.  New found love dish - Lamb Cumin!  It's over the TOP spicy HOT!
author: Pam S.

description:
I still can't believe how cheap the prices are compared to the amount and quality of food you get. I get waaay too much food every time I come here but it's totally worth it because not only do you help donate to the SF food bank, but you get delicious leftovers.

I've had the egg custard (4/5), tea-smoked eel (4/5), lion's head (4/5), chinese BBQ (4/5), salt cod fried rice (5/5), and broccoli beef cheeks (3/5). I loved the flavor and interesting texture of the eel but it was a tad too sweet. The lion's head would have been better if it had been less salty. The salt cod fried rice is perfect.

It always helps to eat at odd hours to avoid long lines in the city. I once ate here around 4PM on Saturday with no wait and we even got free pickles!
author: Janet L.

description:
Finally made it to eat here after much anticipation. The place is always packed with at least an hour wait. Made it early on a Monday evening with a short wait.

The place lives up to the hype. A very small and decent space (no air and it get pretty hot inside), with some interesting decor and a pretty cool huge dragon going along the entire ceiling.

The menu is simple with a good variety of intriguing dishes that are all very reasonably priced. 

Ordered the pork belly app (yumm) crispy crunchy outside with a soft moist scrumptious fatty inside. Very interestingly presented on top of rolled up noodles and an amazing soy egg (never had anything like it before)

Also had the Tingly Lamb Noodle Soup. The lamb was melt in your mouth delicious and the broth was very tingly indeed. Almost a little overpowering, very unique and definitely a must try.

My favorite though was the Salt Cod Fried Rice. Wow! this was good and a dish I highly recommend. 

The food came out quick, a little too quick. I would have liked to enjoyed our app then the soup and rice, but the soup came out first and then the rest of the dishes. They just pump them out to you as they come, which I don't really mind.

Over all this place is pretty darn amazing with great, unique, interesting, cheap food. I will definitely come back to try the other menu items.
author: Uriah B.

description:
Ok, this is probably the most hipster restaurant I have ever been to.  Tacky decorations leftover from the previous Chinese restaurant? Extremely dim lighting supplemented by Christmas lights? Check. Waiting in line even though there are multiple empty tables waiting to be cleared? Check.  Music is someone's iTunes playlist on a Macbook in the corner? Check.  (Uncensored 90s rap FTW)

But you know what? The food is actually pretty good. And cheap to boot. It manages to somehow remind me of my mom's home cooking and yet incorporates new flavors and ingredients that would never be found in her kitchen. Pretty nifty trick.

Salt cod fried rice - spot-on. 
Pork belly with tea smoked egg - yum. 
Tingly lamb noodle soup - wtf (they weren't kidding when they said "numbing broth"!) 
Mongolian beef cheek - spicy and delicious.
Broccoli beef - this ain't your Panda Express version.
Taro chrysanthemum panna cotta - the only thing I would pass on (one-note and too sweet).
Flying ninja on the website - fucking awesome.

If liking this place means I'm a hipster, I don't want to be right.
author: Leslie L.

description:
A friend recommended trying this place and he had rave reviews. I didn't know what to expect from a Chinese restaurant in the Mission District. I was definitely worried when I saw the chicken wings come out on a plate swimming in a sea of hot peppers. But luckily there were some dishes that weren't so spicy. There were some surprising dishes like the broccoli beef which is not what you expect - it was Chinese broccoli and 1 big chunk of braised beef cheek. The Ma Po Tofu was also good - the gravy was just right. The Pork Belly was delicious on the bed of a slice of toast. This is a different take on the typical Chinese food. The meal was fulfilling and I ordered a soda since the tap water had an odd taste. 

Came here with a group of people at before 12 noon and there was no wait. The place not that big and our party took up like 1/3 of the restaurant. When the meat cravings come, this is where I'll be.  

On a side note: I was reading an article on 7x7 and saw Danny Bowien was listed as 1 of 10 finalists for the up-and-coming chefs of SF. woo-hoo good luck to him!
author: Candace F.

description: Came here because ma po tofu was on "the list". Didn't think it was that good and it was really spicy for me. Also, got their mustard greens because i wanted something not spicy and healthy...and thought it was just okay. They weren't cut up so it was hard to eat and really bitter. Disappointed in this place especially since it was on "the list" and had good yelp reviews.
author: Liwei Y.

description:
Overall, I thought this restaurant did live up to the "hype" - I'm always a little worried when I go out somewhere that I've heard so much about since it's hard to live up to expectations, but I was really pleased with the atmosphere and the quality of the food.

We had the thrice cooked bacon (my favorite - spicy but not overly so, with chewy rice cakes, sweet tofu skin, bitter melon, and chilis - bacon was very tender and flavorful); the pork belly small plate (so-so - the pork could have been more tender and the preserved eggs were SO salty, but the rolled noodles were to die for!); and the cumin lamb (my boyfriend's fav - not spicy at all, super tender and flavorful). I also snuck a bite of our neighbor's ma po tofu - we were at a communal table and struck up good conversation with them.  That dish was more spicy, but very flavorful and tasty.
author: Sara C.

description:
This food is merely OK. Maybe below OK. The chinito was obviously sitting in the refrigerator all day long and microwaved. And not microwaved enough, it was cold in the middle.

The vegan delight was bland and uninteresting. I mean, I liked it fine, but it wasn't on my top ten for Asian soups.

The lamb pot was way too hot. Call me a wimp, but spice should add to flavor, not cover it and make you cry. I love spicy stuff, but a meal that challenges you to finish it is not a good meal, its a gimmick.

This could only be good Chinese food to hipsters who never leave the mission. Take the BART downtown and have a real Chinese meal. You'll thank me.
author: Mark F.

description:
Savory Egg Custard - believe the hype... this is good if you like stuff that has an ocean/fish flavor... I do so I was incredibly impressed with this. This is a dish served cold... the revenge of the eggs! Sea Urchin, Salmon, and chicken eggs mixed together. The chicken egg is the base for the custard, and it is topped with salmon eggs and uni with a cold broth. Very unique.

Char Siu Pork Belly - a deep fried pork belly with plum sauce and flat noodles. I thought it was good, as it tasted similar to Lechon Kawali, the filipino equivalent of deep fried pork belly. The plum sauce was a great compliment to the dish, and the rice noodles added a nice bit of neutrality to the strong plum sauce and fatty pork belly.

Ma Po Tofu - Not your average Ma Po Tofu... this is completely different from any Ma Po Tofu out there... it uses pork belly, and has seasoning like star anise! Very interesting modernized take on Ma Po Tofu. A little heavy on the star anise, as it did taste like black licorice at some points. This dish is pretty spicy... definitely spicier than what I'm used to from Ma Po Tofu. The tofu is also different... as most places I've eaten this at uses firmer tofu which allowed for cubing... they use a softer tofu, so the texture is mushy.

Overall, a good experience for me. My gf didn't like it, but I thought it was good. Price point is high for Chinese food, but again, this isn't your typical chinese restaurant.
author: Marc T.

description:
Damn I had high expectations given the fact that it was listed as a top restaurant in the nation.

The food was ok and priced ok. I definitely had better food - Chinese or not.

I ordered the tea smoked eel, salt cod fried rice and the pork belly...just nothing special about it. 

I applaud them for reinventing these recipes and making it very creative...but the taste was missing. I didn't feel it was "elevated" enough to recieve high praises.
author: Brian P.

description:
FINALLY got a chance to eat here after four previous attempts!  First and foremost I must say I get annoyed by restaurants that don't take reservations.  It makes no kinda sense.  It irritates people.  Perhaps in the future there will no longer be this frustrating first come first serve free for all.  As a big big fan of anything spicy this place hit the mark for me with very spicy Sichuan style dishes inventively prepared.  Expect a lot of numbing Sichuan peppercorns and chili paste and chili oil.  

The ambience is your typical hole in the wall Chinese eatery with random mismatched pictures on the wall and a tacky paper dragon on the ceiling.  But as with many dumpy Asian restaurants the food more than makes up for the surroundings.  

No complaints at all about the food!  The tea smoked eel, Hainan chicken rice and cumin lamb were really good.  Lamb in a Chinese dish works surprisingly well, at least the way they do it.  The piece de resistance has got to be the spicy chicken wings in a basket of flaming hot dried chilies.  Salty, hot, crispy, even the dried chillies were great.  I compare most spicy Sichuan food to Spices II on Clement and 6th ave.  Both places are great in its own right.  Spices II is more traditional fare and Mission Chinese is more creative and fusion.  It's lived up to all the hype.  I'll be back again.
author: P.J. D.

description:
So much fun. A great experience. Who knew how much fun it could be to eat chinese food in a teeny tiny crowded space with blaring hip hop on the dial? 

Crowd of people outside is deceiving, it looked like it would take an hour for a table, but we only waited about 20 min. Don't let the sign on the awning fool you either, this place is a restaurant inside a restaurant--- so like, we're doing metafood now too? Don't ask me how to actually order the food from the other place...

Just as i started to believe that there's only so much you can do with with szechuan, this place gets all inventive on me. The chicken wings were wild, they were dry rubbed with something that numbed our lips. We also had the bacon with rice cake thing that was DELICIOUS. We should have ordered more of the meat dishes. The bokchoy, fried rice, and fish dumplings were pretty standard. We'll be more adventurous next time. 

All in all, this place is more memorable for it's non-food attributes. It's more a circus.
author: Erica L.

description:
Not your normal, every day kind of Chinese restaurant.

Oddly enough, their BBQ platter is the best dish in the house! I also enjoyed the pickled stuff. 

I must say that their porridge was just okay...a little bland tasting (meaning, add salt). 
But other than that their foods are pretty good. They serve beer. 
Oh and the setting is really weird! But I still like this place!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
If Eve C. is going to create an account just to complain, then I'll do the same to set the record straight. 

Sure, they were super busy yesterday -- wonderfully so. I think any new, highly anticipated place -- especially one that's sharing space with another operation -- should be cut a little slack and given the opportunity to work out their kinks before you march to the Internet and whine about being kept waiting. What else did you expect on opening day? 


As far as the food goes, everything my dining companions and I ate last night was very much worth the time we spent waiting. And that's one of the beauties of being in Lung Shan -- we just picked up a bottle of wine a couple doors down to pass the time. 

I foresee lots of late night duck chinito orders -- it was the perfect combination of salty, sweet, savory. I could have eaten two by myself, easily.

Was slightly scared about the tofu pre-order -- but ended up pleasantly surprised by it. Just the right amount of spiciness. Total comfort food.

Fried rice was pretty great spin on the classic. The tiny bits of sausage were killer; found myself digging them out long after our other dishes came. 

Speaking of rice, the roast chicken is worth ordering for the "chicken" rice it comes with alone. Already dreaming of recreating it in my kitchen. 

The nice thing about being in Lung Shan too was you could order from both menus. We got potstickers - which were simple but good -- but hopefully the MSC dudes will play around with their own version soon.
author: Manda L.

description:
I don't get it, I thought this place was totally overrated. Did we just order EVERYTHING wrong on the menu?!? It's kinda hard tho since there's a limited Mission Street Menu.   

Forewarning when you go, wear something that you'll either toss or will wash immediately. When you open the door, a waft of cumin (? or some herb) hits you in the face and stays on your clothes even after leaving the restaurant.  The place is inconspicuous, there are no external lights.

 You wouldn't even guess that they're still open until you drive by, look beyond the semi-closed gate and see ppl still sitting on the inside, which is only lit up by dangling Christmas lines along the walls.   

I get that they're trying to spin-off reg Chinese food, but everything was salty except for the Mongolian Beef, which sadly, isn't even one bit reminiscent of the actual dish. 

They give you a bottle of water for the table, not to calm the tingling of the spices, but rather, to quench your thirst after consuming so much sodium.  

Mongolian Beef: expected more bite to it, it was just ok, brisket was very tender at least, and it was palatable.  

Ma Po Tofu: big portion but too salty, even with rice. At first it was ok, but the more you eat it, the worst it got. It is difft, not oil laden like most Chinese restaurants and thicker consistency.  

Chicken Wings: at first bite, I thought they were awesome, they've got def zing to it, balanced with some saltiness! This is the first time food was so spicy that it actually made my lips and mouth, not only burn but tingle. Def difft sensation. But the more I ate it, the more saltier it got. The wings are smaller in size than reg wings you would get at any other Chinese restaurant too.   

Cumin Sizzling Lamb: Unimpressed. Aside from the lamb being tender, there was a lot of fat in the meat and no other taste. It was just a dry cumin seasoned dish. Supposedly the dish came with long beans and the owner said it was coming, it never did and we didn't care to ask for it either. By that time, we just wanted the check and were ready to leave.   

Though the waitstaff was a little slow, but understood since it was packed (Wed night too!) On the upside, they were always still friendly, so a star for that. Yeh, I still don't get all the hoo-hah abt this place, would never go back.
author: Ly T.

description:
I don't get the infatuation that people have with this place.  My friend and I went on a Friday night.  We ordered one appetizer (the vegan chinito) and two entrees (he ordered the vegan delight, I ordered the islamic lamb hot pot).  The appetizer and his entree both came out immediately, while my hot pot took 20 minutes.  When it finally did arrive, it was basically a thick stew of chili pods, and was excruciatingly and inedibly hot.

I have an extremely high heat tolerance, but this was so bad that after one spoonful I was choking and refluxing and in complete agony.  This is the first time I've sent a meal back; when the waitress asked what I'd like instead I asked for the mapo tofu, which she said was even HOTTER.  I ended up just going with the vegan delight, which was simply OKAY, but I still felt the aftereffects of the spice all night long.

Not pleasant, not recommended.  Their chefs need to actually TASTE THEIR FOOD.  Spice is supposed to enhance the flavor, not completely mask it.  I have a feeling that whoever prepared mine just wasn't paying attention to how much chili they were putting in, because again, I am perfectly fine with a lot of heat.  But this was just ferocious.

Also, the chinito was clearly made in advance and had been reheated in the microwave - but not thoroughly.  So it was lukewarm with a couple of cold spots.  It tasted good, but it just seemed pretty half-assed.
author: J S.

description: This is fun, experimental Chinese-like food.  I always end up with a couple dishes I like, at least one dish that is so spicy it's actually physically painful, and a dish I'm not into at all.  The food is good and different and interesting, you are not rushed, you can sit and chill and enjoy the food and the people you came with, and the beer and wine are cheap.  I always get beer to help to combat the spice bomb.  There is almost always a bit of a wait, so don't come starving, it's going to be a while before you get a table.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Was told that I had to try the spicy tofu thing.  Was really psyched for it, but, of course, it's made with pork (non-veg-friendly, and not possible to substitute).  Sigh.

So, we went with the pickles, the salad, and the cold noodles.  (All veg) -- The pickles were good (it was more of a dish of pickled stuff, there were no actual cucumber pickles in it); the "salad" was actually a bunch of spring rolls, which were good; the noodles were amazing.

The music was great -- they had a Wu-Tang Pandora station going the entire time.  

I was ready to be happy with the overall experience, and then made the mistake of using the bathroom, which was through the kitchen.  Yikes.  There's a reason that most places keep the kitchen/back alley/whatever away from the eyes of customers.  This place needs to renovate and move the bathroom somewhere else.  It's scary walking back there..
author: DH H.

description: enjoyed the pork belly, lamb dish, and porridge.  Got a few other dishes here, but didn't like it too much.  I would def come back again for those first three dishes I mentioned tho.  Super tasty and flavorful.  A little overpriced in general, but not too bad for the city.  I recommend trying this place for sure if you dont mind a crowded environment, waiting for a table, and can handle a noisy place.
author: David D.

description:
Not sure I understand or agree with all the hype around MCF. 

My friend and I ordered take-out, and waited about an hour for delivery. (Not surprised, as it was dinner time on a Friday). Per the reviews on Yelp and various blogs, I expected the food to be incredible. In reality, the food was just "ok" and left a strange feeling in my tummy.

What we ordered:
- Salt cod fried rice: Very boring fried rice with very few bits of cod and very few tiny slivers of chinese sausage.

- Lamb noodle soup: Very greasy, gingery soup base but decent handmade thick noodles. However, not enough noodles!

- Szechuan pickles: Random order to fulfill the $20 min required for delivery. Had no idea what to expect. All I can really say about this dish is it's SPICY!

Despite my less-than-stellar first impression of the food, the ever-changing menu intrigues me enough to try MCF again.
author: Elaine C.

description: I have been meaning to try the Mission Chinese in NY for awhile now but I was always scared of the wait.  Since I was visiting SF, I figured why not go to the original?  I like some spice in my food but I was a little fearful of going 3 fire sign route since it was just 2 of us and I didn't want to commit to eating half of an order of ma po tofu.  We ended up sharing the rice porridge (salty and satisfying with rock shrimp, egg and beef) and the thrice cooked bacon (with rice cakes and bitter melon; really delicious and an amount of heat that I found perfect for me.  It was the first time I actually wanted more bitter melon).  I was really pleased with these dishes and I can't wait to go to the one in NY with a group so I can try the ma po tofu and the kung pao pastrami without having to finish it all myself!
author: Lisa W.

description:
On my recent visit to San Francisco, I made it my mission to pay homage at Mission Chinese Food.  Once inside, Mission Chinese has a distinct hipster vibe punctuated with kitsch overtones juxtaposed with tradition; a full scale dragon hanging from the ceiling greets you along with a weathered older asian lady, who brings you to your table where a severely tattooed Mission-type waitress takes your orders, with the likes of Muse in the background all this while.  The interior decor is decidedly humble but the eclectic symphony works harmoniously with the friendly staff.

For food, we ordered the Westlake Rice Porridge, Broccoli Beef Cheeks, and Sizzling Cumin Lamb.  I love that chinese broccoli was used and the beef cheeks were done to perfection.  Although the other two dishes tasted good, I felt that the spices used were too heavy handed, a far cry from the subtle and delicate blend of spices I'm used to in traditional regional Chinese cuisines.  The porridge was overpowered with ginger whereas the lamb was literally layered in cumin.  Overall, while we had a good dining experience, Mission Chinese did not live up to expectations, especially when San Francisco has many and better alternatives.
author: Nicholas C.

description:
Please let me start by saying that I do not know much about Chinese food. I do however know about "gastronomie". In that regard, Mission Chinese is absolutely incredible. My friend and I had the following dishes: tea-smoked eel as a starter, stewed beef tongue and turnips, sizzling cumin lamb and fried pork belly as main courses. The beef tongue was my very favorite - the broth was very tasty, the consistency of the meat perfect, the turnip delicious. 

Among other things, I like the fact that they do not offer 10,000 dishes like most Chinese restaurants but, instead, focus on a few and take them to the level of an art: gastronomy. Note that they do not have any desserts (I am not crazy about Chinese sweets anyway!) Here, it's about real food. Forget about a fancy setting! Forget about tradition! Also forget about your low fat diet!
author: Cecile P.

description: Warm beer. No ice. Bad attitudes. The food wasn't bad, but definitely not worth the hype or the wait. Probably better take out than dine in.
author: Lauren Gayle S.

description:
A-OK. That's how I'd describe the experience.

I went here for a double date last night. The girl of the other couple had said that this was listed in some blogger's top 100 restaurants in the city, and that THIS place actually got the coveted #1 position. Needless to say, I was very excited, and the long wait and the Asian guy in the window with the girl name tattoo making homemade dumplings wasn't making my wait any easier.

Let me just warn you that the sign doesn't say "Mission Chinese Food." It actually says something else more complicated, so it's easy to miss. Maybe that's the charm? You get to eat at some "underground," obscure place that's not well-known to the public except for other people who are also in "the in"?

Anyway, we got in after about a 30 minute wait. The inside decor was typical to a Chinese restaurant: mismatched things on the wall / ceiling and fake flowers on the table. We ordered the Chinese BBQ, Mapo Tofu (the #1 thing on the menu), pork dumplings (come on, they were homemade!), some vegetable and pork belly.

Chinese BBQ: GREAT. It even came with slices of white toast. Great cuts of pork, good BBQ sauce, and it came with an awesome bowl of pickled cucumbers and onions. The vinegar even cut the sharpness of the raw onion and it was perfect.

Mapo Tofu: wayyyy too spicy. It's the spicy that's so hot, you can't even taste any other flavor. I would've liked if the tofu was a little softer. The ground pork was plentiful and large, but almost had a mealy consistency to it. I don't understand how it's the most popular thing on the menu.

Vegetables: I think it was the bok choy. Very well seasoned, good side dish

Pork belly: came with thin, flat and wide rice noodles and thinly sliced cucumbers and boiled eggs. Had nice presentation and tasted great; pork belly was a little dry.

Dumplings: came last. We had to flag two different waitresses to bring the dumplings (they had forgotten and even gave us our check before we had gotten them). They were aite, but pretty disappointing. To be fair, they tasted better with the broth they came in, but it's not what you'd think a homemade Chinese dumpling would taste like. And I know they changed the regulations of the temperature/color of what's suitable to eat for pork, but the middle of mine looked VERY pink. Like, up-at-2-in-the-morning-hocking-up-food-poisoning pink.

Overall, it was an okay experience. I'm thinking this is the new "it" place where you want to be seen and where you can find the most up-to-date "it" food with other local hipsters and cool kids. I went to Washington Bakery and Restaurant with the bf today and we ordered dumplings to make up for last night's disappointment, and it was oh-so satisfying.
author: Becky K.

description:
This has got to be not only the worst Chinese food I've had but also the worst food I've had in America overall. I agree with another reviewer who said that Chinese people don't eat here for a reason. And we were starving so we weren't even being picky. 

The ma po tofu was way too spicy to the point that it overpowers all the other flavours (even for my friend who normally can take a lot of spice). The dumplings were average and dry. The cumin lamb was also dry, overcooked and so salty it was like someone had poured salt directly into my mouth. Then add on top of that the extremely long wait. 

My favourite part of the meal was the white rice and water. 

Safe to say I would never recommend this place to anyone. Ever.
author: Kate C.

description: Recipe for a rad first time in SF: land, BART it to the Mission District, walk to MCF, order the Kung Pao Pastrami and jam to the Ginuwine blasting. Maybe I'm naive coming from Chicago, but this food was amazing and started my trip off proper.
author: Kristian C.

description:
[A-only review]
There needs to be more places like this in the city. I've been coming here for lunch ever since it opened. Great food-- reminds me of Spices in the Richmond, only a little more exotic. I've had the Ma Po tofu and braised beef cheek-- both awesome. The portions have even gotten bigger over time. I guess the word is getting out so no more fine dining portions!

It can get overly busy at night, so I prefer only to go at lunch. Parking in the Mission is ridiculously bad, unless you drive a Mini. Then again, if you're driving a Mini to the Mission to get $8 Chinese food, you're probably too cool to care.

If you're curious about the regular menu-- stick to Mission Chinese Food.
author: Kel S.

description:
Feeling like a lazy oaf never tasted so good. Normally I would never order delivery because it can cost mucho dinero, and I like making food for myself at home because somehow I feel more in control of the universe that way. But today I was like, "You've earned it. It's almost the weekend, goddamnit, and you deserve a tasty dinner to sit & watch the new season of Jersey Shore with", so I gave Mission Chinese Food a call after having stared at their online menu the past few days drooling on myself.

I called at about 6:15pm, and ordered the Lung Shan Vegan Delight (soup) and the Garlic Eggplant. The girl told me that she'd waive the credit card minimum because it wasn't the dinner rush yet. I immediately fell in love, even though I ended up paying in cash instead.

The goods came in about 40 minutes and immediately my entire room smelled of garlic, in the most delicious way possible. I slurped down the Vegan Delight soup, which was a miso soup broth with scallions and soft dumplings made of savory mushrooms, in no time. Then I moved onto the Garlic Eggplant, which was seriously garlicky and amazing. The tender eggplant was encrusted in chili flakes and fried garlic, and sprinkled with jalapenos and Thai basil. There was grilled garlic cloves throughout. Good thing I don't have anyone to kiss tonight!

The portions were a tad small but I didn't mind because I'm one of those people who has to eat everything in front of her all at once. Next time I'm going to try the Thrice Cooked Bacon, the Tingly Lamb Soup, and the Szechuan pickles!!
author: Laura M.

description: Personally, I prefer to eat in than order to go because my favorite dishes are not available for delivery...such as the squid ink noodles. Yummy savoriness.
author: Linh S.

description: This was by far the worst food Ive ever ordered on Grubhub.  The food is way overpriced and is of terrible quality.  The Fried rice was absolutely the worst Ive ever had in my life and had to reorder food on Grubhub because it was terrible.  If I could rate this a negative 10 I would.
author: Travis S.

description:
Amazing amazing amazing.  Mission chinese exceeds any expectations I could have had for Chinese food.  Though to be honest, I hadn't heard of it before a friend had taken me and my expectations weren't very high.  Especially after seeing the comically pathetic looking sign out front.

I'll try and dig up the fond memories I had a few days ago:

Beer Brined Sichuan Pickles- 5/5 Delicious, succulent, but refreshing dish.  I used it as a pallet cleanser between some of the richer dishes.  Equally delicious on its own.

Smashed Cucumbers in Garlic Sauce- 4/5 Used it for same reason as above, but not quite the amazingness.  Still very good

Tiki Pork Belly - 5/5 Oh my god.  My mouth is watering thinking about this right now.  Perfectly cooked hunk of fatty meat that epitomizes the melt in your mouth deliciousness you'd expect from a restaurant with a higher price tag.

Grandma's Spicy Dumlings - 4/5 Very good dumplings.  I'm a dumpling fiend and these fulfilled my hopes, but perhaps I'm holding out on the perfect ones for a 5.

Stir Fried Pork Jowel and Radishes - 3.5/5 Actually better than my rating suggests, but this was one of the dishes I had high expectations for.  Piled my plate once, but saved room for the other dishes.

Thrice Cooked Bacon - 5/5 Yep. Amazing.  Other reviews say this was over salted, but seriously?  We're talking about bacon here.  Rice cakes were paired perfectly and this dish and it got cleared off the fastest.

Salt Cod Fried Rice - 3.5/5 Same idea with the Radishes.  High expectations that didn't get met.  A little overly salted and was a little too mushy for my usual desire with fried rice. 

Westlake Rice Porridge - 4.5/5 Great hearty porridge.  Would make the best meal on a cold rainy day inside.  

I can't wait to go back and try again.
author: Jesse M.

description:
So I feel the only fair way to review Mission Chinese is in two different halves. Without a doubt this was probably one of the more unique experiences I've had at a restaurant. 

The mere thought of a Chinese restaurant in the heavily Mexican district of San Francisco with Hipster waitresses blasting (awesome) folky music, might turn away a couple of Chinese food purists. 

But who cares about them anyways? 

We waited about an hour outside to get a seat for 3, which I've heard is pretty typical for MC. 

So overall, I think it's a pretty great place for a date if you're with someone that's a relatively adventurous eater. Read: DON'T TAKE SOMEONE WITH A WEAK STOMACH YO!

What we ordered:
Red Braised Pork Belly (Fatty awesomeness)
Salt Cod Fried Rice (Best I've had in a long time)
Egg-Egg Noodles (Gingery and crazy good)
Thrice cooked bacon (Spicy, but delicious)
Chongqing Chicken Wings (DAFUQ!?!?!)
MaPo Tofu (I CAN'T FEEL MY FACE)

So we started off with the Red Braised pork belly. If you're adverse to fat or have existing heart conditions, it may be wise to stay away from this. If not, this is melt-in-your mouth, party in your pants awesomeness. I've had better at traditional chinese places, but this is a pretty well done dish. Good to share with a few people. The Salt cod fried rice was done perfectly. Not too stinky and salty from the salt cod, a really great balance of scallion, eggs, chinese sausage. Probably my favorite dish of the night. The egg-egg noodles took me by surprise. They give you a raw egg yolk to mix in with the egg noodles, which gives it a richer, creamy texture. The dish is heavily gingered, but they do it in a way that is really successful. The thrice cooked bacon with Korean rice cakes was probably my second favorite dish. The bacon was salty, a little crispy and so well done. The addition of the rice cakes was a perfect vehicle for the spiciness of the dish. It's exactly what I needed. 

And now we enter the second half of the review, which deserves a name of it's own: 

WELCOME TO THE DEPTHS OF HELL. 

Chongqing Chicken Wings. No dish has ever left such a lasting impression on me, maybe in my life. It lasted the entire rest of the meal, the rest of the night, and the following morning. This dish is not for the light of heart, the light of spice, and the light of HOLY BALLS WHY!? These wings are pretty heavy in Chinese 5 spice, which can be a little off-putting for those that aren't used to it. When you bite into them, you'll notice that they're well fried, and incredibly fragrant. Then your lips start to tingle. Then your mouth goes numb. The wings are coated with Chinese numbing spice, better (or maybe not) known as Sichuan flower peppers. It's an incredibly intense experience and I don't know if I've ever had my face literally go numb from spice. On the plus side, the wings are an incredibly flavor enhancer. Eating the noodles, the thrice cooked bacon, and the salt cod fried rice directly after eating the wings, made each food even more amazing. It was absolutely remarkable, it was like we were eating three completely different dishes. 

Then came the Mapo tofu. Now, I am a student of spice. I grew up with a father who loved to cook Sichuan style and grew his own Thai hot peppers. This Mapo wasn't the best I've ever had, but it's definitely worth giving a try. It's a little salty, so I suggest having some white rice around to help balance out the saltiness and spice of the dish. Maybe it was because of the Devil wings we just ate, but on medium spiciness, we were dripping in sweat, which in my case was spreading the spiciness across my face and thereby producing a numbing sensation. What the mapo lacks in balance of salt and spice, it makes up for in flavor. It's a pretty fragrant mapo dish and uses chunks of pork shoulder which fall apart in your mouth. I might get this again, but probably without the chicken wings. 

Overall, I give Mission Chinese a 4/5 because I would definitely go back, I would probably order most of the things I got again, but there are ton of really great items on the menu that I really want to try. The wait staff is pretty attentive and friendly. It certainly will be a while before I forget this experience. Damn you Chongqing Chicken wings. Damn you.
author: Brian C.

description:
sorry i don't see what's all this hype about.

like the food wasn't bad here but it wasn't amazing. there are plenty of chinese restaurants all over san francisco that serves delicious chinese food. however, apparently this place ended up on the food channel and the newspapers and the magazines and the etc and everyone supposedly loves it and flocks to it as if it were a celebrity sighting. 

what i found was that it's a regular chinese restaurant that serves regular chinese dishes with a few twists. there wasn't anything special about this place. it wouldn't be my first choice chinese food place but since my supervisor paid for my lunch, i can't really complain.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
Mission Chinese more than lives up to the hype. This is basically sichuan food with a twist, so don't go expecting Hunan or whatever. The flavors are intense and complex, with unexpected ingredients. We ordered the numb lamb face, the lamb noodle soup, the tiger salad rolls, the slow cooked pork belly, the peanuts and the eel and ham jock rolls. The only loser in the bunch was the eel, which had great textures, but overpowering smoke flavor in the eel. Both lamb dishes made judicious use of sichuan peppercorns for just a tiny bit of numbness on the tongue. Both also used fresh hand pulled noodles. The tiger salad rolls were simple and refreshing, maybe worth saving for the end of your meal as a palate calmer/cleanser. The pork belly was rich and crispy, almost like duck confit. 

Dishes came out as they were prepared as of the case at most asian restaurants. Service was friendly but aloof. Ambiance is nonexistent. We went on a saturday at 2 and there were several tables. Overall, a fantastic and memorable meal. Check out the donut shop across the street too.
author: Rob F.

description:
The staff are super friendly and really cool, and the food is outstanding and is easily the best Chinese food in the Mission.

The Slow Cooked Char Siu Pork Belly was delicious, and went fast.

The Tiger Salad was unlike any other roll I've ever had. It came with the most flavorful leaves sticking out of it, and when I asked what it was, I was told they were "purple Chrysanthemum leaves." Just awesome.

The Ma Po Tofu was quite hot, was a big portion, and was as good as I've had outside of China. Probably even hotter than at Z & Y.

These guys are like mad scientists in the kitchen so they change the menu a lot and I can't wait to see what they come up with next.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Ran into this restaurant with my stomach set on some Yamo, actually. But upon arrival we discovered that Yamo's was closed on Sundays, or maybe at 3pm, or maybe at 3pm on Sundays. So Yelp pointed us to Mission Chinese since it was right there practically. Plus it looked pretty promising. 

Walked in, grabbed some menus and sat ourselves. A lady in a ski vest came out a little later and gave us even more menus. I guess we grabbed the wrong ones? We were kind of starving but have been trying to practice portion control. So a plate of black bean tofu chow fun, extreme garlic eggplant, veggie delight dumplings, some kinda Szechuan salad, and rice it was! And oh boy did this place keep its promise. Everything was tastefully delicious. I'm a noodle fiend and luckily the fun did not disappoint. The veggie dumplings were delightful and the garlicky eggplant made my day. The salad was really refreshing, except I was pretty cold so I enjoyed the hot items more. 

We had leftovers that I packed for lunch at work the next day. I announced how delicious it was and proceeded to not share. Very greedy of me, but ever so satisfied and promised. 

I wanna go back, and soon!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Sounded hip, but it was all hype.

Peking Duck, Lamb, and Salt Cod Fried Rice.

Food lacked flavor.
Non-existant service.
Waited and waited for check. Tried to get their attention.
Finally,we calculated our tab plus taxes plus a little more. Left the cash on the table and left. Didn;t need to take the leftover rice since I'd bitten into a questionable piece of  sausage. Before that, we had considered giving a second chance to try the beef cheek. It looked pretty good when the guy plopped it on our table, then came running back after he realized it was for a to go order.
author: S A.

description:
Okay, I am going to be blunt here. but born and raised in Sichuan province and lived bicoastal in the states, I guess my palette has a say in both authentic and fusion-style Sichuanese food (- which chef Dave claimed to be his inspiration although admitted he had never been until he was already well-known for cooking it.)

MISSION CHINESE IS A  HYPE . 

Foodies like you have much better choices in the city if you are hunting for Sichuan-inspired dishes, which I will spell out at the end. 

Here are my experience with MC. 

The Pickle
A must-have appetizer for Sichuanese cuisine and normally given out for free. But in MC you pay $4 for what is really just Korean Komichi ( the chef's true origin) except it has no taste. 

The Pork Belly
In Sichuan, Pork Belly dish is considered an art of slow cooking. It is all about  timing and  degree of the heat. Well-done pork belly is  tender with texture, not greasy (肥而不腻). But in MC's version, the lower part of the belly is too fatty, too soft even watery and the top skin are just too stifle to chew...I didn't even touch the second piece. (It's $10 for two pieces)

The Eel spring role
Too salty. Too much soy source added to the juice, which is often deemed a sign of amateur Sichuanese cooking. You need to drink a lot of water and beer to go with that.  

Sichuanese cooking is also about which part of vegetable goes with which part of meat. But  in MC,  I once ordered a meat dish (forgot the name) just to see major part of my plate was full of  WHOLE baby radish. And it's so tasteless and hard to process, I basically just give up the whole dish. 

NO, Sichuanese cooking is NOT not all about spicy source. Spicy  source is normally just the final touch. But in MC, I have had dishes that are basically cooked in the same mix of spice, except they are too salt and too spicy ( MC is using wrong pepper and pepper corn!)

MY ADVICE?
If you want fusion, go to THE HOUSE in Mission. If you crave for authentic Sichuaness, go to Z & Y in Chinatown. The latter was never on food critics' radar only because they are too busy with Chinese customers and because they haven't  mastered American's FOOD MARKETING skill -sometime, its all it takes to be famous.
.
author: Din D.

description: The food was fantastic, the atmosphere was homie like a real small Chinese restaurant. The food was on another level! Salted code fried rice was excellent. The radish and pork dish was so authentic and tasty. I want more!
author: Dwight D.

description:
My friend and I planned our trip to San Francisco around eating at Mission Chinese Food. We were really excited to try some different and delicious food that is hard to find around the Berkeley campus area. It is a short 5 min walk from the 16th St Mission BART station which is convenient. 

Thankfully, the wait was not that long but the restaurant is small. The first thing we noticed was the atmosphere... in the back of the restaurant, we saw a familiar scene of Chinese ladies peeling vegetables but that contrasted with the hip hop and techno music blaring from the speakers. This is not your average Chinese restaurant and we could see that from the menu as well. For example, we ordered the Hainan chicken rice which I'm very familiar with. When this dish came out,  it caught me by surprise. Although it had the typical "you fan" (oil rice) with roasted peanuts, there were tiny pieces of chicken mixed in with the rice which was a bit disappointing especially for the price. 

We also ordered thrice cooked bacon and ma po tofu because they were the dishes our waiter recommended for our first time here. I was really hesitant to order the ma po tofu because they warned us that it is super spicy (one of the two dishes on the menu to receive two spicy icons). It is definitely spicy but very flavorful. The thrice cooked bacon has to be my favorite. I think it was my friend's favorite as well. Despite the dish being a tad oily, it was extremely flavorful because of the pork (thrice cooked bacon). It also had the perfect "wok hay" element (the distinct flavor and taste of the food in a hot wok). 

The portions were quite large, especially the ma po tofu. We barely managed to finish the thrice cooked bacon dish and my friend had to take the ma po tofu home. Price-wise, I would say it is decent based on the portion size of the dishes we ordered. Yes, it was a bit oily and we were thirsty afterwards perhaps from the MSG but what do you expect from a Chinese restaurant? Our lunch was very filling and the homey yet modern atmosphere added to the experience. We'll be back again! Oh, and our waiter was super nice and friendly :)
author: Helen W.

description:
When it comes to Chinese food, I usually gravitate toward the authentic.  Although I don't like to admit it, I generally avoid Chinese restaurants if I don't see it filled with Asians.  In my book, hipster fusion Chinese food = BAD.  Last night I violated my unspoken standards, and gave in to the hype that is Mission Chinese Food.       

Warning: If spicy food bothers you, don't go.  If it bothers your friends, don't bring them.  And stay away if you are expecting traditional Chinese flavor combos.    

But for the open mind and adventuresome palate, you owe it to yourself to visit MCF!   Check your Chinese food standards at the door, forget about comparing it to anything you've tasted, and wipe away the notion that this is supposedly Chinese food.  It's just food.  Good food.  The rest is details.   

We arrived @ 5PM to avoid the wait.  We were seated immediately.  We ordered more dishes than we needed, because we were in a tasting mood.  We asked for some advice/direction from our hipster server.  Next time, I'll rely on my instinct.  

Our order consisted of the following:
-Kung Pao Pastrami
-Thrice Cooked Bacon
-Chow Mein
-Salt Cod Fried Rice
-Wild Pepper Leaves

The decent, but not spectacular:
Our least favorite was the Thrice Cooked Bacon, and I have a love affair with bacon.   We found it lacking in texture and missing an element of crunch we had expected.  Perhaps I should have gone with my instinct and ordered the Pork Belly.  A nearby table ordered it and it looked amazing.  The Pepper Leaves were tasty, but a little on the chewy side.  I still finished my portion completely, even though I knew full well my TMJ would punish me later.   

The fantastic:
Surprisingly, the Chow Mein was perhaps the most flavorful I've tasted - just excellent!  I'm still thinking about it a day later.  And the Salt Cod Fried Rice was addictive!  It had perfect texture and a wonderful depth of flavor for a single dish.  I was floored about how good it was for a supposedly simple rice dish.  The Kung Pao Pastrami was layered, spicy, and altogether awesome.  

Near the end of the meal, we found ourselves planning what we would order on our next visit.   

In short, Mission Chinese Food rocked my palate last night!!  It completely surpassed our expectations.  And that is a beautiful thing.
author: Jeffery G.

description: Yummy food. Loved the fried rice and eel smoke roll. Delivery was great.
author: Cynthia L.

description: Great! Definitely get the pork belly and the combo fried rice. Wasn't too big on the pork jowl or the peanuts. But overall tasty! The bumping old school hip hop was fun too!
author: Alicia S.

description:
Youna said this is on her 7x7 of sf, so here we are!  Don't be fooled by the green awning that says LUNG SHAN, you have now reached MISSION CHINESE FOOD. haha, hopefully they update the sign soon.

A must try on SF's 7x7.... we ordered what was recommended the spicy tofu with ground beef.  BEYOND SPICY.  It was a beautiful day in SF 80 degrees, and yup no SF store is prepared for the rare summer days in the 80s, so no air conditioning.  Not fun while eating their spicy tofu.  Also ordered the pork belly!  WELL DONE, applause for the pork belly.  Loved it, I'm filipino so I appreciate the fat of pork belly.

In the middle of the mission so you have to walk past all the druggies/ bums/ slums.  Not so fun either.  But the atmosphere is kinda hip amongst the fake flowers, christmas lights, and DJ.
author: L V.

description: Freaking delicious is the only way to describe the multitude of dishes we shared.   Everything was good.   Everything.
author: Elana G.

description:
My first encounter with Mission Chinese was something of a second hand experience. I should have expected an unremarkable dinner when I popped the "Tingly Lamb Noodle Soup" into the microwave for a nice bath of radiation. One bite and I was thoroughly unimpressed. My problem was I was eating my girlfriend's leftover stew. A few months later I was actually in the Mission (current Oakland resident) and a friend suggested we eat there. Looking at this place from the outside only made it less appealing but I went in and I am very glad I did.

This place serves great food. Let me elaborate. The wait is long but if you manage to get a table order as much food as your body can hold at one time. You definitely do not want to make the mistake of having just one dish, and the atmosphere begs you to share your food so bring a few friends. On my second try I found myself in a state of euphoria after indulging in so many fatty foods I thought my heart would explode from happiness. I'll just talk about the dishes in the order in which they were served because ultimately, as my chopsticks became a natural extension of my hands, I feel like everything was being consumed simultaneously. 

The first dish that was served was the Salt Cod Fried Rice. The names of the dishes are in no way misleading as this a pile of fried rice with some salt cod. The dish, however, is tweaked just enough to make the palate appreciate the flavors that are being combined. The second dish was the Broccoli Beef Cheek which tasted a little like Mexican comfort food oddly enough. The beef cheek was so tender it tore apart easily with a pair of chopsticks and the taste is reminiscent of the Mexican dish "Caldo de res". A fan of this dish will feel right at home with this one. The last and my preferred dish was the Thrice Cooked Bacon. It's everything a bacon lover needs. Nice fatty pieces of bacon with rice cakes. The textures are satisfying to the point that even eating the rice cakes by themselves is as gratifying as finding the last piece of bacon on the plate.

Based on the food alone this place is great. Forget about the ambiance and the people that are there or aren't there because chances are you probably won't be talking to them and if you do you might just surprise yourself at how nice Hipsters or people from other lifestyles can be. Do yourself a favor and check this place out before it's gone.
author: Javier E.

description:
I went a during the summer and was thinking just another Chinese food place. I was told to go here from some friends that came from Indiana for a visit and they brought along the NY Times article. I figured why not, give it a try, being that i don't venture much to SF as much as i should. The wait was not that long give or take 10-15 min. Big crowd and the menu looked like a good variety.
we asked people we sat next to what they ordered and asked the waitress what she recommended. We ordered a little bit of everything and man! I was pleased. This is def. a hole in the wall with great food and potential. the Lamb stew and rice was off the hook, can't complain.

One thing was a bit off for me was how our cups and forks were a bit dirty and we had to ask for new ones but they were nice about it. Also a bit too dark, an extra light or 2 would be nice.

Other than that allllll good = )  i will be going back, I already told a few people about it so hopefully they went. 

ps: we meet this guy and he was super nice, he even signed my friends article. down to earth place, cool vibe, good food = )  just be willing to try something new, for me it was the uni custard. Blew my mind = )
author: Monica D.

description: Not your traditional Chinese spot. Everything we tried was Hella good. Eat here and be happy. You will not find 20 varieties of fried meat with some sauce on it.
author: auclair k.

description: The restaurant opens at five, but you have to get there at least 15 minutes prior in order to avoid a long wait. The place is not fancy--generally a good sign for some legit chinese--and the place is unmarked other than a yellow sign that says "Lung Shan Restaurant." The thrice cooked bacon and cumin lamb were FANTASTIC but some of the other dishes people had suggested (aka fried rice and chicken wings) weren't up to the hype. I eat a lot of authentic chinese food though and I expect to feel nothing but a humming vibration in the bottom half of my face after a good sichuan meal so my expectations might be strange.
author: Catherine M.

description:
In short: it's good, but I've had way better. 

Three friends and I went here for dinner. I had eagerly awaited coming here after hearing the hype. 

I love spicy food, and this place brings it on. We ordered five dishes, and we ate all of it. No leftovers! Either they know portion size, or my friends were all hungrier than they had let on. 

The food was good. I won't lie, I've had about as good Panda Express fresh out of the wok.  Service was prompt and helpful, they even suggested a dish when we wanted one more thing. 

The atmosphere was an all ages crowd. Very claustrophobic. Clearly breaking fire code and ADA laws. 

3 stars for the food. 
+1 for service. 
-1 for atmosphere.
author: Adam K.

description:
Preface: I REALLY wanted to like this place.  

Review: I did not like this place.

I went yesterday for lunch with my boyfriend and neither of us could stomach more than a couple bites of our meals.  The food was incredibly salty and not at all appetizing.  The best thing it had going for it was the price.  $25 for lunch for two is pretty good in SF, but I would gladly pay more for better food.  If it hadn't been for Sunday Streets in the Mission and a delicious pre-Mission Chinese Food cheese board and glass of wine at Mission Cheese, I would say the afternoon was a waste.  Luckily, there are other fantastic eateries very near Mission Chinese.  They may not be Food Network reviewed, but they sure are better than anything we ate there.
author: Jessica H.

description:
What's to hate?  A creative menu (you can't go wrong with the Chinito and Salt Cod fried rice), a cozy space, quick delivery, and CHEAP for what it is.  I've absolutely loved every dish I've tasted here.  

And thank you, MCF, for finally making a MaPo Tofu that will make an Asian sweat.  The heat is glorious.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Not a typical Chinese restaurant or Chinese food.  Not Asian fusion like you know New American Asian fusion.  This is like traditional Chinese food, seasoning and way of cooking but with an occasional westernized ingredients.

We tried ma po tofu, which was good, but definitely slighting different than traditional.  Also had the lamb belly in cumin, which reminds me of the street lamp skewers, which I love, but it is very very heavy on the cumin, so that can be tough.  I would say on the whole everything is a bit overseasoned.  

Would be back to try the char siu pork belly which is so raved about.
author: Li Y.

description: I was waiting in line for about an hour, but it was worth for wait. This best dish that you can't miss is Ma PO tufu. It was super spicy with stinky scene. I got sweat so bad ,but feel so good. The other dishes that I really like are tiger salad and tea-smoked eel.
author: Ben C.

description:
I read Michael Bauer's recent review in The "Chronicle" and decided to go to Mission Chinese Food for lunch since it's relatively near to me and we wanted to get out for a walk. It didn't disappoint! 

Chef Daniel Bowein deserves his inclusion on the list of the Top 5 Rising SF Chefs in 2011. MCF is fun and funky and the dishes successfully blend flavors in a unique "new wave" Chinese style with a bit of spice and a lot of taste. 

We had the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts appetizer which had a lot of delicious garlic. For our entree, we tried the Taiwanese Eggplant with three kinds of garlic and sweet, hot chile sauce. This was our first visit but we'll definitely be back since the menu changes often and we look forward to trying more tasty treats. Even better, they deliver !!
author: Dean J.

description: They have very good delivery service. Fast and reliable, at least to Noe Valley. And I love the food. The kung pao pastrami is my favorite.
author: Nelson M.

description:
I've heard reviews about MCF not being REAL Chinese food and it's overrated and overpriced etc.. It still didn't stop me from giving it a try myself...

You walk in and the restaurant is thought out decoratively to old school tables and chairs with a twist to their "modern" and delicious menu.

Not your typical Chinese restaurant but hands down their food is amazing.  

Because there's so much to choose from for a party of 3 we decided on the following:
1. Ma Po Tofu with ground pork shoulder, peppercorn goodness
2. Green Mussells with Pork Belly treasures underneath
3. Salted Cod Fried Rice - chinese sausage, scalion, egg
4. Thrice Cooked Bacon with bitter melon, rice cakes and tofu skin
5. Cha Sui Slow Cooked Pork Belly

We were almost tempted to try their Veal dish as well but 5 dishes was enough for 3 people...  Right?

This just means I have to go back because I have to say I do crave their Ma Po Tofu and the Mussells... It's just THAT good....
author: Caroline C.

description: I didn't leave a yelp review the first time I came here but this second time isn't any different from the first time. If you want authentic chinese food I would go somewhere else. This place is overpriced and over hyped. I should of known that my expectations were too high when I was the only Asian customer in the restaurant. I won't be eating here again.
author: Natalee P.

description:
I kind of feel like anyone who has anything negative to say about Mission Chinese Food is trippin'.  If you want low-quality, weird meat, MSG chinese food - this is not your spot.  And I feel like some of the reviewers want that.  Also, if you do not like spicy food - this is not your spot.

That said, Mission Chinese Food, is hands down the BEST delivery food I have ever had in my life (and the BEST chinese food).  And I do not typically like Chinese food - it's not my favorite in the Asian category because of the high salt factor and the "scary" factor.  But I LOVE this chinese food.  This is "foodie" chinese food.

I am so happy they deliver!  I recommend the Peking Duck Chinito and the Salt Cod Fried Rice.  I need to try to Ma Po Tofu next since it is getting rave reviews.
author: Kelly A.

description: Some of the most original Chinese food I've had, and if the quality were more consistent, I'd give them more stars. At the restaurant, I ordered their grilled lamb and it was a revelation - so crispy and tender all at once. I ordered the same for take-out, and got 5 pieces of seared lamb fat. Yuck. I might try going to the restaurant again, if only to try out their new dishes, but no more takeout for me.
author: Mike T.

description:
I waited 2.5 Hours to get a seat on a busy Saturday night.  Was it worth it? not 2.5 hours, but pretty close. What's great about these guys is that you can put your name down and come back to check your place in line. If they've already called you, you can let 'em know and you're next in line.

Awesome. 

Technically, the wait isn't that long. It's about what you're going to do while you wait. We walked over to Sycamore and had us a couple beers. 

Things you need to get:
* Pickles (hot like hades, with a sprinkle of puckering sourness)
* Mapo Tofu (hot like hades)
* Veal (devine!)
* Pork Belly (pork belly can do no wrong)
author: Vince H.

description:
Like many of the other reviews, I ordered from here because of Anthony Bourdain's "The Layover" I am so glad I did. 
First off they deliver everywhere! I live in the inner richmond for just a few extra bucks they delivered the food right to my door. 
The food was SOOO fantastic we got the thrice cooked bacon and the beef cheek. The cheek was so tender and delicious and the bacon was spicy and sweet and had these chewy chow-fun like noodles in the dish that were exceptional. 

I would definitely go back to this place. Delicious.
author: Hashtagfoodtrip S.

description:
Have dined several times, hands down the best Chinese food I've ever had, and in the top 5 restaurants I've ever been to.   

If you want a 5 star dining experience, go to a 5 star restaurant.  If you want a chef that cares about his food and does it at a very accessible price, check out MC.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Are you serious?!       "Best new restaurant in America?!!!"  "MOst interesting restaurant in America"  
  
 Gimme a fucking break!  This place was ok at best.  Decent chinese food with a menu that reads better than the food end of being.  Basically its just chinese food with a hipster flare.  
  I would say I was expecting greatness and got meh.
  Go elsewhere if you want to be wowed.  Like next door, at Commonwealth.
author: schmoo l.

description: We got the chicken wings, the curried lamb, and thrice cooked bacon. The curried lamb was the best out of the three, but the portions, price, taste (greasy, salty) all just summed up to be an ok dinning experience.
author: Misha Z.

description:
I ordered the smoked eel, veal ribs, and cumin lamb. 

The eel: this was delicious. It is a variation of classic dim sum "cherng fun". It had a crunch from the lettuce, it was salty because of the fish and soy sauce, but it was also a little bit sweet.

The veal ribs was also very good. I originally was not going to order this but I did once I saw the adjacent table order it. It was a veal ribs-something you don't see often on restaurant menus and especially Chinese menus, but it was cooked in a Chinese sweet and sour sauce. It seems like an odd combination but it worked very well.

The cumin lamb was a very interesting dish and I think summed up the whole restaurant. The cumin lamb itself tasted like it belonged on an Indian menu, but on the dish was also spicy pickled green beans, that you find at szechuan restaurant. It exemplifies the modern Asian fusion food this restaurant aims for.

I give this restaurant four stars for great food for the price, but a one hour wait for seating. The decor (too dimly lit) and location (dangerous) are also cons. The dishes all have great potential but can be improved. The waited told me the chef will update the menu soon, so we will see if it is five star worthy.
author: Jason C.

description: This place is overrated. The pork and the lamb dumplings are nothing you cannot get in a traditional Chinese dumpling house. The eggplant was spiced well but again, nothing you cannot find elsewhere. The only differentiating factor is the owners and clientele are all hipsters so it might be a good place to meet like-minded folks, but this place is a dive and should be treated as such.
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description: ordered delivery at 8:30 pm. got a phone call from a woman telling us that they were out of the chicken dish we ordered at 9. we chose something different. i called at 10 inquiring about our delivery order and we got the same stock answer every restaurant with shitty delivery gives: "it's on it's way." it is now 10:20pm. the restaurant closes at 10:30. we do not have our food and they are not picking up their phone. i am now starving and pissed. we will not be ordering from here ever again.
author: Meagan M.

description:
I'm posting my review a month and a half late, but still my experience was beyond positive. 

The venue is really laid back, casual, and yes, hipster. I didn't expect the food to be so interesting/creative. We went for lunch on a Saturday and barely had to wait for a table. We ordered the Cold Dan Dan Noodles, vinegar peanuts, egg custard with trout roe, and the Szechuan Pickles from the cold dishes. We also had the Hainam Chicken Rice, Ma Po Tofu, Salt Cod Fried Rice, and the Cumin Lamb. Everything was good. EVERYTHING. I think the Salt Cod Fried Rice could've been a little saltier, but it was enjoyable nonetheless.

The Cumin Lamb was some of the best lamb I've had the pleasure of devouring. I urge you to please order it. The Cold Dan Dan Noodles was my favorite of the cold dishes. I have a feeling that no matter what you order here, you can't go wrong. I imagine this place gets more and more popular daily, so getting a table might not be as easy anymore. I also think it's amazing that they deliver.
author: Dennis M.

description: Very expensive for small portions and simply unacceptable quality. I ordered the cumin lamb and got 4 ribs that were just big chunks of charred fat and bone with hardly any meat. Yuck.
