BARF level yuck. $16. Can you say "day-light robbery"? Their menu is sparse, and with so few choices, you'd expect them to be good. The Chonquing wings were overdone and way dry. $11. Ouch, that's ridiculous. Grandma Zhou's Pork Dumplings were doughy and cold and small and we got only 8 of them. $9. WTF? Over a buck for a small lump of dough? The market greens were choi-sum -- the cheapest Chinese vegetable you can buy. $12. Rip-off! First and last time. BAD, BAD, BAD. One star is one too many.
author: Edward J.

description:
GET TAKE OUT/DELIVERY!  The wait is meh.

So here's the deal, the food is delicious, but extremely flavorful (spicy is spicy here) and yes oily.  Honestly the oily part doesn't bother me, there's a certain expectation to it.   It's like when you go to a burger joint, you don't write that the cheeseburger is oily right?  That's the expectation.

Favorites (as in what I seem to be ordering once a week)-
THRICE COOKED BACON - I love these type of rice cakes.  I wish they would put more bitter melon in (I have literally asked for more over the phone several times), and the tofu skins are so good.  In fact, the bacon is my least favorite part (except they add that yummy smoky flavor to the whole dish)
TIGER SALAD- Great herbacious salad, with an indescribably salty savory *magic* dressing, nice differentiation if you're ordering heavy, oily food, which you are since see note above.
WESTLAKE RICE PORRIDGE- yum, so delicious, nice hunks of crab, and nice ginger bites too.
MAPO TOFU- It's good, spicy, but good

The fried rice was ok, the brisket noodle soup salty, the long beans and watercress were just ok too, the eggplant was really meh for me.

Not everything is good, but what's good is great!
And again, get take out/delivery.  Use that 45 min wait not on yucky mission st in the cold, but in bed catching up on Game of Thrones on your computer.... such a better idea right?
author: YJ P.

description: We order mission Chinese delivery about twice a month, and have been for about 2 years now. It's pretty awesome. The thrice cooked bacon is always in our order. Not sure why people would wait in line when they can get this yummy goodness delivered hot and fresh to their doorstep. MC delivers to nearly every neighborhood in the city.
author: dana m.

description:
Been waiting to try mission chinese and wasn't disapointed. Showed up at 5:15 and was seated immediately, but by 6 the place was packed.

Lamb dumplings and kung pao pastrami were amazing.


Go early to avoids lines
author: Sean K.

description:
What's up with the hipster backlash?  I went for the first time this past weekend and was pretty impressed.  Food-wise, I would say it was so-so.  I agree with everyone else that the ma po tofu was freakin hot, but the tingling sensation it left on my tongue was a pretty unique experience.  I also had the 'hong kong chow mein' off the lung shan menu, which was pretty typical cantonese (good thing).  It might have been a bit too salty but not unbearable.  The lamb dumplings were quite good (very herb-y) but not extraordinary.  

So if I were rating this place based on food, I would give 3 stars.  I appreciate the attempt to recreate some of the more traditional chinese dishes.

In my opinion, the ambiance was pretty cool.  Definitely hipster-friendly, but I didn't a pretentious vibe that some other reviewers talked about.  I found the clientèle to be pretty diverse, actually.  There were a few scenesters mixed in with a seemingly normal crowd.  Even a couple tables of chinese people (including me).

Another note: the playlist was quite fantastic. Bloc Party, Crystal Castles, Thom Yorke, and of course stuff I didn't recognize that sounded good.

Boom. 4 stars. :)
author: Kevin C.

description: So delicious. Creative Chinese fare in a comfortably divey atmosphere.
author: Lian C.

description:
POS:
+quite tasty "Salted Shrimp and Mongolian beef" 
+very hot and spicy
+quick service
+price is reasonable. 
+parking is not so bad, just have to go one to two blocks away and they are all metered. 

NEG:
-some of the waitress are Chinese and not understand English.
-place is very small
-the wait can be long; luckily we came at the right time
-quite dirty interior and old.
-in a ghetto neighborhood

Overall, I would come back just because of the food. The chef apparently is quite hippie and listening to heavy metals and still doing waiting service at same time. Price is reasonable
author: Huan T.

description: Came here for lunch on Oct 16, with a friend.  We shared the wings, pork jowls, and BBW veal ribs with a side a rice.  The wings are great, dry rubbed so no gooey which I prefer, the wings were actually pretty big and very fresh and juicy.  They are covered with those red peppers (see the pics there is tonnes of them), it it worth taking a bite it is very good with a mild numbing effect on the mouth, I don't recommend eating a lot but do try one if you like spicey  The pork jowls were very good as well but was overshadowed by the wow are you messin with me  factor of our veal ribs.  The ribs were so off the chain good, veal is not the kinda meat that I find very flavorful, so this is the best way to make it.  It's a huge smoky, braised, juicy,spicy hunk of meat served on small veggies. ( frankly I cannot remember what it came with because the taste was so good my dining partner basically just stopped talking).  I highly recommend it and will be coming back any chance I get, oh and the kicker is that it is a great bang for your buck.
author: Valerie G.

description:
Great vibe: fun music, funky decor, relaxed service style.

Salted cod fried rice great.
Brocoli and beef way to fatty for my tastes. 
Wine pretty bad....

Now that I've been, don't need to go back...especially not to wait in line.
author: Bradley H.

description:
GOOD:
- They say no reservations but they made an exception for my group of 8. I guess if you have really large groups, they will help you out. Just ask nicely.
- #11 CUMIN LAMB was hands down the best dish of the meal. The lamb was crispy and fatty and I've never had lamb prepared this way before (and I love lamb). I will order this dish every time I return.
- #1 PORK BELLY was good but nothing ground breaking. It was your standard stewed pork belly.
- #8 THRICE COOKED BACON was good and had a lot of smokey flavor in the bacon. 

JUST OK:
- #3 MA PO TOFU was good but nothing really special.
- #5 BEEF CHEEKS was actually substituted with kalbi short ribs because they ran out of beef cheeks. It was also good but not great.
- # 7 COD FRIED RICE was basically fried rice with some salted fish pieces. I guess if you love fried rice you should get this but you also get white rice with your meal
- #9 TAIWANESE EGGPLANT was kind of over-sauced and mushy. I would have preferred more firmness and less sauce in the eggplant.

BAD:
- Portions tended to be on the small side, especially of the dishes that were the most tasty. We had 4 guys and 3 girls and got 7 dishes and it was about right (no leftovers). 7 dishes would not be enough for 7 guys.

CONCLUSION:
- Mission Chinese Food is an interesting dining experience (especially given the Mission location). It isn't necessarily super authentic (for you Chinese ppl out there) but it isn't super salty and Americanized either. Many of the dishes are SPICY so if you or your party cannot handle spicy, this might not be a good place to eat. The food was decent but not great and I probably won't come back for awhile because you can get better Chinese in Sunset or Richmond. I also  tried most of the menu and maybe only the CUMIN LAMB was worth returning for.
author: Alex P.

description:
Mission Chinese was okay. 

We arrived early on a Thursday evening, no sidewalk wait and only one other couple in the restaurant.

The service was okay, not bad but I've experienced better.

As for the food, we ordered:
-Grandma's Spicy Lamb Dumplings: not very spicy and full of vinegar flavor, didn't stop us from finishing the bowl though.
-Thrice Cooked Bacon and Rice Cakes: the rice cakes in this were great but the bacon pieces were mostly fat and hardly edible due to texture.
-Egg Egg Noodles (only available for eat-in): this was for sure my favorite dish, if I could have added a bit of sriracha it would have been perfect. Hearty, warm, and full flavored.
-Combination Fried Rice: sounds alluring with all the awesome offerings (crab!) but this one fell flat. Not enough spices really, felt like I could easily make this at home.

It was good to experience Mission Chinese just the once to form my own opinion but I probably won't be back. Overall not worth the hype.
author: Paige E.

description:
As a fan of both the food at MSF and their mission, I was excited to try their take on chinese food.  So the bf and I walked in on a Tuesday night (no crowds, only a couple of tables taken) and placed an order for take-out.  We wanted to try everything on the menu but we settled for the salt cod fried rice, the mao po tofu and the bok choy.  15 minutes later (precisely what the told us the wait would be), we walked them back around the block and dug in.

Mao Po Tofu:  Woo!  Yep, it was spicy.  But importantly, it wasn't TOO spicy.  Very flavorful, and the spice didn't overwhelm.

Fried Rice: Pretty solid.  The cod is a nice addition; not fishy at all.  I'm going to say its not quite as good as the chipotle fried rice at SO, but it was pretty freakin' close.

Bok choy: crispy and fresh.  Not overly seasoned, which was a good balance to the other big, bold flavored dishes.

When we started eating, we felt like the portions were too small, but I just put away a decent amount of leftovers, so I'm not sure portions are a problem (the fried rice was particularly generous).  Prices average $9 a dish, which is certainly pricier than your everyday American chinese food, but nothing we tasted was just everyday American chinese food.

Nothing in terms of atmosphere or service, but the food is good and we'll definitely try out another couple dishes the next time we're feeling lazy.
author: Kristin P.

description: Yeah, I guess my expectations were a little too high. So, the delivery was close to the 45 minute predicted time, which was good. I enjoyed the cold noodles - the chili vinegar provided a nice edge to the otherwise slightly plain noodles. On the other hand, I wasn't crazy about the pickles (mainly cabbage) (although peanuts were a tasty addition). I don't think it's really fair to say the pork belly was too fatty - the crispy, meaty part of it was really lip-smacking good, but most of it was just seemed a little...slimy. The wrapped noodles that came with it were good though! Finally, the ma po tofu... I can't quite say this was bland, because it had spicy elements, but somehow the big chunks of tofu muffled most of the mushroom and pork shoulder that were apparently in the dish. So, overall, fine...
author: Lisa K.

description:
We've been here twice now in the last three weeks. During those visits, we've had these eight different dishes: Tiger Salad, Cold Dan Dan Noodles, Tea-Smoked Eel, Hainam Chicken Rice, Ma Po Tofu, Kung Pao Pastrami,  Thrice-Cooked Bacon and the Slow-cooked Char Siu Pork Belly w/ Soy-Cured Egg.

All of it has been good. The first time we had the Thrice-Cooked Bacon, I thought it was absolutely incredible. My taste buds were dancing like there was no tomorrow, haha. The rice cakes in that dish were especially marvy. The Tea-Smoked Eel is served sushi-style in fresh noodle wrappers, and is really good. Same goes for the Tiger Salad, which is much larger and you know, has salad stuff in it. Nice appetizer. The Hainam Chicken Rice is *very* tasty. Also a very good appetizer choice.

My least-faves would be the Dan-Dan (which was surprising to me, cuz I LOVE the hot version and I make it at home) and the Kung Pao Pastrami. Something about the flavors in that dish just haven't done it for me. I also thought the Slow-cooked Pork Belly was so-so. The surprise for me was the Soy-Cured Egg in that dish. I usually hate hard-boiled eggs; the yellow stuff in there I just can't stand. But, this egg was a revelation. I didn't taste anything in it that I didn't like.

The only negative I've experienced is the waitress on the second visit was aloof and disinterested. She tried to act liked she cared when she had to talk to us, but it was obvious to me that she couldn't care less.

The waitress on the first visit wasn't like that at all. Helpful and friendly, as was Karen Leibowitz (co-founder).

I love the ambiance of the place. The lighting, the paper dragon hanging from the ceiling, the 'Christmas' lights, the volume of chatter coming from the diners who've packed the place to overflowing, the pretty groovy music with just the right amount of attitude, perfect for the setting.

We need to find a place nearby that serves cocktails, so that we can have one after we add our names to MC's wait list. You do have to wait for 30-45 minutes, even if you get here by 6:30. So far so good - it's been worth the wait every time.
author: Steve R.

description: I think the food is good but it is overrated by the media. I also think this is Fusion, not strictly Chinese. I believe some dishes do have this special touch. In short, good food if you are looking for some surprise in your tofu but if you are a traditional hardheaded Chinese cuisine person, you might get mad.
author: Eric L.

description: Place is interesting. Waited about 1 hour for a table for 2. We ordered the pork belly, the pickle things with the peanuts, salted cod fried rice, and some other dish that didn't leave a lasting impression. The salt cod fried rice was really good. And I would come back just for that. The other things well... not so much.
author: Linda L.

description: Maybe Danny Bowien is too busy hyping up his NY location but the SF location has gone down down.... use to be one of my favorite restaurant but now when I think of Mission Chinese food, all I think about is SALTY and overly spicy and HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE! It's too bad they took out the dumpling station. That was such a highlight of the place. Perhaps I should make a trip to NY to try out the NY location. Really disappointing when these Chef turns into celebrity chefs and the food is nothing more than food from a chain restaurant : (  !
author: Jay S.

description:
I saw both the good and bad reviews so , with an open mind, I decided to give it a try. I had to concur with the complaints about the extreme saltiness of thrice-cooked bacon. The ChongQing chicken wings had so much star anise that it numbed my mouth for a few minutes after just 1 wing. Westlake porridge, Mapo Tofu and a couple of the other dishes were nothing to write home about.  Service was all right. 
The food are not just to my tastes at all.
author: Dave T.

description: A contemporary take on traditional Chinese food.  The cumin lamb ribs are fantastic -- smokey, tender, and no gaminess.  The blend of flavors in the dishes are very well conceived.
author: Chester S.

description: Not bad, but not Chinese.  The name should defiantly be changed  to Mission ??
author: Bradley C.

description:
It's good. It's cheap. It's freaking spicy. So if you enjoy all of that and don't expect any other frivolousness, then you'll like Mission Chinese Food.

MCF is located inside Lung Shan Chinese restaurant which is a bit of a hole-in-the-wall. Actually everything on that block is kind of sketchy. But don't be put off by that. Earlier reviewers have mentioned that this isn't authentic Chinese food. Not the case, I've been to regions of China where Schezuan peppers were used in abundance. It'd common, it's delicious BUT it's very, very mouth numbingly spicy.

Top of my list: spicy chicken wings, salt cod fried rice, ma-po tofu. Come with several people so you can try a bunch of things.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
ok.

gave you another two chances and so far...you guys have beefed it up. took two hours for my food to arrive but the same guy from last time was super nice and my food was fab.

you are back in my life again.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
For your context, this place is supposed to be incredibly amazing: you are expected to be honored to be let in the door. I definitely found it different. The menu is creative and sometimes even good. But mostly, it's pretentious. And you need to be lucky to have an overall good experience because it's all highly inconsistent (just look at the wide swings in the reviews). And you need a strong inclination towards lots of spice (I adore spice and found most things I tasted to be too much.)
San Francisco is one of the best places in the world to eat - any food. If I were to make recommendations to an out of town guest, they would not have the time to go here. It's not good enough.
author: D Z.

description: This place has enough reviews as it is, so i'll be brief.  Thrice cooked bacon, spicy long beans, and the salad that is wrapped in rice paper.  The manager, Greg, is awesome because he cares about food and the patrons.  I'd come during off-peak hours or take out.
author: Diane K.

description: It's worth the wait.  Don't forget they do delivery!!
author: Benjamin M.

description:
I like the idea of Mission Steet Food better than the food.

I had the Braised Mongolian Beef Cheek $9 and the Szechuan Pickles $3.  There where a lot of peppers in the Beef Cheek but it wasn't hot.  I'd even say the Chow Fun noodles where bland once I finished the beef.  The pickles where also nothing to write yelp about.

Glad some of the money went to the Food Bank but it's not enough to keep me going back.
author: Jason S.

description:
I thought it only fair to review my favorite local spot ( not so local after recent reviews) for my first YELP . 

Beefcheek..umm yes please. 
fried pork belly....bring it. 
Mongolian green beans....i love you. 

It's everything you want out of the Mission hispter scene in SF.  Cheap food, great soundtrack and soft red lighting that makes you think the sloppy decor was purposfully set to make it feel more "authentic". High five Mission Chinese. Hopefully we can keep you as the little jem you are.
author: Kimberly P.

description: I'm Chinese.  Everything was way to salty and oily for me.  But it seems white folks love it because pretty much everyone inside was white.  The Hip hop music was good!
author: Mark Z.

description:
I really enjoyed this place when we ate in a few weeks ago and attempted to repeat the experience with a delivery.  

It was simply the WORST delivery chinese I have ever eaten.  The Braised Beef Cheeks were slabs of fat that wasn't even cooked enough to get the fat soft (the fat had hard yellow cold sections in it).  The Ma Po TOFU was watered down and bland (as opposed to fiery and tongue tingling like before), the Pork belly was undercooked and cut into thick slabs and the noodles used were over salted and soggy.  I'm not sure whether the chef was indisposed taking a big crap and had the janitor cooking instead but it was like the food came from a different restaurant altogether.  I called them to get this fixed, they took down my number and stated someone would call me back the next day, still no word from them.  We threw away most everything except the Cod Fried Rice and the Shrimp with Lobster sauce (ordered off the regular menu) which were both pretty bad but at least edible.  

Bottom line is they have poor quality control, and definitely don't get stuck ordering delivery as you will not be able to send this inedible food back.

Addendum:  OK, I tried them again and their food was much better, still not stellar, but edible.  Upgraded to 3 stars.
author: Robert K.

description:
I use Yelp so much, I finally decided to join the masses who help me choose my dining options in a pinch.  And when better to start than the new year, right?!

Had a crazy NYE and finally managed to drag our butts out of the house by 2pm on 1/1/11.  Needless to say, I was starving.  And nobody wants to be around Hangry Mel.  I needed comfort food.  A bowl of rice.  With something to warm me up in rainy SF.  Lung Shan it is!

Ok, so I've been here before when they used to do Thursday night pop ups as MCF (it was a tribute to Rene Redzepi of Noma) and I've ordered delivery once, but I had not actually eaten inside when it was just a Chinese restaurant.  Not really sure what to expect... although I did hear they offer three menus.  Apparently, the third one is a secret one (or maybe you have to be a native speaker?) since we only got two.  But we ended up picking items from just the MCF menu.

Vegetarian Delight - I barely even read this description, but they suggested it to us when they told us there were no pork dumplings and we still wanted soup.  First off, the name does not do it justice.  This is soup and not some mish-mash of veggies, which is what I would think based on the name.  It's three mushroom/veggie dumpling in this broth that was just out of this world.  A lot of times, I'm tempted to dump soy sauce or chili in broth-y soups cause they just don't have a lot of flavor.  Not this one.  This was not in-your-face-crazy, but rather a very delicate and yet super flavorful broth.  4.5 stars.

Tiger Salad - this was a bunch of herbs/greens stuffed in a rice crepe and then drizzled with chili oil.  A surprising burst of freshness and bold flavors that really woke up my taste buds.  I imagine this to be a staple for me.  Be warned though, it is very filling.  5 stars.

Taiwanese Eggplant - I've never met an eggplant dish I didn't like, but I was a little underwhelmed by this.  It was good for sure, but maybe I was expecting amazing after the first two dishes.  3 stars.

Sizzling Cumin Lamb - wow.  Very stimulating to my eyes/ears (the smoke wafting from the sizzling goodness), nose (earthy, cumin/onion goodness), and mouth.  Oh the flavors and the texture!  The meat was very tender and although it was at times fatty, it was complemented by the crisp onions that soaked up all the cumin lamb flavors.  Yum!  5 stars.

Overall - For all of that, it amounted to less than $40.  It really could have fed 3-4 people, but since I was soooo hungry, it only fed two of us.  But then again, I barely ate the rest of the day cause I was so full.  Definitely the value here is great.  Service though was just okay.  Granted, it was new year's day and apparently their regular people weren't working (it was the cook giving us our teapot, but forgetting the tea cups).  Also, I'm not sure how authentic these foods are, but for me it's irrelevant since the food was amazing.  I will definitely be back.
author: Melody A.

description:
Three stars is "A-OK" according to Yelp.

Anyone else wonder why they put so many grungy photos of the prep/kitchen area in the new book?  Not great PR, but maybe it's part of their deal....you know, cheap food at cheap prices, cheap cleaning budget, cheap, cheap cheap.....anyway they might like to know what reactions that has inspired (me - meh, but odd; mom in NY - 'I wouldn't eat there', and mom's kinda worked the trenches; friend here - see I told ya the place was a sketchhole....)

The best thing on the menu lately is the long beans, but the green chili in it should be cooked a little longer - seems like it is cooked separately from beans/onion, even if you want a contrast they are basically raw; I've ordered the fried rice last couple times and still wondering where the escolar confit is; the pepper leaves dish  - why compress tofu just to let it uncompress in a broth?  Don't get that one, but tasty as usual.

All  in all I keep wishing they'd put more crispy on the menu and less broths and porridges...but hey those things keep in the fridge for 3 weeks or so.......
author: Brian H.

description:
On the yellow awning, it states "Lung Shan Restaurant" or something to that name.  

Once you walk inside, you step into no light but sparkling x'mas white lights. It reminded me of being back in China when the restaurants don't turn on the lights to conserve electricity.  They have a DJ playing "hip" music.  It was not too busy. 

Anyways..you walk in and the waiters are not your conventional chinese waiters (old, tries to speed you up to put in an order).

The back kitchen/bathroom area is dumpy.  They have vats of pans (fried chicken) and chinese ladies washing dishes and cutting up bitter melon. 

The menu consists of "Lung Shan" menu but also a "MISSION CHINESE  FOOD" menu.

We ordered from the MCF menu and we got the following:

1) Mapo Tofu - tingling to my tongue b/c of szchuan peppercorn.
2) Bittermelon, bacon, rice cake dish - I highly recommend this dish.
3) They gave pork belly on the HOUSE (score!) This was tasty.
4) They gave a side of their mystery pickle on the house (score!) This was alright. 
5) Bacon Salt Cod Fried Rice - It's basically salty fish (chinese style) with bacon.  
6) Eggplant with basil - This was okay.

We both spent about $25 each.  

The waiter had the audacity to say we were "short on change" but it was his error but we pardon him because he was nice about it. 

Parking - Street parking if you are lucky and get there by 6pm (free meters after 6pm)
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I really liked the food here when I first tried. Before then I wondered why there were many people standing in front of this old building. Now I know why. The price is a little higher than reasonable but I wouldn't mind visiting from time to time.

The only thing I don't really like is the service. It's disorganized and offensive. I've only been to a couple times for foods to go only, so I don't really know how the actual serving would be like for eat in, but by far what I have experienced especially today ,the service got  A LONG WAY to improve; either drop that shitty american attitudes, or adapt more genuine asian modesty.  Unlike many other asian restaurants, most of people who serve in this restaurant seemed to be less of native asian language speakers which was interesting, maybe for better, faster serving purpose, because of  the busy crowds....I thought.

However, I  guess my luck was out of fortune on one of the busy nights, when I stopped by at this place and ordered a food to go. As usual, I waited for my order outside at the door because inside was crowded and busy. I told this dumb caucasian lady who took my order, told her that I would wait outside because there was almost no space inside, and she didn't even bother to give me any sign even though the food was already ready to go. I basically literally waited outside standing for 50 minutes under the cold weather at night. When I came inside again, she totally ignored me and pretended busy working, not knowing anything at all without a single apologetic word or glance. 

Then this asian kid with a hat was happened to be unfortunate one to deal with my displacement when I was already quite upset with my exhaustion, but what he gave me even worse was his back talk with "chill" american attitude...."can't you see we are busy here?"...as if he owned all the rules in the house.
I was pissed off and I asked him for the manager and he even wouldn't let me by saying he's the one. 

When I talked to the real manager, I cancelled my order and got refunded despite of his free offer. He humbly dealt with me in proper manner regardless how he was thrown off. At least the manager seemed to know how to gather his acts straight in his position.

Thank Santa Clause, had mercy on that arrogant offenders on the Christmas eve. If this incident happened in Asia, at least in my country, they would be torn apart in tears without a word.
author: D K.

description: We usually order delivery from here but yesterday was the first time I actually went in to eat at the restaurant. To my surprise, there was no wait at all! Granted it was 5:30pm on a Monday but when we left (about an hour later) there were still plenty of tables. The Mapo tofu was delicious. So were the peanuts and Kung Pao Pastrami. I would also recommend the salted cod fried rice. The waitstaff was really friendly but they didn't really come to check on us after we got our main dishes. Overall, this place is great!
author: Stephanie A.

description: The food is cool, and certainly different from most Chinese joints, but the wait was hellllla long, it was more money than it should have been, and the music was so fucking loud I had to scream to the person two feet in front of me. Not worth it
author: Doppelganger Z.

description:
Move over highway divider - this joint's as middle of the road as it gets.

The food was elegantly prepared, but half the dishes were, well, bland. I will concede that the belly was indeed flavorful, and service, in general, was a lot friendlier than the joint's previous incarnation as Mission Street Food. 

I ate more food than the belly I'm pretty sure, but I can't really remember it.

Which pretty much sums it up.
author: matt s.

description:
My love affair with Mission Chinese started in the fall of 2010 after a day of lounging around Dolores Park and having bottomless mimosas for Sunday brunch. Since then, I've been there a handful of times, and the wait time has gotten longer and longer each time. Their décor hasn't been updated since the Lung Shan days, but I don't mind it that much. What I do mind, however, is having to strip down and jump into the shower as soon as you get home because the stench of grease clings to your hair and all your clothing on the way out.

Of everything I've had, the fresh tofu appetizer is my favorite. Even though, like everything else, it's on the greasy side, the black bean sauce is simply divine. They used to have a different version of it that I liked better, though. I'm also a fan of the thrice cooked bacon and the eggplant. My friend, Lynn, complains about the overuse of Sichuan peppercorn, but whatever. I love it. Everything is spicy, bold, and flavorful. The salt cod fried rice and vegan delight also throw in some much needed delicious subtlety and lightness. 

Last time I went with a group of eight, the table before us took forever to finish up, so the waitress gave us some free char siu pork belly and Szechuan pickles, neither of which I was a fan of. I mean, I usually like pork belly, but not when the fat to meat ratio is astronomically high and the pieces are cumbersomely large. The free food was a nice gesture, though.

I especially like that this place is not overpriced, AND they donate $0.75 from each entrée to the San Francisco Food Bank.
author: June L.

description:
The best Chinese I've ever had!

My favorites were:
-  the eggplant, beef cheek & seaweed salad.

We ordered pretty much everything on the menu between three & it was $25 each with tip.  Its BYO too & there's a bottle shop next door.

So delicious!
author: Sofia I.

description:
skip the lines and carry out for lunch, dinner, anything.  the ambiance and decor is lacking, to say the least, and the food tastes just as great if you get to eat it sitting in front of the telly wearing your fat pants.

i, too, was skeptical about claims regarding authenticity.  mapo tofu in the mission?  cumin lamb in the neighborhood where burritos are king?  worry not, my friend.  i have yet to try many dishes on the menu, but let me wax poetic about the mongolian long beans.

oh long beans, oh long beans.
how spicy and tongue-tingly you are
from the lips of an uncouth chinese daughter
you taste of guilt and high expectations and home

i'll be back to order more.  tried the thrice cooked bacon (vegetarian version) and i'd recommend you skip it next time.  note to self -- never order a vegetarian version of a dish that has meat in the title.  DUH.
author: Amy S.

description:
Wow! Really fantastic. Realized while eating it that I've never had REAL Szechuan food before

This will change your life.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Came here for lunch while visiting SF with a friend who lives in the area. The restaurant's ambiance is nothing special (there is none), but the food was great. We split two dishes:
- Thrice cooked bacon & rice cakes: Very tasty.  
- Broccoli beef brisket: SO good. The beef was delicious, but what I'm still thinking about (3+ wks later) is the broccoli. It was cooked really well.
author: T M.

description:
It's a weird set-up in a hole-in-the-wall, kinda dumpy Chinese restaurant (without a sign outside indicating it's Mission Chinese Food), but the food was super yummy.  We (esp my hubby) LOVED the broccoli beef which is not what you think of as the "traditional" stir-fried dish (read the description on their menu).  I'll concede that the salt cod fried rice was not spectacular, but having a dish that was relatively simple balanced out the well-spiced other things on the table.  
It's a refreshing take on Chinese without being pretentious.  A definite YUM that I'd go back to in a heartbeat, even if just to get a chance to try the other dishes.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I always love awesome food at budget prices, and MSF is right in the sweet spot.

We had the Pork belly and the Beef Cheeks.  The pork belly was tender with a nice crust, had a tremendously flavorful sauce, and was served over noodles that had some aromatic vegetables aimed at being "moo-shoo-esque".  The Beef cheek was huge came with a dry rub of spices on top of the sauce , with sliced and fried onions, hot red peppers and green jalapeno peppers; quite spicy, but balanced out by the fat in the beef.  Both dishes were very flavorful.  

I'm looking forward to a return trip!!
author: Fiid W.

description: Delicious and creative meal, but prepare to wait. Even after you get a table you'll find yourself waiting to order and get your check during peak hours. Food's the bomb though so tough it out!!!
author: Alexander M.

description:
the wait here is ridiculous.  maybe my rating would be higher if i got delivery or takeout.  put your name down and go get a drink somewhere else.  come back an hour later, and you'll be ready to sit.

we got here around 840 last night, so we didn't eat til 945 or so.  by then, they ran out of some dishes already, including the tiger salad and the tea smoked eel.  we ended up getting the salt cod fried rice, thrice cooked bacon and the mouthwatering chicken.   the portions here are big, so we had enuf to take home (there were 2 of us).  the food was tasty but pretty greasy.  

it's super dark in the restaurant too, so i wasn't sure what i was eating half the time until i started chewing.
author: Helen T.

description: Delicious!  The salt cod fried rice is a must. The wings are unique - definitely worth a try but don't expect them to be covered in sauce.
author: Matt B.

description:
Went here last night after reading the chow hound article and it was everything that was advertised. 

You walk into the restaurant and you're senses are put into overdrive. 

Eyes - Fresh dumplings being made to your left
Ears - Real old school hip hop
Nose - The smell of spices, which makes me start to salivate 
Mouth - Saliva
Touch - .... alrite nothing to really touch, but great christmas lights everywhere

We (the two of us) didn't really know how large the portions were going to be so I guess we got a little carried away. Here's what we ordered:
- Fresh tofu: loved the crunchy black beans
- Ma po tofu: not your ordinary ma po tofu, but damn good
- Lamb noodles - mouth numbing which is a little weird, but the lamb was damn good (deep fried?)
- Vegan dumplings - nice and refreshing after all that spiciness
- Cold noodles - awesome surprise, I can't put my finger on what it tastes like or what regular chinese dish it's suppose to spin off, but good nonetheless.

Overall great food, great music.

PS. if that haole guy that was at at MCF on Saturday 12.5 reads this, that song you said was Biggie is actually 2-PAC!! Check yo self before you wreck yo self!
author: edrick w.

description:
Annoyingly bad Chinese food. My girlfriend called it Panda Express for hipsters, which is right on the money.

First of all, the decor in this place is just offensive. Remember those racist shirts Abercrombie & Fitch created around 2003? It had those Chinese guys on it with rice hats and slanted eyes? That's basically the decor in this restaurant. It's completely over the top. It's like watching a Chinese comedian in yellow face telling racist jokes about herself/himself in order to entertain a white audience. As my girlfriend said, "I didn't think the decorations would be so 'chinky.'" We did see one other Asian couple, but no other people of color at all.

1) Chilled Buckwheat Noodles - So salty it was nearly inedible. Just not good.

2) Salt Cod Fried Rice - I got this because it was the most mentioned dish on yelp. Are you kidding me? You can make this at home in about 10 minutes. If you don't know how, just go to youtube and search for "How to cook fried rice." There is absolutely nothing special about this. It's just egg fried rice with a few little bits of fish and chinese sausage. And the salt cod did not taste anything like what you expect when you get a Chinese dish with salted fish.

3) Thrice Cooked Bacon - What a mess. It's like they took a bunch of random ingredients (black bean sauce, bitter melon, pork belly, rice cakes), cooked it together, then drenched it in chili oil. Seriously, what is this?

Get it together people. Throwing a handful of cilantro on Chinese food doesn't make it gourmet. I'm not categorically against hipster food or fusion food etc. I just went to Hawker Fare for lunch today in Oakland for the 6th or 7th time and enjoyed it. But this food is just bad. How did this place get so overrated? It boggles my mind. We ate at Hakka in Outer Richmond a few days later to help us forget.
author: Owen L.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in Bay Area. Chef Danny Bowien is Korean and had never cooked Chinese before coming to the Lung Shan Restaurant,  as the sign out front says, but he nails some classics like ma po tofu and his fried rice is some of the best I've ever had. 

There was loud metal music playing inside with some cheesy iconic Chinese lanterns and a long paper dragon hanging in the middle of the room ... and it was all awesome. Go now!
author: Mark R.

description: Although I found it pricey, I did enjoy the rock cod fried rice. However, me and a friend discovered a cockroach on our table and lost our appetites. Service was not exactly the best. i recommend to order takeout if you really wanna try their food
author: David L.

description:
I was craving noodle soup, and asked my aunt for lunch recommendations in her neighborhood and she mentioned this place.  From across the street, this place looked like a legit hole in the wall.  Okay.  they're probably going to have simple food, which is exactly what I wanted.

Then I look at the menu and noticed it was all in English.  WTF?  And a Chinese kid with hipster glasses and tats are standing behind the window scooping soup or something.  Interesting enough.

It's packed in the late afternoon so I assumed it had to be good. The menu is small.  I like that already.  The ingredients sound Chinese.  I like that too.  Then there are words like "confit" and animal parts like "belly" and "cheeks" that belong on the list of words I love to hear.  This place is pretty serious, sounds like they really know something about food...  I'm in.

I only got two things.  Lamb noodle soup and cumin lamb.  The soup was quite possibly the most delicious noodle soup I've EVER had.  I love fresh Shanghainese noodles, and there was something dangerously delicious in that broth though I am opposed to drinking soup for noodles, I slurped it up to the last teaspoon.  I never had lamb belly before, but was curious because god knows the most superior cut of meat to have ever been placed on this earth is pork belly and this place has now put doubt in me about that.  I saved the cumin lamb and brought it home for my mom and she DESTROYED it.  She was like "Where'd you get this?  Can you get this for me again?  I'll give you money tomorrow."  "Mom it's all the way by where auntie lives, in San Francisco! ... Wanna go there tomorrow for dinner?"

The food has a very distinct Chinese flavor, so I wouldn't call it Asian fusion.  Maybe not even Chinese American, especially when you think about all the other things out there that are labeled as such (panda express etc).  It's very much classic Chinese comfort food, but also more refined than that.  For example, the Sichuanese peppercorns are ground and put in the rub so they don't peskily get stuck in your teeth.  You can tell there is a lot of effort and thought placed into the cuisine.  Is it better than my favorite Chinese cafe in Oakland?  Maybe not, but it does stand out and has something unique and delicious to offer our growing population of food enthusiasts.
author: Biqi C.

description:
Thrice Cooked Bacon....huh?   All I know is that it was out of this world.    The rice cakes really pulled it all together and I could not stop eating.  

Grabbed take out of Numbing Lamb Face Biang Biang Mein and it definitally numbed my face...but the lamb was sooo succulent (and I rarely enjoy lamb) and the noodles were incredible.  Scoville rating over a million for sure.  Wow. 

It feels like the same crappy chinese place you grew up eatting in, but the food, can we talk about the food.

I'm obsessed and will be stopping in again very soon.
author: Susan C.

description: the folks at mission chinese were super flexible and accommodating with our group of 12. the food was incredible and the service was on point.
author: Burke R.

description: How is it that the original is not as good as its outpost in New York? Mission NY has been my go-to place for chicken wings and fried rice since I first went there a few months ago. I had the chance to visit the original Mission in the Mission district of SF recently. The menu was similar but the tastes were actually quite different. The cod fried rice was very good and very close to what it tastes like in New York. The pork belly and the chicken wings were similar but the taste was much more savory and sweet. It was as if they had put chicken salt and sugar into the mix. Overall, it's still a fun experience to go to Mission and the crowd is always happy and cool.
author: Wesley H.

description:
My heart still skips a beat for MCF. They haven't lost their lustre. In fact, this, my 4th visit just cements MCF's place in my top 5 restaurants. I can seriously eat this food every day! If only...

I love the lack of pretense even though it has a "hipster" label, but honestly, whenever I'm there I don't see hipster. Rather just all kinds of people enjoying the food. There is a palpable casualty to MCF and  Danny Bowien is always nice and approchable; his down home Southern charm ever evident. If you're seriously expecting some high fallutin' dining experience take your money elsewhere where the food is middle of the road. Leave MCF to those of us who love and appreciate it.
author: C P.

description:
This place confused me, with its two names. But after realizing we were in fact at the correct restaurant, chose a table and ordered immediately. 
1. Peking Duck Chinito: so so creative! Spicy hoison sauce, duck, chinese doughnut, all wrapped up in rice noodle. Delicious!
2. Salted cod fried rice: pretty good, with pieces of chinese sausage and green onions scattered about. Nice crispy piece of tender cod on top. The cod could've been a bit more salty.
3. Ma Po Tofu: holy freaking god. This dish was SPICY. Fiery spicy. Sweating spicy. My bf and I were sweating like we were sitting under the sun in the Mohave Desert. It was pretty embarrassing. Just be prepared.

I want to come back and try the Braised Mongolian beef cheeks, thrice cooked bacon and dessert! 

Oh, the place was packed, so service was a bit slow...We had to really wave down the servers a few times. Our server apologized though and seemed sincerely apologetic.
author: Carol L.

description:
Worst food I ever had. I found the lamb dumplings good but the lamp ribs were inedible - old, gamey-smeling, leather-hard mutton. 
The Mongolian long beans are apparently normally hot but when asked if they could do a just mildly hot version were delivered scorchingly hot. I normally like "normal spicy" food so I was surprised. To their credit they took them back and off the bill. 

I don't get what all the fuss is about. This is horrible food. The only edible thing we ordered was the $15 Combination Fried Rice. $15 for fried rice? 

I won't be back.
author: pam s.

description: Really, really authentic country Chinese food. Loved the numbingly spicy tofu soup but wish they still had the duck donut roll that everyone mentioned.  The pork belly was good & the salted fish fried rice was on point.  Menu could have been more extensive.
author: Segue P.

description:
The Peking Duck Chinito is the ultimate jam. Order three of these and put 'em straight into your mouth hole.

The Ma Po Tofu and Islamic Lamb Hot Pot are also contenders with atomic red chili oil sauce (though not as crazy as the color would indicate). Enough kick to give you a bit of the sweats, though it's fairly spicy if you're not into butt explosions.

The taro pudding is awesome too.
author: Sidney L.

description: Anthony Bourdain does not lie. We loved the creative dishes. The dry rubbed wings are pretty good but, not awesome good. The spicy bacon dish and crab porridge are awesome good. Go on a weekend day late afternoon to avoid the insane crowds. Cool dive bar vibe and the music was spot on.
author: Michelle L.

description: Awesome with amazing ambience!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Super nice and friendly staff with incredible food. I ate their with my sister and she felt the same way. I really recommend it for any dinner you want to impress someone with.
author: Captain J.

description:
I was skeptical when I saw the outside but like people always say you can never judge a book by a cover. I was blown away by the time that is spent to prepare a single dish from this menu. 
Some items I think are must get items are the broccoli beef, braised pork belly, spicy chicken wings and the mao po tofu. Out of all the dishes I tried my favorite is the brocolli beef because I have never tried a dish that had such tender meat. The meat literally falls off the bone. 

Amazing!
author: Kevin L.

description: I will blame Mission Chinese for the bout of food poisoning I got. I took about five bites of the squid ink lamb curry dish and knew that something was wrong with it. But other than shitting myself rotten, am I missing something? Please, enlighten me about why this place has received such undeserved hype and praise. I ordered the tea soaked eel, and it was unimpressive. What an amateur dish, and so poorly executed. But the squid ink curry noodle, I couldn't even eat it. Five bites in, and I knew something was wrong with it. The cheese was bad, or something. Every bite was different from the last, and I ended up getting sick from it. Never again.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
We heard it was good, so our expectations were high. 

I thought the place, even with those expectations was great. We asked the owner to order four dishes for us: Ma Po Tofu, Salt Cod rice, Cumin Lamb, Pork Belly. All were great, especially the rice and the pork belly. The Tofu is spicy with lots of chiles and peppercorns in it, but it says that on the menu, haters, so if those don't work for you, or if you're too lazy to eat around them, then don't order the dish. 

It's a GREAT addition to the 'hood and we will be back. Often.

But most of all, the owner Danny was super wonderful.  A personable guy who wants to make the best food that HE enjoys (as opposed to what people think they want). And he's struck on something. As much as the food, he (along with our waitress) made the night really great. 

I hope this place is around forever. And for those of you who need the lines and the undeserved-hype of all the restaurants nearby (I'm looking at YOU, Tartine), then by all means, go patronize those places and leave the real food to the grown-ups. 

This place is for real!

Yay.
author: Emil W.

description: Ummm...somebody could have mentioned that the string bean will make your mouth go num! Szechuan peppercorn!! Wow New for me.
author: Deme M.

description:
I guess the management has been reading the reviews about bad service and taking that to heart. Four of us dined there on October 14 and were greeted with great courtesy. Our waiter was very forthcoming and helpful with menu items. Our favorite dishes were the tea-smoked eel, the thrice cooked bacon and the squid ink noodles.
The service was quick and efficient.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Salted cod fried rice, thrice cooked bacon, and pork belly. All delicious. If you do not like spicy food I wouldn't recommend it. It's a month later and I am still thinking about this meal. I'd give it 4.5 stars if I could. The 1/2 star cut for the super long wait, but I'd say it's pretty worth it. I hear the one in NYC has a free keg while you wait, SF hop on that. If I'm ever back in SF I will be back to Mission Chinese.
author: Jesse M.

description: This is not traditional Chinese food. Never the less I had high hopes for this we had stopped here on our anniversary in hopes of trying something new and different. Sadly we were greatly disappointed and they are way overpriced for the portion size they give you. I don't think will be returning. Not to mention they felt bothered by a request to leave out items due to a very serious food allergy. We ordered veal ribs and they were almost all fat it was disgusting. We also ordered the three times cook bacon and wow that was a decent dish it's not enough for me to come back once again. Additionally the rice we ordered was dry and old not to mention it was long grain. I have to say how sad I was that this was not a positive experience as it has been on my food bucket list for many years to try. The only happy thing I can say about my experience is that Mission pie is only a few blocks in the way
author: Allison M.

description: I wish I had read the recent reviews before I plunked down $60 on fiery, insipid takeout food. Everything was tasteless unless you consider salt and hot spices to be tasty. The worst was the Salt Cod Fried Rice that had no cod; just greasy, creepy and fishy tasting. My meat eating friend kind of liked the Thrice Cooked Bacon when he wasn't choking on the peppers. The only dish that wasn't overly spicy and salty were the Stir Fried Peas that were microwaved frozen peas and they were simply bland.
author: Lydia W.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of traditional Asian food in general (It's a rice and gummy sauce thing), but the only thing that struck me about MSF being traditionally Asian about this place was the crappy service.

Just because white (kinda glow-in-the-dark white). But, DON'T BRING ME A FORK. EVER. Unless I ask for one.

Okay, I digress.

I went in for the Mo Pa Tofu (To kickstart the 7x7 2011 Big Eats) but they were out of it.  As a matter of fact, they were out of several things. I was okay with that, really, I was.  There wasn't anything on the menu that didn't look good.  And NONE of it looked traditional either.  That's what I like about it.

The Chilled noodles that I did get were FANTASTIC, starting from the first bite (really over dressed, but I knew what they were going for, and I can be forgiving).

I'll be back for the Mo Pa Tofu (and the winds and the lamb dumplings...), but definitely takeaway.
author: Michael M.

description:
I was expecting this place to end up on my Overrated Hipster Obsession list.

In fact, the food was fantastic. Not cheap, but delicious. Everything.
author: Railroad T.

description:
Went with a friend last night; we'd both been meaning to check it out for a long time, and I was eager for the opportunity.

To keep it brief: The food is delicious, but the heat, it burns - and this is not coming from someone who has trouble with spicy food. My friend and I both have high tolerances for capsaicin, but we come from culinary traditions (Mexican;Indian) in which there's somewhere to run (queso fresco; raita). With Chinese food like this, once the chili starts to burn, there's no exit. 

This is mostly our fault; we didn't pay attention to the warning flames on the menu. So I'd advise prospective diners to take those warnings deadly seriously. 

It probably also makes sense to talk to the server about the spice level in what you're ordering - they don't offer you an option about the spice level on individual dishes, but they could easily give you a sense of whether or not you're ordering in an imbalanced way. Some of the dishes we ordered didn't have heat warnings, but were nonetheless very fiery.

All that having been said, I'll definitely be back. I just wanted to warn people: MCF has serious spice.
author: Chris P.

description: I know people rave about this place, but I just don't get the hype. The first time I tried this restaurant, I luckily only had to wait 10 minutes before getting seated. We sat at a communal table with little elbow room and there were random dragon lights hanging from the ceiling. I got the salted cod friend rice, which was underwhelming. We tried a few other dishes, but nothing really stood out. The second time I had food from here was when my friend and I had it delivered to her hotel room. I have to say, everything seemed to taste better during my 2nd experience, but overall I found it to be quite average. Some of the dishes are just too spicy that any flavor that seemingly exists is masked. I probably won't eat here again unless I'm in the neighborhood and the line is super short.
author: Cathy L.

description:
So this place was so good the first time I had to come back to make sure that it wasn't a fluke and guess what y'all....$h*t was the BOMB second time around!!!!!

Tried the ma po tofu dish this time and it was off the hook, really spicy with a great pork : tofu ratio.  It comes in a huge bowl but it was so good that the three of us polished it off.

Next time I have to try the wings and salt pepper shrimp because they looked off the hook to.

Oh and it seems that the great service got even better, plus they had Wu-Tang pumpin over the speakers.

To all the people that give this place 3 stars or less where are you eating chinese food, Singapore, Hong Kong?  Seriously let me know and if it is better than Mission Chinese Food I will buy you dinner at your spot.  

Hit me up haters!
author: Richard N.

description:
I'm so very happy that this place is only a few blocks from Casa De ME! I'm hysterically addicted and cannot go three to four day's without my Mission Chinese Food fix. My recomendation, is to go with what Chef/Owner, Danny suggests. It's fail-proof and easy. 
I have been reading a lot of the other reviews and I do get where some of you are coming from, regarding spicyness or being Americanized. But, come on! It's about time that there is something different out there to stimulate the "safe" pallet's of this city. I'm personally burning out on sushi or the small, shared  plate establishment's, with their "local" ingredient's and holier than thou attitude's. If I see one more hanger steak or rock-and-roll...I'm going to cry. 
 Cheers to MCF! Spice it up, make it different, keep me guessing (and happy). You have a true fan in me.
author: Gabe T.

description: So I'm form Philadelphia much bigger city  than SF and we have tons of Chinese restaurants  but nothing like MISSION CHINESE ! Besides the hour and a half long wait because the food is soo good and unique and the fact that they don't have many tables, the spicy food and options are to die for. They have many vegan options the service is great for them to be so busy and all the staff was very polite :) but if your a tourist it's one of the places you MUST go to.
author: Ashana D.

description: This place is great for people who don't usually like Chinese food.  (That's not meant to be a compliment nor a slight, just a fact.)  I've had the food about 4 times now, and while I appreciate their spin on Chinese food, most of it ends up being so spicy you can't taste any other flavors.  Would I eat here again?  Sure, their dishes always sounds great on the menu.  Would I ever initiate eating here?  Probably not.
author: Christine L.

description:
Wow. My tongue had an orgasm. My tongue went on its own LSD trip. I don't understand what just happened. I write this as my mouth is coming down from its high.

My wife was excited to introduce this dining experience to me. She was stating things such as greatest chef ever or in SF or something - irrelevant. The man's a genius.

We ordered the tiger salad something or other. This is by far the absolute most delicious dipping sauce I have ever encountered. I don't even get how anything like this could be so good and I simultaneously don't understand how I have never experienced this flavor any previous time in my life. There are thousands of great chefs, SF is a foodie haven, and yet this was my first experience with such a sauce. This needs to be bottled and sold.

My wife ordered the eggplant. I loathe eggplant. I find it's only good when severely overcooked. This guy's eggplant is amazing. The texture, to me, was catfish-esque. The flavor was amazing.

But my tongue was truly blown away by the Lamb noodle dish. It started off tasting really good but nothing above and beyond that. My wife was insistent that I wait some time to assess because my tongue wasn't yet experiencing what it ultimately would. Whatever, I thought. Then my tongue kinda went numb and that felt cool. My wife still insisted I let it play out until the euphoria set in. I had my doubts about this euphoria thing she spoke of. Then it happened. My tongue started doing its own tingly flavor dance. It was vibrating with deliciousness and it felt as though the flavor kept replicating itself right onto my tongue. It was an acid trip completely contained on my tongue. I stopped eating ten minutes ago and it's still tingling.

I took the food out of the restaurant so I can't account for the service or level of hipster-ness. The place was pretty dead on this early Sunday evening. By the way, hipsters tend to eat at great places (except Ike's _ I still don't understand this one). Also, are there any hipsters that think they're hipsters? I would guess that only 10% would admit to that.

Anyway, EAT HERE!!!!! I definitely will again!
author: Robert V.

description:
My thought leaving this place was: Meh, not really my thing.  I had been wanting to try this place for a while but with so many complaints about the wait time I never really wanted to wait that long.  We showed up early enough so that our wait time was only about 5 minutes (for a "table of 2", quote marks are appropriate since we just sat at a long table with a bunch of other people).

The menu was much too exotic for me.  Frankly, I just don't like or want to eat pig jowls or some of the other strange kinds of meat.  We ordered the chicken fat friend rice (which tasted a bit salty to me), the pork belly (which was ok but a bit burnt), and the goat (which was also a bit burnt).

The food was just ok, not amazing in any respect.  I should disclose that as soon as I entered I was already not feeling the place - it was filled with non chinese folks which to me already said it probably wouldn't be all that good chinese food.
author: Alex G.

description:
MISSION--There's a familiar urban legend about an unprepared art school flunkie who pulls off the impossibly unlikely when he, on the morning his senior thesis project is due, tumbles out of bed to find a forgotten Mountain Dew aluminum-can pot pipe, which he hastily repurposes into a passable social-statement-artist-submission, thereby managing to dazzle his professors and, in turn, graduate with distinction. 

After enduring months of buzz on a level with Apple's new iTV or 4G electric wine opener, I finally had occasion to get to this place at an early enough hour as to avoid a wait. My Mission Chinese Food experience recalls the tale of the art student in his audacious willingness to serve up something daring and edgy, if only half baked.

Despite whatever genius the chef and proprietor hold at generating praise and attention, I'm both underwhelmed and baffled as to how this place could be considered one of the best restaurants in the Bay, if not the nation.

The set up and context:

You're dining in a divey "underground" environ with chintzy pinata-quality dragons dangling from the ceiling, cheap Christmas-tree wall lighting flickers out and back on along with the stereo every time someone bumps the overloaded wall socket, the wine glass and the beer glass are one and the same cheap, thick, and unappealing stemware vessel, the only beer offered is in a can, and the servers carry that distinct Mission chip-on-their-shoulder monkey where the indifferent waitress acts like she's going to be the next goddamn Karen O. or Lady Gaga and you should just be grateful she's bothering to acknowledge you. (Here's a tip for you Sweetie, and for all you other aspiring servers from someone who has waited tables: It's hardly ever acceptable -- and certainly not advisable when your venue is vying to be be a serious contender (regardless of whether it has managed to dupe the NYT into believing you're a bellwether restaurant) --- to ask if you can bring me some change. And for that little faux pas of a phrase to be the last thing I hear out of you -- unpardonable.) 

That aside, the Chow Mein was pretty decent. The dish of beef cheeks was gristly, off-putting, and fairly awkward to eat in a social situation considering I had to spit the better part of it into a napkin. It looked like a giant mushroom and had the consistency of the floppy elephant-ear bread served in Eritrean restaurants.

Overall, a rather unremarkable dining experience. Cost: about $50 for two courses and four drinks plus rice.
author: JayBee L.

description:
Come SF Hipsters, you can do better than this?.........

1) rude service at the door 
2) continued rude service at the table
3) the smell of stale fish 
4) when asked about beef cheeks and broccoli it was described as the most tender part of the cow. Are you kidding me. We ate about 10% of the broccoli and left the beef cheeks for the rodents
5)which brings me to my next point. My vinyl chair was cut across the top from so much use and lack of reinvestment and  I always worry when the light are so low and the music is pounding. I would love to see the kitchen. 
6) you serve beer and wine , but don't have red wine .  Come on, time to hit the local market for wine in a box. It would be a great fit with the sophistication of the Restaurant 

Overall I'm embarrassed for the people who think of themselves as SF foodies and dare give this restaurant anything but a true and fair review. Wake up SF your killing the food scene .

We left of course and went to grab pizza. No kidding after spending forty bucks for two we ended up sharing a slice of pizza.

Save your time folks, unless of course you enjoy dry cleaning your  clothes after a meal. The stench is unbelievable. 

Hated it from start to finish.
author: Joe D.

description:
Heard good things about this place but didn't live up to expectations.

Ordered Salt Cod Fried Rice---it was lightly fried which was nice...but there was no fish or taste of fish anywhere!  Also little or no veggies in it and some super thin slices of sausage so basically paid 10-12 bucks for plain rice...not worth it.

The broccoli beef cheek was the best dish of the night with the beef being tender like a short rib...although it did have a decent amount of fat/grizzle.  It has chinese broccoli, not american, just a warning for those who think you're getting american broccoli...although I didn't mind.  It also had some two oysters on it which were tasty as well.

Ordered the westlake porridge as well.  It again is soup for like ten 10 or 12 bucks.  Chicken broth with some ginger and rice.  I thought porridge would be a little thicker consistency but it's soup...which once I learned I was wrong in what I ordered, I'm fine with a good soup...but again...it's just soup. I thought it would have crab in it...it had a tiny amount of what I think were beef cheeks again...but fattier and less quality pieces.

Doubt I'd order from here again.
author: Diana K.

description:
I never really write reviews, i think its kinda lame, but thought id help save a few of you a trip.

If you like salty food over flavor this is the place for you. I went in and it was the first time being in a dim/dark chinese food restaurant. I was the first one there, i usually see a big line so i though hmm, this might be like San Tung, might be a hidden gem, more like a buried, mossy rock. Im a native, so im not the type to get hyped over sub par chinese with cool decor. They were playin heavy metal in there, which kind of through me off, The service was cool, they dont baby u there, but i dont rate based on service unless its bad. I ordered the forbidden rice, which should be forbidden, like never spoke of, it was a black rice, with some mealworm looking crunchy things, it taste bad, just super salty, i found myself drinking alot of water just to keep up with the salt. Its like going into sephora and smelling one thing and having to smell the coffee beans in order to  smell anything again. Anywho, the menu was limited, and made to sound cool, im on a new journey to try to find new restaurants, i think i may just stick to the places that i goto that are actually good.
author: Pete F.

description:
To me, this place was worth 5 stars.  I typically don't like Chinese food, at least not the typical southern chinese broccoli beef fare.  

I also don't like overpriced Asain fusion places.

This place provides the hard hitting punch that you expect from an ethnic restaurant, the creativity and fresh ingredients you would come to expect from a modern american SF restaurant, and also the reasonable price point of a low-key neighborhood joint. 

We had an egglant dish, a pork belly dish, and cumin lamb dish.  The cumin lamb dish was billed as lamb belly, but it seemed like a combinatoin of rack of lamb and lamb belly.  The seasoning was perfect and the lamb was grilled to perfection.  Tons of great flavor.

The pork belly was nice and crispy on the outside but soft and tender in the inside.  The type of pork belly texture I enjoy the most vs the typical black bean sauce or hoisin sauce soaked limp variety.  The plate also had awesome ginger soft boiled eggs (delightlfully sweet), and house made pickles to bring some acid into the dish.  This was a terrific dish.  

The eggplant was similar to the kind you get at thai restaurants, but better.
author: Jeremy R.

description: There's not a lot I can add. Simply put, delicious. As a vegetarian who is mostly vegan, I have a tough time finding tasty meals. That wasn't the case at Mission Chinese. Spicy, yes. Fantastic, totally. The vegan version of theThrice Cooked Bacon was fabulous, as was the Wild Pepper Leaves (with pumpkin, pressed tofu and salted chili broth). The Szechuan pickles were great, too. My meat-eating brother had and loved the Smoked Beef Brisket Soup Noodles.
author: Jamie S.

description: I heard from a friend (whom wishes not to be mention) that this place was the hip spot where everyone is going to eat. First impression after reading the menu is that this might be interesting because they're renovation the traditional Chinese dishes to compliment the current generation. Great idea but food didn't meet my expectations. The dishes we had were over powering, drenched in soy sauce, peppers and salty. Truly a unique spin on the traditional Chinese dishes and I have to say not in a good way. I did like the pork belly and that's keeping me from giving them only one star.
author: Koua T.

description:
I feel like I might be turning into an anti-hipster. It's not that I dislike mid 90s hip hop; it just seems a tad contrived when I walk into a chinese restaurant where it's blaring.
The contrivance would have been minor if the food had lived up to the hype. It's A-OK, as yelp star # 3 suggests. 
The ma-pao tofu was WAY TOO HOT, with an overuse on the chilis that completely detracted from any complexities of the dish. The cumin lamb was well-flavored, but entiely too fatty and chewy and hard to eat.
The lamb dumplings were delicious. The thrice-cooked pork is lovely, and of course has the perfect name. The eggplant dish was too oily.

I'm not sure whether standards have dropped as a result of this place's ascent to hipster-trendiness or this is another example of MIssion over-hype.

But overall I was not as impressed as I thought I would be. 
Good, but not great.
author: Kathleen G.

description: Dear guy in the park who told this family with three young children to go to dinner here.. We did NOT enjoy it. Ugh. They use way much smoke to flavor their food!
author: Emily S.

description:
I miss the old MSF set up, but this is still a unique dining experience with yummy, affordable food.

Ate at MCF the first week they were opened and felt they were still hammering things out, waaaay too much spice in the food. There's never a need to hide great flavor with too much spice. So I stayed away for a while. 

Returned on Jan 15 2011 with a group, the food was much improved, though some dishes still were overwhelmed with spice. The use of hot spices also seemed to be a fetish. numbing and tingling.

But still, great value, great food. 

BYOB and down to earth staff. Ask them what does not have too much spice and you'll love it.
author: Christian A.

description:
Word of the Meal: HELLACIOUS

There's a lot of hype surrounding Mission Chinese - some of it warranted and some of it overrated. The Mister and I hit up Mission Chinese after the gym one day. We put our names on the waitlist and ended up waiting about 40 minutes. As we watched patrons walk out, we overheard each party make a snarky comment. When our turn to be seated approached, the waitress tried to seat us at the end of a table of a party of 8. We politely declined due to the cramped quarters. When we were finally seated, we we struck by the blunt heat in the restaurant. Yes, it's a hole in the wall, but there could have been better ventilation, A/C or fans at the very least. We were covered in sweat in a matter of minutes.

The standout of the meal was the thrice cooked bacon and slow cooked pork belly. The pork belly definitely stood out. It was crispy on the outside and juicy melt in your mouth goodness on the inside. We ordered the salt cod fried rice and weren't too impressed. It just tasted like bland friend rice. We also had the spicy chicken wings. At first glace, I was highly anticipating the wings, as they were dry and not swimming in sticky sauce per usual at Chinese restaurants. However, the wings were submerged in a huge pile of dried red chili peppers. Not only that, they were dusted with a layer of cayenne pepper. So the heat factor (from both the spiciness and the temperature) were scalding. This added to the cramped quarters, the sweaty environment, the experience was down right hell-acious. Personally, I left with no tastebuds on my tongue and numbness on my lips. I would come back for takeout or delivery and definitely get the pork belly and and thrice cooked bacon. Too bad their delivery menu is limited. 

Boo.
author: Sean A.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile now and finally did it about a month or so ago.  

Ordered the Mongolian braised beef cheeks, which turned out to be my favorite dish.  The beef cheeks were tender and flavorful, while the onions, chilies and green onions that came with it were a good accompaniment to the beef.  It was spicy (and you can see all the hot chili oil they used in the dish) but not overly so.  Also go the pork belly.  This was also good, but there weren't enough things accompanying the very fatty pork belly.  It really needed additional components to make the dish better (and the 4 slices of cucumber and pita-like bread were not cutting it).  Finished off our order with the mabo tofu.  This was just a standard dish, nothing extra special about it (as i was expecting it to be amazing since everyone raves about their mabo tofu).  I have no complaints, it was spicy, the tofu was tender, the portion was huge but it wasn't anything special.

Will I order from Mission Chinese again when I'm in SF?  That would be a definite yes.  I'm drooling thinking about the beef cheeks as I type.  And they deliver!!
author: Pornsakdi T.

description: Trip two was no more impressive.  I wouldn't seek it out.  I definitely wouldn't wait for it.  But I wouldn't say no.  It's good Chinese food.  Not great.
author: Mark A.

description:
I don't see what the fuss is about, IMO: "Meh. I've experienced better."
Spring rolls too oily and the meat is rather bad. 
2* and I tried it twice..
author: M S.

description: I know. It looks like a dive. But this is the spiciest, most awesome fusion Chinese grub you will ever eat. Order the Mongolian long beans and thrice-cooked bacon. You think you've eaten spicy food, but your eyes will water.
author: Sophia K.

description:
Here's why you should come here: 

It doesn't matter if you have certain expectations of what a restaurant's ambiance should be like. I am USED to $40 plates and devoted, hygienic restaurant staff. But when it comes down to it, I turn into a competitive eater from Long Island when I step into Mission Chinese. Amazing food is amazing food. Just ignore the tattoo on the waitress's love handles and the music better fit for your nephew's stoner dorm room. 

I could eat their hot chicken wings, sweet peas, and salt cod rice every day for the rest of my life if my blood pressure would allow it. This is one of my top 3 favorite "hole-in-the-wall" restaurants in SF. Be prepared to wait for a while unless you're with someone who's friends with a staff member.

Bonus points for an extra relaxed BYOB policy if you're into that sort of thing.
author: Ashley T.

description: Truly wanted to not be a minority in my own people's restaurant but alas the value proposition that's always answered with a resounding Yay in my peeps eateries is contradicted here. not worth the hassle or the money IMHO. Get better food without the stomach aches elsewhere.
author: Ron W.

description:
Very confusing place simply because there is really no sign indicating that it's called Mission Chinese Food

We asked the waitress what's up with the name, it's pretty much 2 restaurants in one.

Service was slow and something they could work on.

Peking Duck was creative, I think next time I go I will get two orders of these.

Salted Cod Fried rice was okay, my mom's version is so much better though...
author: Eric A.

description:
Quite impressive food in the Mission District. 

My friends and I enjoyed and highly recommended:
1) Savory Egg custard w. Sea Urchin, Trout Roe, Rice wine & Shiso
2) Tea-Smoked Eel w. Had Hock, Chinese Celery, Rice Noodle, Cognac & Soy
3) Salt & Pepper Shrimp w. pork fat, Fennel, Caramelized Onions & Fried Garlic.

~The all three dishes are AMAZING~!
Creative and have good balance of quality ingredients, texture and seasoning. WOW! 
I LOVED the whole shrimp with head & shell. SO Crispy & Juicy!

We also ordered the following, which were O.K.:
1) Ma Po Tofu
2) Pork Dumplings
3) Fish Dumplings

We dine Sunday night and got offered a shared table less than 10 minutes!

This is the only place one of my friends & I thought worth coming back again. So GOOOOOD :D

My bow to the chef.
author: Yoshiko M.

description:
Absolutely terrible. THE worst excuse for Chinese food I've ever had. 

Here is a solid tip that you should live by, if you don't see Asian people in the restaurant (Asian hipsters do not count), its probably not good. 

Save yourself the long wait, and eat at a real Chinese restaurant.
author: Peter C.

description: Definitely a hipster chinese food joint. Btw, that's not a bad thing. Food was excellent. Everything we ordered (tiki pork belly, thrice cooked bacon and rice cakes, salt cod fried rice, and their dumpling special) was soooo good! As soon as we entered, the place was small, but the space was lit in red light and decorated with lanterns everywhere. I thought it was cool, like a little indoor Chinatown. The only thing is, we didn't have a private table and had to share it with other people. The couple that sat next to us were obviously on a date and I could hear their conversation. I was thinking, I hope the guy doesn't date that girl again lmao! She wasn't good for him I thought coz she acted a little spoiled and privileged. Anyway, back to the restaurant. Service was good too and they were attentive, although we had to cram the dishes so it doesn't overlap on the couple's space next to us! Parking was a little hard to find when we were there. But I still give them five stars because the food was excellent. I would definitely come back. Maybe I'll try during the day and see what it looks like then, minus the lighting?
author: Cindy S.

description: My second time having their food -- not really sure what all the fuss is about.  Yes, some of the dishes are original and not something you'd find at your neighborhood Chinese place.  But just because it's inventive doesn't mean it's good.  Their flavors are interesting, using unusual spices and ways of combining them, but it's just not working for me.  The spicy things are super spicy in a strange way (numb tongues, anyone?) that makes you not taste anything else that's on your plate, and everything seems to have 5-spice powder.  The cod fried rice, on the other hand, was bland: I was hoping for more fish and salt, but it just had no flavor (Panda Express, anyone?).  Save your money and just get take out at Henry's Hunan, Eric's, Red Jade, or the mom-and-pop Chinese place at the nearest corner; they're much better.
author: Carlo A.

description:
I grew up frequenting the dim sum houses and roast duck windows of Chinatown and I thought I had a handle on "the best places" to fulfill my Chinese food cravings. Leave it to MIssion Chinese Food though, to change my perspective and open up a new window in Chinese cuisine. Don't let the generic name fool you. This place is legitimately a gem that packs a whole load of flavor and excites you with every bite. 

Asian cuisines use a number of spices and Mission really does 'em justice by bringing out their full potential in each of the dishes. Sizzling Cumin Lamb is a great dish that treats the palette to a great balance of spice, tartness, and saltiness. I loved the spicy pickled bean accompaniment, which added the perfect amount of heat to the tender lamb belly and sweet, roasted onions. The Mongolian Beef Cheeks were another hit with me. Similar to the lamb dish, the veggie/herbal ingredients really made an impact and elevated the dish to whole new level of deliciousness that separated it from the dishes made by the neighbors in Chinatown. 

I dig Mission Chinese Food and I'm excited to keep going back, so I can treat my palette to a spice adventure.
author: Christina N.

description:
Had the Ma Po Tofu and Beef Cheeks delivered. Both had waaaay too many peppercorns.  Overwhelmed the taste. 

The rice was really good and I loved the chow fun with onions.

Fast delivery. Great presentation. Just not flavored to our liking. Your mileage may vary. I really, really wanted to love this place and the dishes we ordered didn't impress.
author: eric P.
