description:
Heard great things about this place and I came in with high expectations. Thankfully I picked a monday night when there wasn't a huge crowd because I would have been very upset if I had waited in line two hours for this meal. 

Atmosphere was loud and cramped. I should've known something was up when I noticed the framed 40oz malt liquor bottles decorating the walls. The wait service was nice, however our waitress forgot part of our order and tried to charge us. I think this was more to do with loud nightclub type atmosphere. For food we had the clams, spicy chicken wings, pork belly, chow mein, spicy green beans and some others I can't recall. None stood out in my mind except for the spicy green, which were SO hot that I'm not sure I could taste anything for the rest of the night. If there was a highlight, it was probably the thrice fried pork belly which was good but I've had better at legit Chinese places. 

If you want hipster Chinese food, then you will be all about this place. For my money, I think you'd be better off sticking with one of a dozen other places in Chinatown for a cheaper and better meal. Overhyped but I guess it was worth a try..
author: Matthew T.

description:
Holy crap was this good!  I'm not a huge fan of Chinese food but I loved this.  Their food is definitely more interpretive than authentic but don't let this turn you off Chinese food lovers.  

I came here for a friend's birthday with a group so were able to try almost everything on the menu.  The pork belly, beef cheek, and the cooked bacon were the highlights of the meal though.  The beef cheek and pork belly were bursting with flavor and the meat just melted in my mouth.  I had such a great meal here, I will definitely have to come back again.  Did I mention that they were reasonably priced, they deliver, annnnd a portion of your entree goes to the SF Food Bank?  I dig this dining and donating thing.
author: Jean A.

description:
We get this delicious food delivered, it's easy and pretty fast. 

Plus when you are done ordering from their menu on the web page, you can while away the minutes until your food arrives by playing a little game with the flying ninja, trying to click on him and stop his relentless attack :)
author: j r.

description:
Best food in the Mission for the price.

They also do delivery and pickup, so if you cannot squeeze in, order takeout. You will not be sorry. I don't want to lazily write a chain of superlatives about this place but I should. They deserve every star I give them. Bravo.
author: Kristina P.

description: My friends and I ordered The lamb dumplings, the cold noodles, the custard, the beef cheeks and the spicy Ma Po tofu. Everything was delightful and tasted amazingly fresh!  If you could pick a lamb dumpling from a tree, it would taste as fresh as what they served us at this restaurant. There's no atmosphere to speak of, but as the restaurant fills up the adorable hipster crowd and succulent aroma of their food is quite pleasing. My friends and I will be back.
author: Virginia T.

description: Put very simply this is bastardized Chinese food for hipsters. Worth a shot if you are in the mission and looking for something different. I just don't think it is worth more than a 20 minute wait for it.
author: White K.

description:
Sunday April 29 around 11:50am (20 minutes after they open).  When we arrived there were 4 other tables sat and one already eating. Began with the Beijing Vinegar Peanuts which were bathed in a pool of soy sauce... and topped with peeled cloves of garlic - way over done and garlich should have been better incorporated. I ordered the Shaingahainese Chow Mein... waaaay salty and more onions than noodles or meat (very low % meat). My buddy ordered the  Kung Pao Pastrami and while he loved the heat, the large amount of potatoes versus the small portion of meat turned him off. Also the rice was dry.  Now for service: they served mine without telling us that my buddy's dish would be MUCH longer. How much longer you ask? About 10 minutes from when mine arrived and this was only after we inquired as he never returned to the table after serving mine to see if everything was ok (I would have said mine was too salty). He explained that the delay happens sometimes when they just open but there was a table taht sat after us that was served first. So to all you hipters who put this on the map...you can keep it. For those looking for good Chinese food and service we live in a very diverse neighborhood - explore!!!

PS: Remove the February 15, 2012 dinner service plan from the wall - it, like the tacky Xmas lights, is not art.
author: C K.

description:
Quick Summary: White people's perception of what good Chinese food is (notice how the ones not liking this place ARE CHINESE). Their vegan options are all INSANELY spicy, too spicy for me to even eat! :o(
The wait was pretty long and the entire place was crowded (very). I like how they say no parties over 8, but in the middle of the floor were 3-4 tables or even 5 put together for a party of about 15-20. The person in charged looked like she was screwing or either dating the head chef, so maybe that's how you can get away with things like that..(lolz).What was funny was how some yuppie woman with a very big handbag walked by a table and accidentally hit the water jug with ehr purse, causing the entire jug to tip over spilling everything on their food and into another person's purse. My major complaint is this: HOW COME NO ASIAN PEOPLE WORK HERE? THERE ARE ASIAN HIPSTERS IN SF OR EVEN OAKLAND THAT WOULD KNOW CHINESE CUSTOMS LIKE WHEN SOMEONE WANTS MORE TEA. 

-Good things about this place:
-Large Mexican coke glass bottles 
-Ginger Beer
-vegan Chinese options, and because it's hipster orientated I know that they actually put some effort into really veganizing the dishes, otherwise they'd lose hip points :( I'm always eery when I eat at Chinese places because you never know if it actually is "vegan".
-The staff didn't seem overwhelmed with the amount of people..or pissed off. (good thing!)

Bad Things to Take Note:
-If you ask a waitress/waiter something, be prepared to ask it again to another person because they're so busy they'll probably forgot your question (like for more rice etc).

This place is overrated, and I doubt I'll come back here to eat unless someone takes me here and I don't have to pay..but then again my boyfriend at the time took me here and I didn't have to pay...I don't know..they need less spicy things then maybe I'll like my food!

Also, you look incredibly dumb drinking beer or wine with a paperbag over it in front of the restaurant...just stop.

Also: Added one extra star for their music...thank you for bringing me back to 2003-2005 with Ciara's "My Goodies" and Lil' Jon's "Get Low".
author: Natalie M.

description:
Kung Pao Pastrami and Ninja's on the menu? Say no more. This is some fresh sh*t!  There is nothing else like it and it rocks.

I will go back again and again.
author: Adam W.

description: The pastrami Kung Pao is the best Kung Pao dish I've had anywhere. As a lover of spicy food, this dish goes right up against the threshold of being unbearable, resulting in sweat not just on your forehead but all throughout your skull, which makes stepping out into the cool outside air all the more refreshing.
author: Alex d.

description:
Mission Chinese is awesome, simply put.

I came here with a friend in the trade, so his palette is far more discriminating than mine-- all I really want is good service and clean silverware. When you step into Mission Chinese you are smacked over the head with a weird hybrid of old-school Chop-Suey Chinese eatery and nu-style, hipster hangout replete with Gansta rap soundtrack and tattoo'd wait staff who are as friendly as could be.

Danny, the owner, looks like a nerdy mix between DJ Steve Aoki and Pat Morita of Karate Kid fame and he's a culinary evil genius. We left our dining fate to him and he brought out plate after plate of delights-- and beer-- for us to sink our chops into, then guzzle beer as we recoiled from the hot chili peppers filling the plates.

All in all, this is my new go-to Chinese spot in the Mission, maybe in the entire city. And they deliver! 

Oh Mission Chinese, I just gained three pounds even thinking about your sweet beef cheeks.
author: Ross S.

description:
Before I start - I'm Chinese, I've been to every established Chinese restaurant in SF, NY, Vancouver and los angeles, and I've traveled china and Taiwan.  Thus, I feel I have a good judgment on Chinese food.  So let me begin my experience at this famous hyped Chinese restaurant in the mission district. 

NEVER NEVER GO HERE, THIS IS THE WORSE OVERHYPED CHINESE RESTAURANT EVER!!!! HORRRIBLE, I HAVE WALKED AWAY DISGUSTED AND ASHAMED OF THIS PLACE THAT EVEN CALLS ITSELF A CHINESE RESTRAUNT!!!  It should be called "I can't cook so I'll overspice everything and yet I will give the WORSE service in the world!!!"   I am still shocked by the people who've rated this place 4 stars and above (it's probably the PF Chang and Panda Express crowd - "Ohhhh we eat Chinese food once a year and order Kong Pao Chicken and Fried Rice.")

Here are TOP 10 reasons why you should avoid this place: 
1) I came here at 7:32pm, they told us it's a 40 min wait. Come back at 8:10pm - "it's a 20 min wait."  I ask the waitress at 8:32pm how long the wait will be - "it's a 15-20 min wait."  I ask again at 9:02pm - "it's another 20 min wait."  I finally get seated at 9:18pm.  I don't care if the wait is long, but please be honest and set my expectations. Don't lie to me to just keep me around
2) SERVICE - Chinese restaurants aren't known for their service.  But when I told the waitress that the food was too spicy, she just walked away. Not one person ever came to us to ask us how the food was or if they could pour us more water. She only cared when the bill came - selfish to only care about the tip.  In all my life, I've never tipped below 10% for food.  I'm a very generous 20% tipper. I gave her 0.2% tip for a crappy $78.90 total bill - i was too lazy to wait for the change. 
3) Food was so spicy!!!! You can hear other people complaining about the spice!  My tongue was burning that I couldn't even taste anything else.  
4) MSG!!!! All they use is MSG and Spice to cover up their lack of ability to cook Chinese food!  I've never tasted more Salty food in my life!!!! This is not Chinese food, dont believe anyone on Yelp that says it is. 
5) Cheapness - we got the fried chicken dish for $9.00 or something close to that.   They gave us seven pieces of small chickens covered with over 120 pieces of peppers!  I can order 7 pieces at KFC for only $1.00.  I couldn't even taste the chicken because of the spices
6) The hotdog stand to your right is more delicious 
7) Nothing was delicious. I can't even think of one thing! We went straight to Bi-rite for ice cream just to cool our mouths after all that crappy filled spicy MSG Chinese food. 
8) Be ready to fart spicy stinky Chinese food.  Whatever toxic spicy crap they put in there, it makes you fart.
9) Plain White rice was the best 
10) This place will probably lead to a case of explosive diarrhea


Overall, this is the WORSE experience I've ever had with Chinese food. I've received better service in hole of the wall restaurants in Beijing (the real Beijing).   If you go this place - just set your expectations so low and you'll be happy. Otherwise, please save your time, money, and sanity - avoid this place.  Any other place in SF beats this scam restaurant.   It is truly a SCAM.  I truly believe everyone who rated this restaurant 4 stars above grew probably grew up somewhere without any Chinese food. 

Go to Sunset, Chinatown or Richmond district if you want real Chinese food.
author: Mike L.

description:
It's been well over a month since I ate at MCF but I remember almost all the flavors to this very day!

My girl, Jane L., scoffed when I told her I wanted to order the beef and broccoli but totally apologized after she took her first bite and fell in LOVE.  The aphrodisiacal oysters may have played a role.  Danny Bowen was even kind enough to stop by our table and explain how the oyster sauce was made since Jane and I were tripping out over the flavor.

We also ate the mapo tofu (with the crazy spice) and the pork belly (with nice sesame noodles).

Personally, I appreciated the food more than I enjoyed it (szechuan spice isn't really my thing) but tasting such distinct flavors with metal music blaring in a janky Chinese restaurant was worth the experience.
author: Krystle S.

description:
***Low Down***
A hole in the wall, unassuming, and truly inventive Chinese inspired fusion eatery in the heart of the Mission.  It began as a pop up but has taken on a life of its own and gone into the stratosphere.  The food offerings are as diverse as the clientele. The place is not huge but can accommodate larger parties in the middle row of tables that run the length of the restaurant. The decor inside is your stereotypical hole in the wall joint with a paper dragon on the ceiling and mismatched pictures adorning the wall. The overhead music playing is gangsta rap!  Lil Wayne, Ice Cube, etc. Ha!  The decibels in here are pretty high with the loud music and conversations going on. You really do need to shout to be heard.  They do not take reservations and the wait times for a table can be very looong but well worth the wait IMO.  Service is hit or miss since its always so busy but always friendly with a smile. Take out and delivery are available which is awesome and speedier than having to wait for a table. Parking in the Mission is spotty for sure. 

***Show Down***
I've eaten here for dinner half a dozen times and have never been disappointed. My favorite dish has got to be the cod fried rice. It is seasoned perfectly and definitely not fishy.  The chongqing spicy chicken wings are coated in numbing Sichuan peppercorns and served with fried dried chili peppers. It's so good I can't get enough. I even eat the dried chilies :-). I've also had the lamb face noodles, thick rice noodles served in a delicious robust broth and chunks of fatty lamb.  Then there's the oddest and most creative of them all, the kung pau pastrami. Big chunks of pastrami stir fried with celery and mushrooms in a savory gravy. So delicious with rice.  This is a can't miss and a truly unique dining experience. I can't recommend Mission Chinese enough.
author: Tara T.

description: One of the worst Chinese restaurants in San Francisco. We ordered their sizzling lamb- there were only 3 small pieces and were charred badly and by the way there were hidden in a mountain of sliced onions and leaves. Their hainam chicken rice was very salty and greasy.
author: Manny P.

description:
Ordered the Salt Cod Fried Rice and the Mapo Tofu.  Went here with the bf because of all the hype surrounding the establishment.  There was a little crowd outside the restaurant.  We realized that we are to sign our name on a list outside their door.  We people watched and looked over their menu which was hanging next to the list.

It was a dimly lit dining room.  Packed.  If it were brighter, the hanging decorations would have seemed quite tacky.  The food arrived shortly after we ordered.  The fried rice was salty tasting, but good, but then again nothing to rave about... The mapo tofu was spicy, but in a deep heat way.  There was no uncomfortable spicy fiery taste or feel.  The only negative about the mapo tofu was that I needed to add soy sauce because it lacked and saltiness.  

All in all I would go back.  There were a lot on the menu I still want to try.  I would recommend going with a large group to try and explore the dishes, but it may be hard to sit together.
author: dublin a.

description: This place is a pretty decent place.  The food here is good but not AMAZING as rated.  I would say the lamb chops were super tasty and the slowcooked bacon were the highlights of the trip.  The salted cod fried rice was good but its definitly overpriced.  We went right after the lunch rush so the lines werent crazy.  I would definitly do it again if i was in the area but wont go out of the way to get some chinese food here.
author: Curtis C.

description:
First off, I don't like waiting in line for hours to eat cheap Chinese food. Plus, for all the hype, the recent batch of Yelp reviews didn't speak very highly of this place. However, Anthony Bourdain's recent visit to the City, and a hungry stomach at around 5:00pm on a Friday, prompted my girlfriend and to give this place a shot. 

I was actually surprised at how affordable this place is. Most dishes are between $10-12. A lot of dishes peaked our interest, but we ended up settling on (i) Thrice Cooked Bacon; (ii) Broccoli Beef Cheek; (iii) Li Bao Dry Braised Noodles; and (iv) Salt Cod Fried Rice. The Thrice Cooked Bacon was outstanding - good smoky flavor with the perfect amount of spiciness. Broccoli Beef Cheek was a very very close second - the beef cheek was moist and soft and the oyster sauce (which included actual oysters) was not overpowering. I thought the Salt Cod Fried Rice was a tad bit on the salty side when I first had it. But when I had it the next day, I could honestly say it tasted way better. I would skip out on the Li Bao noodles as there was a strange aftertaste that wasn't appealing. Note that the portion size is quite large and we managed to turn this dinner into two additional meals the next day. 

After a more in-depth look at some Yelp reviews, I've come to the conclusion that a lot of people knock this place because of its hipster clientele, personified by its owner Danny Bowien. I've also come to the conclusion that people suffer from unrealistic expectations - a Michelin experience in a place adorned with empty Cristal bottle vases stuffed with fake flowers. But this place doesn't pretend to be authentic Chinese; rather it openly confesses that it serves "Americanized Oriental food." My kudos goes out to MCF not only for its charitable endeavors, but for challenging my palate to experience something beyond various interations of sweet and sour pork, Mongolian beef, and kung pao [insert protein here]. I'll be back, even if everyone around me is wearing skinny jeans.
author: Lael A.

description: Went early (6:30ish mid-week) and didn't have to wait. Ate family-style with a friend. A lot of the dishes were great! We had the smashed cucumbers (pretty good), fresh rice noodle (just OK), stir-fried pork jowl and salt cod fried rice (both ah-mazing). Good beers too. Don't expect to linger, though: we were (politely) asked to vacate our table as soon as we paid the check, since there was a sizeable line outside.
author: Soo J.

description: I am Chinese and I would never eat here.  I live less than two blocks away.  Die Hipster Scum!
author: Coyote B.

description:
For all my fellow reviewers who have given this place a decent rating, I think 1 of 3 things are happening:  
1. You guys must be out of towners from a place where Chinese food is not common or you are bandwagon reviewers.  There is NO WAY this is good Chinese food or even good food!
2. The restaurant must have contacted you when you originally wrote your honest bad review.  They asked you if you took it down they'd refund your bill or give you a free meal, so you did.
3. We are all being Punk'd!

This place is truly a scam or some sort of joke on San Franciscan foodies! I can deal with a place with bad food and good service, and I can deal with a place with good food and bad service.  But to deal with a place that makes you wait over 2 hours, when originally quoting you 45 minutes and then having to deal with the bitchy pint size waitress with the tacky eagle tattoo on her left arm or deal with the blonde chic with the batman t-shirt where they roll their eyes at you when you ask if you've ordered too much food, and then give you a scornful look when you comment on how spicy the food is, and then don't even bother checking up on you to see how it's going, it puts me over the edge! 

The food has WAY TOO much MSG and spice!  The noodles were greasy.   It all seemed to be a brown color.  We ever got the green beans, and those even tasted nasty.  The food came out so fast that it was definitely not made fresh. I just felt so unhealthy after the meal.

We all work hard for our money and to spend time to come to this place and waste my time and money was just a joke.  The food was the WORSE FOOD EVER.  Let me say that again, just in case you didn't get it the first time - WORSE. FOOD. EVER!  Do not waste your time, your money, your dignity, and your ability to ever taste again for this ATROCIOUS place.
author: A T.

description:
CA-fresh chinese food delivered in 20 minutes.  Sweeeeeet.

Black cod fried rice.....
Fresh pea shoots w/ thai basil, cilantro in rice noodle rolls & rice vinegar....

Simple fresh ingredients in delicious combinations.
author: Melanie C.

description:
This place is awesome...

One of the only places in the city where you can get authentic Szechuan peppercorn in your food (the other one I can think of is Z&Y in China Town, which is also awesome but more expensive).

I have had a variety of things here and everything has been awesome.  They change up their menu often so there are always new things to try.

Some of my favorites have been The Eggplant, Chicken Wings, and Lamb Chops (actually some of the best chops I've ever had), Thrice Cooked Bacon, and the Ma Po Tofu.

They also give a portion of each check to the SF Food Bank, which is pretty nice :)

They got 4/5 stars because their beer selection is sort of weak... otherwise, I'd give them 5.

Highly, highly recommend!
author: Joseph H.

description:
0 stars!  Overhyped (thanks NYTIMES) and just plain terrible.  I went with a large group and tried a good cross-section of the dishes, and the food was uniformly awful. The biggest complaint here is the level of spiciness- every single dish was absolutely drenched in jalapenos and other super hot spices, so any other flavors were completely undetectable. Why even try to have a so-called interesting take on Chinese food if you're just going to destroy your diner's mouths in fiery bites of fire? We're no strangers to spicy food, but our mouths (and other orifices) didn't recover for days.  Even if you can look past the horrifying spice issues, the food was totally disappointing. For example a lot of the dishes seemed to skimp on the good stuff-  pastrami and bacon are hard to find in the dishes that supposedly feature them.  The barbecue dish we had also came with soggy white bread which promptly disintegrated into a paste, just foul.  The dining experience was further ruined by the awful dim fluorescent lighting and the pounding house music. Even the bathroom was terrible! The only positive points- we discovered an interesting rice cake in the bacon dish, the prices were inexpensive, and the wait staff were friendly and prompt. 

Bottom line- Don't waste your money on this trend unless you like to wait outside for hours to have your taste buds burned off. This was the worst meal I've had in my 6 years of eating in San Francisco.
author: Paul T.

description: Overrated- food is not flavorful, just all spice! I love spice as long as there is flavor to go along..
author: Romita J.

description: After sacrificing 1 hour of my life waiting in line for a mediocre but extremely hip asian food restaurant, all i could say it's just Ok. Am I gonna go back again? Probably No!
author: Beril Y.

description:
after hearing about all the hype and watching it on Anthony Bourdain's Layover show, we came to try the place out. being on a saturday evening, of course we had to wait almost an hour for a table. i am not big on spicy food and this is definitely a spicy food place. my opinion on the place though is that it is overrated and is catered as a chinese restaurant for guay lows.

the place is run by chinese people but hire an american wait staff and make the ambience have that darker lighting with some chinese decorations, ie. big dragon in the ceiling which is actually sort of cool.

some of the dishes sounded interesting with a fusion style blended with szechuan style chinese food but everything was basically spicy and greasy.

the pork belly was crispy but nothing that was memorable.

the fried rice was tasty, but the description made it sound a lot more interesting and unique that what it was.

the lamb noodle soup smelled and tasted very gamey. i dont usually like lamb though.

the chicken wings were nicely fried and tasty but it makes your tongue numb which i am not a fan of.

it was definitely worth trying for me but probably not a place i would go back to.
author: Alex H.

description:
Finally got myself to this great little spot on a whim, walked right in & got seated. We had the salt cod fried rice and I think something called Tiger Salad? Both were excellent & spiced perfectly! The salt cod had yummy little Chinese sausage slices. The 'salad' was really a fresh spring roll crammed (almost too big for my mouth!) with greens, veggies & drizzled with a spicy sauce. 
I have always loved the mellow Mission dining areas (miss you Country Station) and Mission Chinese has really created a new niche. They not only have a friend's kitchen feel they also give a percentage of proceeds to the Food Bank. The prices are great, the portions are large and you're giving back while eating well. Win Win Win!
author: Colleen B.

description:
Wow, this food has F L A V O R. The pork dumplings are the best I've ever had!  The noodle soup with lamb was incredible. I've never tasted this kinda flavor at a Chinese place before. The ma po tofu was tasty, but was a bit too spicy. We'll DEFINITETLY be back for more. Lucky for me I live in the 'hood. 

The decor is definitely not your typical Chinese joint. It's more a cross between local Mission joint and Chinese with some 60s aesthetic thrown in. It just added to the experience for me, making it feel like ur eating in the Mission.
author: Scott L.

description: My favorite restaurant in SF. Love this place. Great, inventive menu. Awesome fun atmosphere. Reasonably priced. I'm never disappointed. Squid ink pasta is the best.
author: J K.

description: Can't believe it's 3 1/2 stars. Should have higher ratings.  I traveled and went to a lot of restaurants. This by far was one of the best meals I had in my life. Normally I'm not a big fan of fusion, but the flavors and spices and creativity of all dishes were amazing. Even though it is fusion it has a lot of traditional Chinese ingredients in many dishes. We went 25 minute before closing (which I recommend if you don't want to wait too long) so we didn't even wait! We had a group of 9 and we tried a bunch of dishes. The more people the better so you can try everything. We ordered the pork belly, Kung Pao pastrami, mapa tofu, salted cod fried rice, green beans, short ribs. Everything was good. My favorite was the Kung pao pastrami, the salted cod fried rice, and short ribs. All these dishes were flavored well and was cooked perfectly. The ambience is pretty cool too with the red lights. Not a luxury scene but for the $ you cannot expect more. Service was excellent as well. This is my first time giving any restaurant a perfect score.
author: jae c.

description:
The Tiger Salad, buckwheat noodles, and Schezuan pickles are some of the best vegetarian food in this town. The existence of spicy, well-thought out non-meaty food in a town where vegetarian often means *meh* makes me almost glow with happy. 

I am living in a golden age. I realize this.
author: H. S.

description:
i just wanted to place a to-go order. i stood at the front-- holding a menu and trying to make eye contact with the servers-- and NO ONE who worked there spoke to me, or acknowledged me for about 10 minutes. they were busy so i tried to wait patiently, but seriously? no one can stop for 5 seconds to ask me if i want a table or take out and deal with me appropriately?

also, i'm vegetarian, and i it seemed like i could maybe eat three things on the menu? eh. whatever magic fairie dust this place seems to have for people, i'd rather go to a place where i can eat and the staff doesn't pretend i'm invisible.
author: Domini D.

description: I have no idea what made NYtimes to list this place as the best of San Francisco. Yelpers know better. Food was way too salty and definitely not fresh.
author: Vipul B.

description:
This place is terrible enough for me to pop my Yelp contributor cherry.

Service: 1 star for the sympathetic waitress, -4 for the owner, Anthony. 
Food: 0 star

6 of us ordered a wide variety of dishes;  westlake rice porridge, ma po tofu, kung pao pastrami, mongolian long beans, sizzling cumin lamb, tingly lamb noodle soup.

Our entire party thought that all dishes of them were extremely salty.  As in, you could barely taste the food.  And in that slight moment of being able to taste it, it tasted sour.  I guess that's the "uniqueness" or "innovative" aspect of this place.

I've had all sorts of Asian food, Thai, Vietnamese, Hunan/Szechuan, Taiwanese, etc in my lifetime, but nothing resembled the awful flavors from our choice of dishes here.

Food aside, there was music blasting from the speakers in the back made conversation impossible.  Our waitress had turned it down, only for the owner (Anthony) to crank it back up later.  It was awfully generous of him to turn it down when requested directly by us.  That is, until he threw us the check not too long after.  In fact, the moment we slid our chairs out to get up, he turned the music right back up.  I guess when you're ego's that big, customer concerns are a non-issue.  

Then there's the lack of lighting as others have pointed up.  Better fire up that flashlight app on you

Summary: 
Having passed this restaurant numerous times and seeing the lines out the door, one would've guessed this place would be good.  Guess this falls into one of those inexplicably over-hyped restaurants.  Seems like those who ranked it highly are those who've never ever had Chinese (Szechuan, to be exact) food.  Even more so when weekend lines could be in the 30-60 min wait range.
author: Corey L.

description: Uggg. What happened here? The food used to be so good. Now it's greasy and gross.
author: Robert C.

description:
After a 50 minute wait and 6 parties ahead of us on the wait list it was finally our turn. The guy running the wait list called out my name and the person below my name at the same time. Immediately the person below my name jumped ahead of me and didn't bother to have the decency to say "they were ahead of us". The bitch just jumped the line. When the list monitor came back outside I brought it to his attention but he ended up blaming it on me saying i didnt mark the box that said all present and proceeded to call another party ahead of me again. As if everyone is suppose to know to mark that box (thinking that that was for restaurant staff to write in).
We were seated shortly after.
The noise level is so high in the restaurant. Not because it is small but rather everyone is packed in shoulder to shoulder and the music is SO loud. You can't hold a conversation without shouting.
However, the food is very good and even though it was super crowded for a Monday, the service, once seated, was great and fast.
Mapu tofu is always the staple order for me.
I keep going back and the wait is worth it.. Just make sure you police the wait list like a hawk.
author: Kawhom L.

description: Visited here on our trip to San Fran... and man was it good.  You know how sometimes you ask the waiter/waitress on what they'd recommend, and they say everything is good?  This is the first place that I felt that that applied.  Also, I drank cold sake for the first time... it was also fantastic.  One very happy customer here :)
author: Mark T.

description: I've never written a 1 star review but I have to say this place under delivered in every possible way. We ordered takeout and got 5 different dishes with plans to save a few things for another day. Not only did we not like 1 dish but we did not save a thing, we both felt each item was either too spicy, to fat, too greasy, etc. I believe this place is completely overhyped and does not deserve the early credit it received. There was probably a time Mission Chinese killed it but for us, we will not go here again. We have never disliked every dish from a restaurant in SF but it happened at Mission Chinese.
author: Louis P.

description: What a surreal experience. It looked like a Chinese restaurant, it has "Chinese" in its name, there were Chinese people working there.... But it was not Chinese food I can remember having as a kid. I am not against paying good money for good food. But I paid $30 before tip for peanuts, cold egg custard, and porridge. I could have spent about 1/3 the amount for better food in the Sunset or Richmond
author: Lisa Y.

description: Wasn't into this place... I heard great things, which drew me to it. The bacon dish was so so so yummy, just what I needed on an early Sunday afternoon. But the pork belly was disgusting and my boyfriend got food poisoning. Totally not worth it. I'll probably never go back here again.
author: Laney W.

description:
In a few words: Not worth the hype.

I had their take out last year and thought it was just ok..nothing special.  But, I kept hearing how amazing it is, so thought I'd check it out again, this time as a dine-in patron.  First instincts proved to be true.

Food: Unique combinations, average quality, some are too salty, fairly fatty foods (aka, where's the beef?)

Ambiance: Kitchy and fun, hole in the wall vibe.  The seating is very tight which is fine as it adds to the hole in the wall vibe.

Wait: Yes, you will wait...and longer then the time quoted. Perhaps there is a reason for the bacon-wrapped hot dog stand outside the restaurant.

Service: We needed to ask for our menu's.  All the food came immediately, at one time.  They initially forgot about some of our drinks. Gave us our bill soon after dropping off our food.  We were conversing, a bit after eating, while finishing our drinks, and were asked to vacate the table.

As much as I wanted to like it....With all of the fantastic eateries in SF, I do not feel the need to return.
author: SF G.

description:
I live a block a way and constantly hear the rants and raves about this place.  I was excited to try it.

We ordered the lamb noodle and the spicy tofu dish.

Both we're COMPLETELY inedible.  The lamb noodle was wildly over salted, the noodles were soggy, the lamb was mysteriously absent.  The Tofu was extremely spicy, but not in a good way.  We barely made a dent in either dish, and asked for it to go because we felt bad.  We literally couldn't eat it.

Let me be very clear I LOVE SPICY FOOD.  I order the spiciest dish at almost every restaurant I go to.  The problem here is that they were disguising a tasteless dish behind a bunch of spice.  There was literally no other taste, complexity or redeeming quality to it.  Like all their other dishes, the meat (pork shoulder) was essentially non-existent.  What was there was fatty, rubbery and not well cooked... also eclipsed by the one flavor of the dish.

This place is a complete bust.  I have no idea what the hype is about.  Maybe all the buzz came from their hipster friends or something, because in a neighborhood FULL of mediocre Chinese food, this place doesn't even earn that title.  THIS PLACE IS DISGUSTING.  DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME AND MONEY.  I expect it will be closed within months.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Wah, wah, wah, I live in San Francisco and love to complain about stuff. Wah!!!!

You guys are killing me, Smalls. We got delivery, it was hot and not at all gross like most delivery places. Sure, it took 45 minutes but that was enough to watch most of an intense episode of Breaking Bad so the wait wasn't that awful. Especially considering all the other Chinese places that take the same amount of time but supply you with crap.

That being said, this is NOT your typical Chinese food, so please be aware before you come on Yelp and complain about it. We had the Ma Po Tofu and the Beef Cheeks. OMG! The beef cheeks were super tender, full of flavor, delicious, and definitely full of spicy KICK. Also, it came with my favorite noodles: THICK RICE NOODLES! FTW. The tofu was equally SPICY and also had these awesome flavors under the layers of heat. You will need extra rice. IF YOU ARE A WIMP, DON'T ORDER THESE, duh!!!

Also: TARO PANNA COTTA. Soggy cookie or not, this creamy delight is not to be missed!

Looking forward to: Salt Cod Fried Rice.
author: Salina Z.

description: Been there three times, and it'll be a long time before I'm back.  The "Emperor's New Clothes" of Chinese food.  Everything spiced with a far too heavy hand.  If the service had been better, the wait shorter, and the tab less pricey, I'd give it one more star.  But as it is...
author: Joe K.

description: Kool atmosphere... Food sucked. Leave it to mission hipsters to over hype this place.
author: Demanding T.

description:
3/4 of the dishes were can't-miss. Peking duck chinito, salt cod fried rice, and vegan delight soup. I was not a huge fan of the Islamic hot pot. People are complaining about the heat but that didn't bother me; it was just too greasy for my taste. 

Delivery was fast and they actually told me not to order a couple of things that don't travel well. I respect that. Will definitely repeat.
author: Jason Y.

description: Came here Sunday night just right before closing (they close the wait list at 10:15pm, although the restaurant closes at 10:30pm).  But they still allowed us to order to go, so we didn't waste a trip out there!   we ordered ma-po tofu (i thought it's a bit salty, but good), salt cod fried rice (really good!), and an appetizer (forgot the name, but had tripe, heart and some other organ--not very good).   I would want to go back and try other dishes!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
We love their salt cod fried rice. We've tried their mapo tofu as well and that was all kinds of weirdness we would never try again. But the fried rice is a certified winner!
This place gets super busy...do takeout if you live in the mission.
author: j d.

description: Seems a little disorganized. A confusing wait list outside that gets ignored while empty tables wait for no-one. Food was good. Very different from what I've had and far more interesting than what I expected. Americanized for sure, which is how I like Chinese food.
author: Hector B.

description: I'd read about this place a few times and was pretty excited for it.  The food was decent, but didn't blow me away.  The thrice cooked bacon was probably the best dish we had.  Also, the fried rice and peanut noodles were good.  The Mongolian long beans were just okay.  I went with a friend who is Chinese and she kept saying that it's not real Chinese food.  If you want your Chinese food to be authentic, you'll probably hate it.
author: Jake W.

description:
Yes this place has a lot of hype. Big deal! Freakin' hype is a good thing! People are excited, I'm excited! The food is fantastic and feels authentic, regional, creative and just so fun. Been multiple times and had takeout and everything we have tried has been amazing. Even things that don't sound good! Clams with black bean sauce, wow! 
Yes it's hipster, who cares. No pretentious foodie bull, if you want 90's hiphop music, cold beer and spicy delicious food, this is for you.
author: J D.

description: I tried the Cod Fried Rice to go and with intent on sharing, and ended up tasting something good enough for me to want my own dish.  I tried the Thrice Cooked Bacon and ended up tasting God in the form of pork, dumpling, and spice. Best dish of my entire life.
author: Jason W.

description:
remember when you could just walk in and get a table?

well, that didn't last long. 

don't walk in thinking you're going to get sesame chicken or sweet and sour anything, because you won't. this isn't panda express and you aren't in chinatown.

just know that most things here are good, if you can check your notion of what chinese food is at the door.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Wait time: There's a sign where you write your name and party number by the door. There were about 15 people ahead of us on a Saturday night, so we were pretty pessimistic. Luckily a lot of groups dropped out (lesson learned: do not wander around; stay by the door!) and we were seated in 20 minutes.

The atmosphere: Being a SoCal native, I'm used to the typical cramped, slightly dirty Chinese restaurants with chipped plates and mismatched chopsticks. This place is exactly like that, except with non-Asian waitresses and club hip hop music blasting around. Oh, did I mention the blacklight paper lanterns? Pretty weird.

The food: The food is definitely not bad, but not GREAT. It's more authentic than your typical Americanized-Chinese food restaurant, but definitely still Americanized. 
We ordered the salted cod fried rice (tastes like something my Mom made for me when I was little), Taiwanese clams (pretty good, I suggest getting rice with this), and Hainam Chicken Rice (not great; I wonder if the rice was even cooked with Chicken Broth or if it was just regular rice seasoned with Chicken seasoning afterwards).

Overall, it's great but not worth the insane hype.
author: C W.

description: I don't care what anyone says. This place is amazing. Sure, it may not be the most authentic (hell, with OG Chinatown close by, this place may seem unnecessary) but it is damn delicious. We came pretty hungry right before close on a weeknight, and the place was packed and the music was loud. The atmosphere is great - it's super hip, and the food is pretty affordable. The hot wings are mouth and mind-numbing (literally and figuratively) and the lo mein is out of this world. We had an asparagus dish too that was perfectly spicy and crunchy. Everything was spot-on! We shared so much food and it was an awesome experience.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I think it would have helped if I had realized it wasn't a traditional Chinese restarant.  It also would have helped if someone hadn't overhyped it before we went.

Took parents of a friend to this when couldn't find parking anywhere near Shanghai Dumpling King.  Should've taken them to Chinatown or somewhere else.  This was not their scene, nor their type of cuisine. Should've seen it was Sichuan style (meaning spicy) which they couldn't eat.

But even for someone who likes to try new things, I was seriously underwhelmed.
 Cumin lamb was interestingly flavored & had there been any ACTUAL lamb in the dish, might've been good --  but there was almost NO LAMB in the dish.  It was a pile of onions & a few other things.  I counted about 5 tiny thin strips of meat.  Maybe they were running out of the lamb or something, but it was so not worth it!!

Thrice cooked bacon dish was just adding bacon to the standard "Shanhai 'cakes'" I've had elsewhere.  Good but did not impress.  Same unimpressiveness for Salt cod fried rice & Mustard greens - Good, but certainly nothing special.  I've had better fried rice.  

Atmosphere, usual for Mission, pee-smelling sidewalks, hole in the wall looking interior.  Full of hipsters. (Our noodle maker was wearing a very holey/ripped Iron Maiden tank-top... "ironically"... I"m sure)

Overall, don't take visiting parents who don't want to experiment - good for a one time try but I think I'll stick to my preferred more traditional Chinese haunts in Sunset & Richmond areas.
author: Kyra T.

description: Finally decided to try Mission Chinese after all the hype and it sucked. You really can't tasted the quality ingredients when everything is drowned in so much heavy sauce. The lamb noodles were too salty with an odd mix of seasonings that clashed together, leaving an icky film in our mouth. The smoked eel appetizer was ok but not outstanding. There was nothing in the dish that gave you any idea of eel as the eel was deep fried and could have easily been crispy smoke anything. Veal ribs were overcooked and dry, doused in heavy sauce. $50 for dish, a bowl of noodles, an appetizer, one beer, and white rice. Much better and more authentic Chinese food in other places for less. We definitely won't be back.
author: Ruth L.

description:
Don't freak out when you see "Lung Shan Restaurant" on the door.  You're at the right place! 

Great food overall with a nice variety; however, service was poor at best.  Our waitress had quite an attitude until it was time for us to fill in the "tip" line on our bill.  Food was was good enough to still give 4 stars despite the poor service.  We would try Mission again.
author: Scott H.

description:
It's easy to pass this place all the time without realizing that this is THE "Mission Chinese" that everyone talks about, because from the outside it's just a sign with some generic Chinese name!

Last time I went it was a full house and I was literally the only Asian person in the restaurant. Welcome to Mission Chinese Food.

Pork belly: amazing. Delicious, with impressive presentation (for being Chinese food).
Ma po tofu: also delicious and hotter than the usual Chinese restaurant tofu. This seems to be a specialty of theirs so it's definitely worth trying.
author: Joy X.

description:
Four of us ate there a couple of times in the past few months and tried quite a number of dishes. No waiting if you go for lunch. Maybe it is not as good or the novelty has subsided. 

The food concept is very interesting. I applaud them for the wonderful twists they put in to regular Chinese food... e.g. adding the rice cakes to the Thrice cooked bacon dish, putting "cheung fun" instead of regular noodles in the Beef Noodle Soup.  However, the executions of most dishes are not refined at all, plus overall the food is too spicy, oily and salty. I have asked the waitress to see if the kitchen can tone down the salt and spice and was given a flat no as an answer.  You can only eat this kind of food once a year if you are at all health conscious.  

The place is a dump and prices do not reflect the quality of the food.  Maybe they are doing better in NYC than SF.
author: Eleanor C.

description: The food was amazing at this location. Very spicy but very good. Their service could stand some help as it is a typical mission attitude (which they may actually like), but we prefer a little friendlier service. The food and beer was great. highly recommend folks to try it. We found out about it in the New York Times 36 hour report and loved it and brought friends here.
author: Brent T.

description:
Hypity hype hype hype!

I have a hypothesis about this place: this restaurant always has a line outside because the service is SO bad. Then, people say things like, "Hey, there's always a line outside that place - so it must be good!" 

We put our names on the clipboard outside and people-watched next to the guy selling hotdogs on the sidewalk for 35 minutes. That wait was somewhat enjoyable plus we're willing to wait even longer for good food. Once we got a table though, we waited for 20-25 minutes before even being acknowledged (the host finally realized and grabbed a server). That's when we started to wonder about this place.

To be fair, the bok choy in popcorn broth was great - a little over salty, but still delish. If you really want it, order take-out or delivery. The egg egg noodles were pretty good too. The peanut noodles were incredibly underwhelming - I make better ones myself.

The best things about this restaurant: 1) $0.75 per entree is donated to the food bank, and 2) there are ninjas jumping across their website. Unfortunately, that's not enough to make me want to go back.
author: Katie S.

description:
ok, the more i have it, the better it gets.

the porridge (congee/jook) is possibly the best i've ever had.  ox tail + cilantro + the usual = the perfect combination.  call me non-traditional, but i find myself craving it time and time again, and not only when i'm sick.

the salt cod fried rice, which apparently, is another popular dish, is pretty standard fried rice, so i wouldn't get my hopes up on that being as unique as some of the other dishes.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Best Chinese delivery I've ever had. This is not your daddy's greasy Chinese-American joint. The food is fresh and flavorful. 

Right now I can only vouch for the Tiger Salad, Ma Po Tofu, and Tingly Lamb Noodle Soup, but I will guarantee that I eventually try everything on the menu.
author: Kendall D.

description: Affordable, exotic, the highest quality ingredients.  What's not to like.  (Oh yeah the place is "hole in the wall-ish" but what do you expect with these amazingly low prices?
author: Theo R.

description:
SALT LICK
wings and lamb were way over seasoned.  Fried rice was good.  May try again but will have to come with more than 2 people so we can play the odds of the food is off.  The rice porridge had a perfectly cooked egg.  Yum.
author: Alex A.

description: Delicious, unique food - unlike anything i've ever had! Highly recommend it, and agree with others who say it is underrated on Yelp.
author: Bethany D.

description: Super hip, kinda grungy joint in the heart of the Mission.  I'll second the other Yelpers and recommend the eel rolls and the pork belly.  Very creative menu which I would call more Asian inspired rather than traditional Chinese.  Just don't look to closely around the restaurant or you might loose your appetite.
author: Kim K.

description:
u know i had to stop by this place....i aint no hipster but i been hearing about this place more than how much my mom nags at everyone in the house, and everytime i pass by here, i see a good amount of body counts, at least 10 waiting outside usually, mostly forming a meandering of asians and hipsters

anyways i came here with 4 other friends and we ordered string beans, chicken wings, pork belly, chow mien and mapo tofu, out of those 5 string beans, wings and mapo tofu were spicy (i have a high tolerance for spicy shit, growing up with kimchi and pepper all the time, i love eating SPICY ASS STUFF) so i didnt think it was too spicy, but my other friends thought it was a bit too much, and they are pretty spicy to normal people in my opinion.

my fav. was mapo tofu and the pork belly, I highly recommend it, chow mein was also good, the string beans and chicken wings were TOO SALTY in my opinion, on top of that it was spicy for others so they also didnt touch them, i found them too salty to eat.

i def. wanna come back here and try other stuff, def. get the mapo tofu again for sure!!

4 stars
author: Michael K.

description:
Different? Yes. 
Interesting? Yes.
Worthy of all the praise heaped upon it? Definitely not. 

I've read glowing reviews and heard raves from foodie friends, sources from which I've gotten really great recommendations previously and, frankly, I don't see or taste what they're so excited about. The menu offers "twists" on standard Chinese dishes, which are interesting but not necessarily inventive. You can get much better and more authentic food in the San Gabriel Valley outside of L.A.; offerings that stand on their own without the need for twists. Further, I'm not one to shy away from salt but every dish we ordered was ridiculously over-salted.  I dont know if the people in the kitchen were having an off day when we visited but, all-in-all, it was a huge disappointment.

Don't believe the hype.
author: B G.

description: The food is full of flavor. I went during lunch to avoid lines, and the place was empty!
author: T S.

description:
hipsters will be in uproar, but i don't really get they hype about this place.  the food is definitely geared toward the western palate (only 4 asians total in sight while i was there) and they play rap music, which i guess ups the cool ante.

we ate very conscientiously so as not to discriminate each dish against what would normally be expected from a more traditional version.  basically, did it taste good even if it wasn't what we were expecting?  i guess that sounds wierd to say when you would think that it should taste even better as a twist on the traditional, right?  sadly, no.

*szechuan pickles - good.  like kim chi but with pickles and peanuts.
*savory egg custard - by far the stand out.  very unique with interesting textures.  roe was salty but the shiso mellowed it out.  if you're a fan of uni, you'll like it.  
*ma po tofu - really really spicy.  if you like spicy you'll probably like this dish.  but you must also like tons of peppercorn, ginger, star anise (?), and lots of oil.  and salt.
*pork dumplings in ham broth - super dense dumplings, way too salty, could use some lightness in the broth, not more pork. skin on dumplings thick.
*salt cod fried rice - all the dishes were too salty but ironically the salt cod fried rice was not salty enough.  we couldn't find the fish.

by the end all the heavy flavors melded together and everything tasted the same.  salty or spicy.  i really wish we had gotten the pork belly, but we probably won't make it back.

service was excellent, so 2.5 stars overall.

ps.  if you're searching for a tasty twist on chinese food, go to san tung instead.
author: Josie M.

description: Authentic Chinese food? No. But the best take on innovative and flavorful hipster Chinese food. Don't know what that is? Go to mission Chinese!
author: Ritesh R.

description:
I am really surprised by some of these reviews. I thought the food was fantastic. I really liked the eggplant and the pickles. I didn't love the chicken wings, but that was the only dish out of the 6 or 7 our group ordered that I was not a fan of, not to shabby. 

Another huge plus, NO corkage fee!!! Will def. be back.
author: Sophia D.

description:
Peanut noodle dish was ridiculously bad. Why pay that much for a bunch of bland sticky noodles with a laddle of peanut sauce on them. I couldn't stomach eating the rest. 

The tripe snacks in the wing app were horrible. Over cooked and hard crunchy that didn't make them good to eat.

The triple bacon was not great and not much variety in it. The bacon slices were 3/4 fat and 1/4 meat.  Their were a ton of tofu slices in it probably because that stuff is cheap and makes the dish look big. I wanted a bacon meat dish so keep the crappy tofu out of it
author: Willam B.

description: I came here wanting Chinese food. I thought it would be really good because there is always a line outside. I didn't like any of it. While I think the combinations were creative, that does not mean that it is good. You still have to pay a lot though, because they are very proud of their weird ideas. It was better than Panda Express though, so there is one point for them there.
author: Shara M.

description: I remember seeing this place on food network.  I found it yesterday and I was not disappointed.  I sat down and the atmosphere was kind of dark and there's a large paper dragon hanging from the ceiling.  We were seated and the restaurant was half full.  A family was just finishing up behind us with a big plate of the Breakfast Fried Rice.  Looking at the menu that sounded really good and they overheard us mention that.  They offered us the fried rice which was really nice of them.  Oh my god, the thing was sooo damn good.  It had bacon in eggs in the fried rice of course.  It was also topped with salmon roe which added the perfect amount of saltiness to the dish.  We're not homeless or anything, we did order some food.  I ordered the squid ink noodles and my wife ordered the pork belly.  The squid ink noodles were good and it wasn't like linguine as I was expecting, but more like the rice noodles you'd find in a chow fun.  It had lamb and yogurt along with some onions and spinach to form a well balanced dish.  The yogurt was a little weird with the squid ink noodles, but overall I was happy with the dish.  The pork belly was delicious giving a nice crispiness on the outside and fatty tenderness on the inside.  They also combined the sweet and saltiness that I really enjoyed.  The service was also great.  We had two servers roaming around.  We were primarily taken care of the dude with the California shirt, beard, and wine red beanie.  They were both friendly, but not too friendly where it would be creepy.  They were both quick and did give us the perfect amount of attention.  My only other critique would be, the bathroom is clean enough, but there were some flies in there.  No flies anywhere else in the restaurant, just the bathroom.  I'd still come back and have a meal here though.
author: Exequiel R.

description: This place is phenomenal. What an exciting dining experience - flavors you have never imagined come together and it is such a treat! I haven't had longer than a 15 minute wait, so I guess I've gotten lucky (and last time I went was a Sunday, so maybe go then!) The tiger salad is a great wait to start. The thrice cooked bacon is yum yum vegetarian style - just ask for mild, because otherwise it is HOT HOT HOT. FYI - the bok choy was a great way to cool down the mouth. Go Enjoy!
author: Lucey M.

description:
With their salt cod fried rice ranking #1 on the 7x7 list for 2012, it was basically mandatory to try Mission Chinese Food. Although I've always walked by, I never wanted to wait that long so instead I called in for take out and picked up my order of the fried rice and sizzling cumin lamb 25 minutes later...score! 

- Salt cod fried rice- Good, but not ohmygod this could be the last meal of my life good. I think my dad makes it better. The lap cheong (chinese sausage) was sliced thin and looked a little too pink for my liking--definitely not authentic. The flavors were good portion was hearty enough for two, but still I wasn't really impressed.
- Sizzling cumin lamb- Hot DAMN it smelled good, but once I opened the take out box, I realized we were only given ~5 small/medium pieces of lamb, 1/2 of which were full fat that was thrown away. What a waste! The pieces that were eatable were very moist and tender and not very gamey at all, but I really wish they gave more meat in the dish. 2/3 of the box was filled with slightly grilled, almost raw onion. Sadness :(

One plus- they accept credit cards! I'm always so surprised when places in the mission aren't cash only.
author: Stefi C.

description:
***VERY AVERAGE***
Just as some of the others wrote, this is not authentic Chinese nor even close to some of the dish name descriptions.

We had:
Ma Po Tofu - base flavor was flat but they fill it with hot peppers (probably to compensate)

Mongolian Long Beans - fiery hot small portion and nothing Mongolian about this dish (Mongolians don't east spicy hot, nor pork nor long beans, so where they got the name is beyond me)

Salt Cod Fried Rice - decent flavor but a bit skimmpy on salt cod and the Chinese sausage

Delivery three blocks away took 45 minutes.

Definitely can't say this is the "best" nor "among the best", so suffice to say it's average....very average.
author: Flynt I.

description: san francisco mission...short wait weekday...tables full throughout evening...menu items changing...finding a tsingtao to start...cold and refreshing...chicken wings first...enormous platter of dried red chili peppers...buried within the seven wings...crispy, peppery and mild chili numbing...good wings and not as spicy as expected...a tiger salad next...quad of large spring roll wrapped salad...good and fresh...salt cod fried rice the favorite...non-fishy goodness...excellent fried rice creation...the spicy veal shank with much needed extra white rice...pricier choice, but quite meaty and large...loaded in red starchy saucing, but extra spicy warning...tears and sweat trickling down...soft and crispy veal drowning in a pool of sweet and spicy death sauce....finding some comfort in beef cheek...tender and braised beef chunks...quite large and meaty, but good...non-spicy!....but, finding a second death in the evil string beans...too salty, too spicy...raising white flag...
author: Hen A.

description: We have a lot terrible restaurants in the city but this has to be in the top 3. These service was sub-par and it was very humor-less.The food was as pompus as food goes and the place was so dark you can't hardly see each other. We had the pork belly as an appetizer and the veal rib and pork jaw for entrees. Well guess what, you're going to be getting a blob of fat and a snide attitude on the side., they didn't replace my fork that had fallen, additionally, they forgot my friends beer and overall this is a place where nobody cares and gets customers because they're in a popular neighborhood.
author: Franco L.

description: Horrible.  Ma po dofu was mouth full of poopoo.
author: Doug N.

description:
HORRIBLE!  
I was at a loss for words after trying trying this food.. oh ya one word did come to mind.. Disgusting!  I couldn't believe how bad the food was. This place is obviously very overrated. Nothing tasted above average or even that good. 
The Broccoli Beef Cheek & the Mongolian long beans were the only two things that were edible but not really great by any means.

Broccoli Beef Cheek- beef was tender, the broccoli was ok. The fact that the beef was tender was the only saving grace for this dish & the only thing that was good about the entire meal.
Mongolian Long Beans- way too greasy, the garlic barely saved this dish to give it some flavor but still wasn't great.
Thrice Cooked Bacon- BAD! fake bacon was gross, this dish was 3/4 onions, besides the salt from the bacon, the flavors in it sucked. I basically paid $11 for a pile of onions. Don't order it.

I am still in shock that this food was so bad. Totally disappointing.
Don't waste your money here, go elsewhere. You've been warned.
Believe it!
author: San X.

description: Maybe it was an off night. Maybe the dude smoking a cig in the back of the kitchen wasn't a chef. Maybe the beer I was given from the ironically labeled "Moldy Fridge" was intentionally lukewarm. Maybe the Pastrami in my Kung Pao dish was supposed to be sparse and the size of bacon bits. Maybe the noodles were supposed to be undeniably cheap and bland tasting. Maybe the Salted-Cod Fried Rice was supposed to be a microwaved heap of old, over-salted rice made damp with fish sauce. Maybe the Tea-smoked Eel was supposed to taste like someone had accidentally spilled a Teavana sample on a salty roll. Maybe it's all genius and I'm too much of a plebeian to ever understand. Or maybe it's all just a sociological experiment attempting to find the perfect equilibrium between "the emperors' new clothes" and shitty food in one of the worlds most affluently pseudo-cultured cities. One of the most laceratingly clueless gustatory experiences I've ever had the displeasure of partaking in. Danny Bowien, you should be thoroughly ashamed.
author: James J.

description:
We tried this place for the first time last night. We were very excited since the restaurant has garnered so much national attention. We ordered delivery at around 9:30 pm, but it was 11 when the food arrived. The delivery guy was nice, but he did not apologize for the long wait.

We ordered the following:
- Thrice cooked bacon
- Smoked beef brisket soup
- Mapo tofu

Of course, the food was tepid by the time we dug in, so we had to reheat everything. All the dishes were overspiced, too salty, and extremely greasy. Overall, we were disappointed with our experience.
author: Twocents F.

description: It's not your typical Chinese food or Chinese restaurant. The menu is simple and innovative. Nothing traditional. Music is played very loud and not the elevator kind of music either (lots of 80's rock). The outside looks a bit run down but don't let that deter you. Having heard nothing but good things about this place my boyfriend and I decided to have dinner here last Tuesday. We were a little afraid that it may not live up to the hype but after trying the veal ribs, tea smoked eel, salted cod fried rice, and wild pepper leaves we were convinced that you CAN believe the hype! All the items we ordered were delicious. I especially enjoyed the tea smoked eel and wild pepper leaves. The veal ribs can be a bit messy since they are smothered in sauce similar to a sweet and sour sauce. The hour wait in the cold was worth it.  If you are a foodie this is definitely one to add to the list.
author: Eileen B.

description:
After seeing Mission Chinese Food repeatedly appear on the Chronicle's top 100 Bay Area restaurants and 7x7's Big Eat / 100 things to eat before you die, I had to go for a visit.

I'd describe the food as Szechuan food with a twist.  It sounds like something I would like.  Ultimately, the food is average and the twist under delivers or is just way out of left field.

We started with the Mouth Watering Chicken (an aside: the literal translation is Saliva Chicken, so I'm glad they modified the name).  It had the typical spicy and numbing elements to it.  The chicken hearts were all cooked a little differently (one was still bloody in the middle while most were cooked through).  Ok dish.

Next was Chicken Wings with Explosive Peppers (aside number two: explosive is a ridiculous term for food and it just reminds me of explosive ...).  This is a take on "la zi ji" (sorry if my pinyin sucks).  Some Szechuan dishes are some meat deceptively covered in a mound of red peppers.  The dry (non soup) versions typically aren't that spicy and this dish was no different.  The meat in this case was fried chicken wings with a healthy dose of black pepper.  Again, nothing special.  Take away the peppers that are really for show and you're left with black pepper chicken wings.

Our next three dishes were my favorite three dishes of the night.

Broccoli Beef Cheek - The oysters in the dish were a real surprise as I clearly didn't read the menu correctly.  Every component of the dish was really tasty (Chinese broccoli, beef cheek, oyster) but the oysters still seemed really random.

Pork Belly - Crispy skin and super fatty.  Really good with spicy marinated pineapples.  I devoured my portion, but my friends had mixed reviews.

Smoked Beef Brisket Beef Noodles - Delivers on both beefy and smoky.  Maybe a little too smoky, but still good.

The last dish arrived late.  We had pretty much finished off the other dishes by the time it arrived, but it would be worth it, right?  The salt cod fried rice sounded tasty and was featured by 7x7.  I've had the dish more times than I can count, but never one that was featured by a magazine and never one with Chinese sausage, so I was definitely excited.  Well, one bite in and I could tell that I was never coming back to this restaurant.  I looked at my friends' faces and they all showed the "really?" expression.  The fried rice was relatively flavorless and pretty much every other salted fish fried rice I've ever eaten has been better.  Maybe this was the healthy version (less oil, less salt)?

All in all, I'd give the food 2.5 stars.  The swing to two stars comes from the following:
- This place is pretty much always busy.  That means a line to get in and everyone is packed in like sardines.
- Our table had spatterings of rice from the previous diners.  There was a baby at the table and a small bowl's worth of fried rice on the ground where he had been sitting.  Can't say I blame the baby.  When we left, the hostess took about 5 seconds and 3 wipes of the table to "clean" it.
- It's very loud in the restaurant with the amount of people and music playing.  The dim lighting also makes it hard to see things, but that could be a good thing.  Some things we don't want to see.
- We had to remind the wait staff of our last dish and it took a while for it to come out.  That makes us wonder if it ever got put in in the first place.
- Bloody chicken heart.  I thought that was normal until everyone else showed me the insides of theirs.  Luckily, I didn't get sick.
author: Winston L.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying this place, but when I finally got to eat here it was underwhelming. It makes me sad to say that I really do think this place is overhyped. :(

We got here a little after 1:30PM on Sunday afternoon. It usually opens at 11:30AM on Sundays, but it was just our luck that they had a private event earlier that day and they were just opening as we got there. Because we got there as they were opening, we were able to get seated right away. There was a good number of people waiting outside, though, so the restaurant filled up pretty quickly.

My group wasn't very hungry, so we just got the Szechuan Pickles, Salt Cod Fried Rice, and Thrice Cooked Bacon.
- For you Koreans, the Szechuan Pickles were just like mool kimchi (water kimchi), except also with carrots, cilantro, and peanuts. A refreshing and tangy side to have, but not a necessity. If you like pickled things, I would give it a go since it's not that expensive.
- The Salt Cod Fried Rice was NOTHING special. First of all, there was practically no cod in there. You wouldn't even be able to tell that it was a cod fried rice unless someone told you. I didn't get any pieces of cod until my third serving from the big plate, and even that piece was tiny. In addition, the fried rice tasted just like any other fried rice from any other Chinese restaurant. I cannot believe this is on the 7x7 Big Eat list because it is completely undeserving. 
- The Thrice Cooked Bacon was pretty good. I liked having the rice cakes in there. I thought it was just the right amount of spicy, but it was spicier than my friends would have liked, so beware if you're not a huge fan of spicy food.

Definitely not bad Chinese food, but really not that special and undeserving of all the recognition it's gotten.
author: Janet P.

description: I LOVE this place. Spicy Salty Fatty goodness with beer. Yum. Must try more of the menu.
author: Cat R.

description:
as a friend of the owners son (sorry bud, but..), this place isn't really chinese food at all. it's along the lines of PF Changs, or worse.

i came here on a rainy night, seats were available and we received quick and friendly service. the decor's alright. a dragon hangs above with some framed pictures on the wall. dim litted, which is confusing to as if it the place is suppose to be intimate or something. 

we ordered 3 or so sides but i only remember 2, the thrice cooked bacon and the ma po tofu. the so called thrice cooked bacon lacked bacon and was extremely salty, (like eating spoonfuls of salt) after a few bites we gave up. the ma po tofu was pretty good though. soft tofu, spicy as it should be, but for someone who doesn't normally eat spicy foods it tasted extremely hot, had to box the rest. the best items were the white rice and water, the only things that didnt pack salt in each bite.
author: Vince L.

description:
Welcome to DELIVERY HELL.  Let me take you on a journey of the night my friend and I decided to get some good hearty food after a long long looooooooooong day of studying.  After studying for hours on end I thought a good way to end the day was to get some delicious food in our tummies and I was craving Chinese.  My friend heard great things about Mission Chinese Food and usually is very good about choosing places to eat so we were pretty excited to order our food.

To start off, we waited forever for the food to come (way longer than they originally told me and I had to call multiple times for status updates).  I think it was about an HOUR longer than what they had originally told us.  I was REALLY hungry but at the same time I was trying to keep my spirits up and did not let the extra long wait put a damper on dinner. 

After the food finally arrived, I was super hungry.  You know when you are super hungry you could eat just about anything and it tastes amazing?  Well keep that in mind when I tell you that the food was REALLY REALLY sub-par.  The first disappointment was that the food looked nothing like the photos.  I got the cod fried rice and it was pretty much plain fried rice.  There was NO FISH.  Maybe I am really clueless and don't know what cod fried rice is but what it sounds like to me is fried rice with pieces of cod (a fish) in it.  When I looked at photos before ordering, my belief was confirmed by the photos that look like they have pieces of some sort of white meat.  For some reason there was none of this present in the actual "cod fried rice" that was delivered to me.  When I called to let the restaurant know, they pretty much told me I was straight trippin' and the fish was melted in and I have no idea what I am talking about.  That was extremely irritating to me.  The pork belly was sooo dry.  It's pork belly, how the hell do you mess that up?  I don't know.  The other thing I ordered was the uni egg custard which tasted like a piece of uni with some sort of salty half-melted egg jello/pudding hybrid.  But I will take responsibility for that last dish because I should have thought twice before ordering uni for delivery but what can I say? I was craving some good food, i LOVE uni, and I was hoping for the best.  My friend got some sort of unagi thing which I think he thought were good but left this really bad taste in my mouth. 

Oh and to top it off it was not a lot of food for the amount of money spent.  What a rip. 

After eating this food, I wanted to CRY.  (Note: I didn't actually cry.) To sum it up, my experience was HORRIBLE.  I hate to be so mean but I really want to warn everybody out there to help even one person prevent this type of situation.  If you are craving Chinese, go to R&G Lounge instead.  I should have done that instead of try this place but now I know better and life is about making mistakes and learning so they can have one star for teaching me a lesson.
author: Amber L.

description:
Given all the press and the discussions about whether Mission Chinese should be judged by the standards of "good" as in "good" or "good" as in "authentic" -- I don't really care. It never seemed as if the guys running the place were driving for authenticity. They seemed more akin to David Chang, though in my opinion, they're not remotely near the vicinity of David Chang's ass in either creativity, taste, quality or execution.

Take this with the following grain of salt: I ate their delivery food and personally I think their delivery policy is fairly generous. 

My other and I tasted the ma-po tofu, the cumin lamb, and the hainan chicken.  Delivery came with a takeout container of rice. Nothing blew our minds. Portions-wise, the ma-po was the largest. Hainan came in the same small takeout box size as the side of rice. Cumin lamb was pretty paltry, given to us as a not remotely meaty "shank".

As a person of Chinese descent, I don't have high expectations for Chinese food in the bay area. In terms of flavors, the cumin lamb was pretty spot on, but then again, in that dish, the dominant flavor is cumin - so it's not that difficult. What I hated most about this dish was how it was served. The best and I suppose, the most "authentic" way I've had this dish is with thin slices of lamp like what you could find for hotpot. I've also had this with a huge meat shank of lamb, more like a leg of lamb. What Mission Chinese Food gave us was ... not particularly edible. The lamb was stringy and particularly gamy. There wasn't a lot of meat. There were however plentiful chunks of lamb fat layered with skin and meat. I don't particularly enjoy lamb fat.  It doesn't have the same quality as beef or pork fat. In this dish, it had solidified in a particularly grainy and not tasty way. You basically were picking stringy bits of meat off the bone and trying to avoid the nasty bits of fat. Not very enjoyable 

Ma-po tofu was really meh. They flavored with bay leaves which was fairly novel. My boy nods in agreement. It didn't add anything to this dish. I suppose it's "spicy." It wasn't for my guy, but he's half korean. It was slightly spicy for me, but not unbearably so. I'd say it's about a 5 on a scale of 1-10.  The lack of flavor though... ugh. 

Hainan was still more meh. Rice was chicken flavored. Peanuts were a nice textural touch. Part of eating Hainan Chicken rice is in the presentation. We weren't served chicken separately. It only came to us as slightly shredded and mixed into the rice. Definitely atypical. I feel a little jipped about the lack of chicken to be honest. Although it is "authentic" to include a quarter of a chicken with the rice, we definitely did not have even 1/5 worth of chicken shredded into our rice. 

I know my experience is from delivery food, but really? Best new restaurant??? from Alan Richman and BA? ... idk man. As far as I can taste, there is nothing brilliant going on here, either "good" or "authentic".  Simply more bay area mediocrity. I'd still head to LA for better versions of anything on their menu. CHEAPER too.
author: Andrea L.

description: The atmosphere was fun. Lots of foodies of all shapes and sizes. The menu was unique- a bit too unique for my taste. Mostly, cuts of meat that you don't like to think about. The place was packed and I felt like a total wimp, when I ask for the non-spicy version of my food. The waitress was very accommodating. I don't know that  I would run back here again.
author: David S.

description: Easily among the worst three meals I've ever had anywhere on Earth in my lifetime so far. We tried four different dishes and each one seemed to try to out-do the other in terms of grotesque textures, and unpleasantly bizare flavor combinations. As others have said: over-hyped, over-salted, over-priced, and over-hipstered.
author: Lotion M.

description: Best place to eat when anticipating the apocalypse (order the veal [it is really fatty, but order it anyway]).
author: David C.

description: I've been here twice, and always enjoyed the interesting take on chinese cuisine. Yeah, its in the rundown mission district, in a rundown asian restaurant. You will probably have to wait for an hour to get a table at night, but you are definitely in for some interesting flavors. Kung Pao Pastrami? Delicious!
author: Ojas V.

description:
There were two things I liked about the restaurant, our first dish chinese pickles, and our server, who was very efficient and friendly.  The rest was downhill. I spent the rest of the meal wondering why the NYT would rave about this food and so many people would wait so long to eat here. Being someone who travels to China at least 8 times per year and eats in many different regions, it was nice to know that this restaurant was using spices used outside of Canton, where 99.9% of all SF restaurants get their inspiration, regardless of how they categorize themselves. However, i could not help but get the feeling that the dishes at Mission Chinese were nothing more than inadequate attempts  to reproduce something like a Sichuan or Yunnan flavor, never quite getting the right spice/flavor balance and resulting in an unpleasant dish. Our pork belly was 100% fat and zero meat, and being deep fried to boot made it hard to stomach.  Again, the original Hunan dish, which provides fatty MEAT delivers a nice balance which Mission fails to do. Our dumplings were dry inside, and some were already broken when they reached us- this would be a travesty in China to serve broken dumplings, as the seal preserves the flavor and juiciness. 

Maybe I am missing something?
author: Brian B.

description:
FOOD: 4 stars.  Porridge, salt and pepper shrimp, all good and so much more to explore on this menu.  Vibrant, fresh flavors.
