DECOR: 5 stars.  Dragon, check.  Christmas lights, check.  Adventure through magical kitchen to restroom, check.

HIPSTRESS WAITRESS:  negative 40,000 stars.  This chick was so bad it was actually funny.  Short dark hair, tattoo involving a naked man with a small dinkus.  Sat us with a frown, maintained frown for entire meal, nonchalantly threw menus on table, never brought ordered tea, seemed pained that we even ordered tea, appeared pained to respond to any question, every answer to a question was a clipped one word response. 

All the rest of the staff at this place was great, so I will not let hipstress waitress drag the review down.  But if you happen to be reading this, Hipstress Waitress, please be nice or friendly.  Your customers deserve more.
author: Jesse H.

description: So the first thing you should know about Mission Chinese is that they do not serve chinese food there. This is NOT a chinese restaurant, just in case you thought it was. Confused? Yeah, me too. What Mission Chinese does serve is closer to asian fusion (I know, I hate that term too and it pains me to even type the words, but there are few other ways to describe it); whimsical plays on common chinese-american dishes. Like for instance the broccoli beef brisket, this dish is like easting pot roast at your grandma's house...if your grandma dumped fried green beans and salty msg gravy over the top of her pot roast..."You spilled your kung pao in my pastrami!"...seriously, talk about two great tastes that don't go great together. And whatever you do DO NOT order the spicy chicken wings. Seriously, don't say I didn't warn you about this. Our server said the wings were a must-try, and that they weren't too hot and really just made your mouth tingle. Well she was right about that part because my whole face was tingling, and not in a good way. I love hot/spicy foods but these wings have an indescribable taste and sensation, sort of like they've been soaked in peroxide, and they're borderline inedible. I will admit that I did like the combination fried rice, and if I were ever to return I would order it again. However I will probably not return because the food is just too bizarre and it is also waaay too expensive, especially considering the place is a dump. I love a good hole-in-the-wall dive as much as the next guy, but not at these prices. I guess I like the idea of this place, but the execution of combining chinese dishes like kung pao and fried rice with traditionally western foods like lamb and pastrami just turns out to be downright weird. You'll leave wishing that you had skipped the long wait to eat here and just picked up a box of greasy chow fun from your local chinese take out joint instead.
author: Benny A.

description: As far as the visuals and vibe, you couldn't get any more communal and kitsch. If "Welcome to the Johnsons" in the lower east side of Manhattan opened a Chinese food restaurant this would be it. Downside is the food is very very spicy, almost unedible to my dining  partner and just not very good. It's over salted and over spiced. They serve a watermelon beer which is interesting and very refreshing, this sorta helped to alleviate the burn. If you want hip and you don't give a sh** about how the food taste this is the place for you. Get drunk and eat food that will tear a hole in your ass. Have a blast!
author: Gene W.

description: Hmmmm...their menu changed, and not really for the better. Though there is still an excellent assortment of flavors. Avoid the short ribs - though they're not bad, they're not infused with the same kind of powerful spices that adorn the rest of MCF's rotating menu.
author: Zachary S.

description: Damn good place. We had the Kung Pao pastrami, the salt cod fried rice, the explosive chicken wings and the lamb numbing face (I think that's what it was called). Service was totally prompt and getting there at 6 pm on a Friday night meant getting seated right away. Whimsical decor and ghost of Anthony Bourdain make this place a total destination.
author: Allison L.

description: I have a few friends who continuously rave on and on about how fantastic Mission Chinese Food is.  I seriously don't get it.  I've ordered take out from here twice and the food was simply inedible.  Both times there were bell peppers in dishes when I was specifically told upon ordering that they did not contain bell peppers.  I'm allergic to bell peppers, so that meant I couldn't even go near half the food ordered.  As for the dishes I could attempt to eat, they were absolutely disgusting.  Probably the worst flavor combos I've EVER encountered.  It's like someone took every bizarre spice available and dumped it in a frying pan with huge globs of fat and subpar meat and then added a dump truck full of salt to finish it off.  Yuck.
author: Gianna S.

description:
100% overrated. 100% disappointment.

I have very high standards for Chinese food because of my background. This place came recommended by my coworkers so I decided to give it a try. The restaurant was not unsanitary but I don't think it's all that sanitary either because it was too dim to even see anything during a bright Sunday lunch time. I ordered the beef brisket noodle soup and it was such a disaster - too salty, too much soy sauce, too much basil, very little beef brisket, and the thick noodle was simply odd because it was still rolled up when I first picked it up with chopsticks from the bowl. I don't know if the noodle is supposed to be a feature because it is definitely NOT conventional Chinese cooking. I am all for cooking creativity, but this dish is just sub par in terms of taste and presentation (black bowl of soup is just not pleasant on the eyes).

I also glanced at the other items on the menu and there was just nothing that caught my eyes. 

Don't give this place too much hope before you go in so that you won't be as disappointed as I was.
author: J P.

description:
Disgusting.  These guys have no idea.  Absolutely none.

Take a look around -- if you're Asian, you're probably the only one.  This is Chinese food for white people who don't know any better.
author: P B.

description: I would give this place 3.5.  Some dishes are great and some are so so.  Love the spicy string beans, the rice cakes and ma po tofu.  It's spicy so you would have to love spicy food to like it.  A lot of the other entrees are just okay.  Have been back twice but would only come back if there is no wait, i.e. at 5:30 or lunch.  If you have to wait more than 30 min. I don't think it would be worth it.
author: Anthony N.

description:
I noticed some people wondering about the delivery radius of this place -- I live near Clay and Polk and ordered delivery no problem, if that helps. 
As far as the delivery service goes, I found it to be prompt and the driver courteous, so no issues there.

As for the food, I wish I could love this place. I love Chinese food and I love spicy food, and in a city with relatively few great Chinese options, I'm bound to be a sucker for a cheap Chinese restaurant with a coherent mission statement, so to speak -- cheap Szechuan cuisine with foodie sensibilities. Yay. 

Unfortunately, the chef is ridiculously heavy-handed with the peppers and spices. While there's really no limit to my spice tolerance, I'm over that phase where I essentially downed hot sauce like someone was daring me to do it. I want to taste my food, not the chili pepper. When too much chili is used, it imparts an unpleasant chemical flavor to the dish. This flavor afflicted half the food I ordered (the eggplant and the bacon). The other seasonings were both sloppily administered and overused, leaving me with several mouth-fulls tasting only of of cumin or curry. 

That said, the food showed potential (the chunks of pork belly and noodles were really, really tasty), and Mission Chinese is an unusual restaurant, so I will definitely order again and hope the food improves.
author: Adam M.

description: Loved the food, especially if you're craving comfort. Lots to look at - whether a Chinese dragon decorating the ceiling above, or the tattooed hipsters serving spring rolls with fresh mint and saucy heat, cod fried rice and pork bellies washed down with a  cold refreshing coke. Hangover sold separately.
author: Dean B.

description: Well, this may be Szechuan Chinese fare by a talented Korean chef via Oklahoma. Fresh and very interesting yummy fare that I cannot really call Chinese but served by a friendly efficient caring staff in a rather fun funky hipster worn out old Chinese restaurant space. Will return again and again.
author: Rad M.

description:
I waited for 45 minutes in the rain - and it  was totally worth it.

Thrice cooked bacon is insanely good.  The Ma Po Tofu hurts so good, very spicy.  I'm not much of a porridge fan, but it's delicious, and a great balance to all of the spicey dishes.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Can not believe that there is such buzz about this restaurant. This is a disappointment on so many levels. The interior is tacky. The food is way too salty.

The wings were dry and the chilies were a waste on the top for presentation. I just hope they reuse them. 

The brisket sandwich on white bread looked like a mess on the plate. 

I would not go back or recommend it.
author: glorianne g.

description:
Over-rated hipster Chinese Food.

After reading about this place in a national magazine, I was really looking forward to trying this place.  I LOVE Chinese food, really all types of Asian food, so I was very excited to see what the fuss was all about.  Arrived at 6:15 on a Monday night.  Place was almost full.  Good sign.  Snagged the last two seats at the the big communal table. By 6:30 there was a crowd outside waiting to get in.  Really good sign.  Also, there was a guy making homemade noodles right up front.  REALLY good sign.

When I order Chinese, I like to get a mixture of salty, spicy, sweet and tangy dishes.  I'm also a big fan of fish/prawns and chicken.  I was surprised to see that there was maybe one cold chicken dish (spicy) and one chicken wing appetizer (seriously spicy).  The only seafood I could see was a hot mussels dish which I have to be in the mood for. Since the menu was tilted towards pork and lamb dishes, We decided to try the char siu pork belly which had been recommended, but didn't see the duck or the dumplings which had also been recommended.  We also ordered the mustard greens, the pastrami and the salt cod fried rice.  The fried rice came first.  It was really good.  Loved the fresh ginger that was sprinkled throughout it.  Nice touch.  However, our next dish took at least 10 min to come out so we didn't get to enjoy the rice with anything.  When the char siu pork finally came, I was disappointed at the skimpy smear of hoisin sauce that came with it.  I'm not sure that you could really call it char siu to be honest.  I liked the soy-cured egg and the noodles that were served with it, but that salty pork needed to be better balanced with some sweetness.  I could really only eat one piece of it.  After reminding the waitress that we'd ordered mustard greens, they finally brought them along with the pastrami (which we'd ordered after the fried rice).  Both dishes were incredibly salty.  I don't mind salt, but wow!  It was just too much.  The pastrami was also studded with nearly raw celery which was kind of pointless.  Paired with another, less salty spicy dish it would've been OK, but there really wasn't a lot of diversity when it came to the dishes.  Everything on the menu was either salty and/or spicy.  Perhaps taken on their own, the dishes were OK, but together, not good.  

The service was also really spotty.  Anyway, the next time I want Chinese, I'll stick to Chinatown.  I can't imagine how I would've felt if I'd waited for 45 minutes to get in here.
author: Tanya F.

description: The staff was great and the food came out pretty quickly, but the food itself was sub par. Basically, everything is covered in onions. What sauce is that? Is this chicken? Who knows? It just all tastes like onions. Cheap prices, but I'd gladly pay more to at least be able to distinguish the dishes from each other. While we were waiting for our table (which is inevitable, there is ALWAYS a wait), one of the dudes who worked there brought us out some little sandwiches to munch on, so that was nice. It's definitely food for the skinny-jeaned, Ray-Banned, Nebraska-bred crowd that doesn't know any better though. Stick with the Sunset and Chinatown for the real deal.
author: Nick G.

description: Salty cod fried rice + pork belly + Kung pao pastrami = yum yum yummiest!
author: Jello B.

description: This place is overrated.  Yes, they got write ups on GQ and other magazine.  I expect more than just okay.  It's just one of the things I learned that never go where magazines writes had been because they always disappoints.
author: GF S.

description:
We had the Mongolian Long Beans but not too sure how they tasted as they were so spicy it burnt the taste buds off my tongue!  Disguising poor food with spice is a one trick pony!

Not enough veggie options either.

Take your money elsewhere!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Update (1 night after first review)

Oh dear. I ordered 4 batches of the duck rice last night (I was hooked!) and it wasn't the same. They over-did the vinegar and no ginger this time. Plus the seasoning tasted really different from the night before. Waaah. Bummer.

:-( 


--------------------------

Duck Rice (5 stars!!)

everything else i had was over-salted, but still pretty good.
author: Sanaz E.

description:
OK, so i love good Chinese Taiwanese food, and am quite the critic having lived in that part of the world for long enough to gain thirty pounds and learn the language.

 I know good chinese food is extra flavorful and often times spicy, which is delicious, but when the spice and salt overwhelm the flavor of everything, What's the flavor??  The taste of the meat that I so wanted to taste was shrouded in salt and heat. 

The menu items all sounded so interesting, we ordered 4 things:

Egg Custard/Sea Urchin/Salmon roe - Unique flavors, again very salty, kind of an experiment of a dish I'd say, something I'm glad I tried but have no desire to have it again.

Mussels/Basil,Pig cheek - the pig cheek was tasty, and so were the mussels, the whole combination was a good idea, but way to salty

Lamb face with belted noodles - I had high hopes for this one, since I love lamb, and it sounded interesting but it totally disappointed, couldn't taste the lamb for the salt/heat, and the noodles are so doughy, they don't seem cooked.

Oxtail porridge- Probably the mildest of all we ordered, it had decent flavor, still too salty though, the crab was unnoticeable , oxtail and egg were good.

I was wondering if we had just ordered the wrong things, all of the too salty things on the menu maybe.

I have a sneaking suspicion that they use MSG  considering the wicked headache me and my friend got while eating, and the almost "too flavorful" trend in all of the dishes I tried.

Do you know how taboo that is? Most Asian restaurants these days boast NO MSG on their menus, that claim is nowhere on their menu.

Come on Mission Chinese Food, tell us  DO YOU USE MSG? step into the light!!
author: Molly M.

description:
how dare they call themselves Chinese food....gosh....guess only American ppl will like their food....Those are not authentic Chinese food!!!

those mapo tofu, spicy chicken wings....all you can taste is spicy, no any other flavor....

will never go to that place any more.
author: Yelp Z.

description:
I've been looking forward to going to Mission Chinese for such a long time. I finally went last night and wished I had gone a few years ago - or not at all. My husband and I found the food to be disappointing (actually awful). It wasn't creative or innovative - or unique in any way. Most dishes were overly salted, and so spicy & greasy that it masked any flavor that might have been.   I guess our expectations were too high based on past reviews.  We had the Tiger Salad - fresh kale type greens wrapped in a soggy noodle doused in soy and vinegar. I added the peanuts to give it some help. The cumin lamb ribs had a blackened crust that was dry & tasted like bark (not the tasty bark of long roasted beef), no flavor of cumin, and the interior was all fat - we casted them aside. The trice cooked bacon and rice cakes were soggy, all stuck together and was nothing like the description on the menu - we pushed that dish aside too. What was good was the spicy beef chow mein - wished we had two orders of it and called it a day. I'm sure I sound like I'm overly harsh but when a restaurant and chef receives such high accolades they should try to live up to them. We spent a fair amount of money to try different dishes that our server recommended as "top dishes".  Maybe we missed some of the good ones.
 To be fair, from the line to get in, people still are willing to wait to dine at Mission Chinese - so there must be something I'm missing. There is a fun crowd and very nice people working there.
author: Chris M.

description:
Bon Appetit Magazine just named this restaurant the 9th best restaurant in America so I had to go and try it. Getting there was an adventure all in itself since we rode the 14-Mission bus from FiDi and getting off on 16th and Mission was like being in East LA. The exterior of the restaurant looks like any run down Chinese restaurant and the inside was not to be in awe of too. The decoration style is on a shoe string budget or hand me down Chinese castoffs but the only thing Americanized was the punk rock and alternative music playing on the speakers. We ordered the very tasty and mild spicy yet mouth-watering selection of Mongolian Long Bean , Char Siu Pig Ear Terrine, and the Chongqing Chicken Wings which comes to you steaming hot buried under bright red dried fried red thai chili peppers.  Your eyes burns and waters in first sight. I highly recommend you try this and maybe take a picture to show your friends but remember to drink plenty of water or bring milk with you. You will need it! 

It will take a lot more visit from me to try the other selections. Until next time MCSF.
author: Patricia P.

description: I had heard such great things about this place and admittedly the first time I ate here was really good. I ordered salad rolls and the Thrice Cooked Bacon, no bacon. Yum! The second time, however, I ordered take-out and my dish the Thrice Cooked Bacon sans bacon was more onions than anything else. And I think I may have gotten a slight case of food poisoning because three hours later I was lying in bed suffering from a horrible stomach ache. I'm disappointed because I really wanted to love this place. It's so close to my home. Since my bad experience I've heard tales of bugs in the food and other sketchy happenings. Too bad.
author: K H.

description: I love to try new food and resturants. I had my order delivered, and they were very quick. This Chinese was not great. I really tired to see what the hype was about in the New York Times article. It felt like they were trying to hard, and missed on the flavors.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Wow. What an explosion of flavors. Service is outstanding and the wait horrendous but worth it. Kung Pao Pastrami is a "MUST HAVE", the thrice cooked pork was delicious. Tiki Pork Belly is melt in your mouth magic. The squid ink noodles were marvelous. I will skip the ribs and the cod fried rice. Amazing experience.
author: Kris J.

description: I had heard the hype for some time and was very VERY excited to try this place. Sadly hype rarely if ever lives up to the expectations. This was the case for Mission Chinese food.  The service was underwhelming to say the least. I know its difficult to talk about the new Liars record AND get me a drink but I am sure you can do it if you put your mind to it.  But service you can get over if the food is AMAZING. Sadly not the case. We tried a few items. The Pork Belly was good but overcooked.  Everything was  FINE but nothing stood out. Next time I go to the Mission I am going to stick to great tacos.
author: douglas B.

description: The experience was fairly fun. I went with several colleagues around 6pm in order to beat the lines, but we still had to wait, but not too long... like about 15 minutes. When our waitress came, I asked what she recommended because my group seemed unsure of what to select as it was our first time there. She was super helpful and had great descriptions that were on point. We decided to order everything she recommended and we were pleasantly surprised with everything. The three stars is because the food and service was good, but it is still kinda like quick (not fast food) chinese food.  It's not an upscale place, but fun for a group that's not looking to splurge on fancy meal. Four stars would be for good food and service and upscale ambiance.
author: gary a.

description:
Ordered something with eggplant and a couple duck things. They were all very tasty but something here gave me severe gastrointestinal distress- and I'm sure it was this place because the same thing happened again after I had some leftovers for breakfast in the morning. I don't think it was food poisoning, but something definitely did not agree with me. Maybe it was the duck? Or the fact that the food just seemed very heavy and rich? 
Anyway, maybe I'll give it another try some time but only after the memory of stomach pain fades.
author: Rika Y.

description: I'll give this place one more try in the future, but on my first go I have to say that anyone who gives this place 4-5 stars is seriously trippin'. Chinese food is all about balance and harmony, and Mission Chinese's M.O. seems to be simply to dump as much spice as possible into each dish. Im a huge fan of spicy food, but the hot dishes here are hot beyond pleasurable and bound to give you massive heartburn. And cut down on the damn cumin, people! I thought this was Mission Chinese, not Mission Indian!
author: Calvin L.

description:
I'm not really a connoisseur of Chinese food, but every now and again I like to try something new. We had the Tiger Salad, which was a salad with a gingery dressing wrapped up in a noodle-like wrapper, pretty basic, but tasty. By far the healthiest item we tried. The Kung Pao Pastrami had the girl next to me and Christiaan gasping for air, but while it was spicy, it was not unbearably so. The Pastrami was tasty but of course very fatty (one bite I had was just a pure lump of fat). This was an incredibly greasy and salty dish, as were the Green Beans. I don't know if it was MSG or just too much salt, but the dishes were just realllly salty and oily. Did I mention salty and oily? Ironically, this is how I imagined Wo Hing General Store's food would taste. If you are in the mood for spicy, greasy, salty food, that may or may not be authentic, go to Mission Chinese. I suspect it might make good hangover food. On the other hand, it could give you a hangover. 

One thing that is kind of fun is the communal tables and the giant Chinese dragon on the ceiling. We had a girl come and try to eat off our plates, which was good for a laugh.
author: Darcy V.

description: Amazing! Put our name on this list and went for a drink around the corner. We were seated immediately after we came back. The cilantro stood out in several of the dishes and everything was extremely flavorful. They have a great variety of meats to satisfy the vegan, vegetarians, and red meat lovers in your group. Hot and cold dishes are offered and we had a great combo of both. You must try!!!
author: Lori B.

description: 6:17pm ordered delivery.  7:00pm food delivered--not bad timing. 7:03 realized Hainam Chicken Rice dish ordered is missing & called restaurant--no apology just said it would be delivered soon.  8:05 no delivery, so called restaurant & he said it would arrive soon.  8:48pm still no delivery & called to demand refund--no apology and asked "so what do you want me to do?".   An apology and some customer service would be a good start!  I asked for a refund since we ate the 2 dishes we did get.  She said they would deliver the money.  9:17pm finally got my $7.00 refund for the dish.  This service totally sucked.  While the 2 dishes we did get were tasty, I won't patronize this crappy place again due to their indifferent service toward customers.
author: Julia H.

description: Super long wait (hour plus) on Saturday night for food that really wasn't anything special. I don't see what the fuss is about, and definitely not worth any sort of wait. Not good enough to take leftovers home.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Giving MCF a rating is tricky, but I'll go with the 4 since I can't do the 3.5 and because it was good enough to warrant a second return in a month (coming from the East Bay).

The little place is tucked under a yellow awning with a different restaurant name on it. The inside is nothing special, just another Chinese restaurant with an awesome floating dragon on the ceiling. Both times I've been the lights were off too - weird. Anyways, I will always chuckle a little to myself when I'm here. The ambiance is just so confusing. The decor and the food are so authentic, yet the ambiance is not like any other Chinese restaurant I've been to (and I'm Chinese). The servers are all young and hip, very "Mission District" and the music is stuff I will hear on Live 105. I always have to ask myself, "Where am I?"

But then the yummy food comes out, and I settle down a bit. The salt cod fried rice, as noted, is delicious - probably my fav. on the menu and will be a go-to from here on out. My second favorite is the shanghainese chow mein - it's so traditional it reminds me of my grandma/mom's cooking (they're from Shanghai). Next would be the kung pao pastrami - a very interesting fusion, but it works! Tied for last (out of the things I've tried) would be the spicy chicken wings and the beef noodle soup. The chicken wings were SOOOOOOO spicy, even my Korean friends couldn't handle it. Lips went numb after one piece. We all concurred that we would never order it again. The noodle soup was too "fusioned" out for us. It tasted so smoky, without any good quality, since it was a soup. And since the noodles weren't actually noodles but were large rolls of cheung fun (like you get at dim sum), it was very hard to eat. It was also lukewarm when it arrived at the table. Sadly, will never be ordering it again.

Overall, love the fried rice and noodles, and since I love so many other things near by, I'm sure I will be back soon enough.
author: Jen L.

description: I don't know where the people with negative comments were eating. Definitely wasn't here! This is one of my most FAVORITE places to eat when I am in San Fran (or NY)-- fantastic food and great staff.  Love all the spicy aroma in the air when you walk in. Had the spicy beans and the soup. Delicious!
author: Dwayne R.

description:
This was an interesting restaurant. The food definitely was more "authentic" than your run of the mill Chinese restaurant, but I am not sure I'll be back again. 

First of all, even though we asked for rice and tea at the beginning of the meal, they forgot the rice and only gave us a small bowl for a table of 8 when we asked again. We had to request our tea to be refilled, I've never been to a Chinese restaurant where they ignored our empty pot of tea for so long. 

The food was merely okay, they didn't have a huge variety, and used peppercorn and salt as a cooking crutch. I wasn't impressed by the portions considering how much it was. 

Between the 8 people, our total came out to $160 including tips and taxes, and half of our party left not entirely full.
author: M L.

description:
How can this place not have a full five stars??! Mission Chinese is the perfect restaurant, everyone's welcome and there absolutely no eying you out or judging you by the clothes or pushy overfriendly waiters. We eat here as soon as the wallet allows us to! We had our wedding dinner here but we've also arrived in 'hanging out at home in comfy clothes' on a Friday night and always felt just as welcome. There's usually a line, but it rarely takes more than ten minutes to get a table. Water is served when seated and without charge (there's sodas, beers and some wine too in addition if one's interested) and the food arrives fast and It is insanely good! 

I'm not a fan of chicken and would never order it at a restaurant, but the Hainam Chicken Rice is really, really good I realized when sneaking a bite! So savory and perfect with the fresh ginger tingle.

We tried the One Pound of Salt & Pepper Shrimps the last time and it's worth it's money (being the second most expensive dish on the menu and that being 12 bucks! The top one is the Sizzling Cumin Lamb for 12.5 but haven't tried that one.) The fennel on top was tasty and perfectly cooked. 

Every time we go we have the Pickles to start with, and every time we say we have to try make these at home! I think they have a spice or two in common with the Tingly Lamb Soup, at least my tongue likes to think so. Crunchy, spicy and fresh!

The Braised Mongolian Beef Cheek and the Lung Shan's Vegan Delight are two other favorites. 

It breaks my heart that the lamb dumplings are gone though, the last time I had them I told my husband I'd eat them as my last meal if I'd get to choose one, they are that tasty! (or were. ;)

If you like tasty food in a relaxed atmosphere, for cheap money and with fast service. You should give it a try!

and oh, I almost forgot, the music, awesome music!! old school beats and guilty pleasure style. love it!
author: emmet g.

description: I would have never walked into this place unless I had been referred by someone. However, word of mouth convinced us, and we tried it, and loved it. It's SPECTACULAR!
author: Sarma A.

description: umm huuummm....this place sure is a MISSION chinese(not so chinese) food! They are trying too hard to make the food taste authentic by adding too much of spices and oil and everything...they think we ASIANS like adding hecka spices and oil?????? never gonna go back here! i rather go to chinatown and eat real authentic CHINESE food! but, the service was excellent and they were quick on their feet. the service was worth 2 stars by itself.
author: Linda T.

description:
Why do people like this place?

Is it because it's in the Mission?

Is it because it's been written up?

Is it because Anthony Myint made a great burger?....because he can't make Chinese food...

Or is it because the hipsters think this place is great without any type of extensive Chinese restaurant experience?

I can name at least 5 Chinese places that are not only cheaper but better.  Ordered the Salt Cod Fried Rice and Pork Belly Greens and found both to be lacking big time.  Off the top of my head, the fried rice chahan at Tanpopo is better than this.  

Greens were bland, and again lacking.  Let's combine the 55 minute delivery time and 40 minute table wait...this is certainly not where you want to be if you want great tasting Chinese food.  

Seriously guys, I absolutely hate it when places don't deserve the rating they have...as of now MCF is 3.5 stars...I think this restaurant deserves no more than 2 stars.  The taste of the dishes was not up to par with other traditional Chinese places, and the wait/hassle of going there pretty much lowers the overall value and opportunity.  

Still waiting for a traditional Chinese place that offers something truly tasty or unique...
author: R. K.

description: Not bad.  we ordered delivery in order to avoid waiting forever for a table and I think we made the right decision.  the food was definitely good, but for what you got i thought it was kind of overpriced.  we shared the brisket noodle soup, the sauteed peas, the rice porridge with shrimp and steak, and the salt cod fried rice.  Everything was definitely good, but i didn't think it was all that special.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I liked this place a lot at first, but a few visits later and I found the food to be bland.

Or as much a tongue-scorching bowl of ma po tofu could be called "bland". I guess it's more like there's no nuance to the food. Load it up with peppercorns, cover it in dried chilies. Serve on excessive bed of onions. Beef cheek, corned beef, and lamb shank end up being practically indistinguishable. Felt like I was eating hot cheetoes - the food is just a spice-deliverance tool for your tastebuds. 

Still, it's only $8-9 for most dishes and has a great vibe to it (look for the beer cans in the dragon's mouth). And hot cheetoes are damn tasty.
author: Victor L.

description: I don't understand why people call this place is a dump because it is not. It's a charming little returant and  the food is amazing!
author: Jan P.

description:
God, i really wanted to like Mission chinese food.  I was in town for the weekend and was super psyched to go; its right down my alley in terms of being a foodie twist on a very traditional type of food.  But....

The decor - i usually don't care about the decor, clean is nice, but i've eaten in many less then clean places and been fine.  MC smells moldy, and i definitely wouldn't walk on the floor without shoes.  The music was good, and the service was simple and efficient.   I just couldn't get over the dank smell.

The food - i love the idea of what they're trying to do, but the execution is far from perfect.  Granted, i tried 2 things.  (the riff on hainan chicken rice, and the beef cheeks and broccoli).  The chicken rice was fairly vinegary, which i didn't mind, but it just wasn't very tasty, and kind of dry.  The beef checks was a hunk of braised beef (i like this.) with chinese broccoli, and some cooked oysters on top.  it was a little runny, and the beef wasn't braised very well.  all in all something that is brilliant as an idea, but when it comes down to taste, was again lacking.

I probably wouldn't go back unless someone else wanted to go and dragged me there, but from my first experience, i was really disappointed
author: Brian C.

description: I know this is a popular place, but I didn't really like it. I love Chinese food, and I've traveled all over China. This just didn't do it for me.
author: Paul O.

description:
finally went here over the weekend...it was definitely good.  it's not necessarily traditional Chinese food, but it's not overly Westernized Chinese food as some reviewers claim as well.  i think some people like to talk smack because it makes them sound like they know food.....these are probably the same people who refer to themselves as "foodies".  if you can't cook a good meal, then shut the hell up....eating good food takes no skill outside of having teef and some money, so there....haha...i'm totally just joking.

anyway, that was a tangent.  i really like the old Chinese restaurant vibe filled with a more Mission crowd (not even sure what that meant), low lighting with x-mas lights, and funky music (can we say, "push it...push it good"?)...it's just kinda different and neat for me, i guess.  the wait is pretty long, and there's always a crowd outside.  if you're starving, just have a bacon-wrapped dog from the vendor that is conveniently situated next to the entrance.

the General Tsao's veal rib is freaking excellent....fatty, with certain parts that are a bit tough, like jerky.  it's not easy to slice up and chew in a sophisticated manner, but the flavor is great, and i like fat....yes, there, i said it, i LIKE FAT.  

the salt cod fried rice is excellent.  it was also good the next day....we experimented and ate half cold and half warm....both good.  

there was this lamb noodle soup that was pretty good.  nice chunks of lamb in there.

the string beans were super spicy....good for some, but not me.  i was sweating....it wasn't a pretty sight....

i thought the servers were super nice.

overall, a cool joint.
author: Miss P.

description: Avoid the cumin lamb. It's 95% fat with almost no actual lamb meat. The dish is so heavily layered in cumin and spice that you can't taste what little lamb there is in the dish. I wasn't too impressed with the other dish that I sampled from here.
author: Richard H.

description: Blech. I didn't like anything here. After two bites my tongue was completely coated with Sichuan peppercorn. This left me with a constant tingling feeling and made everything else have a metallic taste, even my water. The next two bites heaped too much cumin on my poor tongue and made it impossible for me to taste anything after that. The waitress was super nice and we didn't have to wait so that was a plus.
author: Tom E.

description:
Restaurants that put all of their money into their food and don't worry about having high-end architects and graphic designers are near and dear to me. It is hard to find places anymore that will supply you with fine food at a reasonable price. The last time I had that I was in Montreal. MCF brings that bargin to the table. 

I came here with 5 people and we ordered ever item on the MCF menu, no disrespect to Lung Shan. Every single item was tasty, curious, and yes spicy. Luckily they kept us fresh with beer and water. 

I highly recommend eating the roasted peppers that come with the chicken wings mixed in with rice. They are so smoky and delicious. 

Did I mention they are also reasonably priced? We got the bill and were pleasantly surprised.
author: Lamb Shanks S.

description: Really worth the hype-- esp the Mo Po Tofu.  We went pre-Bona Appetit article and you can just walk in, now the line is insane (it's not even a line but a mob in front of this unassuming, old school Chinese restaurant.  Love the food and even the cheesy decor but the long wait leaves something to be desired. I would recommend ordering the food to go so you can enjoy it in the comfort of your own home.
author: Belle M.

description: If you haven't yet heard of this restaurant then listen up. Mission Chinese is a wonderful new restaurant in the Mission (at 19th) and it has been my partner's and my favorite restaurant for about a year now. When we started going after it first open it was due to the referral of one of my partner's coworkers. We got to the restaurant and sat down easily and were of the few patrons in the restaurant.  It is safe to say it is difficult to get in now. I went last week and waited for the better part of an hour to get a table (they don't take reservations). The food is well worth it though and well priced. So if you want to give your taste  buds a roller coaster ride- go to this restaurant. It is great. There are also some bars in the neighborhood you can patron while you wait for your name to be called.
author: Daniel R.

description: I have heard a lot about Mission Chinese so I decided to go check it out with a couple friends. Food was generally good but nothing to extraordinary. This is like Chinese food with a twist (that does not always work).
author: Boris H.

description:
Do not believe the hype. Tonight I had one of the worst meals of my life and it was at Mission Chinese Food.  It took forever to be seated and upon entering I looked around realizing that I had just waited forty minutes to be seated in a dingy looking chinese restaurant; complete with christmas lights and a contrived mix of late nineties hip-hop.  We ordered the seaweed salad, ma po tofu and broccoli beef.  The seaweed salad was merely average, far too many noodles, it was over-dressed and there was far less seaweed than anyone ordering seaweed salad would expect. The ma po tofu was terrible; too viscus and the sichuan was incredibly overpowering. I'm quite comfortable eating spicy food and I'm familiar with the mouth-numbing effect of a sichuan pepper but this was simply unacceptable. There must have been about twenty whole dried peppers tossed into our dish making it nearly impossible to eat.  Ma Po Tofu is known for being a more complex dish, but this left much to be desired. The flavor was underwhelming and dominated by the sichuan and the sauce was too oily, you could actually see puddles of oil in the bowl. The broccoli on the other hand was very good, the beef was braised and the broccoli was crisp, flavors were well-balanced and the cooked oysters were sweet and not rubbery.  

Just as I was beginning to think the place wasn't all that bad a COCKROACH appeared on our table and began making it's way towards me.  In effort to be polite and to not alarm other patrons I got up, stepping back from the table and waited for my waitress to appear. The waitress looked at me completely expressionless, like she didn't know why I would be bothered by a cockroach sitting on our table with our food; she took the napkin from beneath my water glass and crushed and killed the cockroach with her bare hand.  This was disgusting and I feel sick writing about it but the absolute worst part of the entire situation was the complete lack of acknowledgment or effort to apologize on behalf of the establishment.  From that point on my waitress was nowhere to be seen; I assumed she was telling the manager or would come out and offer an apology but nothing.  Between the cheap decor, underwhelming food, horrendous service and grotesque cockroach, I will absolutely not be returning to Mission Chinese.
author: Monica P.

description: I had heard this place was great. It came highly recommended. I don't get it. Did I order the wrong food? I had the broccoli beef. It was awful. Just alot of strong brown sauce over old tough beef. I was too nervous to finish the dish.  I also wanted to try their dumpling.  They ran out. At noon? Did they have an off day? And I didn't understand the decor.  Is tacky "in" now? I was just looking for some good  ol' Chinese food.  This  place is too "modern" Chinese for me.
author: Isabella L.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time I was not blown away. I thought the food was good but too spicy (and I love spicy food like nobody's business). The second time did it for me though.
I went with a buddy and we had the proper warm up - stiff drinks at Blondies and beers on the sidewalk outside the restaurant with some hipsters (seriously, does it get any cooler than drinking beers on a public sidewalk? Only in the Mission). We even warmed the palate with a Mexican hot dog. I do recommend. 
Our wait wasn't horrendous. When we finally got a table, service was quick and efficient. As others have noted this is not a place you bring a first date, the ambience is horrible, but the brave like us go for the food and not the surroundings.
We decided on salt cod fried rice, the bacon dish, salt and pepper wings and some kind of beef short rib dish that I now don't see on their online menu. All were simply sublime.
The salt cod fried rice is amazing, just loaded with flavor. When combined with something like the thrice cooked bacon it really is mind blowing. The fusion of spices and flavor is perfect. 
The wings, covered in red chili peppers, were divine. Perfectly crunchy exterior with a nice combo of salt and pepper, revealed by perfectly tender chicken past the skin. The beef dish was very good but by then we were so full we barely made it through that dish. 
I will definitely be going again. I hope they open into a more decent restaurant somewhere but even if they don't I'll be back. I walked away thinking that was probably the best Chinese food I've had. From a longtime fan of Henry's Hunan that is noteworthy praise from this wannabe critic.
author: Matt H.

description: I'll take Santung any day of the week over Mission Chinese. Sorry. The food wasn't bad. It was worth a wait.
author: Chris G.

description:
I've ordered delivery from these guys twice and have been pleasantly surprised both times!  I have enjoyed the mapo tofu, braised mongolian beef cheek, duck chinto, and duck rice.

It seems like every time I visit their website, the menu is slightly different.  I'm not sure if the menu will ever stabilize or if they plan to always change it.  I appreciate the short but changing menu!
author: Carol L.

description:
The food is great and it's coming from a Chinese person. 

One thing, though, I have to say the neighborhood is not the best. Didn't feel safe parking in the street in the area.
author: Frank L.

description: The food of chef Danny Bowien gets 4 stars alone and while I haven't had the pleasure of sampling the menu after the addition of their new smoker, I can only imagine the results.  You can't go wrong with any of their dishes and $0.75 from each entree is donated to the San Francisco Food Bank!  If you're like me and LOVE spicy dishes, the Ma Po Tofu is the way to go.  There is no getting around it, it's HOT but the flavor is amazing and the dish is perfectly balanced.  Finally, call me crazy but unless you have a Christmas light fetish or an adventuresome spirit that likes braving cramped kitchens to find restrooms, order out (or have it delivered if you're lucky enough to live in the area).
author: Sean H.

description: I love Mission Chinese. It's fun to go to when we have friends in town to give them the SF experience. But we mainly order delivery - the kung pao pastrami is our favorite. Delivery time to the Marina varies - usually 45 minutes to 1 hour. We get it nearly every Sunday night. Enjoy!
author: Megan M.

description:
Such a disappointment. After waiting outside for 25 minutes, my friends and I were so excited to eat this place everyone talks about. 

Ma Po Tofu was horrible. The pork shoulder tasted like bologna. It was too spicy to taste anything else. I had 3 bites.

Pork Belly was room temp...meh, but the only thing we finished.

Westlake Rice Porridge was forgettable.

My friend ordered a Tiger Salad that never appeared at our table.  

As for service? How much time do you have? THE WORST!  Everyone is just too fucking cool. You are a WAITER, relax!

I don't understand why people keep coming back to this place.
author: Melissa P.

description: I've never felt whiter in my life. Everything I ordered was supposed to be the least spicy thing on the menu. And like 3 bites into the Thrice Cooked Bacon i was burnin up. Eek. It didn't help that there was a giant hot pepper sitting in the dish that I put in my mouth because I thought it was a green bean. You know why I thought it was a green bean? Because it was too dark to see anything in there. I mean would it kill them to turn on a light or two? Or is that not hip enough? Do I sound like a crotchety old white woman yet? All I'm saying is, I'm not sure it's worth the hype.
author: Lindsay S.

description: This is my third time here and I guess that was the charm.  We ended up getting the vegetarian thrice cooked bacon, salt cod fried rice, and some spicy chicken wings.  The veggie dish was the best tasting as well as the fried rice.  The fried chicken wings was a little salty but not over salted.  The presentation was crazy on the fried chicken.  Bunch of dried red peppers and it looked like a bunch of insects on the plate.  Really good and it kept with the theme of hole in the wall chinese food restaraunt.
author: ray s.

description: Love it! Such a great alternative to the Chinese food that is available in SF. Super casual vibe, and the dishes have an eccentric twist but are all still super good.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
This place sucks.  We waited over an hour because the place got alot of attention lately.  We ordered 4 dishes but none of them were good.  The dishes had no taste, and the 'spicy' Kung Pao Pastrami was just a few pastrami slices with a bunch of potatoes and chilis thrown on top !

Then we realized why the place is so hyped.  It is overrun with hipster zombies who cannot bear the thought that after waiting for over an hour, they are served food that pretends to be smart and creative,  but actually sucks!

.
author: Passy G.

description: Fulfills rare craving for good (fresh ingredients, relatively subtle flavors) Chinese ("Chinese-style" for you snobs) food.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Have had many meals here since the first review - both in the restaurant as well as through take out, and the food has continued to be solid, and in some cases, has improved.

One welcomed aspect is the changing menu - not because the new items are necessarily 'better' than the old ones, but because they bring some variety to the small menu.  

The Lamb Hot Pot has been replaced by Xi'An Lamb, for $5.  It comes across as sort of 'French Dip'-ish, and is piquant, with a lamb jus dipping sauce.  Very tasty and well priced.

Similarly, the roasted chicken has been replaced with 'Thrice Cooked Bacon" for $9.  This dish was fantastic, and surprising.  Texturally, there was a lot going on - chewy rice, soft and fried-eggy tofu skins, and crispy, crumbly bacon.  Taste wise, the bacon and the tofu skins were particularly intense, and throughout the dish you'd get an occasional jolt from the bitter melon.  Bitter is not my favorite taste, but they were judicious with the melon use, and ultimately, it was good to break up the rich savoryness of the dish.

Prices remain extremely competitive for the neighborhood.  A lavish take-out meal here will be significantly cheaper than one from Big Lantern, the current Mission chinese powerhouse.
author: Daniel M.

description: Mission Chinese is a great spot for dinner with friends. It is cozy with a unique character. You better like spicy food if you go. We had a group of 6 people and didn't have much trouble getting a table on a Sunday for lunch. They are very accommodating to food restrictions and allergies.
author: Arun V.

description: The Ma Po tofu is freaking spicy.  It burned when it came back out.  Pwned.  I felt like most of the dishes were sour.  The lamb cheek noodles were good but sour.  The Ma Po Tofu was spicy but also sour.  The savory egg custard was decent.  The Hainam chicken fried rice was pretty tasty.  I would definitely come back to try some other dishes.  Its tough to order a lot cuz this place isnt good for groups.
author: Fatty A.

description:
damn good chinese food.
chicken rice is a-m-a-z-i-n-g
order it to go or delivery, not worth the wait with hipsters.
author: TVAT T.

description:
hipsterish chinese fusion restaurant in mission.  tons of great reviews in many magazines but doesn't live up to the hype.

first things first.  there is this old angry lady that gives you a dirty look all the time.  I'm so scared.

second, it's too dark.  I can't see what's going on.  I'm so scared.

third, i don't know what's inside these dishes.  I'm so sacred.

bbq sandwich and the pork belly were just average.  Their cod fried rice was the best thing on their menu.  I enjoyed more just hanging out with my old friend than the meal (though i value friendships, that's rare...i'm just kidding...)
author: Jang David K.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while now, based on friends who say they like it and well, all the hype. Usually there is such a long line we pass, but last night we were actually hungry at 5pm when they open and got a table right away.

They get 2 stars for excellent service and for playing really, really great music.

But the food itself was pretty bad! The brisket soup was insanely salty, and the thrice cooked bacon, though it had nice heat, had no real flavor behind the heat. The bacon was so chewy/gummy I had to spit a couple pieces out into my napkin (something I've not done since I was a child). 

Maybe we just happened to order the two worst items on the menu? Still, don't think I'll give it a second chance.
author: alexis a.

description: OK, we had a great dinner there last night, I thought it was called Long Shan, but I guess it goes by Mission Chinese Restaurant  too. The food was delicious, very spicy, I mean really spicy so if you don't like spicy food I don't suggest you go there. The fried rice to die for, did not care that much for the wrapped salad. The Lamb omg sooo good. And oh yeah the chicken wings make sure you get a napkin because your eyes are gonna be watery... :), very spicy and very delicious. The music was kinda loud, the service was great, the wait was long almost 1 hours for a group of 9, but worth it.
author: Ra'ed E.

description:
I ordered the Ma Po Tofu, the Beef Cheek and the Cold Tofu appetizer on Sunday night at 6pm.  On Sunday night at 830[m, it got delivered.  They said delivery would take an hour (at the most).

I think the dishes were cooked at around 6:10pm because by the time it got to me OVER TWO HOURS LATER, all the food was cold and there was probably 3/4 inch of oil floating on the top of the Ma Po Tofu dish.  Talk about unappetizing.  

The only dish I would eat again would be the cold tofu appetizer--that was actually tasty.  The other two dishes were so awful I can't believe that I wasted 2+ hours of my life salivating in anticipation of what I thought would be a delicious Sunday night dinner.

Never again.
author: Nicole S.

description: This place f*cking rocks and is my favorite restaurant in SF. I don't understand these people that complain about it. Order the Pastrami or the Long Beans if you like spicy (and I do). Absolutely love the vibe and the music. Don't come expecting Chinese Food, though .. it's not authentic nor traditional Americanized Chinese. This is a whole different, delicious ballgame!
author: Tom F.

description:
TO THE CHEF: BRING BACK THE ORIGINAL PASTRAMI DISH, not this minced up meat dish.
My husband and I loved this place, we had take out at least once a week here.  This past week, we ordered our usual, one of them being the pastrami dish.  We absolutely loved this dish but this time we noticed that they presented it differently.....totally went cheap on it and went from strips of pastrami to cut up little bits, way less meat and the potatoes which we loved were different too.  Please bring back the original style and bring back my chicken stir fry!
author: cacao r.

description: Finally made it here.   After reading the yelp reviews, we decided to try a bunch of the dishes repeatedly mentioned.  Every one was uber-hot, so be prepared for that.  The flavors are very over the top and come through the heat very nicely.  Our favorites were the cumin lamb, the thrice cooked bacon and the ma po tofu.  These were somewhat milder than the others we tried (pickles and the pastrami).  The pastrami will blow out your taste buds for sure., as it has the Chinese dried peppers, fresh jalapenos, and  crushed red peppers  throughout.   We'll be back to try other dishes and will repeat the lamb and the bacon.  Can see why this place is a darling right now, as the food is very unusual.  7% of the proceeds goes to charity.
author: John K.

description:
I'm sorry, but I dont get the hype. After reading an article in Bon Apetit about this place, I was super excited to try it. Got the egg custard, the pickles, the cold chicken dish, the beef cheeks, the bacon, and the pastrami. The egg custard was ok, texture was slimy on slimy. Pickles were ok. The chicken dish was just super spicy, didnt have much flavor. Beef cheeks with oysters were bland, had one oyster, and more fat the meat. The pastrami was super spicy, lacked pastrami and was filled with potato. The bacon was the best dish, but again, lacked bacon - should be called an onion dish with some bacon. 

In all, not worth the price, the hype or the following, especially in a city filled with fantastic Chinese food.
author: gabe k.

description: I hit up this place like many others due to the 7x7 writeup.  I thought it was good, but not crazy amazing.  The salt cold fried rice was tasty, as was the beef-cheek broccoli, but the ma po tofu was just too spicy, and the service was poor.
author: Corey C.

description:
so first off, i visited this place because of the fact that it got #2 on the bon appetit best places in the country right now.

http://www.bonappetit.com/magazine/slideshows/2011/09/best-new-restaurants-america#slide=9

i had beef cheeks with gai lan (Chinese Broccoli) it was ok, but the cheeks needed more umph of flavor! 

the congee (rice porridige) was legit, it advertised a poached egg, which i was excited about, but it ended up being an hard boiled soy sauce egg, which was flavorful, but not what i expected. 

i mean overall this place was ok. you should definitely try it for yourself and make your own judgement. but i think it is just ok....
author: Mei L.

description: I might have felt differently about this meal if I had waited a long time to be seated (we showed up at 5:30) or maybe if I had read the NYTimes magazine article on it (paywall) but with no expectations other than hoping to be served good food, I'd say it hit the mark.
author: Erich V.

description:
Got delivery from here when visiting the Mission District. I was so excited to try it and I was not dissapointed! We ordered Salt Cod Fried Rice, Ma po tufu, and sizzling cumin lamb. 
The fried rice was sooo good. I'm not a fish fan and I had worries that it may be too salty, but it was seasoned perfectly and was something I must have again. Next time I go to Cali I am so getting more of that! The mapo tofu was sour and spicy and more like a soupy sort-of dish. If you like those flavors and textures you will enjoy it, but I just ate 2 bites and left it. The lamb was spicy and AWESOME. I am always a fan of lamb and will order it anytime I see it, but I had never had lamb belly before. Perfectly tender and seasoned very well. Even my gf liked it and she hates cumin.
This place is doing awesome things and I am very happy I got to try it!
author: Megan B.

description: The pork belly and mapo tofu where pretty damn good. The pork melted in your mouth as soon as you bit into it. The salt cod fried rice was NOT worth it, despite its listing on 7x7. Maybe I expected too much from it, but honestly not that great. It's usually always crowded, but the wait isn't too long. It's a bit dark inside. They play classic hip-hop, which is a bit unfitting to the venue, but I guess it adds to the charm of this place.
author: Emmanuel C.

description:
It cheap and yet, it's priceless.

The mixing of Chinese food with an American spicy twang. Satisifying the discriminating Asian foodies taste buds, it challenges the street food carts of Taiwan and HK. We saw "auntie" inside and she seemed a bit glum. It is weird that Mission Chinese is located inside another restaurant called Lung Shan.
author: jenny n.

description:
Mission Chinese Food has been getting a lot lip service on the SF foodie tweet and blogospehere. While I was not unsatisfied, I was rather underwhelmed by my meal.  As others have pointed out, the eggplant was just okay.  The pork belly was a nice balance of sweet and salty, although maybe too fatty for some, while the spicy pickles were also quite delicious.  The chicken wings were so salty they hurt our mouths.  We hypothesized they had used some sort of salty "pop rocks" in the dry rub.
It sounds like this might be a case of not ordering the right things.  I will try the varioius tofu and bacon dishes as suggested.  Given the low price (35 for three people without drinks) and their donating part of their proceeds to the SF Food Bank , I'll give it another shot .
author: Molly J.

description: Maybe I hyped this place up in my head too much so when we finally were in the right time and place we were able to try out some much talked about chinese grub.  We ordered the trice cooked bacon, eel in rice roll, jook and ma po tofu.  They didn't serve the duck dish anymore and they ran out of the savory custard.   Trice cooked bacon, really flavorful and tasty, would order it again.  Eel in rice roll was very unique and a nice cold appetizer to counteract the spicy dishes.  The jook had really good crab flavor but was a little thin for my fiancee's tastes.  The ma po tofu, maybe it was the huge portion it came in but after three bites all I could taste was cumin and spice.  It overwhelmed everything else.  If we do go back I wouldn't try the ma po tofu again but another interesting dish instead.
author: Gina W.

description: I am a FAN.... been 4 times and love the mix of asian/Chinese ingredients with a funky fusion ..... Pastrami Kung Pao remains my favorite. I have been going for lunch and recently get seating right away..... Good place eclectic interior and good tasty food. Worth a try you'll go back!
author: Sam B.

description:
I really love this place when I'm in the mood for spicy food. You have to be ready for spice, though, because it is no joke. For me, the combination of ma po tofu and fried rice is really great--spicy mixed with not-spicy (and their fried rice is not oily like at most chinese places). Overall, the food has a really fresh, non-MSG taste. I like the way some of the dishes are served in a kind of artistic way, like with each little piece of meat perched on a slice of cucumber. Fancy!

Overall, the whole experience is pretty fun, with the chef coming out and talking with customers sometimes. They've also started remodeling, which I hope means they're going to stick around for awhile. I've come here several times over the last few months, and I like the way they keep updating the menu. Some days the dishes are spicier than others. Not sure what that's all about.
author: George L.

description:
We made a special stop here on a recent visit from LA. We tried the sizzling lamb with cumin, mustard greens and the pork belly.  

We first got the mustard greens which were fresh and tasty - lots of garlic and I liked that the ingredient was the star of the dish. The greens were cooked more than I like but they retained a vibrant flavor. Then we waited quite a long time for the lamb, which came on a sizzling platter piled high with onions, green peppers and pickled long beans. The lamb belly turned out to be a combination of belly and ribs- ok with me, I love bones.  The meat was redolent of cumin and was fried very crisp. Good texture but the flavor was somewhat one-dimensional and a bit underseasoned. If you could get a perfect mouthful of lamb, pickled beans and onion, it worked. But there weren't enough of the beans to provide that acidic balance to the richness of the lamb and the sweet raw flavor of the onions. The pork belly had a wonderful crispy exterior and the fat was delicious. My only complaint is that the meat was a bit dry. The crisp skin should be contrasted by meltingly soft meat and fat. I liked the boiled egg served with it. The yolk was still runny and the soy infused exterior provided a great contrast. The sauce with the pork belly tasted like plain hoi sin which is a shame. 

The restaurant itself is a dive but I like dives. My bf reported that the Bathroom was  dirty. I get that it's an old building but there is no excuse for dirty restrooms. Service was ok.
author: Evie D.

description: Ordered food for delivery at 5:00 just to be sure I would beat their dinner rush, (sounded reasonable) I was told it would take 45 minutes, well I FINALLY got my food at 7:15 (yes over two hours later!) food was cold and all of the juices from the food had spilled into the plastic bag. I called the place and tried to talk to the lady about the situation,she didn't seem to care and hung up on me, telling me that my location was too far.  Ok, I understand that Masonic and Geary is not very close to Mission and 18th st., but if it's too far THEN DON'T DELIVER THERE, and if it's going to take 2 hrs. and not 45 minutes like I was told, THEN DON'T TELL PEOPLE 45 MINUTES!!!     ....Needless to say, I'll never order from Mission Chinese Food again, sad because I was really looking forward to the food.
author: Randy J.

description: Really really good food! Very affordable, huge portion and very tasty... Looking fwd 2 my next visit. Also very friendly waiters :)
author: Oge c.

description: Lives up to the buzz. Mongolian Green Beans were on fire and I would have eaten the full portion but I couldn't feel my tongue after a quarter of the way through. My friend is vegetarian and I thought that would limit us, but the pumpkin chili soup was amazing. I'd go back for sure.
author: Arthur P.

description:
Exceptional food that delivers!!  Only took 35 mins to Lower Haight and I called it in at 7pm.  For a place that is rated so highly among food's best minds, that an incredible feat.

What we had:
Szechuan Pickles - their Kimchi.  Tangy, spicy, sweet.  Great starter to a meal.
Beijing Vinegar Peanuts - Great taste and a good snack.  Still good, but least favorite dish.  Would try something else next time.
Tea-Smoked Eel - Great smokey flavor in sliced spring roll.  Texture was really unique as well.
Ma Pa Tofu - Best dish we had.  Spicy throughout the dish, with a bit of sweetness from the tofu to balance it.  Great dish.
Thrice Cooked Bacon - If you like smokey dishes, this is your dish.  Tofu skins are a great addition to this dish.  Accidentely crunched down on a piece of bitter melon, which is awful, but dish was still very good.

Overall, great food, and i'd get in again in a heartbeat.  If you want to beat the lines, i'd suggest getting it to go.
author: Justin G.

description: Not your average Chinese restaurant! So don't bring your Asian family they wont like it! But an must try, this place deserve a four star for the following reasons. 1) Great English speaking service for an Chinese restaurant that is 2) Outside of the box design 3) Good food but a little pricey for the taste.
author: Tony L.

description: Awesome modern-style Chinese food. A little spicier than I prefer, but I love the concept and the excellent execution. Wasn't planning on returning because of the spicy factor, but I didn't try the salt cod fried rice that people keep talking about, so maybe I'll give it another shot.
author: Amanda S.

description: This is hangover food in a serious way.  We ordered...everything.  We had the pork belly with soy cured egg (holy fuck), the szechuan cucumbers, kung pao corned beef, thrice cooked bacon, braised mongolian beef cheek, sizzling cumin lamb and bok choy.  A word of warning, everything was very spicy.  And amazing.  But spicy.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Emily T.

description: I still remember the old establishment when I was a little kid and was pretty surprised to find out this is the Mission Chinese that has everyone talking. So I came here to see what all the hype was about, and that's all I felt there was to it, all hype. The food here was good but not worth all the rave reviews it gets as one of the best Chinese food in SF, considering the cliental...Iet's just say I get it. Followed protocol and ordered the popular items especially since I was in a group of 10, I was able to sample a lot of dishes. To name a few, we ordered salted cod, chongqing chicken wings, and kung pao pastrami. All the dishes were full of flavor which I am not mad at. I like my spicy and salty foods, but I felt like a lot of the spices over powered some of the dishes. I love some of the fusion ideas and respect the creativity but I think the dishes can be a little overwhelming when each dish comes out very strong. Good spot, big crowds, and a little pricey for Chinese food, I would come back but not worth going out of my way for.
author: Limuel G.

description: Decent food but honestly, if I wanted to spend $12 on Kung Pao Celery I'd find another restaurant. Most of the entrees I've tried here are all veggies and no meat, even though they're listed on the menu as meat dishes. Mostly onions, celery, and more onions. And on the rare occasion where there was a morsel of meat or two, it was mostly fat. Then there was the Veal Shank Incident. It was so overcooked I couldn't cut through it. Again, overpriced for what you get. I'd only go back for a huge helping of Salt Cod Fried Rice. That was certainly the highlight.
author: Ann H.

description:
This is really 3.5 stars, because I do like this place and it has a few things going for it, but its not quite a 4 star restaurant so I'm pulling back. And because Yelp is so overrated.

So....I've been here 3 or 4 times and this place is definitely unique and they should get an A for effort at trying to put out relatively authentic szechuan food.  I'm just a simple lo-fan so I know not what I speak of, however, I did grow up eating northern chinese cuisine at my buddy's house three times a week so I think I have the right to say a little something. Also, I've been to china several times recently, so have dipped my beak in the fountain of authenticity.

Every time I liked it, but something was just a little off.  First, the Ma Po Tofu.  The first couple times, I really liked it - very hot, a little greasy, lovely szechuan peppercorn tingle, good light texture to the sauce, a peppery burn - very interesting, if the flavors were somehow not quite spot on.  Unfortunately, they have now changed the recipe, which gives it a deeper meatier flavor, but that meaty flavor now overwhelms the Tofu, and turns a relatively light, spicy dish into a heavy gloopy meat stew that has a texture closer to Chef-Boy-Ar-Dee than anything else.  Af first I was puzzled about the change, but I asked the chef about it and he said that he had indeed changed the recipe.  Not sure what to say about it - I still kind of liked it, but it reminded me of nothing so much as the sucking sound that comes when one pours Spaghetti-O's out of a can.  

Home made pickles.  Love-em.

Pork BBQ in cocacola sauce?  Not really chinese, but mmm tasty.

Beef cheeks?  Meh - just a little bit off.

Tingly Lamb Soup - just ok, a bit overwhelmed by the pepper corn.

Tiger Salad.  Let me just say, this was about the worst dish I've had at a decent restaurant in many moons.  First:  Not A Salad!  Its a couple rolls.  Second:  The flavors are completely off. I could not finish this - its a wierd combination of overwhelmingly sour and herbs with a "dressing" that i couldn't choke down.  Do not order this dish.  

Cumin Lamb - this is an ok version of what is one of my favorite dishes on the planet.  They do a version at Old Mandarin Islamic that isn't much better, but neither approaches what should be a culinary orgasm.

Ok, so that's it.  For some reason, even though I don't love the food, I find myself thinking about it, and I keep going back, because they're food is interesting, different, and relatively cheap.

Hope they keep it up, and bring back the old Ma Po Tofu recipe!
author: Mike L.

description: Visited only once, so there's that. Insane experience. Super dim lighting. Seated at a long crowded table with other strangers, crammed together it was exactly like a Passover feast in a Jewish ghetto except for the hardcore rap that played incessantly at excessive volumes. Competing with the mood music to converse with your company quickly begins to strain your vocal apparatus.  The other diners didn't hesitate to escalate their words to the scream-level...but I expect this, it's CA, people's thoughts and opinions demand a platform without pause. The room is not acoustically neutral; echo chamber of deafening sonic chaos. Food was tasty. Crazy experience. If I knew that this precise atmosphere was replicated faithfully each evening, I would certainly recommend visiting at least once to experience it.
author: Brian H.

description:
I'm impressed by the ability of Danny Bowien and Anthony Myint to stay calm in the madhouse that is Mission Chinese Food on a Saturday night. We got chewed out by the hostess for docilely following the rules. That kinda sucked but I'll give her the benefit of the doubt, even though she barked at us to "come" as if we were animals. The calm friendliness of everyone else there compensated for her lack of composure. 

THE FOOD. THE FOOD. I get a kick out of eating whole prawns. Even the eyeballs. It was a ridiculous dish with a ton of competing/complementary flavors, generous with the cumin, and lots of cilantro, ginger and fennel playing off each other. The broccoli beef was falling-apart tender, amazingly good. There's an attention to detail in the dishes that really impresses. 

I'll even forgive them that secret, hallucinogenically-spicy chili that was sneaked into our otherwise-mild prawns and caused me to tear up and feel dizzy for about ten minutes. I can't remember the last time I was in that much pain. It was revelatory. 

I love Mission Chinese Food because it's food you can't get anywhere else. It's inventive and adventurous. 

But I really miss Mission Street Food. I wish someone else would take that concept and run with it. Please?
author: S H.

description: Meh, I've heard this place was OK before I tried it. Ordered the Thrice-Cooked Bacon with Rice Cakes and the Rice Porridge. I would skip the bacon, it's kind of greasy for my taste. The porridge rocks though. I think the prices could be slightly lower for the quality/quantity of food you get here.
author: Samuel H.

description: Ummm...not sure what to say about this. I had high expectations because I'd heard such good reviews. Unfortunately, I just wasn't impressed. The salt cod was definitely the best dish. The beef cheeks were also good but varied considerably by the bite (some pieces of meat good, others not). The rest were mediocre and unmemorable (and we ordered A LOT). If I'm in the mood for some fun Asian food I would much rather go to Burma Superstar or Marnee Thai.
author: Amy F.

description:
I'll keep this short and sweet.  I've dined here probably not quite ten times.  My favorite dishes are thrice cooked bacon (I get the vegetarian version almost every time), Mongolian long beans, and the stewed beef tongue and turnips.

The service is always good, despite the long wait. Ordering take out is a great option for this place.  Prices are pretty reasonable for this area.

The only downside is that they sometimes make the dishes too salty (most of the dishes are intended to be salty anyway, but sometimes its too much). Still, I love this place and I hope the chef has a protege in the waiting to continue making the food if he actually departs for New York as has been rumored.
author: Miles R.

description: The food was terrific got there at 5 pm no wait.  Things came quickly, maybe too quickly since forgot the wine,also server got the order wrong. Food good,service no so good good.
author: Penney M.

description:
3-3.5 stars, really.

I'd like to start off by declaring that I am pretty damn critical when it comes to Chinese food. In fact, I am so picky about it that I seldom go out to eat Chinese food because most of it in the Bay Area sucks. Sorry if this sounds snotty, I really didn't intend on making it appear that way.

OK anyway. Went here last night with a couple of friends and we were all very curious about this place...this restaurant within a restaurant. Since most of the reviews mentioned a long wait and we didn't want to wait in the freezing cold, we went right when they opened. FYI - by the time we finished, which was around 6, the restaurant was 90% full. 

We ordered:

1. Smoked Beef Brisket Noodle Soup: not the typical Chinese-style beef brisket, but the meat was very tender and flavorful. I wish they used actual rice noodles (hor fun) as opposed to rice noodle wraps (cheung fun). The broth tasted like soy sauce. Oh, the portion was very small; it literally came and went.
2. Pork Belly: lacked sauce/flavor, but the meat was excellently prepared. The meat part of the belly cube was succulent and crispy, whereas the fat part melted in your mouth. I really admired the texture. 
3. Thrice Cooked Bacon: the rice cakes were a little hard and some were even clumped together. The bacon was soft and packed with flavor. Overall, the dish was smothered in black bean sauce and peppers. A little spicy (for those who can't handle.)
4. Ma Po Tofu: I wasn't too excited to learn that this was their famous dish because....seriously, ma po tofu isn't that hard/special to make. Anyway, this tasted like chili. The tofu wasn't all that silky, either. I'd say skip this and you wouldn't miss a thing.

Overall:

Their flavor, composition and even presentation may not be that authentic, but I can tell they put a lot of work into the texture and preparation of the meat, which is essential in Chinese cuisine.  So mad props for that. Actually, their food beats 90% of the SHIT they serve in Chinatown(s). 

Service was OK. 

It was really dark (red?) in the room.

I did not find the place one bit hipster.

Yes, the journey to the restroom is quite adventurous and have you questioning if you really want to eat there, but hey...if you're craving for authenticity... ;)

I did not love it, but I didn't dislike it, either. It was decent; I did not regret coming here, and even want to take my Chinese food Nazi father here to see what he thinks. That might endure some scolding....
author: Grace C.

description: Had a good experience at Mission Chinese.  Tried the the Salt Cod Fried Rice, Thrice Cooked Bacon, and Smoked Beef Brisket Soup.  The salt cod fried rice was solid.  Nothing mind blowing, the flavors were subtle, but overall an enjoyable dish.  My favorite was the Thrice Cooked Bacon, the flavors were excellent, and the noodles in dish tasted amazing. I didn't really like the Beef Brisket soup, it was a little oversalted and the flavors where 'meh'.
author: Tim O.

description:
Good...not great
Tasty...but pricey for what you get
Went there with high expectations.  Waited waaaaaaay too long for the experience.  A unique spin on some traditional dishes and actually served well, but for the wait and the price we could have served a family of  6 a really good "family dinner A" from one of scores of Chinese restaurants or really splurged and had "family dinner B" for 4 people (includes special house fish...mmmmmmmm!)

I don't want to hate...General Tsoa's pastrami is good idea in theory and it wasn't bad, just wasn't enough to make me come back or wait an hour + for a table.  Salted Cod Fried rice is delishhhh....but family dinner C includes Orange chicken and I LOVE ME SOME ORANGE CHICKEN.  Expand from the idea of a pop up, take reservations, and I would probably go back.
author: jacob s.

description:
Im not giving it two stars because it didn't live up to the hype, Im giving it two stars because the food was genuinely not that good.  I was starving and a little drunk when I got here, so it was a recipe for a great meal no matter where I was eating, right?  Guess not.  

Thrice cooked bacon: literally maybe 6-7 2 inch pieces of bacon in a greased filled plate covered in fried rice patties.  No real striking taste, the bacon chewy and bland.  i mean, it's bacon, how could it be bad?

Slow cooked pork belly:  this was actually good and the only enjoyable food I had.  But for $10 (i think that's what it was) I expected a bit more than 4 pieces.  

fried cod fish: didn't have it but my friends ordered it and said it was bland with no taste of fish and not even any veggies in it.  looked like a plate of half fried rice for $10.

smoke beef brisket: definitely smoked.  that's about all you could taste.  the brisket was nice and soft but had 0 taste and even the bok choy, which i love and am obsessed with, was under cooked and not tasty at all.  not sure how they managed that one.  

the cucumber cold salad was good but I've had that at about every chinese restaurant i've been too.
