but yes, def hipster chinese food.  i appreciate places that cater to the neighborhood as well as the community that they are representing.  this one only does the former, probably on purpose.  wouldn't go back, much less wait for another 30 minutes.  i just don't understand how it's so popular?  probably the hipster rock music, christmas lights, and cute dragon inside.
author: Isamarie P.

description: Dear San Francisco, yet another disappointment. I don't want to move back to NYC, and I won't, but I stand by David Chang's negative comments a few years back. As for Mission Chinese, I had the squid ink noodles with lamb and the flavors were neither deep nor complex, and wow, I love fat, but there's a difference between greasy and fatty. I also had the pea shoots, for which I'd say pretty much the same thing, but would add that they're supposed to be spicy and I had to add hot sauce. I really wanted to like it but I left craving something like the ramen at silver lake ramen in LA or even some good bread and butter. I'm gonna go get some now.
author: Simcha K.

description: Came here with my boyfriend since he raved about it so much and I wanted to see what the hoopla was about. It is not your typical Chinese restaurant. The ingredients used are definitely not the typical ingredients you find Chinese restaurants and even any other restaurant, like different types of meat. Some foods that may seem typical Chinese is more traditional like they're green beans which is made in the Sechuan cuisine (lots of chillis). I can see why some people like this restaurant but I'd rather go to the homeland for some real Chinese cuisines.
author: Linda L.

description: Had the 5 meats...pork, chicken wings, fish/cod rice, lamb, and veal. amazing!!! best lamb and veal i've ever had.
author: Nick C.

description: I love the experience of eating here... everything is unique and interesting and mostly delicious. But the Wild pepper soup is just amazing. It has pumpkin and pressed tofu. It sounds kind of plain but the flavors are incredible. Yum.
author: Claire b.

description: Came here on a Sunday and luckily there was no wait! We ordered the westlake rice porridge, beef stew and some buckwheat noodle with smoked eel. The steak in the rice porridge was overly smokey, which is a really weird combination. The egg that came with the porridge was awesome, but $10 for some porridge is ridiculous. The beef stew with noodles had a really weird flavor, which i think is the cardamom in it, doesn't really go well with the flavors in the broth, the brisket was VERY good! Lastly the buckwheat noodles is the nastiest dish I've ever tasted, I think it also had a numbing effect on my tongue, eel was good though, wish that came over some hot rice. My porridge took forever to come out so they offered us some cucumber salad, which was just meh. Also they notice I barely touch the buckwheat noodles so they didn't charge for it. I took it home in hopes that it wasn't just my taste buds that didn't like it, but none of my family touched it! Some really good components to each dish but overall they didn't work together nicely.
author: Nancy T.

description:
This place is so yummy!!  I cannot wait to go back!  I went with a group of five and ordered:
-Beijing vinegar peanuts
-hot and sour cucumber
-Hainam chicken
-vegan thrice cooked bacon
-broccoli beef cheek
-Mongolian long beans
-wild pepper leaves
The dishes that stood out the most were the THRICE COOKED BACON, BROCCOLI BEEF CHEEK, and MONGOLIAN LONG BEANS.  The thrice cooked bacon made me feel homesick because it reminded me of a dish my mom makes.  The beef in the broccoli beef was just falling apart, it was so tender.  And the long beans were just like how I used to get them in Beijing, pretty authentic.  
After enjoying this amazing meal and ordering a couple drinks, our bill came out to only $15 a person, and that's including tax and tip.  What a great deal!  We were all shocked at how affordable it was for the quality of the food.  Maybe they messed up our bill, but I don't think so.  Double brownie points for being delicious and affordable!  Definitely worth the wait.
author: rose h.

description: Great food for a great price. I had the broccoli beef cheek YUMMMM. Atmosphere was good. Pumpkin dish was not all that great though. Super salty and very spicy. They need to tweak the recipe a bit. I want to come back and eat some of the other dishes that sounded delicious. =)
author: Genaro R.

description: good food. good service. perfect place to kick back with some friends and enjoy an ice cold tsingtao with a generous bowl of egg noodles.
author: Kat R.

description: Heard about this place for awhile and finally got it delivered...which that alone is a plus on a rainy, lazy evening.  The brisket noodle soup was to die for...tender melt in your mouth meat and big fat rolled up noodles.  Prices a little higher than many...but worth the quality
author: Judith K.

description: Ordered the tingly lamb noodle soup which was delicious.  High quality broth, perfectly chewy noodles and lamb cheek.  Also ordered a sit-in special (ribs) which was served with a knife sticking straight up out of the ribs.  Presentation aside, the ribs were tasty enough, but lacked the accompaniments and integration that make for full dishes in my mind.  I understand that it's best to come to these places and order family style so you get some variety, but we were eating purely meat and rice gets old after awhile.  Willing to come back and give it another go though, mainly because of the high reviews in the chronicle
author: Taylor J.

description: I love it when something lives up to the hype.  (In this case, considerable hype!)  But I gotta say, I really enjoyed this place.  Now, I'm a big fan of real-deal Sichuan food, and I am familiar with the flavors, and always find it a treat to find real Sichuan, as opposed to General-Tso's Chinese.  If you don't dig spicy food, don't go here!  But if you do, the ma po tofu and the fiery chicken wings will blow your mind.  We asked them to dial down the spice on the ma po tofu, and I was glad we did.  It was just spicy enough that a little Tsing Tao made everything ok again.  The staff were all really affable and I really enjoyed it.  OH - GO EARLY.  If you go at 6, you'll be amazed when you walk out how many people are waiting.
author: Bobbie J.

description:
CONS:  Super long wait to get a table.  I recommend ordering take-out.


PROS:  A nice different take on Chinese food, especially if you like spicy foods.  

OVERALL:  Definitely overrated.  I would go back but would go either in a non-rush hour time or get take out.
author: Victor T.

description: I went here last night with my roommate. We were seated almost immediately and had a great waitress who was super friendly and helpful. We had the tiger salad which was rolled in rice paper and really different (and good!). Also the szechuan pickles (very spicy!), lung shan's vegan delight (soup with mushroom dumplings), taiwanese eggplant and vegan thrice cooked bacon (my favorite dish, very flavorful). Even though we are vegetarians and ordered pretty much all the veggie dishes they had, we want to go back soon! Everything was just delicious.
author: Emma S.

description: Finally.  Waited months to go here and went for a late Saturday lunch.  No wait - we were seated at the far end table where we watched the stern server ladies pick greens from the stems at a round table.  Fascinating but a bit strange.  Tiger salad - a bit too heavy on the raw leafy stuff. It was an interesting concept but hard to eat and the leaves did not hold the 'dressing' so it pooled on the plate and you were left munching just greens.  The rice porridge was great!  The chunks of oxtail were flavorful and the egg had a pungency that went well with the soothing rice soup. The Kung Pao pastrami was a fantastic dish.  Tender beef slices, the potatoes utterly wonderful, well seasoned with a smoky flavor.  Loved loved loved this dish.  Generous helpings for the 2 of us - we brought home left overs and enjoyed them all over again.  Would love to go back.
author: Ash A.

description: What a disappointment!  A good friend of mine has been raving about this place for 6 months, so I decided to check it out.  I was expecting a wait similar to Burma Superstar and didn't mind going down the street to grab a drink while waiting for a table.  The good news is that once you get in, you don't have to wait very long for your food to come out and they bring you water very quickly.  However, the food itself is terrible.  I ordered 4 dishes and the only 1 I enjoyed was the pickled vegetables.  All of the other dishes were over-salted and the meat was pretty much all fat.  The dishes are very creative, but they were not my cup of tea.  I prefer more traditional Chinese food.  On a side note, the waitress splattered soup on me and the girl sitting next to us and didn't apologize.
author: Sarah K.

description: A hipster twist on classic Chinese dishes such as Ma Po Tofu. Spicy and delicious food. But an attitude. Crowded with posers with the beats too loud. The wait staff wasn't particularly interested in being nice, either. Next time we try delivery.
author: Jeff E.

description:
My experience was not good in so many ways.  First, we were told it would be an hour for delivery, wish was fine.  An hour and ten minutes later, we called to check on the order, but they couldn't give us an update.  Twenty minutes later, someone finally shows up.

As if being 30 minutes late wasn't enough of an issue, the food was not good.  I had the cold noodles and they were just soaked in oil.  Gross.  The cucumber pickles had some pretty good flavor, but again, soaked in oil.  My friend's chinese broccoli was pretty good, but the oysters inside were pretty fishy.  Not cool.
author: Olivia T.

description:
It was the first night of Hanukkah and, after searching at Walgreens, Safeway and CostCo all in vain for Hanukkah candles, I was feeling down and dejected. We decided to have a restaurant adventure to cheer me up and make the evening feel festive. I've had Mission Chinese Food on my list forever, and as we parked across the street and looked at the dingy Chinese restaurant front I realized how appropriate it was I'd chosen Chinese food as Jew feeling restless on the holiday ;-) 

As soon as we had our first bites of food my mood lifted. The beer was cold, the music my favorite cheesy 90s songs (mostly hip hop) and the dishes were AMAZING. I was so happy, I literally started dancing in my chair and humming as I was eating. That happy. And I didn't care, I just kept dancing between mouthfuls of the food, which was packed with flavor and generously portioned. In order of our favorites, we had the sizzling cumin lamb, mao po tofu, pickles, veg dumplings and seaweed salad. We loved it so much we were already talking about how much we want to come back, but we adore spiciness (which most everything was) and funky environs. If you want white tableclothes, a calm quiet setting or no spicy peppers, onions or tons of other bold in-your-face flavorings, go elsewhere. This is not your typical Chinese restaurant and people who may not be up for bigger flavors and creativeness could be taken aback. I think those are the people panning this place, and that's fine with me... more for all the people clearly ecstatic about their experiences here.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
Didn't really meet expectations.  The service was courteous and the food was fresh, but too much spice.  And by spice, I don't mean chillis - I mean, every dish had the same crunchy afterbite spice.

The chilli chicken wings left a weird after taste on  your tongue.

The ma po tofu was interesting, but for all the hype this place has garnered, I probably won't try it again.

Oh - eating Chinese food in a dimly lit restaurant with hip hop music blazing - that part was worth it!
author: That's For N.

description: Danny Bowien is a genius! This place lives up to the hype. One of my favorite places to eat and if you don't feel like waiting 2 hours they even deliver! Everything is fantastic, but my absolute favorite is the Thrice Cooked Bacon.. i would pick it as my last meal. Other highlights include the rice porridge (comfort food) and the beef cheek.
author: Steve K.

description:
About halfway through the meal, my wife and I looked at each other and exchanged the phrase that indicates pure disappointment with a restaurant, while simultaneously trying to feel good about having spent the money (even if in this case, very little): "I'm glad we tried it".

When all that you're left with to say is "I'm glad we tried it", by default, you have nothing positive left to say.

Let's recap, then the positive things we had said by that point::

-The cold noodles (appetizer page) are GOOD.
-Beer is not overpriced (Tsing Tao @ $3)

What other observations, exclamations, or other points of general "ations" had passed between us by that time?

-the Mapo Tofu reminded me of what you would get if the USDA school lunch program decided to make Mapo Tofu. In other words: vaguely recognizable as such, but it took a lot of generosity of spirit and imagination to believe. 

-the chicken wings were hilariously not good. You get one taste from them: salt.

-the pickles were average in the way that a stabbing at 16th St. Bart is average.

I am not a prescriptivist. That is, I don't run around saying "this is soooo AUTHENTIC", or "this ISN'T authentic so it SUCKS!". The world turns, chefs take a known quantity and add, subtract, or otherwise modify it, and this is how new dishes are born. I get that.

The eating world to me is somewhat binary - I like it or I don't. And the fact is that I found little to like here. There is better sichuan food in SF (though only a few places, sadly). Try Spices!! and Panda Kitchen - both in the Richmond. They're light years ahead of MCF on every count. 

PS, tons of places in SF have dishes featuring sichuan peppercorn. Ya just gotta learn how to ask for it.(HUAjeeOW)
author: r g.

description:
I was lucky enough to eat at Mission Street Food once before it closed, and it was one of my favorite meals ever.  The combination of the idea, the nutty venue, the crowd, and the menu (I think it was sort of a "Best Of" the season) made for a memorable experience.  In particular I was blown away by the brilliance of the dessert: yogurt with mint infused olive oil, spring peas, basil, and some other green.  One taste of that and I was like "these guys are not messing around."  Or rather they were, in really fantastic ways.

So, I went into Mission Chinese Food with this high expectation plus that of all the great reviews and attention it's received since opening last year or so.  It retains the familiar vibe and concept of the "borrowed" venue and kitchen, Christmas lights, hot waitresses, and blaring Jay-Z/Kanye contrasting with ridiculous posters of rainbow spectrum horses running somewhere and a truly hideous canopy outside.  It was raining and there was still a crowd of hipsters waiting 45 minutes to get in.  We were 4 and ordered 4 items:

* Guilin Rice Noodles - $8 - came first, was tasty.
* "Mouth Watering" Chicken - $7 - not my thing, as I do not enjoy the anesthetic effect of Szechuan peppers.
* Thrice Cooked Bacon - $11 - my favorite dish
* Mongolian Long Beans - $10 - 2nd favorite dish

and some rice.  It was just the right amount of food, as we chowed pretty much everything, and as you can see the prices are a steal, so overall, I thought the experience was fine, but I would not wait in the rain for 45 minutes to eat here again.  I do wish, however, that Mission Street Food reopened.  I miss that (wider) sense of gastronomic adventure.
author: Rob P.

description: Mission Chinese: Spicy, warm, great flavors overall, but a tad excessive on the oil/meat-fat quotient.
author: Jack G.

description: damn! thrice cooked bacon drops from the heavens and has to be caught before serving.
author: Abi R.

description:
Fantastic!
Phenomenal inventive Chinese food. I think I sense a Burmese flair, but that may be their secret. Started with the Tiger Salad. YUM! Great presentation. Then had the Cold Noodles. Delicious with a unique flavor. The third dish was the Salt Cod Fried Rice infused with delicately balanced flavors. The two of us were very quiet as we enjoyed the new experience. We were in awe. These three dishes were plenty. 
The ambiance was, well, like an established Chinese restaurant. Very little was spent on swanking it up, leaving it very, very charming. I'm quite happy not having to subsidize a multi-million dollar remodel, making their prices very fair.
The service was extremely helpful.
author: Joe B.

description:
My husband and I ordered delivery on a night after I had had minor surgery. The food came pretty quickly, but with a serious price tag - I think it was about $50, for take out!

We had the salt cod fried rice, which was pretty good, lamb noodle soup - which was ridiculously spicy, and I always order things really spicy. This was actually each had a serving and then threw away the rest, it was just too spicy. We asked for their recommendations at the end, if there was anything great we need to try, they suggested the savory egg custard. Yuck, my husband and I each had a small taste of this and then threw it away - we never do this, so all in all, this was a pricy night of food.

The portions are really big, that's a good thing and the flavors are definitely unique so you won't find a lot of the combinations anywhere else. It was fun to try once, but wouldn't be my go-to.

I do really like that they donate $.75 from every entree to the SF Food Bank.
author: Lauren M.

description:
more like 3.75 stars.

i came here to be hipster-status cool.

and it was my birthday, so my hipster-at-heart roommates, who have been telling me about how this place is yummy, made the executive decision for us to come here for my birthday dinner. we arrived at about 5.15pm, and didn't have to wait long at all. upon leaving at around 6.30-6.45pm, there were many, many people outside waiting to get in.

beijing vinegared peanuts - whets the appetite well. especially liked the smoked garlic bits.

szechuan pickles - this too was good; a good appetizer pairing with the vinegared peanuts.

sizzling cumin lamb - T____________T these are tears of joy. for the lamb was most excellent. beautiful, beautiful flavor, melted in my mouth - and i don't even like lamb on the usual. i fell in love.

salt cod fried rice - necessary carbs, tasty enough but not the best i've had.

an order for the ma po tofu was made, but it never came. no issue, they struck it off our bill no problem. no issue, because

I GOTS ME A COMPLIMENTARY BIRTHDAY DISH OF SPECTACULAR VEAL.

now this veal....this veal was amazing in many ways i cannot as of yet find words to describe. flavors were plentiful and robust, so meaty and fatty and coma-inducing. goes so well with the rice, we all scooped up the sauce to drench over stuff on our plate. this wasn't any crappy piece of complimentary birthday protein, this was so very satisfying. thank you muchos to our waiter.

place gets very packed, so holding a conversation is very hard. not an issue though, because one should really just focus on the food. don't expect traditional or mom & pop chinese restaurant-type offerings, simply expect a delicious chinese/chinese-inspired meal. 

my hipster friends at school gave me props for finally making my way here. however, they thought it not fit for me to declare myself hipster-status cool upon my telling them that i'd yelp this place and give it a 3.75 -star review, because apparently, that's not enough stars given to this place to warrant entry into their circle.

oh well.
author: Eliza D.

description: Tried this place two more times after being blown away and it was not the same. The vinegar peanuts are always delicious but the sliced peanut noodles were just ok
author: Ojus P.

description: I think I was just on episode of "Portlandia". It's so alternative and confusing it is actually an experience I'd recommend to others to try...Asian dudes dressed up as tattooed X Game contestants co-work with toothless chinese grandmas to serve smoked meats, tofus and veggies in heavily spiced gooey sauces. The place is a kitchy dirty eyesore that blares hip hop/street music and seems to work hard to be stealthy, unimpressive and concoct a vibe that can be nothing short of "painfully hipster" (think back to the pickling episode). Not to be a snide shit: I think it all is delivered with true integrity but I wish I was stoned so I could enjoy the humor and experience even more. I'd give 4 stars but the incessant runs I have had since my departure keeps me at a good spirited three. Good luck in NYC, they should love it
author: Matt H.

description: We had the Brisket, Pulled Pork and Chicken Wings which is eat-in only as well as the Thrice Cooked Bacon and the Lung Shan's Vegan Delight soup. Great BBQ !!! It's sort of BBQ food truck meets Chinese Food. I'm definitely going back for the beef cheeks and pork belly. It's a great take on Chinese Food and reasonably priced. I wonder if they are going to offer break dancing lessons soon. That would hit the spot.
author: Mike C.

description: This is not your usual Chinese restaurant. Very hipster. Odd dishes. Delicious food, but not in a sweet & sour chicken way. Think more brisket and bok choi. It's on a sketchy block and the decor is nothing to write home about, but worth a visit for its novel take on the cuisine.
author: Kevin F.

description:
I got the Ma Po Tofu, which was a huge portion and will easily provide another meal.  The flavors were all great, nice and spicy.  I also ordered the cold sesame noodles, although it was totally not necessary based on the quantity of the ma po tofu, but I wanted to try.  The noodles were very delicate, but the flavors were just not to my personal liking.

Service was... abrupt.  Meal came out insanely quick.  I went at about 1pm on a Sunday, and there wasn't a wait at all.

Overall, I'd go 3.5 stars if I could.
author: Jason S.

description: What can I say, I'm a sucker for hipster food. Mission Chinese is truly awesome, it's more "Chinese influenced" than actual Chinese food (although you can still order off the Lung Shan menu for more traditional fare), which makes it even cooler. No frills, terrifically creative and delicious food, and cheap beer and wine. No wonder there's a line down the block most nights. The chef often brings out dishes and will explain them in great detail if he senses you care about that sort of thing.
author: Ella L.

description: I thought the food here was just OK. Some dishes were good. They do use high quality spices. But, others were bland and uninteresting.
author: Eater S.

description: This place is best to check out for lunch if you are in the Mission. The dinner line can be long, but worth the wait. Some of the dishes are rich and others spicy and some both rich and spicy. Be prepared for a hot fiery dish. The dishes are great interpretations of Chinese food. Suitable to most foodie tastes.
author: Unkl- T.

description:
I came back to dine in more than a year after my first review and was happy to see many more options on the menu.

In general most of the items don't suit my preference in Chinese cuisine (I grew up with Taiwanese and Shanghainese) but it's perfect for people who love a lot of heat and salt.

The mongolian long beans, salt cod fried rice, and sizzling cumin lamb seem to be long-standing favorites.  My favorite was probably the pork belly, which comes with a wonderfully half-cooked (though very salty) egg.

I can see why a lot of people like this place, but it doesn't really do it for me.
author: S L.

description: This is one of the best restaurants in SF! Yes! Finally a great Chinese restaurant in the city that is not in Chinatown! I will be referraing all of my frineds here. You can't go wrong. Get yor faovrite Chinese dishes and you will leave happy (and with leftovers!)
author: Laura A.

description: Started with the fried rice which was very, very good. They then brought us a spicy tofu dish that was VERY spicy. It had a tomato based sauce that just burned your mouth, good but boy was it spicy. Then we ended with a porridge soup which we wished we had gotten second. But, overall, very fresh and very tasty & HOT SPICY food!
author: P G.

description: Tried the tingly lamb noodle soup and the ma po tofu.  Both were delicious. For being as well known and quality as they are, they keep the prices, service and environment real.  Will definitely be back.
author: beverly l.

description: Our server could do no wrong. She led us through the Sherwood Forest that is the MCF menu with nimble expertise. The slow-cooked pork belly could have been her crowning achievement.  Sweet glaze on a crisp exterior contrasted with the soft inner mush of a slice of pork belly over a fat noodle with a soy pickled hard-boiled egg? Are you freakin kidding me? I love the twist on the mussels where they add pork jowl. C'mon! That's AWESOME. If you don't like pork, you're probably going to look askance at this menu. However, if the pig is your friend, do not be afraid! Just be sure to show up a little early and put your name on the list before you dine.
author: Robin P.

description: This was one of those meals I would call trans-formative.  It changed the way I think about dining out in a way, and definitely opened my mind to the way things can be combined in a dish.  This is not the place for traditional Chinese cooking but if you appreciate food & flavors this is the place.  Don't be intimidated by all the hipster talk - they are open to anyone who appreciates good food & brings an adventurous attitude to the table.  This is almost like going to dine in a friend's basement, if your friend was as creative, fun & casual as Danny Bowien appears to be.  The vinegar peanuts are a MUST.  So complex.  And they complimented other dishes when they were eaten together.  I crave these things.  The longbeans were Schezwan style as in super spicy, and super addictive.  Everything here screams fresh, flavorful and complex.  I tried a friend's Thrice Cooked Bacon - holy moly, super yum but definitely for sharing.  We also shared some kind of peas but they are no longer on the menu so I can't remember exactly, just that I ate Mission Chinese leftovers for lunch 3 days in a row following my visit and I was glad to do it!  Go!  Now!
author: Lora L.

description: A strangely fun pop-up experience even though we had to wait one hour on the street and then eat in crowded/loud/dumpy Chinese restaurant. The food didn't really blow me away but was definitely interesting and inventive with clean tastes. Our faves were the pickled dishes, fresh noodles, and tasty crab porridge. Fun time!
author: Peter H.

description:
After hearing all the buzz, we finally made it. First impression: it's a whole in the wall, that could use remodeling- they better deliver in food department. We were prepared to wait in a very long line, so 40 min estimated wait wasn't huge surprise. But guy who took our names was pretty cool about it: he recommended few bars around and mentioned that even if we miss our line, he will get us back in. So the wait was quite enjoyable with pitcher of sangria at Cha-cha-cha. We had high expectations about food and we were not disappointed: Amazing! My ratings: #1 lamb, #2 veal ribs, #3 chicken baked rice, #4 chicken wings #5 pork belly.  Service was great and they even allowed us to switch table when 2 more friends decided to join us at the last minute.  Cool place that succeeded our pretty high expectations- we'll be back. 
PS Interesting that there is Mission Chinese and Lung Shan on Yelp to review, but it is actually the same restaurant.
author: Jeanette E.

description: I went here with 7 other guests and it was fantastic. I love the concept and the food tastes really good. Its all very full flavored, well prepared. I appreciate the innovation. Yes it is in the Mission and so its grittier than some would want, but I like that. I'll be back for sure.
author: Lady D.

description:
I liked it on my first visit but then on the second visit, I realized that the food was too greasy and overly spicy. 
Certain dishes like the cumin lamb are definitely unique but the restaurant overall not worth a 20 min wait.
author: Insi L.

description: Anyone who gives this place less than 5 stars is dead wrong.  It's not a fancy restaurant, it's a restaurant that puts all its energy into the food, not the presentation or the locale.  And as such, you should only be comparing it to other regional/north/central chinese places.  I'm no expert, but I've eaten at about 5 other places that do the same kinds of dishes.  Amazing.  'Nuff said.  Kinda wish they would move to a bigger space, tho-- the wait for a table can be sooo loooong almost every night they're open!
author: throw a.

description:
Lunch is the way to go! No wait until we left at 1pm. 

The salt and pepper shrimp with curried pork fat were amazing. Good Hainan chicken rice. Mapo tofu was quite savory and HUGE.
author: Halle L.

description: The food is fine, flashy, and photogenic, and there are a few moments of "wow! that's delicious" but overall this place is overhyped and cramped. The kitchen obviously prides itself on its Szechuan roots but goes overboard with the spicy hotness so much that it overpowers the other flavors. The pork belly was phenomenal and I loved it. The green beans looked promising but tasted musty and like funk. No thanks, never again. Enjoyed the pastrami dish but it is definitely overrated. Ordered the cod rice but it never arrived. The chicken wings are perfectly cooked but there are too few of them and they are literally buried under dried chili peppers (I wonder if the chili peppers are reused since no one eats them) for effect rather than any kind of purpose.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Amazing trice cooked bacon but the service recently has been lacking.  We waited for as long as we actually sat down, and the waiter came over after 1 hr and told us to leave so they could fit a new table in.  We had basically just signed the check and tables seated before us were still enjoying their meal.

I get that it's now a famous place to eat in SF, but no need to be snooty.  Why not get a bigger space?  I'll be ordering takeout going forward.
author: Tamara S.

description: Too bad it's so damn busy. I'd love to go more. For now, I'll stick to weekend lunches to avoid the insanity. Salt Cod Fried Rice was my favorite so far. The wings were also magical. Will return again and again.
author: Jimmy L.

description: Whoah for the "MEDIO LITRO" bottle of Mexican Coke LOL.  Wait time was a bit long since this is such a popular place.  Surprised with the music they play because it makes you feel like you are not eating at a Chinese restaurant at all.  Ambiance for me was great.  Our Server was helpful and courteous. Food was delicious.  I dared try to eat what I haven't eaten before, and I must say It took me breathless with all the spices and flavors.  I can't wait to dine back again or grab something to go.
author: Joel Q.

description: Fusion or not, it is spicy good- flavorful spicy good.  After two hours of waiting in line, I've decided it was worth the wait and every cent of my hard earned money, plus there is nothing like listening to great trance/electronic music to help digestion!
author: Ruthie K.

description: Over rated....  Food is decent... all the meats we ordered were super fatty. Not worth the wait.
author: Jeff B.

description: I don't understand the bad reviews. This place is amazing. I have never been able to walk in and get a table but i have also never waited more than 15-20 minutes. The quality of the food plus the price makes this a hands down 5 star joint. You will not get your americanized chinese fair here so look elsewhere for greasy deep fried sugar coated "food." Some of my faves are the brisket with noodles soup it's smokey with deep flavors, sizzling cumin lamb is seriously banging as well.
author: Joe P.

description:
best new restaurant of SF? i don't know about that..but it's some dinky chinese food place. got the egg custard...beware..it's cold...

got the pork thing with egg...it was okay..

nothing that I'd crave....

just a small snack before we went to flour+water
author: John S.

description: Totally lived up to the hype for me. I went twice while I was in town visiting my sister. We brought friends, so we got to try a lot of the things on the menu. Highlights are Beef Cheeks and Broccoli, Tingly Lamb Soup, Pork Belly, Ma Po Tofu, and Beijing Vinegar Peanuts. Don't worry about the wait. Have fun. Be happy.
author: Wes B.

description:
Note to owners/managers of Mission Chinese: Train your staff or hire better servers who care.  Does Mission Chinese have good food?  Yes.  Has it received praise from the food gods of SF?  Yes.  Does that make up for horrible service?  NO!

After our first visit a few months ago, my husband and I left with full, happy bellies, but kept saying "I wish we could've tried ____, but that would've been just too much food."  We were excited to visit again last week with more people so we could order more items off the menu.  We have tons of wine left over from a recent party so I thought it would be nice to take a bottle or two.  I called to ask and received a long 10 seconds of "uuuummmm" from the guy who answered the phone.  He put me on hold to ask someone else and came back with "no you can't bring your own wine".  I thought that was odd, so I looked back on Yelp reviews and sure enough just 2 days prior there was a review saying that they brought their own wine.  Naturally I called back to confirm.  Same guy - "Uuummmmm, well, I don't know.  Wait hold on.".  He passed on the phone to someone else.  I, very nicely and politely said "Hi" and got cut off by a very RUDE "Yeah, do you have a question because we're really busy right now.."  What the..!  Anyway, I did have a question, which I asked and sure enough you can bring your own wine with a minimal corkage fee.  Fine.  On to Mission Chinese.  At least the food is good.

We ordered what we loved before: Tiger Salad and Salt Cod Fried Rice.  We had the Cumin Lamb on our first visit, but it was really a plate full of sauteed onions and 4 meager pieces of lamb.  Good flavor though.  We were torn between the Beef Cheeks and Corned Beef and asked our waiter what he thought between the two.  He was CLEARLY annoyed by the question. He was like "well, both are good...it depends on what you want."  Really?  That's your response??  Seriously?  Anyway, we went with the Corned Beef.  Although tasty, it was a plate full of potatoes and a few slices of corned beef.  Why so stingy with the meat, Mission Chinese?  Oh, and we didn't get a serving spoon with our Salt Cod Fried Rice.  When asked for one, a fork was literally dropped on our table 5 minutes later.  

I would've given one star, but the Salt Cod Fried Rice bumped up the rating.  There are way too many great restaurants in SF that aren't bothered by the great business they receive and are happy to serve their guests.  Attitude such as the one displayed at Mission Chinese was appalling enough to turn me away from the establishment all together.
author: Aisha W.

description: Everything Linda L. said plus the salted cod fried rice, hell, everything I have had is a tasty treat. Go early and don't have a group over five peeps unless you like to wait. Smoked 3x Chinese Bacon...yep!
author: Joe Bob J.

description: I've only ordered take out from here once, but it was stellar. Salt cod fried rice and eggplant were yummy. Ma po tofu was the best I've had since visiting China -- super spicy and well-flavored with pork.
author: Casey S.

description: tiger salad, rice porridge, and a pound of crawfish delivered home within the estimated 45 minutes! It was all gobbled up by two folks with no leftovers.  A truly delish meal after a long day at work!
author: Jenny K.

description: If you like mediocre food,  a foul-smelling dining room and amateur service, you'll love this place!
author: TJ Z.

description: We heard a lot about this place but it was a bit of a let down. The food is pretty one note. You could definitely do much better in SF.
author: e c.

description:
one of my bffs took me here for dinner last night. i was wary at first just from him describing the the entrees. really? we're having chinese food? to which he says, but it's not your typical chinese fare. um. ok...

so we pulled up around 7 and there was a crowd on a tuesday night! we were seated in about an hour. lukily, the host told us ahead of time we could go grab a drink first elsewhere and we won't lose our spot. 

we ordered: 
savory egg custard - if you like ocean/fishy sea water, this is for you. sadly, not for me. bleh. it's a cold dish, with sea urchin on a silky tofu (custard) like base in fishy, fishy clear broth. 

Tea-Smoked Eel - it was like a "rice roll" but with eel and the crunch of celery. the sauce gave it a little something extra. didn't love it, but it was worth a try. 

Brocolli Beef Cheek - they were out of beef cheek and were using "steak". It wasn't cubes of steak, but whatever they did to it... it was super tender.  not your typical brocolli beef with oyster sauce, that's for sure. for starters, there were actual oysters in the dish!

Salt Cod Fried Rice - If you've ever had salted fish and chicken fried rice, this is not the same thing. but good.  it was the most normal thing we had last night.

OVERALL, i can say that everything was a VERY different and unique take on what I'm use to for typical chinese food. It was worth a try and I'd probably go back to try a few other things (mouth watering chicken, char siu pork belly, ma po tofu that every table seem to have, long beans).  Portions were fairly generous, given we both were able to have enough for lunch today... 

If you love "chinese" food and want to opt for something more... adventurous? give this place a shot. you'll either love it or hate it. 

me? I think i'll give it another go.
author: Milly S.

description: Been here several times for lunch, dinner and take out. Was waiting for that blown away moment that I've been reading/hearing about so much lately. Being a devout lover of Chinese food in all it's forms, I am sad to say that I really don't love this place. The food is ok, def not great. Have tried everything on the menu. Most dishes taste alike, heavy on the sichuan pepper and other chilies, greasy and a lot of onion. Don't get me wrong, love all those elements, just expect a lil more from one of the best Chinese spots in the country. Feel like this is a spot for "wide eyed westerners" to feel like they are getting authentic cultural food in an environment they are comfortable in.
author: I D.

description: Hard to find due to old signage but well worth it.  Creative takes on classic dishes will satisfy many, even those who typically may shy away from chinese...ambiance lacks but food and service more than makes up for it...only disapointment is we wont be able to enjoy it every week as we are back home in South Carolina where Chinese food is bad at best.
author: chris g.

description:
so my bbf and i came here on a saturday at about 6:30. we put our names down and go for a drink at a nearby bar. the wait was going to be an hour or so. they have a fair system with the name calling. if they call your name and you are not there, they will high light your name and once you get back, you let them know and they will give you the next available table. so no worries about missing your place in line.

please keep in mind that you are not going to be getting authentic chinese food. their style of cooking is very closely similar to szechwan style type of chinese cuisine. they use  A LOT of spices in every dish and it is pretty unique. definitely worth trying at least one if not twice.

no lets get down to the nitty gritty, the 2 of us ordered:

 1)west lake rice porridge- this "jook" was sooo satisfying! it was just the right proportion of liquid to rice. if you like porridge, this is a must get!
 
2)ma po tofu- this dish wasn't spectacular and i wouldn't get it again
 
3)thrice cooked rice cake- this was surprisingly good. i dont like bitter melon but i couldn't really tell it was in there. it was flavorful!
 
4)salt cod fried rice- ppl complain how they don't really see the cod pieces, but if you know anything about salty cod, you only need a little to make the rice flavorful. they can't put more salty cod in the rice because then the rice will be too salty. the cod is not really the main feature of the dish as how the way it makes the rice taste is. so if you want more fish. don't get this fried rice dish
 
5)tingly lamb noodle soup- this was great on a cold nite. the lamb wasn't gamey and the spices they used cleared my sinuses!
 
6)slow cooked char siu pork belly- this was my least favorite dish. i thought the pork belly was overcooked and dry.
 
7)the ribs (forgot the name) it came with a knife stabbed in it!- this dish is a must get!!the ribs was a jerky like texture on the outside but the meat  on the inside was very moist and tender!

i know we ordered a lot of food. even the waiter/owner came over and said to us that he was so happy to see that we wanted to try everything! shout out to him!
author: Irene L.

description: Great food when I go there in person and brave the extraordinarily long lines.  Their delivery service was a no-call no-show.  :-(
author: jonathan m.

description:
Food:  Eeh, blehh.  Oversalted, overspiced.  Almost all of the dishes I ordered were swimming in chili oil and a dumping of pepper.  And this is not to confused with good spiciness.  I LOVE heat, but it doesn't qualify as Szechuan just because you overkilled it with la yu and Sichuan peppercorn.  The pickles, which are already full of flavor in and of itself, only tasted like really salty pepper and oil.  I mean, who does that?!?

What I ordered: 
Ma Po Tofu - too much pepper and chili oil
Islamic Lamb Hot Pot - too much chili oil 
Szechuan Pickles - too much pepper and chili oil
Salt Cod Fried Rice - too much pepper
Baby Choy Sum - the only decent dish I ate and no chili oil and pepper!
Seared Turnip Cake - not available

Service:  I know they just got started, but it's not like they haven't done this before.  And really, the hired help needs some major training.  All of them were running around like chickens with their heads cut off, moving around, but not actually doing anything productive.  

I call for take-out, and the girl who answered sounded like she had no idea what items were on the menu.  The turnip cake turned out not to be an option.  No reason, just not like they sold out  or anything.  She tells me food would be ready to pick up in 10 minutes.  Got there in 20.  Nobody knew what my order was.   Apparently the girl hadn't remembered or bothered to put down my name with my order.  It's a bad sign when you see 20 paper order slips scattered across the cash register with the staff having no clue which order they belonged to.   Had to repeat 5 times.  After 10 minutes of "looking" for my order, I was told it would be ready in another 10 minutes.  Ok, so I decide to get a few items from the Duc Loi market.  Make it back in 10.  Had to wait another 5 minutes before being helped.  And guess what, I had to repeat my order again.  Two more times.  

Overall:  Not impressed.  I don't see how this is anything above what you'd find in a typical Chinese joint in SF.  Oh wait a minute, it's actually worse because of the shoddy service and the lousy food that I couldn't believe was food, let alone good Chinese food, because all I could taste was pepper and oil.  

What a shame.
author: Eve C.

description:
I find it revealing that some reviewers of this restaurant have to prove JUST how multicultural they are by proclaiming themselves to be experts in Chinese food and will brag about how this is Chinese food and that is not). Now I am all for cross cultural exchange, and one accessible way is through food but you don't see me declaring myself  to be the expert on authentic Ethiopian food, Mexican food, or Korean food. Bottom line is, unless you grew up in that culture and have access to all its nuances, you do not know enough to proclaim yourself as an expert. It's okay not to be so worldly and experts in everything, even Anthony Bourdain (as he usually goes to "exotic" places and experiences cultures not his own), he can still fully enjoy the food and experience. Because even as a so called expert and food writer, he has the intelligence and humility not to fall into that "I am an expert in ______ culture".) 

Likewise, I found Kelly A.'s review to be offensive in her xenophobia and stereotyping. Now she admits she does not like Asian food for the high salt (valid from a health standpoint) and "scary" factor (totally xenophobic and racist).  I can tell you that 99.9% of Chinese restaurants in America serve nothing more scary than what you see in an Italian or French restaurant. Once in a while there will be a restaurant that serves items like turtle, frog, ostrich but there is rarely "weird meat" out there-- what's next, is she going to conjure up visions of opium dens and stories of white slavery in Chinatown?

Now that I have gotten that off my chest, the food was decent. The mapo tofu was good but there is much better (and truly spicy) Sichuan food at Z & Y in Chinatown, Panda Country on Geary, and Little Sichuan in San Mateo. We did quite a bit of eavesdropping on the tables around us and everyone was raving about how big the portions was for the price and how it was soooo authentic! Umm, not really. It was bigger compared to places like Slanted Door that serves you tiny plates at $15 a pop but compared to most Chinese restaurants, the prices were about $2 too high per item and the portions maybe 30% smaller. (We only ordered off of the Mission Chinese Food menu and not the Leung San menu.) The peking duck chinito was tasty and a spin on a very similar Cantonese breakfast dish, which had all the same ingredients but the duck. The soup was tiny, even at $5 but tasted alright. Props to the restaurant for at least not charging us for staples such as tea and an extra bowl of rice which they will do at some hipsterfied establishments. Service was especially slow for us as the waitress for our area spent half of her time chatting up her friends at the next table and regaling them with her travel itinerary. And she did this while the restaurant was very busy and everyone else was running around. But, when she did come to our table, she was all right. 

So do I have anything against people that like this place? No, the food was decent and everyone has a right to how they liked the food but please stop there. You have nothing more to prove. And as for someone's opinion that this is "foodie" Chinese food, in my experience, this was not. There are other places if you want "foodie" Chinese food. The food was decent but its popularity is greatly helped by the hipster oh-let's-be-ironic decor and the pompous confirmation it gives to some reviewers of their expertise in other people's cultures.
author: Empress C.

description: It's fine. It's sort of expensive. The food is almost interesting. Sitting inside is terrible. The wait is excessive. But apparently something clicked- I guess they're opening one in New York?
author: Jake W.

description:
Finally made it to MCF on the 30th of March. Our party arrived at 6:30 and the wait was  minimal. We Promptly were seated and were salivating over the menu. Our table of 4 ordered a bunch of entrees
 entrees including Egg Custard, Kung Pao Pastrami, Brocoli Beef Cheek, Mongolian Long beans, Salt cod fried rice, Ma Po tofu and Sizzling Cumin lamb. I Really liked the Salt cod fried rice,and 
Pastrami but the rest was just okay. When they say it is hot, get ready to fan yourself off to coolness. I might be back and am gald I got to experience the hype of this place but I will not be rushing back soon.
author: Sarah N.

description:
Finally got around to trying this place.

Lines started even before they opened at 5!  Was excited but was a bit disappointed.  Don't get me wrong, the food was actually pretty good.  But, it was something I'd be able to get any many San Francisco chinese restaurants.  

I thought I'd get something way more out of the box especially the salt cod fried rice... nothing special in my mind.

For people who don't usually have good chinese, this place will be very good though.
author: Victoria L.

description: Mission Chinese Food in my opinion is only a place for locals who love their Chinese food on the heavier side. It is definitely not for diners who eat light. Dishes here are very heavily salted and spicy. My favorite was the oxtail crab porridge and the egg custard with uni and roe. Szechwan cuisine is not my favorite type of chinese food because it usually is way too heavy for my palette but I can see why people would like this restaurant. Definitely not a restaurant I would drive from out of town to eat here again. Not fit for all Asians.
author: Stanley C.

description: Somewhat disguised and hard to find, but I guess that's what makes it cool! MC looks like a regular Chinese spot, but do not be fooled. The food is fierce and firey. The simple peanuts dressed with vinegar and soy sauce was delicious and highly addictive, combing a stronger salty with a more meek sweet. For me, the beef brisket was a tad too smoked. However I was delighted by the ma po tofu, which proved to be spicy, laced with cumin scallion. I would definitely go back to try other items and can only hope they reopen the NYC location.
author: Pamela N.

description: long time for delivery, but worth the wait. spicy green beans so good you remember them the next day.
author: donkey d.

description:
My husband and I made a much anticipated visit to Lung Shan and now all we are talking about is going back.
We had the sweet and sour cucumbers, the salt cod fried rice and the pork jowl with winter radishes. Everything tasted great, subtle yet flavorful. They were busy but their staff was very attentive and we didn't have to wait for anything.
Great place.
author: Cris P.

description:
This was my third visit over the course of a week - needless to say, I'm a fan.  Locale leaves a bit to be desired - I can't tell if it's appropriate or just plain dingy.  

First visit - Ma Po Tofu, Szechuan Pickles.  Ma Po Tofu was excellent: fiery and rich, the Berkshire pork showed especially well.  Would have liked some flower pepper, though.  Szechuan pickles were less impressive - good kick with the flower and chili peppers, but a little too acidic for me.  

Visit II - Szechuan Chicken Wings, West Lake Rice Porridge.  Wings were fine - it's hard for me to not like anything fried szechuan-style.  Porridge was AWESOME - great rainy day comfort food.  Oxtail and dungeness lend it a lot of richness which is cut nicely by the ginger and cilantro.

Part III - Tea-Smoked Eel, Thrice-Cooked Bacon, Cumin Lamb.  Eel is definitely worth a try - eel comes wrapped in cheong fun (cool presentation), with celery (good contrast), and possibly fried noodle (good for texture).  Fun take on cheong fun.  Thrice-Cooked Bacon was equally kick-ass - great spin on nian gao (shanghai rice cake).  Spicy peppers, rich fatty pork goodness, and some slightly sweet tofu skin made for a unique and well-balanced dish.  Cumin lamb also had some great flavors going on (interesting presentation with huge chunks of lamb belly on bone).  The accompanying side of pickled long bean was nice (though a bit salty on its own).

It's hard to pin down what's going on here.  I don't buy Mission Chinese Food's claims of being "Americanized" per se, it's a place I'd happily take my parents and grand parents to.  It's certainly a unique take on Chinese food, borrowing from many regions.  To me, it's fun, light-hearted, and also a great take on Chinese dishes and cooking styles.  Many Chinese dishes can be a bit one-dimensional - the dishes here always have a lot going on and show great balance and depth.  Great value, too - it's quickly turning into a staple in my diet.
author: Christopher C.

description: I have been transformed.  This is the best Chinese food, outside of China, that I have ever had.  Tingly spice in all of the dishes - fresh, amazing food.  Salt & pepper prawns (think Chinese fajitas) were incredible - cumin, fennel, perfectly carmalized, kicky spice.  Lamb noodle soup - rich dark broth, toothy noodles, crispy lamb (never mind the bits of fat, just go with it).  And of course, the ma po tofu was divine.  The slow-burning spice creeps up on you over time, which makes this dish get better and better.  We'll be back, and back, and back.
author: Julie L.

description:
I'm going to go out on a limb and call this the San Francisco/California/Chinese Momofuku.  I mean that as the highest of compliments, so I hope it's not taken in the wrong way!  It's a California/American take on (mostly) Sichuanese food in the same way Momofuku is a New York/American take on Korean/Japanese food.

I'd venture to say that the Yelp reviews are MCF are so bimodal because of the difference in expectation.  If you go expecting traditional renditions of your favorite Chinese dishes, you will be sorely disappointed.  You're better off saving that experience for somewhere in the South Bay (or better yet, the SGV waaaay down south!).

That being said, I thought MCF was just outstanding.  The dishes I had were exploding with flavor.  They were also quite spicy (it helps that I absolutely loooove spicy food and the ma la quality which characterizes so much of Sichuanese cuisine).  I also thought the dishes were quite thoughtful and creative.

If you don't want to get too intellectual about it -- just go because the food is interesting and delicious.  But it's definitely not traditional.

What we've tried so far:
Egg custard with uni & trout roe - The coldness caught me by surprised even though it's in the 'cold dishes' section of the menu (duh).  Very crisp, clean, and seafood-y tasting.  If you don't like fish, steer clear of the fish roe.  The shiso was a nice and unexpected complement to the briny, fishy flavors.

Numbing lamb mien - Hand-pulled noodles had amazing flavor and texture.  Spot-on.  Spicy and numbing as promised -- but also oh-so-flavorful.  If you have a low heat tolerance, you'll probably only taste the spiciness.

Sizzling cumin lamb - Milder heat with green chiles & onions.  Speckled with whole cumin seeds, which made for a nice contrast of textures.  Lamb belly was rich and unctuous.  

Young mustard greens -- Not spicy at all.  Nicely blanched and  then tossed with minced garlic with good crunch and flavor to the greens.  Excellent complement to all the other fiery dishes we had!

Thrice cooked pork -- I was surprised to find dduk (Korean rice cakes) in a 'Chinese' dish but then again, this isn't really a traditional joint.  Fatty, spicy and delicious.  What else can I say?

Total bill (including two beers and a ginger beer):  $70 plus tip.

The wait was longer than expected (we were told '30 minutes') but it was probably closer to 40-45.  It was absolutely worth it though.  Even though the place was packed and our server was a little harried, we never felt rushed or pressured to leave, which was an unexpected bonus.

Definitely go.  Even though I'm going to call this place 'fusion,' it's not fusion like PF Changs.  It's just mouth-wateringly good.  Extra bonus points since we got to watch Danny Bowien pulling noodles in the window -- shortly thereafter, he personally brought our our cumin lab dish.  If that's not a restaurant owner pouring his heart, soul, and sweat into his establishment, I don't know what is.
author: Coco L.

description: hmm.. so apparently this place is mad hyped cuz it's a Mission hipster chinese place that donates $0.75/entree ordered to the SF Food Bank (which I am impressed by, but obviously they just mark up each dish by $0.75).  I ordered for delivery.. got the thrice cooked bacon and the broccoli beef.. both were just average.  Maybe I need to try the other dishes, but for now, this place gets 3 stars in my book
author: Toby C.

description: Really enjoyed it. Beef cheeks with broccli and asparagus was outstanding! There was even oysters in there! Tiger salad was unique and good. Also got a bunch of korean style ban chis (sp) peanuts, mild Kim chi and sweet and sour cucumbers. Noodles with the lo mein were bomb! Probably more like 3.5 stars but delivery to Nob Hill makes it an easy 4 star!!
author: Tom W.

description: Freeking amazing, serious food in a totally casual setting. Decor=0, food=10
author: Bill W.

description: I am an adventurous eater and I was thrilled to hear about such a unique twist on Chinese-American cuisine. Although the decor of the restaurant has the style of a typical Chinese restaurant in the States, the food is far from it. It is creative, thought provoking, and inventive. I had the pork dumplings with dill pickles and peanuts, kung pao pastrami, and (by the server's suggestion) the squid ink noodles in a lamb bouillon. I was blow away by the flavor combinations of squid ink, lamb, green onions, and secret spices that balanced out the dish perfectly. The menu has changed since the last time I dined there, so I am looking forward to trying the new menu items. I can't wait to see what new flavor combos the chef had in store!
author: Bianca I.

description: This place was crazy.  4.5 star crazy.  Crazy wait for a table:  over an hour.  Crazy crowded: obviously tightly packed shoulder to shoulder.  Crazy fast:  once we ordered, the food came out almost immediately. Crazy spicy: some dishes were uncomfortably spicy (long beans).  Crazy tasty:  some dishes were really tasty!:  lamb, eel, veal, pork belly, mussels, porridge, chicken rice, all very good.  (One thing was they were kinda skimpy on the lamb).  The ma po tofu was both good and overly spicy, (but not nearly as spicy as the long beans, which were straight fire in yo mouth).  Crazy competent: Service was great.  On point with everything, no complaints.  Crazy cheap: We ordered probably 2.5 times as much food as we needed, yet the total was relatively cheap.  It was kind of an ordeal to get in but it was worth it for the food and for the food-adventure experience.  I was sweating like crazy and cramped up and super full but couldn't stop eating.  (I might have been biased b/c I hadn't eaten the entire day).
author: Easter E.

description: All I know is that it takes a lot of effort to not go to the airport and hop on a plane to San Francisco when I'm craving Chinese food.  Thrice cooked bacon.  Doesn't get any better than that.  Best Chinese food I've ever had.
author: Dave F.

description: I love spicy food so this place fit the bill. Creative twists of ok'd classics give it an extra star. The chef sat next to us and we watched him put down 14 hot dogs Kobyashi style. Weird, but wonderful.
author: peter j.

description:
spicy hot going in....


spicy hot going out....


but once its out of my system, i start craving it again. 

the vicious cycle continues!
author: fina a.

description: Well, our very high expectations were met. It's a small place, and there was a wait on a Monday night, but you can BYOB. We had: cold sesame noodles (the only really average dish of the night - just bland), szechuan pickles, salt cod fried rice, broccoli beef cheek, ma po tofu, kung pao pastrami, bok choy with mushrooms and garlic, xi'an lamb, lamb cheek biang biang mien, and the "chinese" BBQ platter. It. Was. AMAZING. If you don't like spicy food, it may not be the place for you, but if you do? Damn. I really can't pick a favorite, because the dishes were all ridiculous, but I lean toward the lamb cheek noodles and the broccoli beef cheek. Though, I will also say, the BBQ brisket may have been the absolute best example I've eaten since I was in San Antonio in 2008. Go. Go now.
author: Betty R.

description: We regularly order out from here if we are in the mood for Chinese food because there aren't a lot of great choices for Chinese take-out in the Mission. Food is OK, not great. Overrated probably because there just isn't much competition in the hood. Not sure what the brouhaha is about this place and being featured in NYT and GQ.
author: marcie v.

description: This is why we live in San Franciso - amazzzing food, originally mashed-up, rooted in ancient traditions.  Somehow, even its cheesy locale (restaurant within a restaurant in a dense neighborhood) has not hindered its discovery by foodies.  BTW, their take-out was surprisingly quick, hot, and delicious, too!  It was a nice antidote to waiting in line - as they don't take reservations. Yes, it is not for the orderly here.  But bring some friends, know what to expect, and you can chat up an appetite before the full-on spicy affair!
author: W G.

description:
Here's what to expect: casual environment, possibly 90s gangster rap on the stereo, under-$10 entrees, and mind blowing flavors.

The chinito is good, but the lamb is better- it's got that vague spiciness that reminds me of having burmese food for the first time: quite unusual but so so good.  The thrice-cooked bacon is super tasty, as is their duck rice.  

If only all affordable and gritty places tasted this good...
author: Arlo J.

description:
I should explain that this is based on one experience, perhaps there are people who have a better experience. 
I'm a vegetarian, so I guess this place just isn't for me- I ordered a dish that was advertised with a vegan option. Unfortunately, what that meant is that the dish was simply radishes and garlic in soy sauce. That's 11 dollars, and is not a meal. I guess I just assumed that if something is advertised as a vegan or vegetarian option, that means that there is some food on the plate, not that they would simply give you the garnish that was around the meat. Again, I get it, this place is for meat eaters, but one shouldn't advertise something as a vegan "large dish" when it is simply radishes, or when ordering, should warn the person that their meal is a garnish.
The owner stonewalled me, said i could have a refund (as though I am about to have a delivery person drive across town to give me $11), and refused to admit that there is anything even slightly funny about the idea of charging the same amount for a large meat dish as plate of garnish. He said I am entitled to my opinion; thanks, dude, here it is, and I believe it is common sense.
Obviously this place is doing well because plenty of folks think lines=quality and salt=flavor. I will go literally anywhere else next time; maybe this place is fine for meat eaters, but they clearly aren't making an effort otherwise, and shouldn't pretend that they are.
If there are any people who can actually eat radishes and salt as a whole meal, please contact me and I will remove this review.
author: Patrick W.

description: Ma po tofu, thrice cooked bacon, salt cod fried rice - every single day I crave their food. By the way, the "tingling" sensation from the chicken is from numbing oil, used in traditional Sichuan cuisine. Can I eat here all the time? For that price point, my wallet says yes! Generous portions, incredible flavors, and philanthropic, Mission Chinese Food lives up to their reputation!
author: Vanessa L.

description: The food here is sublime. If you are worried about how crowded it is, simply have a ton of food delivered to your house (even if you live clear across the city, for a small fee).  If you think it is too expensive, well you are probably right, but it's a fun food experiment nonetheless.  I was blown away by the Tingly Lamb Soup.  The meat and noodles were fresh and of superior quality - different than any kind of Chinese food experience I have had.  The cumin lamb, broccoli beef check and long beans were also delicious and spicy, but not transcendent.  Oh yeah, and I am sucker for the Szechuan pickles.  WIsh I could try the lamb face and pork belly, but those entrees were sold out when I called.
author: Matt G.

description: This place is easily my new favorite when it comes to "Chinese" food. It's not really Chinese food, but that's the point. For purists, just file it under fusion and enjoy it. The rest of you, just enjoy it. Anyway, I appreciate authentic, but I appreciate good food even more. And the food here is pretty fantastic. Having sampled a little over half the menu, I would go for the pork belly, the eel, chicken rice, and the soba noodles as an appetizer. The tingly lamb soup is also great.
author: Martin W.

description: Best Chinese food you'll ever have.  Period.  The salt cod fried rice is outstanding and the interpretation of beef and broccoli is interesting and flavorful.  Thrice cooked bacon is smokey goodness.  Go here.
author: Bradley D.

description: This review is for delivery only.  I have enjoyed my delivery from this place a few times and the food has always arrived ahead of schedule and hot.  Tonight I was told 45 - 55 minutes, I called after 65 minutes and was told the delivery person left awhile ago and should be there shortly.  After 90 minutes I was told they were super busy and he should be there soon "busy night" but was assured food would be warm.  When it finally showed up almost 2 hours after I ordered it and was told by delivery guy 'busy night' - then why tell me 45 minutes? My food was luke warm at best and not all that flavorful. If they can't handle the orders don't take them or set more honest expecrtations, had I known they were that busy I may have chosen to not order tonight.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Recommended to me by a friend so I made the trek, as I wanted to have some good Chinese food. What I got was an unexpected surprise..not your typical Chinese fare (no Kung Pao or Moo Shu here) so I was a bit taken aback by the menu. I consider myself an adventurous diner, but I was actually a bit scared and confused as to what to order. Went the "safe route" and chose a few of the less spicy dishes..the Brisket Noodle Soup ($12) and the Crisp Pork Belly  ($9.50) .Soup was divine with fat, flat rice noodles at the bottom of the bowl, tender brisket with just enough fat, and a rich broth swimming with herbs-delicious! The pork belly was nicely presented..very crisp large 2-3" cubes or pork belly on an oyster style sauce, topped with a fresh chili and micro sprouts, with fresh pineapple on the plate as well; a bit of a play on sweet and sour. One of the neighboring tables shared some of their salt cod rice ( they found it too salty, but I liked it) and  Ma Pao tofu with us..that was awesome: thanks neighbors!  
I too liked the music selection,and  our waiter was really friendly. If you want typical Chinese, this isn't your place. If you want something different, bring a few friends and share some dishes.  It can get a bit salty as you eat the dishes, so not for those intolerant of salt.
author: Dawn B.

description: That mapo tofu is sooo spicy that it can hurt to eat it. But you eat it anyways cause it's so damn good.
author: Judy L.

description:
I want to give it 3.5 
It was good Chinese food, really really spicy. The numbing lamb face literally gave me a spice high. The chicken wings surrounded by kung pao was pretty good, lusciously red. The egg custard was a nice cool down tone to all the spice. The service was okay... the place was super busy and packed.
author: KL L.

description: What a find, not your ordinary Chinese take out. Salt cod rice, pork belly, beef cheeks w/broccoli , westlake porridge w/ ox-tail and dungeness crab, all great. I love lamb and I love bacon but I didn't care too much for the thrice cooked bacon (too spicy and cloying sweet) and the lamb noodle soup (too much citrus). I think its great that they deliver
author: pascual e.

description: This was a really solid restaurant.  Nice and spicy, however not overwhelming.  It really feels like a restaurant in the city.  There are lots of people.  You may even have to wait an hour or two.  The service is commendable considering the large amount of people traffic in the restaurant.  Very unique flavors: perhaps a little too salty at times.  Great place to look into if your visiting or living in the city.
author: Michael G.

description:
I loved this place. Went there for a late dinner expecting to wait for at least an hour because when we wrote our names down, our party of 4 was 11th in line. Preceding us were parties of 2 or 4 or 6 and peeking through the windows the place was already packed. But we must have timed it well because some parties dropped out or wandered away missing their call and we actually got in within 20 minutes.

The dining area was small and very eclectic with the white tiny holiday lights decorating the walls and the long cloth dragon suspended over the length of the ceiling. Odd that rap music was playing in the background. The diners were in their 20's to 30's but I didn't feel awkward being the senior patron of the establishment for the evening. Even though the tables were pretty much nestled so close together you had to skinny up to walk through, when we sat we did not feel crowded at our table. 

Daughter had been here a couple times before and recommended the BBQ platter which had 3 different types of pork and a perfectly poached egg adorning each side of the platter. I saw a dish of bok choy on one of the tables and ordered that and being such a common dish, this was so flavorful with the garlic chives and mushrooms and cooked to perfection....not soggy or limp. The pork belly was classified as a small plate on the menu but there were 4 huge portions on the plate and it was crispy and melted in your mouth at the same time. The salt and pepper shrimp was done with whole shrimp so there was no excuse not to suck all the spices and flavoring before ripping off the head and the shell to eat the meat. We also had the pork dumplings in the hot and sour broth and the best way to eat it was to make sure you slurped some of the broth while eating the dumpling. Steamed white rice and tea rounded out our meal. I was surprised at how large the portions were for each dish. I had assumed it being asian fusion that the size would be smaller and am glad to have been wrong. 

I would be happy to eat here everyday so that I can select all the other items on the menu. I don't know if they offer up new dishes daily but Daughter said there were different options from when she had dined here previously. I had expected this place to be overhyped but it is not and if you have to wait in line, it is worth it.
author: Lily L.

description:
This place is pretty good. Stumbled upon it while searching for something to quickly eat. The atmosphere was really interesting. Lots of young and kinda trendy (ahhahaha) waiters while the cooks and register lady were old and asian. 
Not a TON of options for vegetarians, but what could I expect after the meat slicing table was in the front facing the street where everyone could see passing by. 
Ordered the tofu, and cold noodle salad with a side of the vinegar peanuts. The peanuts were heavenly although kind of awkward to eat. 
All of the other dishes were great too, and had really interesting modern flavors for Chinese dishes. I would recommend maybe going with a lot of friends so you can sample a lot of the dishes, and go if you eat meat because the meat dishes looked wonderful even though I don't eat meat. Only four stars because it was super loud in there and because I wish they had more veggie options.
author: Cherish P.

description:
i really enjoyed the food here.  the mission chinese food peeps take over the lung shan chinese restaurant kitchen, so it's operating as two restaurants using one kitchen.  you can order off both menus, but i would take a stab at the mission chinese food menu first.  

last time i was there, they were cooking up some spicy szechuan food.  i believe they rotate their menu.  my favorites were mapo tofu, pork belly, spicy chicken wings, salted cod fried rice.  

the mapo tofu had pretty complex flavors for such a simple dish.  it's not just hot and spicy!  try it and let me know what you think.  

the pork belly dish was SUPER good, crispy outside and tender pork.  im not a huge pork belly person, but i thought it was quite good.  i just can't get over eating the fatty part!  bleh.  

the spicy chicken wings were also very good. deep fried chicken wings wok friend with whole dried whole red peppers.  it will look like a plate of peppers, but just dig a bit and you'll find the chicken wings.  

the cumin lamb was OK, not that flavorful.  it comes out fajita style, on a sizzling platter.  i just wish it tasted better! 

the salted cod fish fried rice was yummy too.  i think i polished this dish off!  it's a spin on the cantonese traditional salted fish fried rice.  i just LOVE fried rice in general, so i don't know if i can give a good review for this.  i liked it a lot.  :)

3.75 stars for this place
author: Wendy S.

description: The five stars is for the food, but I want to put in a note about the  ambience. I've always loved the food here- been here several times and hadn't had this problem before, but this past Thursday night when I was there with some friends, the music was turned up so high that it felt like we were in a dance club. Impossible to talk amongst ourselves. We asked the staff several times to lower the volume and they did for a few minutes and turned it up again. Too loud- very, very annoying. Anyway, the food is absolutely awesome- egg egg noodle, thrice cooked bacon, lamb dumplings and the mapo tofu- divine!
author: Tripthi K.

description: Had this place on my list for a while and FINALLY went. The cold Dan Dan noodle dish was perfect to start. The Tsing Taos went well with the mild spicy kickkk. Then I also had the chicken rice plate. Very tasty and would have been happy to eat it as leftovers but I ate the whole damn thing! The service was great and there's a guy making noodles at the front. YEAH!
author: Rachel S.

description: I went there yesterday, got the Mapo Dofu & Salt Cod Fried Rice.  It was disappointing.  The Mapo Dofu was crunchy - not a texture I like with that dish.  On further inspection, it was star anise & peppercorns, I took them out.  The star anise was enough to destroy any complexity of taste in the dish.   Heat does not equate good Chinese food all you white folks!  And neither does foodie ingredients like kurobuta  pork & the novelty of salt cod.  Though I appreciate the efforts on inventiveness,  neither dish was a ground breaker.  I have long awaited someone to make reasonably priced Chinese food where I don't have to worry that I have just eaten a weeks worth of fat & mystery ingredients.
author: Sunset S.

description: I thought it was ok, maybe cause didn't order a lot, and i'm cheap , salt cod fried rice was good, like all fried rice, we had chicken wings, they alright, and my cousin got like #22 some noodle thingy, dont get it, super oilly like 1 inch in oil, and doesn't taste great, i wanted to try one of the noodles, but they only serve for dinner. It alright, maybe i didn't know what to order, but was in ny times so got to try it.
author: David L.

description: I write this with a heavy heart as I was hoping to love this place. This could possibly be the worst meal I have EVER eaten.. The general  tso's veal ribs were burnt to a crisp - not able to get the meat off the bone. The bacon/rice cake dish was SO salty - that my blood pressure went through the roof after one bite. The lamb dumplings and the green beans had to be thrown out after a few well intentioned attempts to enjoy. There is no reason for Asian inspired food to be this bad in San Francisco. Even though there is a ton of buzz about this restaurant - I suggest you avoid at all costs or at the very least consider yourself warned!
author: durand G.

description:
Whats with the negative reviews? What is not to like about this place?

Ok, so first off, this place isn't traditional chinese food. Nor is it the typical americanized chinese food. It is more like chinese inspired cooking and is damn good.

4 of us, about 16 bucks each. We left all full and all very pleased. This place far exceeds its price tag. I loved the beef cheeks, pork jowl, pork belly. The thrice cooked bacon I didn't enjoy as much, it was a bit smokey for me. The veggies in that dish were definitely awesome though.

The quality of ingredients used at this place are clearly top notch. They must go to great lengths to secure prime ingredients, and it shows.

Atmosphere is casual. I was there on a saturday night, accidentally got there 30 minutes before they open (open at 5) so killed some time nearby before we went back about 5:05. There were only a few tables left at that point. We  sat down and the remaining tables filled up within about 5 minutes. There is a steady stream of traffic going to this place, its clearly popular (the # of yelp reviews they get would confirm this). I commend them for so far staying down to earth and simple and just sticking to creating a very high quality product for a decent price and without pretension.
author: Josh R.

description:
Disgusting Period.

If i threw $60 down the drain I would feel better.

More fat than meat in every dish.

The only good thing about this place was on time delivery.
author: Artur L.

description: A GEM!  So great to be able to eat "different" Chinese food.  Love that we could share tables with strangers, nice enough to share with us what little we were unable to order. (We reciprocated of course).  Love it here!
author: g m.

description: We went a little later than standard dinnertime, and only waited for 20 minutes for a table for 2.  We got the lamb dumplings, Kung Pao Pastrami and Squid Ink Noodles.  All the food was great, but we liked the Squid Ink Noodles better than the Kung Pao Pastrami - it wasn't what we expected, though I can't really be sure of what we expected to be totally honest.  Overall, a cool and delicious dining experience everyone should check out when visiting SF!
author: Denise G.

description:
We are regulars and get take-out from here often. Favorites include the spicy lamb noodle soup, the fried rice, and the ma po tofu. Last week, we ordered our usual and were really bummed about the change in the ma po tofu. What's up with the pork chunks? The seasoning is all the same, fantastically mouth-tinglingly szechuan pepper spicy, but we missed the ground kurobuta pork. Please bring it back Mission Chinese!!! Or, hopefully it was just an off night because the lamb dish we ordered last week came out as ribs with very little meat and not the seasoning that had been on the menu. 

The restaurant does play some good music for a Chinese restaurant but may need to change up its playlist a little (I know, can't have it all). But, if you've been there a few times, or go regularly, you'll hear some of the same old school R&B again. I'd much prefer having the ground kurobuta pork again and would gladly forgive the music repeats when you bring that back. ;)
author: Tina Z.

description: Not a fan. Low quality meats, extremely greasy. Left feeling ill.
author: Harrison F.

description: Love this spot.  The dishes are unique and fresh, different from typical "American" Chinese food.
