This is a great place to come with a small group and mix and match your dishes - most everything is served family style.  Tingly lamb = the bomb.  Great hand-made dumplings, and I love their soups.  The seating area is small, and they don't take reservations, so get there early or be prepared to wait.  Definitely worth trying - the food here is inspired and affordable.  Looking forward to my next visit already, mmmmmm....
author: Jenna C.

description: visit # 5 with 7 diners (dishes with ratings)...2 Tiger salads- 5; 2 pickles- 4; Hainam Rice- 5, 2 Pork Belly with soy eggs- 5; salt cod fried rice -5; wild pepper greens -6!!! egg custard 3; thrice cooked bacon with bitter melon & rice cakes 5; Mongolian long beans with chili 5; chicken wings with chilies 5; smoked brisket 3/4....long wait.. almost 1 hour ...went to Cha Cha Cha for drinks..brought 1/2 bottle of wine back no problem!!! our table right under music a bit loud host was nice and turned it down.  Except 4 me... all other eaters first timers..every body wants to return..great night!!! next time skip brisket (a bit  sweet  but good just didn't fit well with other stuff), ,pickles, egg custard...will maybe try smoked eel, pig ears.....good value about $25/person with enough leftovers for 2
author: Bob W.

description: I like when steam starts coming out of my boss' ears and his face turns all red. This usually occurs when he eats really spicy food. Maybe I am sadist when I laugh at people in pain. What if I am, sue me. That being said the food was good too. The peking duck chinito was pure genius!
author: Sophia C.

description:
meh.  in the words of randy jackson, it was just aiight for me.

on a menu that small, nothing should be a throwaway dish.  

sorry hipsters, i think i want a real chinese restaurant please.
author: Linda L.

description:
Ordered 5 dishes for take out. 

Dan Dan Noodles - good. spice sneaks up on you.
Long Beans - good. spice hits you over the head with a 2x4. 
Mapo Tofu - ok. flavor profile strays a little too far from the original.
Hainam Chicken rice - off the hook! 
Beef Cheeks - really good!
author: Ryan S.

description: This rating is based on the notion that we didn't choose wisely and ordered all really spicy food that we weren't prepared for... So I'm giving myself two stars for being a newbie and not ordering a more palatable selection... Will go back and try again for sure...otherwise, I can see this being a 4 star place.
author: Matthew S.

description:
The most over-hyped restaurant in San Francisco this year. 

Pros: cheap, massive portions, interesting flavor profile, delivery

Cons: long wait, servers don't seem happy (overworked?), big portions make it hard to try multiple things if you are just with one person, hole in the wall ambiance is fine starting out, but maybe someone could go to Ikea considering all the press and make the place a little more presentable.

I might order delivery for the Salted Cod Fried rice, but never again will I take an out of town guest to this place. There are far too many restaurants in this city with amazing food and a little effort in the appearance.
author: Courtney s.

description: Food is excellent. Bad reviews are from people locked into their Grandmother's "authentic" cooking style. Total Bottle Shock mentality.
author: Bib G.

description:
Awesome food. Thought-provoking, life-affirming & easy on the wallet. 

Service is pretty bad, or rather overworked given the place's popularity. I don't mind though, given how delicious the food is. Get a beer and hang out. Share your dishes and eat them as they come out. 

Hipsters don't go there cause other hipsters go there-- they go there because it is delicious.
author: Stephan M.

description: Giving the four stars solely based on the salted cod fried rice. So simple, delicious, and flavorful. This will definitely be a go to dinner in a pinch. Also tried the Tiger Salad and Don Don noodles. They were decent, but nothing to write home about.
author: Heidi K.

description: would definitely go back, but not wait in line as long as we did..about 40 min.  the place prob looks more desirable because of the line outside, but in truth, it's a tiny place.  other reviews report how ridiculously spicy the food is.  i disagree.  it has some heat, but it's about right.  the menu is kind of strange and you will likely be surprised that what you thought it would look and taste like; doesn't.  its a good surprise.  you will dine family style so bring some friends and order a variety of stuff so all will get a bite of the best thing. they do a big take out business, so if you live in the area, that would be the way to go.  beware..it's loud thumpy urban music in the background and dimly lit...kind of masks the "grunge" factor that you definitely would notice otherwise.  a bit of grunge doesn't bother me, but it may you.
author: Howard B.

description: The food here is phenomenal. I live in LA, and get exposed to a lot of regional Chinese cuisine in the San Gabriel valley. It is cool to see a lot of those regional dishes (Cumin Lamb from Xinjiang province! The best) combined onto one menu, executed with creativity and technical precision, and made with well-sourced ingredients. They should get an extra half star for playing loud gangsta rap music and letting us drink four lokos after service.
author: joel w.

description: I heard a lot about it so we went.  Food was ok. Pricey for what we got. I lived in China and I know Mission Chinese is doing their own take on some classic dishes and flavors, but it doesn't hold up to the original. I'm not a purest at all, I like a creative twist, they just don't it all that well. Service was fine. i won't be back. Just not that good.
author: Richard F.

description: Amazing, Amazing, Amazing...worth the wait...though I'd go next door to to the corner grocery and get a brown bag beer while you are standing outside.  Everything on the menu is delicious.
author: Austin C.

description: First of all, mega-hearts for delivering to the Haight. You made my work-at-home day so much better. Food-wise, this review is based on two dishes, the dumpling soup and the Ma Po Tofu with rice. Both delicious. I'm used to dousing Chinese food with flavor and spice but one look at the neon blood-red bath of tangled greens, tofu, and mushrooms in the (generous) tub of Ma Po Tofu told me, "hey guy, maybe skip the saucing this time." It didn't need anything. Total spice O.D. Hunger sated. Leftovers remain.
author: Alee K.

description: Friday, August 2nd, early take out dinner: porridge had too many herbs, the new rice dish was under seasoned, and the Ma Po Tofu had so many peppercorns it was unpleasantly bitter. What's going on over there? Your food usually rocks.
author: leyla a.

description: We got here around 5 pm on a weekday, so there was no wait. The food was decent. The pork belly is something you must try if you don't mind a bit of fat. The service was good. Hot tea comes from a tea bag.
author: Eddie L.

description: I was excited to try this place out since I remember it got a little buzz awhile back and I know a famous chef has eaten here. I appreciate that it's Chinese food that takes a chance to be a little different however I'm not sure if that merits the price of it's meals. I got the salt cod fried rice which was good but to be honest I don't know how this is different than fried rice with Chinese sausages.  It didn't seem to have a lot of cod for me to say that it should be called "Salt Cod Fried Rice". I also ordered the "Sour Chili Chicken" which was tasty and I really liked that it had potatoes.  My least favorite was the "Ma Po Tofu" which I have to admit wasn't bad.  It's just the dish that didn't get finished.  The problem for me is the price. I ordered take out for 3 entrees that cost me 43 bucks.  I called it in and food was ready when I came by so service was not an issue. I will most likely come back to try the bacon dish but I do not see me as a regular customer. The dishes are not worth the price and the taste profiles from the dishes I tried doesn't venture too far to prevent me from going to a cheaper Chinese food restaurant.
author: Jazmin J.

description: Consistently exciting food. While the service and sticky plastic table vibes leave much to be desired, it doesn't matter. Come for explosive flavors, unique pan-Chinese mash ups.  Tingling lamb noodle soup, Kung Pao pastrami, Salt Cod Fried rice - all smashing successes.
author: M J.

description: I think this place is more hype than awesome.  While there are some interesting combinations for fusion Chinese food, it is ultimately too salty and I left the place extremely thirsty.  I went with a friend and we ordered the salt cod fried rice, mapo tofu, chongqing chicken wings and the tea smoked eel.  The best dishes that we had were the fried rice and chicken wings. The mapo tofu was much too salty and the tea smoked eel was very disappointing.  The hygiene of the restaurant was a bit sketchy too. My napkins had stains on it and had to ask for fresh ones from the waiter. Plus, I was snuggly seated at a table family style right in the middle of a long rectangular table. The random person sitting to my left was sick and coughing a lot which made me a bit paranoid about getting sick.  Lastly, I had a view of their not so clean kitchen throughout dinner since it's hard not to stare into a bright kitchen from a dark dining room.
author: Kai C.

description:
Offers unique Chinese dishes that keep me coming back for more.  I have never had a bad experience at Mission Chinese and have tried several of the menu items.  Great veggie options and good portion sizes.  

After living in China for several years, I've been looking for a place that offered an eclectic flavor to authentic dishes.  I found it here!  I love that when they say HOT they really mean HOT!  Not like most places that cater to the Western palate.  

The only thing that sucks is the queue out the door.  But, I've started to  call my order in and pick it up on my way home.. perfect!
author: AdeleAdele S.

description: I had a so-so experience at Mission Chinese. I'm excited for the concept and plan on returning very soon but I definitely need to try different dishes. Folks, get your spicy taste buds ready. Whoooo boy, I was close to asking for a glass of milk! The menu descriptions should be much more explicit with the spiciness levels. I was fully prepared for the hotness of the tofu dish but the lamb hot pot was a shocker. Even my Indian friend couldn't handle the heat from both dishes (it's ok, he lets me stereotype him). When I return, I'm hitting up the mongolian beef and roast chicken. Or maybe I'll just order five plates of the peking duck and call it a day.
author: Susan L.

description:
Danny Bowien communes with God. And Buddha, and some unnamed God of BBQ that resides somewhere deep in the south. I'm on my third visit to MCF. If I could go everyday I would. 
There's a lot of hype about this place and it is true that it's loaded with hipsters that beg to be made fun of, carrying in their cans of PBR and Tecate wrapped in small brown bags and sporting expensive t-shirts that manage to look pretentious, expensive, yet all together meaningless and cheap all at once. (How is it that Hipster seems to be a male identified fashion movement? Hipster chicks are somehow simply accessories with pixie cuts and skinny jeans?) But I digress...
As stated elsewhere, MCF is somewhat undercover, serving out of Lung Shan restaurant. The melamine tables and no-frills sensibility of the restaurant are rendered charming by the large parade dragon that coils around the ceiling, and the reddish glow of the paper lantern covers and dragon somehow make everything look exactly as it should in a secret Chinese hole-in-the-wall that turns out amazing chow. The whole effect is made somewhat surrealistic by the ever changing soundtrack. My first visit involved some Nick Cave and Lou Reed, The second was hip-hop and tonight was apparently Katy Perry remix night, What?
Unless you go during the day, be prepared for a wait. Don't pout, don't whine, just put your name on the list and enjoy the wildlife viewing of the Mission until your name gets called. We waited quite a while, and the smell wafting out of the door as diners came and went was nearly maddening. At some point 30+ minutes into the wait, the door opened and a bolt of light from heaven revealed the man himself, Danny Bowien, bearing a steaming plate of pulled pork trotters and a pile of forks. "You guys have been waiting a while, share it around out here". I stood there like I'd won the lottery. I held the plate and passed the love along. It was a glorious mess of pork happiness atop a layer of white bread soaking up the saucy deliciousness and a side of fresh pickled cucumber and onion. Our entire wait simply melted away and the goodwill amongst waiting guests was palpable.

The food is supernal. Tonight was my other mother's birthday, we planned on ordering a lot of food with the intention of taking leftovers home, and we executed that plan with the precision and aplomb of a Gay spandex clad drill-team. (ok, not as many leftovers as we thought)

The service is fast and friendly, the servers busy, but gracious. We started out with the pickled vegetables. My mom slurped the pickling juice out of the bottom of the bowl it was so good. The Lion's Head meatball is the stuff that Cup o' noodles dreams of growing up and being, if Cup O' Noodles dreamed of being a neurosurgeon spice merchant adventurer who models for Vogue on the side. The Hainam Chicken rice is creamy, mild, understated and rich. The smoked eel left my husband begging. The chili chicken wings came in a sea of chili pods so dense that you had to dig to even see the wings. Like little buried treasures, the slightly metallic tang of the chili's on the thin perfectly crisp skin passed quickly into a long, slow tingle that lasted the duration of the meal but never interfered with the other dishes. The Char-siu pork belly was a textural masterpiece of dense meaty pork and ethereally light fat. I'm sure that fat layer took an entire day off of my lifespan and I don't care, It was worth it. The tea smoked egg on the side had a runny yolk that was so creamy and delish I'll be trying to figure out how they did it for weeks. We got the Ma Pa Tofu which tastes like a Chinese mother re-imagining Bolognese with what she had on hand after only reading about it in culinary fairy tales.

I guess you might think the roll-back bars on the window's are for after-hours safety, but I now firmly believe it's to keep people from leaving too many nose prints on the windows. 
Go, Go now. Go often.
author: Joyce H.

description: Best Chinese( or Chinese fusion) meal ever. The food was incredibly creative and delicious and lived up to all of expectations after reading their book. Highlights were the tiki pork belly, salt cod fried rice, peanuts, and Kung pao pastrami. Notable mention was the pea leaves with pressed tofu noodles and pumpkin. Service was ok but who cares at a place like this. Don't miss this experience.
author: Jason R.

description: Great food. The flavor in the shrimp dish was unbelievable.
author: Shannon A.

description: Yes to it all.  Go with four, as the portions are large.  Simply, excellent: distinct, and rather rarified flavors combine in often surprising ways.  Service is lagged, at best.  However, the host (Owner?) was overtly apologetic in sensing our disdain for the wait.  Looking forward to eating here often.  Nothing too heavy, nothing too light.
author: James S.

description: When I first heard the name if this place, I didn't know what to think.  Really? They couldn't have come up with a better name than "Mission Chinese Food?" I ordered the pork belly and house fried rice. The pork belly was amazing and oozed with flavor and grease. I think that one serving hit my heart attack preventing quota for year. The fried rice was good, but nothing special. I'll only come back for my annual pork belly craving.
author: Michael Paul C.

description: Overall, pretty damn awesome food and a good deal for the price.  The cumin lamb was definitely on the fatty side, but that didn't stop it from being delicious.  Triple-garlic eggplant was nicely spiced and, while the three types of garlic weren't noticeable, the flavor was excellent.  Perhaps the biggest surprise was the chicken rice--a mundane sounding dish that packed a tremendously rich, meaty flavor in every bite.  How they accomplish this with rice is beyond me, but I can only assume that they simmer it in chicken fat.  Oh yeah, and the spicy pickles are respectable, too.  Napa cabbage has rarely tasted so good.  The service was prompt and unremarkable.
author: Ray L.

description: Wow!! Not really a chinese food fan, but this place blew all of my expectations out of the water. The beef cheeks melted in you mouth.  Tea smoked unagi was light and delicious. Will have to come back soon!!
author: Chris B.

description: Holy crap (can I say that here?) this was the best Chinese food I have had so far in the Bay Area. I loved everything we ordered, particularly the stupendous salted cod fried rice. Yes the wait was long, but was worth it. I've already earmarked this place as something to revisit before I fly home to Manila. Try it. It will change your life.
author: Timothy G.

description: Not worth the hype or wait.  Mediocre Chinese food at best.  Definitely would not survive or be able to compete if it were to open in "Montray" Park down in LA.  Everything was edible, but nothing was truly memorable.  I know this place is not supposed to be a traditional Chinese restaurant, but HK-style cafes in socal do Asian fusion a hell of a lot better and with more value for your money.  This establishment is best for those looking for something different or don't really know any better what Chinese food is supposed to taste like.  Not really a place to take someone from the motherland looking for a taste of home.
author: Simon L.

description: This restaurant is all hype.  The staff is obviously self-satisfied by the condescending conceit of the bare bones restaurant.  A restaurant that offers this little ambiance, and such poor service, needs to exceed expectations with the food, but it does not.  The food might satisfy would-be hipsters on a budget who prefer dishes heavy on vegetables or high on animal fat, but for the rest of us, there is very little balance.  Some plates are all green - one, a chicken wing dish, is almost all chiles - or all heavy meat.  The prices are reasonable, but there are far superior, and more authentic choices, in SF that there is no reason to come here unless you want to see or be seen, or add the visit to your hipster scorecard.
author: Henry J.

description: I've had the food delivered to my house 5 times now (so I can't review the ambiance of the place).  It's my favorite dive restaurant by far. The best way to describe this food is Asian fusion, as in a mix of various flavors from all over Asia with the predominant theme being Chinese.  Everything is hot here, so beware, even the food labeled not hot.  The spiciest I can go is one chilli pepper.  Delivery service is a bit spotty, once it took an hour and a half and another time 1/2 hour, so patience is required but also well rewarded.
author: Gisela S.

description: No MSG and yet really authentic and flavorful with most of the dishes being real departures from the predictable standard options for US-based Chinese restaurants. The waiter was polite and spoke excellent English. Service was fast. Not the most sumptuous interior decor, for sure, but this place is definitely worth better than the 3.5 stars average it got when I wrote this review. I plan to go back... often.
author: Victoria B.

description: i'm not gonna lie, i had damn high expectations for this place before i actually took a bite of their offerings...and the 45+ min wait only elevated them. sadly they did not come close to what i had envisioned how my taste buds would react upon contact with the food. not to say the food wasn't good, it just wasn't that good to garner SO much praise from countless reviews, magazine mentions, news articles, the list goes on. I've probably read and heard about mission chinese food from 30+ sources! i just can't justify it. there are so many restaurants in the city that make really good chinese food and never get the recognition they deserve, or maybe just a peep from sfgate. kinda unfair imo, but hey i'm just the average joe patron. you give this place a try and decide for yourself. just make sure to come for late lunch or early dinner to avoid the dreaded wait.
author: Melissa Y.

description: This place looks like a dive from the outside, and the owners still have the signage form the previous owners as we understood.  Once you get inside, it still looks like a dive, but it's clean and the service is friendly.  They have community seating and a few four-tops in the dimly lit restaurant.  We ordered the Black Vinegar Peanuts to start, then moved onto the Kung Pao Pastrami and the Salted Cod Fried rice.  I think the dishes could be best characterized as authentic Chinese flavor meeting contemporary creativity.  The peanuts were tasty and fun to eat with chopsticks, definitely a salty dish, but good if you don't mind salt.  The salted cod fried rice was full of flavor, but since it didn't have much salted cod if we went again we'd probably set that aside as a family style side.  The Kung Pao Pastrami was so good it almost pushed this to a five-star review.  Aggressively spiced with chili oil, but the perfectly tender Pastrami and a melange of peppers, chilies, onions, and roasted peanuts made an excellent combination.   $10 corkage and good deals on beer.  We'd probably pass on the house sake next time, but there definitely will be a next time.
author: Stephen P.

description:
Service was better than previous reviews during my visit Sunday, August 28th for lunch. We were sat within 10 minutes, order taken within 5 and food came out fast.

My problem was with the sanitation of this place. Chopsticks came out with leftover food from the previous guests stuck on the tips. Spoons, cups and plates were also suspect in cleaning standards. Bathroom was a health hazzard.

Food was as follows - Beef Cheeks and Broccoli was very flavorful, but fatty and a little salty. Cumin Lamb was all bone, but bursting with flavor. Chicken Wings were a complete mis-fire, but Salt Cod Fried Rice was the star of the day, I could not stop eating it.

Our "too cool for school" Chef kept running out for groceries during our visit which was interesting because they were out of many items by the time we sat down. Dining Room was packed with MCF groupies, so this place will do well for a very long time until everyone grows up and figures out that the place is a dump with off the wall Chinese soul food.
author: Lucy B.

description: Ma Po Tofu: Bleccchhh!
author: Jeff J.

description:
The thrice cooked bacon (sans bacon for me!) is the stuff dreams are made of. I wish I could eat here every day without gaining 500lbs. You also get a lot of food for the price. One dish is enough for two people, but if you're like me, you'll want it all to yourself.

It's always busy, so be prepared to wait a little while, but it's totally worth it.
author: Emily W.

description:
Come here if you are looking for something that kind of reminds you of Chinese food, but don't come here expecting to find the familiar comfort Chinese food flavors if you grew up with them like I did.  I should've known that when I realized I was the only Asian customer in the nearly 80% occupied restaurant.  My biggest issue was the excessive usage of chili pepper/jalapeño.  It made me wonder:  are they using the chili to mask the lack of depth in their dishes' flavors? 

1)  Slow Cooked char siu pork belly 
-The dish came with 5 pieces of pork belly beautifully cooked.  It's fatty and flavorful.  Unfortunately, portion was cut too big.  I felt sick after having half of 1 piece.  In other restaurants where I enjoyed similar dish, the meat would be cut more into a bite-size portion.  Tea-smoked egg was just okay.  The flavor was barely detectable after eating a couple of other [tongue-numbing] dishes.

2) Salt Cod fried rice
-one of the my two most-likable dishes of the meal.  Nicely balanced flavors.  When it first came out, cod pieces were too salty.  However, the left-over next day was much better.  Good 'day after' dish.

3) Thrice cooked bacon
-the bacon had a nice smoky flavor.  Rice cake was cooked well with a chewy bite.  Again, it was seasoned with too much chili oil that over-powered most of the ingredients.  When I was able to successfully uncover a single piece of a rice cake or bitter melon that's not overly covered by the chili oil, I was quite happy the original flavor combination (sans chili oil)

4) Taiwanese eggplant
-my favorite dish of the night.  Eggplant was cooked nicely with a wonderful balance of basil flavor.  I don't know how Taiwanese it was, but I'd say that was one dish more recognizable as Chinese food.

5) 7 chicken wings with explosive chili pepper
-imagine a large serving plate with 7 little wings on.  Then, pile on chili pepper after chili pepper until it resembles a small mountain.  To eat the wings, you have to fish them out under the big pile of pepper.  After you've consumed all wings, you wouldn't be able to tell that you didn't just simply order a large plate of chili pepper with nothing else.  Taste?  I doubt anyone tasted anything after their taste buds have been numbed by all the spiciness in all other dishes.  The skin was a bit dry & chewy... not in a good way.

6) Sizzling cumin lamb
-if I could imagine less chili oil, the flavors probably worked well.  Lamb could've been prepped more to minimize the strong "lamb" taste.
author: diana t.

description: they deliver to me. its amazing. the ma po tofu is hot and filled with meat bits and perfect red chili oil. the veal rib is meaty and delicious but the crust can get a bit tough. the fried rice is pretty great as well. the brisket noodle soup and the lamb face noodle soup are both outstanding with flavorful broth and soft noodles. and get the cumin lamb if you like food that tastes good. the only item i had that wasnt phenomenal pretty much was the tea smoked eel, which had too many conflicting textures to let the flavor of the smoked eel come through. the menu changes often enough, so these items might not be there when you go, but for the most part the chefs are really skilled and take chances with chinese food that i haven't seen in the usa before. be adventurous and prepare for food that actually brings some spice. it will most likely be well worth it.
author: Michael J.

description: The best meal that I had on my trip to San Francisco.  The Szechuan Pastrami is out of this world.  We ordered a ton of food (probably half of the menu) and everything was pretty amazing.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I grew up between Seattle and San Francisco, so suffice it to say I have eaten a great deal of Chinese fare in my life.  I've had the high-end, the greasy, dim sum, pastry, hole-in-the-wall specialties (hello Gourmet Delight BBQ!), and more.  I therefore wish to be taken seriously when I say that the Szechuan-based cuisine at Mission Chinese Food (not Lung Shan) is The Best Chinese Food I Have Ever Eaten.  The best.  Particularly when you take into account the low prices they charge for dishes you would only find at fine dining, new Chinese establishments.  Almost every single dish I've been served so far has been mouth-wateringly delicious, cooked superbly, and spiced wonderfully.  The two exceptions so far have been the Szechuan pickles, which are neither as spicy nor flavorful as I'd expect, and the Salt Cod Fried Rice, which is delicous but needs a little more salt cod in my opinion.  Yes, it's a hole-in-the-wall, and the interior is spare other than the AWESOME dragon chandelier that spans the ceiling of the room.  I don't care about decor when I have food like this that makes my soul smile.

UPDATE: The Mission Chinese Food cookbook is coming out in May!  I couldn't be more thrilled!
author: Nick B.

description: Good food and really great service over the phone. Hipsters who really get the food industry are great. Others are just annoying posers. My last order wasn't that 'chinese' so going for the other items in the short menu tonight. And they are no longer charging extra for delivery - I am just outside their zone. I'll be including it in the tip anyway. But yay.
author: Esso E.

description: Pretty American (especially the rap music), but not too greasy or salty, and the wings were awesome!
author: Paul K.

description: Beef cheeks, pork belly, lamb dumplings, pork dumplings, hot and sour soup, and Outkast on the stereo... nearly derailed by the delicious but dangerous and lip-numbing explosive chicken wings. Tshingtao beers to our rescue. Sort of.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I can't wait to go back. My favorite item was the tea smoked eel. Get there early to avoid the wait.
author: m t.

description: be prepared for the hipster foodies that like pop-up restaurants. then be prepared for the long wait, the lack of aisle space, dark lighting, and overseasoned food.
author: Julia C.

description:
so delicious.  and so hidden.  same concept as mission street food, but permanent.  You can order off of the 'traditional Chinese food' menu, which is your standard general tso's chicken, lo mein with grease type deal, or off of mission chinese food's menu.  This is the one I recommend...  different chef, different ingredients, different quality, but same affordable price.  We had the peking duck chinito (duck confit, chinese donut, hoisin sauce, delicious), the salt cod fried rice (not greasy at all, just tasty), the beef cheeks (spicy and tender) and the bok choy (fresh, crisp and served with ham).  We were pleasantly full, incredibly happy, and out only $35.  I cannot wait to come back here.  

yum.
author: Connor S.

description:
Had the Westlake porridge and salt cod fried rice, my friend had the chicken with chicken hearts on spicy sauce and cucumber, which balanced the spice perfectly, and pork with noodles. Must say the porridge was sublime, so delicate, and the fried rice was so light.
Love this place in unconventional, as it is brilliant chef Bowien.
thanks!!!
author: Delia C.

description: I got so excited about the food I ate here twice in 2 days. I sat in for lunch the first day and was seated and served promptly and politely. The second night I ordered delivery and it arrived hot in 30 min. I can highly recommend the pork belly, peanuts in vinegar, salt cod fried rice, and ESPECIALLY the pickled cabbage (the spice is amazing and so nice with the fried rice).
author: l y.

description: I don't know what it is with the "I hate the hipsters" crowd when it comes to reviewing a restaurant. I don't care who's eating at the next table. I care whether I like the food or not, and in this case, I do like the food. The spicy things are definitely quite spicy, at the high end of my tolerance, so watch out for that. But the salt cod fried rice is my new favorite fried rice! Service was good, no complaints. I'll be back!
author: Bruce C.

description: Danny Bowien and Andy Ricker are geniuses. Whereas Andy Ricker's Pok Pok looks to bring Thai dishes in their most traditional and authentic forms to the masses, Danny Bowien is taking Chinese and Sichuan dishes, going balls out creative, Westernizing it, and then delivering it to the masses and saying, "HOW YOU LIKE ME NOW?" And it's freaking delicious. The savory egg custard (with sea urchin, salmon roe, citron, apple, and green perilla) is pure ridiculous delicious decadence. Stir-fried pork jowl and radishes (with fermented black bean, mint, and red perilla) is so unbelievably satisfying, it's hard to believe it's not laced with something illegal. The salt cod fried rice (mackerel confit, Chinese sausage, egg, and scallion) is both familiar and different yet remarkable. Sizzling cumin lamb (salt and peppered lamb belly and chili-pickled long beans) is best summed up with this phrase: HOLY CRAP. There's no need to talk about anything else at Mission Chinese Food. it's all about the food. This is CLEARLY not your traditional Chinese. It's not trying to be. And God bless Danny Bowien for that.
author: Jeff M.

description: Vice magazine of Chinese cuisine, which I'd place in the "Don't" section.
author: B B.

description: Unconventional, unusual, delightfully spicy and delicious food. I love, love, LOVE the Ma Po Tofu, and get at least 2 orders of the pickles every time. While many of the menu items are interesting and equally delicious such as the beef cheeks, pork belly and broccoli beef, I can't help but feel they would be 50% better if consumed immediately, in lieu of being packaged, transported and eaten an hour later. The food is inconsistent, but never bad. I like that the menu rotates, and you can also order from the Lung Shan menu for the traditionalists. Delivery is prompt. Worth a try, but be for warned, if there is a red lightening bolt next to the menu item, it is spicy as hell!
author: Kate R.

description: Visited on a two Thursdays ago at 5pm to avoid any wait (and there was a steady stream of customers even at that hour). The food here is an acquired taste. I ordered the Chongqing Chicken Wings and Kung Pao Pastrami. The wings were way over-spiced, and, I think, unnecessarily overpowering, with substantial amounts of spice rub that could be scraped from the skin (they serve only the flat mid-joint, not the "drumstick" part). As for the Kung Pao Pastrami, I'm used to NY-style pastrami that's been cured in brine, and not so heavily smoked as here. The pastrami chunks were a bit dry and too lean; there should be some marbling. Finally, the lack of useful lighting didn't help in taking in the overall dining experience, even with a table close to the window at this hour. The hung Christmas-type lighting hung on the walls was more decorative than functional. Overall, MCF not a place I'd return to anytime soon.
author: Beriah B.

description: Good food. Not exactly "traditional" chinese food, so don't go there for that. Beers were cheap ($3) and for $1 you can bring your own.
author: Travis H.

description: I am giving it two stars since service was good and they had large glass water containers on the table.  I needed ALOT OF WATER since this FOOD WAS TERRIBLE.  I cant remember striking out on 3 dishes like we did tonight.  The Cold Noodles, Hainam Chicken Rice and Brisket were all AWFUL, pickles were okay.  I should have done some more homework and tried this Fried salty Cod people are yapping about but I cant really see this place putting out a good dish honestly.  I LOVE UNIQUE chinese food with LOTS OF FLAVOR (Ie. Big Lantern, NanKing and Yamo(Burmese), etc) but this food was just bland and flavors never went together.  Thank god for all the water and some white rice.  I have never turned down leftovers and just couldn't fathom taking this home and eating it again or giving it to a homeless person to eat this garbage.  I wanted to like this place but it has to be a conspiracy theory for the great reviews and wait time to get a table  I took a gamble on brisket and knew it may be a bad call but for them to screw up the noodles and Hainam Chicken rice so bad was totally a joke.  I am sorry but has to be worst food I have had in my hundreds of restaurants I have ate at in San Francisco.
author: Harry E.

description: Blaring hiphop, long lines, quick service, communal seating, atypical menu combinations (e.g., general tso sauce + veal rib) all make this place a must. Fun spot, great food at a reasonable price. The veggie dishes were silly and paired with salt cod well.
author: Ndamukong S.

description: we ordered delivery, and they were at our house in exactly one hour.  we ordered the broccoli and beef cheek, ma po tofu (very spicy), and the salt fried rice.  we enjoyed everything, and found the flavors to be very bold and delicious.  they do a great twist of combining traditional and modern chinese cooking.
author: Sheri N.

description: It's been 3 hours, we have no food, and while they knew what our order was 1.5 hours ago when we called to check in (and were told it was 'on the way'), they don't seem to know we ordered anymore.
author: Emily L.

description:
Hubby and I went to the City today for a diversion from our culinary backwater - Napa Valley.  We have seen a lot of glowing reviews about Mission Chinese Food, from NY Times to Bob Appetite.  I had looked it up on the web to see what the menu looked like and had some trepidations before we even got there.  I was worried about the food being too spicy for my husband, and I was worried myself about extremely fatty food like pork belly.
But because of all the great reviews, we decided to give it a try.  The best thing I can say is that we got a great parking place, and there was no wait at 1:00 on Monday.
We ordered fried rice, chicken salad with chicken hearts, and the cumin sizzling lamb with long beans.  
Fried rice was OK.  Miniscule amounts of chicken, a few peanuts, nothing great, but nothing bad.  Slightly more tasty than white rice.  
The chicken salad was the best for me, but too spicy for my husband.  Slices of chicken breast, cucumbers and cilantro on top, deep fried chicken hearts which were pretty tasty, a pretty good dish, but swimming in chili oil.  
The sizzling lamb dish came on a sizzling iron skillet and smelled wonderful. Alas, it didn't turn out so much.  The meat was 5 - 6 chunks of bony fat.  The vegetables, mostly onions, were good with the aforementioned rice, but despite its lack of a "spicy icon" on the menu, was loaded with some type of small, sliced, and extremely hot peppers.  Needless to say, hubby wasn't a fan, and I picked most of them out of my portion as well.  Perhaps it was a blessing that there were no long beans on the plate.
Perhaps we should have refrained from going here in the first place, and maybe the negative review is too harsh, but we made an effort not to order things we knew ahead of time that we wouldn't like - spicy & fatty.
Interior doesn't seem funky or hip to me, just dumpy, and I actually have an unbelievably hysterical vision of the Chronicle/NYT/Bon Ap reviewers walking through the grubby kitchen to the garbage and junk strewn restroom area.  Yuk.
I guess you can tell that I won't be back and advise you not to go the first time.
author: Lee D.

description: Mission Chinese takes spice and creativity to a new level, which I'm not sure is always a good thing.
author: Heather D.

description: Solid unique Chinese food. Our server was great. Dimly lit with a very hip croud
author: Nicole E.

description: Salted cod fried rice was the best. Spicy chicken wings had bit too much mouth-numbing dry spice rub, but went really well with the fried rice. Recommend having a small bite of spicy chicken, followed by a spoonful of fried rice as the combination was incredible. Fairly high salt in most dishes, so caution to people with heart conditions.
author: Jay B.

description: I was super excited about trying this spot out after reading about it in a few food articles. Even braved the hipster scene to try it out. Luckily a friend and I went early (5:45ish) and beat the rush. Sadly, the place did not live up to all the hype. Heard great things about the uni custard, but we couldn't even finish it, and I love uni. The first few bites, it felt refreshing, and we wanted to like it, but we couldn't really convince ourselves to finish it. Salty, odd, I appreciated the effort that it was definitely unique, but the flavors just didn't work. We also ordered the salt and pepper lamb belly dish, which came out with 4 tiny chewy overly fatty pieces of lamb that had hardly enough meat on it to satisfy 2 people. The dish was 90% onions. Huge let down. I really wanted to like this place, but I won't be coming back. Service from one of the girls was atrocious as well. Rude, disinterested, acted like we were an annoyance for being there. I'm giving this place one star for responsibly sourced food and another star for their charity contributions. Food left me extremely disappointed.
author: Sophie P.

description: Seriously, did I miss something?  The only thing that was edible was the salt cod fried rice.  The food tasted like a child made it. What a waste of our time! So gross.  Even the eggplant was ruined. I usually love eggplant.  Definitely won't be back. ikk!
author: Cia C.

description: I am taking back my last review (4 stars.) While the food here is affordable and tasty, much of what is on the menu is inedible for how overly spicy/hot most of the food is. It looked great. It smelled great...but I could not eat my "salad" tonight nor could I eat my entree. It was so so so SPICY. In one cup of salad, there were 14 whole chilis and about 10 slices of raw jalapeno.  I wish they would just take it down a notch. Maybe I am not the hot food warrior I once believed myself to be...it would have been so good :(
author: Hilde L.

description:
mcf, i like your food and i want to continue to support your business. but  please don't dismiss me when i call you one hour after i place my delivery order and say, "the driver is out" as the explanation with no apologies. my food was finally delivered one and half hours later and i didn't get even an acknowledgement from the driver that the delivery took 90 minutes. perhaps you shouldn't advertise that delivery times are between 20-45 minutes.

i will return but please don't betray me.
author: Rob D.

description: Haven't written a review in awhile but my recent experience at MCF was so disappointing I was compelled to speak up. Talk about overhyped. Had read and seen all the incredible press about Danny Bowien and this place and really expected a standout, original, quality meal once I made the trek in from LA. What I got instead was a phenomenally greasy and disgustingly over salted (note: I'm an admitted salt fiend and even this was too much for me) semblance of supposedly authentic Chinese food. Ordered the much lauded salt cod rice (seriously? Zero salt cod flavor. Couldn't hold a candle to even the most average hole in the wall shop you'd find in the streets of Hong Kong); the thrice cooked bacon (swimming in grease, intensely salty), the tea smoked eel (the actual rolls weren't bad but were ruined by the pool of soy sauce they sat in, making it inedibly salty); and the sweet peas (probably the best dish of the four because it was so simple and didn't get slammed by an over seasoned heavy hand). All in all, it was a terrible meal that left both myself and my date feeling not only let down after much anticipation, but physically pretty awful after (heavy MSG perhaps?). I've read that Bowien has since abandoned the SF MCF to tend to his bustling new outfit in NYC. And maybe that's the problem here. But when you're a restaurant that gets so much of an upper hand in the oversaturated, tough business of food with the attention you've gotten, it almost feels irresponsible and disrespectful to not quality control your establishments, no? This eater thinks so.
author: M L.

description:
Honestly people, how can you guys think this place is good???!

I'll admit that this was my first time and maybe they were having an off day (which would SUCK for everyone else b/c there were crowds of people out the door).  But to call this Chinese food? Authentic? Innovative? However you want to qualify it -- this meal was straight up HORRIBLE.

We ordered the much talked about Sichuan pickles (see SFoodie: http://blogs.sfweekly.com/foodie/2011/05/no_x_sichuan_pickles_at_missio.php; No bueno Jonathan...). And it was SALTY as all hell.  The sodium level pierced all corners of my mouth. Every single bite caused my eyes to tear. 

We also got the triced-cooked bacon.  This was probably the easiest dish to stomach.  Still salty, but the rice cakes did wonders to evenly distribute the sodium...

Then, the lamb noodles and salted cod rice came.   Now, I have to admit that I had high expectations for the lamb noodles considering I dined at Xian Famous Noodles (see the best place on earth: http://www.yelp.com/biz/xian-famous-foods-new-york-3#query:xian%20noodles) three times in a single week.  Again, the sodium content was through the roof.  It didn't help that the dish was spicy too.  It was literally paintful getting through every bite.  The sodium, then spicy, then sodium again -- one punch after another. No frigggin relief.  Don't get me wrong - I live for spicy food. But a great meal is about a plan, a strategy, a complementary pairing -- not just THROWING TOGETHER THE SALTIEST AND SPICEST INGREDIENTS YOU GOT.  And the noodles. Oh how sub-par they were. These noodles are supposed to be al dente and chewy.  That's the beauty of these noodles.  MCF's noodles were overcooked and mushy.  Maybe if MCF focused on bettering their flavors would this dish actually work!

And I have no comment on the salted cod fried rice. Its sodium content was probably through the roof too. But it was one of the last dishes that came, and by then my mouth was starved for something bland that the rice did just the job. So it tasted like plain white rice to me. No joke people.

So if you want really good Chinese food, don't come here. Stick to the SUnset, Richmond or Chinatown.
author: Connie N.

description: If you want traditional chinese, go to chinatown. If you want unique and imaginative asian fusion go here. Went early with 2 locals and seated right away. Service was swift and friendly. Had Sliced Peanut Noodles; Steamed Eggplant; Salt Cod Fried rice; Sizzling Cumin Lamb (tasty but overcooked); Thrice Cooked Bacon and braised water cress. Beers a must.
author: Lawrence J.

description: You don't need to read my review. You just need to come here. Or order food for delivery, you lucky bastards in San Francisco who get to do that. I went here last November and have neglected to write a review of this, the best Chinese food and some of the best food period I have ever had. I just went to the NYC branch that recently opened as I write, which inspired me to finally write this quick blurb about the original. Anthony and Danny are geniuses as far as I'm concerned. The thrice-cooked bacon, tea smoked eel... really it's all brilliant. My mouth is watering (and burning) as I think about it. Oh my god. It's so good. It was so good, I bought their cookbook in house, had Anthony (and Danny) sign it and even made their pork belly recipe a few times. Also really good. I'm so happy they opened a place where I live. Like, really, really so fucking god damn happy. OK, really, I'm done now.
author: Steven S.

description: Went to MCF on Saturday afternoon with some friends. Got a seat right away, no waiting, no signing in. Our server was really nice and attentive, she put up with me bugging her even 5 mins for another tsing tao. Lucky for me you pass buy kitchen on the way to the wc. Kitchen was clean. We split the tiki pork belly and the kung pao pastrami, both were really good. The tiki pork had a nice sweetness to it. The pastrami was really good, loved the smokey flavor, I felt that it was a little too fatty, but pastrami tends to be that way. The spice was perfect for my level, my better half said her eyes were burning as we finished, and she didn't eat past one bite of the pastrami. They weren't playing any 90's hip-hop (which would have been dope), but I still liked the music. Note: They don't have ice. Yes...you may think it sucks, but you can now experience what it's like eating out in a third world country.
author: Dean M.

description:
Mission Chinese Food... My friends and I have always wondered what was so "awesome" about this place. It definitely is a very successful popup, which basically is permanent now. V and I came here at 2:30 pm, right before the kitchen closed. Since 7x7 had the salt cod fried rice on their top 100 list, V and I ordered that. For a dish called salt cod fried rice, it didn't have much salt cod. AND the salt cod was not salty. Honestly, Danny Bowien should have just called it chinese sausage green onion fried rice, which is something I do like! But if you do order the salt cod fried rice, don't expect much from it. There are a ton of Chinese restaurants in the city that make a way better and more authentic salt cod fried rice. 
We also ordered the slow cooked pork belly with sweet and sour pineapple and cucumbers. The pork belly was incredibly fatty, but well cooked. 
Honestly, the food here is just eh. It's definitely better than any American Chinese restaurant, but compared to the rest of the city, this place is not worth it. However, one point for the Chinese lady who was working there :)
author: Fiona N.

description: 1.5 hour wait for the saltiest meal of my life.  Yikes.
author: Gabriella K.

description: This place is definitely for the hipster crowd. Not a Chinese person in sight working the place. Waited for 1 hour 45 minutes for a table. Had the pork belly, fried rice, ma po tofu, and thrice cooked bacon. Everything was decent but the ma po tofu caught me off guard because it was sweet. I did not like. I would not wait in line again to eat this place but may do a to go order to try some of their other dishes.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: I had high expectations for this place after seeing the great reviews. I was completely disappointed. I ordered the thrice fried bacon, mapo tofu, and an eggplant dish. In general, the dishes were soaked in oil, salt, msg, and heavily loaded with chilli peppers, in a failed attempt at imitating schechuan-style spicy. The cooking seemed very amatuerish, nothing close to fine chinese cuisine. No surprise, as the cooks were not chinese, but a bunch of young, twenty-something caucasians. For the price they charge, not worth it. Many restaurants in Flushing are much better.
author: Joseph T.

description: I got Mission Chinese delivered the other night.  It came in 45 minutes after the guy got lost.  The Chinito was an interesting and salty mix of textures but I hoped it would be crispier.  The Ma-Po Tofu was not only spicy (OK) but PACKED with peppercorns.  The soft tofu, mushrooms and ground pork were good once I overcame the heat . It was flavorful and creative but I'd hoped for more...
author: Eric S.

description: I am not sure what the hype was. I had a very disappointed lunch experience there. The food was WAY TOOOOO SALTY!!!!!  I could not even eat the Chongqing chicken wings, it was so salty.  The ma bo tofu was also very salty and the black vinegar peanuts was ok. Thank goodness it was not crowded, the only waitress there was friendly enough. I am so glad I tried it out in SF so I will not go to the one in NYC.
author: Mary Y.

description: I ordered delivery over the phone and was given an hour and ten minute wait time. That time passed and I called to see when I could expect the delivery. This was her exact response, "Uhhh I don't know, we busy, I have no idea." I ask her if she could call the driver and check as I was waiting for the delivery so I could leave my house and she said "Uhhh I don't know hold". She obviously set the phone down instead of placing me on hold because I could hear her tell another customer who clearly had the same question that she "had no idea because it was busy". She than came back to the phone and I explained to her I needed an estimate because I was planning to leave the house, "Uhh I don't know" in a rude tone was still her response. I than I asked for the manager and she said, "no manager" and hung up. I literally felt like I was getting punk'd. I called her back and told her to refund my money as I no longer wanted to wait around. She said "ok" and hung up. This place is a joke and I would NEVER order from them again. I get that you are a business and it is busy, but that does not excuse you from being able to answer basic questions and treating your customers with respect.
author: gabrielle d.

description: I really liked the mapo tofu and am happy that there's now an interesting chinese delivery option in the Mission/Noe. My neighborhood is a bit of a wasteland for that and even though MCF a bit avant garde-ish, it's still good.
author: Jennifer C.

description: 3 things stink at Mission Chinese Food: 1. My hair and 2. clothes after eating here, and 3. the food. The taste was way too strong, there was no subtlety of flavors. Overhyped. Overpriced. The wait was 45-60 minutes on a Saturday night. I would not return if the prices were halved and there was no wait. Service was decent though.
author: Presto G.

description:
I did NOT like the food here at all:
1.  Everything is covered in the same mixture: sliced garlic, julienned chili peppers, green onion, peppercorn, peanuts all tied together with some slightly thickened soy/oyster sauce.  Two of the dishes I got were covered in this mixture.  For example, my beef dish was 10% beef and 90% of the mixture.   You really have to dig through this mixture to find the meat in your dish. There is really only so much of this mix that you can eat and it makes the dishes taste one-dimensional. 
2.  I ordered beef noodle soup b/c I saw a guy in the corner of the restaurant making them. The texture of the noodles I got was ok but again the flavor of the beef soup was mediocre. The beef chunks were not cooked long enough so they were not tender enough.
3.  I ordered the dumplings b/c I saw the guy making them. Dumpling skin was too thick and filling was not unctuous enough.
4.  Also tried the steamed egg custard with uni and trout roe. The texture was unpalatable--everything was soft and slightly slimy.
author: Karen C.

description: normally a hole in the wall old tacky joint like this would mean reasonable priced food, nope and  (theres a reason they keep the lighting dim in the restaurant ) serving up chinese "fusion" fare. ambiance and food totally unworthy of my time and money, the food does not justify the prices charged. and mainly meat dishes on the menu. i should of known having seeing no asian patrons this place would be a red flag.wont be going back.
author: tony t.

description: After my cent visit, I felt compelled to write an update.  Overall, the food this time around was pretty ok - but I would stay away from the pork belly.  It was a real disappointment - honestly it tasted like a thick, chewy, flavorless piece of pork fat.  Just writing this review brings back that awful memory.  We left it practically untouched.  Everything else was ok - not as good as my first visit.  Service definitely has a bit of that hipster cool attitude, but it was acceptable.
author: Eric C.

description:
once you got past the dirty windows and glass door with the residue
of notices removed, it was very good food. I went to the bathroom first
to make sure the kitchen was cleaner then the front of the restaurant.
But the food is good and will be back in the day time. The neighbor hood
is way way to rough in the evening.
author: Robert F.

description:
not really Chinese
not even Asian fusion
not even Americanized Chinese
I don't know what you call this place
the spicy is basically numbing so you won't taste the real flavor of food.
no idea how this place becomes so popular
author: Astro P.

description: This place is excellent. Get there early to avoid the long wait. The lamb cheek noodle soup and the egg egg noodles were fantastic.
author: Thomas K.

description:
First this place is awesome. There were a lot of flavors you can't find at other run-of-the-mill Chinese places (hua jiao, what what!). One warning though, if you don't like fatty meat this place probably isn't for you. Not to say you shouldn't try it; I used to be a lean-meat only kind of guy too, but once you get past the initial texture, fat can be super delicious if it's done right.

I noticed there seems to be some confusion over whether this is "real" Chinese food. Chinese cuisine varies widely from region to region; the kind of bland food you get in Shanghai is vastly different from the hearty lamby goodness you can get in Beijing (yes, I am biased towards Northern food). Food in Sichuan is even more different and has a lot of "Sichuan Peppercorn" in it. That's the stuff that makes Mission Chinese food's tingly lamb soup tingly. 

That said, Mission Chinese food has created a menu with traditional foods from many different regions of China. Ma po dofu hails from Sichuan, Cumin lamb and tingly lamb soup live in the North and Hainan Chicken is the national dish of Singapore. I can't personally speak to how "traditional" the flavors were in all the dishes on the menu, but I can tell you that the broth in the tingly lamb soup tastes almost exactly like the broth from a famous beef noodle soup place in Taiwan. The meat is fatty and tender, but not grisly and the noodles look fresh and are probably made somewhere close by (they don't have the smooth look of machine-made noodles).  In addition to the soup, I had the beef cheek--not something I ever saw on a menu in China, but it wasn't far from some other things I had in Beijing. It was scrumptious, too.

In short this place is uber good and has a really diverse menu with a lot of dishes that are hard to find other places in SF.
author: Jacob G.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the bay area, an incredible deal for how uniquely delicious it is. Good portions, easy service, and pretty quick turnover. Everything is amazing - my favorites are the Veal, Fried Rice, Pepper Leaves, Chicken Wings, Ma Pa Tofu.
author: Sarah W.

description: This place redefined the way I think about Chinese food.  The atmosphere is understated.  The wait staff is competent and prompt.  The prices are low.
author: Aaron S.

description: Yep. Damn good. Have to get the pork - the fermented long beans are good too. Just go now.
author: Michael S.

description:
Meh, don't really rate it. Heard about it from a friend and just seemed like any other over-hyped restaurant in the Mission.  I thought most dishes had the same flavor and ingredients in them and nothing really wowed my socks.  The only real positive was that the prices were reasonable so after the end of the meal we didn't feel bad about wasting too much money.  
The things I wouldn't get again:~~~~
Pork dumpling-didnt like the sauce with it, could take it or leave it

Lamb dumpling-I think if these dumplings didn't come in the broth it would have been alright.  I know this sounds weird-but the broth reminded me of the smell of fabric bandaids.

Beef cheek-Totally overspiced

Things I would get again (but don't get me wrong-none of the below selections really thrill me)~~~~
Hainam Chicken Rice-nice, real plain fried rice

Pork belly-pretty good but not spectacular

Crawfish-this was okay.  I think I would have liked this the best if the crawfish was already out of its shell because most the flavors end up peeling off with the shell.
author: YA Z.

description: I have no idea how this restaurant is so popular. Service here is not good. It took 30 minutes for them to take our order on an evening where the restaurant was not even full. However, we thought the food was going to make up for it. I don't think I've ever had such salty food before. With one of the appetizers, I went through two glasses of water almost instantly after a bite. And then they forgot one of our orders. Which actually we were pretty thrilled about given how long the food took to come out. But then it took another 20 minutes to get our bill when we finished and another 20 minutes for them to accept our credit card (we had to chase down a different waitress-our waiter was traipsing about the back of the restaurant). Seriously, there are better restaurants than this. Do yourself a favor and avoid this one.
author: Shane A.

description: Surprised this has 3.5 stars. Obviously does not have a good ambiance or service. The lamb was good but everything else was a hack. A bunch of us went there and I had opportunity to try multiple dishes. The service is horrible and dont even try to use the restroom. You have to walk through the kitchen and you dont feel like eating anything there after you see the dirty kitchen and the people without hairmesh or gloves. The waiter/waitress were full of bad attitude. I really hope there were having one bad day.
author: Sri S.

description: had the slow cooked pork belly and the cumin lamb! the bomb!!! not authentic, but phenomenal!
author: Jason P.

description: The music sucked and was way too loud, but OMG the food was amazing. I'm so desperate to get back there that I'm wondering if they slipped a bit of crack into it.
author: Annie B.

description: The food here was so refreshing and original I have been yearning to return. The portions were generous and the price was great. We enjoyed the addictive kung pao pastrami, the slice peanut noodles, and a beautiful bowl of vibrant green peas with red onion pickles. The concept of invigorating an existing institution is genius. The amount donated to the SF Food Bank truly noble. I loved how the the resources went into the food versus overhead. Such an intelligent, resourceful and surprisingly novel idea.
author: Gennifah G.

description: best damn chinese food in this city.  AMAZING!
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Food: Two of the four dishes were very good. The Thrice Cooked Pork had a nice variety of ingredients such as bitter melon and tofy skin. It was spicy and had that tingly, slightly citrus flavor you get from Szechuan peppercorns. It reminded me of a similar dish at Momofuku Ssaam Bar. The Szechuan were pickles also quite tasty. Kind of like Kim Chee, but with some roasted peanuts. The Tiger Salad was a miss. Too raw and stemmy. The Salt Cod Fried Rice was ok, but a bit of a misnomer. Salt cod reconstituted dried cod, so it's is dense and very fishy. Here the cod was fresh and bit bland. The slices of Chinese sausage could have saved the day, but they were paper thin and hard to discern.
Service: Friendly service. Very prompt. All dishes came out around the same time.
Ambiance: Better than I thought. Death Cab for Cutie and Built To Spill wafting through the air. Kind of like Minako in a way.
Price: 3 dishes, the pickles and one beer = $38 A decent of amount of food for that price.

Overall: What I liked, I like a lot. There are a number of other things I'd like to try, so I'll be back. I think this place is on the rise and there is so little  good Chinese food in La Mission.
author: Yogi B.

description: Service was Horrible.  Food was inferior quality, except for the fried rice, but anyone can make fried rice....I waited 45 minutes for my meal and my guests were already done eating by the time mine arrived.  cockroaches in the lights and a woman was pealing eggs and caughing all over them.  Staff were dirty and did not care about service or follow through on the quality of the food.
author: Mark W.

description:
Came here to check what had become of Mission Street Foods afterglow. Many reviews complain about the use of peppers, i may be biased because of my love for spice but i actually didn't think it was that spicy. 
The Chinese pickles were amazing, we couldn't wait long enough to try them with the food.. the were gobbled up right away.
The food was pretty un-spectacular, the Chinito donut thing was interesting but was lacking in flavor.
The Islamic/Chinese lamb dish actually took some work to put away. Not because of the spiciness, but more the fact that it was just really heavy with oil, the lamb rib was chewy and over cooked... and there weren't really that many noodles to back it up.
I think the place looks to be the unfortunate outcome of Lung Shan not taking proper inspiration from their time as partners with MSF.... At least they don't use MSG and the friendly and cute young servers were kind and attentive enough. I will try it again, but i hope they change the menu often.
author: J R.

description:
I was psyched to try this place and was somewhat disappointed, but I want to give it another chance.   I ordered the duck chinito and even though it tasted good, it was not what i expected.   The description and my expectation did not match the actual dish. I thought the duck would have a crunchy texture, but it did not and the actual duck appeared ground up, which I did not like,    The salt cod fried rice was good, but not spectacular.  Anyway, I will give this place another try and try some of their other dishes..  

Bernie
author: Bernie B.

description: Straight up this is one of the best restaurants I've been to.  I waited for about a half dozen trips before I wrote this simply because I didn't want to be driven by hype.  It's a hipster hang out but I don't consider myself one and I feel right at home there.  I'm happy it's a first come first sat place because I'm afraid if you were allowed to make reservations you'd never get to eat here.  There are 27 dishes so there's guaranteed to be something of your liking for you and your group.  Though I'd never try and come here with more than 4 people.  Food is excellent and in many cases indescribably good.  If you like Chinese food this place kicks it up a notch and slightly sideways.  To understand that you really just have to try it.  A great place for people who aren't that adventureous but want to start. From Sea Urchin, to Oxtail, to Tounge he has dishes featuring those and other non-standard things that anyone (and I do mean anyone) can enjoy.  Prices for food this well done are very reasonable.  It's not like cheap Chinese food but it certainly doesn't match the quality.  Service is always solid but the wait can be long yet worth it.  If only someone would open a bar next door.  I would go on and on but I want to stop so I can go back tonight.
author: Joco F.
Sumomo O.

description: Went for lunch 9/10/11based on rave reviews on the blog of famous London chef Yotam Otolenghi. Expected one of the best meals. Instead I had the single worst meal I have ever had. (Been dining around the world for 60 years). The sizzling cumin lamb was cumin/onions and animal fat- there was no visible lamb meat at all. The pork belly also was fat only with no meat. At best the flavors were awful. Both dishes have been praised online. Perhaps I am the only one to see the emperor naked but this left us both sick. I should have returned them both to the kitchen and refused to pay.
author: Alias G.

description: When it comes to Chinese food I am usually a traditionalist (although I am white, and haven't been to much of China).  But I can  the internet, damnit!  So I was predisposed to hate (based on the hipster ethos) but intrigued by the style of some the dishes deemed most delicious (Szechuanish).  Anyway, I will testify that the char siu pork belly and the braised beef cheek were truly delicious.  The pork belly was appropriately char siu flavored, and the texture was the best I've had.  It is very fatty, so if you are against that, avoid it--you don't know what you're missing.  The beef cheeks were quite spicy, and I'm a spice lover so that is a great thing, and were perfectly tender, and deliciously beefy.  I'll be back, and wishing they delivered to Berkeley.  Too bad my yupster SF friends don't appreciate these qualities.
author: Taco T.

description: upon reading all the hype on this place, I finally went today, after exhausting all the mission places I frequent. I love Chinese food and was hoping to have a great meal. I ordered the lamb noodle soup and was so let down. my first two bites both had hair in them. the noodles weren't bad, but there was this buzzing flavor that made your tongue feel numb. after this sensation happened, everything tasted bad, even the water. i don't know if it was MSG or what, but I"ve never experienced anything like this before. I don't mean to be a hater, but seriously, this place was a let down. I feel compelled to write, as so many people claim it's sooo good. hmmmmmm..
author: Andrew P.

description: I ate here for the first time in two years, and it is  the worst food I have eaten In a long, long time. The lamb cheek noodles were pretty good, but the Kung pao pastrami was composed of very fatty, inedible tiny pieces of meat cooked in vegetables that were too salty and spicy. I love spicy food, but these favors were unbalanced. The long beans were disappointing.I liked the ma po tofu, but the overall experience was so terrible that it was even hard to enjoy an okay dish. I say don't waste your time here, since SF has so many good Asian restaurants.
author: Emily D.

description: warning:  some of their dishes are burn your mouth spicy, without any signs on the menu (i.e. don't have that pepper sign next to it.)
author: S. M.

description: I was heartbroken when mission street food got discontinued, but this new, relatively more permanent incarnation is a great consolation prize. The peking duck is not to be missed. Everything else on the menu is quite tasty, with varying degrees of culinary innovation. I wish they'd bring back some of the MSF favorites (I miss the PB&J!), but I'll still enjoy coming back to this restaurant.
author: Raja H.

description: I was looking forward to eating here and was lucky enough to be met with a short line. But overall, I must say that this place has either really fallen off or was totally overated. The service was horrible.  We almost had to throw things at the wait staff to get another beer or our check.  The food was really disappointing. The sweet peas were basically a big bowl of frozen peas stir fried in too much oil.  No flavor, no spice.  The bacon cooked three times only had about 3 pieces of bacon and the noodles that came with the tea eel were totally over cooked. They blast crappy old 80's music as well.  Save your time and money for the hundred or so other awesome (and cheaper) good Asian spots in S.F..
author: Joe A.

description: Yesterday, a Sunday, I had a cold, and was just vegging out all day with my roomie, who is also battling one. I wanted spicy food cuz that's good for colds. We were browsing online and decided to try Mission Chinese, which I'd heard was good, and also because it delivered. Oh, and they donate 75 cents per entree to the SF Food Bank which is great. We started with the tea smoked eel. It was cute, my first bite I thought hmm this tastes so different, and I kind of liked it. By my second piece, I didn't like it anymore. Too weird for me. Roomie didn't like it on the first go, and we ended up throwing it out. We also got the thrice cooked bacon. It had a very smoky flavor, which was the worst part of the dish. I still liked it, roomie was sort of teetering between liking and disliking. We also had the ma po tofu, which was pretty much a soup. It is a little spicy but not very spicy like the 2 spicy on the menu makes you think of (oh and the bacon one wasn't spicy at all). We both liked this dish, I think it was yummy! Best dish of the meal! Lastly, we had salt cod fried rice, which we both liked and finished right up. For the two of us, there was a little left over, not enough for another meal, and the price was around $50. Roomie said he'd probably not eat here again. I probably would, everything is a very different type mix of foods and flavors. I think it was a pretty good meal, and a good place to try different types of food.
author: Merredith L.

description: Feels like one of those places that gets the chefs some attention, they move on, make money on an expensive cookbook and the food is basically coasting. The Kung Pao Pastrami, which I tried the first time I ate there a ways back and thought was genuinely unique, was served last night with barely had any pastrami in it at all, consisted mostly of filler onions and peppers, and was a total rip-off. The Tiger Salad was overly vinegary, all presentation and not worth the money. We could have stayed home and stir-fried a bunch of peppers and inhaled the smoke. Gave the waiter a good tip because the food wasn't his fault, but anyone who's really familiar with the range of Chinese cooking available in SF doesn't need to bother anymore.
author: Steve L.

description: Food was great but we ordered delivery and it took 2x longer than promised and they forgot two dishes
author: Kaitlin B.

description: I recently went back to Mission Chinese, and didn't have as good of an experience as I did last time.  I had the braised lamb with hand-pulled noodles.  I was warned that the dish was "face numbing" and maybe that just wasn't my cup of tea.  The lamb was tender and tasty, and the noodles had a nice texture to them, but -- similar to my experience with the ma po tofu last time -- the dish was just far too oily.  It's probably still deserves 3.5 stars overall, evening out the two experiences I've had so far, but they lose that extra half star because of the bathroom there.  Both times I've been there, the bathroom has been gross.  Both times the bathroom was dirty and the floor was slippery, and this time it just smelled like someone had puked.  I know that you can only maintain the bathroom so much, but the fact that it was bad both times means that it's probably a common problem there.  I'll probably try it again in the future, because the dishes look so interesting, but this time was definitely disappointing.
author: Pilan C.

description: was so excited about going to this place having lived in asia ... liked the vibe food wasn't that great.  people standing in line..(20 peeps at least.)  got there early enough.  dumplings were the bomb!  beef chow mein ... s a l t y .... way too and i am a salt freak.  all asian ladies back of the house who should be tipped out.  i hope they are.  but not sure why this place is on every list of the best in the city.  cause it's mission hipster?  over mission hipster.  going out to the avenues for the real thing.  shouldn't have expected anything... just like the house of nanking.
author: Amanda J.

description: i am a vegetarian and though there were not many non-meat options on the menu, i ordered the wild pepper leaves and it was delicious! me and a friend went for lunch at around 12:50 and there was no line (for once), the service was good and there was good music.  my friend got the smoked beef brisket soup noodles and his only complaint was that it was pretty luke warm. over all, delicious lunch!
author: Alice L.

description: HORRIBLE. SALTY. LONG LINES. OVERPRICED. I generally give five stars and rant and rave about places. This is the first time that I am giving a negative review, I am surprised that this place has become so popular. The food is DISGUSTING. The one redeeming quality about this place is that they play AWESOME music. we ordered five dishes and every single one of them was disgusting. This was the worst restaurant I have ever been to in my entire life. HORRIBLE. It left a disgusting aftertaste in our mouth, we had to get icecream to find our tastebuds. The wait was 45 minutes, it ended up being a huge waste of $ and time. HORRRIBLLEEEEE food. The pork belly was decent. There were parts of it that were burnt into a rock like formation. The tofu was the worst, it was gross and way too salty. The lamb dumplings were edible. The pastrami was disgusting. HORRIBLE. AVOID AT ALL COSTS. Seriously TYPICAL HIPSTER SHI*T. OVERHYPED. WORST PLACE IN HISTORY. I'm writing to warn my fellow foodies to not waste their time on this place.
author: Divya P.

description: We saw the waiting line is always kind of long.  We though it must be very good.  We finally tried it today.  It is very disappointed.  The waitress was coughing on the dish she served!
author: Jeni S.

description:
very oily. very hip.

the mongolian long beans are great and spicy. the tiger salad (fresh rolls) was very good and had a nice flavor but don't be fooled, it was still dowsed in oil.

it's family style, so hard to get a meal if you are just ordering for yourself and don't want to eat an entire plate of string beans or an entire plate of meat only.

the flavors are slightly atypical and they have quite a variety of meat products.

there were three guys smoking cigarettes in the lightwell/kitchen.

the severe irony of this place is not worth the severe gastrointestinal maladies.
author: Sophia L.

description: On the positive side, the music was outstanding, could hardly sit still, service was fast and efficient and Thrice Cooked Pork and Westlake Porridge were quite good.  On the flip side, Wild Pepper Leaves was simply inedible.  Tasted fine but the leaves (and vines) were like eating rope.  Longer we chewed bigger it got.  We were all looking forward to Mo Po Tofu, what a letdown.   Even in Seoul Korea, I easily hold my own with the locals on the spicy/hot but the Mo Po Tofu, we were served last night, was simply inedible.  It nearly ruined the entire meal for the rest of the table.  Taste buds were seared beyond recognition.   Based upon my couple of spoonfuls it really was nothing special.  We probably would not have even finished it even if it had been edible.  For our table of 4, Mission Chinese is a take-out option, at  best.   Hype can do wonders for mediocrity.
author: Hn J.

description: Would have to say there is definitely plenty of HYPE over this place. Between Martha Stewart and the hipsters that love the joint, I'd have to say it really is A-OK. My hubby decided he needed to see what was the haps, so over the bridge we went, dragging another pair of asians. Given that my granny is a mighty mean cook, it's hard for me to give big stars to a chinese restaurant with a cook that's confessed he never really cooked chinese food before. Gotta say, the food was pretty tasty. The place isn't that big, but it does have a cool paper dragon lantern hanging on the ceiling. Prices are good and the portions were filling. Don't know if we'd make a special trip to come again, considering while we were still eating we felt like they were in a rush to get us out. I know there's folks waiting, but they should make sure our tummies are full and happy before they make us leave. The waiter didn't even come by to see if we wanted to order anything else, just gave us the bill. (and where the heck was my fortune cookie or sliced oranges)
author: Cindy F.

description: Came here with the boyfriend last week - Monday night, around 8pm - and waited an hour to get in. We almost bailed a couple times, but stuck it out, as our motto is "long line, good food". You can write an arrow next to your name, go off for a drink during the wait, and if they call your name and you're not back, they won't knock your name off the list. Inside, the decor is awesome. Dragons, lanterns, paintings and blacklights. And club music. Dark and loud and hip. For food, we ordered the appetizer of pickles, which took maybe 30 seconds to get to our table, even with the place as busy as a restaurant can get. It was salty, not as vinegar or acid heavy as I expected, but good. A little spicy. The peanuts in it were insanely amazing and the cabbage wasn't bitter. Then came the Pork Belly. Can you say AMAZING?! 4 pieces, each the size of a large egg, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Literally, nothing has ever melted in my mouth quite like that. You need to be OK with pork fat (who isn't?) because I would say it's 50% or more fat, but it melts on your tongue is so soft. And the plum sauce is great. Last up was the Thrice Cooked Bacon.
