HUGE plate of thick, fatty bacon, onions, hot peppers, rice cakes (think scalloped potatoes) and an amazing sauce that words cannot describe. It is salty, but not in a bad way. But the SPICE. Oh, lord. I can handle a LOT of spice, but that was A LOT. My lips hurt. My forehead sweat. My voice stopped working. My eyes burnt. My mouth screamed for mercy. But the taste defeated all the pain and I ate, and ate, and ate some more until I think I was numb. My boyfriend, poor soul, can handle a lot less spice than I, and he was near death by bite 5. But, alas, the taste overwhelmed and he kept eating. And drinking water. It was amazing, but please be warned. That is HOT. We think it's a good deal for the money and worth the wait, on occasion. If you're adventurous is your tastes and spice acceptance. I recommend.
author: Dallas K.

description: Make sure to come early and be prepared for a long wait but no matter the food is so worth it.  Do not order the chicken wings unless you are up for some sizzling hot adventure.  Every single dish we ordered were amazing.  I will definitely come back again and again
author: Tabp F.

description: This little hole in the wall doesn't look like anything special upon entering however, it's some of the best Chinese I've ever had. The dishes are spicy when they should be and innovative. You won't find that typical too-fried American Chinese food here.  I spend a good deal of time in SF and will definitely be back to Mission Chinese.
author: Ashley S.

description: Had all of the standard  recommendations. Rated it solid but not incredible as the press would lead you to believe. Get there early or prepare to wait. This place is known all the way to NYC and was just mentioned in the New Yorker now that they have a branch out there as well.
author: norman g.

description: Definition of a hypster restaurant that has been overhyped beyond explanation. The fact that Alan Richman wrote that the brisket and egg custard were one of the top ten dishes in San Francisco is laughable and probably the last time I'll take anything he says seriously. The food is just fine but it just appears disorganized, incoherent and at times tasteless. Some people say that it shouldn't be judged against real Chinese food rather comparing it to an Americanized version. That's fine but even then it doesn't measure up to the pletheora of five star ratings. If you looking for great Chinese food, Americanized Chinese food, experimental American-Chinese food, or whatever people call it this place is unlikely to satisfy. A good variety of dishes were sampled: cold sesame noodles, egg custard, char siu pork belly, lion's head meatball, Mongolian Onglet, salt & pepper shrimp, bok choy, and bbq platter so it's not just one bad dish that I had.
author: Procter F.

description: Delicious, but the green beans were seriously spicy.  They weren't joking around when they put peppers next to the name of the dish on the menu.
author: Sweaty P.

description: DAMN, this place is gooood. Not your typical Chinese food. The plates are interesting and the flavors are incredible. Totally great in price and absolutely worth the wait. The one thing I would say is, when they note a dish as spicy, they are not effing around - so proceed with caution. I will be back for sure!!
author: A.B. F.

description: We started with the chicken and rice. I don't know the name of the dish but the favors were so flavorful. Net chicken wings. I am a wimp when it comes to spicy but they were fried so perfectly and so yummy I couldn't stop eating them.  On to the lamb soup. I love lamb and this soup was delicious. So unique were the favors like nothing I've ever had in a Chinese restaurant. Last was the pork belly.  Pork belly is everywhere and even though I love it I'm kind of over it but with that said I ordered it anyway and am I happy I did.  The crispness of the belly along with the sweetness of the pineapple was a great combination.  Is this place regular Chinese NO and I'm so glad it's not.  You can get that anywhere, this is new and different and wonderful.  Usually I don't care about service for me its all about the food but today I compliment the service.  It's was friendly and fun.  Right about when we were done with our fabulous meal the waitress played Le Tigre on the sound system, it put a smile on my face and reminded me that I was hip once.
author: Veronica L.

description: i loved it.  i went on a Friday and waited 30 min. we had the mapo tofu and the spicy chicken and the spicy salad rolls and the spicy mussels and the eel rolls and drinks. 4 of us for 120$ and we had some other stuff. it all was great.  i am going back.
author: george robert v.

description: Hands down the best Chinese I've ever had.  Not terribly traditional, but very creative and expertly executed dishes (and not that all-too-often-disappointing modern or fusion Chinese).  The Thrice Cooked Bacon, Slow Cooked Pork Bellies, Shanghainese Chow Mein, and Long Beans are among the best dishes I've ever had.  Gotta love the ambience too!
author: J M.

description: I've been following the journey of co-founders Danny Bowien and Anthony Myint for some time and I'm happy to see Mission Chinese Food settled in our beloved Mission District. Described as "Americanized Oriental Food", don't expect typical dishes like Beef Broccoli and Kung Pao Chicken. Instead, there's Broccoli Beef Cheek and Kung Pao Pastrami, which is my personal fave! The pastrami in this dish is smoky and tender, absorbing lots of the chili flavor. Their spicy dishes are absolutely spicy! Thrice Cooked Bacon and Mongolian Long Beans are other fave spicy dishes. To cut through the spice, add the Cold Dan Dan Noodles, Westlake Rice Porridge, or Salt Cod Fried Rice- all delicate, greaseless, yet flavorful. I'm glad to know Mission Chinese Food extended their dining hours. To avoid the crowds, I suggest early afternoon (they open at 11:30am everyday, but closed on Wednesdays), however, Mission Chinese offers dinner hour (6pm) specials like house-made dumplings! Expect to spend $20-25 per person, which is pricey for "Chinese food", but keep in mind that a portion of sales benefit the San Francisco Food Bank. Delivery service is available, but wait time is about an hour. So if you can, definitely make a trip down to Mission Chinese Food!
author: Leroid D.

description: What Can i SAY!!!!  America has no clue to real Chinese Food!  Never has and probably never will!  This place is fun only because Danny B is not trying to be true to cuisine...his take on famous Cantonese fried rice dish is pure American by using salt cod instead of cured 'stinky' dried fish...the real pungent smell in front of those Stockton Street vendors is genius.  This is like what American Chinese was like 40 years ago with Moogugaipan (Mushroom Chicken) and Beef & Broccoli (his beef cheeks...) but now his take is far more adventurous!  So go there and please do not think this is great Chinese is not by a long shot as the technique and finesse is purely lacking but enjoy the spirit of his creation as it is something original by his own hand...whether true or not to pure Chinese cuisine, is not the point,  He is just doing his thing...don't believe me...watch him trying to pull noodles...hilarious and innocently beautiful as a child playing with ramen for the first time!
author: Gregory C.

description: I went to check out what the hype was about. What a disappointment. Flavorless and unsanitary conditions made it difficult to appreciate any creativity or locavore ingredients. I expected the dark, scruffy interior given it's pop-up history. The lack of cleanliness ruined appetite. The chipped plate did not seem washed completely with a black speck on it. When I walked thru kitchen to bathroom it looked messt and dirty, and it was not busy at all. Waitress sniffled and sneezed while taking order, wiping her nose. I often look beyond some sanitary violations for some kick ass authentic ethnic food. But this is eurocentric chinese with food stripped down to singular flavors, lacking intensity and meat-centric. No hot, salty, sour, sweet, or other flavor contrasts. Just mono-flavor or meat. Pepper greens w/ tofu skin& pumpkin sounded interested and the ingredients seemed very high quality, but it was served in flavorless broth tasted like nothing but peppers in hot water. I recall a chicken dish I had that tasted and looked like high quality chicken but was flavorless, no spices, nor any hint of the birds juices in the meat. Barely any chicken meat either. Salad of herb & lettuces was not dressed at all..just plain. It would have been a nice contrast on its own had other dishes been bolder. Creatively served summer roll style w/ rice paper. Recommend putting a sauce or dressing on side to dip in.  Did not have some or the star dishes that reviewers rave about, but if you can screw up the simple selections I'll pass.
author: Rafi C.

description: I came with 2 friends and all of us like the food here but the waiting line is long and sometimes you have to wait for like 15 - 30 min. The price is reasonable for the quality. If you are a fan of Chinese food, you should try it.
author: Lisa J.

description: Had some of the best Chinese food I've ever had here. Can't attest to the ambiance or service, as I took the food to go -- but plan to return again very soon!
author: Tadeek P.

description: fun fusion of flavors. spice is right! twice cooked pork was PERFECT. The only other place that I've had fried chicken as good as that was in Taipei. They do Sichuan with style here.
author: Beth G.

description: We liked the food overall. But the menu was lacking chicken options. The line is long but that's expected for a very popular restaurant.
author: R And J.

description: Delicious. Limited vegetarian options when I was there, but the one dish I got was so. f'ing. good. And the meat-eaters with me were chowing down on their big spread of deliciousness as well...Normally I don't do hipster-places, & as a rule, a Chinese restaurant with no Chinese people eating in it is a bad sign. In this case, I make an exception.
author: C P.

description: Sorry to say--but service is terrible. It took TWO HOURS for our order to arrive.  Calling to follow-up was futile. The food is not worth this wait.   I don't think I'll ever order from this place again.
author: Pete T.

description: I thought this place was great. Plenty of vegetarian options on the menu. The long beans especially were a table favorite. I love the paper dragon on the ceiling! Come sort of early as I've noticed a line develops.
author: Danielle L.

description: I ordered delivery from here the other day after reading so many reviews and being unable to resist the awesome ninjas on their menu page and the hipster foodie that is within me.  I tried the saltcod fried rice - I found it tasty but not amazing as other reviewers seemed to find it.  The chinese sausage inside was a bit dry and while it was good, for me it didn't hold that "crave" factor that takes something from "it was decent" to "I'll definitely be coming back for this one."  I got the szechuan pickles - honestly, not my thing, I was disappointed!  It was super oily, WAY too many peppers in there which were just taking up space and not enough actual pickles!  I liked the peanuts in it but overall, I would not get it again.  I ordered the famous ma po tofu.  Again, SUPER DUPER oily.  It was tasty but only order this if you're prepared to deal with mouth numbing heat (mostly I'm not - I like heat that gives a kick but doesn't numb you - perhaps I just can't handle Szechuan heat!) it takes away from enjoying the flavors.  I must say, the delivery man was topnotch - for him, I rate him 5 stars, I think his name was Lien?  Liang?  I think I may try this place again but I'll try some of the other things on their menu.
author: Suzanne V.

description: The first time I had Mission Chinese Food was about a year ago and since then I've had Mission Chinese two more times.  The first time, we had the Ma Po Tofu and a bunch of other dishes that I can't remember now.  I walked in with an open mind, understanding that this wasn't going to be traditional Chinese food.  The food is definitely a flavor bomb--in some ways good, but in many ways kind of terrible.  After our first visit, I remember thinking, "Yeah, I wouldn't mind eating here again".  But when we went our second time, the fried rice tasted old like it was made from frozen old rice and had been sitting out for a while.  The other dishes were also not good  and we were not impressed with our second visit at all.  I convinced myself that maybe they were just inconsistent or maybe we ordered the wrong things and that I should give it one more try.  Well, our last meal at Mission Chinese was today and it disappointed again.  We had the chongxiang wings which wasn't very spicy, but it left my entire tongue numb and I couldn't wait to go home to wash off the taste.  We also had the broccoli beef and the egg-egg noodle.  The broccoli beef was okay--the beef was very tender, but the flavor was off-putting and I couldn't finish much of it.  The egg-egg noodle was the best dish we had, but that's not saying much either.  I remember reading an article on the owner of the restaurant and he had said he wanted to make Chinese food because it's what he craves after a night of drinking.  Well, everything tastes good after a night of drinking except I'm pretty sure Mission Chinese would make my hang over feel worse.  So, I really don't understand why people love it here but my honest opinion is: it sucks for an "Asian-inspired" place and I wouldn't waste my money here again.
author: Trinh N.

description: I joined yelp just to scream to the world how good this place is!!  First, Mission and Chinese?  Who knew!  The fire wings were delish and the brandade fried rice was great.  But the real winner was the Veal Rib and a lamb soup that made me want more.  Next time I order the whole menu.  Also, the $10 corkage is extremely fare.
author: Toby W.

description:
we went here for lunch on the thursday after christmas...arriving at about one....a short wait....then....we were seated way in the back..very loud music , turned down at my request....with a happy smile...
we ordered tiger salad, green beans, pork belly, tofu dish and short rib dish....i thought the food was the best non traditional chinese food i have eaten in california...yes, a little salty...yes , very spicey....good portions...and really great for a thursday lunch....trendy people everywhere...i usually shy away from this...and strollers..and baby carriers...everywhere....bad attitude hipster parents..nerely ruined the meal...but....delish food....great service....want to do the take out.....
author: Patricia M.

description: Even before Mission Chinese Food was named one of the bay area's top 100 restaurants, I've been ding to go here. There has been so much hype and build up about this place and I was hoping that this place can deliver... figuratively speaking. I recently went here with seven of my closest friends to celebrate my birthday on a saturday night. I was concerned about the wait time due to the fact that there was eight of us and that it's a pretty small restaurant. They do not accept reservations, so first come first serve. We waited a little while, but no more than 15-20 minutes.  Or server was attentive and punctual. We all ordered an assortment of dishes so we could all share. I had to get my hands on the porridge and the salt cod fried rice! The porridge had light and delicate flavors and the addition of salted peanuts, served on the side enhanced my senses. The salt cod fried rice was very authentic. There was just the right among of salt in it.  You must try the lion's head meatball served with ramen noodles.  The meatballs are fork tender, ginger and green onions compliment the dish and tie the meatballs  together nicely. The main event of the evening came when the pork belly and kung pao corned beef arrived. The pork belly was sweet and salty, perfectly crispy on the outside, and molten hot like lava on the inside.  Flavors of star anise and cumin shine with every bite.   The corned beef which we were told, had been smoked for 12 hours. The attention to detail results in a dish both spicy and explosively flavorful. I was not disappointed, the hype is for real, chef Danny Bowien is for real. I can't wait to come back for another visit.
author: Jeff F.

description: food is something special here. not everything suited my taste, but the quality of ingredients and cooking was high.
author: Daib S.

description: This review is for delivery so that means the food is compromised from the start.  That said.... I was expecting more.  It seemed unnecessarily spicy and a bit over greased.  The onion to meat ration in the lamb dish weighed heavily on the onion side.  The green beans were almost inedible due to the intense spice of the chili peppers.  I mention this as I specifically picked dishes that were not marked as spicy.  I will try again but I agree with other posters that Mission Chinese might be a bit too spicy for the unprepared.
author: Mary H.

description: Saw this joint featured on the Cooking Channel last year.  Had to try it.  Tried the Kung Pao Pastrami which was great, 3 times cooked bacon, and the Ma Po Tofu.  Great spices and great flavours.  You can BYOB for a $10 corkage too.
author: Jon R.

description: I can kind of see why people like this place.  But overall it was too much for me.  Every dish had something that was too much.  Too much hoison sauce, too much seasoning, too much cilantro.  Once I removed some of the offender the food was good, even though it was spicy.
author: Amanda H.

description: The place was grossly dirty...hostess wiped our table with a dirty looking rag leaving a big hair on glass table top.  There was an empty planter box near the front door with what appeared to be nothing more than trash in in.  I like dives and edgy places but this is just a dump.  We didn't stay to eat so can't comment on the food.
author: Joe S.

description: This place was incredible.  Super busy.   The produce is local and the meat organic, which I appreciated.  I don't really like Chinese food, but this place is not normal, fat laden, lard fused Chinese (American style) cuisine.  I went with 8 people and we shared as many dishes.  Everything was fantastic.
author: Josh P.

description: I love spicy and I can eat it all meals. This was one of the best mapo tofu I have had... I had to order to-go because the line was so long. Will be back next time to sit inside and eat other dishes...huh...
author: Michelle Y.

description: I usually reserve 5 stars for truly stellar places, but the high quality of food, delivery, and reasonable prices at MSC forced me to give it 5 as well.  I went last night with a large group of friends and we ordered 2 of everything on the menu (plus beers and tea and tip, it was $25 per person with plenty of leftovers and everyone really full).  Some of the dishes were great - the tofu, pork belly, lamb soup, eggplant, and beef cheeks.  Some of them were good - thrice cooked bacon, salt cod fried rice.  Some were just ok - the salad, pickles (just not my thing), spicy chicken wings (depends on how you feel about spices that make your mouth go numb).  All in all though, the great things were REALLY great - the noodles all had an amazing texture, everything was well-seasoned, the service was super fast and friendly, and they had no problem accommodating 9 people.  I am excited to order delivery from them next time I need a chinese fix, because it was so vastly superior to any chinese place I've ordered from in the city.  Yum!
author: Emily d.

description: great on so many levels. taste explosions. creative fresh and spicy. shitty wait and tables but so what.
author: Fzarond K.

description: HYPE!!!  It's true!  After everything I read about Mission Chinese, I was expecting something on the level of Pok Pok in Portland, or Sol Food in San Rafael.  Great authentic cuisine.  What we got was not just mediocre and very, very GREASY food, but also incredibly RUDE service. They literally could give a sh*! about their clients.  We ordered the beef cheeks which were basically covered in so much greasy breading you couldn't taste the beef cheeks.  We also got the kung poa pastrami, which was good for one bite but then way too overpowering.  The salt cod fired rice was actually pretty good, and so were the Mongolian long beans.  But, with the level of FILTH this place has (just venture to the bathroom and you'll see what I mean) it's shocking that it has been written up in so many publications.  Sometimes people are like sheep, and this restaurant is a prime example.  I feel for the hype once, but never again.  Adios Mission Chinese, may you rest in peace.
author: Ashley K.

description: This place was a bit of a surprise. After looking at the menu and peering into the restaurant, I have to say I was slightly put off. After a 15 minute wait at around 1:00 PM on a Saturday, our party of two was sat next to a large group. As in, directly next to them... at the same table. I think that's a little strange, but it can be overlooked for good food. It was also unfortunately humid in the dining area -- but not so humid we felt the need to leave. The menu is lacking some detail for me so I was wary about what to order but finally decided on the Kung Pao Pastrami. My boyfriend ordered the Smashed Cucumbers and Lamb Face Noodle Soup. Everything was just the right amount of greasy that you expect from Chinese-American food and was really tasty -- very inventive flavors! I was impressed. The reason this establishment is getting four instead of five stars is twofold: whomever made the food used just a hint too much chili oil *almost* overpowering the food and the service was subpar (again, another thing I can mostly overlook for good food). Otherwise, I'm looking forward to going back and trying something else the next time we're in SF.
author: Ash T.

description: really over rated despite getting accolades from others.  it really is chinese food for people not familiar with really good chinese food.  way too salty and too spicy, i think people like the unusual setting in the mission but this resto does not make my mouth water, does not equal all the rave reviews.
author: dennis m.

description: Quirky story, quirky setup, quirky staff, great food. The mapo tofu is otherworldly. It is one of the most amazing sensory overloads ever! The salt cod fried rice is not your typical fried rice, but really, what is typical about this place? So happy we found out about this place. Minus one star for lack of cleanliness
author: Brian O.

description: Fabulous food! Went for the second time last night and had Ma Po Tofu (hot!), Tiki Pork Belly (I like paper umbrellas! Those who don't lack an irony gene) Cumin Lamb, Sliced Peanut Noodles, and the Salt Cod Fried Rice. All were terrific. Some things are *spicy* but not the hottest food I've ever eaten, but timid eaters beware. Here's the secret to enjoying Mission Chinese...either live in the Mission or have a friend who does and order delivery. It's free within most of the Mission a couple of bucks further out. You avoid the long wait outside, the dicey interior and any perceived staff snubs (I've found them to be friendly both on the phone and when ordering for takeout at the restaurant). Another plus, you can have a nice bottle of wine with your meal. As for those who say meh or "average Chinese" I'd love to know where you normally eat. This is very unusual (and unusually good) "Chinese" food -- unlike any other that I've had in SF, LA or NY.
author: Tom M.

description: Good stuff, not too pricey. Mapo tofu is destructive. Everything is delicious, sometimes to the extreme heights of comfort food. We were a little disappointed by the chicken wings. They arrive under a huge pile of whole (fried?) hot chiles. But the wings themselves have no chile flavor. They do have lots of sichuan peppercorn flavor, and are not bad, but there's a feeling of false advertising. Are the wings fried with the chiles? There's apparently no migration of chile heat to the wings. Also, luekwarm tap water. Maybe the ice maker was broken.
author: Wangston P.

description: This is one of those hipster places that seems to be popular just because everyone's on the bandwagon. As a lifelong eater of Chinese food who lived in China for a while, I find its dishes abominable - simply awful. I'll admit that I only had the vegetarian items, which are usually less developed than the carniverous ones, but still! Every dish was a mismatch of ingredients which had apparently been selected for the most jarring meeting of flavors and textures, which could be great if done well, but... The decor is basically an inside joke for a bunch of white hipsters making fun of the schlockier aspects of cheap Chinese joints. The servers were elderly Chinese women who looked clinically depressed from having to witness the atrocity being committed against Chinese cuisine. A co-worker who has had the meat dishes says that they specialize in the fatty and gristly cuts of meat, which is apparently a big hipster theme right now. How this pace became popular is a huge question in my mind.
author: Alexander A.

description:
love love love this place.  ate it about once a week for about 2 months when i first heard about the joint. i love it all, but here are my favorites (take note - i eat mostly veg dishes) : salt cod fried rice, the ma po tofu (not veg but AMAZZZZZZING), tiger salad, seaweed salad, and last the BEST DISH OF ALL taiwanese eggplant!!!!   i hated eggplant until i tried this and i have turned 3 former eggplant haters into lovers here!

the staff is so sweet, always comes out to check in on how we are liking the food.  

YOU MUST GET THE EGGPLANT AND THE MA PO TOFU!!!
author: Tania G.

description: pickles, westlake porridge, pork dumplings and chicken rice! 4 simple, but surprisingly unique and *bursting with flavor* dishes. the variety of all the dishes made it fun to eat here for the first time. pricing comparable to portion size. good service, too! will go back soon to try more of the menu, for sure.
author: kathryn s.

description: NO STARS! The other day, I ordered the lion's head meatball soup for lunch.  The soup was delivered, along with some other AWFUL dishes (ie mushroom dumplings, hainam chicken), promptly and packaged well (individual containers for the noodles and soup).  When I opened the box of noodles there was MOLD throughout!  I couldn't believe it.  I guess they packaged the noodles ahead of time?!  But for mold to grow?!  How long ago were those noodles packed?!  I couldn't even eat the soup after.  What a waste...
author: MJ L.

description: if you don't like salty food.You don't like spicy.Dont like wait in the line.Dont come to mission Chinese food.
author: Jimmy S.

description: Our go to chinese delivery place in SF.  Interesting takes on Chinese food.  Love the salt cod fried rice.
author: Steven C.

description: i know it's all popular, but christ, the food is amazing. i love the cold custards, and that dish with the bacon and thick noodles, and really, everything i've had.  fast service, cheap as hell. the line is bad.  it is worth it if you can get around this somehow. i have, but i will not tell you how. sorry.  definitely one of the best places i've been too. pretty impressed by the crazy business model.
author: allison d.

description: mmmm.  though the wait is long, you can chain smoke outside and all that tar only works up your appetite for more mission chinese food.
author: Luna K.

description: i don't know who was in the kitchen making the ma po tofu last week, but it was super dissapointing (we order it about twice a month on avg). usually it's very flavorful and made w ground pork LOVE it. this time around, no flavor, just saltiness and the meat was in chunks (fatty chunks)..so whoever did make that batch - pls stop cooking. the rest of the items we ordered also were underseasoned or were a little 'off' seasoning-wise - super disappointing all around.
author: Me H.

description: In a word: Bold. I had hoped that we'd be able to find something mild that my 10-year old son could eat. We found it in the marvelously tender Brisket with the Smoked Cola BBQ sauce. I was intrigued by the many parties who ordered the Veal Rib ($16) while we waited for 40 mins in the rain to get into this popular joint. It was moist on the inside, crusty on the outside, and smothered in a spicy sauce that my adventurous foodie uncle said was the "hottest thing I've ever tasted."  (I thought it was very flavorful) We also enjoyed the very cumin-ly spiced Sizzling Lamb. The onions and Thai peppers combined nicely with the edgy spice, and were oishii! We also tried the Westlake rice porridge. While it had plenty of silky dungeness crab meat in it, along with ample minced cilantro, it was a bit saltier than I would've liked. This is the perfect food for a cold, rainy night in SF. The bottom line: I should have read more of the Yelp reviews to gauge the SPICY index. I liked the food, though my dining companions were less enthused. Very good service--very un-Chinese restaurant like!
author: Neal L.

description: this place is ridiculous.  i dare martha stewart to hype it so much that everyone hates it.  nope, can't be done.  she tried.
author: Tyler W.

description: for lunch we got seats right away... glad I didn't wear anything nice... for sure my clothes would smell of chinese food... the  dishes  was just okay...  service staff was good...
author: William W.

description: pretty damn good food.  i couldn't pinpoint the exact flavor from the chix wings that came on a bed of red peppers, but couldn't stop eating them.
author: David H.

description: Mission Chinese Food is more Mission than Chinese, in a good way. The food I would say is Chinese inspired, not authetic. And that's great, considering we have no dearth of Chinese restaurant in this town. The chef at MCF adds unusually touches to the dishes, and the result is totally delicious. I want to eat those soy cured eggs all day...I mean how does anyone braise the eggs with lots of flavor while still have the yolks ne runny? Mission impossible! But orgasmically delicious. And the pork belly is so good, and I happen to be a self proclaimed connoisseur of pork belly so I should know. The best dish is ma po tofu. Nothing like Mom used to make, but it's addictive like crack (which Mom also did not used to make). Skip the more subtle flavored dishes like congee (which is as good as I've had but nonetheless still subtle) and fried rice and go straight to spicy dishes like ma po tofu (my mouth is watering just thinking about it). That's where the chef shines. MCF is the future of Chinese Food.
author: Jason J.

description: good food but what's more amazing is the amount of effort the chefs put into it. it does remind me somewhat of momofuku although it's not quite on the par, yet (if it's up to me i'd say tune things down just a slight notch). when we were there we saw the way they were working on the dough, and it's clear they are putting heart and soul into it. keep it up.
author: shane y.
